items.short_synopsis: A film director and a screenwriter (played by Lars von Trier and his actual screenwriter, Niels Vørsel) research and develop a screenplay in which a deadly virus spreads through the entire world. However, like their protagonist, the duo do not notice that a real epidemic is developing around them.
items.default_editorial: Lars von Trier takes a starring role in his second feature, a metafictional—and metaphysical—exploration of creative culpability. If the title suggests a resonance with our contemporary condition, Epidemic soon reveals itself as a playfully ironic portrait of the artist-philosopher as a young man.

items.title: Eraserhead
items.short_synopsis: In an industrial town, Henry lives in an abandoned building amidst constant noise and smoke. He finds solace in the Lady in the Radiator’s music. His girlfriend, Mary X, has fits and gives birth to a terrifying mutant child, injecting sexual imagery into the chaotic mix.
items.default_editorial: One of the great independent features, David Lynch’s 1977 debut is a miracle of craft and sound design. Featuring an enigmatic lead performance from Jack Nance and spilled-ink lensing from Frederick Elms, Eraserhead is a visionary nightmare that plunders the darkest recesses of the American psyche.

items.title: Escape
items.short_synopsis: In her room, Mona, a young teenager, gets ready for her piano lesson. Sitting at home, she eagerly awaits the arrival of the one she loves…
items.default_editorial: Katell Quillévéré has established herself as the director of family dramas that delve with piercing insight into the emotional turmoil and interrelationships of her characters. Her third short film is an exquisite chamber piece exploring the dynamics between a daring teenager and her piano teacher.

items.title: Europa
items.short_synopsis: A young, idealist American gets a job as a train conductor for the Zentropa railway network in postwar, US-occupied Frankfurt. As various people try to take advantage of him, he soon finds his position politically sensitive, and gets caught up in a whirlpool of conspiracies and Nazi sympathisers.
items.default_editorial: This early triumph by Lars von Trier, which won no less than three prizes at Cannes, is one of his most bizarre yet accessible works: a feverish retooling of film noir, an unhinged thriller, and a visually mind-blowing odyssey into a nightmare of our past.

items.title: Exhibition
items.short_synopsis: When couple D and H, both artists, decide to sell their modernist dream home they have loved and lived in for two decades, they begin a process of saying goodbye to their shared history under the same roof. The upheaval causes anxieties, memories, fears and dreams to surface.
items.default_editorial: A penetrating, impossibly elegant exploration not only of a marriage among artists but also of how your home shapes your life. James Melvin’s glass-shrouded London house is as much a character as the couple inside it—no less than The Slits’ guitarist Viv Albertine and conceptual artist Liam Gillick!

items.title: Fallen Leaves
items.short_synopsis: In modern-day Helsinki, Ansa and Holappa, two lonely souls in search of their first love, meet by chance in a local karaoke bar. However, the pair’s path to happiness is beset by numerous obstacles—from lost phone numbers to mistaken addresses, alcoholism, and a charming stray dog.
items.default_editorial: Moviegoing dreamers, there is hope for us still in this timeless, tender romance from living legend Aki Kaurismäki. Imbued with the filmmaker’s idiosyncratic playfulness and deadpan humor, this bittersweet comedy charmed even the most dour of critics and, delightfully, won the Jury Prize at Cannes.

items.title: Fantastic Planet
items.short_synopsis: On the distant planet Ygam, enslaved humans called Oms are the playthings of giant blue native inhabitants, the Draags. Terr, kept as a pet since infancy, escapes from his gigantic child captor and is swept up by a band of radical fellow Oms, who are resisting the Draags’ oppression and violence.
items.default_editorial: René Laloux’s beloved fantasia is a shimmering treasure in the canon of science-fiction cinema. Cosmic landscapes populated by strange, otherworldly creatures—thanks to the distinct cut-out animations of Roland Topor—and set to an ice-cool psychedelic jazz score: The results are out of this world.

items.title: Father
items.short_synopsis: In a “haunted” mansion in the north of Spain, two caretakers do their best to keep the slowly crumbling building safe from the threats of time and vandalism.
items.default_editorial: A historic estate in the Basque Country, which dates back to the Middle Ages, is thoroughly explored by José María de Orbe’s discreet camera. Gorgeously shot by Jimmy Gimferrer, the film is a meditative testament to the timeless power and strange beauty of the process of age and decay.

items.title: Festen
items.short_synopsis: At a countryside manor, a lavish 60th birthday celebration is being held for revered family patriarch, Helge. Everyone has been invited—most importantly, his wife and three grown-up children, Christian, Michael and Helene. That night, Christian makes a speech nobody will ever forget.
items.default_editorial: Arguably portraying one of cinema’s most messed-up families ever, Festen is considered the first film made under the rules of the radical Dogme 95 movement. Thomas Vinterberg’s madcap time-bomb of latent secrets and repressed grudges makes any family dinner seem like a piece of cake.

items.title: Fists in the Pocket
items.short_synopsis: In a claustrophobic villa in Italy’s Apennine Mountains, Alessandro still lives with his blind mother and three adult siblings. Tormented by twisted desires, Alessandro decides to take drastic measures to cure his dysfunctional family of their various afflictions—by plotting to murder them all.
items.default_editorial: The twisted psychodrama of a degenerate provincial family make for riveting viewing in this truly subversive debut from the great Italian filmmaker. Taking aim at social decadence, religious hypocrisy and the myth of the nuclear family, Bellocchio’s film landed a punch to the gut of Italian cinema.

items.title: Florentina Hubaldo, CTE
items.short_synopsis: A chronicle of the struggles of a young woman held captive by her father and forced into prostitution in the Bicol region of the Philippines. Her story eventually intersects with that of a farmer and his dying wife, as well as that of two treasure seekers from the city.
items.default_editorial: The Filipino master of slow cinema intertwines a story of impoverished treasure hunters with the tale of a drifting woman coming to terms with a damaged mind and body. Extraordinary handheld camerawork captures the minutest of details, bringing the struggles of life into stark reality.

items.title: Flowers of Taipei: Taiwan New Cinema
items.original_title: Flowers of Taipei: Taiwan New Cinema
items.short_synopsis: With Taiwan remaining in the grip of martial law in 1982, a group of filmmakers from that country set out to establish a cultural identity through cinema and to share it with the world. This engaging documentary looks at the movement’s legacy.
items.default_editorial: Featuring interviews with Hirokazu Kore-eda, Hou Hsiao-hsien, Wang Bing, Kiyoshi Kurosawa, and Jia Zhangke, this documentary portrait provides a thorough perspective on the landmark New Taiwanese Cinema. An essential document of one of 20th century cinema’s most significant chapters.

items.title: Flux Gourmet
items.short_synopsis: Jan runs the Sonic Catering Institute, a creative retreat for artists working between avant-garde music and outré cuisine. Currently in residence are a performance art collective locked in a power struggle. When Jan attempts to nurture the group’s craft, personal and creative tensions begin to rise.
items.default_editorial: Served this time in a culinary sound studio, Peter Strickland’s latest offering is another baroque feast for the senses: a bold fusion of gastronomy, grotesquerie, and sauciness, reminiscent of the great Peter Greenaway and starring the enigmatic Greek Weird Wave actor Ariane Labed. Bon appétit!

items.title: Following
items.short_synopsis: Driven by boredom, a writer randomly shadows strangers on London’s bustling streets. What starts as fictional research becomes an unsettling journey when he’s confronted by a burglar named Cobb. Drawn into Cobb’s world of crime, the writer treads a perilous path, entangled in obsession and danger.
items.default_editorial: Before Christopher Nolan became a towering talent in the game of big-budget filmmaking with the likes of Inception and Oppenheimer, he made this ingenious small-scale thriller. As complexly structured and cerebrally tangled as his best work, this intimate neo-noir is as beguiling as the classics.

items.title: Following Diana
items.short_synopsis: Diana’s husband returns home one night with big news: he has taken on a second wife and expects Diana to live in harmony with this new situation. So, Diana does what is least expected—she decides to take her life into her own hands.
items.default_editorial: Premiering at the Toronto film festival, Kamila Andini’s heartbreaking short examines the power structures that exist between men and women within marriage, family, and society at large. Melding melodrama with intimate dialogue, Sendiri Diana Sendiri is an astutely rendered Indonesian miniature.

items.title: For You I Will Fight
items.short_synopsis: We follow a girl, at the end of the adolescence, Ana, who does not know any more who she is and what she wants, but who chooses to fight, to arm herself, and who finds in the group, in the discipline, and sometimes even in the alienation, a stand to be.
items.default_editorial: The first installment of Rachel Lang’s Ana Trilogy is an exploration of the transition from adolescence to adulthood and the uncertainty that comes with it. This Silver Leopard winner marks the beginning of the collaboration between Lang and Salomé Richard, which will culminate in Baden Baden.

items.title: Forest of Bliss
items.short_synopsis: A priest performs sacred rites at a shrine near the Ganges. The king of a cremation grounds sells sacred fire to mourners. A healer attends pained people. Unfolding from one sunrise to the next: an account of the grief and happiness that punctuate daily life in the holy city of Benares, India.
items.default_editorial: The great American ethnographic filmmaker Robert Gardner passed away in 2014, leaving behind a legacy of innovative work that connects a line between filmmakers such as Jean Rouch and Werner Herzog. This gorgeous, contemplative exploration of an Indian city ranks among his many groundbreaking films.

items.title: Forty Shades of Blue
items.short_synopsis: Laura, a young woman from Russia, lives in Memphis with her boyfriend, aging music legend Alan James. When Alan’s estranged grown-up son, Michael, shows up in Memphis for the first time in years, his initial hostility to Laura soon turns into something much more, and they embark on an affair.
items.default_editorial: Surfaces appear diamond-hard in this modern melodrama, but expensive looks can be deceiving. Gliding through white middle-class America with serene sadness, actor Dina Korzun is astonishing as a detached interloper in Ira Sachs’s masterful film of betrayal, heartache, and hushed ecstasy.

items.title: Four Nights of a Dreamer
items.short_synopsis: In Paris, Jacques saves Marthe from a fateful leap off the Pont-Neuf. As they open their hearts, they agree to meet each other again. Over the course of four nights, Jacques finds himself falling deeply. But what does Marthe think about Jacques?
items.default_editorial: All the poetic iridescence of the Seine at night shimmers in eye-catching blue in this new 4K restoration of Robert Bresson’s post-’68 romance. Adapting Dostoyevsky for a dynamic moment of modern art, folk music, and free love, this film distills the bittersweet taste of youthful, capricious desire.

items.title: Four Roads
items.short_synopsis: The COVID-19 pandemic forced many to stay at home, preventing people from meeting each other in real life. In the absence of any physical connection, an old 16mm camera, a zoom lens, and a few meters of expired film will forge alternative modes of contact among neighbors.
items.default_editorial: Alice Rohrwacher’s lockdown film escapes the claustrophobia of video calls to seek connection through a zoom lens. The faces of her neighbors are captured on tactile 16mm film and accompanied by the director’s gentle narration in this humanist gem that sparkles with kindness under the Italian sun.

items.title: Four Unloved Women, Adrift on a Purposeless Sea, Experience the Ecstasy of Dissection
items.original_title: Four Unloved Women, Adrift on a Purposeless Sea, Experience the Ecstasy of Dissection
items.short_synopsis: Long live the new flesh. Surgery is the new sex. These Cronenbergian epigrams come together in a tableau that reimagines the ecstasy and eroticism of Renaissance sculpture for the future. Or is it already the present?
items.default_editorial: No stranger to the sensual and medical contours of the body, horror icon David Cronenberg turns to 18th-century wax cadavers as his new muses for this poetic short. Sonically caressed by a chorus of pleasurable sighs, these anatomical Venuses are both alluring and uncanny in their voluptuousness.

items.title: Fragment 53
items.short_synopsis: Comprising interviews with seven different men of varying rank about atrocities they committed (or ordered) during the Liberian Civil War, this frank and frequently disturbing documentary examines the nature of modern violence and an essentialist concept of warfare.
items.default_editorial: Reminiscent of Joshua Oppenheimer’s The Look of Silence, this celebrated first-person documentary film crucially visualizes essential questions about the human capacity for war. A dark, enthralling investigation into the living history of Liberia’s bloody internal conflict.

items.title: Fragments for Venus
items.short_synopsis: A Black woman wanders alone through the galleries of a museum, carefully examining each painting, searching for something. Across Brooklyn, another Black woman wanders the streets, her gaze full of wonder at the Black women she encounters.
items.default_editorial: Alice Diop colors in the blind spots of art history with this thoughtful short starring Kayije Kagame (Saint Omer). Countering clichés and absences in Black portraiture with the joys of real life, Fragments for Venus leaves behind Old Masters to widen the frame on where we find aesthetic pleasure.

items.title: From the Reports of Security Guards & Patrol Services No.1
items.original_title: Nr. 1 - Aus Berichten der Wach- und Patrouillendienste
items.short_synopsis: With her two small children in hand, a woman heads to a construction yard. She then climbs up a high crane to the very end of the boom, clutching her kids. She threatens to jump if, by that evening, she’s not provided with a flat that she can afford.
items.default_editorial: We enter with typewriters and leave with sirens. Activist and veteran filmmaker Helke Sander has never shied from controversy, and she won the short film Golden Bear at Berlin for this eerily detached account of an incident from the fade out of the Cold War. A rarity from the Deutsche Kinemathek!

items.title: From What is Before
items.original_title: Mula sa Kung Ano ang Noon
items.short_synopsis: The Philippines, 1972. Mysterious things are happening in a remote barrio. Wails are heard from the forest, cows are hacked to death, a man is found bleeding to death at the crossroad and houses are burned.
items.default_editorial: Lav’s Golden Leopard winner in Locarno is an epic remembrance of a period of transition that marked the traumatic time of dictator Ferdinand Marcos’ rule. The film’s structure unfurls with slow power, growing increasingly complex, political, and emotional over its five-and-a-half hour story.

items.title: Fruits of Passion
items.short_synopsis: In 1920s Shanghai, unbridled lust and excessive excess dominate the sexual life of the rich. The noble Sir Stephen trains his submissive, young lover O in a brothel. Caught in a whirlpool of pleasure, O longs for ever harder and more exciting punishment.
items.default_editorial: Japanese avant-garde filmmaker Shūji Terayama is known for his visually striking and highly provocative works, from which Fruits of Passion is one of the most controversial. Presented at the Directors’ Fortnight in 1981, this is a sexually abrasive and disturbingly powerful tale.

items.title: Further Beyond
items.short_synopsis: Taking the compelling 18th Century figure Ambrose O’Higgins as their point of departure, two filmmakers attempt to retrace his remarkable journey from Ireland to Chile and speculate on the idea of place. But the duo continually get sidetracked by a competing story of immigration and displacement.
items.default_editorial: A riveting, completely original anti-biopic from one of our favorite filmmaker duos, whose revisionist crime film, Helen is an ingenious gem. Molloy & Lawlor’s first foray into documentary explores identity and space while playfully dissecting the very nature of cinematic language. And it’s funny!

items.title: Futura
items.short_synopsis: Pietro Marcello, Francesco Munzi, and Alice Rohrwacher set out to interview Italy’s youth about their hopes, dreams, and fears. With today’s political divisions, socioeconomic unease, overreliance on technology, and global weather crisis, these young adults ask themselves: is there a future at all?
items.default_editorial: Open-hearted and disarmingly candid, this deep dive into the hopes and fears that Italian youths harbor for the future doubles as a road trip through the country’s scenic wonders. A collective effort from three of Italy’s most exciting filmmakers, the luminous 16mm footage exudes a modern nostalgia.

items.title: Ga-ga: Glory to the Heroes
items.short_synopsis: Scope, a prisoner on a behemoth space station, is chosen to ‘volunteer’ to explore far-away planets. Landing on planet Australia-458, Scope finds that his freedom comes with a high price—his violent demise will be broadcast live for the viewing pleasure of Australia-458’s inhabitants.
items.default_editorial: Taking inspiration from Pasolini’s La Ricotta, Piotr Szulkin closes his “Apocalyptic Tetralogy” with an anarchic riff on the Passion of Christ. The funniest of the four films, Ga-Ga: Glory to the Heroes is a rich sci-fi allegory that puts the European colonial project in its satirical crosshairs.

items.title: Gambler
items.short_synopsis: Filmmaker Nicolas Winding Refn struggles to clear a personal debt of DKK 5.5 million after his film Fear X becomes a box-office flop. Grappling with artistic compromise, Refn navigates the complexities of securing funding and balancing family life, all while filming in the Copenhagen underworld.
items.default_editorial: Gambler documents how Danish auteur Nicolas Winding Refn bounced back from a million-dollar debt (!) after his film flop, Fear X. Ambo’s darkly entertaining chronicle of a director plunged into show business hell offers a fascinating glimpse into his process and the sacrifices made to keep going.

items.title: Gasoline Rainbow
items.short_synopsis: With high school in the rearview, five teenagers from inland Oregon embark on one last adventure. Piling into a van with a busted tail light, their mission takes them to a place they’ve never been—the Pacific coast, five hundred miles away. Their plan, in full: “Fuck it.”
items.default_editorial: Reimagining the road movie with the next generation of misfits, celebrated directorial duo the Ross Brothers make a coming-of-age film that runs on free-flowing feeling. Alive with friendship and the promise of the moment, Gasoline Rainbow is a beautiful reminder of what matters and what’s real.

items.title: Get Ready
items.short_synopsis: Found footage from a feature film. From an idyllic scene at the sea to a speedy car driving by night. The radical movement of objects, bodies and senses illustrates the power of cinema.
items.default_editorial: A propulsively jittering journey through the cinematic imaginary using glitchy found footage and jacked-up cyber sounds, Get Ready hits the highway hard and takes us with it. A car crash? An escape? This turbo-charged condensation of cinematic moods and tropes makes much of its tiny run-time.

items.title: Golem
items.short_synopsis: In some dystopian future, scientists attempt to create a new, pliable race of humans out of degenerate individuals. A seemingly ordinary product of the effort, the genetically engineered Pernat is subject to round-the-clock monitoring as he goes about his life—until he rebels against his guardians.
items.default_editorial: Drawing on Jewish legend, this Kafkaesque work of speculative science fiction is the debut feature by one of the great visionaries of the 20th century. From a nightmarish world of gods and monsters, Piotr Szulkin forges a modern Prometheus as a potent allegory for Poland’s Communist experiment.

items.title: Grand Theft Hamlet
items.short_synopsis: With theaters shut during the COVID-19 pandemic, two actors, Sam and Mark, are uncertain about their futures. Finding solace in the virtual chaos of Grand Theft Auto Online, they decide to stage Hamlet in the game’s unpredictable world. This film was produced independently by Project 1961Ltd.
items.default_editorial: Swapping the tumult of a locked-down world for the anarchic digital hinterlands of gaming’s very own Wild West, this uproarious documentary yanks Shakespeare into the 21st century. Winner of the Grand Jury Award at SXSW, Grand Theft Hamlet finds community and creativity in the unlikeliest of places.

items.title: Grand Tour
items.short_synopsis: Burma, 1917. Edward, a civil servant for the British Empire, jilts his lovestruck fiancée Molly the day she arrives to be married. As he flees into an unexpected odyssey across Asia, the free-spirited Molly—amused by his moves—follows in pursuit, embarking on a globe-trotting cat-and-mouse chase.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Best Director prize at Cannes, Miguel Gomes’s transcendent travelogue sets sail for spellbinding horizons, where romance and adventure thrillingly entwine. Guided by the capricious will of the heart, this epic tale of love on the run is a movable feast for the mind and the senses.

items.title: Granny's Dancing on the Table
items.short_synopsis: Eini, 13 years old, grows up isolated from society with her violent father, a man afraid of the world. The brutality that Eini is exposed to pushes her to almost lose her sense of self but through her invincible fantasy, she creates a world within, from which she can draw strength to survive.
items.default_editorial: A brutal case of domestic abuse lies at the core of this story of female empowerment, seen through the eyes of a teenager and through chilling, atmospheric imagery. The young girl’s memories and thoughts are represented through animation sequences, all the more haunting by their abstraction.

items.title: Guilty Bystander
items.short_synopsis: In New York City, ex-cop Max Thursday, now the house detective at a scuzzy hotel in an even scuzzier part of town, exists in an alcoholic haze until his ex-wife appears with news of his son’s disappearance. So, Thursday stumbles through the city’s sleazy underworld searching for his kidnapped son.
items.default_editorial: Not as well known as he should be, Joseph Lerner directed four noir features between 1947 and 1951. One of these is Guilty Bystander: a booze-soaked and paranoia-inflected independent feature shot entirely on location in the never-grubbier streets of New York City.

items.title: Guts and Glitz
items.short_synopsis: Audiovisual material gathered by filmmaker Fox Maxy over a decade, including documentary footage, television clips, and animation—sometimes layered on top of one another—are presented as one collage. Amid this sensory barrage, themes of sexual violence, community, confidence and joy are explored.
items.default_editorial: Re-edited and re-titled specifically for our Next Prize collection, Fox Maxy’s dynamic feature debut moves between the personal and the virtual with dazzling inventiveness. With its vortex of genre-defying imagery, Guts and Glitz announces an impressive new voice in Indigenous experimental cinema.

items.title: Hail
items.short_synopsis: Fresh out of a Melbourne prison, Dan reunites with the love of his life, Leanne. Together, they are a fierce, passionate, and tender couple—and Dan soon resolves to go straight. But when Leanne’s mysterious old criminal friend appears with a proposal, Dan is lured back to a life of crime.
items.default_editorial: With striking visuals and cinematic prowess, Hail draws the struggles of life after prison through a compelling relationship. Based on testimonies of a former inmate, this docu-drama, portraying violence and tenderness in equal measures, was received with acclaim in festivals worldwide.

items.title: Hamlet Goes Business
items.short_synopsis: When Hamlet discovers his father’s deceased body, he finds himself pulled into a power struggle as his scheming uncle attempts to secure a monopoly on the Scandinavian rubber duck industry. Will Hamlet avenge his father? Will he become the king of rubber ducks? Does any of it really matter?
items.default_editorial: Having already adapted Dostoyevsky for his feature debut, Aki Kaurismäki turned to Shakespeare for a radical, noir-adjacent take on the Danish play. A business-world satire shot in starkly modernist black and white, the anarchically funny Hamlet Goes Business is a hard-boiled, deadpan delight.

items.title: Happy as Lazzaro
items.short_synopsis: Lazzaro, a peasant so good that he is often mistaken for simple-minded, meets Tancredi, a nobleman cursed by his imagination. They find joy in a pastoral world of deception and lies. The truth will separate them, but Lazzaro’s loyalty will lead him to travel in time, landing in a bleak city.
items.default_editorial: Following an innocent fool from lustrous landscapes of the past to a modern-day city, this magical-realist tale explores how the winds of modernization displace Italian traditions. Feeling at once timeless and altogether new, this treasure won Alice Rohrwacher an award for Best Screenplay at Cannes.

items.title: Here
items.short_synopsis: After the sudden death of his wife, He Zhiyuan loses the will to speak and is sent to Island Hospital. While He adjusts to life within, he is selected for an experimental treatment, forcing him to confront the devastating truth behind his past, present, and future.
items.default_editorial: Inspired by conceptual art and anti-psychiatry, Ho Tzu Nyen’s debut feature blends a clinical documentary style with an innovative plot of alternative therapies. Selected for Directors’ Fortnight at Cannes in 2009, Here still stuns as an astounding dose of historical reenactment and reckoning.

items.title: Hide and Seek
items.short_synopsis: In urban Pakistan, queer individuals manage personal conflicts and the pressures of society. Drag performer Kami lives openly with his boyfriend. Jenny, a trans student, just underwent surgery. Meanwhile, Neeli has been instrumental in changing Pakistan’s constitution to recognize the third gender.
items.default_editorial: Tackling the stigma and taboos related to sexuality head-on, Hide and Seek presents an honest and emotional portrayal of complex gender struggles in contemporary Pakistan. A moving and compelling study of societal power structures and the courage that enables people to rise beyond them.

items.title: High & Low - John Galliano
items.short_synopsis: Fashion designer John Galliano was widely recognized as one of the most influential names in 1990s and 2000s couture until his career abruptly ended in 2011. Candid footage—plus conversations with Naomi Campbell, Kate Moss, Anna Wintour and more—trace Galliano’s turbulent career through the decades.
items.default_editorial: Reliving triumphs and controversies, fashion designer John Galliano takes center stage in this grippingly nuanced portrait from Oscar®-winner Kevin Macdonald. Star-studded interviews and rare archival footage reveal the toxicity behind exquisite glamor and spectacle, both on and off the runway.

items.title: Hiroshima mon amour
items.short_synopsis: In postwar Hiroshima, a French actress and a Japanese architect engage in a brief, intense affair. Their consuming mutual fascination compels them to exorcise their own scarred memories of love and suffering.
items.default_editorial: With an Academy Award®–nominated screenplay written by no less than Marguerite Duras, Alain Resnais’ French New Wave landmark is a painfully intimate mosaic of memories of love and suffering. Rendered through a startling, jagged flashback structure, this is one of the most beautiful films ever made.

items.title: Hollywood 90028
items.short_synopsis: Mark, a disturbed cameraman, films porn by day and stalks Los Angeles by night, strangling women he lures from peep shows and strip clubs. When he pursues a model from one of his shoots, a frustrated Mark is led to shoot a different kind of Hollywood ending…
items.default_editorial: From exploitation tropes of sex and murder, Christina Hornisher paints a hallucinatory time capsule of 1970s Los Angeles, smattered with vagabond souls and trampled Hollywood dreams. Admired by Sean Baker and Ti West, this spellbinding vision of a wasted Tinseltown is now restored in glorious 4K.

items.title: Holy Spider
items.short_synopsis: In the holy city of Mashhad, journalist Rahimi investigates the murders of sex workers by the “Spider Killer”—a man who believes he is on a divine mission to cleanse the city of sinners. As she tries to bring him to justice, support for his actions grows as many hail him a hero on a religious quest.
items.default_editorial: Zar Amir Ebrahimi won Best Actress in Cannes for her performance as a fearless reporter in Ali Abbasi’s gripping serial-killer procedural. Based on a shocking true story, Holy Spider prowls the Iranian night, refusing to pull any punches in its trenchant critiques of misogyny and hypocrisy.

items.title: Horse Money
items.short_synopsis: Ventura, an elderly Cape Verdean immigrant living in Lisbon, is seemingly the inmate of a cavernous, antiquated psychiatric ward. As he traverses a seemingly endless night, an odyssey into his real, imagined and nightmarish memories begins.
items.default_editorial: From Portugal’s greatest living filmmaker comes this dreamlike hallucination of a lost soul belonging to the country’s repressed, abused, misused and forgotten underclass. With his rivetingly poetic political cinema, Pedro Costa gives the unheard and unseen a voice and a true cinematic presence.

items.title: Hot Thrills and Warm Chills
items.short_synopsis: Rita Alexander stars as the towering gang leader of a trio of hoodlum gals looking to make one last big score, run away with a mess of diamonds and live the dream in paradise. An eccentric gem from Texas wildcard director Dale Berry, underscored by a relentlessly brilliant Perez Prado soundtrack.
items.default_editorial: This much fun should be positively criminal! Mardi Gras is the beating heart of eccentric Texan director Dale Berry’s sleazy girl gang romp. Expect lots of tawdry dialogue, soft-core sex and naked dancing ladies, but don’t expect too much plot. With Latin rhythms from King of Mambo Pérez Prado!

items.title: House of Seven Belles
items.short_synopsis: The late Andy Milligan never completed his Southern melodrama, and all he left behind was a single unfinished workprint. As he said, “it’s all there, except the finale I was unable to shoot.” Thus, it may be left to the viewer to complete his Civil War epic, revealed here for the first time.
items.default_editorial: Cult horror auteur Andy Milligan has a select yet fanatical fandom: among them is Nicolas Winding Refn, who protects his legacy by salvaging obscure prints. This incomplete Civil War epic is one of them. Shot on Staten Island, yet packed full of Southern gothic touches, it’s more than just a curio.

items.title: House on Bare Mountain
items.short_synopsis: Exploitation film maven Bob Cresse goes full drag as the matriarch of “Granny Good’s School for Good Girls” in this delightfully silly “nudie cutie,” which somehow mashes the “old dark house” monster movie, lowbrow comedy, the rock & roll dance party and the peep show, in eye-popping candy colors.
items.default_editorial: A forgotten curio in the history of trash cinema, House on Bare Mountains is an early 60s nudie-cutie where Hollywood models meet monsters and the rest is mayhem. Naïve dramatic vignettes entail wildly inappropriate excuses for nudity—as the poster says, it was shot in “Nuderama” after all!

items.title: How to Have Sex
items.short_synopsis: Three British teenage girls go on a rites-of-passage holiday, drinking, clubbing and hooking up in what should be the best summer of their lives. As they dance their way across the sun-drenched streets of Malia, they find themselves navigating the complexities of sex, consent and self-discovery.
items.default_editorial: Vibrant with the ecstasies of being young and fleetingly free, this Cannes prizewinner from British filmmaker Molly Manning Walker is an honest take on female friendship and first sexual experiences. Buzzing with the excitement of new horizons, Mia McKenna-Bruce shines in a star-making performance.

items.title: Humanist Vampire Seeking Consenting Suicidal Person
items.short_synopsis: Sasha is a young vampire who is too sensitive to kill. When her exasperated parents cut off her blood supply, Sasha meets Paul, a lonely teenager who is willing to give his life to save hers. But their friendly agreement soon becomes a nocturnal quest to fulfill Paul’s last wishes before day breaks.
items.default_editorial: As if growing pains aren’t confusing enough, the conundrums of life as a vampire add more chaos to the mix in Ariane Louis-Seize’s delightfully deadpan comedy. Approaching the gloom of death with gentle humor, this offbeat tale of love and friendship embraces the beauty of shared eccentricities.

items.title: I Am Not a Witch
items.short_synopsis: In Zambia, eight-year-old orphan Shula is accused of witchcraft and exiled to a witch camp run by a corrupt government official. As the only child witch, Shula is exploited by adults for financial gain and forced to decide whether to resign herself to life on the camp, or take a risk for freedom.
items.default_editorial: Exploring Zambia’s little-known culture of “witch camps,” Rungano Nyoni’s debut masterfully combines comedy, tragedy, and mesmerizing visuals. A portrait of a defiant young girl, I Am Not a Witch mounts an acerbic critique of women’s oppression and corruption through tourism, media and superstition.

items.title: I Hired a Contract Killer
items.short_synopsis: Henri Boulanger wants to die. Since his helpless attempts to end his days go down the drain, he hires a contract killer to do the job. While waiting for the killer, however, he makes the mistake of sipping a whisky for the first time in his life, meets a woman and promptly falls in love.
items.default_editorial: In his first collaboration with Aki Kaurismäki, iconic French star Jean-Pierre Léaud proves a perfect fit for the director’s droll and deadpan, not-quite-comedy style. Absurd and existential, the London-set I Hired a Contract Killer is a rare and fascinating outsider’s view of late-80s Britain.

items.title: I'm the Angel of Death: Pusher III
items.short_synopsis: As drug lord Milo struggles to prepare his daughter’s 25th birthday party, his business proves equally challenging when a shipment of ecstasy arrives instead of heroin. Forced to work with a new drug he knows little about, he must find a way to maintain his dominance atop the Copenhagen underworld.
items.default_editorial: Nicolas Winding Refn saves the best for last. Set over a single night, the focus shifts to drug baron Milo—another Pusher antihero up against the clock. Refn keeps multiple plates spinning and anxiety levels off the scale, while foraging for bloodied scraps of humanity among the moral ruins.

items.title: If Footmen Tire You, What Will Horses Do?
items.original_title: If Footmen Tire You, What Will Horses Do?
items.short_synopsis: A piece of unadulterated Christian propaganda spiced with enough violence and bloodletting to satisfy the most jaded gorehound.
items.default_editorial: B-movie evangelists the Ormond Family are at it again! In the final installment of their deranged trilogy with preacher Estus W. Pirkle, matters soon get out of hand. Hippies, communists, non-believers: all are cast with eternal damnation in this bonkers slice of Baptist propaganda.

items.title: In omaggio all'arte italiana!
items.short_synopsis: Presented at the 2015 Venice Biennale, this short film by Jean-Marie Straub is a fragment of the last reel of his film History Lessons, based on Bertolt Brecht’s The Business Affairs of Mr Julius Caesar and  dedicated to the memory and materiality of cinema.
items.default_editorial: In a protracted act of adaptation, Jean-Marie Straub retrieves and recontextualises this installation piece from the last reel of one of he and Danièle Huillet’s Italian films: History Lessons, itself a retelling of Brecht’s unfinished historical novel The Business Affairs of Mr. Julius Caesar.

items.title: In the Name of Christ
items.short_synopsis: In a small village in West Africa, a pig-herd decides to save his people after nearly drowning, presenting himself as the cousin of Christ. Somewhat crazy and a bit of a thief, he rules as master and pushes his convictions to the limit, going as far as having himself crucified like Christ.
items.default_editorial: A classic of African cinema, Ivory Coast filmmaker Roger Gnoan M’Bala came to international attention for this enticing, subversive social satire. Scathing in its comedy, In the Name of Christ takes aim at the theatre and—even more ambitiously—the colonial enterprise of religion in West Africa.

items.title: In the Realm of the Senses
items.original_title: 愛のコリーダ | Ai no korīda
items.short_synopsis: Sade Abe is a former geisha working as a hotel maid in pre-World War II Japan. After she begins a torrid affair with the owner, they become completely infatuated. Their experimental sexual encounters spiral into an all-consuming and destructive love affair where even life is worth sacrificing.
items.default_editorial: A no-holds-barred cult classic from director Nagisa Ôshima, this provocative chamber drama has lost none of its unsettling power. A vigorous attack on Japanese cultural values and patriarchal mores, In the Realm of the Senses steers its tragic tale of amour fou into a transgressive death spiral.

items.title: Incoherence
items.short_synopsis: A teacher hides his pornographic magazine from a female student. A jogger steals milk and blames it on a newspaper delivery boy. A drunk man desperately searches for a public toilet late at night. Over three episodes, three respectable middle-aged men find themselves behaving badly.
items.default_editorial: Made with his signature blend of acidic satire and social critique, this witty graduation short from Parasite auteur Bong Joon Ho is a delightful prelude to an illustrious career. Contrasting public righteousness with private vice, Incoherence boldly strips Korean elites of their hypocritical masks.

items.title: Indecent Desires
items.short_synopsis: A man finds a doll in a garbage can, and seeing that the woman he lives with looks like the doll, he starts touching. However, the doll transmits these touches to her.
items.default_editorial: One of Doris Wishman’s late 60s “roughies,” Indecent Desires features many of the legendary director’s authorial quirks, like cutaways to kooky interiors, out-of-sync voice-overs, and erratic continuity. This splintered tale of depravity and occultism up-turns male domination and obsessive desire.

items.title: Irma Vep
items.short_synopsis: Hong Kong action diva Maggie Cheung (playing herself) comes to France when a past-his-prime director casts her in a remake of the silent classic Les Vampires. Clad in a rubber catsuit and unable to speak a word of French, Cheung finds herself adrift in the insanity of the film industry…
items.default_editorial: Starring alongside Jean-Pierre Léaud, Maggie Cheung is the mysterious, latex-clad femme fatale at the center of haute auteur Olivier Assayas’s spiky and dizzyingly hip 1990s satire of the French film industry. Irma Vep both pays tribute to 100 years of French cinema and adds plenty of its own!

items.title: It's Not Me
items.short_synopsis: For an exhibition that in the end never took place, the Pompidou Museum asked the filmmaker to reply, in pictures, to the question: “Where are you at, Leos Carax?” He attempts an answer—full of questions—about himself and “his” world: “I don’t know, but if I did, I’d reply that…”
items.default_editorial: Leos Carax—the visionary mind behind Holy Motors and Annette—returns with his most personal film: a dazzling 41-minute collage of self-portraiture. Spinning political and philosophical histories into a Godardian dance of ideas, It’s Not Me is a stylistically arresting work of cinematic confession.

items.title: Jaggi
items.short_synopsis: In rural Punjab, a schoolboy’s impotence sparks rumours about his sexuality, leading to relentless bullying. As family secrets surface and inner demons grow, he’s pushed to the brink. When faced with an arranged marriage, he must make a devastating choice.
items.default_editorial: Made in a DIY fashion, this Punjabi indie is a testament to the audacious passion of its crew. Backed by Ramnish Chaudhary’s gut-wrenching portrayal of the titular Jaggi, Anmol Sidhu’s remarkable directorial debut boldly confronts toxic masculinity and clichéd Punjabi machismo tropes onscreen.

items.title: January
items.short_synopsis: After murdering his wife, Horatio and his lover Lucrecia run away to a cabin in the country. As Horatio becomes increasingly consumed by guilt and memories of his dead wife, Lucrecia starts to question whether she should remain by his side or not.
items.default_editorial: Adrián González’s debut feature film—the first produced by a Michoacán director!—makes us feel like voyeurs as we become witnesses to the breakup of a relationship. Following a “crime of passion,” two lovers are forced to confront the consequences of their actions and the limits of their boundaries.

items.title: Jessica Forever
items.short_synopsis: In a dystopian world dominated by an oppressive regime, a woman named Jessica rescues orphaned boys and gives them love and understanding—offering them an escape from their violent past. Bound by a united hope for peace and harmony, this matriarchal family fights for a better future.
items.default_editorial: After several acclaimed, provocative short films, French filmmakers Caroline Poggi & Jonathan Vinel’s feature is a revelation. An intimate science-fiction film concerning a matriarch and her “orphans,” Jessica Forever is an enigmatic polemic on the power of platonic love in a pre-apocalyptic world.

items.title: Juha
items.short_synopsis: Everything changes for rural farmer Juha and his wife Marja when a sophisticated stranger is brought fatefully into their lives after his car breaks down in their village. Soon, Marja is seduced by the city slicker and runs away with him, only to find herself in a dire situation in the metropolis.
items.default_editorial: Move over The Artist, there’s a new black-and-white silent-movie pastiche in town. Given his characters’ penchant for monosyllabism, it’s surprising it took Kaurismäki so long to make a silent film. Stunningly shot by Timo Salminen, this wistful melodrama is a stylistic triumph of parodic affection.

items.title: Jules and Jim
items.short_synopsis: Two artist best friends—the German Jules and the French Jim—love the same woman, the enigmatic and alluring Catherine. Over three decades, the love triangle’s bond will be strengthened, broken, and tested as events like the Great War take place.
items.default_editorial: An exuberant French New Wave classic, starring the unforgettable Jeanne Moreau in one of her most notorious, spellbinding performances. François Truffaut plays wildly with images—using freeze frames, jump cuts, and newsreels—to elevate cinema’s innovative potential in this paean to lost innocence.

items.title: Kinetta
items.short_synopsis: In a desolate Greek resort town, a chambermaid, a man obsessed with BMW cars, and a photo-store clerk stage re-enactments of a local serial killer’s murders. What seems to be an investigative experiment turns out to be more of an exploration into the depths of their own psychosexual obsessions.
items.default_editorial: If you enjoyed The Lobster and The Killing of a Sacred Deer, you might want to know where it all started (that’s right, Dogtooth wasn’t the beginning). Greek maverick Yorgos Lanthimos’ debut is an elliptical and weirdly captivating take on alienation that was also produced by Athina Rachel Tsangari.

items.title: Kokomo City
items.short_synopsis: Daniella Carter, Koko Da Doll, Liyah Mitchell, and Dominique Silver are four Black transgender women navigating the sex work industry in Atlanta and New York City. They recount tales of resilience, survival, and identity—challenging stereotypes and revealing the harsh realities of their world.
items.default_editorial: Shunned by the music industry after her transition, Grammy-nominated record producer D. Smith brings a dynamic sense of rhythm to her format-defying debut. A raw and honest look at the lives of Black trans sex workers in New York and Georgia, Kokomo City breaks social stigmas with a vivacious style.

items.title: Krisha
items.short_synopsis: After a long absence, a woman reunites with her family for a holiday gathering. She sees it as an opportunity to fix her past mistakes, cook the family turkey and prove to her loved ones that she has changed for the better. But her delirium takes her family on a holiday that no one will forget.
items.default_editorial: An American indie that took 26 year-old director Trey Shults (It Comes at Night) all the way to the Cannes Festival, the sleeper hit Krisha casts Shults’s own aunt Krisha Fairchild in this disarming, distressing confrontation with the reality of addiction. Winner of the Grand Jury Award at SXSW.

items.title: L'avance
items.short_synopsis: Aliou, a burgeoning student at Les Beaux-Arts in Paris, sells a painting of his dead mother for 3000 euros to a famous collector. Upon delivering the painting, he is taken on a journey through which he will bear the burden of the money he has just earned.
items.default_editorial: After collaborating with fashion icon Virgil Abloh, rising star Djiby Kebe muses on the transactional realm of art for his astute debut short. Smudged with wavering feelings of unease, L’avance adds color to the existential dilemmas of an African diasporic painter with vitality and novel style.

items.title: La antena
items.short_synopsis: An entire city has lost its voice. Mr. TV, the owner of the city’s only television channel, is carrying out a sinister plan to control all of the city’s inhabitants. He kidnaps a singer, the only one who still has The Voice. An inventor witnesses the kidnapping and flees to thwart approaching doom.
items.default_editorial: The first film ever to screen on MUBI, this surreal fairytale from visionary auteur Esteban Sapir champions the power of the human voice over consumerism and totalitarian control. Using the language of silent cinema, La Antena devises a fantastical dreamscape, packed with eye-popping visual effects.

items.title: La Chimera
items.short_synopsis: In 1980s rural Italy, English archaeologist Arthur aids a ragtag group of local graverobbers to find ancient tombs filled with valuable artefacts. But Arthur, who mourns the loss of his love, Beniamina, uses the digs to search for the door to the afterlife, where he imagines reuniting with her.
items.default_editorial: Met with exuberant critical acclaim, Alice Rohrwacher’s fourth feature is abundant with the treasures of a bygone Tuscany. With a handsome Josh O’Connor and the iconic Isabella Rossellini leading a charming troupe of graverobbers and rascals, this mythic yet earthy romance casts a beguiling spell.

items.title: La jetée
items.short_synopsis: After World War III, Paris lies in ruins. A scientist researching time travel hopes to send subjects to various time periods. He finds a suitable subject in a prisoner with a vivid pre-war childhood memory. The prisoner travels in time and comes to understand an incident he witnessed as a child.
items.default_editorial: Chris Marker’s game-changing photo-roman is an inventive distillation of cinema, combining montage and voiceover to create a recursive stream of melancholic memories and striking fragments. Forget about special effects: this ingenious vision of science-fiction embraces the power of the imagination.

items.title: La libertad
items.short_synopsis: Matriarchs have assembled around a backstrap loom, a pre-Hispanic technique preserved by indigenous women of Mesoamerica. Unfolding like a weaving of figures and the gestures making up this labor, the film circulates between a domestic space, an archaeological museum, and a weavers’ cooperative.
items.default_editorial: Produced at Harvard’s Sensory Ethnography Lab (Leviathan, Manakamana), La Libertad dives into a matriarchal universe and knits a rich portrait of female independence. Through the exploration of an ancestral craft, Laura Huertas Millán’s film quietly challenges our idea of freedom.

items.title: La Paz in Buenos Aires
items.short_synopsis: Erasmo Chambi is a Bolivian migrant who survives on the outskirts of Buenos Aires by giving lucha libre wrestling performances in small local clubs, bringing his own hand-made ring to each show. Back home, he was a legendary wrestler named “El Ciclon.” Now, he trains his son to become his successor.
items.default_editorial: Marcelo Charras’ up-close-and-personal documentary on the world of local wrestling in Buenos Aires intimately studies the intergenerational bond among the tight-knit community of Bolivian immigrants. The love between a former champion and his son is embodied by hours of blood, sweats and tears.

items.title: Laberint Sequences
items.short_synopsis: Laberint d’Horta, Barcelona. In the park’s garden, at the center of its maze, a statue of Eros waits. Several journeys take place in search of the center. While navigating the maze’s false pathways, structures start to crack, and a mysterious underworld floods its gates.
items.default_editorial: Light doubles and bends in Blake Williams’s sixth short, as the snaking camera twists and turns around corners that buzz with histories of 3D cinema. Deragh Campbell materializes toward the spectral end of this mesmeric experiment in perception, which coruscates with wonder in the Catalonian sun.

items.title: Lady
items.short_synopsis: An unnamed woman in a red wig welcomes a documentary crew into her New York apartment. The crew captures her everyday life, as she fights with her boyfriend and gossips with her friend. These scenes alternate with black-and-white footage of a woman in a red wig escaping a suburban existence.
items.default_editorial: Anchored by a magnetic central performance, this free-form short captures both the thrill and isolation of New York City life. Ira Sachs borrows from cinéma vérité and TV melodrama to craft an intimate and intriguing portrait of a woman grappling with her own uncertain sexuality and gender identity.

items.title: Land of My Dreams
items.short_synopsis: After many years apart, Bianca and her mother meet again in the streets of Porto. Together, they hit the road with their stripping show, running after lost time, impossible love, and strange fantasies.
items.default_editorial: Once we discovered French director Yann Gonzalez’s debut, You and the Night, we had to see more. So we’ve tracked down the short he made just before his first feature—and, unsurprisingly, it is pure kink featuring a mother-daughter stripping act. Hyper-stylized, campy and sexy, the film simply pops!

items.title: Lateral
items.short_synopsis: Artist Charlie Shackleton realizes he can trick the human brain into detecting 3D images without using two cameras. He scours cinema history for hidden depths, testing out tracking shots from various films, including works by Chantal Akerman and Stanley Kubrick.
items.default_editorial: Adopting a simple formal trick, this understated short is a beautiful reminder that the human eye plays a crucial part in the creation of movie magic. Inviting us to participate in a quietly stunning experiment, Charlie Shackleton’s soothing narration conjures up exciting filmmaking horizons.

items.title: Le bonheur
items.short_synopsis: François, a happily married carpenter with a young family, falls in love with telephone operator Emilie. As he basks in the joy of his new relationship, his feelings for his family intensify. But when he tries to share his joyful news with his wife, her reaction is far from the delight he hoped for.
items.default_editorial: Agnès Varda’s color-saturated third feature is a thorough takedown of the nuclear family, which deconstructs the one-way relationship of a husband and wife and their apparently idyllic life together. Bold, sun-drenched and provoking, Le bonheur is a proto-feminist time bomb that’s ready to detonate.

items.title: Le Havre
items.short_synopsis: In the French harbor city of Le Havre, fate throws young African refugee Idrissa into the path of Marcel Marx, a well-spoken bohemian who works as a shoe-shiner. With innate optimism and the tireless support of his community, Marcel stands up to officials pursuing the boy for deportation.
items.default_editorial: Aki Kaurismäki returns to France with this sun-kissed utopian parable. One of his most politically resonant films, Le Havre echoes The Man Without a Past’s ruminations on community and resilience, albeit this time (via a hat tip to Carl Dreyer’s Ordet) with a nod to the vagaries of the divine.

items.title: Le Moulin
items.original_title: Ri yao ri shih san pu zhe
items.short_synopsis: Poetry, literature, painting and old film clips converge in this lyrical, unusually designed film essay about Le Moulin, the Taiwanese poets’ collective which protested in the 1930s against the cultural superiority of the Japanese occupier and the domination of realism in poetry.
items.default_editorial: With remarkable variety of form and a graceful touch, this expansive yet tremendously sensitive debut by Huang Ya-li is an epic and detailed immersion into a remarkable group of writers in Taiwan. Spanning three decades of political turmoil and war, we movingly watch their struggle to create art.

items.title: Léa
items.short_synopsis: Léa, a student in Le Havre, takes care of her grandmother who requires constant attention, and works as a waitress to make ends meet. But when she is accepted at a prestigious school in Paris, she must make decisions. In order to pay her way through school, she becomes a stripper.
items.default_editorial: Moving from the town of Le Havre to the city of Paris, and one class to another, Léa is a character study with a sly, clever set-up: a close-up on a young woman who resorts to a career in stripping to bankroll her studies. A debut feature from Bruno Rolland, co-written with lead actor Anne Azoulay.

items.title: Lemon Tree
items.short_synopsis: At a Halloween carnival, a young father steals a magician’s rabbit to impress his ten-year-old son. The thrill of the petty theft quickly dissolves when the young boy is tasked with getting himself, his father, and his new pet home safe.
items.default_editorial: All the irresistible charms of Americana sparkle in this bold debut from New York filmmaker Rachel Walden. Navigating luck, risk, and small scares on a whiplash of a road trip, a man and his curious child bond in a film propelled by beautifully grungy 16mm imagery and immersively frenetic editing.

items.title: Leningrad Cowboys Go America
items.short_synopsis: A struggling Siberian rock band leaves home in the lonely tundra to tour the United States because, as they’re told, “they’ll buy anything there.” The musicians bravely venture across the States, carrying a bandmate and some beer in a coffin, and sporting hairdos resembling unicorn horns.
items.default_editorial: Eastern European dry humor meets American idiosyncrasies in Aki Kaurismäki’s delightfully absurd classic, released the same year the Berlin Wall fell. Speeding through the Deep South, this off-beat adventure—featuring a Jim Jarmusch cameo—marks the birth of the most unforgettable cover band on film.

items.title: Leningrad Cowboys Meet Moses
items.short_synopsis: Living in Mexico with a top-ten hit under their belts, the Leningrad Cowboys have fallen on hard times. But when their manager, who has become a delusional self-proclaimed prophet, secures a gig for the band on Coney Island, they must illegally cross the Mexico-United States border to get there.
items.default_editorial: The boys are back in town for this rowdy sequel to Leningrad Cowboys Go America. With half the band killed off by some dodgy tequila, the remainder take to the road for a deliriously dippy satire of communism and religion. Aki Kaurismäki plays the hits, but the gags come thick and fast.

items.title: Letter
items.short_synopsis: In a remote village in the Northwest of Russia, a psychiatric ward exists in an old wooden house. The place and its inhabitants seem to be untouched by civilization. But in this pristine setting, no articulate human voice is heard, and all pain is muted.
items.default_editorial: Made by Ukrainian auteur Sergei Loznitsa while shooting his 2001 doc The Settlement , this short film eerily plays with time and space. Shot with a special camera—with each image appearing as if it was taken in the early years of the 20th century — Letter is an impressionistic work of non-fiction.

items.title: Letter from Siberia
items.short_synopsis: A traveler goes on a journey through the vast territory and isolated villages of Siberia, recording his observations on its people and places, wildlife and culture. Urbanization, reckless deforestation and the demise of the wooly mammoth all fall under his critical gaze.
items.default_editorial: Bolstered by a cheeky script and a spirited score from the French New Wave’s Georges Delerue, Chris Marker’s stunning travelogue charms with a sweet tenderness for the people and the landscape of Siberia. As in his other celebrated works, the presence of animals is at once unexpected and delightful.

items.title: Letters to Max
items.short_synopsis: A record of the epistolary encounter between French artist and filmmaker Eric Baudelaire and Maxim Gvinjia, former Foreign Minister of the breakaway Caucasian state of Abkhazia, Letters to Max is both a chronicle of a developing friendship and an ingenious and unusual essay film.
items.default_editorial: Eric Baudelaire’s rich and speculative essay film is a moving meditation on nationhood, which also traces the emergence of an unlikely friendship. With echoes of Chris Marker’s Letter from Siberia, this 2014 festival hit explores the unexplorable through a chain of correspondence.

items.title: Lick the Star
items.short_synopsis: Kate has been absent from high school for a week due to a broken foot. Upon returning, she learns her clique of girlfriends has devised a secret plan with arsenic—codenamed “Lick the Star”—to make the boys weak.
items.default_editorial: Before The Virgin Suicides and Priscilla, Sofia Coppola had already transformed onscreen portrayals of girlhood and female friendship in her first directorial outing. Ultra-cool 1990s outfits, a killer soundtrack, and dreamy 16mm imagery make this audacious short an instant classic of teenage ennui.

items.title: Lights in the Dusk
items.short_synopsis: Outcast by his co-workers and living alone, Koistinen is a security guard who works the night shift in a luxury shopping mall in Helsinki. But when icy blonde Mirja approaches him, the lonely Koistinen falls helplessly for her, unaware she is manipulating him for her criminal boyfriend.
items.default_editorial: Aki Kaurismäki concludes his so-called “Loser Trilogy” with a minimalist Bressonian fable. An existentially charged anatomisation of urban loneliness indebted to the work of Edward Hopper, this noirish morality tale seeks love and redemption along modern Helsinki’s thoroughfares of broken dreams.

items.title: Lingui, The Sacred Bonds
items.short_synopsis: On the outskirts of the capital of Chad, determined single mother Amina works tirelessly to provide for herself and her 15-year old daughter Maria. When Amina discovers Maria is pregnant and does not want a child, the two women begin to seek out an abortion, condemned by both religion and law.
items.default_editorial: In this sumptuous masterwork from Mahamat-Saleh Haroun, the outskirts of N’Djamena shimmer with a vivacity that belies brutal prejudices. A powerful ode to the resilience of Chadian women in the face of patriarchal cruelty, this quietly radical drama has all the healing warmth of a mother’s embrace.

items.title: Lips of Blood
items.short_synopsis: When a photograph of a decrepit seaside château evokes a childhood vision of an encounter with a mysterious girl, Frederick is compelled to investigate. Soon, he uncovers a surreal and erotic netherworld of vampirism from which he might never return.
items.default_editorial: Elegantly roaming from castle ruins to the streets of Paris, the wanton vampires in Jean Rollin’s bloodsucking classic are ethereal visions of eros. Fired up by passions that transcend time and space, this spellbinding cinematic puzzle is entranced by the enduring hold of childhood memories.

items.title: Listen Up Philip
items.short_synopsis: As Philip awaits the publication of his second novel, he feels pushed out of his adopted home city by the constant noise and a deteriorating relationship with his girlfriend Ashley. When Philip’s idol offers his summer home as a refuge, he finally gets to focus on his favorite subject: himself.
items.default_editorial: In Alex Ross Perry’s audacious dark comedy, Jason Schwartzman, Elisabeth Moss, and Jonathan Pryce round out a stellar cast for a story that takes emotionally rich, surprising turns. A comment on the loathsome, narcissistic writer figure that’s full of brutally acidic humour hiding deeper ponderings.

items.title: Living Still Life
items.short_synopsis: In a world in decay, Fièvre, an enigmatic woman, collects dead animals. She brings them to life by filming them and creating animated films. However, one day, a man comes to see Fièvre. He has a request for her regarding his dead wife…
items.default_editorial: Another of Mandico’s chimerical cinematic offerings, Living Still Life echoes the strange rhythms and internal logic of dreams. Stop-motion animation and up-close, visceral shots of animals bring to life a world in decay, as we chase down the rabbit hole a woman driven by strange pursuits.

items.title: Lost and Beautiful
items.short_synopsis: Pulcinella, a foolish servant, is sent to present-day Campania to grant the last wish of shepherd Tommaso: he must rescue a young buffalo called Sarchiapone. In the Royal Palace of Carditello,  the ruins of which were once looked after by Tommaso, Pulcinella finds the buffalo and leads him North.
items.default_editorial: This beguiling shape-shifter of a film began as a portrait of the groundskeeper of an Italian palace until the subject’s untimely death transformed the project into something more fable-like and phantasmagoric. Martin Eden’s Pietro Marcello embarks on an enigmatic journey through a bucolic Italy.

items.title: Lost Highway
items.short_synopsis: Fred Madison, a musician, starts receiving mysterious VHS tapes of him and his wife in their home and is tortured by the idea that his wife is having an affair. After being suddenly convicted of her murder, he inexplicably disappears and is replaced by a young mechanic leading a different life.
items.default_editorial: This misunderstood cult classic sees surrealist mastermind David Lynch back in Los Angeles, journeying once more down the rabbit hole. Indulging in a career-long interest in doubling and doppelgängers, the looping and splintered story of this nightmarish neo-noir weighs heavily with foreboding.

items.title: Made in England: The Films of Powell and Pressburger
items.original_title: Made in England: The Films of Powell and Pressburger
items.short_synopsis: Martin Scorsese celebrates the enduring legacy of visionary writer-directors Michael Powell and Emeric Pressburger—two of British cinema’s greatest filmmakers. With a treasure trove of clips and rare archival footage, Scorsese investigates the duo’s bold genius and colossal impact on cinema history.
items.default_editorial: The Red Shoes, Black Narcissus, A Canterbury Tale, and so much more—Powell and Pressburger were a legendary filmmaking duo. With superfan Martin Scorsese leading viewers on a personal journey through the work of these cinematic titans, Made in England is a rousing introduction to a visionary oeuvre.

items.title: Magic Farm
items.short_synopsis: When a misguided American documentary crew in search of their next viral segment ends up in the wrong town in rural Argentina, chaos ensues. As they collaborate with locals to fake a new music trend, unexpected relationships form and an unfolding health crisis becomes apparent.
items.default_editorial: Things get weird in Amalia Ulman’s kaleidoscopic film, a colorful comedy of errors and an imaginative send-up of millennial media. Starring Simon Rex and Chloë Sevigny, this story of a frantic search for an internet sensation is electrified by wit, subversion, and distinctively fluorescent style.

items.title: Mala Noche
items.short_synopsis: In Portland, a young store clerk named Walt falls for Johnny, a Mexican migrant worker. Despite the language barrier and Johnny’s indifference, Walt pursues him, drawing himself into a tangled web of desire, frustration, and fleeting connection on the city’s fringes.
items.default_editorial: In the 80s, American cinema entered a grungy Golden Age, as a generation of indie films blossomed from modest origins. Made for $25,000 on 16mm, this debut from Gus Van Sant (Elephant, Milk) is a quintessentially American classic, as well as a vital precursor of the New Queer Cinema movement.

items.title: Manderlay
items.short_synopsis: After leaving Dogville, Grace and her father discover an Alabama plantation whose inhabitants live as if slavery had never been abolished. Grace, feeling a sense of duty to the people behind the heavy gates, stays to liberate the slaves and see them through their first harvest.
items.default_editorial: A difficult yet rewarding film from the equally complex Danish provocateur Lars von Trier! This fiercely polemical, little-seen sequel to Dogville tackles a topic as sensitive as slavery, all the while maintaining its predecessor’s Brechtian premise, anti-American bent, and yes, its brilliance.

items.title: Manufraktur
items.short_synopsis: Using found footage from commercials showing mainly women’s legs and cars, a tangled network of movements is woven, broken out of the found footage, and compiled anew. Discharged from all its semantic burden, what remains is a self-sufficient swarm of splinters, fleeting vectors of lost direction.
items.default_editorial: A playful interrogation of the materiality of celluloid, Peter Tscherkassky’s Manufraktur explores the tension between an image and the film on which it is captured. The avant-garde filmmaker’s architectural fascination stands out from the film’s temporal, sonic, and material manipulations.

items.title: Mariner of the Mountains
items.short_synopsis: Filmmaker Karim Aïnouz decides to take a boat, cross the Mediterranean and embark on his first journey to Algeria. Accompanied by the memory of his mother, Iracema, and his camera, Aïnouz gives a detailed account of the journey to his father’s homeland, interweaving present, past, and future.
items.default_editorial: Following his Cannes win for The Invisible Life of Euridice Gusmão, Karim Aïnouz returns with this intoxicating blend of travelogue, affective memoir, and personal memento mori. A poignant exploration of displacement and identity, Mariner of the Mountains shimmers with feelings of loss and longing.

items.title: Martin Eden
items.short_synopsis: Martin is a self-taught proletarian with artistic aspirations who hopes that his dreams of becoming a writer will help him rise above his station and marry a wealthy young university student. His dissatisfactions of working-class toil and bourgeois success lead to political awakening.
items.default_editorial: Luca Marinelli won Best Actor at Venice for this beguilingly romantic study in class and political evolution. With indefatigable stylistic energy, director Pietro Marcello transposes Jack London’s autobiographical novel to the streets of Naples, forging a rich, panoramic metaphor for modern society.

items.title: Masculin Féminin
items.short_synopsis: Paul is young, just demobbed from service in the French Army, and disillusioned with civilian life. While his girlfriend builds herself a career as a pop singer, Paul becomes more isolated from his peers and from their social politics.
items.default_editorial: Humming with energy, pop music, politics, sex, and above all cinema, this classic is a model of filmmaking freedom. Starring Jean-Pierre Léaud and yé-yé singer Chantal Goya, this is a recent restoration of one of the most emblematic films of 1960s Paris, and a must-see in Godard’s filmography!

items.title: Matt and Mara
items.short_synopsis: In Toronto, creative writing professor Mara bumps into Matt, a free-spirited author from her past. Bonded by their shared interests, the two grow closer as Mara juggles marriage, motherhood and work. But when Matt joins her on a road trip, pressure slowly mounts against their undefined relationship.
items.default_editorial: Risking ellipses and question marks, Canadian director Kazik Radwanski traces the ambiguous forms that romance can take with Matt and Mara. Through the surprises and genuine laughs of improvisation, the talented leads articulate a rare, real attraction for which there are, ordinarily, only clichés.

items.title: Maurice's Bar
items.short_synopsis: In 1942, on a train to nowhere, a former drag queen remembers a night from her past in one of Paris’ first queer bars. Lingering fragments of customer gossip conjure memories of the mythic bar and its mysterious Jewish-Algerian owner.
items.default_editorial: Reclaiming a piece of queer history, Tzor Edery and Tom Prezman’s animated short movingly resurrects a forgotten gay bar from its tragic fate under the Nazi occupation of France. Awash with voluptuous imagery, this is a vital ode to the radical joy that dares to flourish in the face of intolerance.

items.title: Medicine for Melancholy
items.short_synopsis: In a rapidly gentrifying San Francisco, a one-night stand between two bohemians, Micah and Jo’, spins off into a woozy daylong affair. Their day is filled with tenderness, friction, and intellectual sparring as they explore their relationships with each other, the city, and their own Blackness.
items.default_editorial: More than a calling card for the Oscar®-winning Moonlight, Barry Jenkins’ feature debut heralded the arrival of a deeply impassioned vision. A yearning portrait of modern Blackness in San Francisco, Medicine for Melancholy is a captivatingly authentic tale of hesitant love and urban malaise.

items.title: Meeting the Man: James Baldwin in Paris
items.original_title: Meeting the Man: James Baldwin in Paris
items.short_synopsis: In 1970, a British film crew set out to make a literary portrait of James Baldwin set in Paris, insisting on setting aside his activism. The author visits Parisian landmarks and reflects on revolution, colonialism, and what it means to be Black in Europe—while bristling at the filmmakers’ questions.
items.default_editorial: Tense, combative, discursive: a meeting with James Baldwin doesn’t quite go according to plan for a group of presumptuous white filmmakers in this rarely seen, Paris-set short film. An illuminating snapshot of Baldwin’s intellectual worldview that bristles with friction and ideas.

items.title: Melancholia
items.short_synopsis: An eight-hour meditation on the maddening persistence of sadness in this world, divided into three parts following a prostitute, a pimp and a nun who wander the countryside.
items.default_editorial: An untold number of persons have disappeared in the Philippines over the years, before, during and after the Marcos dictatorship. Melancholia is devoted to the grief and search for meaning over such disappearances, told across a vivid array of Philippine society.

items.title: Melrose: Rich Little Bitch [MV]
items.short_synopsis: The music video for “Rich Little Bitch” by Melrose. The group performs live in front of a crowd during the shoot of Hamlet Goes Business.
items.default_editorial: Kaurismäki’s love for the toe-tapping rhythms of rock ‘n’ roll burns bright across his entire filmography, but he has a special place in his heart for the band Melrose. Shot live, this four-minute concert film captures the group in their element: tearing up the stage in a packed Helsinki dive bar.

items.title: Miniatures: Many Berlin Artists in Hoisdorf
items.original_title: Miniaturen – Viele Berliner Künstler in Hoisdorf
items.short_synopsis: On a weekend in June 1983, in what was deemed a “country outing,” an impressive number of Berlin-based artists went to a small German village to give the local residents a taste of Berlin’s avant-garde art scene. Back in Berlin, the footage was manipulated to produce an “experimental examination.”
items.default_editorial: Playful and otherworldly, Peter Tscherkassky’s visual record of an avant-garde experiment put on by a group of Berlin artists erase the undue emphasis on individuality. Instead, the collective are highlighted, as scratched, manipulated Super 8 images transform human figures into enigmatic shadows.

items.title: Minotaur
items.short_synopsis: A wraithlike fantasy that observes three thirtysomethings as they sleep, dream, read and receive visitors in a Mexico City apartment.
items.default_editorial: This short feature from director Nicolás Pereda is a beautifully dreamy and enchanting work of indolent bohemian languor. Inspired by Last Year at Marienbad, the film sees three individuals in an apartment communicating through sleeping positions and books, creating a wonderful psalm of nostalgia.

items.title: Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters
items.original_title: Mishima: A Life in Four Chapters
items.short_synopsis: November 25, 1970. Yukio Mishima, the acclaimed Japanese author, faces his final day. Meanwhile, interrupting flashbacks intertwine Mishima’s past with scenes from his works, revealing the inner turmoil and contradictions of a man who attempted an impossible harmony between self, art, and society.
items.default_editorial: For the centenary of Yukio Mishima’s birth, we’re revisiting one of cinema’s greatest experiments in biopic form. Drawing from the Japanese iconoclast’s life and art, director Paul Schrader harmonizes a series of fractured sketches into a ravishing, expressionist elegy for violent transcendence.

items.title: Moon
items.short_synopsis: Sarah, a former mixed martial artist, takes up the offer to work as a personal trainer for the three daughters of a wealthy family in the Middle East. In a palace surrounded by walls and with constant surveillance on the sisters, Sarah finds that they are not really interested in boxing training.
items.default_editorial: A Locarno prizewinner, Kurdwin Ayub’s confidently provocative film grapples with a stifling, ultra-rich realm where freedom shimmers like a desert mirage. Orbiting a knockout turn from Florentina Holzinger, Moon plummets out of safe zones into unpredictable, explosive arenas of trouble and threat.

items.title: Moor Mother: Jazz Codes
items.short_synopsis: Poet, musician, visual artist, and Afrofuturist Moor Mother roams a hallucinatory Mojave Desert alone. Meanwhile, in Los Angeles, Moor Mother visits the Pan Afrikan Peoples Arkestra HQ and plays with jazz luminaries and elders, including Henry “The Skipper” Franklin, Michael Session, and Maia.
items.default_editorial: Looking to the future of jazz while honoring the legends of the past, Moor Mother’s spellbinding music transcends time and genre—and so does Cyrus Moussavi’s companion piece. Kaleidoscopic in its editing style, this prismatic short goes on a sonic journey between the Mojave Desert and Los Angeles.

items.title: Motion Picture (Employees Leaving the Lumière Factory)
items.original_title: Motion Picture (La Sortie des Ouvriers de l'Usine Lumière à Lyon)
items.short_synopsis: In the darkroom, 50 unexposed film strips were laid across a surface, upon which a frame of La sortie des ouvriers de l’usine Lumière was projected to create a new kind of film…
items.default_editorial: Stripping the Lumières’ famous first film of its figurative elements, Peter Tscherkassky’s experimental short playfully reinterprets the birth of cinema. The painstaking manipulation of film strips and the exposure process reimagine the medium in its purest form: a dance between light and darkness.

items.title: Mouchette
items.short_synopsis: Mouchette is an adolescent living in the rough countryside. Her mother is dying and her father is absent. Remaining silent in the face of the humiliations she undergoes she finds respite in the woods. Everything changes when she meets poacher Arsene.
items.default_editorial: Among the very best of Robert Bresson’s films, Mouchette is a supreme example of the refined, enormously evocative style of its filmmaker: a cathartic purge of emotion, a tragedy in its most fundamental sense. An unforgettable Nadine Nortier leads this profoundly poignant, affecting film.

items.title: Moving
items.short_synopsis: Renko, a spirited sixth-grader in Kyoto, struggles to accept her parents’ separation. When her father leaves, her mother sets new rules Renko can’t make sense of. In a bid to hold on to their old life, she hides the divorce papers and plans a getaway to a lake they once visited as a family.
items.default_editorial: The rich inner worlds of children—filled with unanswered questions and fantastical reveries—come vividly alive in Shinji Sômai’s poetic masterpiece. Trailing after the hurried footsteps of a lovably mischievous troublemaker, Moving  probes the delicate passage between innocence and understanding.

items.title: Murder in Mississippi
items.short_synopsis: Torn-from-the-headlines exploitation or daring social commentary? Joseph P. Mawra’s film is a little of both, using the true story of the killing of civil rights workers in the American deep South as a gritty springboard for another ultra-low-budget entry from the director of Chained Girls.
items.default_editorial: From the prolific (and mysterious) exploitation director Joseph P. Mawra comes this noir-lit and furious grindhouse affair about a racist police force.
