A hugely ambitious sci-fi-hybrid steeped in metaphor, as well a touching, human romantic drama.

items.title: The Future Tense
items.short_synopsis: When two Irish filmmakers travel home from London with their daughter, they reflect on their relationship to Ireland, and their adopted home, England. They explore their own experiences in ageing, parenting, and mental illness, along with the brutal history that lies beneath Ireland’s heavy earth.
items.default_editorial: Bumpy journeys across the Irish Sea don’t come more timely than this. Playing with turbulent, limbo-like airspace between London and Dublin, directorial duo Christine Molloy and Joe Lawlor make profound use of poetic license to investigate what it means, in a fast-changing present, to belong.

items.title: The Girl with the Needle
items.short_synopsis: Struggling to survive in post-WWI Copenhagen, a newly unemployed and pregnant young woman is taken in by a charismatic elder to help run an underground adoption agency. The two form an unexpected bond, until a sudden discovery changes everything.
items.default_editorial: An Oscar®-nominated marvel of exquisite empathy, Magnus von Horn’s masterful vision of early 20th-century Denmark searches for tenderness and morality under fraught circumstances. Drawing on chilling true events that continue to resonate, this gothic parable is a visceral reckoning from the past.

items.title: The Gleaners and I
items.short_synopsis: With a digital camcorder in hand, Agnès Varda sets out to make a documentary about the lives of gatherers, recyclers, and treasure hunters she encounters in the cities and countryside of France. Often sidetracked, Varda finds time to reflect on everything from aging to the birth of cinema.
items.default_editorial: Always one to break new ground, Agnès Varda put together what is simply one of the greatest documentaries of all time. Warm, generous, and very human, this late-career triumph showcases her self-reflexive filming and constant hunt for raw material, finding beauty in the most unexpected of places.

items.title: The Here After
items.short_synopsis: When teenager John returns to his rural hometown after serving time in prison, he finds that his crime is neither forgiven nor forgotten. The local community and students at his old high school struggle with his presence. Soon, John is being attacked by fellow pupils and strangers in shops.
items.default_editorial: Before The Girl with the Needle, Magnus von Horn charted rugged psychological terrains in his suspenseful debut feature. Capturing the ripples that violence sends through a community in mourning, The Here After is an intricate study of a violent mind, and a provocative meditation on murder.

items.title: The Human Surge
items.short_synopsis: Buenos Aires. Exe, 25 years old, has just lost his job and is not looking for another one. Online, he meets Alf, a boy from Mozambique who is also bored with his job and who is about to follow Archie, another boy who has run away into the jungle.
items.default_editorial: Shot across three continents—and divided in three parts interlinked in unexpected ways—Eduardo Williams’s enigmatic feature debut takes us on a visceral journey to explore the ominous hyper-connectivity of today’s world. One of the most accomplished and refreshing films of recent years.

items.title: The Hypnosis
items.short_synopsis: Vera and André are a couple who get the chance to pitch their startup business at a prestigious pitching competition. Right before the contest, Vera tries hypnotherapy to quit smoking, with an unexpected side effect: she loses all social inhibitions.
items.default_editorial: For his zany feature debut, Ernst De Geer mounts a biting satire of startup culture, where authenticity is just another branded product for sale. Wreaking havoc as a modern couple on the verge of chaos, stars Asta Kamma August and Herbert Nordrum channel millennial anxiety with terrifying accuracy.

items.title: The Idiots
items.short_synopsis: In the Copenhagen suburbs, a commune aims to disrupt bourgeois society by spontaneously feigning physical or mental disabilities in public—including a new recruit motivated by a secret sorrow.
items.default_editorial: A controversy stormed, the Dogme 95 movement took center stage, and an angry critic got kicked out of the Cannes screening. When the dust settled, Lars von Trier was left with this poignant, boundary-pushing film, which explores the very price of provocation. Presented here in a new restoration!

items.title: The Invisible Life of Euridice Gusmão
items.original_title: A Vida Invisível de Eurídice Gusmão
items.short_synopsis: Rio de Janeiro, 1950. Euridice and Guida are two inseparable sisters. Each has a dream: becoming a renowned pianist, or finding true love. Because of their father they are forced to live without one another. Separated, they take control of their destiny, while never giving up hope of being reunited.
items.default_editorial: In this lush historical saga, Brazilian auteur Karim Aïnouz uses his flair for storytelling to craft a ravishing anti-patriarchal drama filled with deep, decades-spanning emotions. Winner of the Un Certain Regard Award at Cannes, Invisible Life is a resonant, beautifully-shot tale of sisterly love.

items.title: The Last Year of Darkness
items.short_synopsis: As the city of Chengdu changes, the future of beloved club Funky Town is unclear. For a vibrant group of DJs, drag artists, ravers, and skaters, it is a sanctuary that allows them to thrive after hours. But as the sun comes up, the friends must face what brought them to the party in the first place.
items.default_editorial: Attuned to the energy of nightlife in the Sichuan capital, Benjamin Mullinkosson’s immersive documentary pulsates to the euphoric beats of electronic music. A love letter to the city’s charismatic nonconformists and the fabled club that provides a queer haven amid an ever-changing urban landscape.

items.title: The Living End
items.short_synopsis: After learning he’s HIV positive, Jon, a gay film critic, embarks on a reckless road trip with Luke, a volatile hustler on the run. As they flee down the California highways, their bond deepens, and their journey becomes a defiant escape from a hostile world.
items.default_editorial: Taking off on a delirious road trip to nowhere, enfant terrible Gregg Araki updates the fragmented style of 1960s Godard into an incendiary zigzag across a hysterically hostile America. Violence, spontaneous sex, and bright color explode across this devastating cult film of New Queer Cinema.

items.title: The Loneliest Planet
items.short_synopsis: Engaged American couple Alex and Nica are backpacking through Eastern Europe. Upon arriving in Georgia, they hire a guide to lead them on a camping trek. Walking for hours, the three trade anecdotes to pass the time—until a momentary misstep changes everything the couple believes about themselves.
items.default_editorial: With its languid cinematography, Julia Loktev’s mesmerizing second feature takes us on a zig-zagging journey with a couple—played by Gael García Bernal and Hani Furstenberg—who have to suddenly confront the limits of what defines human relationships. What is left unsaid can be far more powerful.

items.title: The Lunchbox
items.short_synopsis: A mistaken delivery in Mumbai’s famous lunchbox delivery system connects Ila, a neglected housewife, to Saajan, a lonely man on the verge of retirement. Through a series of exchanged notes that they pass back and forth through the lunches, Saajan and Ila find comfort in their unexpected friendship.
items.default_editorial: A dazzlingly moving tale of chance and romance in Mumbai, The Lunchbox was a worldwide success, and one of the Indian hits of the recent decades. A gentle and charming portrait of loneliness and disenchantment within the huge, modern city, where two souls cross paths through a most uncommon manner.

items.title: The Maidens of Fetish Street
items.short_synopsis: One-of-a-kind “experimental grindhouse” film (and the sole effort by director Saul Resnick) is a series of kinky vignettes centered around a lonely, wandering soul, purportedly set in a 1928 Los Angeles that seems curiously infused with 1960s S&M iconography.
items.default_editorial: Saul Resnick’s sole film is a quirky quickie ripe with sexploitation sleaze. An experimental grindhouse with an avant-garde streak, The Maidens of Fetish Street perversely plays with early 60s S&M iconography and off-the-cuff quips in 20s L.A. It’s quick, it’s freaky, and it’s a lot of fun too!

items.title: The Makes
items.short_synopsis: The starting point of this film is a book of unfilmed scripts by Antonioni: That Bowling Alley on the Tiber. This film essay is ‘acted out’ by the real-life critic Philippe Azoury, who plays a non-existent critic discussing these non-existent films from Antonioni’s non-existent ‘Japanese period’.
items.default_editorial: Baudelaire’s The Makes is an inventive, amusing reflection on the interchangeability of reality and fiction. This love letter to Antonioni is enacted through a critical commentary of his apocryphal Japan period. This is a film that doesn’t look like a film and talks about films that don’t exist!

items.title: The Man Without a Past
items.short_synopsis: Arriving in Helsinki, a nameless man is beaten within an inch of his life by thugs, miraculously recovering only to find that he has completely lost his memory. Back on the streets, he attempts to begin again from zero, befriending a moody dog and becoming besotted with a Salvation Army volunteer.
items.default_editorial: Aki Kaurismäki scored one of his biggest hits with this winsome ode to community and kindness. Earning an Oscar® nod for foreign picture alongside its armful of prizes from Cannes, The Man Without a Past harmonises compassion and rarefied stylistic poise into a swoonworthy serenade to humanity.

items.title: The Mastermind
items.short_synopsis: In a sedate Massachusetts suburb circa 1970, unemployed family man and amateur art thief J.B. Mooney sets out on his first heist. With the museum cased and accomplices recruited, he has an airtight plan. Or so he thinks.
items.default_editorial: With an artful eye and jazzy unpredictability, Kelly Reichardt unravels the threads of the heist film in this standout from Cannes. As an antihero kicking about on the brink of the ‘70s, Josh O’Connor is unmissable, lending rumpled discontent to this ironic, wry vision of American individualism.

items.title: The Match Factory Girl
items.short_synopsis: Iris is a shy young woman who leads a terribly dull life working at a match factory and living with her neglectful parents. She dreams of finding love at the local dance hall. But when Iris discovers she is pregnant after a one-night stand, years of pent-up rage explode in a shocking outburst.
items.default_editorial: The final part of his Proletariat Trilogy, The Match Factory Girl finds Aki Kaurismäki at his most stripped back. One of his greatest films, the bleak social realism soon takes a turn into viciously dark comedy, as Kati Outinen’s downtrodden protagonist wreaks revenge on her relentless persecutors.

items.title: The Modern Jungle
items.short_synopsis: A story of globalization filtered through the fever dream of a Mexican shaman, The Modern Jungle is also an intimate portrait of Zoque culture, commodity fetish, and the predicament of documentary.
items.default_editorial: The Modern Jungle highlights the ethical complexities of nonfiction filmmaking. What is the relationship between ethnographer and subject? What is owed and what is transacted? A daring project of documentation and uneasy exchange that explores the relationship between indigenous and Western culture.

items.title: The Myth of the American Sleepover
items.original_title: The Myth of the American Sleepover
items.short_synopsis: Four teenagers’ paths cross on the last night of summer before the school year starts. They explore the suburbs of Detroit in search of love and adventure–chasing first kisses, elusive crushes, popularity and parties–and discover the quiet moments that will later resonate as the best in their youth.
items.default_editorial: Moving and unsentimental, as well as starring a talented ensemble of nonprofessional actors, The Myth of the American Sleepover is the stellar debut feature from the enormously exciting emerging talent David Robert Mitchell, director of the critically-acclaimed 2014 horror It Follows.

items.title: The Nest of the Cuckoo Birds
items.original_title: The Nest of the Cuckoo Birds
items.short_synopsis: An undercover agent is sent to infiltrate bootleggers in the Florida Everglades, but winds up lost in the swamps and stuck in a decrepit hotel with a few of peculiar inhabitants. What starts off like a police actioner quickly morphs into an unholy fairy tale of Southern Gothic melodrama and horror.
items.default_editorial: Following a limited release, this mid-60s Southern Gothic melodrama disappeared into thin air but has since grown in cult status. A terrifying B-movie nightmare about deranged bootleggers, the film is suffused with a sinister mood, outré performances, and chilling, black-and-white imagery.

items.title: The Nile Hilton Incident
items.short_synopsis: Weeks before the Egyptian revolution, Noredin, a police officer in Cairo’s corrupt system, investigates the murder of a singer at a hotel club. What seems to be a crime of passion turns into something that concerns the elite of Egypt, forcing Noredin to break the rules in order to obtain justice.
items.default_editorial: Swedish filmmaker Tarik Saleh ventures out to Cairo for this impeccably executed noir, a tense political thriller set to the backdrop of the 2011 Egyptian revolution. Breakout star Fares Fares commands the screen as the compelling and unpredictable anti-hero of this Sundance prizewinner.

items.title: The Piano Teacher
items.short_synopsis: Erika, a piano teacher at the Vienna Conservatory, lives with her tyrannical mother in a hermetically sealed world of love-hate and dependency. Her sex life consists of voyeurism and masochistic self-injury. But when one of Erika’s students decides to seduce her, the barriers around her collapse.
items.default_editorial: The great Isabelle Huppert is the intensely smoldering center of this gripping tale of lust and obsession, which won Best Actress, Best Actor, and the Grand Prix at Cannes. One of Haneke’s most popular films, and one of the most incisive, disturbing and psychologically rich dramas of this century.

items.title: The Protagonists
items.short_synopsis: An actress takes an Italian film crew on a tour of London, recounting a senseless real-life murder that occurred just four years previous. The culprits were two upper-class teenagers from Oxford who traveled to London, driven by delusions with the intent to kill. The crew reconstructs the crime.
items.default_editorial: Long before Queer and Call Me By Your Name, Luca Guadagnino partnered with the one-and-only Tilda Swinton for his experimental debut feature. A surreal faux-documentary about a mysterious murder, this cinematic fever dream presciently taps into the current cultural obsession with true-crime dramas.

items.title: The Reconstruction
items.short_synopsis: In 1983 a fifteen-year-old boy was kidnapped and brutally murdered. Seventeen years later, the five men convicted still claim their innocence. This film follows the police investigation and juridical process using the original videotaped reconstructions of the murder performed by the defendants.
items.default_editorial: The independent and deeply incisive Israeli documentarian Avi Mograbi ignores the dramatic thrills to emphasize institutional procedure as he re-visits and re-imagines the scene of a terrible crime in this shocking documentary. Was justice served?

items.title: The Red Sea Makes Me Wanna Cry
items.original_title: The Red Sea Makes Me Wanna Cry
items.short_synopsis: A haunted woman named Ida journeys from Germany to Jordan, to an eerie and deserted port town on the Red Sea where her partner, Ismail, recently died. Wandering through desolate bars, hotels, and offices, Ida attempts to feel Ismail’s presence one last time and to say goodbye.
items.default_editorial: One of the first Jordanian films to premiere at Cannes, Faris Alrjoob’s beguiling short languidly drifts on the shifting tides of love and loss. At once eerie and sensuously pleasurable, sun-drenched frames are imprinted with the specter of grief, made achingly tangible on sumptuous 16mm film stock.

items.title: The Reluctant Revolutionary
items.short_synopsis: In Yemen, tour guide leader Kais offers reflections on loss, anger and hope during the build up to the Yemeni Revolution of 2011-12. Soon, Kais himself embarks on a journey from pro-president to reluctant revolutionary, joining angry protesters in the increasingly bloody streets of Sana’a.
items.default_editorial: Before the acutely moving A Syrian Love Story, Sean McAllister directed this surprising documentary, where he lucidly dissects the reality of Yemen amid the Arab Spring uprisings. An uncommon central character guides us through a simmering revolution.

items.title: The Sacrifice
items.short_synopsis: Alexander, a retired actor, is celebrating his birthday with family and friends when a TV announcement warns of an impending World War III and imminent nuclear catastrophe. Faced with an existential crisis, Alexander vows to renounce all he holds dear to prevent the disaster.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Grand Prix at the Cannes Film Festival, this shattering masterwork was the final film by Russian visionary Andrei Tarkovsky. Shot in Sweden by legendary cinematographer Sven Nykvist and newly restored in 4K, The Sacrifice is a profound metaphysical interrogation of the artistic soul.

items.title: The Second Game
items.short_synopsis: In 1988, one year before a revolution toppled Romania, a Bucharest football game between the country’s leading teams took place. It was refereed by the director’s father. The director and his father watch the match, their commentary accompanying the original television images in real-time.
items.default_editorial: Corneliu Porumboiu’s minimalist doc might feel as simple as chatting during a match, yet he creates a super-charged situation where audiences come to dissect the hidden meaning lurking behind the images. A captivating look at Romanian history, father-son relationships, and football.

items.title: The Snails
items.short_synopsis: A gardener tries his best to make his salad plants grow. It is only when he cries that his tears finally water the field and the salads grow huge. The incredible size attracts a multitude of snails that quickly become giant too, causing disasters and panic in the nearby city.
items.default_editorial: Before the legendary French animator René Laloux went to outer space with his psychedelic fantasia Fantastic Planet, he kept his feet firmly rooted in the soil in this charming—and award-winning!—short about snails. Exactly what will it take to make the poor farmer’s plants flourish?

items.title: The Swindle
items.short_synopsis: Betty and Victor, an ill-matched couple, tour around France living on part-time swindles. However, when naive financial courier Maurice stumbles into their web, they become involved in an international money laundering affair that might become their biggest score yet.
items.default_editorial: Chabrol’s fiftieth feature delivers two of the utmost cinematic pleasures: cunning scams and La Huppert double-crossing men in gorgeous outfits. Packed with off-kilter characters and dark humor, with a side of Hitchcockian perversity, this is a delicious milestone for the master of the genre film.

items.title: The Tango of the Widower and Its Distorting Mirror
items.original_title: El tango del viudo y su espejo deformante
items.short_synopsis: A man is haunted by the ghost of his wife, who appears everywhere he goes. Gradually, he starts to resemble her, spiraling into a chilling reality where we learn he was never married. Instead, it’s a psychological unraveling—a schizophrenic game of identity and illusion.
items.default_editorial: Originally intended to be Raúl Ruiz’s debut feature in 1967, this experimental drama was posthumously revived by Valeria Sarmiento through editing and dialogue reconstruction. The melancholic and the grotesque become strange bedfellows, as a haunted widower sinks into a whirlpool of hallucinations.

items.title: The Time Masters
items.short_synopsis: Piel, the young son of a space traveler, is left behind on the planet Perdide, where huge and hungry hornets roam. Jaffar, Piel’s father’s friend, abandons an important mission to rescue the child, with the help of an old sailor and two dwarves who communicate by telepathy.
items.default_editorial: While less well-known than Fantastic Planet, René Laloux’s second Stefan Wul adaptation is just as mind-bending. Illustrated by none other than the legendary cartoonist Mœbius, this mesmerizing rescue mission in a savage galaxy juxtaposes childhood innocence with the thrills of adventure.

items.title: The Times of Harvey Milk
items.short_synopsis: In 1977, Harvey Milk is elected to the San Francisco Board of Supervisors, becoming California’s first openly gay public official. This portrait of Milk showcases his neighborhood activist beginnings, his ascent as a symbol of gay political achievement, to his devastating assassination in 1978.
items.default_editorial: Made long before Gus Van Sant’s acclaimed biopic, but only 6 years after Milk’s murder, this documentary builds on TV footage and interviews to trace the life of the activist. A historical document bearing witness to the simultaneous liberalization and rampant homophobia of 1970s San Francisco.

items.title: The Towrope
items.short_synopsis: Alicia feels lost. The memory of war clings to her mind in a terrifying rumble. Thrown off her land by armed conflict, she tries to build a new life at ‘La Sirga’, a rundown boarding house on the shore of a large lagoon high up in the Andes mountain range.
items.default_editorial: Nature—in the form of vast mountainous regions of rural Colombia—figures as a central character in concert with the beguiling non-actor Joghis Seudin Arias in this haunting drama. Moving with patient and oneiric rhythms, this is a transfixing story of a people searching for a sense of home.

items.title: The Ugly One
items.short_synopsis: Winter, Beirut. On a beach littered with cans washed up from the sea, Lili and Michel meet. Perhaps they know each other from before. As they struggle to piece together the fragments of an uncertain past, memories emerge: an act of terrorism, an explosion and the disappearance of a child, Elena.
items.default_editorial: In Eric Baudelaire’s inspired collaboration with Masao Adachi—the notorious Japanese film director and member of the Red Army—a dislocation between sound and image gives shape to this impressionistic mosaic of infinite interpretations. Is it a love story? Or merely the wreckage of a revolution?

items.title: The Umbrellas of Cherbourg
items.short_synopsis: Geneviève, a young Frenchwoman who works in her mother’s small-town umbrella boutique, falls for dashing mechanic Guy. Their brief romance is interrupted when Guy is drafted to serve in the Algerian war. Pregnant, Geneviève has to choose between waiting for Guy or accepting an offer of marriage.
items.default_editorial: A candy-colored masterpiece that won the coveted Palme d’Or, Jacques Demy’s sung-through musical propelled Catherine Deneuve to international stardom. Dazzlingly romantic, Michel Legrand’s swooning score gorgeously evokes the youthful intensity of first love and the sweet pangs of romantic longing.

items.title: The Unheavenly Host
items.short_synopsis: Spiritualist Mrs. Drusse tricks the doctors into admitting her into the neurosurgery ward of the Kingdom hospital, where she discovers the sounds of a weeping child in the elevator shaft. Swedish consultant Dr. Helmer is confronted by the results of his sloppy work treating a brain-damaged patient.
items.default_editorial: Strange things are happening in the underbelly of a Danish hospital in Lars von Trier’s long unavailable cult TV phenomenon. Stunningly restored in never-before-seen versions, The Kingdom I is a wickedly funny supernatural mystery. Let the battle between good and evil commence!

series.title: The Kingdom

content_rating.label: mature
content_rating.description: Contains material and themes suitable only for mature audiences.

series.short_synopsis: Filmmaker Lars von Trier’s internationally acclaimed, cult classic series tells the story of a hospital built on top of the old bleaching ponds in Copenhagen, where evil has taken root and medical science faces a daily struggle with itself; where the Swedes curse the Danes, and the mysterious and inexplicable blend together in a mixture of horror and humor.
series.short_synopsis_html: Filmmaker Lars von Trier’s internationally acclaimed, cult classic series tells the story of a hospital built on top of the old bleaching ponds in Copenhagen, where evil has taken root and medical science faces a daily struggle with itself; where the Swedes curse the Danes, and the mysterious and inexplicable blend together in a mixture of horror and humor.
series.default_editorial: Director Lars von Trier’s magnum opus, The Kingdom is a TV phenomenon three decades in the making. A compulsively entertaining supernatural mystery, this incomparable blend of workplace comedy, potent melodrama, and nail-biting ghost story pitches science against superstition in unholy conflict.
series.default_editorial_html: Director Lars von Trier’s magnum opus, The Kingdom is a TV phenomenon three decades in the making. A compulsively entertaining supernatural mystery, this incomparable blend of workplace comedy, potent melodrama, and nail-biting ghost story pitches science against superstition in unholy conflict.

seasons.short_synopsis: Strange things are happening in the underbelly of a Danish hospital, where the ghost of a young girl cries in the elevator shaft, a phantom ambulance appears nightly, and secret societies meet in the basement. Tensions rise among staff, oblivious to the dark force awakening beneath the hospital.
seasons.short_synopsis_html: Strange things are happening in the underbelly of a Danish hospital, where the ghost of a young girl cries in the elevator shaft, a phantom ambulance appears nightly, and secret societies meet in the basement. Tensions rise among staff, oblivious to the dark force awakening beneath the hospital.
seasons.title: The Kingdom I
seasons.default_editorial: Strange things are happening in the underbelly of a Danish hospital in Lars von Trier’s long unavailable, cult TV phenomenon. Masterfully harmonizing mordant humor and poignant pathos, The Kingdom I is a wickedly funny occult mystery. Let the battle between good and evil commence!
seasons.default_editorial_html: Strange things are happening in the underbelly of a Danish hospital in Lars von Trier’s long unavailable, cult TV phenomenon. Masterfully harmonizing mordant humor and poignant pathos, The Kingdom I is a wickedly funny occult mystery. Let the battle between good and evil commence!

seasons.short_synopsis: The troubled Kingdom Hospital continues to be plagued by the rise of a greater evil. The motley crew of physicians and administrators continue to squabble among themselves, unaware of the profound evil rising from the bowels of the haunted Copenhagen hospital.
seasons.short_synopsis_html: The troubled Kingdom Hospital continues to be plagued by the rise of a greater evil. The motley crew of physicians and administrators continue to squabble among themselves, unaware of the profound evil rising from the bowels of the haunted Copenhagen hospital.
seasons.title: The Kingdom II
seasons.default_editorial: Leaning into the inimitably jagged style he had refined through the making of Breaking the Waves, Lars von Trier returns to enrich the mythologies of his TV phenomenon. Moving nimbly between exhilarating farce and poignant pathos, The Kingdom II ushers in the ultimate battle between good and evil.
seasons.default_editorial_html: Leaning into the inimitably jagged style he had refined through the making of Breaking the Waves, Lars von Trier returns to enrich the mythologies of his TV phenomenon. Moving nimbly between exhilarating farce and poignant pathos, The Kingdom II ushers in the ultimate battle between good and evil.

seasons.short_synopsis: Years after darkness first surfaced beneath Kingdom Hospital, sleepwalker Karen is drawn to the haunted Kingdom Hospital by a voice in a dream. As Christmas nears, she teams up with porter Balder and surgeon Judith to banish its evil spirits, unaware that new staff bring secrets of their own.
seasons.short_synopsis_html: Years after darkness first surfaced beneath Kingdom Hospital, sleepwalker Karen is drawn to the haunted Kingdom Hospital by a voice in a dream. As Christmas nears, she teams up with porter Balder and surgeon Judith to banish its evil spirits, unaware that new staff bring secrets of their own.
seasons.title: The Kingdom Exodus
seasons.default_editorial: The Kingdom Exodus is Denmark’s answer to Twin Peaks: The Return—at once enriching and recontextualizing what came before. Wielding nostalgia like a matador, Lars von Trier lures us with its comforts before pulling them away to reveal the moral quandaries on which the iconic hospital shakily stands.
seasons.default_editorial_html: The Kingdom Exodus is Denmark’s answer to Twin Peaks: The Return—at once enriching and recontextualizing what came before. Wielding nostalgia like a matador, Lars von Trier lures us with its comforts before pulling them away to reveal the moral quandaries on which the iconic hospital shakily stands.

items.title: The Valley Below
items.short_synopsis: Dividing four related narratives of hope and struggle into four self-contained vignettes, first-time feature director Kyle Thomas creates a Raymond Carver-esque portrait of life on the Alberta Badlands.
items.default_editorial: Director Kyle Thomas’s impressive debut may be small in scale but its weighs big on emotional ambition. With touching sensitivity, Thomas adeptly weaves together four intimate stories of lives that have reached breaking points, exploring the touchstones of family, community, love, and loss.

items.title: The Wandering Soap Opera
items.short_synopsis: In an alternate Chile, reality does not exist but rather is an ensemble of soap operas. A series of telenovela episodes sees actors—self-aware stars playing archetypal soap figures, including adulterers, femme fatales, and more—in increasingly absurd and fantastical situations.
items.default_editorial: Despite dying in 2011, Raúl Ruiz continues to make cinematic mischief. This comic and surreal pastiche of telenovelas was made during a fertile workshop Ruiz ran in 1990. Finished and restored by his wife and editor, Valeria Sarmiento, TV melodrama collides Ruiz’s fabulism and the era of Twin Peaks.

items.title: The War of the Worlds: Next Century
items.short_synopsis: Poland, Christmastime. A band of hyperintelligent, bloodthirsty martians take over the country and enlist hapless television newscaster Iron Ide as the voice of their propaganda machine. But when Iron dares to go off message, he makes an enemy even greater than the aliens—the state itself.
items.default_editorial: Pulled from the Cannes competition in the same year that Poland declared martial law, Piotr Szulkin’s tale of alien invasion is a blazing satire of the media machine. Dedicated to H.G. Wells and Orson Welles, this noir-inflected sci-fi is an eerily prescient interrogation of the fake-news era.

items.title: The Watchman
items.short_synopsis: Sergeant Bulut dutifully maintains a solitary guard atop a remote watchtower. Night after night, Bulut scans the horizon, awaiting an enemy that never materializes—until the sudden appearance of ghostly apparitions disrupts his routine.
items.default_editorial: Haunted by absences and uncanny visions, Ali Cherri’s eerie short soon slips from an atmosphere of suspense into a more surreal realm. Making potent use of nightmarish imagery, the acclaimed Lebanese visual artist crafts a poetic allegory for the absurdity of conflict with poignant force and care.

items.title: The Watermelon Woman
items.short_synopsis: Cheryl, an aspiring Black lesbian filmmaker working in a video store, is making a documentary about a black actress from the 1930s who was typecast, credited only as “the watermelon woman.” While uncovering the meaning of her life, Cheryl simultaneously experiences an upheaval in her own.
items.default_editorial: Groundbreaking in more ways than one, Cheryl Dunye’s autofiction work was the first feature to be directed by a Black lesbian filmmaker. A highlight of the ’90s New Queer Cinema, this joyous comedy wittily reflects, with contagious energy, on film history, representation, race relations, and desire.

items.title: The Wife Master
items.short_synopsis: 40-year-old Bora is gay, unemployed and lives at home. When his family kicks him out, he accepts his uncle’s offer to marry a Cambodian woman for $10,000 so she can come to the United States. When the money runs out, Bora gets another wife, then another… until he has more wives than he can handle.
items.default_editorial: Shot in a vérité style, this irreverent comedy about green card marriages sharply critiques the homophobic intolerance within the Cambodian community and the absurdities of the immigration system in the US. While dealing with hefty topics, the film’s riotous performances make for a delightful watch.

items.title: The Wonders
items.short_synopsis: An extraordinary summer for Gelsomina and her three younger sisters, in which the strict rules that hold the family together begin to break: due to the arrival of Martin, a German boy on a youth rehabilitation program, and also the community’s participation in the TV competition “Village Wonders.”
items.default_editorial: Between Corpo Celeste & Happy as Lazzaro, writer-director Alice Rohrwacher won the Grand Prix at the Cannes Film Festival for this, her sophomore feature. An intelligent, impeccable family drama that parallels adolescence and the tension between tradition and modernity—featuring Monica Bellucci!

items.title: The Young Girls of Rochefort
items.short_synopsis: Twins Delphine and Solange dream of getting out of their small hometown Rochefort to find love and fortune in the big city. As they plan to leave, both are hired as carnival singers. Over the course of one weekend, Solange falls for American musician Andy, while Delphine searches for her ideal man.
items.default_editorial: This finale in Jacques Demy’s romantic musical trilogy is sparkling and spellbinding: buoyed by the marvelous combination of Catherine Deneuve and real-life sister Françoise Dorléac, and one such American in Paris, Gene Kelly. A film of many moving parts, all dreamily put together.

items.title: This Closeness
items.short_synopsis: In Philadelphia for the weekend, Tessa and Ben, a couple on the rocks, rent a room in the apartment of Adam, a reclusive stranger who quickly becomes an unwilling voyeur to the most private parts of the couple’s life. Tensions rise as the three enter an intimate battle to gain and reclaim territory.
items.default_editorial: Intimacy is brilliantly weaponized in this standout film from American rising star Kit Zauhar. Assembling a chamber drama with staggering performances and bruising humor, she twists space and sound into battle zones of emotion where closeness is at once bitter and erotic, touching and barbed.

items.title: Time to Love
items.short_synopsis: On the Princes’ Islands to the south of Istanbul, the days are rainy and full of longing. Poor but proud painter Halil gets a job in one of the island’s villas, where he encounters the photograph of a beautiful woman and falls in love with her image.
items.default_editorial: For MUBI’s first-ever restoration project, we are thrilled to present Metin Erksan’s unsung masterwork, an achingly gorgeous love story inspired by Sufi tales. Imbued with a longing for self-actualization amid modern loneliness, this mercurial wonder evokes the fatal idealism of cross-class romance.

items.title: Toni Erdmann
items.short_synopsis: Prankster Winfried doesn’t see much of his estranged, high-powered consultant daughter Ines, who lives in Bucharest. One day, he decides to surprise her with a visit, but this brings tension as Ines is working on an important project. To enter her corporate life, Winfried creates a fictional alias.
items.default_editorial: Sandra Hüller is the burned-out straightwoman to one of cinema’s funniest dads in Maren Ade’s Oscar®-nominated comedy. Tangling hilarious—and absurdly hairy!—gags into the serious business of post-crash Europe, this unpredictable film tickles the heart with sudden moments of unbuttoned emotion.

items.title: Toomas Beneath the Valley of the Wild Wolves
items.original_title: Toomas Beneath the Valley of the Wild Wolves
items.short_synopsis: After losing a well-paid engineering job, Toomas, a young hot wolf, gets cornered into working as a gigolo to support his family. He keeps it a secret from his pregnant wife, Viivi. However Viivi also has a secret—she is attending a female empowerment seminar involving male slaves.
items.default_editorial: Can wolves ever be tamed? This unpredictable short suggests that some creatures are happier embracing the wilderness within. Undermining strict gender norms with audacious humor, this provocative film smuggles daring sexual politics into delicate, pastel-colored animation.

items.title: Total Balalaika Show
items.short_synopsis: June, 1993. Helsinki. Over 50,000 people witness the Aki Kaurismäki-formed rock group, Leningrad Cowboys, performing with 100 singers, 40 musicians, and 20 dancers from the Alexandrov Red Army Chorus and Dance Ensemble. From start to finish, the concert is a roaring success.
items.default_editorial: With two movies, a handful of shorts, and a healthy discography under their belts, there was only one thing left on the Leningrad Cowboys’ bucket list: to go on tour. Across an hour of outlandish rock ‘n’ roll covers, Aki Kaurismäki’s raucous concert film captures the band in all their loopy glory.

items.title: Totally F***ed Up
items.short_synopsis: In ’90s Los Angeles, a group of queer, disaffected teenagers form a kind of makeshift family as they navigate love, rejection, and identity. Through a series of fragmented episodes, they confront the harsh realities of adolescence in a world that refuses to accept them.
items.default_editorial: Edgy and raw with emotion, Gregg Araki’s fragmented portrait of queer teens in 1990s California captures their ennui with the lo-fi fuzz of color video. Numbing pangs of existential angst and loneliness with alternative music, hot sex, and sharp wit, these disenchanted kids rebel with good cause.

items.title: Touch of Crude
items.short_synopsis: A woman moves into a new house. As she explores this empty and eerie space, she encounters a mysterious entity—a Black Box. When she peers through its peephole, the woman unlocks access to multiple universes, each viewed from the perspective of a different woman.
items.default_editorial: Nicolas Winding Refn taps into fashion’s power to suggest strange and enticing worlds in this advert created for Prada. Influenced by the experimental cinema of Kenneth Anger and with hints of Lynchian surrealism, this enigmatic film conjures up an atmosphere that lies between danger and sensuality.

items.title: Toxic
items.short_synopsis: Dreaming of escape from the bleakness of their industrial Lithuanian hometown, two thirteen-year-olds, Marija and Kristina, form a unique bond at a local modeling school. But the promise of a better life pushes girls to violate their bodies in increasingly extreme ways.
items.default_editorial: A Locarno prizewinner, Saulė Bliuvaitė’s debut feature is as unsparing as measuring tape and as sharp as high heels. Looking at an exploitative fashion industry through the gaze of determined teenagers, Toxic is a visually striking portrait of girls zigzagging between competition and friendship.

items.title: Train Again
items.short_synopsis: In Train Again, Peter Tscherkassky condenses the long history of railways in the movies into a rousing blast for the senses, created in heartfelt tribute to another local legend of experimental cinema, Kurt Kren (1929-1988).
items.default_editorial: Set to the relentless industrial rumble of train tracks and film leader, the latest film from the Austrian master of the avant-garde mounts a frenetic, flash-framed tribute to early cinema’s love affair with trains. All aboard a phantasmagoric journey into the flickering mechanics of moving images!

items.title: Tram
items.short_synopsis: Every day, a tram conductor shuttles silent, identical men to work. As the ride begins, the rhythm of tickets punching stirs her desires, and the tram takes on a life of its own. Her arousal transforms the mundane journey into a surreal, phallic fantasy.
items.default_editorial: Making playful use of repetition to build an increasingly lively, jazzy tempo, this prize-winning short keeps time with its protagonist’s mounting satisfaction. Distracting her from work, her idle fantasizing lifts the film from the mundane into gleefully psychedelic imagery.

items.title: Tripping With Nils Frahm
items.short_synopsis: An iconic artist at an iconic location. This concert film captures several mesmerizing live performances from the renowned German composer and producer Nils Frahm at the legendary Funkhaus Berlin. Expect soaring ambient and neo-classical piano from one of the greatest contemporary musicians around.
items.default_editorial: Renowned composer Nils Frahm is no stranger to cinema, having scored Sebastian Schipper’s one-shot film Victoria and the Cate Blanchett vehicle Manifesto. For this immersive concert film, his intimate and enthralling shows are captured on handheld cameras, centering us amid a unique experience.

items.title: Trouble Every Day
items.short_synopsis: Shane and June Brown are an American couple honeymooning in Paris in an effort to nurture their new life together, a life complicated by Shane’s mysterious and frequent visits to a medical clinic where cutting edge studies of the human libido are undertaken.
items.default_editorial: One of the luminaries of the contemporary arthouse, Claire Denis makes her own version of a vampire tale in this elliptical, sensual film of disease and desire. Loaded with mystery and tactility, Trouble Every Day stars Béatrice Dalle and Vincent Gallo with an intense score by Tindersticks.

items.title: Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me
items.original_title: Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me
items.short_synopsis: While investigating the mysterious death of a nightshift waitress, Special Agents Chester Desmond and Dale Cooper unravel bizarre clues and mysterious disappearances in the peaceful town of Twin Peaks. This leads them to the last seven days of Laura Palmer’s troubled life, and ultimately the killer.
items.default_editorial: Once derided and now revered as the key to all Twin Peaks mythologies, this crucial prequel/sequel to David Lynch’s iconic TV series resurrects the late Laura Palmer to reveal her harrowing final days. A surreal psychological horror, made all-too disturbingly real by its remarkable star Sheryl Lee.

items.title: Twin Peaks: The Missing Pieces
items.short_synopsis: Twin Peaks before Twin Peaks and, at the same time, not always and entirely in the same place as Twin Peaks: Fire Walk with Me. An hour and a half of deleted scenes and alternate takes from the series prequel continue to tell the story of the final week of Laura Palmer’s life.
items.default_editorial: Delve deeper into the scandalous mysteries of Twin Peaks: Fire Walk With Me with this mesmerizing collection of outtakes from David Lynch’s febrile masterwork. At once a companion piece and an oneiric, standalone feature, The Missing Pieces enriches the dark mythologies of a pop-cultural phenomenon.

items.title: Two Shots Fired
items.short_synopsis: Mariano, 16, inexplicably and without warning, shoots himself twice and improbably survives. Then, life goes on. His brother pursues a romance with a girl working at a fast-food joint, his mother takes off on a trip with a stranger, and Mariano recruits a woman to join his medieval wind ensemble.
items.default_editorial: Martín﻿ Rejtman’s comeback 11 years after The Magic Gloves did not disappoint. Taking a suicide attempt as the starting point and surprising us at every turn, the film is a fascinating and subversive exercise in comedy: its sophisticated storytelling, dark humor and deadpan beauty are just genius.

items.title: Un Film Dramatique
items.short_synopsis: For four years Éric Baudelaire regularly met with students from the film group at Dora Maar middle school in Saint-Denis. Time for them to grow together, time to find the form of a film in which they would be the true subjects: its characters, its authors and its promise.
items.default_editorial: In a beautiful act of collective creation, Eric Baudelaire shares the director’s chair with twenty schoolchildren in Un film dramatique. The result? A kaleidoscope of spontaneous self-representation, an ode to both subjectivity and collaboration movingly exploring the possibilities of cinema.

items.title: Unclenching the Fists
items.short_synopsis: Ada is stuck. Living in a dead-end industrial town in North Ossetia, she is a young woman caught in the grip of the domineering men in her life. But when her older brother returns home and her tyrannical father suddenly falls ill, Ada finally sees a possible path to freedom.
items.default_editorial: The winner of Cannes’s Un Certain Regard award in 2021 is the visceral story of a young woman’s struggle to free herself from the grip of her father—and the patriarchy with it. With the intensity of a thriller, this stirring feminist portrait announces a tremendous talent in director Kira Kovalenko.

items.title: Unrelated
items.short_synopsis: Discontented, 40-something Anna decides to spend her summer holiday apart from her husband, in Tuscany with friends. As the days go by, she finds herself more attuned to their teenage children, gravitating towards Oakley. Sexual tensions simmer and Anna believes she has found a second chance.
items.default_editorial: Joanna Hogg, one of Britain’s best directors, transitioned with this film from working in television to a new, completely unpredictable career in cinema. A penetrating and carefully balanced examination of the class that can vacation in Italy, starring Tom Hiddleston.

items.title: Vagabond
items.short_synopsis: In the south of France, during winter, a young drifter named Mona is found frozen to death in a ditch. Through flashbacks, those who have met her—including a Tunisian vineyard worker and a family of goat farmers—talk of their interactions, revealing the story of an enigmatic and defiant woman.
items.default_editorial: A classic in Varda’s filmography, this film is as uncompromising in its portrayal of a woman who will not adjust as it is in its daring story structure. Winner of the Golden Lion in Venice, it is both a testimony to the director’s profound humanism and to her critical eye on our social judgments.

items.title: Vanaja
items.short_synopsis: Vanaja, the 15 year old daughter of a financially troubled fisherman goes to work in the local landlady’s house in hopes of learning Kuchipudi dance. She does well, but when the Landlady’s son returns from the US, what begins as innocent sexual chemistry turns ugly.
items.default_editorial: Shot in India’s rural south with a cast of nonprofessionals, this beautiful drama from Rajnesh Domalpalli evokes the melodic majesty of Satyajit Ray’s immortal classic The Music Room. With its vibrant colors and dazzling dance sequences, Vanaja is an exquisitely textured portrait of village life.

items.title: Vice Is Broke
items.short_synopsis: Chef, author, and host Eddie Huang traces the wild rise and fall of Vice Media—from a scrappy alt-punk zine in ’90s Montreal to a global media empire worth $5.7 billion. Along the way, he meets key insiders to unpack how the powerhouse of the indie sleaze era burned bright—and crashed hard.
items.default_editorial: With investigative zeal, VICE alumnus Eddie Huang dives into his former employer’s lawless archives to uncover where it all went wrong. Smoking out tales of legit highs and unholy lows, this gonzo documentary eyeballs the timely comeuppance of a pop-cultural behemoth that flew too close to the sun.

items.title: Waging War
items.short_synopsis: Seven cousins find themselves for the last time in the house of their childhood. While they are bored, they find the suitcase preserving the disguises in which they used to dress-up in to play when they were children. They decide to throw for the last time a game of Waging War.
items.default_editorial: In this idiosyncratic black-and-white short, boiling grownup tensions and philosophical woes suddenly find a chaotic release in the form of therapeutic child play. The freewheeling cinematography emulates the emotional catharsis and clarity made possible by adults learning to be kids again.

items.title: Walk the Walk
items.short_synopsis: Previously lost, this is a sordid psychedelic saga starring Bernie Hamilton (brother of jazz drummer, Chico) as a desperate junkie trawling the L.A. hippie rock underground, and produced by the notorious carny barker of exploitation films, Kroger Babb.
items.default_editorial: Restored from its only surviving print materials, this semi-autobiographical debut from director Jac Zacha offers a jagged ride through the drug underground of the 1970s. With the stoner wilds of psychedelic Los Angeles as the main backdrop, Walk the Walk is a bizarre yet elegantly shot swan song.

items.title: We Are the Flesh
items.short_synopsis: A young brother and sister, roaming an apocalyptic city, take refuge in the lair of a strange hermit. He puts them to work building a bizarre cavernous structure, where he acts out his depraved fantasies. Trapped, they find themselves sinking into the realms of dark and forbidden behaviour.
items.default_editorial: Channeling cinema’s provocateur-in-chief, Gaspar Noé, Emiliano Rocha Minter’s outrageous debut feature plays brinkmanship with boundaries in a post-apocalyptic bonfire of taboos. Infernal visuals sear the eyes, but it is the committedly wild lead performances which brand the brain.

items.title: We Can't Go Home Again
items.short_synopsis: Retired from Hollywood, Nicholas Ray is teaching in upstate New York, schooling lively students on the process of making a feature collaboratively. Together they experiment with narrative and multiple images, and in front of the camera, the group reflect on politics, identity, and filmmaking.
items.default_editorial: Not one to be dulled by age, Nicholas Ray (the maverick behind Johnny Guitar and Rebel Without a Cause) came to Cannes in 1973 with a cut of his most experimental film yet, a radical, impassioned journey into American chaos. This avant-garde swansong is now open to all, restored in HD!

items.title: We're All Going to the World's Fair
items.original_title: We're All Going to the World's Fair
items.short_synopsis: In her attic bedroom, smalltown teenager Casey joins an online role-playing horror game. As she becomes absorbed, she begins to record herself, documenting strange shifts that blur the line between imagination and reality.
items.default_editorial: Take a tumble down the rabbit holes of internet culture with this uncanny coming-of-age tale from director Jane Schoenbrun. Skirting the boundaries of horror, We’re All Going to the World’s Fair is a nerve-shredding fever dream of collective psychosis from the dark heart of the online zeitgeist.

items.title: Wetlands
items.short_synopsis: Helen is a nonconformist teenage girl who maintains a conflictual relationship with her parents. Hanging out most of her time with her friend Corinna, with whom she breaks one social taboo after another, she uses sex as a way to rebel and break the conventional bourgeois ethic.
items.default_editorial: Based on an autobiographical erotic novel of the same name, this unabashedly fleshy, raunchy film of a capricious adolescence stays true to its viscous title: the “wetlands” are those of an abject femininity on colorfully itchy, sticky display and embodied excellently by the lead actor.

items.title: What Do We See When We Look at the Sky?
items.short_synopsis: In the Georgian riverside town of Kutaisi, summertime romance and World Cup fever are in the air. After a pair of chance encounters, pharmacist Lisa and soccer player Giorgi find their plans for a date undone when they both awaken magically transformed—with no way to recognize each other.
items.default_editorial: An enchanting love story suffused with magic, this amiably ambling fable is fit-to-burst with hope and wonder. Alexandre Koberidze’s generous ode to romance wanders the sun-dappled streets of Georgia’s ancient Kutaisi with open arms, inviting its inhabitants—and their mysteries—into a warm embrace.

items.title: White Ant
items.original_title: 白蟻─慾望謎網 | Báiyǐ ─yùwàng mí wǎng
items.short_synopsis: Bai Yide is a young man living alone. He works at a bookstore and derives sexual pleasure by stealing and wearing women’s underwear. One day, he receives a DVD in which his activities have been recorded and he becomes anxious.
items.default_editorial: Three alluring, disparate characters shape this elliptical story, which faces the many complexities of sexuality amongst alienated youth in contemporary Taiwan. Director Chu Hsien-che’s approach is considerate and acutely stylized in its brave confrontation of challenging subject matter.

items.title: White Turnips Make It Hard to Sleep
items.original_title: Les navets blancs empêchent de dormir
items.short_synopsis: 1. Find a reassuring explanation for a bout of sleeplessness: the eating of white turnips; 2. Observe the mechanisms of passion; 3. Escape inadequate ideas. It’s the story of a breakup.
items.default_editorial: The authenticity of Salomé Richard’s performances is one of the main reasons for the extraordinary emotional reach of this triptych. White Turnips sees Ana trapped in a fading relationship, gradually coming to terms with the idea of letting go. A delicate and truthful chronicle of a death foretold.

items.title: Wild Guitar
items.short_synopsis: Bud Eagle, an aspiring teen pop singer, lands in L.A. to try and make it big. But when he is given a shot by Mike McCauley, the crooked owner of a small record company, Bud soon finds himself swallowed up by the evils of showbiz.
items.default_editorial: Ray Dennis Steckler made his directorial debut with this surfer rock-scored, Elvis-inspired B-movie about an aspiring musician’s sudden success. Swerving between Faustian fable, pop comedy and music industry parody, it features the early work of Oscar®-winning cinematographer Vilmos Zsigmond!

items.title: Winter Boy
items.short_synopsis: 17-year-old Lucas is drifting through his last year of boarding school until the sudden death of his father strips away everything he took for granted. Left filled with anger and despair, he visits his older brother in Paris seeking comfort in the new city.
items.default_editorial: Christophe Honoré returns to his timeless themes of family, mortality, and sexuality in a gay coming-of-age story imbued with breathtaking poignancy. As a teenager trying to make sense of grief, newcomer Paul Kircher is devastatingly good—and shares the screen with none other than Juliette Binoche.

items.title: Winter House
items.short_synopsis: Mario Bellatín is a one-armed Mexican writer with an amazing vitality; even when he says that he is already dead, and even when he writes auto-biographical texts where his own name perishes and is replaced by a heteronym who still recognizes himself as his own ghost.
items.default_editorial: Argentine director Gonzalo Castro manages to capture the beauty of everyday life in this experimental portrait of the one-armed Mexican novelist (and ultimate prankster!) Mario Bellatín. Just like Bellatín’s fiction, the film treads a fine line between “truth” and “fiction”—wait, is the joke on us?

items.title: Witches
items.short_synopsis: Director Elizabeth Sankey explores the connections between postpartum mental health and the portrayal of witches in Western society and popular culture. Sankey intertwines her personal experiences with historical and cinematic footage—while creating a new coven of women to reclaim their stories.
items.default_editorial: Witches are figures of solace in this intimate documentary, which unravels the social stigmas that women have endured across centuries. Between affecting interviews and vividly illustrative film clips, Elizabeth Sankey concocts a potion that brims with courage, compassion, and healing insight.

items.title: With Blood on My Hands: Pusher II
items.short_synopsis: Tonny, just released from prison, tries to bring order to his life and gain the respect of his father, the Duke, a notorious gangster who despises his son. Trying to repay a debt held over from prison, he makes misstep after misstep. What’s more, Tonny must contribute to the upbringing of a child.
items.default_editorial: Following his memorable supporting turn in the first Pusher film, Mads Mikkelsen moves center stage for this adrenalized sequel. Refn’s tale of fathers and sons is once again filtered through the fatalistic prism of noir, albeit this time with a nightmarish agenda that borders on the surreal.

items.title: Within Our Gates
items.short_synopsis: Sylvia Landry, a teacher at a school for impoverished black children in the Deep South, takes a fundraising trip to Boston upon learning that the institution is nearly bankrupt. There she meets Dr. Vivian, who travels back south with Sylvia after falling in love with her.
items.default_editorial: One of the earliest surviving works of African-American filmmaking, Oscar Micheaux’s remarkable drama offers a vivid tapestry of the intricacies of the Black experience. A pioneering independent director, Micheaux’s mesmerizing vision acts as a gut-punching indictment of systemic racism in America.

items.title: Woman Is the Future of Man
items.short_synopsis: The first snow has fallen over Seoul. Munho, a young art professor, is catching up with his friend Hunjoon, a broke filmmaker who has just returned from the United States. After a few drinks, they decided to track down Sunhwa, a woman they were both in love with a few years earlier.
items.default_editorial: Stark sexual encounters and digressive alcoholic afternoons punctuate Hong Sang-soo’s fifth feature, a mosaic of different moments that trace the tangle of a love triangle between friends. Each scene unfolds with a candid lightness, thanks to the measured touch of the South Korean auteur.

items.title: Women Reply: Our Bodies, Our Sex
items.original_title: Réponse de femmes: Notre corps, notre sexe
items.short_synopsis: What does being a woman really mean? How do women live the status society reserves for them? To such questions posed by a television station, a group of women filmmakers, beautiful or not, young or not, gifted with motherly instinct or not, answer before Agnès Varda’s camera.
items.default_editorial: Posed the question “What is a woman?,” Agnès Varda responds with this provocative, polemical short film — encapsulating an argument propounded in second-wave feminism, after Simone de Beauvoir’s Manifeste des 343, and after the campaign for legalized abortion in France.

items.title: Working Girls
items.short_synopsis: Photographer Molly works part-time in a Manhattan brothel. Over one day, she juggles a stream of clients while nurturing relationships with her coworkers and satisfying her ambitious madam. In a trade where the personal and the professional easily blur, Molly fights to maintain her sense of self.
items.default_editorial: Where dominant culture was salacious and judgmental, Lizzie Borden desensationalized sex work with a feminist film of wit and radical warmth. Immersed in the mundane details and rhythms of labor—bad bosses, long hours—Borden’s clear-cut images strike with vital realism in a lucid restoration.

items.title: Yannick
items.short_synopsis: On a rare night off, parking attendant Yannick goes to the theater to catch a production of the comedy The Cuckold. Dissatisfied by the boring performance, Yannick hijacks the show: he takes the theater hostage and demands to become the playwright.
items.default_editorial: In this hilarious satire, social contracts are broken and hackneyed forms of entertainment are upended. Corralling a brilliant cast into a boisterous deconstruction of actors’ egos and audience expectations, Quentin Dupieux revels in the insights of an outsider in his latest meta-provocation.

items.title: You Are Here
items.short_synopsis: A fantasy about a reclusive woman who searches for meaning in the mysterious documents that keep appearing to her, turning her home into an archive. As realities collapse and intersect around here, she must make a final choice: is she a free agent, or just a tool of the archive?
items.default_editorial: Daniel Cockburn’s auspicious debut is one of the smartest and most ambitious of the decade, marking the Canadian video artist as a true emerging talent in cinema. A dazzlingly puzzling exploration of detection and consciousness, its clever approach has drawn comparisons to Borges and Inception.

items.title: You Hide Me
items.short_synopsis: Buried deep in the basement of the British Museum, hidden in plastic bags and wooden boxes, lies a wealth of ancient and rare African artifacts. Over one day, the valuable objects are unveiled for the first time, revealing the vast expanse of African art stolen by colonial forces.
items.default_editorial: Banned for anti-British sentiment even in recently liberated Ghana, this short casts essential light on African art’s histories of circulation and exhibition. Illuminating the myriad hypocrisies of colonial forces, Nii Kwate Owoo’s radical show-and-tell unambiguously calls for immediate restitution.

items.title: Yuki's Sun
items.original_title: ユキの太陽 | Yuki no taiyō
items.short_synopsis: Left on an orphanage’s doorstep as a baby, young Yuki leads a happy, free-spirited life in the beautiful countryside of Hokkaido. But, one day, she gets adopted, and everything changes.
items.default_editorial: Thirteen years before beloved animator Hayao Miyazaki co-founded Studio Ghibli, he made a miniature pilot for an ultimately unmade TV series. Brisk but completely delightful, this five-minute short is an early example of his incredible talent in compassionate storytelling and vivid world-building.

items.title: Zama
items.short_synopsis: An 18th-century Spanish magistrate is eternally languishing in anticipation for a transfer from the outpost to which he has been relegated. When his last hope of departure comes to naught, he joins an expedition to track down Vicuña Porto, a legendary outlaw who may or may not exist.
items.default_editorial: In an ingenious adaptation of the existentialist novel Zama, Argentine auteur Lucrecia Martel inserts her own incisive commentary on colonialism and masculinity. Frenzied first-person narration transforms to become a cinematic fugue state in this singular and stupefying period drama.

items.short_synopsis: Chow Mo-Wan was a writer. He thought he wrote about the future but it really was the past. In his novel, a mysterious train left for 2046 every once in a while. Everyone who went there had the same intention: to recapture their lost memories. It was said that in 2046, nothing ever changed.
items.default_editorial: Forming a loose trilogy with Days of Being Wild and In the Mood for Love, Wong Kar Wai’s series of romantic dramas culminates in this sweeping, time-traveling epic. A film of ravishing visual grandeur and incredible ambition, 2046 offers a wistfully bittersweet look at love and loneliness.

items.title: About Love
items.short_synopsis: Three generations of the Phadke family live and work together in South Mumbai. As they prepare for a family wedding, director Archana Atul Phadke, who is not in any hurry to marry, observes the shifting, often very funny household dynamics.
items.default_editorial: Armed with an honest approach and a handheld camera, filmmaker Archana Phadke paints a moving portrait of her multi-generational family. An earnest tribute to the affection that binds families, About Love is sharp in its observations on the patriarchal structures that define women’s domestic lives.

items.title: Aftersun
items.short_synopsis: At a fading vacation resort, 11-year-old Sophie treasures rare time together with her loving and idealistic father, Calum. Twenty years later, Sophie’s tender recollections of their last holiday become a powerful and heartrending portrait of their relationship.
items.default_editorial: Oscar®-nominated Paul Mescal and newcomer Frankie Corio are unforgettable as a dad and daughter abroad in Charlotte Wells’s moving debut. Revealing the laughs, heartache and tenderness of a trip that means more with each passing moment, Aftersun captures a family snapshot of astonishing poignancy.

items.title: Against the Tide
items.short_synopsis: Two friends, both Indigenous fishermen, are driven to desperation by a dying sea. Their friendship begins to fracture as they take very different paths to provide for their struggling families.
items.default_editorial: Sarvnik Kaur’s nuanced look at the maritime lives of two Koli men is a poignant tale of friendship, sustained amid economic and ecological crises. Winner of the Special Jury Award at Sundance in 2023, this powerful observational documentary is an environmental wake-up call for us all.

items.title: And, Towards Happy Alleys
items.short_synopsis: A passionate declaration of love for the cinema and poetry of Iran, which also offers a frank view of the precarious situation for critics of the regime and shows the uncompromising daily struggle of Iranian women against their oppression.
items.default_editorial: This warm look at the struggle of women, artists, and political dissidents in Iran is also a moving personal journey for its director. Sreemoyee Singh’s encounters with figures such as filmmaker Jafar Panahi and human rights lawyer Nasrin Sotoudeh form a poetic tribute to their spirit and culture.

items.title: April
items.short_synopsis: Nina, an obstetrician-gynecologist working in the only hospital of a provincial town in Georgia, is unconditionally devoted to her patients, even if that means crossing the line legally or socially. But after she is accused of negligence, she will be forced to question her choices.
items.default_editorial: Storm clouds darken fields of rapeseed and livestock shrink from torchlight in Dea Kulumbegashvili’s unblinking second feature, named after the cruelest month. Resolutely formalist in its depiction of moral courage, April reckons with male violence and salvific endings in the season of new life.

items.title: Ashes of Time Redux
items.short_synopsis: In ancient China, on the edge of a vast desert, swordsman Ouyang Feng lives the life of a vagabond, controlling a network of assassins. Pitiless, his heart has long been wounded by a love he neglected then lost. But as seasons, friends and enemies come and go, he reflects back upon his solitude.
items.default_editorial: For his most ambitious project to date, Wong Kar Wai brought his languid rhythms and poetic modes of action to the wuxia genre. With ravishing cinematography by Christopher Doyle and an all-star cast of Hong Kong greats, this Redux cut from 2008 re-established the film as a martial-arts classic.

items.title: Benedetta
items.short_synopsis: A scandalous lesbian affair rocks a quiet convent in 17th century Tuscany. Benedetta, a nun visited by increasingly sensual and violent visions of Jesus, arouses the suspicions of abbess Sister Felicita. Distrust grows when new arrival Bartolomea develops a dangerous attraction for Benedetta.
items.default_editorial: From showgirls to nuns: the latest sensation from the king of erotic thrillers immerses us in the religious visions and illicit desires of a 17th-century mystic abbess. Sensual, elegant and scandalous, Benedetta offers up a perversely provocative critique of religious hypocrisy.

items.title: Certified Copy
items.short_synopsis: While touring Tuscany, Italy, promoting his new book, English author James meets French store owner Elle, and the two hit it off, deciding to spend a free day together. As these two strangers get to know each other, however, it becomes clear there’s more to their new relationship than meets the eye.
items.default_editorial: Abbas Kiarostami’s first feature made outside his native Iran is this sumptuous, brain-teasing romance, in which a deceptively simple relationship morphs into something more complex—and keeps the audience guessing. Cannes winner Juliette Binoche is enigmatic, vulnerable and perfect in the lead role.

items.title: Chaityabhumi
items.short_synopsis: Chaityabhumi, where Dr. B. R. Ambedkar’s last rites were held, holds vital significance for the Dalit community. This musical film captures the December 6 commemoration, witnessing how the community honours the day and the political relevance it holds for their identity in contemporary India.
items.default_editorial: A thought-provoking meditation on Dalit resistance, memory, and belonging, Chaityabhumi is a moving record of Dr. B. R. Ambedkar’s inspiring legacy. Observational in style, the documentary tenderly places the community’s pride and joy at the center of its cultural and political expression.

items.title: Chungking Express
items.original_title: Chung Hing sam Iam | 重慶森林
items.short_synopsis: In Hong Kong, two lovelorn and lonely police officers cross paths with two mysterious women. Cop 223 falls for a mysterious woman in a blonde wig, not knowing she is a big-time heroin smuggler. Meanwhile, Cop 663 visits a late-night diner, and the new server becomes secretly infatuated with him.
items.default_editorial: Shot in just 23 days while making Ashes of Time, Wong Kar Wai’s international breakthrough remains among the most beloved of his pictures. From Brigitte Lin, iconic in bleached wig and shades to Faye Wong’s California dreams, it blushes with reasons to fall for its hurtling, newly restored charms.

items.title: Close
items.short_synopsis: Thirteen-year-olds Leo and Remi are inseparable; they spend every waking moment together, playing in the flower fields and sleeping at each other’s houses. However as they start a new school year, the pressures of early adolescence challenge their bond with unexpected and far-reaching consequences.
items.default_editorial: Both a Cannes prizewinner and Oscar® nominee for Best International Film, the exquisitely acted Close evokes the fragile beauty of boyhood. Set among the flower fields of the Belgian countryside, Lukas Dhont’s profoundly empathetic look at adolescent intimacy reveals the trappings of masculinity.

items.title: Cow
items.short_synopsis: A portrait of the life of a dairy cow called Luma, this observational documentary unflinchingly chronicles its subject’s daily life, from grazing in green fields to giving birth, making milk and everything in between.
items.default_editorial: An astonishingly singular feat of sensorial cinema, Andrea Arnold’s first foray into nonfiction filmmaking finds yet another indelible heroine in Luma, a dairy cow. Resounding with transformative empathy for the inner lives of animals, this powerful documentary wears its loving heart on its sleeve.

items.title: Dancer in the Dark
items.short_synopsis: Selma, a migrant single mother in rural America, is slowly going blind. While daydreaming about the musicals she adores, she works endless shifts at a factory, saving up for an operation that will save her son’s eyesight. But when a neighbor accuses Selma of stealing his savings, tragedy strikes.
items.default_editorial: The ultimate postmodern musical, von Trier’s quirky genre hybrid hinges on a ravishing performance by Icelandic pop star Björk, which makes the most of her innocent vitality. This idiosyncratic fantasy and overpowering tearjerker took home the Palme d’Or at Cannes, along with Best Actress for Björk!

items.title: Dawson City: Frozen Time
items.short_synopsis: Using archival footage to tell the story, Dawson City: Frozen Time pieces together the bizarre true history of a collection of some 500 films dating from 1910s-1920s, which were lost for over 50 years until being discovered buried in a sub-arctic swimming pool deep in the Yukon Territory in 1978.
items.default_editorial: A history lesson had never been so mesmerizing! This wondrous work of cinematic excavation by Bill Morrison is an archival odyssey into the abyss of capitalism. The documentary is an exquisite ode to the materiality of celluloid and a political and poetic act of resistance in the digital age.

items.title: Dr. B. R. Ambedkar: Now & Then
items.original_title: Dr. B. R. Ambedkar: Now & Then
items.short_synopsis: Through the discerning lens of a Bahujan feminist filmmaker operating within the upper-caste Indian film industry, the film delves deep into critical themes of liberty, equality, fraternity, social justice, exclusion, and marginalised representation.
items.default_editorial: Anchored in Ambedkarite thought, Jyoti Nisha’s formally radical documentary boldly critiques caste representation in Indian media. Blending animation, interviews, and personal footage, the film draws a compelling arc from historical injustice to contemporary resistance and identity assertion.

items.title: Drive My Car
items.original_title: ドライブ・マイ・カー
items.short_synopsis: Two years after his wife’s death, Yusuke Kafuku receives an offer to direct a play at a theater festival in Hiroshima. There, he meets Misaki, a reserved young woman assigned to be his chauffeur. As they spend time together, Kafuku starts to confront the mystery of his wife that quietly haunts him.
items.default_editorial: Winning the Oscar®, BAFTA, and Golden Globe for International Feature, Ryusuke Hamaguchi’s expansive Haruki Murakami adaptation is a film of engrossing pleasures. In detailing the effects of the past and the present, of memory and imagination on the creation of art, Drive My Car contains multitudes.

items.title: Emilia Pérez
items.short_synopsis: In Mexico, overworked lawyer Rita is hired by notorious drug lord Manitas Del Monte to help him disappear and live as Emilia Pérez, the woman he has always dreamt of being. Rita arranges surgeries and fakes Manitas’ death—but as Emilia begins a new life, the past threatens to unravel their plans.
items.default_editorial: Sharing the Best Actress award in Cannes among its ensemble cast, Jacques Audiard’s audacious musical is one of a kind. Storming spectacularly between cartel thriller, telenovela, and powerful ode to self-actualization, Emilia Pérez explodes onto screens like an unstoppable force of nature.

items.title: Fallen Angels
items.original_title: 墮落天使 | Do lok tin si
items.short_synopsis: Two tales of crimes intertwine in present-day Hong Kong. A coolly detached hitman wants to finally escape a life of violence—much to the dismay of his partner who is secretly besotted with him. Meanwhile, a mute ex-convict repeatedly encounters a girl during his nights of wreaking havoc.
items.default_editorial: Christopher Doyle’s woozily unmoored, ultra-wide lens induces genre reveries in this stylistically iconoclastic companion piece to Chungking Express. Stunningly restored, and presented for the first time in CinemaScope, this is Wong Kar Wai’s masterpiece as you’ve never seen it before.

items.title: Family
items.short_synopsis: Sony is a good Christian, the beating heart of his rural Catholic community. He always lends his fellow villagers a helping hand, assists children with their school lessons and organises volunteer activities. Under his genial exterior, however, lurks something dark.
items.default_editorial: Exposing the unease beneath everyday piety, Family is a haunting film that resists spectacle. Peeling back the layers of a close-knit rural community through spare dialogue and static dim-lit frames, this unsettling slow burn dissects the silences and allegiances that allow perpetrators to endure.

items.title: Farewell Amor
items.short_synopsis: Reunited after a 17 year separation, Walter, an Angolan immigrant, is joined in the U.S. by his wife and teenage daughter. Now absolute strangers sharing a one-bedroom apartment, they discover a shared love of dance that may help overcome the emotional distance between them.
items.default_editorial: Tanzanian-American director Ekwa Msangi’s debut insightfully describes the experience of immigration with a personal yet universal approach too little seen in film. Set in New York, this tender family drama delighted critics at Sundance in 2020 and features star-making turns from its three leads.

items.title: Faya Dayi
items.short_synopsis: Ethiopian legends say khat, a stimulant leaf, was found by Sufi Imams in search of eternity. Through a spiritual journey into the khat trade, stories of government repression, mystical fantasies, and risky journeys beyond borders are told, showing the dreams of a youth longing for a better life.
items.default_editorial: Emulating the intoxicating potency of the khat plant, Jessica Beshir’s documentary on the herbal drug trade in Ethiopia is pure poetry in motion. Casting a spell on the landscape, the gauzy black-and-white cinematography evokes the hazy line between the hardship of harvest and the stupor of bliss.

items.title: First Case, Second Case
items.original_title: Ghazieh-e Shekl-e Aval, Ghazieh-e Shekl-e Dou Wom
items.short_synopsis: While a teacher writes on the blackboard, a disruptive noise breaks the silence—but the culprit won’t confess. Two versions of what follows unfold: in one, a student gives up the troublemaker; in the other, a silent pact binds seven classmates who refuse to betray one another.
items.default_editorial: When a harmless case of classroom misconduct occurs, Abbas Kiarostami imagines two scenarios that might follow: snitching in one case, and a show of solidarity in the other. As adults reflect on this little event, their words resonate profoundly with the fractious atmosphere of revolutionary Iran.

items.title: First Cow
items.short_synopsis: In the 1820s, a taciturn loner and skilled cook travels west to Oregon Territory, where he meets a Chinese immigrant also seeking his fortune. Soon the two team up on a dangerous scheme to steal milk from the wealthy landowner’s prized Jersey cow—the first, and only, in the territory.
items.default_editorial: Kelly Reichardt, an inimitable voice of American cinema, redefines the notion of what a western can be. Set among outcasts on the edge of capitalism’s grasp, First Cow is a rare tale of the blossoming of a heartfelt male friendship, and one told with sublime gentleness and touching compassion.

items.title: Fit to Be Untied
