items.short_synopsis: This documentary was distilled from a 3 1/2-hour television film Nessuno o Tutti, to make the point that many inmates now in mental hospitals could be released without harm to society, and to their advantage.
items.default_editorial: By giving voice to patients’ experiences, this groundbreaking documentary contributed to a groundswell of change in Italian psychiatric institutions. A raw cinematic clarion call for justice and an early collaboration between some of Italy’s great directors, like Bellocchio and Agosti.

items.title: Great Freedom
items.short_synopsis: In post-war Germany, liberation by the Allies does not mean freedom for everyone. Hans is imprisoned again and again under Paragraph 175, a law criminalizing homosexuality. Over the course of decades, he develops an unlikely yet tender bond with his cellmate Viktor, a convicted murderer.
items.default_editorial: Unearthing heartrending chapters of queer history in postwar Germany, Sebastian Meise’s moving drama harnesses the healing power of intimacy that blooms in defiance of systematic oppression. Franz Rogowski mesmerizes with a powerhouse performance in this absorbing tale of resilience and resistance.

items.title: Happy Together
items.original_title: 春光乍洩 | Chun gwong ja sit
items.short_synopsis: Lai and his lover Ho go on a trip to Buenos Aires from Hong Kong. Their torrid relationship lives out among lusty tango bars and the salsa music of La Boca sidewalks. But tensions grow between the two lovers, as they find themselves far from home with their lives drifting in opposite directions.
items.default_editorial: Wong Kar Wai pushed boundaries with this sumptuous, recently-restored queer love story. He won Best Director at Cannes, but just as much praise is due the exquisite look from cinematographer Christopher Doyle and the heart-wrenching performances by superstars Tony Leung Chiu Wai and Leslie Cheung.

items.title: Hot Milk
items.short_synopsis: Sofia and her ailing mother, Rose, travel to the Spanish seaside town of Almería to seek the help of Dr. Gómez, an enigmatic healer who may hold the key to Rose’s mysterious illness. As long-buried tensions simmer between them, Sofia finds herself drawn to the magnetic and free-spirited Ingrid.
items.default_editorial: Rising star Emma Mackey stuns in this searing adaptation of Deborah Levy’s acclaimed novel about sensual longing and animal instincts. Intoxicated by the sun and salt sensations of the Andalusian coast, her hot-headed heroine swims clear of her mother’s stinging gaze in a break for self-realization.

items.title: In the Mood for Love
items.original_title: 花樣年華 | Fa yeung nin wa
items.short_synopsis: In the sleepy, proper Hong Kong of 1962, Mrs. Chan and Mr. Chow, a journalist, move into neighbouring apartments on the same day. Their encounters are formal and polite—until a discovery about their respective spouses creates an intimate bond between them.
items.default_editorial: Hong Kong, 1962. Brushed hands and stolen glances trigger earthquakes of yearning along the crimson corridors of Wong Kar Wai’s swooning, melancholy masterpiece of suspended love. With a soundtrack by Shigeru Umebayashi to die for, one of cinema’s greatest romances returns in a dazzling restoration.

items.title: Kiss
items.short_synopsis: A young filmmaker gets in trouble with the censors over a scene in his new film.
items.default_editorial: Multi-hyphenate filmmaker Varun Grover made his directorial debut with this imaginative short, which transforms an ordinary cinema into a sci-fi space of dreams. Taking aim at media censorship in India through dry humor, Kiss dares to unleash transgressive desire in the face of draconian rules.

items.title: Lalanna's Song
items.short_synopsis: Two young women on what seems to be a routine day dealing with prejudice and sexism. Their world starts to break down into David Lynch-like shards, triggered by their encounter with a possibly supernatural young girl, Lalanna, whose song may bring death with it.
items.default_editorial: At first a straightforward slice of social realism, this mysterious short soon unveils a vertiginous chasm at the heart of things. Smoothly melding the everyday with the uncanny, Lalanna’s Song evokes women’s desires and fears through enigmatic sound design and visceral imagery.

items.title: Lamb
items.short_synopsis: A couple living alone on a remote farm in Iceland find their quiet existence shaken by the astonishing discovery of a mysterious newborn amongst their sheep. They decide to raise the child as their own, but soon face the consequences of defying the will of nature.
items.default_editorial: Precision-timed in revealing its uncanny mysteries, it’s little wonder that Valdimar Jóhannsson’s nightmarishly eerie debut took the Prize of Originality at Cannes. Led by a magnificent Noomi Rapace, this genre-defying fable stages a cloven reckoning with the psychological landscapes of motherhood.

items.title: Leningrad Cowboys: These Boots
items.short_synopsis: The music video for “These Boots” by the Leningrad Cowboys. A history of Finland from 1952 to 1969, beginning with the birth of a Leningrad Cowboy, who soon discovers the joys of drinking, loving, and Finnish saunas.
items.default_editorial: Ever wondered what a Leningrad Cowboy looked like as a baby? Once seen, never forgotten in this music video for their cover of the Nancy Sinatra classic. Aki Kaurismäki furnishes the band with an origin story in this deranged delight, which also doubles as a fanciful lesson in cultural history.

items.title: Leningrad Cowboys: Those Were the Days [MV]
items.original_title: Leningrad Cowboys: Those Were the Days [MV]
items.short_synopsis: The music video for “Those Were the Days” by the Leningrad Cowboys. A man and a donkey walk into a bar run by an Elvis impersonator…
items.default_editorial: All Jean-Luc Godard needed to make a movie was a girl and gun. For Aki Kaurismäki, an Elvis impersonator and a donkey will do. Throw in a Finnish band, a Parisian bar, a 1920s Russian pop standard, and some pointy shoes, and you’ve all the ingredients for a classic Leningrad Cowboys singalong.

items.title: Leningrad Cowboys: Thru the Wire
items.short_synopsis: The music video for “Thru the Wire” by the Leningrad Cowboys. Somewhere between Alabama and Utah, sometime in the future, Nicky escapes from a prison. He searches for his girl in every bar and hotel. Meanwhile, two agents of the law pursue him.
items.default_editorial: Cigarette smoke hangs in the air throughout this early Leningrad Cowboys music video. Shot in high-contrast monochrome, and with the band decked out in trench coats and fedoras, the vibe is pure pulp. Kaurismäki aces the noir pastiche, while the boys lend their gravelly vocals and some sultry sax.

items.title: Majonezë
items.short_synopsis: Ersekë, Albania. Elyria lives with her family following the strict rules imposed by her father, hiding her anger with obedience. A powerful desire for rebellion grows in her day by day that will lead her to the fulfillment of a bitter but necessary act of revolution.
items.default_editorial: Set amid snow-covered mountains, this film burns its tale of a daughter’s dissent with the kindling of swift, kinetic camera movements and other stylish surprises. Throwing raw eggs in the stony face of tradition, director Giulia Grandinetti squeezes a feminist riot into 23 mischievous minutes.

items.title: Medusa Deluxe
items.short_synopsis: After a stylist is found dead at a hairdressing competition, the remaining competitors try to uncover the killer over the course of an evening. Rivalry and mistrust build as the contestants suspect that someone may be trying to rig the competition, by gruesomely picking off its entrants.
items.default_editorial: The air is thick with hairspray, wicked gossip, and even murder in Thomas Hardiman’s audacious and extravagant one-shot whodunnit, uniquely set amid a hairdressing contest. Feast your eyes on a dazzling array of wild styles concocted by the legendary Eugene Souleiman—they are surely full of secrets!

items.title: Memoria
items.short_synopsis: One morning, Jessica Holland, a Scottish orchid farmer visiting her sister in Bogotá, is woken by a loud ‘bang’. This haunting sound dispels her sleep for days, calling into question her identity and guiding her from recording studios to secluded jungle villages in an attempt to find its source.
items.default_editorial: For his first feature made outside his native Thailand, Apichatpong Weerasethakul ventured to Colombia with the great Tilda Swinton. Winner of the Jury Prize at Cannes, Memoria is a dazzling metaphysical mystery whose cosmic cannonades reverberate with the weight of history, memory, and identity.

items.title: Occupied City
items.short_synopsis: Past and present collide in a modern-day Amsterdam haunted by its history. As a narrator details significant events that took place in the Dutch capital during the Nazi occupation from 1940 to 1945, contemporary footage shot between 2020 and 2022 captures the exact locations where they occurred.
items.default_editorial: Adapting Bianca Stigter’s monumental book of biographies and testimonies, Steve McQueen’s bold epic redefines how stories of the Second World War are told onscreen. An engrossing rumination on how ghosts of the past linger in a modern city, this poetic documentary is both shattering and inspiring.

items.title: Old Joy
items.short_synopsis: Two old friends, Kurt and Mark, reunite for a weekend camping trip in the Cascade mountain range east of Portland, Oregon. When they arrive at their final destination, a hot spring deep in the forest, they must confront the divergent paths they have taken in life.
items.default_editorial: After 12 years away, Kelly Reichardt returned to independent filmmaking with this small scale but beguiling portrait of two men, no longer young, not quite old, trying to resume a friendship. With a lush Oregon setting and precise social detail—a director hallmark—she made a road movie in miniature.

items.title: On the Road
items.short_synopsis: After his father dies, aspiring writer Sal Paradise meets Dean Moriarty, a charming ex-con married to the liberated and seductive Marylou. Sal and Dean bond instantly, and the three take to the road. Travelling across the country, they encounter a mix of people who impact their journey indelibly.
items.default_editorial: Soaring out of decades in development hell, this long-awaited adaptation of an era-defining Beat novel is fired up by an all-star cast that includes Kirsten Dunst and Kristen Stewart. Tearing into Jack Kerouac’s syncopated prose with passion, the actors reignite 1950s counterculture with style.

items.title: Paradise
items.short_synopsis: An Indian tourist couple arrive in the hill country of crisis-ridden Sri Lanka to celebrate their fifth wedding anniversary. But, when things take an unexpected turn, conflicts deepen revealing cracks in their relationship.
items.default_editorial: The girlishly expressive face of actor Darshana Rajendran is canvas for a cascade of emotion in this atmospheric film, set in the land of waterfalls. Ancient Hindu mythology and mass unrest in late-capitalist Sri Lanka converge and crackle like static, unleashing a perfect storm in lovers’ paradise.

items.title: Paris, 13th District
items.short_synopsis: A group of four loosely connected young adults alternate between being friends and sometimes lovers as they navigate their lively neighbourhood in the French capital’s 13th arrondissement.
items.default_editorial: Jacques Audiard’s luminous tale of friendship, sex, and romance reunites co-screenwriter Céline Sciamma with her Portrait of a Lady on Fire star Noémie Merlant. Shot in silky black-and-white and set in a diverse area of Paris, this is a tender and hyper-contemporary ode to the city of love.

items.title: Petite Maman
items.short_synopsis: After the death of her beloved grandmother, eight-year-old Nelly meets a strangely familiar girl her own age in the woods. Instantly forming a connection with this mysterious new friend, Nelly embarks on a fantastical journey of discovery which helps her come to terms with this newfound loss.
items.default_editorial: Following the international triumph of Portrait of a Lady on Fire, Céline Sciamma returns to the mysteries of childhood with this spellbinding adventure in imagination. Delicately playful, and tinged with melancholy, Petite Maman weaves a spectral fairytale from a child’s-eye view on love and loss.

items.title: Prayers for the Stolen
items.short_synopsis: Three young girls live in a rural village in Guerrero dominated by the violent presence of the local drug trade and the threat of human trafficking. Trained by their mothers to flee at any moment and forced into extreme measures to evade capture, they must learn to navigate their harsh surroundings.
items.default_editorial: Under the shadow of drug and human trafficking, girlhood reveries tenderly bloom in Tatiana Huezo’s sensorial narrative debut. Produced by the team behind Roma, this profound tale of love and survival juxtaposes the lushness of rural Mexico with the cartel violence looming over crimson poppy fields.

items.title: Priscilla
items.short_synopsis: From a German army base to his dream-world estate at Graceland: through Priscilla Presley’s eyes, Sofia Coppola tells the unseen side of a great American myth in Elvis and Priscilla’s long courtship and turbulent marriage.
items.default_editorial: The gilded cage of fame is beguiling but lonesome in Sofia Coppola’s sumptuous adaptation of Priscilla Presley’s memoir. Starring a revelatory, award-winning Cailee Spaeny next to Jacob Elordi as Elvis, this dark fairytale charts the highs and the lows of a life spent in the shadow of the King.

items.title: Queer
items.short_synopsis: 1950. William Lee, an American expat in Mexico City, spends his days almost entirely alone, except for a few contacts with other members of the community. His encounter with Eugene Allerton, an expat former soldier, shows him that it might be finally possible to establish an intimate connection.
items.default_editorial: Starring an astonishing Daniel Craig as a lovestruck sensualist, Luca Guadagnino’s audacious adaptation of William Burroughs’s infamous novel is suffused with romantic longing. Under the sway of infatuation’s exquisite pains and entrancing pleasures, Queer travels to the mesmerizing ends of love.

items.title: Rapado
items.short_synopsis: Lucio is a young man stuck living at home with his parents. After the theft of his motorcycle, Lucio bums aimlessly around Buenos Aires, drifting from one arcade and record store to the next—indulging in short chats with friends and, more often, setting out onto the streets alone.
items.default_editorial: Martín Rejtman’s debut is today regarded as the film that launched the New Argentine Cinema, and prefigures his trademark style of comedies imbued with a languid melancholy and hilariously deadpan humor. Presented in its recent restoration, this now-cult film is always ripe for (re)discovery.

items.title: Return to Seoul
items.short_synopsis: Wanting to reconnect with her origins, 25-year-old Freddie impulsively returns to her birthplace of South Korea for the first time since she was adopted and raised in France. Freddie begins to track down her biological parents, embarking on an unexpected journey in a country she knows little about.
items.default_editorial: A moving search for identity in neon-drenched Seoul, Davy Chou’s mercurial drama aches with diasporic longing, which thrums through an exquisitely curated soundtrack. Dazzling in her vulnerability, first-time actress Park Ji-Min ferociously embodies the tragicomic chaos of living between cultures.

items.title: River of Grass
items.short_synopsis: Cozy, a thirtyish Florida housewife bored to tears with her drudging life, runs away with Lee, a young loser in search of thrills. After accidentally shooting a man, Cozy and Lee try to go on the lam as every outlaw couple before them—without quite ever getting it right.
items.default_editorial: Before moving to Oregon, Kelly Reichardt made a fugitive film set in the Florida wetlands—more like the grungy filmmaking of Jim Jarmusch than her later slow cinema. Tailing wastrel lovers on the run, River of Grass shows she has been committed to America’s margins and outcasts from the very start.

items.title: Rocky VI
items.short_synopsis: Touching down in Helsinki, the all-star American boxer Rocky defends the Free World by fighting against a gigantic opponent from Siberia named Igor. Will Rocky finally meet his match?
items.default_editorial: Liberally reinterpreting Sly Stallone’s inspiring underdog story, Aki Kaurismäki takes his typical deadpan humour to a whole other level with this exuberant 80s short-film satire. Relentless glam-rock guitar riffs soundtrack this pain-and-gain parody—outrageous, outlandish, and a little bit sad!

items.title: Shakti
items.short_synopsis: Federico, in his mid-20s, lives alone in Buenos Aires. The day his grandmother dies, he plans to break up with his girlfriend, only for her to beat him to it, leaving him absurdly fixated on her reaction. The support of his family, his shrink, and a new encounter pull him back to the present.
items.default_editorial: A master of deadpan comedy, Argentinian filmmaker Martín Rejtman bookends his luminous short with a mouth-watering feast of Jewish delicacies. Condensing all the fine irony, absurdist humour, and unassuming warmth that defines his work into only 19 minutes, Shakti is a delightful minimalist gem.

items.title: Silvia Prieto
items.short_synopsis: When she turns 27, Silvia Prieto decides to change her life: she quits marijuana and looks for a job. When she discovers that there are other women who share her name, she develops a bizarre obsession with the “other” Silvias, an obsession that involves unraveling the riddle of her own identity.
items.default_editorial: A timeless, minimalist deadpan comedy, this is a young woman’s deliciously eccentric quest for sense of self in a world of doppelgängers, with an unforgettable performance from Rosario Bléfari. Committed to hilarity in all forms, Martín Rejtman’s cinema conjures humor and warmth in equal measure.

items.title: Sun Song
items.short_synopsis: A poetic journey from the darkness of dawn into the brightness of the midday sun in the American South. Filmed over the course of six months on one bus route in Durham, North Carolina, Sun Song is a celebration of light and a meditation on leaving.
items.default_editorial: Discovered at Rotterdam’s film festival, Joel Wanek’s short film is at once lyrically poetic and precisely documentarian. The lighting evolves as the day ages, and we watch portraits in miniature of Durham’s workers, students, and other passengers. Luminous with a quietly dark undercurrent.

items.title: Taste of Cherry
items.short_synopsis: Middle-aged Mr. Badii wishes to die in a society where suicide is considered an abomination. Driving in the hills above Tehran, he searches for an accomplice who is willing to bury him after he is dead. He meets an assortment of different characters, but each have reasons to turn down the job.
items.default_editorial: Capturing the miracles and mysteries of everyday life in all his films, Iranian master Abbas Kiarostami will always be one of cinema’s greatest poets. His Palme d’Or-winning Taste of Cherry is a spiritual road movie of tremendous humility: a meditation on mortality with an unforgettable coda.

items.title: The Box
items.short_synopsis: Teenager Hatzín travels from Mexico City to collect the remains of his father, found in a communal grave in Northern Mexico. But a casual encounter with a man who he shares a physical resemblance with introduces both doubt and hope around the truth.
items.default_editorial: Venezuela’s submission to the Oscars® in 2022, Lorenzo Vigas’s gripping thriller beats with a politically conscious heart. Informed by the plight of migrant workers in Mexico, the central mystery of mistaken identity is shatteringly poignant, capturing the human cost when lives become disposable.

items.title: The Delinquents
items.short_synopsis: Bank employee Morán schemes to steal enough money to liberate himself from corporate monotony, then confess and serve prison time while his co-worker hides the cash. Soon under pressure by a company investigator, accomplice Román later encounters a mysterious woman who will transform him forever.
items.default_editorial: Rebelling against the banality of work, Rodrigo Moreno’s playful and restorative Cannes highlight reinvents the heist film as a free-flowing adventure in which love and epiphanies bloom. A beguiling and defiant quest for personal freedom that dares to embrace the strangeness of life with open arms.

items.title: The Double Life of Véronique
items.short_synopsis: Polish choir soprano, Weronika, has a double. She is Véronique, a French music teacher. They have no blood relation and lead very different lives but are otherwise identical: sharing a sublime gift for singing, a cardiac disorder, and a mystical awareness of each other’s existence.
items.default_editorial: Irène Jacob won Best Actress in Cannes for her magnificent dual roles in this lyrical masterwork from Polish auteur Krzysztof Kieślowski. With its luminous cinematography and unforgettable score, The Double Life of Véronique is a magical and enigmatic tale of love, ambition, and twinned identities.

items.title: The Hand
items.short_synopsis: Hong Kong, 1960s. Zhang, a shy tailor’s assistant, is riveted by his imperious client Miss Hua. Upon meeting her, she seduces him to make sure he will truly remember her when designing her garments. After this intimate first encounter, a rapport develops between the two.
items.default_editorial: Wong Kar Wai’s segment of the omnibus film Eros is presented for the first time in its extended cut. Returning to ’60s Hong Kong for a gesturally-charged tale of desire and repression, The Hand finds Wong operating in a more sumptuous classical register, en route to a coda that ranks among his best.

items.title: The Humans
items.short_synopsis: Over the course of one night, the Blake family comes together for Thanksgiving at Brigid and her partner Richard’s lower Manhattan apartment. As the evening unfolds, the family member’s frustrations and insecurities are exposed as home truths and long-hidden secrets rise to the surface.
items.default_editorial: A holiday reunion takes an eerie turn in this gripping debut from Tony-winning writer-director Stephen Karam. With a stellar ensemble that includes Richard Jenkins, Amy Schumer and Steven Yeun, The Humans cuts a jagged path through its fractious family drama before beginning its descent into terror.

items.title: The Last Rhododendron
items.short_synopsis: In a small village in the mountains of Uttarakhand, a daughter is lured by the possibilities of city life, while her mother is haunted by the prospect of their land’s desolation.

items.title: The Magic Gloves
items.short_synopsis: In the wake of Argentina’s financial crisis, the fortunes of many dysfunctional Buenos Aires locals intersect—including a dog walker with a penchant for over-the-counter medication and a cab driver who doesn’t care about his life spiraling out of control as long as he can sit in his old Renault 12.
items.default_editorial: Fuelled by a top-form ensemble cast, The Magic Gloves is one of Argentine auteur Martín Rejtman’s funniest films. This clever, humorous take on the mid-30s crisis is another trademark mix of absurdist charm and endearing warmth. A unique view of Buenos Aires full of lively, strange characters.

items.title: The Making of Priscilla
items.short_synopsis: Film student Liv McNeil shadows Sofia Coppola on the set of Priscilla, a 30-day shoot that involved transforming 1950s Germany one day into 1960s Memphis the next. Featuring on-set footage with actors Jacob Elordi and Cailee Spaeny and interviews with Priscilla Presley, Coppola, and the cast.
items.default_editorial: An exclusive, behind-the-scenes look at Sofia Coppola’s Priscilla, Liv McNeil’s documentary sparkles with an infectious enthusiasm for the magic of cinema. From visual moodboards to the creation of Graceland, this engaging short reveals the extraordinary craft behind the making of a dark fairytale.

items.title: The Settlers
items.short_synopsis: Chile, 1901. Three horsemen embark on an expedition, tasked with securing a wealthy landowner’s vast property. Accompanying a British lieutenant and an American mercenary is mestizo marksman Segundo, who comes to realize their true mission is to violently “remove” the indigenous population.
items.default_editorial: Writer-director Felipe Gálvez emerges as a startling new voice in Latin American cinema with this searing revisionist western. Capturing majestic landscapes with a painterly eye, Chile’s official Oscar® entry is a singularly immersive reckoning with national myth-making and its attendant violence.

items.title: The Wind Will Carry Us
items.short_synopsis: Irreverent city engineer Behzad comes to a rural Kurdish village in Iran to keep vigil for a dying relative. While death hovers around the corner, Behzad gains perspectives on life and spirituality as he befriends the locals and experiences nature’s majesty, changing his own attitudes as a result.
items.default_editorial: With delicate notes of absurdist humor and serenely beautiful landscapes, Abbas Kiarostami continues to plumb some of the eternal questions in The Wind Will Carry Us. The emphasis, once more, is on the journey rather the destination. This is essential, transcendent cinema.

items.title: The Worst Person in the World
items.short_synopsis: On the verge of turning thirty, Julie is faced with a series of choices that force her to pursue new perspectives on her life in contemporary Oslo. Over the course of four years, she navigates love affairs and existential uncertainty as she starts deciding who she wants to become.
items.default_editorial: Formally playful and humorously observant, Joachim Trier’s Oscar®-nominated gem embraces with open arms the messiness of life at a crossroad. Winner of Cannes’ Best Actress Award for her star-making turn, the effervescent Renate Reinsve commands the screen–and our hearts–with her ravishing vivacity.

items.title: There Are Four Flowers and There’s the World
items.original_title: Chaar Phool Hain Aur Duniya Hai
items.short_synopsis: A meandering brook of moments from two afternoons spent with Vinod Kumar Shukla, his wife and son at their home in Raipur, saunters between the mingling geographies of past, present and future, drifting in and out of pauses—to ponder, to reflect, to reminisce, and to share.
items.default_editorial: With striking composition and a melodious play of light, Achal Mishra (Gamak Ghar, Dhuin) paints a meditative portrait of noted Hindi writer Vinod Kumar Shukla. Through fleeting glimpses into his personal world, the film unfolds as an essay on the beauty, depth, and poetry of everyday life.

items.title: Three Colors: Blue
items.short_synopsis: The wife of a famous composer survives a car accident that kills her husband and daughter. Now alone, she shakes off her old identity and explores her newfound freedom but finds that she is unbreakably bound to other humans, including her husband’s mistress, whose existence she never suspected.
items.default_editorial: An arthouse staple of the ’90s, the Three Colors films hold up some twenty years later as complex, emotionally resonant, and visually beguiling tales of contemporary Europe.  The first part, Blue, is a story of death and rebirth that features a tour-de-force performance by Juliette Binoche.

items.title: Three Colors: Red
items.short_synopsis: Part-time model Valentine unexpectedly befriends a retired judge after she runs over his dog. At first, the grumpy man shows no concern about the dog, and Valentine decides to keep it. But the two form a bond when she returns to his house and catches him listening to his neighbors’ phone calls.
items.default_editorial: Sumptuously stylish and sexy, this modern classic takes an unconventional look at fate, love, and chance in an interconnected society. Starring Irène Jacob, it was an Academy Award® nominee for Best Director and Screenplay and is arguably the great Polish director’s masterpiece.

items.title: Three Colors: White
items.short_synopsis: Karol Karol, a Polish immigrant living in France, is a hairdresser who opts to leave Paris for his native Warsaw when his wife sues him for divorce (her reason: their marriage was never consummated) and then frames him for arson. Karol Karol, in return, plans an elaborate revenge plot.
items.default_editorial: Alternately gritty, funny, dark, and farcical: this is a film that truly defies categorization. Starring the great Julie Delpy (who appears in all the Three Colors Trilogy), Krzysztof Kieślowski offers a unique take on twisted love while satirizing the divide between Eastern and Western Europe.

items.title: Titane
items.short_synopsis: Alexia is a dancer who, after being injured in a car accident as a child, has a titanium plate fitted into her head. Amidst a series of brutal and unexplained murders, her path crosses with Vincent, a firefighter desperately searching for his long-missing son, changing their lives forever.
items.default_editorial: Exploding onto MUBI in a gnarled helix of chrome and flesh, Julia Ducournau’s Palme d’Or-winner is a jaw-dropping blast of Cronenbergian gothic. Conceptually audacious and dripping with insouciant attitude, Titane ignites a Molotov cocktail of gender politics, familial compassion, and female desire.

items.title: Tortoise Under The Earth
items.short_synopsis: In a uranium mining area of Jharkhand, India, a tribal couple copes with the loss of their daughter. Tortoise Under The Earth is a poetic elegy to a world that is rapidly disappearing, subsumed by unchecked development and displacement.
items.default_editorial: The grieving couple in Shishir Jha’s quietly lyrical film express themselves largely through song and ritual, blurring the boundaries between personal pain and communal trauma. Still takes capture their helplessness in the face of brutal changes in their environment, but also their unwavering love.

items.title: Trailer of the Film That Will Never Exist: 'Phony Wars'
items.original_title: Film annonce du film qui n'existera jamais: 'Drôles de Guerres'
items.short_synopsis: Director Jean-Luc Godard plans a feature adaptation of Charles Plisnier’s 1937 novel Faux Passports. Godard narrates the film’s trailer as he compiles a complex collage of history, politics, and cinema constructed of paper and glue, paintings and postcards, Shostakovich and silence.
items.default_editorial: The first Jean-Luc Godard project to be released after his death is a gift to all cinephiles. Created in collaboration with film theorist Nicole Brenez, this collage of paintings, pictures, written notes, and JLG’s unmistakable narration shows the master at work, his ingenuity as inspiring as ever.

items.title: Zivan Makes a Punk Festival
items.short_synopsis: Every summer for the last five years, Živan, a punk rocker and a poet, has organized a punk festival in his native village outside of Belgrade in Serbia.He always lost money on it, but his dreams are focused on changing the way the villagers think.
items.default_editorial: Ognjen Glavonić’s documentary adroitly chronicles its protagonist’s Quixotic pursuit of his dream, an against-the-odds realization of a big ambition. A touching tribute to one man’s beautifully boundless enthusiasm, and a marvellous film.

items.title: Life Span of the Object in Frame (A Film About the Film Not Yet Shot)
items.original_title: Chas Zhyttia Objekta V Kadri (Film Pro Nezniatyi Film)
items.short_synopsis: Choosing photography as his subject and memory as a guide, the director finds himself trapped in a labyrinth. Engaged in a back and forth between theoretical meditations and visual flashes, he winds through the image-filled maze, encountering an angel, Dante, Muybridge’s sequences and much more.
items.default_editorial: At once a meditation on time and memory, this experimental feature takes a photograph as its material of choice to examine its properties in relation to cinema. From Ukrainian artist-filmmaker Aleksandr Balagura, this fascinating film is a hypnotic provocation in photography’s enchanting enigmas.

items.title: Sorry Angel
items.short_synopsis: Paris, 1993. Jacques is a writer and single father in his thirties trying to maintain his sense of romance and humor in spite of the turmoil in his life. While in Brittany, he meets Arthur, an aspiring director in his twenties, who is exploring his sexuality, eager to get out of his parochial life.
items.default_editorial: A film of profound resilience and fragility, Christophe Honoré’s queer romantic drama glows with the warmth of a new love that blooms underneath the specter of the AIDS crisis. Intimacy is evoked, not only with electrifying carnal touches, but also through thrilling exchanges on art and literature.

items.title: Winter in Sokcho
items.short_synopsis: In the snowy seaside town of Sokcho, 25-year-old Soo-Ha works at a guesthouse. She drifts between her mother’s fish stall and her boyfriend until a French artist’s arrival stirs questions about her identity. As winter deepens, Soo-Ha and the artist form an unspoken connection through food and art.
items.default_editorial: Two beautifully tender performances lift this subtle love story, which washes away the residual haze of romantic cliché. Adapting the twinned portrait of solitude from an award-winning novel, Koya Kamura suffuses his directorial debut with shoreline blues and exquisitely vaporous watercolor imagery.

items.title: All These Sleepless Nights
items.short_synopsis: A new era is coming, and Warsaw stands uncomfortably at its edge. Art school classmates Kris and Michal, on the precipice of their own coming of age, restlessly roam the streets in search of living forever inside the beautiful moment. Floating from party to party, romance and sex hang in the air.
items.default_editorial: An intimate glimpse into the party scene in Warsaw, Michal Marczak’s Sundance prizewinner boldly blends fiction and documentary. Reminiscent of Terence Malick’s signature style, the Steadicam-based cinematography lends a touching ephemerality to the intense passions and contradictions of youth.

items.title: Control
items.short_synopsis: In 1970s Manchester, troubled musician Ian Curtis is on the brink of international fame and fortune as lead singer of the band Joy Division. A husband and father, Curtis begins to feel the strain of his band’s growing success, his crumbling marriage to wife Deborah, and his worsening epilepsy.
items.default_editorial: The story of Joy Division is given impecable treatment by auteur Anton Corbijn, who photographed the post-punk band in their heyday. Recalling the minimalist monochrome of Corbijn’s photography, this moody portrait of a doomed star features an electric and uncanny performance by Sam Riley.

items.title: Finding Vivian Maier
items.short_synopsis: The mysterious Vivian Maier was a nanny who secretly took over 100,000 photographs that were hidden in storage lockers. When these were discovered decades later, she earned a posthumous reputation as one of America’s greatest street photographers. This is her life story.
items.default_editorial: In 2007 the previously undiscovered photographs of a reclusive nanny took the art world by storm. Soon after, the ripples extended to this documentary, which obsessively reconstructs her story through archival materials. It just shows: some of our greatest artists may be hiding in plain sight.

items.title: That Sinking Feeling
items.short_synopsis: Unemployed and aimless teenager Ronnie, and his hapless pals, spend their time hanging around the rainy parks and dingy cafes of dreary Glasgow. But their world is about to change when Ronnie hatches a complicated scheme to make them all rich by stealing stainless steel sinks from a warehouse.
items.default_editorial: Quick cash proves to be more than just a pipe dream in Bill Forsyth’s buoyant debut about a group of Glaswegian lads who speculate to accumulate in ludicrous fashion. Shrugging off a gloomy tradition of kitchen-sink realism, this cheery comedy looks at the follies of youth with genuine affection.

items.title: Amy George
items.short_synopsis: Thirteen-year-old Jesse wants to be an artist but believes his mundane middle-class Toronto life has left him unprepared. After reading a book on what it takes to be a ‘true artist,’ he sets out looking for risk, ecstasy, wildness, and women.
items.default_editorial: The debut feature from up-and-coming Canadian filmmakers Calvin Thomas & Yonah Lewis, Amy George is a sharp, moving, and unusually sober portrait of adolescence. Made for practically nothing, this honest slice-of-life feature beautifully captures the awkwardness of a difficult time in life.

items.title: Battle Royale
items.short_synopsis: In the near future, unemployment has soared and juvenile crime has exploded in the face of economic recession. The Japanese government passes The BR Law, in which 9th graders are sent to a remote island where they will be forced to hunt and kill each other until there is only one survivor left.
items.default_editorial: Before Squid Game was even invented, cult director Kinji Fukasaku caused a sensation with his dystopian bloodbath, Battle Royale. Based on a controversial novel by Kōshun Takami, this highly political and adrenaline-charged movie adds a modern twist to the classic Lord of the Flies scenario.

items.title: Beanpole
items.short_synopsis: 1945, Leningrad. World War II has devastated the city, demolishing its buildings and leaving its citizens in tatters, physically and mentally. Two young women, Iya and Masha, search for meaning and hope in the struggle to rebuild their lives amongst the ruins.
items.default_editorial: After his shockingly powerful Closeness, this searing war drama from Russian wunderkind Kantemir Balagov grabbed us by the throat. An entrancing immersion into post-war turmoil,  this towering ode to women’s resilience stuns with its tour-de-force performances and jaw-dropping use of color.

items.title: Hara-kiri: Death of a Samurai
items.short_synopsis: Poverty-stricken samurai Hanshiro is seeking an honorable end. He requests to commit hara-kiri in a feudal lord’s courtyard. Trying to dismiss his wish, the lord recounts a similar plea from a young samurai years ago. But soon he will realize that Hanshiro’s request is different from what it seems.
items.default_editorial: Following the explosive 13 Assassins, the iconoclastic Takashi Miike revisited the samurai genre with this underrated remake of the 1962 classic Harakiri. Scored by the legendary Ryuichi Sakamoto, Death of a Samurai is an elegant reckoning with notions of sacrifice and duty in the 17th century.

items.title: Hockney
items.short_synopsis: British painter David Hockney, considered one of the most influential icons of the 20th century, still paints seven days a week. The remarkable life of this free-spirited artist, who defied categorization, is chronicled through an exclusive tour of his archives and into his studio.
items.default_editorial: British painter David Hockney’s fascinating life and colorful work has lent itself well to the cinema, with films shot by artists like Gregory Markopoulos, Jack Hazan, Tacita Dean & Bruno Wollheim. Randall Wright’s documentary has the feel of a diary: an intimate, frank, and honest visual chronicle.

items.title: Mr. Kaplan
items.short_synopsis: After fleeing Europe for Uruguay during WWII, Jacob Kaplan built a quiet life. Now 76, he begins to question his worth. After learning of a mysterious German prowling the shores of a nearby beach, he becomes convinced that he’s found a Nazi in hiding and plans to expose him.
items.default_editorial: A kidnapping plot goes from bad to worse in this riotous caper from Uruguay’s Álvaro Brechner: a fun-loving, crowd-pleasing black comedy. Balancing the serious with slapstick, this two-hander is nonetheless brought to life by a large ensemble of quirky characters and curmudgeons.

items.title: Poverty and Other Delights
items.short_synopsis: Marcel and Joseph are tireless walkers. Their itinerary is an invitation to discover improbable places and fascinating people. Everlastingly looking for Stanley, Marcel’s only friend, they meet an unlikely crowd of extravagant characters. Each has a story to tell, his hope to share.
items.default_editorial: With his knack for creating unique characters and getting equally distinctive performances out of his actors, Québécois filmmaker Denys Arcand (Jesus of Montreal) elevates Claire Richard’s clever script into an unforgettable episodic drama about peculiar friendships.

items.title: Swallow
items.short_synopsis: A pregnant housewife, Hunter appears to have it all. However, as the pressure to meet her controlling in-laws and Ken-doll husband’s rigid expectations mounts, cracks begin to appear in her carefully created facade. Hunter develops a dangerous eating habit, and a dark secret from her past seeps out.
items.default_editorial: With a stellar performance by Haley Bennett, Swallow is a surreal and candy-colored female empowerment thriller about the struggle for bodily autonomy. Joining the ranks of remarkably terrifying films about pregnancy, this drama revives the suspenseful mood—and style—of Rosemary’s Baby.

items.title: Delicatessen
items.short_synopsis: In a dystopian city stands a building inhabited by strange characters. On the ground floor, a butcher with limited meat supply sees his stock increase when some tenants begin to disappear. A young former clown lands a job there, oblivious that he might be the butcher’s next victim.
items.default_editorial: Before The City of Lost Children, film duo Jean-Pierre Jeunet and Marc Caro made their ingenious debut with idiosyncratic stylization that only cartoonists could conjure up. Set in a truly surreal vision of Paris, Delicatessen is a comic cult classic about the banality of post-apocalyptic existence.

items.title: Instructions for a Light and Sound Machine
items.original_title: Instructions for a Light and Sound Machine
items.short_synopsis: The hero of Instructions for a Light and Sound Machine is easy to identify. Walking down the street unknowingly, he suddenly realizes that he is not only subject to the gruesome moods of several spectators but also at the mercy of the filmmaker.
items.default_editorial: Using painstakingly artisanal methods, the Austrian avant-gardist turns Sergio Leone’s The Good, the Bad and the Ugly into a black-and-white celluloid spectacular: his “attempt to transform a Roman Western into a Greek tragedy.” A vividly reactive and highly combustible CinemaScope short.

items.title: Passing Summer
items.short_synopsis: A woman faces a variety of emotional crises as she spends the summer interacting in differing ways with friends, family, and lovers in this drama. Valerie is an author in her early thirties who has just moved to Berlin, while her best friend Sophie will be spending the summer in Rome.
items.default_editorial: Everyday dreamers imagine their attachments scattering to the breeze and becoming someone else in these tableaux of summertime Berlin. As Angela Schanelec threads serendipities—music, movement, tenderness—into ennui’s enervating haze, she outlines the pattern for her critically acclaimed cinema.

items.title: A Brother's Love
items.short_synopsis: After failing to secure a faculty position in the philosophy department, 35-year-old Sophia is forced to “temporarily” move in with her older brother Karim. Their unbreakable bond will be put to the test when Karim falls deeply in love. Feeling abandoned, Sophia is forced to finally become an adult.
items.default_editorial: Star of Xavier Dolan’s Heartbeats, Monia Chokri made her directorial debut with this charmingly verbose comedy about two siblings who can’t stay out of each other’s pockets. Codependency and a lack of self-worth are just some of the obstacles on the protagonist’s rocky road to happiness.

items.title: A Lizard in a Woman's Skin
items.original_title: Una lucertola con la pelle di donna
items.short_synopsis: Carol Hammond, a married upper-class woman and daughter of a prominent lawyer, experiences disturbing LSD-induced hallucinations in which she imagines wild orgies hosted by her alluring actress neighbor. When the neighbor is found dead under mysterious circumstances, Carol becomes the prime suspect.
items.default_editorial: Heightened by psychedelic imagery and a hip Ennio Morricone score, this Swinging London-set giallo from Lucio Fulci plumbs the mysterious unconscious. The underside of the hippy dream morphs into a blood-soaked nightmare, culminating in a stunning chase sequence through the iconic Alexandra Palace.

items.title: A Night of Knowing Nothing
items.short_synopsis: An Indian film student writes letters to her boyfriend from whom she was forcibly separated. She reflects on her daily life, disillusionments, and inner thoughts—her voice blending with images of unrest in university campuses, press clippings, and archival footage from Narendra Modi’s rise to power.
items.default_editorial: Before she took the Grand Prix at Cannes for All We Imagine As Light, Payal Kapadia crafted a poetic, thought-provoking chronicle of student unrest amid the chaos of Modi’s India. Aching with the urgency of revolution, this romantic, epistolary documentary is a flickering love letter to cinema.

items.title: Alan Vega, Just a Million Dreams
items.original_title: Alan Vega, Just a Million Dreams
items.short_synopsis: Renowned visual artist Alan Vega tells unique stories from his experiences in the 1970s and 1980s when he was a pioneering figure in the minimalist electronic rock scene as the vocalist and composer for the punk/post-punk duo Suicide.
items.default_editorial: A legendary performer with an attitude, punk pioneer Alan Vega shows a softer side to his swaggering image in this intimate short. Director Marie Losier observes the musician in his private life as a father and a husband, where his inimitably smoky voice mellows into an instrument of loving care.

items.title: Alice
items.short_synopsis: A quiet young English girl named Alice finds herself in an alternate version of her own reality after chasing a white rabbit. She becomes surrounded by living inanimate objects and stuffed dead animals, and must find a way out of this nightmare, no matter how twisted or odd that way must be.
items.default_editorial: Take a tumble down the rabbit hole of possibility with this extraordinary adaptation of the Lewis Carroll classic from legendary Czech animator Jan Švankmajer. An eye-popping wonder of energized bric-a-brac, Alice steps through the looking glass for a magical journey into childhood imagination.

items.title: Alice in the Cities
items.short_synopsis: Phillip is a roving German reporter who, after a chance encounter with an elusive American woman, reluctantly accepts temporary custody of little Alice. Their friendship grows while traveling through various European cities on a search for the girl’s grandmother.
items.default_editorial: Ten years before Paris, Texas, Wim Wenders put together this moving portrait of shared loneliness, which explores the emerging, unexpected friendship between a frustrated writer and an abandoned young girl. A luminous black-and-white road movie that journeys through restrained emotional landscapes.

items.title: Altiplano
items.short_synopsis: War photographer Grace renounces her job after a devastating incident. Her husband Max is a surgeon in Peru’s high Andes. Nearby, villagers get ill because of a mercury spill from a mine. As they turn their rage on the foreign doctors, Max is killed. Grace decides to visit the place of his death.
items.default_editorial: The second part of a trilogy from directing duo Jessica Woodworth & Peter Brosens, Altiplano is set among the breathtaking landscapes of the Peruvian Andes—an area often desecrated by mercury excavations. A story at once tragic and spiritual, the film is enriched by striking cinematography.

items.title: Asako I & II
items.short_synopsis: Asako is a young woman who meets and falls madly in love with a drifter, Baku, who one day drifts right out of her life. Two years later, in Tokyo, Asako sees Baku again—or, rather, a young, solid businessman named Ryohei who bears a striking resemblance to her old flame.
items.default_editorial: Ryusuke Hamaguchi’s intimate and immersive Happy Hour is one of the best films of the past decade. Equally devoted to the innermost feelings of its characters is his follow-up, Asako I & II, an entrancing, Vertigo-inspired romance mystery, featuring a lively soundtrack by J-Pop star Tofubeats.

items.title: Baby Anger
items.short_synopsis: A lost CGI baby, abandoned by those who gave birth to her and confronted with a contemporary world and its empty spaces, asks herself how to grow up. After the death of her friend the star, the baby doesn’t want to do anything but cook—and reflect on the end of humanity.
items.default_editorial: The angry infant at the heart of this touching and ingenious short may be the id of the internet: an amalgam of the fear, desire, and longing for connection that fuels the online world every day. Invincible but purposeless, outraged but alone, smart but ineffectual—is this the new human condition?

items.title: Babysitter
items.short_synopsis: Cédric is suspended from work after going viral for drunkenly kissing a TV reporter. Stuck at home with his exhausted wife Nadine and their crying baby, Cédric embarks on a therapeutic journey to free himself from misogyny. Enter Amy: a mysterious babysitter who will turn their lives upside down.
items.default_editorial: A thrillingly audacious takedown of casual misogyny, Monia Chokri’s pastel-hued and retro-styled sophomore feature also takes some pot shots at the cult of modern motherhood. Shot on 35mm, Babysitter is a bold and bitingly funny statement from the Québécois director and star of Xavier Dolan’s films.

items.title: Bad Luck Banging or Loony Porn
items.original_title: Babardeală cu bucluc sau porno balamuc
items.short_synopsis: Emi, a high school teacher, finds her career and reputation under threat after a personal sex tape she filmed with her husband is leaked onto the internet. Forced to meet the parents demanding her dismissal at an emergency community meeting, Emi refuses to surrender to their pressure.
items.default_editorial: One of the first films from a major auteur to be shot during the pandemic, Radu Jude’s outrageous contemporary satire is an absurdist jolt of punk provocation. Stylistically bold and mischievously confrontational, Bad Luck Banging serves up a profound critique of social hypocrisy in the online age.

items.title: Beau Is Afraid
items.short_synopsis: Beau lives alone in a downtown apartment where every moment is a waking nightmare. Prone to anxiety and paranoia, he visits his longtime therapist who prepares him for his journey to visit his mother. But mayhem ensues on the eve of Beau’s departure, spinning his life in a surreal new direction.
items.default_editorial: Ari Aster’s mind-blowingly ambitious odyssey reaches into the depths of an anxious psyche and takes horror to frenzied, often hilarious heights. Joaquin Phoenix is phenomenal as a once-beautiful mommy’s boy who has tragically fallen from grace—and stars alongside a terrific supporting cast.

items.title: Bergman Island
items.short_synopsis: Filmmaker couple Chris and Tony retreat to Fårö island for the Summer to write in the same place Bergman lived and found inspiration. As both work on their scripts, souvenirs of Chris’ first love resurface. However, soon the lines between fiction and reality begin to blur and tear them apart.
items.default_editorial: Vicky Krieps, Tim Roth, and Mia Wasikowska star in this bewitching fable from Mia Hansen-Løve. Shot on Fårö where Ingmar Bergman made some of his greatest films, this sun-kissed voyage sails across the past and the present, fiction and reality, probing the prickly yet romantic process of artmaking.

items.title: Best Secret Place
items.short_synopsis: Every night, characters wake up in a secret place. They don’t know where they are or how they got there. In search for clues on the walls, in the graffiti, they populate the space with their fears, desires and dreams. In this unusual dream-like decor, the melancholy gradually turns into light.
items.default_editorial: Melding the cool aesthetics of video games with a warm humanism, this surreal film compares the existential malaise of its living protagonists with the fates of dead avatars. For directors Caroline Poggi and Jonathan Vinel, winning seems a hollow victory—self-fulfillment is to be found elsewhere.

items.title: Bim, Bam, Boom, Las Luchas Morenas
items.original_title: Bim, Bam, Boom, Las Luchas Morenas
items.short_synopsis: Meet Las Luchas Morenas: three sisters and professional luchadoras who practice Mexico’s national sport of wrestling. When the sisters are off stage, a camera swirls curiously around them, capturing the lively trio’s close bond and how they bring the ethos of Lucha Libre into their personal lives.
items.default_editorial: Following a family of wrestlers in Mexico, Marie Losier’s rousing portrait of sisterhood somersaults between private hijinks and the spectacle of the ring. Commanding the screen with their vivacious energy, these formidable women dare to take up space in a male-dominated sport, one kick at a time.

items.title: Blancanieves
items.short_synopsis: Once upon a time in 1920s Spain, there was a little girl who never knew her mother. She learned the art of bullfighting from her famous father but was despised by her wicked stepmother. When she meets a troupe of dwarfs, she begins an adventure that will lead her to a destiny like no other.
items.default_editorial: The thwarted destinies and evil stepmothers of a Grimm brothers fairy tale are transposed to 1920s Andalucía, at the heart of Spain’s traditions and history, in this dazzling homage to silent cinema. An enchanting cinematic wonder, acting both as a mockery and a celebration of Spanishness.

items.title: Blue Jean
items.short_synopsis: 1988. In a climate of rampant homophobia, PE teacher Jean is forced to live a double life. A respected member of staff during the week; on the weekend she slips into Newcastle’s gay scene. When a new student threatens to expose her, Jean is caught in a dilemma to protect her job and her integrity.
items.default_editorial: Georgia Oakley’s BAFTA-nominated debut tells the stirring tale of a gay woman’s secretive double life. Rosy McEwen’s red-eyed and poignantly understated performance communicates, with great emotional depth, the extent of her struggle to be true to herself in homophobic Thatcher-era Britain.

items.title: Boyhood
items.short_synopsis: After his parents’ marriage falls apart, Mason moves to Houston, Texas with his mom, Olivia, and sister, Samantha. Over twelve years, snapshots of Mason’s life capture him changing from a child into a young man, as he deals with his parents’ divorce and experiences the highs and lows of growing up.
items.default_editorial: Unprecedented in its long-haul production methods, this expansive drama from writer-director Richard Linklater is a coming-of-age tale like no other. Nominated for six Oscars®—including a Supporting Actress win for Patricia Arquette—this is a deeply felt ode to growing pains and parental wisdom.

items.title: Bye Bye Tiberias
items.short_synopsis: Leaving her village to follow her dream of becoming an actress, Hiam Abbass also left behind her mother, grandmother and seven sisters. Thirty years later, her filmmaker daughter Lina returns with her to journey through the vanished places among the scattered memories of four generations.
items.default_editorial: Through touching home videos and tender conversations with her mother, Lina Soualem gently charts the brutal impact of displacement on the Palestinian women in her family. Vanished places and vivid memories intertwine in a moving homage to her elders, honouring both their pains and their desires.

items.title: Carol
items.short_synopsis: An aspiring photographer develops an intimate relationship with an older woman in 1950s New York.
items.default_editorial: One of the most beloved films of this century, Todd Haynes’ Oscar®-nominated Carol is a stunningly directed story of forbidden love. Evoking Douglas Sirk’s lush melodramas, this adaptation of Patricia Highsmith’s novel features intimate and moving performances from Cate Blanchett and Rooney Mara.

items.title: Castle to Castle
items.short_synopsis: Spring 2017, in between the two rounds of the French presidential election. Pierre is a young student living with 75-year-old Francine, who is disabled and wheelchair-bound. Politically and socially opposed, they are perplexed and disoriented as they witness the unfolding electoral spectacle.
items.default_editorial: Fusing fiction and documentary, the first collaboration from the filmmaking duo behind Zero Fucks Given broaches the powerful possibility of intergenerational understanding. While the political storm of divisive rhetoric rages on, two unlikely companions find a safe haven in dialogue and empathy.

items.title: Cinema Paradiso
items.short_synopsis: Salvatore, a famous film director, returns to his hometown for the funeral of the local theater’s film projectionist, Alfredo. He reminisces about his life as a young boy falling in love with cinema.
items.default_editorial: One of the most beloved films in modern international cinema, Giuseppe Tornatore’s nostalgic ode to moviegoing and childhood is suffused with an unwavering romanticism. Winner of the Oscar© for Best Foreign Language Feature, Cinema Paradiso is a heartfelt love letter to cinephiles everywhere.

items.title: Cold War
items.short_synopsis: In post-WWII Poland, Wiktor and Zula fall obsessively and destructively in love. As musicians forced to play into the Soviet propaganda machine, they dream of escaping to the freedom of the West. When a chance to leave for Paris arises, both make a split decision that will mark their lives forever.
items.default_editorial: Peering behind the iron curtain of 1950s Poland, Paweł Pawlikowski’s melancholic, jazzy period piece ruminates on the possibility of borderless love in an ideologically polarized world. An exquisitely shot, black-and-white gem nominated for 3 Academy Awards® including Best Director.

items.title: Collective
items.short_synopsis: In the aftermath of a tragic fire in a Romanian club, burn victims begin dying in hospitals from wounds that were not life threatening. A team of investigative journalists move into action uncovering the mass corruption of the health system and of the state institutions.
items.default_editorial: Following a fatal nightclub fire, Alexander Nanau tracked the furious efforts of journalists and demonstrators to destabilize the malfeasant, incompetent Romanian authorities. Kindred in political spirit to Laura Poitras, this tense and revelatory documentary was nominated for two Academy Awards®.

items.title: Crash
items.short_synopsis: After surviving a brutal car wreck, commercial director James Ballard finds himself slowly descending into a fetishistic underworld of scarred, omnisexual car-crash victims, who find metallic collisions a sexual turn-on and a jolting life force they come to crave.
items.default_editorial: A mysterious object from David Cronenberg, this adaptation of J.G. Ballard’s scandalous novel charts the deepest chasms of human desire. One of the great films of the ’90s, Crash is a transgressive, psychopathological reckoning with sex, death, and the anesthetizing effects of parasitic connection.

items.title: Dead Ringers
items.short_synopsis: Identical twin gynaecologists Beverly and Elliot Mantle routinely trade each others’ identities, lives and even lovers. This ability leads them to a shared relationship with a well-known actress and, ultimately, a physical and psychological tailspin that sends them both to the brink of madness.
items.default_editorial: This expressionist masterpiece from David Cronenberg transposes his career-long preoccupation with bodily disintegration into the realms of the psychological. Featuring a career-best Jeremy Irons in (literally) twin roles, Dead Ringers is a profoundly moving tale of separation anxiety and despair.

items.title: Decision to Leave
items.short_synopsis: From a mountain peak in South Korea, a man plummets to his death. Did he jump, or was he pushed? When detective Hae-joon arrives on the scene, he begins to suspect the dead man’s wife Seo-rae. But as he digs deeper into the investigation, he finds himself trapped in a web of deception and desire.
items.default_editorial: In this seductively twisted, modern romantic thriller, obsession is taken to wondrous and vertiginous extremes. Without a doubt one of the most electrifying minds working in cinema today, Park Chan-wook won the Best Director award at Cannes for his sumptuous, Hitchcockian masterwork.

items.title: Domain
items.short_synopsis: Teenager Pierre spends all his time with his aunt Nadia, a flamboyant mathematician. The anarchy that reigns in Nadia’s life fascinates Pierre, who is coming to terms with his sexuality. But Nadia is a wounded soul, dependent on alcohol—and little by little, she slips away…
items.default_editorial: Like a lonely black cat in the night, a philosophical Béatrice Dalle stalks the streets and the dance clubs of Bordeaux in Patric Chiha’s volatile debut. Swinging between euphoria and total self-destruction, this portrait of a woman on a downward spiral grapples with the paradoxes of addiction.

items.title: Dry Trip
items.short_synopsis: After yet another sleepless night of partying and getting high, Jordane returns home to find her little sister anxious about a strange water cut. Realizing the drinking water shortage affects the entire city, Jordane embarks on a delirious on-foot journey across Marseille to quench their thirst.
items.default_editorial: Drought sends this neon-tinged short careening forward through winding Marseille streets, toward the glinting sea. Fish-eye lenses, flashy colors, and thumping electronic music capture post-rave meltdown and the unrelenting restlessness of young generations growing up in a world on fire.

items.title: Elle
items.short_synopsis: Michèle seems untouchable. Helming a powerful video game empire, she controls everything—including her emotions. When she’s attacked at home by a masked stranger, she refuses to be shaken. Instead, she tracks him down, and a dangerous game begins, threatening to spiral out of control at any time.
items.default_editorial: Perhaps the most daring provocation from director Paul Verhoeven, this tricky, thorny thriller successfully prevails in an audacious performance from the fearless Isabelle Huppert. A satire of contemporary France, and a study of the complex, often opaque, and always agentive character at its centre.

items.title: Ennio
items.short_synopsis: As legendary composer Ennio Morricone reflects on his six-decade career, collaborators like Quentin Tarantino and Dario Argento, along with admirers such as Hans Zimmer, Bruce Springsteen, and Joan Baez, offer insights into his groundbreaking music and enduring cultural legacy.
items.default_editorial: In this engrossing documentary, Giuseppe Tornatore pays heartfelt tribute to legendary film composer and collaborator Ennio Morricone. While the maestro regales us with vivid accounts of his life and art, colleagues and famous fans—from Clint Eastwood to Bruce Springsteen—reflect on his legacy.

items.title: eXistenZ
items.short_synopsis: After unveiling her new virtual-reality project eXistenZ, superstar game designer Allegra is attacked by an anti-gaming group. She is rescued by Ted, and insists that they play the game to know if it has been damaged. They soon find out that their sense of reality can become dangerously distorted.
items.default_editorial: A true thriller for the virtual reality age! Landing in cinemas alongside The Matrix, Cronenberg rewired his cult classic Videodrome for the world of video games, creating a quintessential 90s mind-bender that stared down the millennium with paranoid eyes. Starring Jude Law and Jennifer Jason Leigh.

items.title: Félicité
items.short_synopsis: Félicité, free and proud, is a singer in the evenings in a bar in Kinshasa. Her life changes when her 14-year-old son is the victim of a motorcycle accident. To save him, she begins a frantic race through the streets of an electric Kinshasa, a world of music and dreams.
items.default_editorial: A headstrong yet vulnerable, playful yet vehement woman is the indelible titular character in Alain Gomis’s Silver Bear winner, shot on location in Kinshasa. Lifted by performances from renowned Congolese artists, Félicité pushes against the weight of poverty with the exuberant energy of music.

items.title: Flee
items.short_synopsis: Amin Nawabi, a 36-year-old high-achieving academic, grapples with a painful secret he has kept hidden for 20 years, the story of his journey as a child refugee from Afghanistan. This traumatic past threatens to derail the life he has built for himself and his soon to be husband.
items.default_editorial: Nominated for three Oscars® and a BAFTA—following its Grand Jury Prize win at Sundance—Jonas Poher Rasmussen’s uniquely animated documentary contains multitudes. At once a queer coming-of-age story, and a harrowing examination of the refugee experience, Flee is a remarkable tale of human resilience.

items.title: Free Jimmy
items.short_synopsis: Roy Arnie works at a touring circus, where the star attraction is Jimmy, an elephant kept on a cocktail of drugs. Roy’s dream is to run his own circus, and Jimmy is the key. A bungled attempt to give the elephant his “fix” leads to his escape, jump-starting a cross-country road trip to find him.
items.default_editorial: A totally irreverent, politically incorrect Norwegian animated film with something of a cult status in its country: the absurd Free Jimmy contains all manner of animal cruelty, making evident that beasts often walk on two legs. With the voices of Woody Harrelson and Simon Pegg.

items.title: Full Moon in Paris
items.original_title: Les nuits de la pleine lune
items.short_synopsis: Fed up with the suburbs and her sweet, steady boyfriend, young interior decorator Louise independently decides to take a pied-à-terre apartment in Paris where she can sample the single life, which includes dealing with the come-ons of her indefatigable friend, Octave.
items.default_editorial: French New Wave director Éric Rohmer always manages to capture the essence of his films’ characters and their time and place. The bracing, contemporary energy of hip ‘80s Paris is perfectly distilled by this fizzing tale of a young woman’s liberation, led by the utterly enchanting Pascale Ogier.

items.title: Ganja & Hess
items.short_synopsis: Anthropologist Hess Green is stabbed with an ancient ceremonial dagger by his unstable assistant—blessing him with immortality but cursing him with a thirst for blood. When the assistant’s outspoken wife, Ganja, comes searching for her vanished husband, she and Hess form an unexpected partnership.
items.default_editorial: How many ideas can fit into a low-budget movie about ancient curses?  Proving how thin the line between B-movies and art can be, Ganja & Hess takes a horror flick premise and turns it into a complex, passionate act of provocation.  A “blaxploitation” classic, now restored to its original version!

items.title: Ginger and Rosa
items.short_synopsis: London, 1962. Two teenage girls are inseparable; they play truant together, discuss religion, politics, hairstyles, and dream of lives bigger than their mothers’ domesticity. But, as the Cold War meets the sexual revolution, and with the threat of nuclear holocaust, their friendship is threatened.
items.default_editorial: Sally Potter’s explosive portrait of adolescent girlhood takes place amid a charged atmosphere of Cold War paranoia and ban-the-bomb marches. Realized on the cosy conventional canvas of the coming-of-age film, Ginger and Rosa is an unsuspectingly incisive look at the political unrest of the 1960s.

items.title: Girl
items.short_synopsis: Teenage Lara dreams of becoming a ballerina. She’s just relocated city to attend a top ballet school and, as she’s in the early stages of gender transition, has newly enrolled in the girls’ class. While pushing herself to keep up with the other girls, Lara also struggles with her hormone therapy.
items.default_editorial: Inspired by a true story, the debut feature from director Lukas Dhont follows the physical and emotional hurdles of a young, ambitious ballet dancer. Winner of the Camera d’Or, this gripping drama sparked debate after its Cannes premiere, but remains a visceral portrait of growing up trans.

items.title: Girl in the Window
items.short_synopsis: After an accident in a Dutch coal mine, Italian workers Vincenzo and Federico travel to Amsterdam. In the red-light district, they spend the weekend with two sex workers, Else and Cori. What begins as a fleeting escape turns into entanglements that leave Vincenzo reconsidering his return home.
items.default_editorial: Cowritten by Pasolini and starring Lino Ventura, Luciano Emmer’s tender drama portrays the lives of miners and sex workers with unparalleled empathy. Moving between blackened coal tunnels and bawdy bars, this neorealist gem offers a humanist vision of class solidarity under capitalist exploitation.

items.title: God's Offices
items.short_synopsis: In a self-help center for family planning, female teenagers and women of all ages and from different sections of society are looking for help. Five counselors speak to these women batting with difficult decisions around contraception, virginity, abortion, and the taboo of sexuality within families.
items.default_editorial: Cast alongside a starry cohort of French actresses, Béatrice Dalle shows a softer side to her screen image in Claire Simon’s tender drama about family planning. Structured around the safe space of consultation sessions, God’s Offices foregrounds the unseen interpersonal dimensions of social work.

items.title: Her Smell
items.short_synopsis: Becky Something is a destructive punk rock icon whose erratic behavior alienates bandmates, family, and fans. Across five turbulent chapters—raging performances, backstage meltdowns, and fragile sobriety—she teeters between collapse and recovery, chasing the creative spark that once made her a star.
items.default_editorial: Odorous with moth-eaten delusions of genius and greatness gone rancid, Alex Ross Perry’s take on a toxic music industry is magnetic: it repulses as much as it thrills. Channeling wicked-witch poison into the role of wasted rocker, Elisabeth Moss weds herself to darkness with exhilarating flair.

items.title: High and Low
items.original_title: 天国と地獄 | Tengoku to jigoku
items.short_synopsis: As Kingo Gondo finally gathers all his assets to become the majority shareholder of his company, he receives shocking news: his chauffeur’s son has been kidnapped, and a huge ransom is demanded. Gondo is faced with a moral dilemma: can he sacrifice his entire fortune to save another man’s child?
items.default_editorial: A masterclass in tension and incisive social commentary, Akira Kurosawa’s sharp hybrid of chamber drama and police procedural is unquestionably one of the most dazzling thrillers ever made. Each immaculately composed shot is a rich evocation of the class conflict set forth in the film’s title.

items.title: Hit the Road
items.short_synopsis: An unorthodox family of four—two parents and their quiet adult son and hyperactive six-year-old boy—drive across the Iranian countryside. Over the course of the trip, they bond over memories of the past, grapple with fears of the unknown, and fuss over their sick dog.
items.default_editorial: Recalling the poetic realism of Abbas Kiarostami and his father Jafar Panahi, Panah Panahi’s sensational debut uproariously speeds through the picturesque terrains of northern Iran. Full of laughter and songs, this heartfelt family road trip embodies the unconditional love that stands against harm.

items.title: Hyenas
items.short_synopsis: Dramaan Drameh is a respected, convivial shopkeeper in the tiny village of Colobane. But a forgotten act of cruelty committed thirty years in his past comes back to haunt him when the young girl he impregnated and abandoned returns seeking revenge.
items.default_editorial: Visionary director Djibril Diop Mambéty (Touki Bouki) makes a feisty assault on economic imperialism in this loose adaptation of Friedrich Durrenmatt’s play, The Visit. Relocated to a Senegalese town, Hyenas is a comic, cutting critique of globalization conveyed with playful, imaginative flourish.

items.title: I Do Not Care If We Go Down in History as Barbarians
items.original_title: Îmi este indiferent daca în istorie vom intra ca barbari
items.short_synopsis: Mariana, an outspoken young artist, is planning an ambitious play reconstructing the anti-Semitic 1941 Odessa Massacre. But resentment among the extras and authorities wanting to censor the spectacle are standing in the way. The performance, conceived as a wake-up call, slowly turns into a farce.
items.default_editorial: This powerfully topical drama from Romanian New Wave director Radu Jude (Scarred Hearts) explores if and how an artist can address the dark side of their country’s history. In the era of fake news and historical suppression, Jude has made a scintillating story about the debate over art’s purpose.

items.title: Ikiru
items.short_synopsis: After learning that his stomach cancer has left him with less than a year to live, a Tokyo bureaucrat struggles to reconcile with his impending death and begins looking for ways to make his remaining days meaningful.
items.default_editorial: A more intimate film if compared to Akira Kurosawa’s epics, Ikiru is a heartfelt ode to the act of living one’s life to the fullest. Starring the director’s regular collaborator Takashi Shimura, this moving drama succeeds for the simple yet deeply resonant story that lies at its very heart.

items.title: Incendies
items.short_synopsis: Twins Simon and Jeanne visit a notary to hear their mother’s will and are surprised to find that they have a brother and that their father is still alive. They travel to an unnamed Middle Eastern country where they discover that the fortunes of their family were determined by the region’s conflicts.
items.default_editorial: Before he became one of the biggest names in blockbuster filmmaking, Denis Villeneuve scored an Oscar® nod for Best Foreign Language Film with this visceral thriller. Tracing the indelible scars of war across oceans and generations, Incendies is a globetrotting mystery of singular emotional power.

items.title: John From
items.short_synopsis: In the heat of summer, teens Rita and Sara hang out by their building, chatting, listening to music, sipping coffee on the terrace, and roaming supermarkets. But when Rita visits the exhibition of their new neighbor—an explorer wrapped in a haze of exotic fantasies—her world is turned upside down.
items.default_editorial: João Nicolau has become one of the most exciting voices in contemporary Portuguese cinema. This dreamy coming-of-age fairy tale is cast in both epic and intimate proportions—just like the flutters of first love. A truly original, delightfully tropical ode to adolescence and the escape into fantasy.

items.title: Kaili Blues
items.original_title: Lu bian ye can | 路边野餐
items.short_synopsis: Chen, a preoccupied doctor working in a small clinic in the rain-drenched city of Kaili, decides to fulfill his late mother’s wish and sets off on a journey to look for his brother’s abandoned child. His partner in the clinic, a lonely old lady, asks him to also find her former lover.
items.default_editorial: This remarkable debut is formed by a playful structure, rich characters, and one of the most beguiling long takes in modern cinema. Kaili Blues is a dreamy rumination into a nation’s past and the eternal grip tradition has on contemporary life. Winner of the Best New Director award at Locarno.

items.title: Killer Joe
items.short_synopsis: When Chris is in debt to a drug lord, he decides to hire a hit man to kill his mother, whose life insurance policy is supposed to go to his sister Dottie. Chris has heard of crazy Dallas cop Joe Cooper, who moonlights as a contract killer. But Joe demands to take Dottie as carnal collateral.
items.default_editorial: You’ll never look at fried chicken the same way again after this wickedly funny thriller from the late, great William Friedkin. With a screenplay by Tracy Letts, and a magnificently unhinged central performance from Matthew McConaughey, Killer Joe is equal parts Southern Gothic and twisted neo-noir.

items.title: Kings of the Road
items.short_synopsis: A roving film projector repairman saves the life of a depressed psychologist who has driven his car into a river. They end up on the road together, traveling from one rural German movie theater to another. Along the way, the two men, each running from his past, bond over their shared loneliness.
items.default_editorial: A landmark film from the New German Cinema, Wenders’s iconic road movie offers up a cool portrait of post-war Germany—and its cinemas—through two lonely, sensitive souls. Photographed in sumptuous black-and-white by legendary cinematographer Robby Müller, the film was also dedicated to Fritz Lang!

items.title: L'Amour Fou
items.short_synopsis: Claire, an actress, is happily married to Sébastien, a director. But when she struggles to embody Hermione in the play Andromaque, Sébastien abruptly replaces her with his ex-wife. As rehearsals progress, life slowly imitates fiction, and Claire descends into a devastating madness.
items.default_editorial: With wounds of a failed revolution still raw, Jacques Rivette holds a cracked mirror to the aftermath of ’68 in this potent film. What starts as play soon falls into frenzied cacophony, as Bulle Ogier stuns in a performance that encapsulates the tragic loss of meaning for an entire generation.

items.title: L'heure Exquise
items.short_synopsis: Filmmaker René Allio narrates the story of his family—Italian immigrants who came to work on Marseille’s construction sites. Against the backdrop of scenes from neighborhoods such as the Le Panier and La Belle de Mai, his voiceover recounts childhood memories and personal anecdotes from his city.
items.default_editorial: Exploring the branches of his own family tree, Marseille-born director René Allio finds them intimately intertwined with the fascinating history of the sunny port city. As wistful narration combines with pastel cinematography and gentle sound design, stories of the past echo tenderly in the present.

items.title: Mandibles
items.short_synopsis: When Manu is hired to deliver a mysterious box, he takes Jean-Gab along for the ride. But when the simple-minded friends find a giant fly trapped in the boot of a car they stole, they name it Dominique—and decide to train it in the hope of making a ton of cash.
