items.default_editorial: Master absurdist Quentin Dupieux tackles the buddy movie genre with this lively tale of two endearingly daft fools trying to pull off multiple illogical cons, including trying to train a giant fly to rob banks. A gonzo comic turn from Adèle Exarchopoulos counts among the film’s baffling delights.

items.title: Marius and Jeannette
items.short_synopsis: Marius is the keeper of an abandoned cement works staying high above the quarter of l’Estaque in Marseilles. Jeannette is bringing up her two children alone with her poor checkout operator salary. Their meeting won’t be without trouble.
items.default_editorial: This tender and funny story of middle-aged love finds its titular protagonists deeply embedded in their lively working-class community. Between maternal histrionics, macho posturing, and neighborly gossip, Marseille-born director Robert Guédiguian detects true emotion, and a kind of wisdom too.

items.title: Marseille
items.short_synopsis: Young photographer Sophie swaps apartments to get away from Berlin. Alone in Marseille, she struggles to capture its essence until an encounter with a local mechanic, Pierre, helps her find her footing. The more she surrenders to the bustling city, the more impossible her former life begins to feel.
items.default_editorial: While trying to grasp the mysterious nature of a world ruled by chance with impressive formal precision, Marseille oozes with serene ambiguity revealing the almost ethereal soul of Angela Schanelec’s work. A quietly radical drama that experiments with cinema’s narrative tools to hypnotic effect.

items.title: Matthias & Maxime
items.short_synopsis: Two childhood best friends are asked to share a kiss for the purposes of a student short film. Soon, a lingering doubt sets in, confronting both of them with their preferences, threatening the brotherhood of their social circle, and, eventually, changing their lives.
items.default_editorial: Xavier Dolan’s sparkling drama features the beloved director before the camera in a touching role. Dolan co-stars in this tender, heartfelt story of a friendship between men from different classes that is challenged by the possibility of separation—and attraction.

items.title: Memories of Murder
items.short_synopsis: A sadistic serial rapist and murderer of young women terrorizes a small province in 1980s South Korea. To prevent further crimes, three increasingly desperate detectives with conflicting methods race against time to unravel the violent mind of the killer in a futile effort to solve the case.
items.default_editorial: Based on the horrifying case of the Korean Zodiac Killer, Bong Joon Ho’s acclaimed thriller strikingly evokes a mood of apathy amid the lonely countryside populated by mysterious tunnels and reed fields. The director’s now-signature weaving of brutal violence and dark humor made this a smash hit!

items.title: Menus-Plaisirs Les Troisgros
items.short_synopsis: Founded in 1930 and holding three Michelin stars for over 50 years, the Troisgros family restaurant sees Michel and Marie-Pierre passing their craft to their sons. From bustling markets to meticulous kitchens, their culinary world unfolds in step with the seasons and shared devotion.
items.default_editorial: Frederick Wiseman is at his most rapturous in this mouthwatering deconstruction of a French haute-cuisine mecca. The legendary documentarian luxuriates in displays of culinary craft, while his precise juxtaposition of staff and clientele raises complex questions about consumption and labor.

items.title: Métamorphoses
items.short_synopsis: When Europe skips class to climb aboard an eight-wheel truck with a magnetic young man named Jupiter, little does she know of the journey of initiation that lies ahead of her. Just off the side of the motorway lies a land inhabited by powerful gods…
items.default_editorial: A cornucopia of Greek myth, this resplendent twist on the Hellenic pastoral makes an Arcadia of the edge-lands of contemporary France. At this cloudless crossroads of antiquity and monopoly capitalism, scenes of lovemaking and encounters with divinities flow together like a fresco brought to life.

items.title: Mid90s
items.short_synopsis: In 1990s suburban LA, Stevie is a shy thirteen-year-old skateboarding enthusiast who spends his time outside to escape his troubled family life. He soon befriends older skaters who take him under their wing, making Stevie’s summer one of many firsts, transgressions, and newfound freedoms.
items.default_editorial: More than a decade after his iconic performance in Superbad, Jonah Hill moves behind the camera with this ode to friendship as the source of true solace. Nostalgia permeates the celluloid texture of this exhilarating, heart-warming coming-of-age film that tenderly reclaims male vulnerability.

items.title: Mundane History
items.short_synopsis: Ake returns to his family home after an accident leaves him paralyzed from the waist down. A male nurse, Pun, is hired to care for Ake, whose hatred of his father has now grown into a hatred of the world at large. Friendship slowly build between them, and Ake begins to discover a new peace within.
items.default_editorial: Uncle Boonmee may have given the fertile Thai cinema scene its biggest moment in the international spotlight, but it’s only the tip of the iceberg!  Witness Mundane History, winner of the Tiger Award at Rotterdam, as it explodes cinematic convention with color and mystery.

items.title: Neighbouring Sounds
items.short_synopsis: In Recife, on the Brazilian coast, residents of a flourishing neighborhood go about their quiet lives until their routines are disrupted by the arrival of a private security company. The company’s presence brings a sense of safety to some and tension to others, as power dynamics gradually emerge.
items.default_editorial: The acclaimed Neighboring Sounds is critic-turned-filmmaker Kleber Mendonça Filho’s feature debut. Subtly commenting on class relations in Brazil through the city of Recife’s ominous sounds, it is a sensorial and unique piece of filmmaking, evoking a state of torpor hanging in the hot, heavy air.

items.title: Night of the Kings
items.short_synopsis: When a young man named Roman is sent to an infamous lawless prison in the middle of the Ivorian forest, he is chosen to participate in a storytelling ritual. Roman begins to narrate the mystical life of a legendary outlaw to make his story last until dawn and give himself any chance of survival.
items.default_editorial: Storytelling is a matter of life and death in this singular drama, which melds raw realism with folkloric lyricism. Grippingly unpredictable, the film proves the historical, psychological, and social power of such tales, as the facts of postcolonial Côte d’Ivoire are transfigured into myth.

items.title: Nobody's Hero
items.short_synopsis: Clermont-Ferrand, central France. Médéric meets and falls in love with middle-aged sex worker Isadora, who is married. When the city center is the scene of a terrorist attack, Selim, a young, homeless guy, provokes a wave of paranoia by taking refuge in Médéric’s building.
items.default_editorial: Making bedfellows of sex, death, and hospitality is hardly extraordinary in French cinema, but Alain Guiraudie does it with a bluntness that turns heads. Finding farce in Islamophobia, this romp pokes fun at the scaremongering that, one newsflash after another, screws with a nation’s psyche.

items.title: Oslo, August 31st
items.short_synopsis: Recovering drug addict Anders is given a day’s leave from his rehab center to apply for a job in the city. Over the course of one day and night, he tries to reconnect with his old friends and family in Oslo, where the ghosts of his past mistakes wrestle with the hope to see some future by morning.
items.default_editorial: A reworking of Louis Malle’s New Wave classic The Fire Within, Joachim Trier’s Cannes hit about a young man’s fade-out is a triumph of sensitive insight and observation, a smart, sharp portrait that even finds within its heavy subject matter the chance for warmth.

items.title: Ostia
items.short_synopsis: Bandiera and Rabbino are two brothers who live in a seaside town near Rome, traumatized by their childhood memories of their abusive father. One day, a group of men find a woman lying unconscious and carry her to the brothers. The three of them embark upon a game exploring attraction and repulsion.
items.default_editorial: Sergio Citti and Pier Paolo Pasolini had been collaborating on scripts for over a decade when the formidable duo mounted this savage satire of 20th-century Italy. Circling around an anarchic ménage à trois, Citti’s inspired directorial debut takes blistering aim at all corners of modern society.

items.title: Our Body
items.short_synopsis: Claire Simon observes the everyday operations of the gynecological ward in a public hospital in Paris. She meets patients in all stages of life—young and old, cisgender and trans. Unique stories of fertility, gender transitions, and cancer unfold, including the one of the filmmaker herself.
items.default_editorial: Compassionate towards its subjects, this critically acclaimed film by Claire Simon explores the issue of women’s health. With an all-female crew and an empathetic eye, the renowned documentarian assembles a deeply invested study that demystifies the bodies we hold in common, across our differences.

items.title: Paris, Texas
items.short_synopsis: Travis walks out of the Texas desert after disappearing for four years. He is picked up by his brother Walt, who has been looking after Travis’ son Hunter. After slowly reconnecting with Hunter, Travis tries to bring his family back together by traveling to Houston in search of his estranged wife.
items.default_editorial: In 1984, German New Wave icon Wim Wenders swept up at Cannes with his dreamy tale of the American southwest. Powered by an eloquent script from playwright Sam Shepard—and starring Harry Dean Stanton, Dean Stockwell & Nastassja Kinski—it casts a doleful, poetic eye on America as only an outsider can.

items.title: Poison Friends
items.short_synopsis: When the new college year starts, Eloi and Alexandre encounter André, the most brilliant student in the lecture theater. Fascinated by his ease and charisma, they quickly fall under his spell: André then offers them his friendship in exchange for complete loyalty to him.
items.default_editorial: This satire of university pretension is filled with tortured passions and friendships, whose dry wit and subtle mania place it somewhere between Evelyn Waugh and Alfred Hitchcock. Emmanuel Bourdieu won the Grand Prize and the screenwriting award at Cannes Critics Week for his highly literary film.

items.title: Princes and Princesses
items.short_synopsis: Each night, two children meet in an abandoned theater. With the help of an old technician, they dress up and invent stories in which they play the main roles. Through shadow theater, they tell six whimsical tales, each revealing different kinds of love: tender, tumultuous, enchanted, or forbidden.
items.default_editorial: A dazzling celebration of the transporting power of the imagination, Michel Ocelot’s treasure chest of a film collects subversive tales of romance and magic. Expressive silhouettes cut through backdrops of radiant color, as the film puts a playful spin on age-old archetypes and myths.

items.title: Radio-Serpent
items.short_synopsis: In a futuristic Parisian apartment, five silent characters move beneath strobing lights to a robotic music score. A blue-eyed girl dressed in bold 1980s fashion reappears frequently. She plays songs from a jukebox, lounges on a couch, and finds herself surrounded by colorful falling balloons.
items.default_editorial: Wearing an ice-cool expression—and chic outfits from fashion house Nina Ricci—Pascale Ogier is the exquisite center in this stylish short from experimental filmmaker Unglee. Amid a whirl of kaleidoscopic lights and radio-static sound effects, the actress’s face becomes as magnetic as an objet d’art.

items.title: Revolver
items.short_synopsis: Cipriani, the deputy warden of Milan’s prison, is blackmailed by his wife’s kidnappers. Forced to help a French thug, Milo Ruiz, escape, he soon realizes they are both just pawns in a vast conspiracy involving politics, the police, and a plot to assassinate an oil tycoon.
items.default_editorial: Fleeced against bitter cold and the depravity of Italy’s Years of Lead, Oliver Reed brings salt and grit to this twisty poliziottesco. Featured years later in Quentin Tarantino’s Inglourious Basterds, the romantic strains of Ennio Morricone’s score soar over snowcapped Alps into Haussmannian Paris.

items.title: Rodeo
items.short_synopsis: Julia, a young misfit who is passionate about riding, meets a crew of dirt riders who fly along at full speed and perform stunts. She sets about infiltrating their male-dominated world, but an accident jeopardizes her ability to fit in.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Un Certain Regard jury’s Coup de Coeur at Cannes, this daredevil crime caper is the feature directorial debut from Lola Quivoron. With its unique setting in the world of motorcycle stunt-riders, Rodeo is a suspenseful urban drama that tears through genre expectations at full throttle.

items.title: Rotting in the Sun
items.short_synopsis: After encountering social media celebrity Jordan Firstman at a gay nudist beach, Sebastián Silva reluctantly agrees to direct his new project. But when Sebastián goes missing, Jordan embarks on a wild, quasi-detective journey through Mexico City.
items.default_editorial: Getting sucked into an infinite loop of drugs, men and dizzying mystery? That’s one cure for writer’s block! Frolicking and squabbling across the beaches, clubs, and rooftops of Mexico, Sebastián Silva and Jordan Firstman play hilarious versions of themselves in this absurd and sexy meta-comedy.

items.title: Saint Louis Blues
items.short_synopsis: At the end of summer, six impatient travelers are in a rush to leave Dakar for Saint-Louis. Through the long taxi journey, with its intense heat and overcrowded routes, these passengers, who seemingly have nothing in common, unite their destinies by turning their life stories into songs.
items.default_editorial: Born in Paris but of Senegalese descent, acclaimed director Dyana Gaye returns to her heritage of transit in this freewheeling film. Oral storytelling tradition weaves with the spirit of Jacques Demy—but put those umbrellas away! This is a musical road trip that shines under the radiant African sun.

items.title: Samia
items.short_synopsis: Samia, a teen from an Algerian family living on the outskirts of Marseille, must navigate the constraints of her repressive older brother, while also facing the prejudices of close-minded locals. Stifled, Samia takes matters into her own hands to shape the future she desires.
items.default_editorial: Painting a polyphonic portrait of a first- and second-generation immigrant family, Philippe Faucon locates the crux of multiple tensions in the rebellious young woman of the title. With dynamic realism rather than cold didacticism, the director lets his clear-eyed protagonist tell it like it is.

items.title: Scanners
items.short_synopsis: A race of telepaths with the ability to ‘scan’ other humans can read people’s thoughts, control their movement and even take over their consciousness. Most Scanners are harmless, but one Scanner with bad intentions becomes hellbent on building a psychic army to take over the world.
items.default_editorial: Leaving behind the domestic agonies of The Brood, David Cronenberg topped the US box office for the first time with his most direct foray into science fiction. An action-packed tale of embattled, telekinetic brothers and exploding heads, Scanners is a thrilling fusion of the sensual and cerebral.

items.title: Sexy Beast
items.short_synopsis: Gal Dove, a retired safe-cracker, is living the good life on the southern Spanish Coast. One day his past appears in the form of former associate Don Logan, whose reputation as the most psychopathic gangster in the London underworld is a sign of very bad things to come.
items.default_editorial: Jonathan Glazer’s debut casts an offbeat look at English ex-pats in Spain in this eerie yet extravagant take on the Brit-flick. Perfectly capturing the sleazy sheen of Costa del Sol’s criminal underworld, Sexy Beast’s cast of gangsters and geezers boasts a brilliant Ben Kingsley and Ray Winstone.

items.title: Slacker
items.short_synopsis: A day in the life of eccentric young people in 1990s Austin, Texas. In a series of loosely connected vignettes, a merry-go-round of amateur philosophers, jilted lovers, inept criminals, aspiring artists, and whacked-out conspiracy theorists searches for a place in society.
items.default_editorial: Before Dazed and Confused and Before Midnight, Richard Linklater debuted with perhaps his most inventive film, defying traditional narratives in favor of a series of offbeat, witty, gently surreal vignettes.  Shot for a mere $3,000, this is one of the essential landmarks of American indie film!

items.title: The American Friend
items.short_synopsis: Jonathan Zimmerman, a picture framer who suffers from a fatal disease, crosses paths with Tom Ripley, who trafficks forged artworks. Drawn into an underworld of shady gangsters, Zimmerman is tempted to commit murder for a sum of money that would ensure the welfare of his family after his death.
items.default_editorial: Wim Wenders meets Patricia Highsmith! The New German Cinema master tackles the famed mystery writer in this rugged gem of a thriller, starring a reliably wild-eyed Dennis Hopper as the notorious Tom Ripley—and with precious appearances by Nicholas Ray, Samuel Fuller, and Jean Eustache as gangsters.

items.title: The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye
items.original_title: The Ballad of Genesis and Lady Jaye
items.short_synopsis: A major artistic figure of New York’s avant-garde and industrial music, Genesis Breyer P-Orridge and their wife and creative partner Lady Jaye, began a series of surgeries in 2000 to resemble one another. This bold, ambitious, and subversive act of love aimed to create a third ‘pandrogynous’ being.
items.default_editorial: Can two become one? That is just one question asked this intimate and impressionistic look at by the art and life of Throbbing Gristle and Psychic TV founder Genesis Breyer P-Orridge and his partner, Lady Jaye. Their aspiration to unite bodies and art is a paean as much to creation as it is to love.

items.title: The Basilisks
items.short_synopsis: In a small, poverty-stricken village in the South of Italy, Antonio, Francesco, and Sergio are three unemployed young men with uneventful lives. They while their time away roaming the streets and chasing girls, constantly hatching half-hearted plans but hopelessly trapped in their own lethargy.
items.default_editorial: Ten years after Federico Fellini’s I Vitelloni, Lina Wertmüller crafted her own striking portrait of Italian youth in limbo. Marked by righteous anger at the plight of these smart but aimless men, this compassionate debut feature has its director’s flair for tragicomedy already in full view.

items.title: The Beast in the Jungle
items.short_synopsis: Over twenty-five years, in a huge nightclub, a man and woman wait for a mysterious event to take place. While they hold out in silence, everything around them is loud and in motion. From 1979 to 2004, from disco to techno, years pass as the duo wait and watch the world from the sidelines.
items.default_editorial: Losing track of time on the dancefloor is one thing. Slipping between decades with the change of a song is another. Narrated in husky tones by the iconic Béatrice Dalle, this tale of star-crossed lovers brings an enigmatic sci-fi edge to Henry James’s source novella as it sways to eclectic beats.

items.title: The Bird with the Crystal Plumage
items.short_synopsis: Sam, an American writer living in Rome, witnesses a brutal attack on a woman in an art gallery. As he grows obsessed with the incident, he is convinced that something he saw holds the key to identifying the maniac terrorizing the city. He launches his own investigation, heedless of the danger ahead.
items.default_editorial: We love the frightening yet exuberant cinema of maverick auteur and giallo maestro Dario Argento. His ludicrously titled thriller masterwork may well be one of cinema’s greatest debuts, with lavish cinematography by Vittorio Storaro (Apocalypse Now) and Ennio Morricone’s unforgettable score.

items.title: The Brood
items.short_synopsis: Frank is becoming concerned about his wife’s secretive treatment at the Institute of Psychoplasmics. The doctor’s controversial methods unleash his patients’ rage, taking on physical manifestations. Frank investigates the institute while a series of brutal attacks are committed by mutant children.
items.default_editorial: The closest he’s come to making a classic horror film, The Brood is David Cronenberg’s most personal feature. Written in the throes of divorce, this Freudian nightmare casts a cold eye on a broken relationship’s open sores, lethally personified in its rampaging manifestations of the maternal id.

items.title: The Color Wheel
items.short_synopsis: JR, an aspiring news-anchor, forces her younger brother Colin to embark on a road trip to move her belongings out of her professor-turned-lover’s place. Traveling through New England, they uncomfortably run into old school-mates or revisit familial history from which they have long since diverged.
items.default_editorial: Before Listen Up Philip, Queen of Earth, and Her Smell, indie director Alex Ross Perry grabbed our attention with this wonderfully acerbic second feature. An uproariously abrasive, fast-paced comedy road movie about a hyper dysfunctional brother-sister duo, shot on gorgeous 16mm B&W film.

items.title: The Eternal Daughter
items.short_synopsis: Julie, a filmmaker out of inspiration, retreats with her elderly mother to a secluded manor in the English countryside — a place her mother once knew in her youth. Julie is soon unsettled by the strange atmosphere and a growing sense that an unspeakable secret haunts the house.
items.default_editorial: Doors creak and things go bump in the night in The Eternal Daughter, but the ghosts of Joanna Hogg’s haunted-house film are as poignant as they are chilling. Tilda Swinton’s bravura dual performance brings to life a fraught familial bond, as untold regrets and stifled memories linger in the walls.

items.title: The Farewell
items.original_title: 別告訴她 | Bié Gàosù Tā
items.short_synopsis: Billi, a headstrong Chinese-American writer returns to China when her beloved grandmother is diagnosed with terminal cancer. She struggles with her family’s decision to keep Grandma in the dark about her own illness as they all stage an impromptu wedding to see Grandma one last time.
items.default_editorial: Lulu Wang’s Sundance breakout is a bittersweet indie hit gently exploring dueling cultural identities through the lens of a Chinese American woman. A deeply personal story for Wang, this emotionally resonant comedy-drama deftly swings back and forth between joy and grief.

items.title: The Nature of Love
items.short_synopsis: Sophia, a 40-year-old philosophy professor, is in a stable—if somewhat socially conforming—relationship with Xavier. Sylvain is a craftsman, renovating Sophia and Xavier’s new country house. When Sophia and Sylvain meet, Sophia’s world is turned upside down. Opposites attract, but can they last?
items.default_editorial: Following her audacious Babysitter, Monia Chokri continues to flip the script on genre conventions with this smart and sexy romantic comedy. Bathed in a warm, hazy glow reminiscent of 1970s cinema classics, lusty entanglements and philosophical conundrums have never looked so swooningly erotic.

items.title: The Quiet Family
items.short_synopsis: Having left Seoul to open an inn in the mountains, the Kang family finds business disappointingly slow as they wait anxiously for customers. But when their first guest winds up dead, it’s only the beginning of a run of seriously bad luck, as everyone who checks in meets a similarly grisly fate…
items.default_editorial: From Oldboy’s Choi Min-sik to Parasite’s Song Kang-ho, this 1990s horror flick assembles a cracking ensemble cast to put an enjoyably farcical spin on the classic cabin-in-the-woods story. Delivering kills and wacky thrills, Kim Jee-woon’s hit comedy spawned remakes in Japan, India, and beyond.

items.title: The Sign of Leo
items.short_synopsis: In anticipation of an inheritance from a recently deceased aunt, a Paris-based American, born under the sign of Leo and confident that luck is on his side, freely wracks up debts only to find himself in dire straits when his windfall fails to materialize.
items.default_editorial: Rohmer’s debut feature lucidly conjures Parisian ’50s bohemia, uncovering the trials that buffet an artist in the face of an often-cruel world. Produced by Chabrol (and with a cheeky cameo from Godard!), this New Wave drama may not have been a commercial success yet it won the hearts of cinephiles.

items.title: The Summer Movie
items.short_synopsis: It’s summer. Philippe is driving with his friend Aurélien and his nine-year-old son, Balthazar. No one gives a damn about the people on vacation, highway rest stops, or the August light, and that dismays Philippe. He wants to leave this world, but Balthazar holds him back.
items.default_editorial: In Emmanuel Marre’s sun-kissed short—winner of the prestigious Prix Jean Vigo—summer tastes of ripe fruit, salty seawater, and bittersweet ennui. Heading for the scenic South of France, this spirited road trip glows with the warmth of unexpected friendship, as kids and adults trade life lessons.

items.title: The Triplets of Belleville
items.short_synopsis: Kidnapped by mysterious henchmen, a Tour de France cyclist named Champion is spirited across the ocean to the metropolis of Belleville. His grandmother and faithful dog, who are taken in by a trio of eccentric jazz-era divas, follow the clues to an Underground betting parlor and now the chase is on!
items.default_editorial: Adored by adults and children alike, Sylvain Chomet’s Oscar®-nominated animation harks back to a bygone France with bags of charm and a character who is a worthy successor to Jacques Tati’s Monsieur Hulot. Prepare to be delighted from the off—the unforgettable title song is an absolute hit.

items.title: The Tsugua Diaries
items.short_synopsis: In sun-soaked Portugal, Crista, Carloto, and João live in rural peace during the COVID lockdown. They pass their time in a spacious farmhouse where the dog days of summer are filled with dancing, chores, disturbed sleep patterns, flirtations, and building a backyard butterfly house.
items.default_editorial: Unfolding like a summer melody of green foliage and ripe fruit, Maureen Fazendeiro and Miguel Gomes’s airy vision of a creative idyll amid pandemic isolation has a few delightful tricks up its sleeve. A meta-cinematic celebration of community and art that embraces all the colorful flavors of life!

items.title: The Whistlers
items.short_synopsis: Cristi is a Romanian police officer who plays both sides of the law. Embarking on a high-stakes heist, he will have to navigate the twists and turns of corruption, treachery and deception. A trip to the Canary Islands to learn a secret whistling language might just be what he needs to pull it off.
items.default_editorial: From Police, Adjective to The Treasure, Corneliu Porumboiu has been collapsing the boundaries between the Romanian New Wave’s signature realism and the intrigue of crime thrillers. Premiering in Cannes, this twisty story of thieving and deceit blossoms into a stylish and sexy neo-noir.

items.title: The World After Us
items.short_synopsis: Struggling young writer Labidi is trying to publish his first novel after a small hit with a short story. While delivering food to survive and sharing a room with his friend, he gets caught up in a whirlwind romance with student Elisa, but is soon confronted with the realities of everyday life.
items.default_editorial: Love is sustained on a shoestring in this immensely sympathetic story of a young romantic with writerly aspirations but limited opportunities. With a delicate, effortless realism, Louda Ben Salah captures what it is to live both precariously and passionately in his subtly striking first feature.

items.title: The Year of the Cannibals
items.short_synopsis: In a dystopian Milan, the corpses of hundreds of boys and girls fill the streets. No one can give the bodies a resting place because of a repressive state decree. But the young Antigone, with the help of a foreigner named Tiresias, undermines the established order to bury her dead brother.
items.default_editorial: From the great Liliana Cavani, whose career has stretched from the controversial The Night Porter to an adaptation of Patricia Highsmith’s Ripley, comes this stunning update of Greek tragedy to a futuristic post-1968 apocalypse. Starring 60s It-girl Britt Eklund, with music by Ennio Morricone!

items.title: Their Algeria
items.short_synopsis: Following their separation after 62 years together, an Algerian couple’s granddaughter delves into their past. She explores their migration from Algeria in the 1950s, their integration into French society as immigrant laborers, and lives marked by displacement and unspoken family histories.
items.default_editorial: In this affectionate portrait of her Algerian grandmother and grandfather, director Lina Soualem negotiates his taciturn nature and her nervous laughter. An exercise in patient attention, Their Algeria honors the integrity of its subjects, and the silences that were necessary to their survival.

items.title: There Is No Evil
items.short_synopsis: Four moral tales about men faced with a simple yet unthinkable choice – to follow orders to enforce the death penalty, or resist and risk everything. Whatever they decide, it will directly or indirectly affect their lives, their relationships, and their consciences.
items.default_editorial: A sharp criticism of the death penalty, Mohammad Rasoulof’s Golden Bear-winning film was secretly shot in defiance of his government, which considers his works to engage in propaganda against the regime. Overcoming any barriers, the Iranian auteur tells us a brave and impassioned moral tale.

items.title: Today
items.short_synopsis: Tonight, Satché will die. Accepting his fate, he decides to spend his last day walking through the streets of his hometown, Dakar. By visiting key places from his past – his parents’ house, his first love, and his childhood friends – he reconnects with his homeland after a long stay in America.
items.default_editorial: Economical in dialogue, Alain Gomis’s enigmatic parable turns instead to the sensorial sights and sounds of Dakar for its surreal contemplation on death. Starring noted poet and musician Saul Williams as a haunted man on an urban drift, Today forms an immersive chorus to life’s final crossing.

items.title: Tony Conrad: DreaMinimalist
items.short_synopsis: The experimental multidisciplinary artist Tony Conrad is shown in his studio with his costumes and wigs, cooking pickled films or playing violin. He reminisces playfully about the 1960s New York underground scene, specifically his encounter with Jack Smith and his involvement with Flaming Creatures.
items.default_editorial: Shot on fuzzy 16mm stock, Marie Losier’s imaginative documentary portrait of composer and filmmaker Tony Conrad lovingly matches the idiosyncratic genius of its subject. From his charmingly chaotic home, a veritable cabinet of curiosities, the avant-garde icon weaves magic out of the everyday.

items.title: Transit
items.short_synopsis: As a modern-day Paris is invaded by foreign troops, German refugee Georg flees to Marseille assuming the identity of a deceased writer. There he delves into the delicate culture of the refugee community, becomes involved in the lives of a mother and son, and meets the writer’s enigmatic wife Marie.
items.default_editorial: Christian Petzold (Afire) boldly transforms Anna Seghers’ WW2 novel into a haunting period film set in an ambiguous present. A stirring melodrama of love during oppression, Transit is every bit as scintillating as Casablanca, thanks in part to the outstanding duo of Franz Rogowski and Paula Beer.

items.title: Un air de famille
items.short_synopsis: Every week, the Ménard family gathers at the café run by Henri. Tonight is a special occasion—it’s Henri’s sister-in-law’s birthday—but an unexpected event disrupts the family’s routine: Arlette, Henri’s wife, has left for the week “to think things over,” unsettling everyone around her.
items.default_editorial: Adapting their stage play for the screen, winning duo Agnès Jaoui and Jean-Pierre Bacri also made unforgettable appearances in Cédric Klapisch’s prickly comedy, a critical and box-office hit. In this witty war of words, set almost entirely in a family bistro, every insult cuts deeper than a knife.

items.title: Under the Cloud
items.short_synopsis: An investigation into the ongoing history of nuclear tests, uranium mining, and nuclear waste disposal on Indigenous lands in North America, elevating the voices of those who have witnessed and experienced the consequences of nuclear colonialism and those who continue to resist it.
items.default_editorial: Acclaimed internationally for his socially conscious art, Pedro Reyes turns to the noxious fallout of nuclear warfare in this profound documentary. Adopting an on-the-ground approach, the Mexican artist-activist scrutinizes the United States’ destructive, extractive policies with a rousing urgency.

items.title: Until the End of the World (Director's Cut)
items.original_title: Bis ans Ende der Welt (Director's Cut)
items.short_synopsis: 1999. To give his blind wife sight, Dr. Farber invents a process that transmits images directly into her visual system. So, Farber’s son Sam sets out on a global journey to “see” and record the world for his mother—during which a French lady, Claire, falls in love with him and pursues him.
items.default_editorial: German maestro Wim Wenders hits the road across four continents in this ambitious science-fiction odyssey. Defined by the director as “the ultimate road movie,” and with its first cut scoring an epic 20-hour runtime (!), the film is an outlandish yet ultimately rewarding journey of a movie.

items.title: Variety
items.short_synopsis: Christine, a bright and unassuming young woman, takes a job selling tickets at a porno cinema near Times Square. Instead of distancing herself from the dark and erotic nature of the theater’s milieu, Christine soon develops an obsession that begins to consume her life.
items.default_editorial: Based on a Brechtian script by Kathy Acker and starring New York underground legends like Nan Goldin and Cookie Mueller, Bette Gordon’s trailblazing New York indie powerfully inverts the gendered conventions of the erotic thriller, foregrounding women’s sexual fantasies in grimy, downtown New York.

items.title: Watch the Fire or Burn Inside It
items.original_title: Il faut regarder le feu ou brûler dedans
items.short_synopsis: In Corsica, a woman attempts to change the world by burning it. Living something of a hermitic existence on the island, she lights fire to cars, the hills, and construction sites. But she doesn’t simply burn the world to destroy it, she views fire as cleansing.
items.default_editorial: Flames purify the earth and the mind in this bracing short. Through the gaze of a mysterious woman, who denounces the hypocrisy of the modern world in frank voice-over, wildfires seem like fair retribution. Angry but poetic, the film seems to ask: when nature fights back, whose side are you on?

items.title: Wheel of Fortune and Fantasy
items.original_title: 偶然と想像 | Gûzen to sôzô
items.short_synopsis: An unexpected love triangle, a failed seduction trap and an encounter that results from a misunderstanding. The characters at the heart of these three stories combine into a telling exploration into the complexities of relationships, told through coincidences that happen to women in love.
items.default_editorial: Ryusuke Hamaguchi may have won the Oscar© for Drive My Car, but his other feature of 2021 is every bit as wonderful. An erotically-charged anthology film that took the Silver Bear in Berlin, these three tales of fate and desire unfold with singularly compelling delicacy and emotional openness.

items.title: Who's Stopping Us
items.short_synopsis: Over the course of five years, a group of 21st-century teenagers from Madrid commence their journey towards adulthood. The teens talk about insecurities, wanting to be accepted, and loneliness. Meanwhile, they ask a collective question: who are we, and who do we want to be?
items.default_editorial: Taking seriously the joys and anxieties of teenagers, this hybrid documentary looks at a generation too often misunderstood. Trusting his subjects to tell their own story, Jonás Trueba lovingly records the future hopes and present reality of young people engaged in their own process of becoming.

items.title: Wings of Desire
items.short_synopsis: Two angels, Damiel and Cassiel, glide through the streets of Berlin, observing the bustling population. When Damiel falls in love with lonely trapeze artist Marion, the angel longs to experience life in the physical world, and finds that it might be possible for him to take human form.
items.default_editorial: Angels walk among the downtrodden in this ethereal spiritual drama from Wim Wenders. Winner of the Best Director prize in Cannes, and featuring a tender, improvised performance from Peter Falk, Wings of Desire is a hypnotic philosophical meditation that finds divine order amid everyday chaos.

items.title: Yojimbo
items.short_synopsis: A nameless ronin wonders into a rural village in feudal Japan. To restore peace in the community, he concocts a plan to play the two head rivals, fighting for monopoly of the local gambling trade, against one another.
items.default_editorial: Has there ever been a Japanese director as key for Western cinema as Akira Kurosawa? Remade by Sergio Leone and Walter Hill, this colorful action flick skillfully explores the world and its self-destructive nature. Toshiro Mifune won Best Actor at the 1961 Venice Film Festival for his performance.

items.title: You Deserve a Lover
items.short_synopsis: Following Remi’s infidelity, Lila struggles to deal with their breakup. From Bolivia, where he has gone on a soul-searching quest, Remi tells her that their relationship is not over. From an encounter to the next, between discussion, consolation and incitements to crazy love, Lila loses herself.
items.default_editorial: Discovered in Abdellatif Kechiche’s The Secret of the Grain, actor Hafsia Herzi went behind and in front of the camera for her first feature—and what a debut! An unabashed and intimate reflection on love and desire told from a woman’s perspective, which pulsates with splendid, spontaneous vitality.

items.title: Zero Fucks Given
items.short_synopsis: Cassandra is a flight attendant for a low-cost airline, always willing to take on extra hours and carrying out her duties efficiently. On the side, she floats between dating apps, parties, and lazy days. When she suddenly gets fired, will she finally confront what she was running away from?
items.default_editorial: The magnetic Adèle Exarchopoulos soars to new heights in Emmanuel Marre and Julie Lecoustre’s riotous, behind-the-scenes look at the corporate grind of aviation hospitality. Against the precarious cycle of long hours, casual sex, and parties, life on the ground beckons as a hopeful emergency exit.

items.title: ‎Trenque Lauquen: Part 1
items.short_synopsis: Laura, a biologist cataloguing plant species in Trenque Lauquen, disappears. Her older boyfriend, Rafael, and colleague Ezequiel set out to find her, stumbling upon intriguing discoveries along the way that may help them locate her. However, the story is bigger and stranger than they could imagine.
items.default_editorial: Love letters secreted in library books spark an epistolary mystery in this playful Borgesian epic from Argentine filmmaker Laura Citarella. Cowritten by its star Laura Paredes (The Delinquents), Trenque Lauquen is a cinematic matryoshka doll hewn from structuring absences and literary obsession.

items.title: ‎Trenque Lauquen: Part 2
items.short_synopsis: The circumstances behind Laura’s disappearance begin to surface. However, an entirely new mystery unfurls: in the suburbs, two lesbian lovers appear to be conducting a scientific experiment.
items.default_editorial: Still teasing at tangential threads, our inquisitive trio tumble further down the rabbit hole in this dazzling conclusion to Laura Citarella’s enigmatic opus. As myriad mysteries compound across multiple timelines, Trenque Lauquen’s narrative labyrinth winds toward the mystical vortex at its center.

items.title: Orlando
items.short_synopsis: Young aristocrat Orlando begins a quest for love and freedom in the court of Elizabeth I as a man. He is granted favours and property by the queen who commands the nobleman to never change. Orlando completes the search 400 years later as a woman, shaking off their biological and cultural destiny.
items.default_editorial: Sally Potter’s fearless adaptation of Virginia Woolf’s supposedly unfilmable book, Orlando was nine years in the making. This restlessly rule-bending, gender fluid, time-traveling epic—starring a dazzling Tilda Swinton on typically shape-shifting form—remains an unmatched feat of queer filmmaking.

items.title: Room 666
items.short_synopsis: In a small hotel room at the 1982 Cannes Film Festival, Wim Wenders initiates a survey among his colleagues about the future of cinema. Godard, Fassbinder, Spielberg, Antonioni, Herzog, and other filmmakers respond to Wenders’ question: “Is cinema a language about to get lost, an art about to die?”
items.default_editorial: From Godard to Antonioni, Herzog to Spielberg, Wim Wenders gathers the great and good of world cinema to ponder an existential question. Enlightening and hilarious, Room 666 considers the aesthetics of television, and asks whether its polluting effects will sound a death knell for the seventh art.

items.title: Tokyo-Ga
items.short_synopsis: German director Wim Wenders travels to Tokyo to explore the world of one of his cinematic heroes, Japanese celebrated film director Yasujirō Ozu. Sequences of Wenders’ view of Japan alternate with encounters and conversations with the crew and cast members of Ozu’s films.
items.default_editorial: Four decades before Perfect Days , Wim Wenders journeyed to his beloved Tokyo to fashion this heartfelt ode to Yasujirō Ozu. Featuring interviews with the Japanese master’s actors—and a rare glimpse of Chris Marker!—Tokyo-Ga is at once a poignant travelogue and a love letter to a cinematic idol.

items.title: Factotum
items.short_synopsis: Self-declared aspiring writer Henry Chinaski has neither qualifications, ambition nor ethics. He works as a manual laborer in factories and warehouses in order to subsidize a life of drinking, race-track betting, skirt-chasing, and most of all, writing stories that no publisher will touch.
items.default_editorial: Matt Dillon, for our money one of the most underrated actors of his generation, embodies the perfect Bukowskian doppelgänger in this irresistibly cynical adaptation. Derived from the tales of the writer’s early working life, Factotum captures all of the vulgar poeticism that was this man’s essence.

items.title: Girl Asleep
items.short_synopsis: Greta just moved to a new town with her family. She floats in a bubble of loserdom with her only friend Elliott, until her parents throw her a surprise 15th birthday party and she’s flung into a parallel place; a world that’s weirdly erotic, violent, and ludicrous – only there can she find herself.
items.default_editorial: Girl Asleep follows main character Greta as she rejects her extravagant mother and the pressures of high school to escape in her own fantasy trip. Reminiscent of the stylized comedies of Wes Anderson, this wacky coming-of-age story set in the Australian suburbia is an absolute blast.

items.title: Involuntary
items.short_synopsis: It’s almost summer in Sweden, minor misbehaviour abounds. Leffe likes to play pranks when he’s drinking. Meanwhile, a righteous school teacher doesn’t know where to draw the line. Then there are two teenage girls who like to party, but one night in a park, one of them is found passed out drunk.
items.default_editorial: This blistering, award-winning second feature from Ruben Östlund would prove his breakthrough. Made up of a series of simmering, fixed-camera vignettes that crackle with self-contained moral dilemmas, Involuntary acutely exposes the fault lines in Swedish society’s carefully cultivated self-image.

items.title: James White
items.short_synopsis: James White is a troubled twenty something trying to stay afloat in a frenzied New York City. As he retreats further into a hedonistic lifestyle, his mother’s battle with a serious illness faces a series of setbacks that force him to assume more responsibility.
items.default_editorial: In one of the most impressive of recent NYC indies—and a debut, no less—Josh Mond delicately constructs a low-key, character-driven drama exploring the bond between a mother & son, the former’s illness and the latter’s self-destruction. A hard-hitting, moving, and superbly acted first feature.

items.title: Palindromes
items.short_synopsis: 12-year-old Aviva is determined to be a mother and does everything she can to achieve this. When her sensible mother intervenes, Aviva runs away from home. As a wanderer, she ends up in a strange world that is itself pregnant with chances, (maternal) insights, bizarre figures and experiences.
items.default_editorial: Prince of controversy Todd Solondz revisited his Sundance hit Welcome to the Dollhouse with this semi-sequel, proving to be as unsettling and sharp as ever. Eight actresses (including Jennifer Jason Leigh) all play the same character in this subversive, darkly comic puzzle that opens our spotlight.

items.title: You, the Living
items.short_synopsis: A series of vignettes present a disparate crew of characters: a stout depressive and her long-suffering husband; a young girl with an unrequited crush on a rock musician; a barber taking sweet revenge on a racist customer; couples with too much to say, or too little; and a diligent tuba player…
items.default_editorial: The Swedish king of tragicomedy Roy Andersson surveys all facets of society in this illuminating, unnerving, and eccentric work of dour hilarity. One of the ’00s most acclaimed arthouse films, this epic comedy is part whimsical anxiety dream, part jam session between Ingmar Bergman and Monty Python.

items.title: 3 Shots
items.short_synopsis: An evening get-together of a group of vampire friends takes an interesting turn when an unsuspecting human visitor arrives.
items.default_editorial: Here’s a tasty little morsel to sink your teeth into. A group of vampire pals have plans for dinner in this sharp-toothed short from Jorge Iván Morales, but when a human arrives, it’s less than clear what’s going to be on the menu. Fans of What We Do in the Shadows will approve!

items.title: 9½ Weeks
items.short_synopsis: Elizabeth, a divorced New York art gallery curator, finds herself drawn into an obsessive sexual relationship with John, a compelling Wall Street broker. At first, the relationship is stimulating and exciting, but as their sex games become increasingly perverse, she begins to fear for her sanity.
items.default_editorial: Kim Basinger and Mickey Rourke tear up the screen in this iconic provocation from director Adrian Lyne. A box-office bomb since reclaimed as a cult classic—and one of the great New York movies—9½ Weeks marries superb location photography to MTV sizzle for a candid study in sex and power.

items.title: A Chiara
items.short_synopsis: The story of 15-year-old Chiara whose close-knit family falls apart after her father abandons them in Calabria. Chiara starts to investigate to understand why her father disappeared and as she gets closer to the truth, she is forced to decide what kind of future she wants for herself.
items.default_editorial: Tender yet gritty, Jonas Carpignano’s coming-of-age tale spirals like a thriller, as family secrets shatter the cocoon of childhood innocence. Sensitive to the inner life of a teenage girl, the last entry in the director’s Calabrian trilogy confronts the intergenerational cost of crime and violence.

items.title: A Different Man
items.short_synopsis: An aspiring actor undergoes a radical medical procedure to drastically transform his appearance. However, his new dream face quickly turns into a nightmare, as he loses out on the role he was born to play and becomes obsessed with reclaiming what was lost.
items.default_editorial: With a heartbreaking Sebastian Stan and electric turns from Adam Pearson and Renate Reinsve, this stylish dark comedy tackles provocative ideas around self-image. Its sharp reflection on beauty standards masks a charged question: when does the problem stop being society, and start to be you?

items.title: A Fish Called Wanda
items.short_synopsis: An ambitious and sexy con artist uses every tool at her disposal to obtain a fortune in jewels stolen by her mobster lover. To help in her plan, she woo’s first her lover’s deadly henchman and then his attorney, eventually falling in love with one of them.
items.default_editorial: One of the most unusual yet most irresistible couples in cinema might be Jamie Lee Curtis and John Cleese. In this fabulous, London-set ’80s heist comedy—a hilarious, wild ride of deception and surprise—Kevin Kline won an Oscar® and John Cleese and Michael Palin two BAFTAs!

items.title: Akira
items.short_synopsis: It’s 2019, thirty-one years after the Japanese government nuked Tokyo as damage control for an experiment involving paranormal abilities in children. Cyberpunk biker Kaneda rides into the unknown on a mission to save his friend Tetsuo from a vast and far-reaching government conspiracy.
items.default_editorial: Calling Akira a pioneering work of animation would be doing it a disservice. It’s a pioneering, hugely influential work of cinema, period. Katsuhiro Ôtomo’s cyberpunk masterpiece hurtles through the neon-drenched streets of post-apocalyptic Neo-Tokyo, and finds jaw-dropping artistry in every frame.

items.title: American Fiction
items.short_synopsis: Monk is a frustrated novelist who’s fed up with the establishment that profits from Black entertainment that relies on tired and offensive tropes. To prove his point, he uses a pen name to write an outlandish book that propels him to the heart of hypocrisy and the madness he claims to disdain.
items.default_editorial: Nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars®, Cord Jefferson’s hilarious debut delivers a brilliant mix of satire and family drama. Taking aim at the racial blind spots of the publishing world, American Fiction gleefully exposes the industry’s ravenous appetite for stereotypical storytelling.

items.title: Amores Perros
items.short_synopsis: A teenager risks it all to run away with his brother’s wife. A model loses everything after moving in with her lover. A homeless man unearths the ghosts of his past. As their stories unfold, human chaos, cruelty, and tenderness come to light – revealing they are more connected than they seem.
items.default_editorial: Alejandro González Iñárritu charged out of the gates with this combustible debut feature, planting the flag for a new golden age of Mexican cinema. A Cannes prizewinner that made a star of Gael García Bernal, Amores Perros is a feral urban odyssey with a bite to match the ferocity of its bark.

items.title: An Angel at My Table
items.short_synopsis: Born in an impoverished but caring family, Janet Frame, a shy redhead child, finds refuge in books and writing poetry. However, as she grows older, a psychological misdiagnosis derails her life. But when she finds acclaim for her writings, Janet can move on in life—embarking on a journey to Europe.
items.default_editorial: In her breakthrough feature, New Zealand’s Jane Campion brings to the screen a Künstlerroman in tribute to her much-overlooked compatriot, writer Janet Frame: a woman who’s unexpected win of a literary prize in 1951 saved her from a lobotomy. A film tripartite in structure, and immaculately told.

items.title: Annette
items.short_synopsis: A seemingly perfect couple—a provocative stand-up comedian and internationally renowned opera singer—live glamorous lives in contemporary Los Angeles. However, when they welcome their daughter Annette into the world, her mysterious gifts will change their lives forever.
items.default_editorial: Visionary filmmaker Leos Carax’s fantastical, mind-melting rock opera swells with visual invention and emotional highs. Stunningly physical performances from Adam Driver and Marion Cotillard, along with hypnotic music from legendary Sparks brothers, make this a once-in-a-lifetime viewing experience!

items.title: Bad Seed
items.short_synopsis: Henry Pasquier, the spoiled son of a wealthy doctor, discovers high-octane thrills, jazz-era romance and a sense of purpose in life when he unwittingly falls into the company of an organized ring of car thieves—and falls for Jeannette, who works as car-bait for the gang.
items.default_editorial: Here’s a treasure from the vaults: the directing debut of Billy Wilder, a comedy made in France in between his flight from Germany and his arrival in Hollywood. Starring Danielle Darrieux (Madame de…), it shows Wilder’s sweet-and-sour sensibility, mixing romance and cynicism, comedy and drama.

items.title: Bear Story
items.short_synopsis: An old bear sets up a wooden theater on a busy street corner daily, featuring tin puppets he crafted. For a coin, the puppets come to life, telling the story of a circus bear longing to escape and reunite with his family, visible through a peephole to passing onlookers.
items.default_editorial: The first Chilean film to win an Oscar®, this bittersweet short deploys the charming language of children’s bedtime stories to tell a real-life tale of loss. As a film about the power of art to sublimate pain but bring joy too, its metatextual qualities make it all the more haunting and moving.

items.title: Beating Hearts
items.short_synopsis: In a tough neighborhood, rebellious teen Clotaire falls for sharp-witted Jackie. Their young love is tested when gang violence tears them apart and Clotaire is charged with a crime he didn’t commit. Years later, fate reunites them—but can love overcome a past marked by injustice and revenge?
items.default_editorial: Starring the inimitable Adèle Exarchopoulos and cowritten with Audrey Diwan, this thrilling film zooms from criminal underworld to teen romance, ricocheting through time and genre. Quickening pulses and breaking hearts, Gilles Lelouche’s second solo-directed feature pops with outrageous flair.

items.title: Bestia
items.short_synopsis: A Chilean secret police agent, trained in torture and responsible for brutal acts against regime opponents, leads a dull life with only her dog for company. The oppressive routine of her home reveals the fears and frustrations of a tormented mind, projecting her self-loathing onto others.
items.default_editorial: Porcelain figurines hint at a cold, harsh reality in this thought-provoking, Oscar®-nominated short. Taking us inside a perverted psyche that is plagued by unsettling visions, this impressionistic portrait of a monstrous woman lingers in the mind long after the closing credits.

items.title: Black Book
items.short_synopsis: Nazi-occupied Netherlands during World War II. Orphaned Jewish singer Rachel Stein joins the Resistance, is assigned a new identity, and infiltrates the German Security Service by seducing a senior officer. She soon becomes entangled in a deadly web of double-dealing and betrayal.
items.default_editorial: After a renowned Hollywood career that included RoboCop and Total Recall, Paul Verhoeven returned to his native Netherlands (and his filmmaking roots) for one of his greatest triumphs: a spectacular, acclaimed, thrilling WWII epic—and the biggest box office hit in Dutch history!

items.title: Black Girl
items.short_synopsis: A Senegalese woman is eager to find a better life abroad. She takes a job as a governess for a French family, but finds her duties reduced to those of a maid after the family moves to the south of France. In her new country, she is constantly made aware of her race and mistreated by her employers.
items.default_editorial: Heralded as the first feature from a West African director, Ousmane Sembène’s award-winning, radical, and haunting debut feature powerfully critiques the colonialist mindset and Europe’s fetishization of Africa. Although nodding to the Nouvelle Vague, Black Girl marches to the beat of its own drum.

items.title: Blow Out
items.short_synopsis: While recording sound for a low-budget horror film, a sound engineer inadvertently records the car crash of a presidential hopeful. As he pieces together the truth with a key witness, he finds himself ensnared in a deadly conspiracy.
items.default_editorial: Foley, cosmetics, political cover-up: the art of artifice bleeds into every corner of a seamy, neon-prinked Philadelphia in this soulful love letter to ambient sound. Brian De Palma assembles a dream team of past collaborators—including John Travolta!—to make this pacy thriller sing and scream.

items.title: Blue Velvet
items.short_synopsis: Home from college, Jeffrey finds a severed ear in a field, leading him into a dark and surreal mystery. As he investigates, he’s drawn into the secrets of small-town life, the mysterious lounge singer Dorothy, and a psychopath who will stop at nothing to keep Dorothy in his grasp.
items.default_editorial: In this twisted, hypnotic take on the coming-of-age drama, David Lynch finds voracious desires and feverish impulses lurking behind the white picket fences of the American dream. Beguiled by Isabella Rossellini’s tragic beauty, Kyle MacLachlan’s wide-eyed voyeur frees love from destructive passion.

items.title: Bolivia
items.short_synopsis: Freddy leaves Bolivia after the drug war destroys his livelihood and finds work in an Argentine restaurant, where he faces exploitation and everyday racism. His only comfort is Rosa, a Paraguayan waitress and fellow undocumented migrant who shares his struggle.
items.default_editorial: Simmering with fiery indignation, a small Buenos Aires café is a cauldron of racial tensions in Adrián Caetano’s unflinching slice-of-life drama, which was awarded at Cannes. Shot on 16mm black-and-white stock, this hard-hitting film has raw, vivid performances and style to burn.

items.title: Bottoms
items.short_synopsis: PJ and Josie, two unpopular girls in their senior year, start a fight club as a way to lose their virginities to cheerleaders. When the fight club gains traction—and the most popular girls are beating each other up in the name of self-defense—PJ and Josie find themselves in over their heads.
items.default_editorial: Besties onscreen and off, Ayo Edebiri and Rachel Sennott kick, punch, and somersault their way to first kisses in Emma Seligman’s riotous followup to Shiva Baby. A refreshingly modern take on the classic teen comedy, Bottoms reimagines high-school hijinks with a whimsical dose of absurdism.

items.title: Buena Vista Social Club
items.short_synopsis: Ry Cooder, Wim Wenders’ frequent musical collaborator, travels to Havana to bring a group of aging Cuban musicians—whose talents had been virtually forgotten following Fidel Castro’s takeover—out of retirement. Within a few months, the group go from obscurity to world stardom.
items.default_editorial: One of Wim Wenders’s latter-day triumphs, this Oscar®-nominated documentary explores the rich and vivacious music scene in Cuba. The New German Cinema icon follows numerous musical legends as they play and navigate the vibrant streets of Havana in this loving testament to the “son de Cuba.” A tonic!

items.title: Carrie
items.short_synopsis: Carrie is a high school loner with no confidence, no friends… and no idea about the extent of her secret powers of telekinesis. But when her psychotic mother and sadistic classmates finally go too far, Carrie becomes an unrestrained, vengeance-seeking powerhouse who causes all hell to break loose.
items.default_editorial: The first film adapted from the work of Stephen King, New Hollywood director Brian De Palma began his string of successes with this iconic, bona fide classic. A career breakthrough for all involved, Carrie is vividly brought to life in all its blood-soaked glory by an unforgettable Sissy Spacek.

items.title: Censor
items.short_synopsis: Britain, 1985. When film censor Enid discovers an eerie horror that speaks directly to her sister’s mysterious disappearance, she resolves to unravel the puzzle behind the film and its enigmatic director—a quest that will blur the lines between fiction and reality in terrifying ways.
items.default_editorial: A knockout debut from writer-director Prano Bailey-Bond, Censor is a delirious ode to the 1980s “Video Nasty” era, Britain’s golden age of VHS horror. A hallucinatory dive down a rabbit-hole of repressed trauma and psychological fracture, this meticulously textured chiller cuts to the bone.

items.title: Charade
items.short_synopsis: After her estranged husband’s murder, jet-setter Regina is pursued by three crooks who want the money her husband stole from them. With her life in jeopardy, she turns to charming stranger Peter for help, but soon discovers he isn’t who he claims to be, and that his own agenda is far from clear.
items.default_editorial: The best Hitchcock film that Hitchcock never made, Stanley Donen’s Charade is a delightful mystery that shines with humor, suspense, and style from the last days of Old Hollywood glamor. Starring icons Audrey Hepburn & Cary Grant, this Paris-set tale is as witty and stylish as its two main actors.

items.title: Christiane F.
items.original_title: Christiane F. – Wir Kinder vom Bahnhof Zoo
items.short_synopsis: 14-year-old Christiane lives with her mother and little sister in Berlin. Although she’s legally too young to enter the new disco the ‘Sound’, she asks a friend to take her. There she meets Detlef, who’s in a clique where everybody’s on drugs. Step by step she gets drawn deeper into the scene.
items.default_editorial: Before the scuzzy sex and narcotics of Kids, cinema’s wasted youth were here, in a grungy nocturne of 1970s West Berlin. Scandalous to audiences on its release and now a cult classic, this nightcrawler of a film falls into darkness fast—but not before slinking about to David Bowie’s rebel sounds.

items.title: Cloud
items.short_synopsis: Ryosuke, a Tokyo factory worker who profits from reselling goods online, moves to the countryside with his girlfriend to expand the business. But their quiet new life unravels when mysterious attackers target him, exposing hidden enemies and shattering his fragile peace.
items.default_editorial: Keyboard warriors make IRL mayhem in this bracingly unpredictable techno-thriller from cult director Kiyoshi Kurosawa. Hyperlinking genres with a whiplash transition from online paranoia to visceral real-world violence, Cloud finds apocalyptic source code in our dangerously atomised society.

items.title: Coffy
items.short_synopsis: Coffy is a one-woman vigilante force, out to even the score with those who have hooked her sister on drugs. Using both her wiles and deadly weaponry, Coffy sets about ridding the streets of drug dealers, pimps, and deviants.
items.default_editorial: Sensuality and political consciousness are a two-piece set in Pam Grier-led blaxploitation films, and Jack Hill’s Coffy—a classic of the genre—is one such formfitting ensemble. A riot of stylish badassery, this vehicle for Grier’s talents seals its Black Panther anger with a glossy lipstick kiss.

items.title: Correspondence
items.short_synopsis: In a visual correspondence, two young, experienced filmmakers share little pieces of their lives and what has led them to tell the stories they tell and become the creators they are today. Personal reflections intermingle with realities which at times change the filmmakers’ perception of the world.
items.default_editorial: Ah, the magic of filmed epistolary exchanges! From Spain to Chile, award-winning directors Carla Simón (Summer 1993) and Dominga Sotomayor (Too Late To Die Young) lucidly correspond about memories, family and filmmaking, compellingly oscillating between soul-searching intimacy and political urgency.

items.title: Crimes of the Future
items.short_synopsis: Accompanied by his partner Caprice, celebrity artist Saul Tenser publicly showcases the metamorphosis of his organs in avant-garde performances. Their movements are tracked by Timlin, a young investigator, as well as a mysterious group set on shedding light on the next phase of human evolution.
items.default_editorial: Charging his return to body horror with darkly humorous debates on art and mortality, David Cronenberg is back with a sinuous tale of corporeal transformation. Starring Viggo Mortensen, Léa Seydoux, and Kristen Stewart, Crimes of the Future is a provocative ode to the sensual allure of the flesh.

items.title: Desperately Seeking Susan
items.short_synopsis: Bored New Jersey housewife Roberta fills her days by reading the personals, following a romance between “Jim” and “Susan”, who lead the kind of free-spirited lives she can only dream about. And dream she does—until, one day, she actually shows up at the couple’s prearranged rendezvous in New York.
items.default_editorial: The whole of downtown Manhattan dances to the tune of Madonna’s frisky grifter in this cat-and-mouse screwball comedy that launched her film career. The hopeless romance of the classifieds and a priceless relic ensorcel a bohemian Big Apple that is as motley as the singer’s eclectic punk ensembles.

items.title: Die My Love
items.short_synopsis: Grace and her partner Jackson move into an old country house. She pursues her dream of writing, and the couple welcome a baby soon after. However, with Jackson frequently absent, and the pressures of domestic life weighing on her, Grace begins to unravel, leaving a path of destruction in her wake.
items.default_editorial: Instincts both maternal and carnal clatter like shards of glass in a blender in this uncompromising portrait of a woman on the edge from director Lynne Ramsay. Starring Jennifer Lawrence and Robert Pattinson in a frenzied pas de deux, Die My Love inflames the exposed nerves of delirium and desire.

items.title: Donnie Darko
items.short_synopsis: Donnie is a troubled high school student: in therapy, prone to sleepwalking and in possession of an imaginary friend, a six-foot rabbit named Frank who predicts the imminent end of the world. Before then, Donnie will navigate teenage life in suburbia while following Frank’s maladjusted instructions.
items.default_editorial: The definitive cult film of the new millennium? We say yes! Richard Kelly’s remarkable debut is a seamless hybrid: part teen comedy, part horror flick, part sci-fi thriller, and wholly original. Though initially ignored, this irresistibly strange and sinister mystery has already become a classic.

items.title: Dressed to Kill
items.short_synopsis: After witnessing a mysterious woman brutally slay a homemaker, prostitute Liz Blake finds herself trapped in a dangerous situation. While the police thinks she is the murderer, the real killer is intent on silencing her only witness.
items.default_editorial: Hitchcock meets erotica in this Brian De Palma picture, which luxuriates in rounded, yielding forms. Things that cut and glint—a razor blade, a diamond ring—lacerate the film’s layered softnesses: Nancy Allen’s brushed-out curls, the slow flow of the Steadicam, the strings of Pino Donaggio’s score.

items.title: Ema
items.short_synopsis: Ema is a magnetic and impulsive dancer in a reggaeton troupe. Her toxic marriage to choreographer Gastón is beyond repair, following a decision to give up on their adopted child Polo. She sets out on a mission to get him back, not caring who she’ll need to fight, seduce or destroy to make it happen.
items.default_editorial: Pablo Larraín takes a dazzling look at sex, power, and family in modern-day Chile in this highly combustible mix of dance and drama. With an electrifying score by Nicolas Jaar, Ema is a whirlwind of no-holds-barred anarchy, anchored by searing turns from Mariana Di Girolamo and Gael García Bernal.

items.title: EO
items.short_synopsis: EO, a grey donkey with sad eyes and a curious spirit, begins his life as a circus performer before escaping on a trek across the Polish and Italian countryside. During his travels, EO encounters many characters, including a countess, a young Italian priest, and a riotous Polish football team.
items.default_editorial: Jerzy Skolimowski’s late-career triumph is a visually intrepid immersion into the world of a long-suffering donkey. Ecstatic and heartbreaking, this dazzling drama of a divided Europe, which boldly reworks Bresson’s classic Au Hasard Balthazar, was Poland’s official submission to the Oscars®.

items.title: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind
items.original_title: Eternal Sunshine of the Spotless Mind
items.short_synopsis: Joel is stunned to discover that his estranged girlfriend Clementine has undergone an experimental psychiatric treatment to have her memories of their tumultuous relationship erased. Still in love with Clementine, he elects to undergo the procedure himself.
items.default_editorial: A fragmented, non-linear look at the elusive and peculiar nature of memory, this gorgeous and romantic, high-concept yet lo-fi/sci-fi cult classic could only come from the genius mind of Charlie Kaufman. Aching and ambitious filmmaking, of a kind rarely replicated.

items.title: Evil Does Not Exist
items.original_title: 悪は存在しない  | Aku wa sonzai shinai
items.short_synopsis: Takumi and his daughter Hana, living in Mizubiki Village near Tokyo, face a threat when a planned glamping site near their home risks the local water supply. As company reps from Tokyo reveal the negative impacts, village unrest and ecological dangers jeopardize their traditional way of life.
items.default_editorial: A profound reflection on humanity’s place in nature, this ecological fable from director Ryusuke Hamaguchi is also an enthralling sensory experience. Eiko Ishibashi’s haunting score brings out the beauty and mystery of untamed woods where good and evil, care and apathy fight their perennial battle.

items.title: Family Romance, LLC
items.short_synopsis: Love is a business at Family Romance, a company that rents human stand-ins for any occasion. Founder Yuichi Ishii helps make his clients’ dreams come true. But when the mother of 12-year-old Mahiro hires Ishii to impersonate her missing father, the line between acting and reality threatens to blur.
items.default_editorial: Join us on a surreal adventure with indefatigable globetrotting auteur, Werner Herzog. Filmed guerrilla-style in Japan, Herzog’s typically unique dramatization of the real phenomenon of renting family members and social stand-ins explores the uncanny essence of human relationships.

items.title: Fargo
items.short_synopsis: A car salesman plans to wipe out his personal debts by hiring a pair of colorful crooks to kidnap his wife and have her wealthy father pay the ransom. The haphazard scheme turns sour during a routine pull-over that leaves three dead bodies in its wake.
items.default_editorial: Unpredictable in its plot, this noir detective tale, a, cult hit from the Coen brothers, hasn’t aged a day. With an award-winning performance from Frances McDormand, Fargo is an offbeat masterclass in dark humor. Suspense, comedy and social observation have rarely coexisted so naturally on screen.

items.title: Fire Supply
items.short_synopsis: Why do podcasts have limits? A person who loves their mother more than their father would want to make ice or steel, or perhaps have a cemetery so their mother wouldn’t suffer because of anyone.
items.default_editorial: With multiple declarations of love and a breathtaking cliffhanger, this epic two-parter is a vivid conclusion to Lucía Seles’s “Pentalogy of Hate.” Indulging in both sequences of delicate contemplation and moments of unexpected action, this lively installment sees relationships dramatically changed.

items.title: Four Weddings and a Funeral
items.short_synopsis: Shy Londoner Charles is a man disengaged from his own heart: the more weddings he goes to, the less he wants to get married—until one nuptials where he meets the striking American, Carrie. He tries hard not to fall in love with her, but one funeral and three weddings later, he’s head-over-heels.
items.default_editorial: The film that made a star of Hugh Grant and set writer Richard Curtis on the path to becoming a British institution, Mike Newell’s bittersweet romcom hasn’t aged a day. With a host of acting greats among the supporting cast, Four Weddings and a Funeral is an irresistible ode to love and loss.

items.title: Foxy Brown
items.short_synopsis: Foxy Brown has found her soul mate in an undercover narcotics investigator, but when he is brutally murdered, she vows vengeance against the crime ring responsible and takes a job as a high-society sex worker to infiltrate the gang.
items.default_editorial: In dagger-collar jackets and studded dungarees, Pam Grier’s streetwise action hero topples a dope operation in Foxy Brown—one trash can to the head, one barstool to the face at a time. Teaming revenge with revolution, this funk-scored crime film reinscribed Grier’s status as an icon of Black pride.

items.title: Free Chol Soo Lee
items.short_synopsis: In 1970s San Francisco, 20-year-old Korean immigrant Chol Soo Lee is racially profiled and convicted of a Chinatown gang murder. After spending years fighting to survive, investigative journalist K.W. Lee takes a special interest in his case, igniting an unprecedented social justice movement.
items.default_editorial: A damning exposé of an unjust judicial system, Free Chol Soo Lee revisits a wrongful conviction thrust upon a Korean immigrant in 1970s San Francisco. Highlighting the radical power of community activism, this vital solidarity call also reveals the lifelong scars that incarceration leaves behind.

items.title: Garden of Delights
items.short_synopsis: A ceremony. A wedding night. A hotel room. A leaking toilet. A man and a woman … and another woman. Memories surface, fears that arise. The first hours of marriage, the beginning of hell.
items.default_editorial: Silvano Agosti’s controversial debut is a biting critique of the Catholic church, the institution of marriage, and the hypocrisy of Italian society. Inspired by Hieronymus Bosch’s famous painting, and notoriously censored by the Vatican, the film boasts a scintillating score by maestro Morricone!

items.title: Get Out
items.short_synopsis: Chris, a young African-American man, visits his white girlfriend’s family for the weekend. At first, Chris reads the family’s overly accommodating behaviour as nervous attempts to deal with their daughter’s interracial relationship—but a series of disturbing discoveries lead him to a sinister truth.
items.default_editorial: Jordan Peele’s seismic horror-satire is a rare era-defining film: both a mordant send-up of Obama-era liberal racism and an early shot at Trump’s America. Delivering its commentary with bloody aplomb, Get Out distills a nation’s anxieties in the indelible image of “the sunken place.”

items.title: Ghost in the Shell
items.short_synopsis: In the year 2029, the world has become interconnected by a vast electronic network that permeates every aspect of life. Major Motoko Kusanagi, a cyborg officer, is spearheading the investigation into a master hacker known only as the Puppet Master, who robs humans of their memories.
items.default_editorial: Influencing filmmakers from the Wachowskis to James Cameron, Mamoru Oshii’s cyberpunk classic is one of the defining anime of its generation. A dystopian vision jeweled with glass-walled skyscrapers and automatons, whose hypnotic beauty begs the fundamental question of what it means to be human.

items.title: Gofer
items.short_synopsis: Alan’s daily life as a driver and assistant to a federal deputy entails enduring the anger and arrogance of his superior; suffering the  contempt of the deputy’s bodyguards and cleaning up all traces of his boss’ misbehaviour. Today, however, Alan has decided that things will be different.
items.default_editorial: When a low-rank driver stops covering for his boss’s crimes, only one thing is in store: trouble. Alternating between Mexico’s vibrant nightlife and the dark corridors where the powerful puppeteer those around them, Gofer is as much a visual treat as a gripping exposé of a corrupt political elite.

items.title: Gomorrah
items.short_synopsis: In the slums of Campania, the Camorra crime syndicate thrives on cocaine, corruption, and chemical waste. Teens Ciro and Marco try to steal weapons to take control, while tailor Pasquale attempts to avoid protection fees. But they soon realize: the Camorra is too powerful to fight.
items.default_editorial: Without a hint of romanticism or sentimentality, Matteo Garrone’s acclaimed, authentic crime drama Gomorrah brings together a large ensemble of characters to build a broad panorama of the causes and effects of criminal life in Naples. Winner of the Grand Prix at the Cannes Film Festival.

items.title: Güeros
items.short_synopsis: The arrival of Tomás gives new energy to his brother Sombra and his friend Santos, whose lives seem to be on hold after a student strike. Together, they decide to go on a road trip to find the legendary musician they listened to as kids, and whose location has been unknown for a long time.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Best First Feature award at the Berlinale, Alonso Ruizpalacios’s vivacious coming-of-age film is one of the most formally impressive debuts in recent Mexican cinema. Seductively shot in black-and-white, the film is an exuberant examination of Mexico’s historic student strike in 1999.

items.title: Hackers
items.short_synopsis: Entering a highly secured computer at a mineral corporation, a newbie hacker uncovers an embezzling plot that could destroy the world’s ecosystem. When the hacker and his pals are targeted for the crime, they must launch a cyber-attack that will clear their names and prevent an ecological disaster.
items.default_editorial: The Nintendo generation gets anarchic in this outrageously enjoyable cult throwback, which pits Angelina Jolie’s laptop-wielding, pixie-cutted hacktivist against digital corporate chicanery. Hackers immortalises the tech-utopianism of the early internet era with punky subcultural style.

items.title: Hair
items.short_synopsis: Drafted for the Vietnam War, naive farmhand Claude arrives in New York, where he befriends a commune of hippies led by the charismatic George Berger. As they challenge his beliefs and introduce him to a free-spirited world, Claude meets and falls for Sheila, a rich debutante with a rebellious soul.
