items.default_editorial: Based on a 1968 Broadway sensation, Miloš Forman’s freewheeling musical casts an introspective gaze at the youthful tenacity and optimism of the anti-Vietnam War movement. Lifted by a band of rebels with a cause, Hair  witnesses the fragility of flower power in the face of a callous establishment.

items.title: Harvest
items.short_synopsis: Over seven hallucinatory days, a village with no name, in an undefined time and place, disappears. Townsman-turned-farmer Walter Thirsk and befuddled lord of the manor Charles Kent are childhood friends about to face an invasion from the outside world: the trauma of modernity.
items.default_editorial: Textured with russet reds and pollinic yellows, Athina Rachel Tsangari’s spellbinding allegory gleans an atmospheric folk tale from a rural idyll. As landowners sow the seeds of modern capital, Sean Price Williams reaps horror and beauty from the earth with swirling, immersive cinematography.

items.title: Heathers
items.short_synopsis: Veronica Sawyer halfheartedly tries to be part of the “in crowd” at her high school. But when the cruel games of her school’s unstoppable trio of mean queen bees—all named Heather—become too much, Veronica gets together with rebel J.D. and plots to murder them and disguise the deaths as suicides.
items.default_editorial: Before Mean Girls, before Clueless, came this wonderfully nasty teen movie, a cult classic that helped launch Winona Ryder. Full of outrageous one-liners, colour-coded outfit perfection, and extreme violence, this delectably witty satire is one of the great high-school movies of the 1980s.

items.title: History and Geography
items.short_synopsis: Gioconda Martínez, a well-remembered comedic television actress, decides to return to her hometown to stage a play about the conquest of Chile, hoping to regain the artistic recognition she believed she had lost—but never truly had.
items.default_editorial: Bernardo Quesney’s biting satire paints a droll picture of a Chilean cultural industry shaped by artists as fragile as they can be cruel. Amparo Noguera’s subtle turn as an actress trying to reinvent herself in the face of barefaced disbelief is the enticing enigma at the film’s black heart.

items.title: I Trust You
items.short_synopsis: Susana and Nélida met in a convent. They abandoned their calling and adopted three-year-old Erika. They were happy, but in 2006, the women were accused of a crime and sentenced to twenty years in prison, although they maintained their innocence.
items.default_editorial: Refusing to be bound by true-crime convention, Agustín Toscano’s resourceful documentary fills in the blanks of an unsolved scandal with stylized reenactments. Musical interludes and slo-mo tableaux enliven an overworked mode, refreshing urgent questions about discrimination in the justice system.

items.title: Invisible Demons
items.short_synopsis: In the sprawling mega city of Delhi, the dangers of climate change are present, not future, for 30 million inhabitants fighting to survive. Invisible Demons explores the dramatic consequences of India’s growing economy, capturing a city in crisis, and our collective climate realities.
items.default_editorial: An urgent look at the climate crisis, Rahul Jain’s eye-opening essay unfolds in a series of stunning, often birds-eye images of a very man-made disaster. Hard to look away from and impossible to ignore, Invisible Demons immerses us in climate chaos as we hear from those caught in the crossfire.

items.title: Jane B. par Agnès V.
items.short_synopsis: On the eve of turning 40, icon Jane Birkin reflects on her career with director Agnès Varda. Candid interviews mix with film sequences where Birkin has creative freedom, playing different parts and Janes, including a classical muse, Calamity Jane, a femme fatale, Jane from Tarzan, and Joan of Arc.
items.default_editorial: On the eve of turning 40, Jane Birkin took a playful walk down memory lane with Agnès Varda. In artful tableaux, chameleonic disguises, and the opulent chambers of her Parisian abode, the chanteuse and actor reflects with singular pleasure and insight on all that is splendid about being a muse.

items.title: Kalifornia
items.short_synopsis: A writer and his photographer girlfriend leave New York to drive to a new life in California. On the way, they visit various murder sites for their new book on serial killers. They pick up two hitchhikers, one of whom could provide an interesting case study for their research…
items.default_editorial: Squeezing three 1990s marquee players into a ‘61 Lincoln convertible, this nakedly morbid road movie reeks of scalding seat leather and sex. David Duchovny’s moodily ruminative voiceover chews over the gristle of cross-class tensions and criminal notoriety, as the hijacked joyride grinds into fifth.

items.title: La Bonga
items.short_synopsis: Two decades after a death threat from right-wing paramilitaries caused a maroon community to flee, the townspeople embark on a symbolic journey through the jungles of the Colombian Caribbean to resurrect a home that exists only in their memories.
items.default_editorial: In this moving documentary, a community’s bittersweet return to what used to be their village makes for a lyrical journey through memory and a brutal reckoning with the passage of time. Determined to right a historical wrong, these inspiring people bravely revisit trauma on their emotional way home.

items.title: La Flor de Lis
items.short_synopsis: Set in the mid-nineteenth century in the western U.S., five sheriffs are looking for a serial murderer who has terrorized the local population.  Suspense and intrigue increases as the murderer remains faceless.
items.default_editorial: A taut action thriller that evokes the sun-burnished landscapes of the great American West (although it was shot in Almería, Seville, and Granada, Spain), La flor de Lis is riven with intrigue when it comes to uncovering the identity of a serial killer on the loose.

items.title: Legally Blonde
items.short_synopsis: Elle Wood, a blonde sorority queen, is dumped by her boyfriend. He is planning to become a politician and wants to find a smarter girlfriend. Elle decides to follow him to law school to get him back, but once there, she learns she has more legal savvy than she ever imagined.
items.default_editorial: A cultural phenomenon that has spawned countless pop culture tributes—including an Ariana Grande music video—this endlessly quotable classic has the iconic Reese Witherspoon breaking gender stereotypes in Jimmy Choo heels! Fashionably executed, revenge has never tasted so sweet and looked so pink.

items.title: Liberal Arts
items.short_synopsis: Bookish and newly single Jesse Fisher returns to his alma mater for his favorite professor’s retirement dinner. A chance meeting with Zibby – a precocious classical music-loving sophomore – awakens in him long-dormant feelings of possibility and connection.
items.default_editorial: The second feature from writer-director-star Josh Radnor, this campus comedy is a charming graduate from the Woody Allen school of neurotically high-minded romcoms. With an alluring performance from Elizabeth Olsen, Liberal Arts is a seductive ode to scholastic nostalgia and May-to-December romance.

items.title: Licorice Pizza
items.short_synopsis: It was 1973 in the San Fernando Valley, and 15-year-old child actor Gary Valentine found himself falling hard for the free-spirited, 10-years-older Alana Kane. As he looks to impress her with entrepreneurial hustle and innate chutzpah, her bemused interest may give way to something more.
items.default_editorial: Riding the hot breeze of a 1970s California summer, this coming-of-age wonder from Paul Thomas Anderson launches a whirlwind of mischief and mayhem. With star-making turns from Alana Haim and Cooper Hoffman, Licorice Pizza is a joyous ode to love, friendship, and the buoyancy of free-spirited youth.

items.title: Love, Women and Flowers
items.short_synopsis: What’s the cost of producing beauty? In the 1970s, foreign companies turned the Bogotá savanna into a flower industry hub, exploiting cheap labor and heavy pesticide use, causing serious health issues and even deaths among the 70,000 women working in the fields.
items.default_editorial: Plucked for Cannes Classics in 2023, this restoration of a deep reckoning with Colombian flower production is, on the surface, profuse with vibrant color. But documentarians Marta Rodríguez and Jorge Silva attend to the roots of those visual pleasures, dredging up the rot behind the pretty bouquet.

items.title: Malcolm X
items.short_synopsis: Biographical epic of the controversial and influential Black Nationalist leader, from his early life and career as a small-time gangster, to his ministry as a member of the Nation of Islam and his eventual assassination.
items.default_editorial: A bravura biopic from writer-director Spike Lee (Do the Right Thing, BlacKkKansman), this insightful, engrossing epic does full justice to its subject: civil rights leader Malcolm X. A nuanced exploration of the man and the myth, anchored by a rousing performance from Denzel Washington.

items.title: Maps to the Stars
items.short_synopsis: In Hollywood, Agatha leaves her psychiatric hospital and rocks the lives of the wealthy Weiss family. Making up the dynasty is patriarch Stafford, a psychotherapist whose self-help books have made him a fortune, and mother Cristina who manages son Benjie, 13, a child star fresh out of drug rehab.
items.default_editorial: Following his indictment of capitalism in Cosmopolis, David Cronenberg set his sights on Hollywood with this piercing look into celebrity culture and its many venomous symptoms. Ghosts, dark secrets, and the occasionally fatal dream machine that is cinema align in this calamitous tale of family.

items.title: Mar
items.short_synopsis: Martín goes on vacation with his girlfriend to Villa Gesell, an Argentinian beach. Everything seems normal and stable, until his mother’s arrival. Lightning strikes, and soon they need to make a car disappear.
items.default_editorial: Shot in Argentina, Chilean auteur Dominga Sotomayor’s sophomore featurette Mar started off as a script-less experiment in improvisation. It turned out to be a visually impeccable, light-hearted, yet incisive look at a stagnant relationship shrouded in all its pastel-colored glory.

items.title: Megalopolis
items.short_synopsis: An upstart architect dreams of turning the Big Apple into a utopia, but the Mayor has other ideas for the city. The former’s vision doesn’t correspond with the conservative ideals of the politician, who turns to dirty politics and organized crime to try and bury the progressive architect.
items.default_editorial: A passion project some 30 years in the making, Francis Ford Coppola’s spectacular sci-fi opus is a work of extraordinary vision and ambition. With an all-star cast led by Adam Driver, Megalopolis conjures a venal society on the brink of ruin, and stages a clash between iniquity and idealism.

items.title: Melancholia
items.short_synopsis: As Justine arrives for her wedding reception in her sister’s mansion home, the battle against her own inner demons resurfaces. Her behavior threatens to ruin the party and family tensions mount. But when a rogue planet named Melancholia appears in the sky, Justine knows it will destroy Earth.
items.default_editorial: Kirsten Dunst won Best Actress at Cannes for this thunderous masterwork about the catatonic effects of depression. It was perhaps inevitable that Lars von Trier’s cinema of suffering would culminate in the total annihilation of humankind. Still, the end of the world has never looked more beautiful.

items.title: Mermaids
items.short_synopsis: In 1963, the unconventional Mrs. Flax and her daughters—teenage Charlotte and young Kate—arrive in smalltown New England. Mrs Flax is prone to moving her family somewhere new whenever a romantic relationship ends. But could the arrival of kind-hearted Lou lead to a permanent stop for the family?
items.default_editorial: Juxtaposing the bewildering experience of newfound desire with the proud sensuality of adults, Mermaids portrays coming of age as a lifelong adventure. Come for Cher’s glamorous sass and Winona Ryder’s hilariously raunchy internal monologue; stay for Bob Hoskins’s radiant charm.

items.title: Metropolis
items.short_synopsis: In a highly-stylized city, a wealthy utopia exists above a bleak underworld where mistreated workers live. When privileged youth Freder discovers the grim scene below, he sets out to help the workers and befriends the rebellious teacher Maria. But this puts him at odds with his authoritative father.
items.default_editorial: One of the most iconic films ever made, Fritz Lang’s dystopian classic is as thrilling today as it was on release in 1927. A mind-blowing visual symphony, Lang’s deeply influential vision is both the foundation of sci-fi cinema and a time-honoured gateway to the expressive wonders of silent film.

items.title: Midnight Cowboy
items.short_synopsis: When Joe Buck, a good-looking, naïve Texas “cowboy,” makes his way to the Big Apple to seek his fortune, the only wealth he finds is in the friendship of Ratso Rizzo, a sleazy, small-time con man with big dreams. Living on the tattered fringe of society, the two outcasts develop an unlikely bond.
items.default_editorial: At once realist and vividly hallucinatory, this sui generis gem and Best Picture Oscar® winner is a lesson in the attraction of opposites. Jon Voight’s rube in cowboy get-up is one half of a lost-soul twosome, whose sweetly strange arrangement transcends the grime and aggression of 1960s New York.

items.title: Misery
items.short_synopsis: Romance writer Paul Sheldon—who just had his life saved by his number one fan—lives to regret it. When Annie Wilkes discovers her favorite character has been killed off in his latest novel, she’ll do anything to make sure he brings her back to life. Now Paul Sheldon must write for his life.
items.default_editorial: In this cult Stephen King adaptation, Kathy Bates thrills as the unkillable Annie Wilkes, whose Colorado farmstead is a chintzy hell on earth for James Caan. A typewriter-inspired staccato score pummels the life out of her beloved Liberace records and soaks this psychological horror in cold sweat.

items.title: Monster
items.short_synopsis: When a young boy displays increasingly worrying behavior at school and home, his mother decides to discuss it with his teachers. It soon becomes apparent that one of his teachers is the source of all the problems. But as the mystery unfolds, the truth becomes more complex than expected.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Queer Palm and Best Screenplay at Cannes, Hirokazu Kore-eda’s intricately structured drama delves into the fragility of boyhood. Bookended by fires and storms, delicate feelings of anger, confusion, and love swell through an exquisite final score from the late maestro Ryuichi Sakamoto.

items.title: Moonstruck
items.short_synopsis: In Brooklyn’s Italian-American community, widowed bookkeeper Loretta agrees to marry kind, steady Johnny. But when she meets Ronny, his passionate and moody younger brother, sparks fly. As family tensions simmer and emotions run high, Loretta finds herself in a dilemma.
items.default_editorial: Love drives people nuts in Norman Jewison’s deliciously farcical comedy, which tears into absurd social mores with glee. Cher won the Oscar® for her warm performance as a woman swept off her feet by Nicolas Cage’s wolfish lover, their offbeat romance glinting in the romantic New York City moonlight.

items.title: Motel Destino
items.short_synopsis: Motel Destino, a sex hotel in Northern Brazil, is run by the hot-headed Elias and his restless wife, Dayana. When a young gang member on the run named Heraldo stays at the motel, Dayana becomes intrigued with him. As the two navigate a dance of power and desire, a dangerous plan for freedom emerges.
items.default_editorial: Drenched in sweat, Karim Aïnouz’s pulse-pounding neon noir is an orgy of sensation and color. Captured vibrantly by famed cinematographer Hélène Louvart, an intoxicating atmosphere of danger and lust surrounds the impulsive, passionate protagonists of this pulpy erotic thriller.

items.title: My Favourite Cake
items.short_synopsis: The 70-year-old Mahin lives alone in Tehran, until she decides to break her solitary routine and revitalise her love life. But as she opens herself up to a new romance, an unexpected encounter quickly evolves into an unpredictable, unforgettable evening.
items.default_editorial: As this heartwarming tale of septuagenarian desire affirms and celebrates, romantic relationships can sweeten life at any age. Winning prizes in Berlin, codirectors Maryam Moghadam and Behtash Sanaeeha bake a plea against repressive regimes into this endearing portrait of a woman looking for love.

items.title: Nosferatu
items.short_synopsis: The mysterious Count Orlok summons Thomas Hutter to his remote Transylvanian castle in the mountains. The eerie Orlok seeks to buy a house near Hutter and his wife, Ellen. But Orlok is also the vampire Nosferatu, and when Hutter struggles to escape the castle, he knows that Ellen is in grave danger.
items.default_editorial: You don’t need sound to be terrified! With its eerie and decaying gothic atmosphere, and Max Schreck’s unforgettable, otherworldly vampire, F.W. Murnau’s Expressionist horror masterpiece seems to get increasingly disturbing as time passes. Cloaked in light and shadow, it creates a symphony of dread.

items.title: Notturno
items.short_synopsis: Shot over three years on the borders between Iraq, Kurdistan, Syria and Lebanon, Notturno depicts the everyday struggles of people attempting to rebuild their lives amongst the devastating effects of civil wars, dictatorships, foreign invasions, and the deadly presence of ISIS.
items.default_editorial: Gianfranco Rosi’s masterful nonfiction filmmaking reaches a new peak with Notturno, a breathtaking, polyphonic look at the scars of Middle Eastern conflict. A prize winner at Venice, this is an urgent cinematic achievement of unmatched grace and humanism from the Oscar®-nominated director.

items.title: Oldboy
items.short_synopsis: Imprisoned by a sadistic captor for 15 years, Oh Dae-su survives only because of his will to get even with the villain who has made his life a living hell. But when he’s suddenly released without explanation, he embarks on a quest for revenge and finds himself plunged into a Kafkaesque conspiracy.
items.default_editorial: One of the most popular international hits of the 2000s, this extreme, hyper-surreal revenge saga justly won the Grand Prix at Cannes in 2004. Amplifying South Korean master Park Chan-wook’s global prominence, Oldboy spasms with an energy that has blown minds the world over.

items.title: Outsider Girls
items.short_synopsis: Rafaela and Gabriela are young friends living in a fantasy world that is threatened when Rafaela discovers she is pregnant. She intends to have an abortion, but in Chile it’s illegal. They face the hostile system to guarantee a safe abortion for Rafaela, fighting to preserve their friendship.
items.default_editorial: A rising star in Chilean cinema, filmmaker Alexandra Hyland makes her feature debut with this spiky tale of female friendship. Staging a fleet-footed dance between comedy and drama, Outsider Girls lobs a firecracker into the public healthcare system to sound a clarion call for reproductive rights.

items.title: Paranoid Park
items.short_synopsis: An unsolved murder at Portland’s infamous Paranoid skateboard park brings detectives to a local high school. 16-year-old skater Alex decides to say nothing and gets into a moral odyssey where he must not only deal with the pain and guilt but also the consequences of his own actions.
items.default_editorial: After Gus van Sant won the Palme d’Or for Elephant, he returned to the lives of teenagers—and again took their melancholy, lethargy, and forms of fleeting escape seriously. Skateboarding is the through line in a dreamlike, mysterious story, drifting gradually toward movements of ineffable beauty.

items.title: Peacock
items.short_synopsis: Matthias is the head of a successful Rent-A-Friend agency: If you need company, want to improve your public appearance, or even manipulate someone–just rent a friend. Matthias plays every role his clients desire–like an actor–but in real life.
items.default_editorial: This polished social satire about a people pleaser climbs to hilarious heights thanks to the comedic presence of actor Albrecht Schuch. Soft-launching his real self on the hustling world, the life-shy Matthias is as winningly clueless as Monsieur Hulot: a Pierrot for the era of toxic productivity.

items.title: Peasants
items.short_synopsis: Between 1972 and 1975, peasants and workers grappled with the rise of coffee plantations and tenants’ demands. Their struggle highlights the cultural and political significance of land, contrasting Indigenous perspectives with the ruling class’s power dynamics.
items.default_editorial: As arresting as the most hard-hitting manifesto, this work of nonfiction also reverberates with folk songs calling for emancipation and change. Exhorting the underclasses to stop making the rich fat and sharpen their scythes instead, Peasants is made in the name of the people and for the people.

items.title: Perfect Days
items.short_synopsis: Hirayama lives a life of blissful contentment, spending his days balancing his job as a caretaker of Tokyo’s public toilets with his passion for music, literature, and photography. His structured routine is slowly interrupted by unexpected encounters that force him to reconnect with his past.
items.default_editorial: Kôji Yakusho won Best Actor in Cannes for this heart-warming, Oscar®-nominated drama from Wim Wenders, who lends his humanist gaze to the inhabitants of his beloved Tokyo. Charged with a superb soundtrack of classic rock and pop, Perfect Days finds beauty and serenity in the most unexpected places.

items.title: Phantom Thread
items.short_synopsis: In 1950s post-war London, renowned dressmaker Reynolds Woodcock is at the center of British fashion, dressing royalty, movie stars, and socialites. But when Woodcock comes across Alma, a young, strong-willed woman—who soon becomes his muse—he finds his carefully tailored life disrupted by love.
items.default_editorial: In this lustrous drama, master craftsman Paul Thomas Anderson handles the sumptuous fabric of a passionate courtship between headstrong lovers. Hand in glove with that feverish romance, Jonny Greenwood’s rippling piano melodies climb to the heavens and sigh at the triumph of tenderness over regimen.

items.title: Pig
items.short_synopsis: Following the death of his wife, a truffle hunter and former chef has given up everything and lives alone in the Oregonian wilderness. But when his beloved truffle foraging pig is kidnapped, he returns to his past in Portland and teams up with a young man to find her.
items.default_editorial: Eschewing the manic, maximalist register that has become his métier, Nicolas Cage delivers a haunted meditation on grief and loss in Michael Sarnoski’s anguished thriller. Quietly subverting revenge-movie tropes, Pig patiently hangs up its knives to reveal a soulful paean to acceptance and change.

items.title: Platoon
items.short_synopsis: Innocent teenage soldier Chris Taylor is thrown headfirst into the bloody Vietnam War. As his platoon battles the Viet Cong, tensions mount between ruthless Sergeant Barnes and compassionate Sergeant Elias. Caught between them, Chris fights to survive the battlefield and the war within his unit.
items.default_editorial: The first Hollywood Vietnam war film directed by a veteran of the conflict, Oliver Stone’s visceral classic confronts the barbarity of combat and the plight of innocent civilians with shocking realism. Resisting flag-waving valor, Platoon douses the myth of American exceptionalism in blood and mud.

items.title: Pleasure
items.short_synopsis: Bella arrives in Los Angeles from her hometown in Sweden, with dreams of becoming the next porn superstar. However, as her ruthless ambition leads her into increasingly dangerous territory, Bella struggles to reconcile her dreams of empowerment with the realities of the darker side of her industry.
items.default_editorial: Centered on a powerful bravura performance from breakout star Sofia Kappel, Pleasure is the refreshingly uncompromising debut feature from Ninja Thyberg. An unflinching exploration of agency, ambition, and consent in the adult film industry that seeks to bust stale taboos about sex work.

items.title: Point Break
items.short_synopsis: In Los Angeles, a gang of bank robbers called The Ex-Presidents commit their crimes while wearing masks of Reagan, Carter, Nixon and Johnson. The FBI believes that the members of the gang could be surfers, and send young agent Johnny Utah undercover to mix with them and gather information.
items.default_editorial: Kathryn Bigelow has wowed audiences with her interpretation of classic genres and the now-cult Point Break does just that, by subverting both action film and surfer buddy movie. A look at male relationships through a woman’s gaze, with Keanu Reeves and Patrick Swayze delivering iconic performances.

items.title: Portrait of a Lady on Fire
items.original_title: Portrait de la jeune fille en feu
items.short_synopsis: In late 18th century France, painter Marianne is commissioned by a countess to paint the wedding portrait of her daughter Héloïse. While posing as her hired companion, Marianne is instructed to complete the portrait in secret. However, intimacy and attraction begin to blossom between both women.
items.default_editorial: Céline Sciamma turns the male gaze over its head to present its female version: a feminist tale of lesbian desire, aching romanticism, and creative collaboration. The result is an instant classic, glistening with sumptuous images and an unforgettable duo: Adèle Haenel and Noémie Merlant.

items.title: Precious
items.short_synopsis: In New York City’s Harlem circa 1987, an overweight, abused, illiterate teen who is pregnant with her second child is invited to enroll in an alternative school in hopes that she can re-route her life in a better direction.
items.default_editorial: A multi-Academy Award®-winner from director Lee Daniels and writer Geoffrey Fletcher, Gabourey Sidibe and Mo’Nique star in the harrowing, hard-hitting Precious: a truly compelling depiction of intra-family abuse and life in the inner city. Based on the novel Push by Sapphire.

items.title: Reality
items.short_synopsis: A former American intelligence specialist receives the longest sentence for unauthorized disclosure of government information to the media. The leaked details pertain to Russian interference in the 2016 United States elections through an email operation.
items.default_editorial: Pulling its dialogue from FBI transcripts, this riveting thriller restages the arrest and cross-examination of whistleblower Reality Winner in close-to-real time. With a superb lead performance from Sydney Sweeney, Tina Satter’s gripping film interrogates the cost of truth and the balance of power.

items.title: Reality
items.short_synopsis: Luciano is a charming and affable fishmonger whose unexpected and sudden obsession with being a contestant on the reality show Big Brother leads him down a rabbit hole of skewed perceptions and paranoia. So overcome by his dream of being on reality TV, Luciano’s reality spirals out of control.
items.default_editorial: The surprise winner of the 2012 Cannes Grand Prix, Matteo Garrone’s enigmatic follow-up to Gomorrah is no simple satire of reality TV, but something much stranger. This absurd comic nightmare looks at a country caught between the sweet life and the Pope. Somewhere out there, Buñuel is smiling.

items.title: Revenge
items.short_synopsis: Jen is on a romantic getaway with her wealthy boyfriend, when his friends suddenly arrive for a hunting trip. Tensions in the house mount until things culminate in a shocking act that leaves Jen abandoned to die. Unfortunately for her assailants, Jen survives and reemerges with one intent: revenge.
items.default_editorial: Weaponizing tropes to neo-feminist ends, Coralie Fargeat fires on all cylinders in this killer film. Adrenalized by the same fascination with transformation that sparks across The Substance, the provocateur filmmaker empowers her heroine to go from Barbie to badass with dangerous, delirious style.

items.title: Rimini
items.short_synopsis: Two men, two brothers, their childhood home in Lower Austria. They drink to their late mother, they bury her. Then they drive back to their real lives. But sooner or later both their pasts will catch up with them.
items.default_editorial: At times recalling The Wrestler in its study of chasing faded fame, Rimini is a funny, sometimes vulgar and often moving tale of people struggling towards contentment despite lifetimes of disappointment. The film is a scathing character study about how easy it can be to commodify people’s lives.

items.title: Ring
items.short_synopsis: A group of teenage friends are found dead, their faces twisted in terror. Reiko, a journalist and the aunt of one of the victims, sets out to investigate. In the process, she uncovers an urban legend about a cursed videotape, the contents of which causes anyone who views it to die within a week.
items.default_editorial: Inaugurating the explosion of “J-horror” exports at the turn of the millennium, this wild—and wildly successful—chiller sounded the arrival of one of the most fertile scenes in modern horror cinema. Forget the American remake, Hideo Nakata’s cursed-video classic remains the definitive scarefest.

items.title: Rodrigo D: No Future
items.short_synopsis: Rodrigo and his friends, restless teens in Medellín’s hillside shantytowns, spend their days stirring up trouble. But Rodrigo has dreams of playing rock and roll. He rallies his friends to form a punk band—which emerges as their salvation from a web of aimlessness, violence, drugs, and fear.
items.default_editorial: The first Colombian film to compete for the Palme d’Or, Víctor Gaviria’s blistering feature debut oozes with the rage and apathy of disaffected youth. Snatches of punk music gesture at an urgent and vital need to release pent-up despair, but also underline the raw beauty glimpsed among ruins.

items.title: Saturdays Disorders
items.short_synopsis: During a surreal pilgrimage to the town of Luján, the protagonist Luján finds herself lost in a maze of suburban oddities. Meanwhile, the local tennis complex is hosting a bizarre tournament featuring only two players.
items.default_editorial: Jumping back and forth in time, this sequel to Smog in Your Heart exposes the restless feelings of a group coming apart at the seams. Black-and-white cinematography adds a parodic sheen of tragedy to the histrionics of characters who are more emotionally unmoored than ever before.

items.title: Semana Santa
items.short_synopsis: Dali, her son Pepe, and her new boyfriend Chávez are on a peaceful beach vacation—but the promise of relaxation quickly fades. Pepe longs for his late father, Chávez frets over money, and Dali silently struggles with her grief. As the group grows distant, each person embarks on a separate adventure.
items.default_editorial: Attuned to the slightest shifts in behavior and nuances of language, Alejandra Márquez Abella gently excavates hidden fractures between three characters in this simmering debut feature. Refined and delicate, the film’s camerawork is also unsparing in revealing secret pains and dormant hopes.

items.title: Seven Chances
items.short_synopsis: Struggling stockbroker Jimmie Shannon learns that, if he gets married by 7 p.m. on his 27th birthday – which is today – he’ll inherit $7 million from an eccentric relative. But, after Mary Jones, whom he’s mooned over for years, turns him down, he has only hours to find a woman who’ll marry him.
items.default_editorial: It may not be as well known, but this high-concept gem is every bit as packed with ingenuity as Buster Keaton’s most iconic treasures. In a climax that sees hundreds of brick-wielding brides chase our forlorn hero through the streets, Seven Chances serves up a masterclass in comic escalation.

items.title: Sherlock Jr.
items.short_synopsis: A film projectionist longs to be a detective, and puts his meager skills to work when he is framed by a rival for stealing his girlfriend’s father’s pocketwatch.
items.default_editorial: With mathematical precision and more than a dash of visionary genius, Buster Keaton created one of the most indelible images in film history when he stepped inside a cinema screen in Sherlock Jr. and clowned around in its images. A century has done nothing to dim its flickering magic.

items.title: Showgirls
items.short_synopsis: Nomi, a young drifter, arrives in Vegas to become a dancer. She gets a job stripping at one of the lesser joints on the strip, but soon catches the eye of talent scouts who hire the performers for a casino. She works her way into the cast, and eventually sets her sights on taking the starring role.
items.default_editorial: From Dutch provocateur turned Hollywood maverick Paul Verhoeven, this glitter-blasted satire of American materialism owes as much to the melodramas of Douglas Sirk as it does the showbiz classic All About Eve. Widely misunderstood in its day, Showgirls is a luridly entertaining icon of ’90s kitsch.

items.title: Silver Linings Playbook
items.short_synopsis: After losing his job and wife, Pat Solatano winds up living with his parents. He wants to rebuild his life, but his parents would be happy if he just shared their obsession with the Philadelphia Eagles. Things get complicated when Pat meets Tiffany, who offers to help him reconnect with his wife.
items.default_editorial: With an all-star cast that includes Bradley Cooper, Robert De Niro, and an Oscar®-winning Jennifer Lawrence, David O. Russell’s funniest film to date is a whirlwind of romantic dysfunction. Fizzing with energy and bounding between cynicism and charm, this breezy romcom is a crowd-pleasing delight.

items.title: Sleepy
items.short_synopsis: Carlos has a disease called “Fatal Familial Insomnia”, which causes degenerative deterioration of his body and mind. An alternative cure is offered to him, which will unveil a story full of deception, pharmaceutical and political interests as well as an intense debate between life and death.
items.default_editorial: The impassioned debut from director and stuntman Joaquín Ortega (La Flor de Lis) follows a victim of lethal insomnia on a quest to find an alternative cure. Exploring the push and pull of life, death, and deep sleep, Sleepy is a fascinating action-thriller about bodies on the brink.

items.title: Smog in Your Heart
items.short_synopsis: Five people work at a tennis complex—the owner Manuel, a tennis teacher named La Tenista, new recruit Sergio from San Juan, shy manager Luján, and a dopey accountant Aristegui. Tensions flare as they consider making a pilgrimage to the cathedral of the town of Luján, but don’t actually invite Luján.
items.default_editorial: The dry humor of multi-camera sitcoms meshes with absurdist minimalism in this hypnotically bizarre workplace comedy. With rapid editing and hilariously vapid dialogue, Smog in Your Heart kickstarts Lucía Seles’s surreal “Pentalogy of Hate,” reimagining the melodrama for our disjointed times.

items.title: Snowpiercer
items.short_synopsis: A post-apocalyptic ice age forces humanity’s survivors aboard a globe-spanning super train that functions via a perpetual-motion engine and through a cruel class system. One of the train’s poorest residents risks everything to incite a revolt for control of the engine, and the future of the world.
items.default_editorial: Before the global success of Parasite, Bong Joon Ho made his English-language debut with this high-concept vision of a world on the verge of collapse. Jump aboard with a monster ensemble including Octavia Spencer, Tilda Swinton, John Hurt & Song Kang-ho and let the clash of class hierarchies begin!

items.title: Some Like It Hot
items.short_synopsis: In 1920s Chicago, two unemployed jazz musicians accidentally witness a deadly mob hit. Dressed up as women, they decide to go into hiding as members of an all-female traveling band on their way to Florida. They both fall in love with Sugar, the band’s vocalist who dreams of marrying a billionaire.
items.default_editorial: One of the defining screwball comedies, this classic from Billy Wilder notably contributed to the downfall of Hollywood’s Hays Code. Starring Marilyn Monroe alongside Tony Curtis and Jack Lemmon, the film’s charming cast matches a perfectly executed madcap script, making audiences howl to this day.

items.title: Something Wild
items.short_synopsis: A straitlaced businessman meets a quirky, free-spirited woman at a downtown New York greasy spoon. Her offer of a ride back to his office results in a lunchtime motel rendezvous, kickstarting an impulsive interstate road trip that brings the two face-to-face with their hidden selves.
items.default_editorial: Jonathan Demme’s off-kilter comedy turns the cliché of the philandering husband inside out to celebrate the thrill of broken rules and skirted responsibilities. Jeff Daniels and Melanie Griffith sizzle as the dynamic duo at the heart of this groovy escapade, doing their best to outrun the past.

items.title: Sometimes I Think About Dying
items.short_synopsis: Fran likes to think about dying. It brings sensation to her quiet life. When she makes the new guy at work laugh, it leads to more: a date, a slice of pie, a conversation, a spark. The only thing standing in their way is Fran herself.
items.default_editorial: Fatalistic daydreams uncannily invade the monotony of office life in Rachel Lambert’s darkly comic drama, starring a revelatory Daisy Ridley. Tempering surreal reveries with down-to-earth feelings, this idiosyncratic character portrait finds love—and the will to live—in the most unlikely of places.

items.title: Strange Way of Life
items.short_synopsis: After 25 years apart, rancher Silva rides across the desert to visit his former flame, town sheriff Jake. But after an evening of shared intimacy, reminiscing, and reconciliation, the revelation of both men’s link to a local crime suggests there is more to their meeting than a trip down memory lane.
items.default_editorial: Stylishly produced by luxury fashion house Saint Laurent, Pedro Almodóvar’s hot-blooded queer western sizzles with the chemistry shared by silver foxes Ethan Hawke and Pedro Pascal. Witness to the eternal battle between order and disobedience, the American frontier is awakened to new fiery passions.

items.title: Sundown
items.short_synopsis: A wealthy man is vacationing with loved ones at a resort in Acapulco, Mexico until he receives a phone call. There’s been a death in the family, and everyone must return home. However, the man pretends to lose his passport, which delays his return.
items.default_editorial: No one needs to tell director Michel Franco how close comedy is to tragedy. Rather than blurring the line, this Acapulco-set tale of midlife crisis simply obliterates it. Starring a magnificently placid Tim Roth, Sundown is a transgressive tour de force from Mexican cinema’s preeminent provocateur.

items.title: Sweat
items.short_synopsis: Fitness influencer Sylwia seemingly has it made: hundreds of thousands of social media followers, endorsement deals, photo spreads in magazines. But as she starts to share more online, the rising pressure forces her to confront her deepest insecurities and the exhaustive demands of her lifestyle.
items.default_editorial: A riveting portrait of modern celebrity, Magnus von Horn’s Sweat strips away the digital veneer to reveal the human cost of influencer culture. Astonishingly embodied by Magdalena Koleśnik in a tenacious performance, this compassionate tale of self-discovery pulses with the energy of a thriller.

items.title: Tango
items.short_synopsis: Mario Suárez, a seasoned film director, struggles with a personal crisis after his wife leaves him due to depression. Immersing himself in his tango film, he becomes captivated by the lead dancer, a passionate performer whose lover, a dangerous mobster, has invested heavily in the production.
items.default_editorial: Embracing the colorful artifice of musicals, this Oscar®-nominated marvel from Spanish master Carlos Saura wanders through the labyrinth of the creative process, where private turmoil and artistic bliss collide. As bodies become entwined, Tango sways to the seductive rhythm of memory and desire.

items.title: Tempestad
items.short_synopsis: A group of innocent people are charged with human trafficking and thrown into prison. Authorities reassure the public that they’ve dealt a blow to organized crime. But an innocent mother is handed over to those for whom she’s being made to atone—in a private prison controlled by the Gulf Cartel.
items.default_editorial: Before her ravishing fiction debut Prayers for the Stolen, Tatiana Huezo delved into the lives of two women caught in a whirlwind of violence in this stark, atmospheric documentary. A frank and contemplative look at the physical and emotional impact of crime that finds poetry in the darkest places.

items.title: Terminal Young
items.short_synopsis: A light-eyed man who, thanks to his best friend, works as an accountant at a tennis complex, rebels against the universe and himself to become an accountant for flower shops.
items.default_editorial: Off from work at the tennis complex where their shared story began, Lucía Seles’s protagonists find in their personal lives little respite from emotional torment. Structured around a turbulent birthday party, Terminal Young is an eventful entry in the director’s deliriously awkward soap opera.

items.title: The Apartment
items.short_synopsis: Ambitious insurance clerk C.C. “Bud” Baxter attempts to climb the corporate ladder by loaning his apartment key to his superiors for their extramarital affairs. But the plan backfires when Bud unwittingly falls for the top executive’s current girlfriend, Fran Kubelik.
items.default_editorial: One year after Some Like It Hot, director Billy Wilder, writer I. A. L. Diamond, and star Jack Lemmon reteamed for one of the most beloved romantic comedies of all time. Gorgeously designed, and with an irresistible turn from Shirley MacLaine, The Apartment is a Best Picture–winner for the ages.

items.title: The Babadook
items.short_synopsis: A single mother, plagued by the violent death of her husband, battles with her son’s fear of a monster lurking in the house, but soon discovers a sinister presence all around her.
items.default_editorial: Horror as a genre has long facilitated some of the most deeply felt renderings of loss in cinema. With her acclaimed film The Babadook, director Jennifer Kent picked up this mantle with a chilling treatise on the many shapes grief can take, and the battle that is motherhood. A modern horror classic.

items.title: The Balconettes
items.short_synopsis: As a heat wave brings a Marseille neighbourhood to the boil, three roommates gleefully meddle in the lives of their neighbours from their balcony. Until a late night drink turns into a bloody affair.
items.default_editorial: Cowritten with Céline Sciamma, Noémie Merlant’s maximalist celebration of sisterhood skewers phallocentrism with Almodóvar-esque style. Girl-powered by kittenish camerawork and screams of laughter, this horror-comedy plays like a feminist reimagining of Rear Window for the age of the house share.

items.title: The Beast
items.short_synopsis: In the near future where emotions have become a threat, Gabrielle finally decides to purify her DNA in a machine that will immerse her in her past lives and rid her of any strong feelings. She then meets Louis and feels a powerful connection, as if she had known him forever.
items.default_editorial: Inspired by a Henry James parable, Bertrand Bonello’s arresting odyssey stars Léa Seydoux and George MacKay in an epoch-spanning tale of doomed love. Awash with dread, desire, and loneliness, The Beast alternates between sci-fi, melodrama, and horror, capturing the paralyzing fear of the unknown.

items.title: The Beasts
items.short_synopsis: An expatriate French couple operate an organic farm in the Spanish countryside. However, their earnest enthusiasm reeks of patronizing privilege to the handful of “hill people” families who have toiled on the land for generations, leading to tensions between locals and foreigners boiling over.
items.default_editorial: Inspired by a shocking real-life case, this small-scale tragedy is a masterclass in escalating tension. A sharp exploration of how egomania clouds judgment, Rodrigo Sorogoyen’s gripping thriller thrums with shifting power dynamics as machismo buckles in a nasty clash at the film’s thorny center.

items.title: The Brickmakers
items.short_synopsis: Amid Bogotá’s urban estates, pottery workers face inhumane exploitation by employers. The intricate connections between technological advancements, production relations, and the ideological framework within this community of laborers, reveal the deep-seated issues that perpetuate their struggle.
items.default_editorial: Brickmakers opens with an epigraph from Marx then persists in that spirit of revolution. Countering a primitive system of horse-drawn contraptions and oppressed people worked to the bone, it uses direct cinema’s innovations in a bold effort to liberate those living hand-to-mouth in 1970s Colombia.

items.title: The Code
items.short_synopsis: Early-pandemic, Jay and Celine head to a rental house to reconnect. While Celine films a documentary on their disintegrating relationship, a recently ‘cancelled’ Jay becomes increasingly paranoid about his portrayal, setting up hidden cameras to spy on Celine.
items.default_editorial: Physical touch has been eclipsed by taps and clicks, but Eugene Kotlyarenko’s absurdist comedy proposes a spicy aphrodisiac for the modern couple: digital surveillance! Swapping foreplay for spyware apps and screen recordings, this film-within-a-film romp searches for love in the time of drones.

items.title: The Descent
items.short_synopsis: A year after severe emotional trauma, Sarah spends some time exploring caves with her friends. After descending underground, the women find evidence of an earlier expedition and learn they are not alone. Underground predators inhabit the crevasses, and they have a taste for human flesh.
items.default_editorial: Plenty of films have been described as among the scariest ever made, but few can back up such claims quite like Neil Marshall’s cave-bound survival horror. Featuring an all-woman cast and with careful attention paid to its group dynamics, The Descent is a relentless, adrenalised rush of pure terror.

items.title: The Edukators
items.short_synopsis: Activists Jan, Peter, and Jule lead a silent revolution as the self-styled “Edukators”. Breaking into houses by the cover of the night, they seek to unnerve the wealthy through their protest art—until a terrible incident threatens not only their political beliefs but their trust in each other.
items.default_editorial: A cult film of the millennium comedown starring Daniel Brühl, The Edukators hot-wires the anger of the 1968 student revolution and refuels it for the nihilistic early 2000s. Natural light and handheld camerawork lend intimacy and immediacy to this exhilarating vision of Gen Y rebellion.

items.title: The Feeling That the Time for Doing Something Has Passed
items.original_title: The Feeling That the Time for Doing Something Has Passed
items.short_synopsis: Ann, a morose New Yorker in her 30s, feels stuck in all areas of her life—the years have gone by quickly in her long-term casual BDSM relationship, low-level corporate job, and quarrelsome Jewish family. As she begins to feel increasingly alienated, she wrestles with herself and her relationships.
items.default_editorial: Written and directed by its sardonic star Joanna Arnow, this critically acclaimed film drily demonstrates the ceaseless absurdity of modern dating, sex, and work. Another New York tale of millennial aimlessness? Not quite: offbeat comic timing and a candid feeling for kink set this oddball apart.

items.title: The Goat
items.short_synopsis: After missing out on a fresh loaf of bread, an innocent and unsuspecting Buster winds up with his face mistakenly on a Wanted Dead or Alive poster all over town. On the run he ends up in the home of Virginia, only to come face to face with his worst fear.
items.default_editorial: Scampering through the city as if it were a playground, Buster Keaton sets off a spiraling comedy of errors as a man mistaken for a murderer. Some of the most immaculately simple gags in silent comedy can be found in the humble twenty-minute runtime of this miniature modernist delight.

items.title: The Good Girls
items.short_synopsis: The year is 1982, and an economic crisis is hitting Mexico. The always charming, perfect, and spoiled Sofia, the queen bee of her friend group, faces the unimaginable—her social decay. Cracks appear in Sofia and her husband’s manicured lives as the social and economic order shifts around them.
items.default_editorial: Opulence turns sour in Alejandra Márquez Abella’s sophomore feature, a slick and delightfully corrosive look at the downfall of the 80s Mexican jet set. Topped by Ilse Salas’ brilliant turn as a desperate housewife of the era, this wicked satire becomes a class nightmare Buñuel would approve of.

items.title: The Good, the Bad and the Ugly
items.original_title: Il buono, il brutto, il cattivo
items.short_synopsis: Amid the chaos of the American Civil War, three gunslingers—Blondie, Tuco, and Angel Eyes—race to uncover a fortune in stolen Confederate gold. Each holds part of the secret to its location, but uneasy alliances and shifting loyalties lead them toward a legendary final showdown.
items.default_editorial: Working on a colossal canvas, genre maestro Sergio Leone stages one indelible sequence after another in this maximalist western epic. Starring Clint Eastwood in one of his defining roles, The Good, The Bad and the Ugly finds only avarice and depravity at the heart of a nascent civilization.

items.title: The Happy Version of Eden
items.short_synopsis: Santiago, 1973. In La Moneda presidential palace, President Salvador Allende wakes up to a call informing him that a military coup is taking place. His lover weeps. F-19 aircrafts poise to bomb La Moneda. Allende refuses to surrender. Bodies are thrown into the air.
items.default_editorial: Trembling hand-drawn animation creates a visceral sensation of frenzy in this breathtaking short. Against a rich audio background of thundering music, radio messages, and combat sounds, images continuously morph into one another, suggesting the relentless march of history.

items.title: The Holy Girl
items.short_synopsis: Amalia, an adolescent torn between her sexuality and Catholic faith, encounters Dr. Jano’s inappropriate advances. Repulsed yet inspired, she believes it’s her mission to save him. Becoming an unusual voyeur, she starts stalking the doctor.
items.default_editorial: Triangulating adolescence with liminal spaces of hotels and pools, Lucrecia Martel followed a seismic debut with an exquisitely framed, richly textured examination of desire. Kissing, tonguing, and touching are acts of divine calling as much as rites of passage in this astounding coming-of-age film.

items.title: The Human Voice
items.short_synopsis: A woman watches time passing next to the suitcases of her ex-lover (who is supposed to come pick them up, but never arrives) and a restless dog who doesn’t understand that his master has abandoned him. Two living beings facing abandonment.
items.default_editorial: For his English-language debut, our favourite Spanish auteur Pedro Almodóvar teams up with Tilda Swinton for a loose adaptation of Jean Cocteau’s timeless play. Swinton delivers a spellbinding solo performance, in which vulnerability and despair turn into a monologue of magnificent obsession.

items.title: The Kindergarten Teacher
items.short_synopsis: Lisa Spinelli, married and living with kids who mostly ignore her, plods through her days teaching kindergarten with growing numbness. But one day everything changes—Lisa discovers that a five-year-old boy in her class may be the poet she can only dream of being. She becomes fascinated.
items.default_editorial: Sara Colangelo won a directing award in Sundance for her remake of Nadav Lapid’s film, starring Maggie Gyllenhaal—also a producer—at her very best! This riveting tale of obsession and disenchantment ambiguously questions what might be the role of art in our everyday life and personal development.

items.title: The Last House on the Left
items.original_title: The Last House on the Left
items.short_synopsis: For her birthday, Mari and friend Phyllis set off to the big city to attend a concert. Attempting to pick up some marijuana on the way, the pair run afoul of a group of crooks, headed up by the sadistic Krug. Gagged and bound, the young women are subjected to a terrifying ordeal.
items.default_editorial: Wes Craven may now be known for his slyly satirizing Scream series, but what new horror fans forget is that he pioneered the modern horror genre with such enduring terrors as this, his debut (!), and The Hills Have Eyes. A sign of their classic status? They’ve been remade into much worse films!

items.title: The Practice
items.short_synopsis: Dealing with a series of absurd situations and relationships, recently separated yoga instructors Gustavo and Vanesa are finding it difficult to live apart. Their challenges include meddling mothers, amnesiac students, and burgeoning romances. Step by step, they find their way back to the practice.
items.default_editorial: Accommodating both the downbeat and the surreal, Martín Rejtman’s first feature in nine years treats midlife depression with a holistic sense of humor. Comic scenarios flow into one another with the flexibility of a master yogi, and achieve a strengthened core in The Delinquents’ Esteban Bigliardi.

items.title: The Quiet Girl
items.short_synopsis: Rural Ireland, 1981. A quiet, neglected nine-year-old girl is sent away from her dysfunctional family to live with in-laws for the summer. At first a bit intimidated by her new environment, she then blossoms in their care—but in this house where there are meant to be no secrets, she discovers one.
items.default_editorial: The first Irish-language feature film to premiere at Berlinale, Colm Bairéad’s award-winning debut is rooted in the small gestures that hold a staggering world of meaning. Uncommonly attuned to the solitude of girlhood, this evocative portrait of 1980s rural Ireland sings with beauty and melancholy.

items.title: The Rose Seller
items.short_synopsis: Thirteen-year-old Mónica rebels against everything, surviving on the streets where she defends her pride, her friends, and her boyfriend, a drug dealer. On Christmas Eve, she sells roses to buy dreams of celebration, but life leads her back to solitude, poverty, drugs, and death.
items.default_editorial: Updating Hans Christian Andersen’s Little Match Girl to the streets of Medellín, Víctor Gaviria’s affecting second feature brings into focus the emotional lives of children fighting for survival. In a world ruled by violence, The Rose Seller restores humanity to characters made to feel expendable.

items.title: The Second Act
items.short_synopsis: Florence wants to introduce David, the man she’s madly in love with, to her father Guillaume. But David isn’t attracted to Florence and wants to throw her into the arms of his friend Willy. The four of them meet in a restaurant in the middle of nowhere.
items.default_editorial: Selected to open Cannes in 2024, Quentin Dupieux’s star-studded and deliriously meta comedy turns the business of filmmaking upside down. From breaking the fourth wall to satirizing AI technologies, this subtly surreal farce predicts the future—or perhaps the death—of cinema with outrageous glee.

items.title: The Seed of the Sacred Fig
items.original_title: The Seed of the Sacred Fig
items.short_synopsis: Iman, a judge in Tehran, grows paranoid amid political unrest when his gun vanishes. Suspecting his wife and daughters, he enforces harsh rules at home, escalating tension as family and societal norms slowly unravel.
items.default_editorial: A raging work of political resistance, this epic thriller from Mohammad Rasoulof was smuggled out of the exiled director’s native Iran. Awarded the Jury Special Prize in Cannes, and set against a backdrop of women-led protests, The Seed of the Sacred Fig is a fierce study of patriarchal oppression.

items.title: The Silence of the Lambs
items.short_synopsis: With a psychopath named Buffalo Bill murdering women and believing it takes one to know one, the FBI sends Agent Clarice Starling to interview Dr. Hannibal Lecter, a cannibalistic psychiatrist. As their bond develops, Lecter’s fascination with the Starling becomes as great as his hunger for murder.
items.default_editorial: Disturbing and captivating in equal measures, The Silence of the Lambs ranks as one of the best psychological thriller-horrors of all times. Winning 5 Oscars® (including Best Film, Director, Actor and Actress), this now cult film stars Jodie Foster, as well as Anthony Hopkins at his most terrifying.

items.title: The Texas Chain Saw Massacre
items.short_synopsis: When Sally hears that her grandfather’s grave has been vandalized, she and her brother, Franklin, set out with friends to investigate. After a detour to the family farmhouse, they discover a murderous cannibal lives next door. Once Leatherface starts to attack, they try everything to escape.
items.default_editorial: Vietnam changed everything for the American horror movie, forcing a seismic reckoning with the fragility of the nation’s value systems. Ruthlessly unsentimental and shot through with gallows humour, Tobe Hooper’s grimy, era-defining classic takes a sledgehammer to any remnants of the summer of love.

items.title: The Wild Goose Lake
items.original_title: Nan Fang Che Zhan De Ju Hui | 南方车站的聚会
items.short_synopsis: In the Chinese city of Wuhan, a network of lakes provide ideal places to hide, and when transgressive mid-level crime boss Zhou needs to lay low, he looks for anonymity amidst the neon-lit hangouts. There he meets sex worker Liu, who works for Zhou’s boss and who may or may not be there to save him.
items.default_editorial: After winning the Berlinale Golden Bear with Black Coal, Thin Ice, Diao Yinan returns with a hyper-stylised noir set in modern China’s underbelly. Twisting the conventions of the genre, this impressively crafted choreography of violence, moral decay and neon colours is striking, intoxicating cinema.

items.title: Thelma & Louise
items.short_synopsis: Independent and strong-willed Louise persuades her timid friend Thelma to leave her controlling husband for a road trip. But when Louise rescues Thelma from an assault at a bar, the two flee across the country, turning to crime and finding unexpected freedom and empowerment on the run.
items.default_editorial: Sparking debate upon its release—and not long after hailed as a classic—this iconic drama earned first-time screenwriter Callie Khouri an Academy Award® for Best Screenplay. Fueled by a pair of vibrant, enthralling lead performances, Thelma & Louise is a feminist road trip for the ages.

items.title: This Is Not Berlin
items.short_synopsis: The year is 1986, and World Cup fever has hit Mexico. 17-year-old Carlos doesn’t fit in anywhere: not in his family nor with the friends he has at school. But everything changes when he is invited to a mythical, underground nightclub where he discovers post punk, drugs, politics and sexual fluidity.
items.default_editorial: A heady plunge into the underground excesses of 1980s Mexico City, Hari Sama’s coming-of-age film roars with a youthful thirst for love, revolt, and the catharsis of art. Rebelling against the nostalgia for artistic hedonism, this subversive time capsule questions the ethics of the creative process.

items.title: To the Left of the Father
items.short_synopsis: In 1940s São Paulo, Pedro’s tasked to retrieve his estranged brother André. André’s departure stems from a domineering father, an overly affectionate mother, and Pedro’s jealousy over the father’s favoritism. Further complicating matters is André’s unconventional relationship with their sister, Ana.
items.default_editorial: Hailed as one of the best Brazilian films of all time, Luiz Fernando Carvalho’s epic family saga stars a sensational Selton Mello as a prodigal son gripped by taboo desires. Weaving multiple timelines and cinematic styles, this brutal, beautiful masterwork is a powerful howl for personal liberation.

items.title: Too Late for Tears
items.short_synopsis: Through a fluke circumstance a ruthless woman stumbles across a suitcase filled with $60,000, and she is determined to hold onto it even it if means murder.
items.default_editorial: A slick and nasty take on the classic noir theme of an ordinary couple dragged into crime and perversion, Too Late For Tears hums with heat and passion. Byron Haskin’s film features femme fatale extraordinaire Lizabeth Scott and the noir stalwart Dan Duryea (Scarlet Street).

items.title: Too Late to Die Young
items.short_synopsis: Chile in the summer of 1990. As the country comes to terms with the end of Pinochet’s dictatorship, Sofía, Lucas and Clara, a group of adolescents living in a rural commune, attempt to make sense of their own burgeoning desires and tangled relationships while preparing for New Year’s Eve.
items.default_editorial: Unravelling during the days leading to New Year’s Eve in a freedom-seeking commune, Dominga Sotomayor’s evocative, sensorial work portrays with aestival languor a turning point from childhood to adulthood, in a Chile reeling from Pinochet’s dictatorship. A multi award-winner in Locarno & Rotterdam!

items.title: True History of the Kelly Gang
items.original_title: True History of the Kelly Gang
items.short_synopsis: Amidst the grueling badlands of 19th-century Australia, legendary outlaw Ned Kelly grows up under the bloody and uncompromising rule of the English. Nurtured by notorious bushranger Harry Power and fuelled by revenge, Kelly recruits a wild bunch of warriors to wreak havoc on their oppressors.
items.default_editorial: In this visceral character study, Justin Kurzel unravels biopic conventions to paint a high-contrast portrait of his mysterious subject. Powered by an energetic performance from George MacKay and impactful turns from Russell Crowe and Charlie Hunnam, this is cinema at its punchiest.

items.title: Valley Girl
items.short_synopsis: When Julie dumps her preppy boyfriend, the last thing she expects is to find love with the rockin’ Randy. The future’s open wide for Julie—but when her disapproving friends find Randy to be unpleasant, she is caught up in a culture clash between her Valley lifestyle and her Hollywood punk hunk.
items.default_editorial: An endearingly goofy Nicolas Cage in his first leading role brings out the dimples in a blushing Deborah Foreman in this interclass teen romance. A 1980s new wave and power pop soundtrack sets the smitten mood of this Romeo and Juliet modernisation that paved the way for Amy Heckerling’s Clueless.

items.title: WarGames
items.short_synopsis: When computer hacker David unwittingly taps into the Defense Department’s war computer, he initiates a confrontation of global proportions: World War III. Together with his girlfriend and a computer genius, David must race against time to outwit his opponent—and prevent a nuclear Armageddon.
items.default_editorial: A daring blend of apocalyptic paranoia and Spielbergian family adventure, John Badham’s nuclear romp brought computer hacking (and Matthew Broderick!) to public attention. User-friendly in its approach to genre and intelligently satirical, this well-calibrated studio film is a Cold War classic.

items.title: We Need to Talk About Kevin
items.original_title: We Need to Talk About Kevin
items.short_synopsis: Eva puts her ambitions and career aside to give birth to Kevin. The relationship between mother and son is difficult from the very first years. When he does something irrational and unforgivable in the eyes of the community, Eva grapples with her own feelings of grief and responsibility.
items.default_editorial: Nine agonizing years after Morvern Callar, Lynne Ramsay returned to Cannes with another acclaimed literary adaptation. Radically reimagining the nature-or-nurture novel, Ramsay—and star Tilda Swinton—transform the text into a chilling film rightfully venerated for its unforgettable visual language.

items.title: Weak Rangers
items.short_synopsis: Neither the cold nor the storms can calm you when facing a new boss you wouldn’t want.
items.default_editorial: Workplace rumors, passive-aggressive colleagues, an unsteady work-life balance—these simmering tensions turn explosive in the most chaotic installment of Lucía Seles’s lo-fi saga. Playing with time, the director lets stupefying scenes of panic sit alongside genuine moments of grace.

items.title: When Harry Met Sally...
items.short_synopsis: Harry and Sally meet as students. They share a drive from Chicago to New York. After the disagreeable journey, they part ways, Harry declaring that men and women can never be just friends. Over the next ten years, Harry and Sally will bump into each other at various life stages.
items.default_editorial: Meg Ryan and Billy Crystal became rom-com icons for their irresistible turns as modern lovers on the eve of the 1990s in this swooning classic, penned by the witty Nora Ephron. Received wisdom about relationships comes loose as the two characters do some more growing up in the scenic Big Apple.

items.title: Where Is the Friend's House?
items.original_title: Khane-ye doust kodjast? | خانه دوست کجاست
items.short_synopsis: 8-year-old Ahmed has mistakenly taken his friend Mohammad’s notebook. He wants to return it, or else his friend will be expelled from school. Determinedly, the conscientious boy sets out to find Mohammad’s home in the neighbouring village.
items.default_editorial: As a young protagonist embarks on a humble quest, a beautiful allegory of friendship and morality is revealed. The first film in Kiarostami’s Koker trilogy, Where is the Friend’s Home? is a unique mélange of poetry, documentary and fiction, that cherishes the everyday in all its abundance.

items.title: Wild Diamond
items.short_synopsis: Liane, 19 years old, daring and fiery, lives with her mother and little sister under the dusty sun of Fréjus in the South of France. Obsessed with beauty and fame, she sees reality TV as her opportunity to be loved. Fate smiles upon her when she auditions for Miracle Island.
items.default_editorial: Spiking the old glamor of Cannes with the new grit and glitz of influencer culture, Agathe Riedinger’s fierce feature debut competed for the Palme d’Or. Scintillating against glowing screens of deceptive promise, newcomer Malou Khebizi adds adamantine tenacity to sparkle in an acclaimed performance.

items.title: Winter's Bone
items.short_synopsis: Faced with an unresponsive mother and a criminal father, teenager Ree Dolly does what she can to manage the household and take care of her two younger siblings. Informed by the sheriff that their father put their home up for bond and then disappeared, Ree sets out on a dangerous quest to find him.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Grand Jury Prize at Sundance and nominated for Best Picture at the Oscars, this enveloping drama by Debra Granik (Leave No Trace) also launched Lawrence’s career with her fiery turn as an ordinary hero.  An intimate odyssey of family, women, and survival, set in the Ozark mountains.

items.title: Women Talking
items.short_synopsis: The women of an isolated religious community grapple with reconciling their reality with their faith. The community of women come together to figure out how they might move forward together to build a better world for themselves and their children. Stay and fight or leave. They will not do nothing.
items.default_editorial: Director Sarah Polley enlists a mighty ensemble cast led by Jessie Buckley, Claire Foy, and Rooney Mara for this electrifying MeToo allegory set in a closeted religious community. Nominated for two Oscars®—including Best Picture—Women Talking is a fiery study in female solidarity and empowerment.

items.title: Workforce
items.short_synopsis: Francisco and his fellow construction workers build a luxury house in Mexico City. After his brother’s on-site death, Francisco learns his sister-in-law won’t receive compensation from the wealthy owner. Facing further abuses and failed attempts at justice, he takes the law into his own hands.
items.default_editorial: David Zonana’s absorbing feature debut unveils the insidious violence behind the seeming pragmatism of Mexican capitalist society. A frequent collaborator of Michel Franco, the director paints a sobering portrait of a system that exploits man’s vulnerability while also tempting his cruelty.

items.title: Written on the Wind
items.short_synopsis: In a Texas oil town, wealthy but troubled Kyle Hadley brings home his new wife, Lucy, stirring tensions with his loyal friend Mitch and his volatile sister Marylee. As jealousy and desire escalate, the Hadley family faces a collapse fueled by rivalry and self-destruction.
items.default_editorial: Lust and impotence, booze, oil money and family scions—and above all, desire for approval, for love. Douglas Sirk’s resplendent melodrama, too often taken as camp, is as serious as cinema gets. Only, Sirk heightens it all: colors bursting, neuroses tormenting, libidos raging—excess barely contained.

items.title: X
items.short_synopsis: 1979. A group of young porn filmmakers have found an exciting location for their new film: a remote ranch in Texas. The hosts, an elderly couple, show great interest in their young visitors. But as night falls, the couple’s leering interest turns violent, and the crew must fight for their lives.
items.default_editorial: A runaway hit that launched a cult horror franchise, Ti West’s hair-raising slasher pastiche pumps fresh blood into a classic sub genre, known for its mix of steamy titillation and chilling gore. With her pearly blue eyeshadow and a killer blowout, Mia Goth takes her throne as the new scream queen.

items.title: 100 Yards
items.short_synopsis: In volatile 1920s Tianjin, a covert martial arts circle arose to deter crime and maintain peace between rival fighting arts schools. When a renowned master dies and names his apprentice—rather than his son—as his successor, a fierce power struggle will bring the entire city to the brink of chaos.
items.default_editorial: With lush production design and elegant camerawork, this epic melodrama pits old traditions against modern times, celebrating the craft of kung fu in style. Seemingly arbitrary rules of combat and stubborn macho posturing lend a wry, comic undertone to a dazzling display of lightning-fast fighting.

items.short_synopsis: In 1980s Texas, a closeted young man returns home from New York for Christmas carrying a heavy secret. As he reconnects with his conservative family, he must navigate love, loss, and the fear of being truly seen—before it’s too late.
items.default_editorial: Set at the height of the AIDS crisis, Yên Tân’s soulful drama gently tugs at the paradox of home, a place where love and sorrow entwine. Heartbreaking as a young man whose clock is running out, Cory Michael Smith delivers a revelatory performance, rich in minute gestures and unspoken feelings.

items.title: A Date for Mad Mary
items.short_synopsis: Mary returns to her small Irish hometown after a brief stint in prison. Her best friend, Charlene, is about to get married, and Mary is the maid of honor. However, when Charlene refuses Mary a plus one, believing she’ll struggle to find a date, Mary becomes determined to prove her wrong.
items.default_editorial: With wit and a rebellious edge, Darren Thornton’s charming debut feature proves that even “mad” girls deserve their sweet coming-of-age story. Seána Kerslake is irresistible as the titular firecracker, her explosive personality hiding an endearing mess of virulent insecurities and unavowed desires.

items.title: A Field in England
items.short_synopsis: England, the 1640s Civil War. A group of men flee from a raging battle but they are captured and forced to take part in a hunt for treasure supposedly buried somewhere in a field. But before they start digging, they gobble up some strange-looking mushrooms and then everything goes pear-shaped.
items.default_editorial: Standing as an eccentric, unprecedented object in his filmography, Ben Wheatley (Sightseers, High-Rise) reaffirmed his position as a driving force in the UK’s independent film landscape with this audio-visual tour-de-force–a hallucinatory B&W period film! A beguiling film set in a bizarre field.

items.title: A Still Small Voice
items.short_synopsis: An aspiring hospital chaplain begins a yearlong residency in spiritual care, only to discover that to successfully tend to her patients, she must look deep within herself.
items.default_editorial: Winner of a directing award at Sundance, this lucid documentary by Luke Lorentzen is a piercingly compassionate examination of hospital chaplaincy. As its selfless heroes eke sacred moments from sobering circumstances, A Still Small Voice counters loneliness and loss with boundless empathy.

items.title: A Traveler's Needs
items.short_synopsis: Iris, a woman who finds herself adrift in Seoul and without any means to make ends meet, turns to teaching French, albeit via a very peculiar method. As she navigates a series of encounters, details of Iris’ situation slowly emerge—but the mysteries surrounding her only deepen.
items.default_editorial: Flushed with the waning light of summer, this cinematic drift through Seoul marks another winning collaboration for Korean maestro Hong Sang-soo and Isabelle Huppert. Between sips of makgeolli, chance connections and found poetry blur the gaps between languages and cultures with luminous delight.

items.title: A Woman Escapes
items.short_synopsis: Audrey Benac lives alone in Paris after having moved there to tend to the home of her recently deceased friend. She struggles to find her footing in the world, moving through the days without any clear motivation or sense of purpose.  Audrey forges a correspondence with two male filmmakers.
items.default_editorial: Echoing the disorientation of grief through a fragmented structure, this work of collaboration between Sofia Bohdanowicz, Deragh Campbell, Burak Çevik, and Blake Williams alleviates a broken soul by epistolary means. 3D imagery tessellates with 16mm and video footage in a prism of cinematic healing.

items.title: After the Storm
items.original_title: Umi yori mo Mada Fukaku | 海よりもまだ深く
items.short_synopsis: Dwelling on his past as an acclaimed author, Ryota wastes his money on gambling and can barely pay child support. After the death of his father, his family seem to be moving on with their lives. Ryota struggles to take back control of his existence and to find a lasting place in the life of his son.
items.default_editorial: Japanese auteur Hirokazu Koreeda delivers a humanist masterpiece with this tale of parenthood and forgiveness. Drawing comparisons to the work of Yasujiro Ozu, Koreeda’s emotionally rich drama quietly observes the dynamics of the family at its center with boundless empathy, generosity, and care.

items.title: Afternoons of Solitude
items.short_synopsis: Filmmaker Albert Serra follows star Peruvian matador Andrés Roca Rey from the solitude of his hotel room to a circuit of Spanish bullfighting arenas, observing the charged spectacle and violent encounters that await him. His preparations and rituals reveal the exacting demands of his profession.
items.default_editorial: Eschewing explanation for rhythmic abstraction, this authentically mysterious documentary poses profound riddles about beauty, violence, and mortality. In the death-baiting, cherubically handsome bullfighter Andrés Roca Rey, acclaimed director Albert Serra finds a welter of enigmatic contradictions.

items.title: Air Doll
items.short_synopsis: One day, a life-size, inflatable sex doll Hideo suddenly comes to life. Without her owner knowing, she walks around town and falls in love with Junichi. Hideo starts to date Junichi and gets a job at the same video store where he works. Everything seems to be perfect—until the unexpected happens.
items.default_editorial: With his trademark mix of tenderness and unexpected comedy, Japanese auteur Hirokazu Kore-eda (Shoplifters) explores the meaning of love and relationships in this quirky story of an “air doll” that comes to life. The loneliness of life in the city is perfectly captured with a melancholy beauty.

items.title: Amisk
items.short_synopsis: In 1973, a group of Montreal citizens organized a festival to raise funds in support of the Cree Indigenous people, who were losing their land because of a local hydroelectric project. Spectacular performances alternate with community meetings where locals talk of their past to defend their future.
items.default_editorial: Testifying to solidarity between diverse groups of people, this rousing film documents a fundraiser that doubles as an absorbing showcase for Indigenous talents. Keep an eye out for Alanis Obomsawin—she’s the woman in red who participates in this joyful event with a beautiful comradely lullaby.

items.title: Antibirth
items.short_synopsis: In a desolate community full of drug-addled Marines and rumors of kidnapping, a wild-eyed stoner named Lou wakes up after a wild night of partying with symptoms of a strange illness and recurring visions as she struggles to get a grip on reality while stories of conspiracy spread.
items.default_editorial: A delirious trip into the dark belly of addiction, Danny Perez’s psychedelic pregnancy horror is conceived with two indie queens: Natasha Lyonne and Chloë Sevigny. Delivering dark humor as well as gnarly practical effects, Antibirth  tackles female autonomy through an exhilarating genre lens.

items.title: Antiviral
items.short_synopsis: Syd March works at a clinic that sells injections of live viruses harvested from sick celebrities to fans. He also illegally supplies these viruses to piracy groups by smuggling them into his body. But when he becomes infected with the disease that kills an A-list celebrity, Syd becomes a target.
items.default_editorial: Body horror must run in the family, because only a Cronenberg (David’s son, that is) could have realized this dizzying cinematic concoction of terror mixed with the darkest shades of humour. Lead by the always unnerving Caleb Landry Jones (Get Out), Antiviral is a razor-sharp satire of our time.

items.title: As If I Am Not There
items.original_title: As If I Am Not There
items.short_synopsis: As If I Am Not There relates one woman’s experience of the horrors that took place at the beginning of the Bosnian War, based on the book by Slavenka Drakulic. Disturbing and powerful, the film is an important testament to the survivors of the atrocities in the former Yugoslavia.
