items.default_editorial: As If I Am Not There is a violent but essential look at the mass rape committed against women during the Balkan conflict, and the brutal means of survival such women might have had to choose. Adapted from a novel based on victims’ testimonies, its realism is both crushing and compelling all at once.

items.title: August at Akiko's
items.short_synopsis: Armed with just his suitcase and a sax, musician Alex Zhang Hungtai returns home to Hawaii after nearly a decade, taking refuge in a Buddhist B&B with a woman named Akiko. As the two grow familiar, they embark on a journey of musical discovery.
items.default_editorial: Christopher Makoto Yogi’s debut feature is a wonderful tribute to a place, pushing against Hollywood’s erasure of Hawaii with affection and contemplation. Starring Alex Zhang Hungtai from the band Dirty Beaches, the film is a musical dream that feels both immensely personal and culturally expansive.

items.title: Bernie
items.short_synopsis: In the quaint town of Carthage, Texas, Bernie Tiede, a much-loved mortician, forges an unusual friendship with sour-tempered widow Marjorie Nugent. As their bond deepens, Bernie finds himself entangled in a shocking murder case, revealing hidden layers beneath the town’s facade.
items.default_editorial: This sweet, surprising true-crime film from Richard Linklater (Before Sunrise) proves part crafty black tragicomedy, part tabloid mockumentary, a lighthearted telling of the real-life story of a 1996 murder in small-town Texas. Starring Shirley MacLaine and an impressive, career-best Jack Black.

items.title: Blaze
items.short_synopsis: The life and times of Blaze Foley, the unsung songwriting legend of the Texas Outlaw Music movement, are reimagined over three different periods. First, his love affair with Sybil Rosen. Then, his last, dark night on earth. Finally, the impact of his songs and death on his fans, friends, and foes.
items.default_editorial: Powered by an avid love for Blaze Foley, a forgotten yet hugely influential country music legend, Ethan Hawke’s golden-hued biopic breaks all the rules. Featuring a stellar cast including Alia Shawkat, this heartfelt ode to a star that burned too brightly basks in the poetry of artistic expression.

items.title: Bloody Nose, Empty Pockets
items.short_synopsis: On the eve of the 2016 US election, a Las Vegas dive bar becomes a stage where its employees and barflies gather one last time before it closes down. Early birds stroll in at 11 am while hardy souls stagger out at the final call—each eccentric dispensing drunken absurdities and pearls of wisdom.
items.default_editorial: Obliterating the line between documentary and fiction, the Ross Brothers staged an all-day bender for this wistful ode to barflies everywhere. From this pickled premise, a poignant microcosm of social and political disillusion emerges, as the film sounds an elegy to communities lost and found.

items.title: Blue Sun Palace
items.short_synopsis: Within the confines of a massage parlor in Flushing, Queens, Amy and Didi navigate romance, happiness, and the obligations of family thousands of miles from home. But when tragedy strikes on the Lunar New Year, Amy is forced to consider her own destiny for the first time ever.
items.default_editorial: Pastel calm and easy camaraderie are interrupted by leaky reality in Constance Tsang’s beautifully assured debut feature. Starring Tsai Ming-liang favorite Lee Kang-sheng, this tenderly bruising film lets loss and intimacy ripple its serene waters—as if two koi fish swirling in each exquisite frame.

items.title: Bob's Funeral
items.short_synopsis: Filmmaker Jack Dunphy secretly films his grandfather’s funeral, hoping to uncover the source of generational trauma in their family. Meanwhile, animated flashbacks and home-movie footage reveal the estranged nature of his extended family.
items.default_editorial: With gentle humor and immense warmth, Jack Dunphy traces his father’s knotty lineage in this heartfelt documentary short, a prizewinner at Sundance. Remixing personal history with cutout animation, Bob’s Funeral paints an endearing portrait of two contrasting families, full of compelling characters.

items.title: Boiling Point
items.short_synopsis: Masaki, an unassuming amateur baseball player, enrages a local yakuza, setting off a feud between the gangsters and his coach. Masaki and his friend Kazuo go to Okinawa on a quest for guns, befriending an eccentric yakuza boss who initiates them into the strange and brutal world of organized crime.
items.default_editorial: In his second feature film, Takeshi Kitano dives further into Japan’s underworld by way of a baseball player turned patsy in this carefully plotted road trip lined with vengeance. Boiling Point deepens Kitano’s analysis of male violence…while also featuring one of cinema’s greatest karaoke scenes.

items.title: Bones and All
items.short_synopsis: Maren, a young woman on the margins of society, falls for the drifter Lee. Together they embark on an odyssey through Ronald Reagan’s America. But despite their best efforts, all roads lead back to their terrifying pasts. Soon, a final stand will determine if their love can survive their otherness.
items.default_editorial: Luxuriating in the sweet taste of first love, Luca Guadagnino’s blood-soaked cannibal romance sizzles with the scorching chemistry between Timothée Chalamet and Taylor Russell. Visceral yet tender-hearted, this wild road trip through the sweeping highways of America is sure to get under your skin.

items.title: Brawl in Cell Block 99
items.short_synopsis: A former boxer-turned-drug runner finds himself in a gunfight between the police and his own ruthless allies. When the smoke clears, he is badly hurt and thrown in prison, where his enemies force him to commit acts of violence that turn the place into a savage battleground.
items.default_editorial: Making commanding use of his imposing height and heft, Vince Vaughn gives a performance of coiled intensity in this noir-inflected descent into the American penal system. A brutally effective dose of neo-grindhouse, Brawl in Cell Block 99 unfolds with a methodical clarity worthy of John Carpenter.

items.title: Brother Number One
items.short_synopsis: The New Zealander and Olympian rowing champion Rob Hamill travels to Cambodia to seek justice for his eldest brother Kerry, who disappeared without a trace while sailing from Australia to Southeast Asia in 1978. Along with two sailing mates, Kerry was murdered by the Khmer Rouge regime.
items.default_editorial: If you saw the Oscar®-nominated, Cannes-winning doc The Missing Picture you know how badly the cinema needs to tell the many stories—both personal and larger—of the Khmer Rouge’s reign of terror in Cambodia. Brother Number One tells of a haunting personal story, and a resilient quest for justice.

items.title: Buddy
items.short_synopsis: Filmmaker Heddy Honigmann meets six service dogs and their owners. These specially trained dogs assist their owners in navigating lives that can otherwise be challenging. Honigmann follows the inner workings of the pairs to unveil what’s truly given and received.
items.default_editorial: Heddy Honigmann’s humanist documentary is a joyful and moving portrait of the bond between people and their service dogs. Moving beyond surface-level sentimentalism, Buddy unravels the emotional complexity of the relationships at its center by approaching its subjects with candor and curiosity.

items.title: Burning
items.short_synopsis: Jongsu, a frustrated introvert, has his life complicated by the appearance of two people: Haemi, a spirited woman who offers romantic possibility, and, Ben, a wealthy young man she befriends. When Jongsu learns of Ben’s mysterious hobby and Haemi disappears, his obsessions begin to mount.
items.default_editorial: An international hit for Lee Chang-dong, this sensuous and sinister story of obsessive love crackles with the flames of foreboding. Starring Steven Yeun and newcomer Yoo Ah-in, Burning twists a Haruki Murakami story into a profound examination of male violence and contemporary capitalism.

items.title: Byzantium
items.short_synopsis: Two mysterious women seek refuge in a run-down coastal resort. Clara meets lonely Noel, who provides shelter in his deserted guesthouse, Byzantium. Schoolgirl Eleanor befriends Frank and tells him their lethal secret: they were born 200 years ago and survive on human blood.
items.default_editorial: With a stellar cast spearheaded by Saoirse Ronan & Gemma Arterton as blood-thirsty mother-daughter vampires, Neil Jordan (Interview With a Vampire) directs a swirling, time-travelling fantasy tragedy, tingled with romance. A dark tale, set within the apocalyptic landscape of a rundown coastal town.

items.title: Camp X-Ray
items.short_synopsis: A young woman joins the military to be part of something bigger than herself, but ends up as a new guard at Guantanamo Bay instead, where her mission is far from black and white. Surrounded by hostile jihadists and aggressive squadmates, she strikes up an unusual friendship with a detainee.
items.default_editorial: Kristen Stewart delivers a remarkable performance opposite Peyman Moaadi in this engrossing debut from writer-director Peter Sattler. Set in at the Guantánamo Bay prison, Camp X-Ray tells an affecting and intimate story that focuses on the human component of a provocative subject.

items.title: Candy Mountain
items.short_synopsis: New York City, 1980s. A struggling musician named Julius has fallen on hard times. He cooks up a get-rich-quick scheme: to track down the legendary, elusive guitar maker, Elmore Silk. Meant to be a simple journey upstate, Julius stumbles down a long, winding road full of dead-ends and wrong turns.
items.default_editorial: Strumming along to the syncopated rhythms of ‘80s America, Robert Frank and Rudy Wurlitzer’s cult film reckons with scraggy countercultural myths of the road. Gathering an alternative hit parade of faces—Jim Jarmusch! Bulle Ogier!—this rough diamond of independent cinema gleams in a new restoration.

items.title: Certain Women
items.short_synopsis: Three women strive to forge their own paths in the American Northwest. A lawyer contends with both office sexism and a hostage situation. A mother’s determination to build her dream home puts her at odds with the men in her life. A young law student forms an ambiguous bond with a lonely ranch hand.
items.default_editorial: Kelly Reichardt’s Montana anthology was a breakout moment for rising star Lily Gladstone. Shining next to a trifecta of illustrious talent—Laura Dern, Kristen Stewart, Michelle Williams—the quietly assured actor stole our hearts as a lovelorn rancher at the tailend of this profoundly moving film.

items.title: Chan Is Missing
items.short_synopsis: In San Francisco’s Chinatown, a cabbie and his nephew set out to find the eponymous mystery man, who’s vanished without a trace, along with all their savings. But what begins as a search for a missing man gradually turns into a far deeper and more elusive investigation…
items.default_editorial: The first Asian-American fiction feature to secure theatrical distribution in the US, Wayne Wang’s barrier-breaking solo debut merges the buddy comedy and the detective film with style. Swathed in puzzling headlines, wisps of gossip, and urban myths, the central mystery invokes a divided diaspora.

items.title: Charli XCX: Alone Together
items.short_synopsis: Seeking solace in music during the COVID-19 pandemic, global pop star Charli XCX asks her fans to help her make an album while quarantined at home. Embarking on a creative and emotional journey, she faces mental health issues, rekindles her relationship with her boyfriend and connects with her fans.
items.default_editorial: Turning quarantine restrictions into artistic inspiration, Charli XCX led her legions of fans—and herself—out of pandemic blues with the power of music. From DIY recording sessions to livestream confessions, this kaleidoscopic documentary captures the pop icon at her most vulnerable and authentic.

items.title: Charlie Victor Romeo
items.short_synopsis: When you board an airplane, who are those people in uniform to whom you entrust your life? What do they really do when things go horribly wrong? Word-for-word recreations of six major airline incidents and accidents reveal the tension-filled cockpits of actual flights in distress.
items.default_editorial: Fasten your seatbelts for a heart-stopping journey into a series of distress calls made from above the clouds. Unfolding in a breathlessly tense procession of split-second decisions, this hybrid documentary collapses the boundaries between film and theater for a disaster movie like no other.

items.title: Christmas at Moose Factory
items.short_synopsis: At a residential school in James Bay, northern Ontario, Cree children share stories of their families and community at Christmas time. Incidents both big and small are illustrated and described through the children’s words and in their crayon drawings.
items.default_editorial: Sitting in on an art class for her first short, Indigenous director Alanis Obomsawin celebrates the nascent creativity of Cree children. Accompanying their lovely impressions of wintry landscapes and nativity scenes, the little artists talk in voice-over about their processes, ideas, and dreams.

items.title: Christmas, Again
items.short_synopsis: A heartbroken Christmas-tree salesman returns to New York City hoping to put his past behind him. Living in a trailer and working the night shift, he begins to spiral downwards until the saving of a woman and some colorful customers rescue him from self-destruction.
items.default_editorial: Need an antidote to the too-often terrible sub-genre of Christmas movies? Look no further than Charles Poekel’s debut: A gem that ignores the schlocky, capitalist veneer of holiday culture, but rather attends to the emotional and economic nuances brought about by the wintry, consumerist season.

items.title: City of Gold
items.short_synopsis: Celebrated restaurant critic Jonathan Gold has a deep and complex relationship with the food and culture of his city, Los Angeles. He tours his city looking for new food experiences, uncovering hidden culinary treasures, and casting light upon the city’s thriving migrant culture.
items.default_editorial: What better way to discover a city’s multiethnic identity than through its food culture? With City of Gold, here is the chance to explore the cultural diversity and culinary gems of Los Angeles through the extensive knowledge and curiosity of Pulitzer-prize winning restaurant critic Jonathan Gold.

items.title: Claire's Camera
items.short_synopsis: Claire, a teacher with a camera, is visiting Cannes. She happens upon a film sales assistant, Manhee, recently laid off after a one-night stand with a director. Together, this unlikely pair works to understand the circumstances of Manhee’s firing, developing new outlooks on life in the process.
items.default_editorial: Shot entirely during the Cannes Film Festival, this endearing comedy is Korean director Hong Sang-soo at his most light and delightful. A self-mocking take on the film industry, it stars an irresistible Isabelle Huppert as the ultimate sunny optimist, who believes that polaroids change lives!

items.title: Close Your Eyes
items.short_synopsis: Aging filmmaker Miguel Garay revisits his unfinished and final film, where his close friend and lead actor, Julio Arenas, mysteriously vanished. With careful reflection, Miguel reconnects with the crew, past lovers, and Julio’s daughter, seeking closure and understanding for their shared loss.
items.default_editorial: Marking his first feature film after a gap of 31 years, this latest triumph from Spanish master Víctor Erice trails after a mysterious disappearance. A sublime meditation on the moving relationship between cinema and memory, Close Your Eyes ponders the permanence of art against the wheels of time.

items.title: Cocote
directors: Nelson Carlo de los Santos Arias
items.short_synopsis: In the Dominican Republic, Alberto, a kind-hearted gardener, returns home to attend his father’s funeral. Upon discovering that a powerful local figure is responsible for his father’s death, Alberto realizes that his family has summoned him to avenge the murder.
items.default_editorial: A bewitching revenge thriller, Nelson Carlo de los Santos Arias’s Locarno prizewinner is as mystical as it is exhilarating. Subverting dominant paradigms of representation to reinvent the genre, Cocote shifts between realist and hallucinatory images, evoking the dizzying torment of broken filiality.

items.title: Contemporary Color
items.short_synopsis: In the summer of 2015, legendary musician David Byrne staged an event at Brooklyn’s Barclays Center to celebrate the art of Color Guard: synchronized dance routines involving flags, rifles, and sabers.
items.default_editorial: A marvel of flying rifles, whirling flags, and synchronized formations, the color guards merge with experimental pop musicians in David Byrne’s life-affirming show. The Ross Brothers also aim for the stars, unfurling the potential of the concert film to capture more than simply the live performance.

items.title: Daaaaaali!
items.short_synopsis: Journalist Judith Rochant has the golden career opportunity to interview renowned artist Salvador Dalí—if only he would sit still and answer one question! What should be a short conversation is continually disrupted by Dalí’s boundless self-regard. Judith soon finds herself becoming the subject.
items.default_editorial: Say it looong. Say it loud! Quentin Dupieux is going for mammoth laughs in this time-warped, gaga homage to a giant of surrealism. Flummoxing Anaïs Demoustier’s straightwoman, a carousel of actors take turns being Dalí—each one with a different, eccentric version of his moustache-twirling panache.

items.title: Dad & Step-Dad
items.short_synopsis: In an effort to bond for the sake of Branson, their 13-year-old son, Jim and Dave, a dad and a step-dad, spend a weekend in a cabin upstate together with their shared kid. However, tensions start to mount as differing parenting techniques come to the fore.
items.default_editorial: The loony spirit of the Martin Short classic Clifford lives on in this irresistible comedy from director Tynan DeLong. Kicking off with a passive-aggressive battle of wills between the titular carers, Dad & Step-Dad modulates its incorrigible silliness with poignant reflections on the modern family.

items.title: De Humani Corporis Fabrica
items.short_synopsis: Five centuries ago, anatomist André Vésale opened up the body to science for the first time in history. Today, human flesh is revealed as a landscape that exists only through others’ attention. As places of care, suffering and hope, hospitals are laboratories that connect every body in the world.
items.default_editorial: Plunging into the viscera of human bodies, the directorial duo behind Leviathan open up glistening worlds of ecstatic abstraction. Never shrinking from grit or guts, this fascinating documentary surfaces in underfunded Parisian hospitals, where doctors inject a good dose of humor into disrepair.

items.title: Deep Red
items.short_synopsis: An English pianist living in Rome witnesses the brutal murder of his neighbor, a psychic. With the help of a tenacious young reporter he tries to discover the killer using very unconventional methods, and the two are soon drawn into a shocking web of dementia and violence.
items.default_editorial: Home to some of the greatest set pieces Dario Argento ever put on film, this hallucinatory giallo remains one of his most iconic features. Paying homage to Antonioni’s Blow-Up by casting David Hemmings as its leading man, Deep Red is a symbolic masterpiece of prismatic beauty and rapturous terror.

items.title: Deerskin
items.short_synopsis: A recent divorcé blows his entire life savings on a 100%-deerskin jacket, then escapes to a sleepy French alpine village where the jacket begins to exert a hold on him. He falls into the guise of an indie filmmaker, enlisting the help of an aspiring film editor to assemble a most unusual film.
items.default_editorial: Quentin Dupieux’s deadpan comedy on the narcissistic nature of filmmaking is luridly obsessed with objects, from suede jackets to mirrors and cameras. Sharing an easy chemistry on screen, Jean Dujardin and Adèle Haenel lend charm and poignancy to this profoundly funny, fantastical fable.

items.title: Demons 2
items.short_synopsis: A birthday party in a high- security apartment building (with bullet-proof windows) is interrupted when the birthday girl is transformed into a vicious demon by watching a horror movie on TV…
items.default_editorial: They’re back!  Not just the demons, but writer-producer Dario Argento and director Lamberto Bava, who present a sequel that is just as wild and outrageous a trip for horror fans as the original.

items.title: Dim Sum: A Little Bit of Heart
items.original_title: Dim Sum: A Little Bit of Heart
items.short_synopsis: A widowed Chinese immigrant faces the New Year with apprehension after it was foretold that it would be the year she would die. All of the things she wants to do before she dies come into focus, including seeing her daughter married and visiting China one last time to pay her respects.
items.default_editorial: The delicate spirit of Yasujirō Ozu’s domestic dramas lives on in Wayne Wang’s gentle portrait of a Chinese-American household unsettled by the tides of change. Words of love, care, and even grievance spill over mouth-watering family meals, where food becomes a conduit for cultural inheritance.

items.title: Dog Eat Dog
items.short_synopsis: In Los Angeles, ex-cons Troy, Mad Dog, and Diesel are hired by an eccentric mob boss to kidnap a baby and hold it for a large ransom. When the abduction goes awry, the men find themselves on the run from the mob and the cops, vowing to stay out of prison at all costs.
items.default_editorial: The bumbling antiheroes of this gleefully unhinged crime comedy find the American dream more out of reach than ever before. They all have their twisted reasons for chasing it anyway. In the way these determined fools catastrophically bungle their mission, Paul Schrader finds both humor and pathos.

items.title: Dogleg
items.short_synopsis: Amateur director Alan loses his fiancée’s dog at a gender reveal party on the day of a big shoot. As he struggles to finish his latest project with the help of a New York critic, the pursuit of the lost dog and the chaos of his film begin to blend—and Alan grows desperate for the day to be over.
items.default_editorial: An oddball mix of interrelated shorts, or just an average day in the city of angels? Director, co-writer, and star Al Warren is a filmmaker on the edge in this metatextual comedy, which conveys a sincere wonder at the chaos of both life and cinema with its sunny cinematography and colorful cast.

items.title: Dream Creep
items.short_synopsis: David awakens in the night to cries for help emanating from his partner Suzy’s earhole. Thrust into a supernatural emergency, the couple face an impossible decision as a voice from beyond compels them to commit unthinkable acts of violence. But if David and Suzy comply, will these actions save them?
items.default_editorial: A cinematic marriage of haunted orifices and sharp objects, Carlos A.F. Lopez’s unnerving short disrupts the rhythm of everyday life with a chilling dose of bloody horror. As the squirmy sound design taps into our most primal fears, Dream Creep transforms sweet slumber into a never-ending nightmare.

items.title: Drowning Dry
items.short_synopsis: Ernesta, together with her sister Justė’s family, her husband Lukas, and their son Kristupas, are spending their weekend at a country house after her husband’s victory in a mixed-martial arts tournament.
items.default_editorial: The coming together and moving apart of two grown sisters is a danse macabre in Lithuanian director Laurynas Bareiša’s lovingly choreographed second film. An exploration of spreading grief and the distortions it performs on time and memory, this poignant family portrait sifts the past for answers.

items.title: Eagle vs Shark
items.short_synopsis: Lily is a quiet, awkward loner who doesn’t fit in anywhere. Jarrod is a warrior in his own world who thinks he’s brave and powerful and is blind to Lily’s adoration—but that could change. Lily crashes Jarrod’s party, and ends up helping his hell bent plan to beat up an old high school bully.
items.default_editorial: Taika Waititi’s meteoric rise to Oscar®-winning writer and blockbuster director began with this whimsical debut. Tipping its hat to the handmade charms of Wes Anderson and Michel Gondry, Eagle vs Shark is a winsomely off-kilter romcom led by Flight of the Conchords’ breakout star Jemaine Clement.

items.title: Eephus
items.short_synopsis: As an imminent construction project looms over their beloved small-town baseball field, a pair of New England rec-league teams face off for the last time. Tensions flare up and ceremonial laughs are shared as an era of camaraderie and escapism fades into an uncertain future.
items.default_editorial: Knocking it straight out of the park in his first feature as writer-director, Carson Lund embraces baseball’s nostalgic pleasures to stage an American elegy. With an audio cameo from documentarian Frederick Wiseman, Eephus goes by that playbook, immersed intricately in a beloved national pastime.

items.title: Enter the Void
items.short_synopsis: Oscar is an American drug dealer living with his sister in Japan. Killed during a drug bust, Oscar’s spirit enters the astral plane. His journey through life after death takes him back to the past and through the present neon club scene of Tokyo after dark.
items.default_editorial: Gaspar Noé’s Tokyo-set audiovisual experience is stunning and scandalous—a hallucinatory techno trip exemplary of Noé’s brand of divisive filmmaking. An intoxicating first-person crawl through the city by night, Enter the Void is sensational cinema at its most phenomenal and visceral.

items.title: Eureka
items.short_synopsis: In a dusty town of the Old West, a cowboy arrives looking for his daughter. In present-day South Dakota, a native policewoman arrests various offenders in a snowy landscape. Meanwhile her niece, a basketball coach, reunites with her grandfather for a decisive journey that will shape her future.
items.default_editorial: A chimeric wonder from director Lisandro Alonso, Eureka slips the boundaries of space and time. Beginning as a Viggo Mortensen-led western before morphing into something else entirely, this metaphysical meditation on the exploitation of Indigenous histories is mesmerising, transcendental cinema.

items.title: Falcon Lake
items.short_synopsis: Bastien, a shy 13-year-old from Paris, is on a family summer vacation in Quebec. There, he meets and bonds with Chloé, the 16-year-old daughter of his mother’s old friend Louise. A fan of folklore and local legends, Chloé begins to tell Bastien a story of a ghost haunting a nearby lake…
items.default_editorial: Blurring the line between horror and romance, Charlotte Le Bon’s enthralling and uniquely crafted debut injects a dose of the macabre into the sweet melancholy of youth. The dreamy setting of a lakeside cabin in Québec delivers all the ingredients for an unforgettable summer, ghost hunting included!

items.title: Familiar Touch
items.short_synopsis: Ruth, an older woman with dementia, leaves her home for a date. But what she thinks is a hotel turns out to be an assisted living facility, and she must contend with an array of new faces, routines, and surroundings.
items.default_editorial: Confidently quiet, Sarah Friedland’s narrative debut is playful but direct in exploring the islanding effects of dementia. Lingering on life’s gladdening details—lily pollen on a varnished tabletop, the tracery of veins on cabbage leaves—serene camerawork finds silver linings in a shrinking world.

items.title: Five Days Till Tomorrow
items.short_synopsis: In a dreamy, crepuscular landscape made up of archival 1970s futuristic architecture, cut-out characters from fantasy comic books roam the night. They sleep, loll, and patiently wait for the extended darkness to come to an end.
items.default_editorial: Clocks without hands are sign enough: this mesmerizingly animated collage exists in a realm flung from linear time. Shifting mid-century iconography into uncanny new motion, American experimental filmmaker Lewis Klahr cleverly plumbs melancholy and eeriness from the enduring ends of modernity.

items.title: Flight of the Red Balloon
items.short_synopsis: As a single mother in Paris, Suzanne struggles to spend enough time with her young son, Simon. Suzanne hires Song, a local university student, to watch Simon. Together, Simon and Song create a vibrant world of imagination, where a red balloon follows them.
items.default_editorial: For the second feature to be shot outside of his native Taiwan, Hou Hsiao-hsien ventured to Paris for this lyrical masterpiece. Starring Juliette Binoche, and captured in swooning tracking shots by cinematographer Lee Ping Bing, The Flight of the Red Balloon is a work of warm and delicate wonder.

items.title: Fremont
items.short_synopsis: Donya is a former Afghan translator for the U.S. government who now lives alone in Fremont, California. When she’s promoted to writing the fortunes at her job at a fortune cookie factory in the city, Donya’s loneliness and longing inspire her to send out a hopeful message of connection in a cookie.
items.default_editorial: America is an adequate refuge but no star-spangled land of dreams when it comes to the modern immigrant experience. Recalling Jim Jarmusch and Aki Kaurismäki with each cool monochrome vignette, this Sundance darling is threaded through with deadpan humor and performances of glimmering insight.

items.title: Geoff McFetridge: Drawing a Life
items.short_synopsis: Geoff McFetridge’s art is everywhere—on your Apple watch, in countless galleries, and in title designs for films by Sofia Coppola. Unprecedented access into Geoff’s multifaceted world reveals his obsessive quest to balance family with a creative life, and a man guided by intention and authenticity.
items.default_editorial: Featuring interviews with its subject’s most famous collaborators—Spike Jonze, Sofia Coppola—this absorbing documentary largely lets the self-aware artist recount his own unusual journey. Embracing a mindful work ethic, he stands in inspiring contrast to the toxic model of the tortured artist.

items.title: Ghost Trail
items.short_synopsis: Hamid, a Syrian literature professor in Strasbourg, secretly belongs to a refugee network tracking down former regime enforcers. When he recognises the man he believes tortured him, his life tilts into obsession. Communicating through a video game, his group closes in, but doubt gnaws at every step.
items.default_editorial: Documentarian Jonathan Millet makes his fiction debut with this electrifying revenge thriller. Featuring a tightly wound lead in Adam Bessa, who plays a Syrian exile on the hunt for his prison torturer, Ghost Trail hitches the refugee drama to the spy movie for a riveting game of cat and mouse.

items.title: Glassland
items.short_synopsis: In a social housing suburb in Dublin, John lives with his alcoholic mother, Jean, while earning a meager living as a nocturnal taxi driver. When Jean has an opportunity to recover, John must offer his services to a petty criminal to help pay for his mother’s costly rehab program.
items.default_editorial: Looking at unhappy lives with patient tenderness, this absorbing drama acknowledges the strength of people who cannot see it for themselves. In finely tuned performances, Jack Reynor and Toni Collette chart a mother and son’s crooked path from despair to transformative hope.

items.title: God's Own Country
items.short_synopsis: Johnny works in isolation on his family’s farm in Yorkshire. He numbs his loneliness with binge drinking and casual sex, until the arrival of Gheorghe, a Romanian migrant worker, employed for the lambing season. Johnny suddenly finds himself having to deal with emotions he has never felt before.
items.default_editorial: Evoking the verdant loneliness of Brokeback Mountain, Francis Lee’s exceptional debut is an intimate queer love story that movingly softens the harsh edges of rural farm life. Tempestuous and carnal, the sizzling chemistry between Josh O’Connor and Alec Secareanu sets fire to societal prejudices.

items.title: Goodbye First Love
items.short_synopsis: Besotted teenagers Sullivan and Camille struggle with a painful push-pull dynamic, heightened by the young man’s decision to leave Paris and travel. Over the course of eight years, we watch Camille, initially devastated by her boyfriend’s departure, emerge with new passions and a sense of self.
items.default_editorial: Anchored by an achingly sensitive performance from Lola Créton, Mia Hansen-Løve’s discerning study of personal revolution depicts adolescence with peerless grace. Illuminating a youthful romance with palpably lived wisdom, this sun-drenched film plumbs the profound immensity of formative first love.

items.title: Greener Grass
items.short_synopsis: Jill and Lisa are two best frenemies and competitive stay-at-home soccer moms who live in a manicured community where people drive around in golf carts. Jill has a strange need to please people, so when Lisa says that Jill’s new baby is adorable, Jill impulsively offers it to her and Lisa accepts.
items.default_editorial: The burden of conformity in soccer-mom suburbia reaches new levels of paranoid surrealism in this neon-hued satire. With nods to David Lynch, Todd Solondz and Stepford Wives, Greener Grass paints a deadpan, teeth-gritting vision of the pressure-cooker world of parenthood by the white picket fences.

items.title: Ham on Rye
items.short_synopsis: A bizarre rite of passage at the local deli determines the fate of a generation of teenagers, leading some to escape their suburban town and dooming others to remain.
items.default_editorial: A wonderful cast of suburban teens face a rite of passage—fraught with anxiety and desire—that starts in the world of Richard Linklater and ends in that of David Lynch. Tyler Taormina’s sly but surprisingly touching debut plays with and then upends the clichés of American end-of-school comedies.

items.title: Happening
items.short_synopsis: France, 1963, Anne is a bright student with a promising future. But when she falls pregnant, she sees her chance to finish her studies and escape the constraints of her social background disappearing. With her exams approaching, Anne resolves to act, even if she has to confront shame and pain.
items.default_editorial: Probing the social prejudices and legal obstacles surrounding abortion, Audrey Diwan’s Golden Lion winner astutely shatters the illusory liberalism of 1960s France. Starring a revelatory Anamaria Vartolomei, this unflinching and powerful cry for reproductive freedom simmers with a timely urgency.

items.title: Happer's Comet
items.short_synopsis: It is the middle of the night in a small town in suburban America. But night is not always for sleeping. A camera peers into the late-night happenings of various residents and witnesses a number of them quietly escape into the dark… on rollerblades.
items.default_editorial: Gliding through a somnolent suburbia, Tyler Taormina’s hypnotic follow-up to Ham on Rye captures the unexpected magic and surprise interactions of the witching hour. In this Long Island lullaby, filmed during lockdown, skaters soar and lovers slink into the dark, keyed in to the rhythm of the night.

items.title: Heli
items.short_synopsis: Estela is a 12-year-old girl who has just fallen crazy in love with a young police cadet in rural Mexico. He wants to run away with her and get married. Trying to achieve this dream, Estela’s family will have to face the vicious circle of drugs and violence that is devastating the region.
items.default_editorial: In his tense, Cannes’ Best Director winning third feature, arthouse favourite Amat Escalante tackles the rising underworld of Mexico’s drug cartels. With a stunning visual style and an air of quasi-documentary naturalism, Heli is confrontational, heart-pounding cinema at its very best.

items.title: Henry Gamble's Birthday Party
items.short_synopsis: At Henry’s birthday pool party the guests include an assortment of grown-ups from the family church, as well as Henry’s friends—including the closeted Logan, who clearly has eyes for Henry. As Henry treads through various sexual possibilities, so too do the adults and teenagers of the party,.
items.default_editorial: Gorgeously steeped in shades of blue, this teenage character study hums with desire, doubt, and secrets that headily ripple through an ensemble cast. Crafting a specific Midwestern suburban milieu, the film acutely captures a state of uncertainty that disrupts one’s religious and sexual identity.

items.title: Hey Sweet Pea
items.short_synopsis: Parental aging and an existential wave collide in the suburbs of LA. Dislocated B-roll, meandering voicemails, and readings from the 1984 children’s sci-fi movie The Neverending Story combine to situate collective grief in the mundanities of everyday life.
items.default_editorial: The past is excavated and reclaimed in this eerie short film from multimedia artist Alee Peoples, who finds poignant echoes between childhood innocence and grown-up grief. Juxtaposing items from popular culture and personal life, Hey Sweet Pea has the uncanny rhythms and textures of a dream.

items.title: House of Tolerance
items.original_title: L'Apollonide : Souvenirs de la maison close
items.short_synopsis: The dawn of the 20th century: L’Apollonide, a luxurious and traditional brothel in Paris, is living its last days. In this closed world, where some men fall in love and others become viciously harmful, the women share their secrets, their fears, their joys and their pains.
items.default_editorial: Set in the dying days of the 19th-century, this crepuscular masterwork from Bertrand Bonello explores the transactional margins of sexuality. With a stellar ensemble that includes Adèle Haenel, House of Tolerance occupies a hermetic netherworld caught between a haunted past and an uncertain future.

items.title: How to Survive a Plague
items.short_synopsis: In a desperate effort to save their own lives, an unlikely group of mostly HIV-positive young men and women took on Washington and the medical establishment. Archival footage from the 80s and 90s reveals the heated meetings, the painful failures, and the joyful breakthroughs of heroes in the making.
items.default_editorial: With great immediacy in its first-hand accounts and an incisive use of archival footage, this Academy Award®-nominated documentary dives deep into one of the most tortured yet tide-turning moments in recent American history. A remarkable portrait on the potentiality of significant social change.

items.title: Hundreds of Beavers
items.short_synopsis: In the nineteenth century, a drunken applejack salesman loses his business in a fire and finds himself stranded in the wilderness. Facing starvation, he must survive a surreal winter landscape overrun by beavers, and devise clever traps to stay alive and win the hand of a mischievous lover.
items.default_editorial: One hazard hides another in Mike Cheslik’s boldly lo-fi comedy, which tracks its hapless hero across a wintry cartoon-scape. Retrofitting video-game cadences to the practical genius of silent-era slapstick, this uproariously loopy film opens up a brave new world of sight gags and stuntwork.

items.title: I Am Divine
items.short_synopsis: The ultimate outsider turned underground royalty. This biography honors Divine in a way she always craved: as a serious artist and immortal star. Featuring rare movie footage, live performances, and brand new interviews with Divine’s family, friends, colleagues and forever indebted devotees.
items.default_editorial: Eulogizing the vivacious drag icon and John Waters muse, I Am Divine is a fun portrait of an actor whose subversively vulgar work appalled and entertained in equal measure. Through glorious archival footage, Divine is among the interviewees in this documentary showing the art that goes into trash.

items.title: I Was a Simple Man
items.short_synopsis: In the rustic countryside of the north shore of O’ahu, Hawai’i, an elderly man facing the end of his life is visited by the ghosts of his past. The ghosts also haunt the countryside, journeying from the high-rises of contemporary Honolulu to the pre-WWII pastorals of O’ahu—and into the beyond.
items.default_editorial: Blurring boundaries between past and present, memory and truth, Christopher Makoto Yogi’s hypnotic film is a life-affirming reckoning with death’s inevitability. Full of luscious images and sounds, moving to the gentle rhythm of a dream, I Was a Simple Man is attuned to the beauty of existence.

items.title: In Another Country
items.short_synopsis: In a Korean seaside town, three versions of a French woman named Anne—each imagined by a young screenwriter—navigate a series of misadventures. As she encounters familiar faces, including a flirtatious lifeguard and a filmmaker lover, uncanny differences and strange echoes start to accumulate.
items.default_editorial: Marking the beginning of a beautiful collaboration, Hong Sang-soo’s first English-language film stars Isabelle Huppert in not one, but three roles! Wondrously meta in its structure, this playful cinematic triptych pairs capricious romantic detours with the unruly rhythms of the creative process.

items.title: In the Loop
items.short_synopsis: The US President and UK Prime Minister fancy a war. But not everyone agrees that war is a good thing. However, after Cabinet Minister Simon Foster accidentally backs military action on TV, he and his team need to go to Washington to fix things. Now they just need to get in with the right people.
items.default_editorial: Best known for creating The Thick of It and Veep, Iannucci fashions a semi-spin-off of the former in the Academy Award®-nominated In the Loop. A scathing satire of contemporary politics, and a perfect acting showcase for Capaldi—reviving his role as the brilliantly belligerent Malcolm Tucker.

items.title: In the Rearview
items.short_synopsis: A Polish vehicle traverses the roads of Ukraine. On board, people are evacuated following the Russian invasion. This van becomes a fragile and transitory refuge, a zone of confidences and confessions for exiles who have only one objective, to escape the war.
items.default_editorial: Blurring the line between objective observer and force for change, filmmaker Maciek Hamela documents his work as an evacuation driver in this clear-eyed film. Unfolding as a series of refugee portraits, In the Rearview negotiates a decimated landscape to gather compelling testimonies of survival.

items.title: Incident at Restigouche
items.short_synopsis: June 11 and 20, 1981. The Quebec Provincial Police raid Restigouche Reserve, Quebec. At issue are the salmon-fishing rights of the Mi’kmaq. With salmon a traditional source of food and income for the Mi’kmaq, the Quebec government’s decision arouses both dismay and anger in the community.
items.default_editorial: With an Indigenous way of life suddenly under fire, Alanis Obomsawin’s practice takes an explicitly political turn in this spirited documentary. Usually present in voice-over only, the filmmaker and activist intervenes onscreen to expose a Canadian official’s prejudice with trenchant insight.

items.title: Inspector Ike
items.short_synopsis: After the conniving understudy of an avant-garde theater group knocks off the star actor, he finds himself in a high-stakes game of cat-and-mouse with Inspector Ike, New York City’s Greatest Police Detective.
items.default_editorial: Best described as the love child of Columbo and The Naked Gun, Graham Mason’s absurdist comedy gleefully spoofs 1970s mystery-of-the-week TV with plenty of love, silliness, and shocking accuracy. Brace yourself for inventive sight gags, increasingly ridiculous suspects, and a sea of bell-bottoms!

items.title: Intermission
items.short_synopsis: In Dublin, the breakup of two young lovers initiates a series of events with cataclysmic force. From a hell-raising petty thief to a maverick detective to a sex-starved single guy and beyond, all are blissfully unaware of how the accidental nature of life is binding them together.
items.default_editorial: Director John Crowley (Brooklyn) and playwright Mark O’Rowe made the move from stage to screen with this rollicking tale of malcontents on the make. With Colin Farrell and Cillian Murphy leading an ensemble cast of familiar faces, Intermission is a crime comedy with mischief and attitude to burn.

items.title: Invention
items.short_synopsis: In the aftermath of a conspiracy-minded father’s sudden death, his daughter inherits his patent for an experimental healing device.
items.default_editorial: Intuiting the state of the nation, Courtney Stephens and Callie Hernandez refract an America of post-truth politics, conspiracies, and quack science through a personal prism of grief. Holding a candle for more benign eccentrics, dreamers, and dads, this one-of-a-kind wonder whirs with invention.

items.title: Jauja
items.short_synopsis: In 1880s Patagonia, Danish engineer Captain Gunnar Dinesen joins the Argentine army with his teenage daughter, Ingeborg. When she runs off with a young soldier, Dinesen defies orders and sets off alone into hostile territory to find her—beginning a solitary quest.
items.default_editorial: Remarkably bold filmmaking from Argentina’s Lisandro Alonso, the enigmatic Jauja is a postcolonial political allegory rendered in witty shots dazzlingly colored and composed. A film hypnotic and transfixing, minimalist and expressionistic. Starring Viggo Mortensen.

items.title: Jethica
items.short_synopsis: On a road trip through New Mexico to flee a stalker named Kevin, Jessica reunites with an old friend. When Kevin mysteriously appears again, Jessica and Elena seek help from beyond the grave to get rid of him for good… but Kevin is different from other stalkers.
items.default_editorial: Something wicked this way comes in Pete Ohs’s irreverent horror comedy, a darkly ironic exorcism of male obsession and entitlement. Dotted with mysterious mounds and dusty roads, the atmospheric deserts of New Mexico provide an eerie backdrop for this cinematic seance, set under the pale winter sun.

items.title: Kaboom
items.short_synopsis: Smith’s everyday life in his college dorms—hanging out with his arty, sarcastic best friend Stella, hooking up with a beautiful free spirit named London, lusting for his gorgeous but dim surfer roommate Thor—all gets turned upside-down after one fateful, terrifying night.
items.default_editorial: Gregg Araki’s deliciously screwed-up foray into science fiction, Kaboom delves deep into the mind of a hallucinating freshman to make its own wicked twist on the college campus sex comedy. This is indie cinema at its most sexually provocative, salaciously silly, and riotously debauched!

items.title: Kanehsatake: 270 Years of Resistance
items.short_synopsis: In the summer of 1990, an armed standoff over a planned golf course on Kanien’kéhaka land unfolded. Filmmaker Alanis Obomsawin embedded herself on the front lines of this conflict for 78 days to film the discord between the protesters, police, and military.
items.default_editorial: Anger links arms with resilience in Alanis Obomsawin’s riveting two-hour account of the Oka Crisis, a bellicose conflict that received global attention. Unwavering in its commitment to sacred land and First Nations struggles, Kanehsatake is among the filmmaker’s most accomplished works.

items.title: Keane
items.short_synopsis: New York City. It has been six months since William Keane’s six-year-old daughter was kidnapped. He is barely able to cope and often returns to the site of her abduction. One day, he befriends a single mother and her little daughter. He hides his story from them and tries to start anew with them.
items.default_editorial: With a cyclonic performance from Damian Lewis at its center, Lodge Kerrigan’s third feature is a searing psychological drama, stunningly restored in 4K. Through penetrative close-ups, Keane locks its gaze on a lost soul in the big city for a jagged and suspenseful examination of obsession and loss.

items.title: Keep an Eye Out
items.short_synopsis: Fugain shows up at the police station to report that there’s a body in front of his apartment building. What he doesn’t anticipate is running into Captain Buron, who will submit him to arduous questioning, each sentence more outrageous than the last.
items.default_editorial: Gleefully toying with the conventions of the police procedural film, Quentin Dupieux’s absurdist cat-and-mouse chase not only breaks the fourth wall, it turns the whole genre on its head! Full of surreal, meta-textual tricks, this Buñuel-esque gem is a breathless ride that delights in manic chaos.

items.title: Keep the Lights On
items.short_synopsis: Filmmaker Erik and closeted lawyer Paul meet through a casual encounter, but find a deeper connection and become a couple. In an almost decade-long relationship defined by highs, lows, and dysfunctional patterns, Erik struggles to negotiate his own boundaries and dignity while being true to himself.
items.default_editorial: Premiering at Sundance, this indie is a sensitive look at the lifecycle of an imperfect match. Director Ira Sachs based the script on his own personal relationship, but transcends the personal aspects of his experience to form a universal and resonant look at the bonds formed through a partnership.

items.title: Kim's Video
items.short_synopsis: Kim’s Video, an iconic video store in New York City, mysteriously closed its doors and sent its legendary film archive to a Sicilian village for “safekeeping.” But what starts as an homage to cinema quickly becomes a rescue mission to ensure the eternal preservation of the beloved video collection.
items.default_editorial: Memories of an iconic video store spark an unusual international investigation in this documentary-essay hybrid. Playfully translating the filmmakers’ emotions to screen and testifying to a bone-deep cinephilia, film clips bring a wild overseas adventure and an eccentric VHS collection to life.

items.title: Kisses
items.short_synopsis: On the fringes of Dublin, two kids, Kylie and Dylan, live in a housing estate devoid of life. After a violent altercation with his father, Dylan runs away. Kylie decides to go with him, and together, they make their way to the magical nighttime lights of Dublin to search for Dylan’s brother.
items.default_editorial: Moving between kitchen-sink realism and fairy tale, Lance Daly’s faithful portrayal of childhood despair and exhilaration is by turns brutal and enchanting. Animated by an electric spirit of rebellion and the transporting songs of Bob Dylan, Kisses is a shimmering ode to dreams of escape.

items.title: Knives and Skin
items.short_synopsis: What happened to Carolyn Harper? After the high school girl’s disappearance, a wave of fear spreads among traumatized town residents. While the darkness lurking beneath everyday life gradually reveals itself, a sense of awakening overcomes the town’s teenagers, who take on strange coping techniques.
items.default_editorial: Dario Argento’s expressionism meets Twin Peaks’ small-town vibes in this impressive, refreshingly weird drama from American writer-director Jennifer Reeder. An offbeat teenage horror imbued with magical realism and steeped in macabre humor, Knives and Skin is a bold and proudly feminist mystery.

items.title: La Cocina
items.short_synopsis: In the sweltering back kitchen of a Times Square restaurant, undocumented cook Pedro is caught between mounting pressures at work and a complicated romance with waitress Julia. When money goes missing, suspicion spreads, igniting tensions that threaten to upend the fragile hopes of the staff.
items.default_editorial: Starring Rooney Mara, Alonso Ruizpalacios’s ebullient vision of a bustling Times Square kitchen underlines the resilience of employees all too aware of cycles of exploitation. Powdery monochrome cinematography evokes dreaming, while spectacular forays into allegory let humanity shine through.

items.title: La jauría
items.short_synopsis: Eliú is incarcerated in a minors’ center in the heart of Colombian forest, for a crime he committed with his friend El Mono. The teenagers perform manual labor and intense group therapy. One day, El Mono is transferred to the same center.
items.default_editorial: The tension of incarceration simmers quietly in Andrés Ramírez Pulido’s arresting tale of crime and punishment, shot under the sweltering summer sun. Drawing a visual parallel between the male form and the contours of Colombian tropical forests, La jauría unearths the insidious roots of violence.

items.title: Land and Shade
items.short_synopsis: Alfonso, an aging farmer, returns to his family home in rural Colombia to care for his son, whose work in the toxic sugarcane fields has left him gravely ill. As ash rains from the burning crops, the family struggles to survive—torn between love, labor, and a land that is slowly destroying them.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Camera d’Or at Cannes, this poignant, atmospheric drama is set amid Colombia’s sugarcane agriculture: looking at its plantations, farmers, and working conditions. A deceptively simple but visually striking tale about a difficult return, played mostly by nonprofessional actors.

items.title: Let the Bullets Fly
items.original_title: Rang Zi Dan Fei | 让子弹飞
items.short_synopsis: In warlord-dominated China of the 1920s, notorious bandit Zhang descends upon a remote town posing as its new mayor, an identity he has hijacked from the former mayor, himself a small-time imposter. Hell-bent on making a fast buck, Zhang soon meets his match in the tyrannical local thug Wang.
items.default_editorial: Once the darling of the art-film world, Jiang Wen set the local box office ablaze with this rip-roaring action spectacular. With a star-studded cast headlined by Chow Yun Fat, Let the Bullets Fly takes to the boondocks of 1920s China for a gleefully madcap, elaborately political genre mash-up.

items.title: Liberté
items.short_synopsis: Just before the French Revolution, a group of libertines expelled from the court of Louis XVI flees for Germany, where they rendezvous with the legendary seducer and freethinker the Duc de Walchen. Their goal? Export libertinage, a philosophy centered on the rejection of morality and authority.
items.default_editorial: From Don Quixote to Louis XIV, Albert Serra is notorious for radically reimagining the costume drama, but little will prepare you for this. A gorgeous tableaux of the nocturnal cruising and sexual fantasies of desperate aristocrats, its confrontational form challenges cinematic vulgarity and excess.

items.title: Los Reyes
items.short_synopsis: Chola and Football, two charismatic dogs, live in a skate park in Santiago, Chile. The park brings together teenagers from different social and cultural backgrounds. From the dogs’ perspectives, stories of adolescence unfold, revealing experiences of love, school, and the pains of growing up.
items.default_editorial: What began as a portrait of young skaters, soon shifted its focus to two dogs residing in the skatepark. The result is an ingeniously crafted, serene look at a community, as Bettina Perut and Iván Osnovikoff juxtapose adolescent conversations heard in voiceover with closely-observed canine routines.

items.title: Louder Than You Think
items.short_synopsis: Gary Young, the unpredictable first drummer of Pavement, brought a chaotic energy that shaped the band’s early sound and trajectory. Archival footage and present-day scenes chart his wild ride from lo-fi pioneer to aging survivor—still drumming, still defying expectations.
items.default_editorial: Crayola-colored puppetry twists its strings with deep-cut interviews and archive videos in this documentary about Pavement’s odd-one-out. Cartwheeling through the past, it hangs out with the old-hippie drummer who threw ‘70s psychedelic groove and prog-rock extravagance into the band’s ’90s sound.

items.title: Lurker
items.short_synopsis: When a twenty-something retail clerk encounters a rising pop star, he takes the opportunity to edge his way into the in-crowd. But as the line between friend and fan blurs beyond recognition, access and proximity become a matter of life and death.
items.default_editorial: Love and obsession are two sides of the same coin in this daring thriller from The Bear writer-producer Alex Russell, featuring rising stars Archie Madekwe and Théodore Pellerin. In a glitzy LA ruled by social currency, Lurker luxuriates in the suspense and the dark irony of celebrity worship.

items.title: Lux Æterna
items.short_synopsis: Charlotte Gainsbourg agrees to play a witch thrown to the stake in the first film directed by Béatrice Dalle. However, the anarchic organization, technical problems, and psychotic slip-ups gradually plunge the filming into a chaos of pure light.
items.default_editorial: A film shoot goes catastrophically wrong in this playful mockumentary from France’s preeminent enfant terrible, Gaspar Noé. Starring a magnificently game duo in Béatrice Dalle and Charlotte Gainsbourg, Lux Æterna is a formally dazzling, mid-length rumination on witchcraft and the filmmaking process.

items.title: Luz
items.short_synopsis: A young cabdriver, Luz, stumbles into a police station on a rainy night. As a psychiatrist hypnotizes her to retrace her past, a demonic entity that longs for her slips into the session, blurring memory and possession with dangerous consequences.
items.default_editorial: Before making the acclaimed Cuckoo, Tilman Singer reconfigured the well-worn possession horror genre with this inventive, unsettling debut. Channeled through a wailing electronic score and stark fluorescent lights, the presence of demonic forces and unhealed trauma turns terrifyingly tactile.

items.title: Madeline's Madeline
items.short_synopsis: Sixteen-year-old Madeline has become an active member of an experimental theatre troupe. When its ambitious director pushes Madeline to weave her rich interior world and her troubled relationship with her mother into their collective art, the lines between performance and reality begin to blur.
items.default_editorial: A sensorial and immersive trip into a teen’s psyche, Madeline’s Madeline boldly dissects mental health, racial tensions, and the vampiric relationship between identity and performance. Starring Miranda July, Molly Parker, and standout newcomer Helena Howard, this is relentless, electrifying cinema.

items.title: Mainstream
items.short_synopsis: In West Hollywood, California, young filmmaker Frankie thinks she’s found a path to internet stardom when she starts making YouTube videos with  Link, a charismatic stranger living off the grid. However, the dark side of viral celebrity soon threatens to ruin them both.
items.default_editorial: Dopamine hits glitch in Gia Coppola’s second feature, an electrifying satire of Los Angeles fame-grabbing for a YouTube moment. As a video-star sensation doing dubious tricks for the likes, Andrew Garfield whizzes what’s fake and what’s real into a performance that steals an extremely online show.

items.title: Mami Wata
items.short_synopsis: When the harmony in a village is threatened by outside elements, two sisters must fight to save their people and restore the glory of a mermaid goddess to the land.
items.default_editorial: Drawing from West African folklore, C.J. Obasi’s transfixing fable heeds the siren call of the sea, a space of both rebirth and destruction. Winner of a Special Jury prize at Sundance, Lílis Soares’s high-contrast black-and-white cinematography conjures a spellbinding vision of aquatic spiritualism.

items.title: Marjorie Prime
items.short_synopsis: In the near future, a service that creates holographic projections has provided 86-year-old Marjorie with a handsome representation of her dead husband. This AI recreation feeds the story of her life back to her in case the widow, who has the beginning of Alzheimer’s disease, forgets her past.
items.default_editorial: In this intimate romance, Sundance darling Michael Almereyda excels at presenting high-concept sci-fi questions in humane and moving ways. With towering performances by Lois Smith and Jon Hamm, Marjorie Prime delivers a gripping and tender reflection on love and identity.

items.title: Me and You and Everyone We Know
items.original_title: Me and You and Everyone We Know
items.short_synopsis: Single dad Richard meets Christine, a starving artist who moonlights as a cabbie. They awkwardly attempt to start a romance, but Richard’s divorce has left him emotionally damaged. Meanwhile, Richard’s sons—one a teenager, the other 6-years-old—take part in clumsy experiments with the opposite sex.
items.default_editorial: Multi-hyphenate artist Miranda July wrote, directed, and starred in her Cannes-winning feature debut: a sparkling, offbeat subversion of the classic romantic comedy. Daring to wear its heart on its sleeves, this infectiously optimistic film champions vulnerability in the search for true connection.

items.title: Meek's Cutoff
items.short_synopsis: The year is 1845, the earliest days of the Oregon Trail, and a wagon team of three families has hired the mountain man Stephen Meek to guide them over the Cascade Mountains. Claiming to know a short cut, Meek leads the group on an unmarked path across the high plain desert.
items.default_editorial: After the discretion of Wendy and Lucy Kelly Reichardt surprised us with her own take on the Western genre: intensely focused, fascinatingly observant, and loaded with portent. It continues Reichardt’s rich partnership with Michelle Williams, but it is Bruce Greenwood as Meek who steals the show.

items.title: Mister Lonely
items.short_synopsis: A lonely Michael Jackson impersonator falls for a beautiful Marilyn Monroe impersonator. The lovestruck duo retreat to a seaside commune in the Scottish highlands filled with impersonators including the Queen of England, Madonna and Sammy Davis Jr.
items.default_editorial: Director Harmony Korine has been a cult hero of American cinema for two decades now and Mister Lonely, one of his more low-key triumphs, shows his gift for oddball beauty and unique understanding of celebrity and outcasts. A strange, sweet, undiluted vision. Bonus: Herzog and Carax are in it!

items.title: MLK/FBI
items.short_synopsis: Throughout Dr. Martin Luther King Jr.‘s history-altering political career, he was treated by U.S. intelligence agencies like an enemy of the state. Newly declassified files detail the FBI surveillance that dogged King’s activism, fueled by the racist and red-baiting paranoia of J. Edgar Hoover.
items.default_editorial: When revelatory intel is obtained through a malicious abuse of power, how much should we know about the figures behind great strides in the fight for equality? No mere history lesson, Samuel D. Pollard’s engrossing documentary cleverly and meticulously interrogates its own existence.

items.title: Mother of Many Children
items.short_synopsis: Filmmaker Alanis Obomsawin meets with Indigenous women from different First Nations, uncovering a proud matriarchal culture that has been pressured to adopt the values of white society. Women reveal how they struggle to regain a sense of equality and pass on their culture to younger generations.
items.default_editorial: In this plentiful picture of gendered experience in Indigenous communities, all manner of grandmaternal traditions are generously shared. Just as attentive to the hardship that results from discrimination, Alanis Obomsawin underlines the vital importance of togetherness, ritual, and education.

items.title: Mountains
items.short_synopsis: In Miami’s Little Haiti, Xavier makes a living as a demolition worker while his wife Esperance holds down two jobs to sustain their cozy household. But when he is tasked with dismantling his rapidly gentrifying  neighborhood, Xavier is faced with the realities of redevelopment
items.default_editorial: Capturing the warmth of home, family, and community, this tender debut feature also brings to light the forces that erode these reassuring structures. In an empathetic character study, director Monica Sorelle gently teases out the connection between culture and identity, and the fragility of both.

items.title: My Name Is Kahentiiosta
items.short_synopsis: 1990. A young Kahnawake Mohawk woman named Kahentiiosta is arrested after the Oka Crisis’ 78-day armed standoff. She is detained four days longer than the other women. Her crime? The prosecutor representing the Quebec government did not accept her Indigenous name.
items.default_editorial: Bureaucracy is another channel for systemic prejudice in this portrait of an ardent protestor, maligned for her Mohawk name. Giving voice to one individual who set aside pacifism to protect an endangered environment and her people, this short resonates with historic fights for self-determination.

items.title: Nam June Paik: Moon is the Oldest TV
items.original_title: Nam June Paik: Moon is the Oldest TV
items.short_synopsis: Nam June Paik was one of the founding fathers of avant-garde art in the 20th century. Performance footage and original interviews from Paik’s peers trace how the Korean artist became a pillar of the American art world and transformed modern image-making with his sculptures, films, and performances.
items.default_editorial: Crackling with ideas like feedback on a video monitor, Nam June Paik was dubbed the “Nostradamus of the digital age” for his piercing insight into the modern media landscape. Voiced by Steven Yeun, Amanda Kim’s eclectic portrait paints a vivid picture of Paik’s outlandish, boundary-pushing vision.

items.title: Naz + Maalik
items.short_synopsis: Naz and Maalik are friends, classmates, business partners, and lovers. As the two closeted Muslim teens go about their regular daily routine on a Friday afternoon in Brooklyn, they arouse the suspicions of an undercover FBI agent who begins to track them.
items.default_editorial: Hustling through the streets of New York, this breezy debut feature from writer-director Jay Dockendorf unfurls across a single summer’s day. With its newcomer leads making for easy, loose-limbed company, Naz + Maalik weighs the price of tenderness and love against the strictures of expectation.

items.title: New Jerusalem
items.short_synopsis: Sean, an Irish immigrant to America, returns from military service in Afghanistan, finds his heart and mind in disarray. He begins work at a tire shop, where he befriends Ike, a strong-willed Evangelical Christian, who endeavors to ensure the fragile Seanʼs salvation.
items.default_editorial: Between this and Kelly Reichardt’s Old Joy, Will Oldham was for a moment the face of male bonding in independent American cinema. In Rick Alverson’s empathetic film about the emotional aftereffects of serving in the war on terror, his amiably, comically persistent character hammers home tenderness.

items.title: Night Across the Street
items.short_synopsis: On the verge of a forced retirement, an elderly office worker begins to relive real and imagined memories from his life, from conversations with Long John Silver to cinema trips with Beethoven to a brief stay in a haunted hotel. All the while, a sinister end appears to be closing in…
items.default_editorial: We love this film but are saddened to play it. Why? It is Chilean exile-fabulist Raúl Ruiz’s final film, marking the end of a career that seemed to be always expanding in wild, unexpected directions. Here Ruiz returns to his homeland to fashion an oneiric and playful ode to old age and cinephilia.

items.title: Nocturama
items.short_synopsis: A group of adolescents prowl the streets and subways of Paris as they carry out a bombing plot. Afterward, they seek refuge in a shopping mall and soon lose themselves in consumer culture. Will they survive the encroaching authorities? Or, as the walls close in, will they even survive each other?
items.default_editorial: A tour-de-force provocation by French auteur Bertrand Bonello, Nocturama imagines a teenage act of terrorism in Paris freed from ideology and motivation. The first half proceeds like a thriller, the second, like a siege film set in a luxe department store.. A seductive portrait of young, lost souls.

items.title: Notice to Quit
items.short_synopsis: Andy Singer is a resilient yet struggling New York City rental agent caught amid his own eviction crisis. As his world begins crashing down around him, his estranged ten-year-old daughter, Anna, appears unannounced on his doorstep just as he’s being thrown out of his apartment.
items.default_editorial: Shot on luminous 35mm, Simon Hacker’s heartfelt debut brings back the iconic New York of classic comedies, a city where each apartment comes with a thrilling tale. Caught in a hilarious yet nervy race against time, an offbeat father-and-daughter duo sweetly reconnect between schemes and scams.

items.title: Omen
items.short_synopsis: After a birthmark convinced his mother that he must be a sorcerer, Koffi was banished to Europe as a baby. Decades later, Koffi and his Belgian fiancée embark on a trip to the Democratic Republic of Congo. But an incident with his nephew convinces them that he’s possessed by an evil spirit.
items.default_editorial: In this visual and sensory feast, Belgian-Congolese filmmaker Baloji explores the conflicting expectations that arise from different notions of identity, culture, and heritage. Navigating a surreal, ever-changing world of myths, his mercurial outsiders strive to reconcile themselves with tradition.

items.title: One Night at Babes
items.short_synopsis: At a rural Vermont dive bar called Babes, cribbage tournaments overlap afternoons of karaoke and nights of raucous queer dance parties. When the aging conservative townsfolk and the younger queer leftists begin sharing the same watering hole, a delicate allegiance flourishes.
items.default_editorial: The warm atmosphere of a queer-friendly small-town bar is palpable throughout this playful documentary short. Casual talking-head interviews with owners and regulars form a delightful patchwork, capturing both the joy and the challenges of accommodating difference while fostering community.

items.title: Other People's Children
items.short_synopsis: When teacher Rachel falls in love with Ali, she also falls for his 4-year-old daughter Leila. Although she feels like a mother, Rachel cannot forget that Lelia is another woman’s daughter. Soon, she begins to long for her own child—but as a forty-something woman, she must make her decision swiftly.
items.default_editorial: In a touching and graceful tale of modern motherhood and romance, Virginie Efira plays a woman of boundless compassion—and is as radiant as ever. Embracing love in various heart-stealing guises, Rebecca Zlotowski’s fifth feature also has a delightful cameo from adoptive Parisian, Frederick Wiseman!

items.title: Our Time
items.short_synopsis: A family lives in the Mexican countryside raising fighting bulls. Esther is in charge of running the ranch, while her husband Juan raises and selects the beasts. When Esther becomes infatuated with a horse trainer named Phil, the couple struggles to stride through the emotional crisis.
items.default_editorial: Carlos Reygadas’s cinema is one of meticulous observation and grandiose revelations. Casting himself and his real-life wife, the Mexican auteur boldly explores—with spellbinding visuals—the dark corners of relationships, dissecting patriarchy along the way. A domestic drama of majestic proportions.

items.title: Pacifiction
items.short_synopsis: On the French Polynesian island of Tahiti, the High Commissioner of the Republic is a calculating man who coolly navigates both the “establishment” and the local underground.  He persists as rumors circulate about the sighting of a submarine whose presence could mean the return of nuclear testing.
items.default_editorial: Topping Cahiers du cinéma’s list of best films from 2022, Albert Serra’s mesmerizing epic conjures up the malaise and paranoia poisoning the Edenic calm of sun-soaked Tahiti. Steeped in moral ambiguity, Benoît Magimel’s stunning performance embodies the corruptive power of the imperial state.

items.title: Party Girl
items.short_synopsis: Mary, a New York City nightclub scenester and social butterfly, rules the underground party scene. By day, however, she lacks purpose and struggles to make rent. When her aunt gets her a job at the local library, Mary initially waffles under the constraints—but soon begins to flourish.
items.default_editorial: Dancing! Fashion! French Existentialism! Daisy von Scherler Mayer’s glittering time capsule of the ’90s club scene in downtown New York has it all. As a chronic reveler in search of another calling, Parker Posey fizzes with screwball charm in one of the most iconic films of her “Queen of Indie” era.

items.title: Passion
items.short_synopsis: When Kaho and Tomoya announce their engagement at a celebratory dinner with friends, they are unprepared for the emotional turmoil unleashed once a past infidelity is revealed. Later, when Tomoya visits the apartment of his former classmate, further revelations of passion come to light.
items.default_editorial: Thirteen years before he won an Oscar® for Drive My Car, Ryūsuke Hamaguchi delivered this shattering Rohmerian drama as his university thesis film. An intricately knitted tale of love, friendship, and recrimination, Passion sees one of the great contemporary writer-directors emerge fully formed.

items.title: Pavements
items.short_synopsis: ‘90s indie-rock band Pavement reunites for their sold-out 2022 tour. But as preparations get underway, surreal tributes emerge: an off-Broadway musical adaptation of their songs, a museum devoted entirely to the band’s legacy, and a shamelessly awards-baiting Hollywood biopic.
items.default_editorial: Refracting the iconic image of lo-fi band Pavement into new, hybrid forms, acclaimed filmmaker Alex Ross Perry innovatively distorts the music documentary. Joe Keery stars alongside the ’90s group, toying with their slacker-indie commitment to alternative culture with dazzling, hilarious subversion.

items.title: Petrov's Flu
items.short_synopsis: With the city in the throes of a flu epidemic, the Petrov family struggles through yet another day in a country where the past is never past, the present is a booze-fueled, icy fever dream of violence and tenderness, and where – beneath layers of the ordinary – things turn out to be extraordinary.
items.default_editorial: A labyrinthine fever dream of contemporary Russia, this maximalist epic from Kirill Serebrennikov is an exhilarating work of acrobatic formalism. Following a comic book artist suffering from a mysterious illness, Petrov’s Flu takes an anxious, timely plunge into the dark nights of the Russian soul.

items.title: Phoenix
items.short_synopsis: German-Jewish cabaret singer Nelly survived Auschwitz but had to undergo reconstructive surgery as her face was disfigured. Without recognizing Nelly, her former husband Johnny asks her to help him claim his wife’s inheritance. To see if he betrayed her, she agrees, becoming her own doppelganger.
items.default_editorial: Collaborating once more with Harun Farocki and lead actor Nina Hoss, Christian Petzold (Barbara) carefully crafts this cleverly plotted, smotheringly suspenseful post-WW2 drama. An especially impressive combination of throwback thriller and genre elements with substantial thematic weight.

items.title: Pieces of April
items.short_synopsis: Quirky and rebellious April Burns lives with her boyfriend in a low-rent New York City apartment miles away from her emotionally distant family. But when she discovers that her mother has a fatal form of breast cancer, she invites the whole clan to her place for a most chaotic Thanksgiving.
items.default_editorial: After screenwriting success with What’s Eating Gilbert Grape, Peter Hedges won the Special Jury Prize at Sundance for his directorial debut. Peppered with the vivacious wit of Patricia Clarkson’s deliciously mordant performance, dysfunction crackles between characters in this meaty ensemble drama.

items.title: Pilgrims
items.short_synopsis: A woman travels to a small town near an airport with the brother of her former boyfriend, who was killed there in a violent tragedy. As the pair retrace his steps, they unravel the circumstances of his death.
items.default_editorial: Violence is in the soil in Laurynas Bareiša’s bold debut, which rakes through the scenes of a crime by knifelike natural light. Digging into the inaction of those who saw and walked on, this penetrating procedural drama explores how one person’s minding their own business is another’s world of pain.

items.title: Pina
items.short_synopsis: Wim Wenders pays tribute to legendary choreographer Pina Bausch, who died in 2009, and her groundbreaking, inventive work with the Tanztheater Wuppertal ensemble. Longtime troupe members re-create classic pieces for the big screen, pouring out of the theater and into the city of Wuppertal.
items.default_editorial: Between Buena Vista Social Club and The Salt of the Earth, Wim Wenders struck gold with Pina, an Academy Award®-nominated documentary profile of Pina Bausch. A fitting tribute to the iconic dancer and choreographer, a cinematic spectacle of movement, of bodies in motion on-stage and off.

items.title: Policeman
items.short_synopsis: Yaron is one of an elite group of police officers working in an anti-terrorist unit in the Israeli police force. He and his fellow officers are the ultimate defence against the “Arab enemy.” However, an encounter with a radical, violent group turns his life upside down.
items.default_editorial: The job of policing Israel is not only a matter of ensuring law and order. Delving into the complexities of the Israeli police, this stunning and politically volatile film marked Nadav Lapid (The Kindergarten Teacher) as an exciting new directorial talent.

items.title: Queen of Earth
items.short_synopsis: Catherine absconds to the sun-soaked serenity of her best friend Virginia’s lakeside cabin, quivering with anxiety and seeking refuge from the haunting memories of the past year. But as their painful pasts come slithering into the already-uncomfortable present, their nerves become intertwined.
items.default_editorial: Calling upon the tradition of the psychological chamber thriller, Queen of Earth unites an astonishing Elisabeth Moss with Katherine Waterston to burrow deep into the complicated identities of two disaffected women. A fiery exploration of the iron grip emotions—both interior and exterior—have on us.

items.title: Realm of Satan
items.short_synopsis: In sunny California, the Church of Satan has thrived since 1966. Half a century later, its members offer a rare glimpse into their lives, revealing everyday rituals and occult practices—from hanging laundry in the garden to latex orgies and the breastfeeding of a baby goat.
