items.default_editorial: Papier-mâché animal heads and occult illusionism shake hands with garden-variety domestic routines in this mischievous, surprisingly colorful documentary. At once prayerful and playful, the film’s access-all-areas vignettes illuminate the motley world of modern-day Satanists by fire-juggling light.

items.title: Red Hook Summer
items.short_synopsis: Flik, a middle-class boy from Atlanta, is spending the summer with his religious grandfather in a Brooklyn housing project. With his grandfather’s preaching and the culture shock of inner-city life, Flik’s summer is a disaster—until he meets local girl Chazz, who shows him Brooklyn’s brighter side.
items.default_editorial: Until Red Hook Summer, Spike Lee hadn’t taken a role in one of his own films since Summer of Sam. Reprising his Mookie character from Do the Right Thing, the New York icon mounts a loose-limbed drama that is equal parts gospel musical, hangout movie, and spiritual sequel to his 1989 masterpiece.

items.title: Riddle of Fire
items.short_synopsis: Wyoming, USA. When their mother asks them to run an errand, three mischievous children embark on an odyssey. On the hunt to obtain her favorite blueberry pie, the children are kidnapped by poachers, battle a witch, outwit a huntsman, befriend a fairy, and become best pals forever.
items.default_editorial: Although shot on nostalgic 16mm, this throwback to the endearingly naive, occasionally disturbing kids’ films of yesteryear slyly updates the adventure movie for the screen-obsessed generation. In this charming feature, fairy tales, witches, and spells still exist—for those who want to see them.

items.title: Robe of Gems
items.short_synopsis: Deep in the Mexican countryside, a community is plagued by the constant threat of looming violence. Here, three women from different social classes—a maid, her wealthy employer and a police officer—become tragically affected by a missing-person case related to cartel crime.
items.default_editorial: Startling stories of cartel crime and class tension in Mexico are deftly, elliptically interwoven in this exceptional debut from Natalia López Gallardo. Previously an editor for Lisandro Alonso and Carlos Reygadas, she won the Silver Bear Jury Prize in Berlin for this urgent, unshakeable drama.

items.title: Room in Rome
items.short_synopsis: A hotel room in the heart of Rome. Two young women who have only just met travel together on an intimate, passionate journey that will deeply mark their bodies and souls. The story unfolds over twelve nocturnal hours, before each woman departs, Alba to Spain and Natasha to Russia.
items.default_editorial: Delving into Julio Medem’s exploration of fate and identity, Room in Rome dissects a transformative one-night encounter between two strangers. The complexities of female desire come to the fore in this gorgeous erotic fantasy—a high-voltage, life-changing emotional and sexual adventure.

items.title: RYUICHI SAKAMOTO: async AT THE PARK AVENUE ARMORY
items.original_title: RYUICHI SAKAMOTO: async AT THE PARK AVENUE ARMORY
items.short_synopsis: A live performance film capturing an intimate concert by composer, pianist and music producer Ryuichi Sakamoto in New York City. The performance marked the first public unveiling of Sakamoto’s new opus, async, hailed as one of the best albums of 2017 by Rolling Stone and Pitchfork.
items.default_editorial: As a special treat after our release of Ryuichi Sakamoto: Coda is this sensorial immersion into a rare concert experience. Watch the great composer perform the debut of his latest musical masterpiece, with accompanying video imagery by Shiro Takatani and experimental filmmaker Takashi Makino.

items.title: Ryuichi Sakamoto: Coda
items.short_synopsis: One of the most important artists of our era, Ryuichi Sakamoto’s career spans from techno-pop stardom to Oscar®-winning composer and anti-nuclear activist. This intimate portrait explores Sakamoto’s return to music following a cancer diagnosis, leading to the creation of a haunting new masterpiece.
items.default_editorial: An eye-opening look at Ryuichi Sakamoto’s life, work, and creative process, this portrait shows an artist aware of his responsibility to the world around him. His fascination with the beauty and violence of both nature and humanity is all the more moving as he candidly reflects on his own mortality.

items.title: Saint Frances
items.short_synopsis: Flailing thirty-something Bridget finally catches a break when she meets a nice guy and lands a much-needed job nannying the obstinate six-year-old Frances. However, an unwanted pregnancy introduces an unexpected complication. Amidst her personal issues, a reluctant friendship with Frances emerges.
items.default_editorial: Grounded by the honest attention to relationships so beloved in the films of Nicole Holofcener, Alex Thompson and Kelly O’Sullivan are endeared to messy reality in their down-to-earth debut. Agnostic about God and other men but committed to women’s stories, Saint Frances is a defiant heartwarmer.

items.title: Sex and Lucía
items.short_synopsis: Lucía is a young waitress in Madrid, who seeks refuge on a quiet, secluded Mediterranean island after the loss of her longtime boyfriend. Amidst the fresh air, dazzling sun, and glistening deep blue water, Lucía begins to piece together the dark corners of her past relationship.
items.default_editorial: An award-winner in its homeland and a sleeper hit abroad, Sex and Lucía is a sensitive, sensuous, and refreshingly earnest drama about adult relationships—and the gap between sex and intimacy. And Paz Vega, who’d go on to work in Hollywood and with Almodóvar, becomes a star!

items.title: Shadow
items.short_synopsis: In a kingdom ruled by a young and unpredictable king, the military commander has a secret weapon: a “shadow” look-alike who can fool both his enemies and the King himself.  Now he must use this weapon in an intricate plan that will lead his people to victory in a war that the King does not want.
items.default_editorial: Reimagining the fabled Three Kingdoms era, Zhang Yimou’s glorious wuxia epic pairs palace intrigue with mesmeric swordfights, conjuring the beauty and terror of the struggle for power among men. Dappled with hues of white and grey, the elegant color palette heightens the grisliness of bloodshed.

items.title: Shirley Adams
items.short_synopsis: In the depressed cape Town neighborhood of Cape Flats, a single mother contemplates her fate and cautiously accepts the help of an overeager social worker as she struggles to care for her paraplegic and suicidal son.
items.default_editorial: Produced by Roland Emmerich, this sobering debut from Oliver Hermanus (The History of Sound) reveals the hidden trauma inflicted by gang violence. Nervy, jagged camerawork evinces the spiraling inner world of a grieving mother, whose turmoil embodies the plight of working-class South Africans.

items.title: Shithouse
items.short_synopsis: Lonely college freshman Alex has closed himself off from his peers, who all appear to have this whole “college thing” figured out. But everything changes one night when Alex takes a leap and attends a party at Shithouse—a legendary party fraternity—where he forges a strong connection with Maggie.
items.default_editorial: A compelling subversion of college romps and meet-cutes, this candid dramedy is astute when it comes to the highs and lows of fleeting connections. Gently capturing the nervousness and isolation of freshman year, Dylan Gelula and Cooper Raiff shine in this delicate directorial debut.

items.title: Sick of Myself
items.short_synopsis: Signe and Thomas are young, attractive, and extraordinarily infuriating. Their relationship as a couple degenerates when contemporary artist Thomas achieves celebrity. Jealous, Signe decides to go to any lengths to get herself noticed. Any lengths at all.
items.default_editorial: The second feature from Norwegian filmmaker Kristoffer Borgli, this wicked comedy is a deliciously dark portrait of a toxic relationship. With a delectable pair of performances at its center, Sick of Myself plumbs the merciless depths of its protagonists’ narcissism for an uproarious modern fable.

items.title: Slow
items.short_synopsis: When dancer Elena meets sign language interpreter Dovydas their instant connection bodes well for a romantic relationship. But when Dovydas reveals he’s asexual, their dynamic changes as both try to find a way to be together while fulfilling their respective needs.
items.default_editorial: Marija Kavtaradzė won Best Director at Sundance with this tender, nuanced film, shot on sensuous 16mm. Attuned to the tentative movements of its magnetic performers, Slow is a different kind of love story—one that unravels sex from intimacy and hazards a newly passionate picture of attraction.

items.title: Slow Machine
items.short_synopsis: Stephanie, a vibrant actress, meets Gerard, an NYPD counter-terrorism specialist who’s an aficionado of experimental theater. Flirtation ensues, ends disastrously, and forces Stephanie to the upstate home of musician Eleanor Friedberger, yet this escape is infected by violent memories.
items.default_editorial: Filtering the conspiracies of Jacques Rivette and the paranoid fantasies of David Lynch’s Inland Empire through the prism of an actor’s life, this slippery wonder balances wit with bite. Shot on atmospheric 16mm, Slow Machine is a surprising, darkly comic drama of identity and performance.

items.title: Smoke Sauna Sisterhood
items.short_synopsis: In southeast Estonia, in a traditional smoke sauna, a group of women from the Võro community come together to cleanse their bodies and share their stories. In observing sauna rituals, these women create space for each other as they each regain the strength they need to face the world outside.
items.default_editorial: Winner of an award for nonfiction filmmaking at Sundance, documentarian Anna Hints takes us to the frosty heart of an Estonian forest, where women open up to one another in the herbaceous heat of a smoke sauna. Suffused with naked emotion, this glistening film invigorates the senses and the soul.

items.title: So Unreal
items.short_synopsis: A cinephile collage, both historical and philosophical, of films on artificial intelligence, cyberspace and virtual reality, from 1981 to 2001: cinema as a way and an instrument to cope with humanity’s euphoria, anxiety, fear and obsession with technology.
items.default_editorial: Channeling the androids of sci-fi cinema, the legendary Debbie Harry narrates this pulsing essay film about tech-neurotic expectations of virtual futures. Collaging from twentieth-century cult films and genre classics, Amanda Kramer pilots a cyber-kaleidoscopic ride through cinema’s electric dreams.

items.title: Song of Granite
items.short_synopsis: Enigmatic and complex, Joe Heaney was one of the greats of 20th-century traditional Irish singing. Shaped by the myths, fables, and songs, Heaney’s emergence from his upbringing in the west of Ireland to life as an NYC doorman to acclaim at the 1966 Newport Folk Festival came at a personal cost.
items.default_editorial: With elements of fiction and documentary, Pat Collins celebrates the art of Sean-nós singing through an atypical, poetic portrait of traditional Irish folk singer Joe Heaney. Told in fragments and sumptuous B&W cinematography, this work of stirring beauty is an ode to the sublime power of singing.

items.title: Song Without a Name
items.short_synopsis: Peru, at the height of the political crisis of the 1980s. Georgina is an indigenous woman from the Andes whose newborn daughter is stolen at a fake health clinic. Her desperate search for the child leads her to the headquarters of a major newspaper, where she meets Pedro Campos, a lonely journalist.
items.default_editorial: Melina León sheds light on a dark chapter in Peru’s recent history in her mesmerising feature debut, which earned comparisons with Alfonso Cuarón’s Roma! With strikingly framed black and white cinematography, the sumptuous imagery of this eerily evocative film brings majesty to a tragic real story.

items.title: Spa Night
items.short_synopsis: David Cho, a timid 18-year-old living with his financially-struggling immigrant parents, chances upon a secret cruising spot when he takes a job at an all-male spa. There he begins to realize hidden desires that threaten his life as a dutiful son and student.
items.default_editorial: With his latest The Wedding Banquet making a splash, Andrew Ahn’s intimate coming-of-age debut is another keen-eyed portrait of the queer Asian-American experience. A heartfelt ode to the vibrant Koreatown of Los Angeles that also digs deep into the hidden prejudices that exist within the community.

items.title: Spree
items.short_synopsis: Kurt Kunkle, a rideshare driver thirsty for followers, has figured out a deadly plan to go viral. As his disturbing livestream is absurdly embraced by the social media hellscape, a stand-up comedian emerges as the only hope to stop this rampage.
items.default_editorial: With Stranger Things star Joe Keery behind the wheel, Eugene Kotlyarenko’s madcap satire adopts the relentless pace of livestreaming with terrifying accuracy. Turning Los Angeles into a mecca of vacuity, this blood-soaked joyride gleefully twists the knife into the poisonous core of online fame.

items.title: State Funeral
items.short_synopsis: Moscow, March 1953: in the days following the death of Joseph Stalin, countless citizens flooded the Red Square to mourn their leader’s loss and witness his burial. Though the procession was captured in detail by hundreds of cameramen, their footage has remained largely unseen until now.
items.default_editorial: What makes this film and Stalin’s funeral so fascinating is that we will never know how much of it was real and how much was staged. With the rise of ‘strong’ leaders backed by heavy propaganda all over the world, this docu is a quiet and unbiased look at our past, and a mirror to our future. – VM

items.title: Stranger by the Lake
items.short_synopsis: Summertime. A cruising spot for men is tucked away on the shores of a lake. Franck falls in love with Michel, an attractive, potent, and lethally dangerous man. Franck knows this—but decides to live out his passion anyway.
items.default_editorial: After winning a prize in Cannes, this thriller quickly became a sensation as the hottest arthouse queer title of the year. Set in the cruising world, it merges eroticism and suspense in a celebration of bodies of all shapes and sizes, engaging in explicit sex under the glinting, menacing summer sun.

items.title: Superior
items.short_synopsis: On the run, Marian seeks refuge with her estranged twin sister Vivian, a housewife in a crumbling marriage. Their reunion unsettles quiet routines, and when Marian’s past resurfaces, the sisters are pulled into a dangerous reckoning.
items.default_editorial: Real-life twins Alessandra and Ani Mesa lend a genuine edge to Erin Vassilopoulos’s hallucinatory tale of sisterhood. Bursting with 1980s sartorial delights—fringed leather jackets and all—and shot on atmospheric 16mm, Superior summons the quiet terror that lurks beneath picture-perfect suburbia.

items.title: Tahara
items.short_synopsis: When their former Hebrew school classmate dies, Hannah and Carrie attend her funeral as well as a Jewish grief session hosted by their synagogue. Hannah, more interested in impressing her crush, convinces Carrie to practice kissing with her, unlocking feelings that turn Carrie’s world upside down.
items.default_editorial: In 2020, comic actor Rachel Sennott starred in two films that muddle religion and sex into the poignant mess of coming-of-age: Shiva Baby and Olivia Peace’s inventive, insightful debut. Tapped into irrepressible desire, Tahara is a darkly funny, sensitive take on the eternal dramas of adolescence.

items.title: Teenage
items.short_synopsis: Teenagers didn’t always exist. As the world’s cultural landscape was thrown into turmoil during the industrial revolution, the concept of a new generation took shape. Whether hip Swing Kids, zealous Nazi Youth or frenzied Sub-Debs, it didn’t matter—this was a new idea of how people come of age.
items.default_editorial: Leaping between the UK, US, and Germany, this fascinating documentary from filmmaker Matt Wolf maps the social and cultural development of teenagers as a political entity. Employing multiple narrators—including Ben Whishaw and Jena Malone—Teenage is a vibrant examination of pre-war youth culture.

items.title: The Assassin
items.original_title: Ci ke Nie Yin Niang | 刺客聶隱娘 | Nie Yin Niang
items.short_synopsis: 9th century China. 10-year-old general’s daughter Nie Yinniang is abducted by a nun who initiates her into the martial arts, turning her into an exceptional assassin. One day, having failed in a task, she is sent to kill the man to whom she was promised, a cousin who leads a large military region.
items.default_editorial: Taiwanese master Hou Hsiao-hsien reunites with his Millennium Mambo and Three Times star Shu Qi for the sublime The Assassin. This historical wuxia finds Shu’s enigmatic woman knight returning from exile and torn between love and duty. An elliptical, enchanting experience.

items.title: The Blue Room
items.short_synopsis: A man and a woman, secretly in love, alone in a room. They desire each other, and even bite each other. In the afterglow, they share a few sweet nothings. At least the man seemed to believe they were nothing. Now under investigation by the police and the courts, what is he accused of?
items.default_editorial: A puzzlebox neo-noir, this erotic thriller from Mathieu Amalric is one where the French actor’s filmmaking is every bit as enthralling as his performance. We hand you the keys to The Blue Room, a spiral of passion, secrets & murder brilliantly adapted to the screen from Simenon’s eponymous novel.

items.title: The Boy With No Name
items.short_synopsis: While attending a religious boarding school, Pedro da Silva, an orphan, discovers his mother’s identity: the Countess Angela de Lima. With the help of Father Dinis, Pedro’s real guardian and protector, the Countess is given a chance to get to know the child he was forced to abandon.
items.default_editorial: A Borgesian matryoshka doll of storytelling, Mysteries of Lisbon is Chilean maestro Raúl Ruiz’s magnum opus—a sumptuous period epic in six parts. Playing in its rarely screened extended version, this sweeping melodramatic saga is Dickensian in scope and magisterial in novelistic ambition.

series.title: Mysteries of Lisbon

content_rating.label: caution
content_rating.description: Contains material that may not be suitable for children or young adults.

series.short_synopsis: In 19th-century Lisbon, a young boy named Joao begins to unravel the mystery of his parentage, setting off a sweeping tale of hidden identities, ancient secrets, and fateful encounters. Over three decades and across multiple countries, a web of interconnected lives slowly reveals its full design.
series.short_synopsis_html: In 19th-century Lisbon, a young boy named Joao begins to unravel the mystery of his parentage, setting off a sweeping tale of hidden identities, ancient secrets, and fateful encounters. Over three decades and across multiple countries, a web of interconnected lives slowly reveals its full design.

seasons.title: Mysteries of Lisbon
seasons.default_editorial: Raúl Ruiz’s sweeping melodramatic epic is magisterial in its novelistic ambition. A Dickensian saga of great expectations, this extended version presents Mysteries of Lisbon in six parts, providing a rare opportunity to get lost in the endlessly generating passageways of Ruiz’s complete vision.
seasons.default_editorial_html: Raúl Ruiz’s sweeping melodramatic epic is magisterial in its novelistic ambition. A Dickensian saga of great expectations, this extended version presents Mysteries of Lisbon in six parts, providing a rare opportunity to get lost in the endlessly generating passageways of Ruiz’s complete vision.

items.title: The Canyons
items.short_synopsis: Modern-day Hollywood. After growing bored with her scheming movie producer boyfriend, Christian, young actress Tara rekindles an affair with a former flame. When Christian learns of her infidelity, the couple is plunged into the darkest depths of human desire.
items.default_editorial: Paul Schrader’s collaboration with Bret Easton Ellis is a caustic take on a Hollywood that lives off the dashed hopes and broken dreams of an ever-renewing influx of chumps and suckers. Sex and violence reign in this stylish and uncanny vision of Los Angeles, all smooth surfaces and digital grain.

items.title: The Childhood of a Leader
items.short_synopsis: In the aftermath of World War I, 7-year-old Prescott moves to a château in France with his German mother and his American diplomat father. As he witnesses his father’s part in the 1919 Paris Peace Conference, the boy learns to manipulate the adults around him, developing a terrifying ego.
items.default_editorial: Brady Corbet’s acting career was quietly developing with roles in the likes of Melancholia, Simon Killer, and Force Majeure, when he surprised us all with his directorial debut: this stunning and ambitious rumination on violence scored by Scott Walker. A visually arresting period fantasy!

items.title: The Death of Louis XIV
items.short_synopsis: August 1715. After going for a walk, Louis XIV feels a pain in his leg. Over the next few days, the king keeps fulfilling his duties, but his sleep is troubled and he has a serious fever. This is the start of the slow agony of the greatest king of France, surrounded by his relatives and doctors.
items.default_editorial: In all playful seriousness, the master of slow cinema Albert Serra surprised audiences with this homage to the legendary Jean-Pierre Léaud. Seen as an allegory for the mythical actor’s own slow decline, this grandiose piece provides some of the most beautiful Versailles imagery ever seen on screen.

items.title: The Death of Stalin
items.short_synopsis: Moscow, 1953: when tyrannical dictator Joseph Stalin drops dead, his parasitic cronies enter a frantic power struggle to be the next Soviet leader. The dweeby Georgy Malenkov, the wily Nikita Khrushchev, and the sadistic secret police chief Lavrentiy Beria bumble and backstab their way to the top.
items.default_editorial: Armando Ianucci, the brilliant comic mind behind The Thick of It, turns to the tyranny of Stalinism for this profoundly funny, absurdist romp. With its all-star cast and a masterful control of tone, The Death of Stalin is a breakneck farce and the only rightful heir to Kubrick’s Dr. Strangelove.

items.title: The Driller Killer
items.short_synopsis: Reno is a struggling artist pushed to the edge by the economic realities of New York living in the late seventies and the punk band practicing in the apartment below. His grip on reality soon begins to slip, and he takes to stalking the streets with his power tool in search of prey.
items.default_editorial: Transfusing exploitation with experimentation, The Driller Killer spills blood, guts, and ideas too. Drilling down into genre, Abel Ferrara’s notorious breakthrough mashes together throbbing punk concerts, lurid grindhouse kills, wicked political satire, and bohemian arthouse digressions.

items.title: The Duke of Burgundy
items.short_synopsis: Day in and day out, lovers Cynthia and Evelyn enact an elaborate sadomasochistic fantasy as mistress and maid. But as their ritual of domination and submission begins to turn stale, Cynthia yearns for something more conventional, while Evelyn tries to push their taboos even further.
items.default_editorial: British one-of-a-kind director Peter Strickland explores a S&M see-sawing power dynamic between two women with piercing psychological insight in this extraordinarily sumptuous feast of image and sound. An increasingly abstract, intoxicating erotic drama lush with pictorial beauty.

items.title: The Father of My Children
items.short_synopsis: Grégoire Canvel has everything a man could want. A wife he loves, three delightful children and a stimulating job. He’s a film producer. Discovering talented filmmakers and developing films is precisely his reason for living. Yet his prestigious production company, Moon Films, is on its last legs.
items.default_editorial: The sophomore feature from Mia Hansen-Løve, this moving drama is sensitively attuned to the intimate dynamics of family life. Inspired by the true-life story of producer Hubert Balsan—famed for his work with Claire Denis—The Father of My Children blossoms with quiet observations on love and loss.

items.title: The Featherweight
items.short_synopsis: In 1964, a camera crew follows Willie Pep, retired featherweight boxing champion. Down and out in Hartford, Connecticut, married to a woman half his age, and dealing with a drug-addled son and mounting debts, Pep decides to make a return to the ring.
items.default_editorial: A knockout of a biopic, this sensational debut from acclaimed cinematographer Robert Kolodny (Pavements) inhabits the cinéma vérité style of 1960s documentaries. With stunning attention to period details, The Featherweight probes the public image and the private turmoil of a fading boxing star.

items.title: The Final Master
items.short_synopsis: In 1930s China, unrest rules the nation. Chen, the last Wing Chun master, arrives in Tianjin to expand his kung fu—but his ambition gets entangled in a power struggle between Tianjin’s martial arts Grandmaster, a dominant underworld madam, and the town’s military leaders.
items.default_editorial: One of the screenwriters on Wong Kar Wai’s kung fu epic The Grandmaster, director Xu Haofeng knows a thing or two about the art of the fight. With dynamic choreography and a breathtaking, weapons-heavy climax, The Final Master is a period action film with a killer eye for clarity in combat.

items.title: The Flavor of Cassava Leaf Over Rice
items.original_title: The Flavor of Cassava Leaf Over Rice
items.short_synopsis: Married to a TV producer and living in the Hollywood Hills, novelist Michael Allegheny feels isolated and blocked. When his wife leaves town, he drifts into a medley of Chinese takeout, hot tub dips, and wine—until a chance meeting with an old flame rekindles memories and unresolved desires.
items.default_editorial: Freehand lines and sinuous saxophone sweeten this moodily sensuous hand-drawn animation about a weekend’s brief encounter. In this Los Angeles of strange angels and mixed fortunes, a coiling Mulholland Drive and the backside of the Hollywood sign share Tequila Sunrise skies with the city’s unhoused.

items.title: The French Doll
items.short_synopsis: Tragedy strikes when young Emili is shockingly murdered by a mysterious stranger. The other four girls present at the scene of the crime—Sae, Maki, Akiko, and Yuka—are unable to remember the killer’s face. The crime goes unsolved. Fifteen years later, Sae is paid a surprise visit on her wedding day.
items.default_editorial: Japanese master of the macabre Kiyoshi Kurosawa brings his incantatory gift for creeping dread to the small screen with this sinuous miniseries. An eerie, pungently atmospheric interrogation of historical trauma, Penance is a devastating psychological thriller that ratchets up tension from the jump.

series.title: Penance

content_rating.label: mature
content_rating.description: Contains material and themes suitable only for mature audiences.

series.short_synopsis: A mysterious stranger approaches a group of young friends at a sleepy small town playground, then kidnaps and brutally murders one of the girls. Wracked with grief, the victim’s unhinged mother Asako demands that the shaken survivors identify the killer or face a penance of her choosing.
series.short_synopsis_html: A mysterious stranger approaches a group of young friends at a sleepy small town playground, then kidnaps and brutally murders one of the girls. Wracked with grief, the victim’s unhinged mother Asako demands that the shaken survivors identify the killer or face a penance of her choosing.

seasons.title: Penance
seasons.default_editorial: Kiyoshi Kurosawa has no fear of cinema’s many shapes and sizes, and his version of a television miniseries takes full advantage of its possibilities for storytelling. The result is a genre-bending, deeply immersive saga of a crime and a curse that follows four girls’s divergent paths into adulthood.
seasons.default_editorial_html: Kiyoshi Kurosawa has no fear of cinema’s many shapes and sizes, and his version of a television miniseries takes full advantage of its possibilities for storytelling. The result is a genre-bending, deeply immersive saga of a crime and a curse that follows four girls’s divergent paths into adulthood.

items.title: The Happiest Day in the Life of Olli Mäki
items.short_synopsis: Finland, 1962. Boxer Olli Mäki has a shot at the World Featherweight title. Immensely talented and equally modest, Olli’s small town life is transformed when he’s swept into national stardom and suddenly regarded as a symbol of his country. There’s only one problem: Olli has just fallen in love.
items.default_editorial: A knock-out debut and the triumphant winner of Un Certain Regard at Cannes, this 60s-set Nordic charmer from Juho Kuosmanen is based on the true story of one of the most romantic of boxers. Shot on gorgeously monochrome 16mm film, there’s one thing for sure: this film will make you happier.

items.title: The Headless Woman
items.short_synopsis: Veronica is driving in northwestern Argentina when her mobile phone distracts her and she runs over something—but drives on. The police confirm that there was no accident, but Veronica begins to have a meltdown, thinking she may have killed someone.  Was it an animal? A child? Or nothing at all?
items.default_editorial: One of cinema’s most talented filmmakers, Lucrecia Martel, brings all her powers of sensual, evocative visuals to this dream-like mystery, which plunges fearlessly into the mindstate of a woman—an incredible María Onetto—on the verge of a nervous breakdown.  Nominated for the Palme d’Or.

items.title: The History of Sound
items.short_synopsis: Two young music students, Lionel and David, attending the Boston Conservatory in 1917, bond over their shared love of folk music. They reconnect a few years later, embarking on a song collecting trip in the backwaters of Maine.
items.default_editorial: Paul Mescal and Josh O’Connor star in this nostalgic, aching romance, lifting a profound story of yearning in exquisitely tender performances. Interweaving timeless folk tunes with sumptuous, autumnal images, director Oliver Hermanus chronicles a love whose reverberations are felt for a lifetime.

items.title: The Innocents
items.short_synopsis: During the bright Nordic summer, a group of children reveal their dark and mysterious powers when the adults aren’t looking. But what starts out as innocent playtime soon turns dark and violent.
items.default_editorial: The kids are not alright in this bone-chilling horror tale from Eskil Vogt, famed for his writing partnership with Joachim Trier. Alert to the supernatural unease that lurks among the sleepy forests of Oslo, The Innocents punctures the edenic cocoon of childhood with disturbing, gruesome deeds.

items.title: The Journey
items.short_synopsis: During the 2006 Northern Ireland peace talks, Sinn Féin leader Martin McGuinness and Democratic Unionist Party leader Ian Paisley are forced to travel by car together. Over the detour-filled trip through the Scottish countryside, they will take the biggest leap of faith and change.
items.default_editorial: With a fire-and-brimstone performance from Timothy Spall and a shrewd, affable turn from Colm Meaney, this gripping work of historical fantasy imagines how mortal enemies might begin a dialogue. In a moving narrative, director Nick Hamm reflects on living for a cause bigger than any one man.

items.title: The Long Night of Francisco Sanctis
items.original_title: La larga noche de Francisco Sanctis
items.short_synopsis: Buenos Aires, 1977. In the midst of the dictatorship, family man Francisco Sanctis receives information of the whereabouts of two people who are being searched by the military. Now he has the chance to save them, although that means risking his own life.
items.default_editorial: This adaptation of Humberto Costantini’s book comments, through its main character, on Argentina’s “silent majority”: the people who remained passive while the military dictatorship assassinated opponents in large numbers. A suspenseful thriller imbued with a subtle, yet gripping, sense of paranoia.

items.title: The Man from Nowhere
items.short_synopsis: A retired government operative, living in obscurity, collects his pension and minds his own business. But when a gang of black market organ harvesters abduct the kid who lives next door, he swings into action, tearing through everyone in his path as he races to the rescue.
items.default_editorial: Lee Jeong-beom’s relentless revenge film, has non-stop high-speed action sequences, breathtakingly violent set pieces, and all the blood and guts you could ever want. The Man From Nowhere is an exemplary action film which doesn’t waste a moment in its relentlessly fiery tale of retribution.

items.title: The Melt Goes On Forever: The Art & Times of David Hammons
items.original_title: The Melt Goes On Forever: The Art & Times of David Hammons
items.short_synopsis: The singular career of elusive African-American art star David Hammons is chronicled from Watts rebellion-era 1960s L.A. to his global prominence today. Artists, curators, and critics uncover Hammons’ category-defying practice, rooted in a deep critique of American society and the elite art world.
items.default_editorial: Focused on an artist who has always escaped definition, this loving documentary paints a multifaceted portrait of an icon from archival footage and expert interviews. Between the creation of objects and performances, his practice opens our eyes to questions of freedom, in the gallery and beyond.

items.title: The Nest
items.short_synopsis: 1980s England. Ambitious entrepreneur Rory has persuaded his American wife, Allison, to leave suburban America and return to his home country. Sensing opportunity, Rory rejoins his former firm and leases a centuries-old country manor. Soon, the promise of a lucrative new beginning starts to unravel.
items.default_editorial: Unmasking the illusory excess of the 1980s, Sean Durkin’s psychologically askew chamber piece is a decadent treat with a poisonous core, boasting standout performances from Jude Law and Carrie Coon. The superbly biting repartee makes this a must-see addition to the pantheon of toxic movie marriages.

items.title: The Nightingale
items.short_synopsis: Tasmania, 1825. Irish convict Clare chases a British officer through the Australian wilderness, bent on revenge for a terrible act of violence he committed against her family. On the way, she enlists the services of a First Nations tracker named Billy, who is also marked by trauma from his past.
items.default_editorial: Jennifer Kent’s first film, The Babadook, may be frightening, but The Nightingale takes terror to another level. Unflinching in its portrayal of England’s histories of violence in Australia, her sophomore feature seethes with an anti-colonialist and anti-patriarchal anger that’s difficult to forget.

items.title: The Passengers of the Night
items.short_synopsis: Election night, 1981. There’s an air of hope throughout Paris. But for Elisabeth, her marriage is ending, and she will now have to support herself and her two teenage children. She finds work at a late-night radio show and encounters a troubled teenager named Talulah, who she invites into her home.
items.default_editorial: The winds of change sweep the streets of Paris at a time both intimidating and liberating for a mother and her teenage children. Charlotte Gainsbourg is at her most enchanting in this drama, which follows in the footsteps of the great Éric Rohmer by tenderly and precisely observing human existence.

items.title: The People's Joker
items.short_synopsis: In Gotham City, where comedy has been outlawed, Joker the Harlequin, a painfully unfunny aspiring clown, grapples with her gender identity while attempting to join the city’s sole comedy program. Soon, Joker the Harlequin is on a collision course with the devious caped crusader controlling Gotham.
items.default_editorial: Taking copyrighted characters for a joyride, Vera Drew’s inventive take on the superhero film bounces between different visual styles, including dynamic animation and puppetry. Basking in the thrill of pastiche, this daring debut keenly expresses the trans experience through the lens of pop culture.

items.title: The Selfish Giant
items.short_synopsis: After being excluded from school, 13-year-old Arbor and his best mate Swifty begin collecting scrap metal for Kitten, a local Bradford dealer, using a horse and cart. But when Arbor begins to emulate the shady Kitten by becoming increasingly greedy and exploitative, tensions start to build.
items.default_editorial: Though self-consciously structured as if a fairy tale or fable, Clio Barnard’s follow-up to the docudrama The Arbor continues the tradition of Britain’s kitchen sink socio-realism. Both devastating and compassionate, The Selfish Giant is a profound film on friendship and the class system.

items.title: The Sound of Silence
items.short_synopsis: Peter, a “house tuner” in New York, works meticulously to diagnose the ambient noises adversely affecting his clients’ moods. However, when he is hired by Ellen, a lonely woman plagued by chronic exhaustion, Peter finds that the mysteries of the soul may be even greater than the mysteries of sound.
items.default_editorial: Peter Sarsgaard often operates according to his own enigmatic frequencies, and here the character actor exactingly fine-tunes his persona as an eccentric intellectual. Playing an audiophile who has a near-mystic obsession with ambient sounds, he exudes weirdness in a magnetic performance.

items.title: The Third Murder
items.original_title: 三度目の殺人 | Sando-me no satsujin
items.short_synopsis: Leading attorney Shigemori takes on the defence of murder-robbery suspect Misumi who served jail time for another murder 30 years ago. Misumi freely admits his guilt despite facing the death penalty. As he digs deeper into the case, Shigemori begins to doubt whether his client is the murderer.
items.default_editorial: Before winning the Palm D’Or with Shoplifters, Hirokazu Koreeda directed this crime thriller filled with nuance and complexity. Defying genre conventions, its whodunit aspect quickly makes room for a deeper exploration of truth, memory and the power of stories that we tell ourselves and others.

items.title: The Unknown Country
items.short_synopsis: Reeling from a devastating loss, Tana is pulled back into the world by an unexpected invitation to her cousin’s wedding. After reconnecting with her Oglala Lakota family, Tana retraces a journey that her grandmother took decades ago—searching for the spot captured in an old family photograph.
items.default_editorial: Lily Gladstone won a Gotham Award for her luminous performance in Morrisa Maltz’s debut feature, which follows the actor from motels and diners to the heart of American life. Creating an authentic, but dreamlike picture of the Midwest, poetry and documentary blur beautifully in this hybrid film.

items.title: The Unknown Girl
items.short_synopsis: Jenny, a talented doctor, refuses to open the door of her practice to a mysterious late-night caller. The next morning, she learns it was a girl who has been found dead, and the police have no way of identifying her. Guilt-stricken by the news, Jenny resolves to discover the name of the girl.
items.default_editorial: Injecting a dose of neo-noir into melodrama, the Dardenne brothers reinvigorate their signature moral intrigue with a daring detective film. Starring Adèle Haenel in an impressive lead performance, The Unknown Girl is never squeamish about probing French attitudes to race and immigration.

items.title: The Way Back
items.short_synopsis: An army officer, sentenced to twenty years in a Siberian Gulag, makes a successful escape with a few other inmates. But they must travel 4,000 miles on foot before they can reclaim their freedom.
items.default_editorial: With gripping characterization and dynamic direction, Peter Weir turns a survival tale into a moving reflection on life’s eternal pains. Braving hostile conditions, his international cast brings out the visceral and universal dimensions of a journey that seems at times absurd, but never futile.

items.title: The Way He Looks
items.short_synopsis: Leo is a blind teenager who’s fed up with his overprotective mother and the bullies at school. Looking to assert his independence, he decides to study abroad. However, when Gabriel, the new kid in town, teams with Leo on a school project, new feelings blossom that make him reconsider his plans.
items.default_editorial: Winning two prizes at the 2014 Berlinale, Daniel Ribeiro drew international acclaim for his film debut, a sensitive coming-of-age LGBT drama. Chronicling the sexual awakening and struggles of a blind high-school student, The Way He Looks is a rare depiction of the awkward ordeals of adolescence.

items.title: Things to Come
items.short_synopsis: Nathalie teaches philosophy at a Parisian high school. She is deeply passionate about her job and enjoys passing on the pleasure of thinking to others. Unexpectedly, Nathalie’s husband announces he is leaving her. With a newfound freedom suddenly thrust upon her, Nathalie must reinvent herself.
items.default_editorial: A profound reflection on personhood and identity, Mia Hansen-Løve’s Things to Come effortlessly brings the pleasures of philosophy into everyday life. In one of her most touching performances, Isabelle Huppert exquisitely conveys the tempestuous gap between one’s private and intellectual personas.

items.title: Time to Die
items.short_synopsis: Juan Sayago was released after eighteen years in prison for murdering Raul Trueba, a man who challenged him only to get in the duel in which he fairly lost his life. Juan returns to his town to live quietly, trying to rebuild his life.
items.default_editorial: After cutting his teeth on Luis Buñuel’s sets, the now infamous Mexican auteur Arturo Ripstein made his debut with this elegiac charro western. Using the genre to stage eloquent questioning of mortality, justice, and retribution, Time to Die entirely lives up to the magnificence of its title.

items.title: Two Days, One Night
items.short_synopsis: Sandra returns to work after a bout of depression to find that her co-workers have voted her out of a job in favor of a bonus. Her boss gives her a weekend to convince them all to change their minds, prompting a series of confrontations that test both her ingenuity and her colleagues’ scruples.
items.default_editorial: With this proletarian drama, the Dardenne brothers made one of their finest in an illustrious career filled with social-realist masterworks. Attuned to the complexities of its rich cast of characters, and led by a never-better Marion Cotillard, Two Days, One Night is as enveloping as cinema gets.

items.title: Undine
items.short_synopsis: Undine is a historian and tour guide at the Berlin City Museum specializing in urban development, while Christoph is an industrial diver. Linked by a love of the water, the two form an intense bond, which can only do so much to help Undine overcome the considerable baggage of her former affair.
items.default_editorial: Christian Petzold puts a unique spin on an ancient myth in this urban fairytale, combining legend, romance and architecture to magnetic effect. We dare you not to swoon at the chemistry between Paula Beer and Franz Rogowski, who prove themselves to be one of the greatest contemporary cinematic duos.

items.title: Unrest
items.short_synopsis: New technologies are transforming a 19th-century watchmaking town in Switzerland. Josephine, a young factory worker, produces the unrest wheel, swinging in the heart of the mechanical watch. Exposed to new ways of organizing money, time and labor, she gets involved with the local anarchist movement.
items.default_editorial: Much like the clockwork timepieces over which its protagonist hunches in exacting scrutiny, this piquant tale of socialist activism is a jewel of precision engineering. A Berlinale prizewinner from Swiss rising star Cyril Schäublin, Unrest is as fastidiously conceived as it is stylistically playful.

items.title: Việt and Nam
items.short_synopsis: In the dark underground passages of a coal mine in northern Vietnam, two young miners steal moments of intimacy and desire, their naked bodies pressed against the dark rocks. Nam is haunted by the past and plans to escape the country, but is grounded by the love he shares with Viêt.
items.default_editorial: Tending to still-open wounds left by the Vietnam War, Minh Quý Trương’s transfixing and redolent film excavates spectral histories, once buried under the sands of time. Lighting up the darkest pits of the earth, coruscating touches between furtive lovers burn with the fieriness of queer passions.

items.title: Weekend
items.short_synopsis: On a Friday night after hanging out with his mates, Russell heads out to a nightclub, alone and on the pull. Just before closing, he meets Glen. And so begins a weekend—in bars and bedrooms, getting drunk and taking drugs, telling stories and having sex—that will resonate throughout their lives.
items.default_editorial: British filmmaker Andrew Haigh is a jewel: a uniquely measured dramatist profoundly concerned with the inner lives of his characters. We adore his breakout feature, taking place over a stretched-out weekend, for its tender, sensual and poignantly realized evocation of the bliss of falling in love.

items.title: Welcome to Chechnya
items.short_synopsis: This searing investigative work shadows a group of activists risking unimaginable peril to confront the ongoing anti-LGBTQ pogrom raging in the repressive and closed Russian republic.
items.default_editorial: Director David France (How to Survive a Plague) captures the work of LGBT+ activists in Russia in this urgent, award-winning documentary. Using deepfake technology to protect the subjects’ anonymity, Welcome to Chechnya remains, above all, a tender and empathic masterwork of political filmmaking.

items.title: Wendy and Lucy
items.short_synopsis: Wendy Carroll is driving to Ketchikan, Alaska, for a summer of lucrative work at the Northwestern Fish cannery—the start of a new life with her dog, Lucy. When her car breaks down in Oregon, the thin fabric of her financial situation comes apart, and she faces a series of dire economic decisions.
items.default_editorial: Arriving on the cusp of the Great Recession, Wendy and Lucy struck a nerve with its stylistically subdued but emotionally powerful look at how American society lets some of its citizens fall by the wayside. And in the title role, indie queen Michelle Williams earned every rave she got.

items.title: Western
items.short_synopsis: For generations, all that distinguished Eagle Pass, Texas, from Piedras Negras, Mexico, was the Rio Grande flowing between them. But when darkness descends upon these harmonious border towns, a cattleman and a town mayor face a new reality threatening their way of life.
items.default_editorial: Concluding an ‘Americana’ trilogy that includes 45365 and Tchoupitoulas, this poignant documentary by the Ross Brothers sounds a hymn to community spirit. With its quiet anatomization of border-town life amid rising violence, Western is an optimistic examination of cross-cultural collaboration.

items.title: Wildlife
items.short_synopsis: 14-year-old Joe is the only child of Jeanette and Jerry—a housewife and a golf pro living in a small town in ’60s Montana. Nearby, an uncontrolled forest fire rages, and when Jerry loses his job, he decides to join the cause of fighting it, leaving his wife and son to fend for themselves.
items.default_editorial: Discontent with mid-century domesticity, a couple flee its demands, throwing their son prematurely into the mess of adult affairs. Wildlife may be his first film as director and screenwriter, yet Paul Dano comes close to the heights of Greek tragedy in this tale of the nuclear family in crisis.

items.title: XXY
items.short_synopsis: The difficulties of adolescence are particularly strong for the 15-year-old Alex, who was born an intersex child.  As Alex begins to explore her sexuality, her mother invites friends from Buenos Aires to come for a visit at their house, with their 16-year-old son in tow…
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Grand Prize at Cannes Critics’ Week, Argentine filmmaker Lucía Puenzo made waves with her fearless debut. Illuminating the limits of the medical establishment, the vagaries of gender, and the uncertainties of belonging, XXY is a coming-of-age favorite among young queer audiences.

items.title: Yves Saint Laurent: The Last Collections
items.short_synopsis: As Yves Saint Laurent, one of the greatest Parisian haute couture designers, draws the sketches for his final collection, behind the scenes, Pierre Bergé manages a series of events to celebrate the fashion icon as a modern myth.
items.default_editorial: Banned for 20 years, this transfixing portrait of YSL comes to life doubling as a zombie film, capturing the thick atmosphere around the fashion myth and the intricacies of a relationship with Pierre Bergé where power, love and creative genius intersect. We bet PTA saw it when making Phantom Thread!

items.title: Zatôichi
items.short_synopsis: Older, wiser but still a wandering loner, the blind, peace-loving Ichi seeks a peaceful life in a rural village. When he’s caught in the middle of a power struggle between two rival Yakuza clans, his reputation as a defender of the innocent is put to the ultimate test in a series of showdowns.
items.default_editorial: After the long (26 film!) road of the Zatoichi series, which was later remade by Takeshi Kitano, it finally ended with this concluding entry directed by the blind swordsman himself: Shintarô Katsu. The dark shadows of regret, retribution, and redemption are cast over this tale of endings.

items.title: 8 Women
items.short_synopsis: In an isolated mansion in 1950s France, a family is gathered for the holiday season. But the patriarch is found murdered, and the killer can only be one of the eight women closest to him. The telephone line has been cut, the car won’t start, and a heavy snowfall keeps the women confined together.
items.default_editorial: Murder, French-style! François Ozon, a master of dark character studies like Swimming Pool, lightened up for this acclaimed musical comedy-mystery that’s every bit as delicious as it sounds. The cast—wall-to-wall French royalty—includes Catherine Deneuve, Isabelle Huppert, and Fanny Ardant!

items.title: Barking Dogs Never Bite
items.short_synopsis: Perturbed by the incessant yapping of a neighbor’s dog, the frazzled, out-of-work academic Yoon-ju resorts to drastic measures to quiet the canine, setting into motion a hilariously warped chain of events that turns a humble office worker into a crusading, puppy-saving avenger.
items.default_editorial: The mordantly funny social satire of Parasite was there right from the start in this feature debut from South Korean genre maestro Bong Joon Ho. A raucously unsentimental feast of dark ironies, Barking Dogs Never Bite takes its canine allegory—and puppy punishment—to wickedly farcical ends.

items.title: Boy
items.short_synopsis: New Zealand, 1984. Boy, a devout 11-year-old Michael Jackson fan, lives on a farm with his gran and brother, and dreams of his heroic absent father. One day his father reappears, eager to find a bag of money he buried before his arrest. Will his father live up to Boy’s lofty expectations?
items.default_editorial: Before Thor: Ragnarok and Jojo Rabbit, Oscar® winner Taika Waititi directed this big-hearted coming-of-age story. Set in his native New Zealand, the film became the country’s highest-grossing local production while gathering attention abroad for its charm and tender depiction of adolescence.

items.title: Breathless
items.short_synopsis: Petty thug Michel panics and impulsively kills a policeman while driving a stolen car. On the lam, he turns to his aspiring journalist girlfriend Patricia, hiding out in her Paris apartment. When she learns that Michel is being investigated for murder, Patricia begins to question her loyalty.
items.default_editorial: Everything is cinema! Godard’s impossibly cool debut revamps the thrills of the gangster film, like shootouts and police chases, with chic, anarchic, and ironic attitude. A hip, free-form tour through Paris, love, and film itself that announced there were no rules—and it was just the beginning.

items.title: Cold Tropics
items.short_synopsis: Strange climate change makes Recife, in the Northeast region of Brazil, a cold city. A foreign TV documentary examines the effects of change on an entire culture that has always lived in a hot climate.
items.default_editorial: This mockumentary short is full of inspired comic tangents, including a professional Santa Claus trying to find comfort in a newly chilly city of Brazil. Only growing in relevance today, Kleber Mendonça Filho’s inventive vision of adapting to climate disaster is dystopian yet delightfully witty.

items.title: Death Watch
items.short_synopsis: As the last days of terminally ill patients are showcased on the TV, Katherine tries to keep away from the media. She meets Roddy, unaware that a chip implanted in his brain is filming her every move.
items.default_editorial: French director Bertrand Tavernier (Coup de torchon) has never been afraid of changing genres or filming new adventures. In 1980 he went to Scotland with Romy Schneider, Harvey Keitel, Max von Sydow and Harry Dean Stanton to film this emotionally felt sci-fi with a creepily prescient concept.

items.title: Eletrodoméstica
items.short_synopsis: 1990s, post-urban Recife, without maracatu, with lots of buildings and traffic. A middle-class family, made up of a mother and her two children, lives in a house that is full of superfluous appliances capable of making a lot of noise.
items.default_editorial: Kleber Mendonça Filho’s arresting short carries the spirit of his later debut feature Neighboring Sounds: an apartment’s cacophonous noises lend this eccentric comedy a sinister air. Building to an unforgettable climax, this look at our symbiotic bonds with appliances is a hypnotizing treat.

items.title: Friday Night Saturday Morning
items.original_title: Noite de sexta, manhã de sábado
items.short_synopsis: After a party on Friday night, a man goes to a convenience store and calls a woman who is in another country. The two talk a lot and try to connect through the call, as if they were meeting.
items.default_editorial: Made before global use of smartphones skyrocketed, the charms of this look at long-distance relationships have gained a new resonance over time. A sketch of two people separated by thousands of miles trying to share in a tender moment, this compassionate short is a masterclass in creative editing.

items.title: Green Vinyl
items.short_synopsis: A mother and her daughter live in an apartment in Recife. The mother gives her daughter a box of old colored records with children’s music. She can listen to anything apart from the green vinyl. If she does, it will have tragic consequences.
items.default_editorial: Innocent sounds of birdsong signal a fresh chance for rule-breaking in this early, playfully spooky Kleber Mendonça Filho short. Spinning a fairytale of risky curiosity into a photo-roman of mischievous girlhood, the Brazilian filmmaker delights in tearing the dreariness of obedience limb from limb.

items.title: How I Learned to Overcome My Fear and Love Arik Sharon
items.original_title: Eich Hifsakti L'fahed V'lamadeti L'ehov et Arik Sharon
items.short_synopsis: As the elections approach, director Avi Mograbi sets out to make a documentary film about Israel’s most maligned politician, Arik Sharon. To his surprise, Mograbi discovers that Sharon is warm and friendly, and completely different from the man he thought him to be.
items.default_editorial: Known for his unwavering commitment to cultural and political justice in the Middle East, award-winning Israeli filmmaker Avi Mograbi turns his lens on infamous politician Arik Sharon. A satirical mockumentary-turned-melodrama that reveals the quixotic proximity nature of opposing political views.

items.title: La dolce vita
items.short_synopsis: Marcello Rubini is a playboy paparazzo who gallivants around the vibrant city of Rome. While Marcello contends with the overdose taken by his girlfriend, Emma, he also pursues heiress Maddalena and movie star Sylvia, embracing a carefree approach to living.
items.default_editorial: One of the most renowned masterpieces in all of cinema, La dolce vita stands beside Federico Fellini’s 8 1/2 as an immortal work of art. It’s a rousing yet sobering look at living the sweet life in ’60s Rome, as a culture of celebrity and glamour began to eat away at one founded on faith.

items.title: Mamma Roma
items.short_synopsis: In postwar Rome, Mamma is ready to give up her life as a sex worker and bring her son Ettore to live with her in the city. She moves to a respectable neighborhood, hoping that Ettore will go to school, get a good job, and marry. But Ettore is lazy, taking for granted the gains his mother provides.
items.default_editorial: A towering avatar for the downtrodden, Anna Magnani is heartbreaking as a sex worker struggling to reinvent herself in Pier Paolo Pasolini’s sophomore feature. Charting the changing cityscape of postwar Rome, where luxury homes mushroom next to slums, Mamma Roma is a powerful cry against inequality.

items.title: Nightcrawler
items.short_synopsis: A disturbed loner, living on the fringe of society, muscles his way into the lucrative underworld of tabloid crime journalism. Scouring the city for crimes of a shocking nature, he is aided by a veteran news director looking to raise station ratings.
items.default_editorial: Jake Gyllenhaal gives one of his best performances as the sociopathic embodiment of journalistic amorality in Dan Gilroy’s Oscar®-nominated neo-noir. Magnificently shot by longstanding Paul Thomas Anderson collaborator Robert Elswit, Nightcrawler is a sizzling satire of the vampiric media machine.

items.title: No Fear, No Die
items.short_synopsis: Dah from Benin and Jocelyn from the Caribbean make money through illegal cockfighting. But Pierre, the owner of the restaurant where the fights take place, pushes them to make the events more violent, and the disillusioned Jocelyn begins looking for a way out from the sordid dealings.
items.default_editorial: In her overlooked sophomore feature, Claire Denis fearlessly explores émigré life in Paris, working for the first time with frequent collaborator Alex Descas. A contemporary noir, No Fear, No Die also draws direct inspiration from the writing of Martiniquan postcolonial theorist Frantz Fanon.

items.title: Rashômon
items.short_synopsis: In 11th-century Japan, a samurai is found dead. Four conflicting accounts are given by a woodcutter, a bandit, the samurai’s wife, and the samurai’s spirit, summoned by a medium. Each tells a different version of the crime—but is anyone telling the truth?
items.default_editorial: Winner of the 1951 Golden Lion at Venice, Rashômon was the film that introduced Akira Kurosawa—and Japanese cinema itself—to international audiences. With its unreliable narrators offering different perspectives on the same event, this feudal allegory’s approach to storytelling was revolutionary.

items.title: Shaun of the Dead
items.short_synopsis: At nearly 30, Shaun drifts through life between his friends, his flat, and the local pub, leaving little space for his girlfriend Liz. When Liz breaks up with him, he resolves to put his life back on track—just as a zombie outbreak turns London into chaos.
items.default_editorial: Ingenious auteur Edgar Wright and his charming company of actors premiered their talents on the big screen with this lovingly grotesque tribute to Romero’s zombie cinema. Delivering pure comedy and ecstatic gore in equal measure, Shaun of the Dead endures as a timeless cocktail of genre filmmaking.

items.title: The 10th Victim
items.short_synopsis: In a futuristic world, the Big Hunt is a large-scale game pitting assassins against each other. The prize for surviving 10 rounds? A million dollars. When renowned shooters Marcello and Caroline are selected for a showdown, their will to win is suddenly replaced by another kind of desire.
items.default_editorial: Far ahead of Battle Royale, Elio Petri’s dystopian sci-fi satire of social bloodlust playfully twists genre expectations. Amidst one of the most striking retro-futurist set designs in 1960s Italian cinema, the cat-and-mouse games between Marcello Mastroianni and Ursula Andress are dangerously sexy.

items.title: The Blue Angel
items.short_synopsis: Respected schoolteacher Rath learns of his pupils’ infatuation with postcards depicting a nightclub songstress. To investigate the source of indecency, Rath goes to the Blue Angel nightclub and is fatefully seduced by the smoldering Lola-Lola, triggering the downward spiral of his life and fortune.
items.default_editorial: With their seven film partnership, Josef von Sternberg and Marlene Dietrich traced a path of lush, scandalous romantic fantasies, of which The Blue Angel was their first. A masterpiece of relationship masochism, The Last Laugh’s Emil Jannings wilts before Dietrich, in her career-making role.

items.title: The City of Lost Children
items.short_synopsis: Krank is a deranged scientist who kidnaps children and steals their dreams in an attempt to reverse his aging process. When Krank’s henchmen kidnap his brother, fisherman and former circus strongman One sets out on a journey to Krank’s laboratory, accompanied by a little orphan girl called Miette.
items.default_editorial: The pinnacle of Jeunet and Caro’s grunge fantasias of the 1990s, The City of Lost Children has all the dark whimsy of dreams and fairy tales gone awry—a far cry from the movies made by Jeunet once the duo separated. A touchstone of cinematic imagination before modern CGI smoothed out the wrinkles.

items.title: The Discreet Charm of the Bourgeoisie
items.original_title: Le charme discret de la bourgeoisie
items.short_synopsis: Six upper-class people sit down to a dinner that is continually delayed, their attempts to eat thwarted by events both real and imagined, from terrorist attacks to ghostly apparitions. In their quest for a lavish feast, the line between reality and dreams becomes unclear, and all hell breaks loose.
items.default_editorial: What secrets lurk inside a group of wealthy sophisticates who only want a nice, pleasant dinner party? Luis Buñuel’s Oscar®-winning classic is one of his signature films: a fiendishly witty comedy bouncing through reality, dreams, faith, sex, and revolution with the lightest and cheekiest touch.

items.title: The Driver
items.short_synopsis: An enigmatic man of fast cars and few words, the Driver excels at manoeuvring getaway cars, making him quite in demand in criminal circles. His notoriety infuriates the Detective, who becomes obsessed with taking him down. Luckily the Player, a resourceful woman, helps him elude the Detective.
items.default_editorial: Ryan O’Neal and Bruce Dern play fierce enemies in this crime thriller by Walter Hill (The Warriors ), also starring Isabelle Adjani. A critical and box-office flop on its release, the film has now gathered cult status and went on to influence modern classics such as Pulp Fiction and Drive!

items.title: The King and the Mockingbird
items.short_synopsis: A pompous king is in love with a shepherdess in a painting. The two-dimensional beauty, however, desires the dashing young chimney sweep in the frame next door. The two seek to escape the dastardly clutches of the tyrant with the help of a brightly feathered mockingbird.
items.default_editorial: A triumph of color animation, this is a delightful fable for both children and adults. With Japanese director Hayao Miyazaki (The Wind Rises, Spirited Away) citing it as a major influence, and co-scripted by French poet Jacques Prévert, The King and the Mockingbird is a work of pure poetry.

items.title: The Piano
items.short_synopsis: When an arranged marriage brings Ada, a mute woman, and her daughter to 19th-century New Zealand, her controlling husband refuses to transport her most prized possession: a piano. A rugged frontiersman agrees to bring it home in exchange for private lessons. A forbidden attraction begins to grow…
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Palme d’Or at the 1993 Cannes Film Festival, Jane Campion’s masterwork concerns a woman’s fortitude in a forced marriage. Uniting two of the finest actors of the era—Harvey Keitel and Holly Hunter—The Piano is a sensuous vision of unlikely romance amid an unforgiving landscape.

items.title: The Prize of Peril
items.short_synopsis: In a near future obsessed with violent entertainment, a hit television game show offers contestants a million dollars if they can survive being hunted by five pursuers through the city. No one has ever won, but unemployed François Jacquemard decides to take the risk in hopes of changing his life.
items.default_editorial: The sadistic urges of popular entertainment turn deadly in Yves Boisset’s muscular reality-television thriller. Based on an astonishingly prescient Robert Sheckley short story, this mean and lean satire plays dystopian cat-and-mouse among the stark concrete modernism of the Eastern Bloc.

items.title: The Secret of Kells
items.short_synopsis: In the Irish woods, Cellach prepares for an attack by the Vikings. Meanwhile, his nephew Brendan works secretly as an apprentice in the monastery, learning the ancient art of calligraphy. As the Vikings near, a revered illuminator recruits Brendan to complete a series of dangerous, magical tasks.
items.default_editorial: Telling the tale of the creation of the Book of Kells—a manuscript created in medieval Ireland—this acclaimed animation draws from Irish history, Celtic mythology, and the book’s illustrations to enchanting and enlightening effect. For adults and children alike, and featuring Brendan Gleeson!

items.title: The Secret of the Grain
items.short_synopsis: When Slimane Beiji, a divorced man in his sixties of Algerian origin, loses his job, he sets out to open a restaurant on a derelict boat in Sète. Hoping to leave a legacy for his patchwork family, he draws them into the fragile venture, soon facing sceptical resistance from the local bureaucracy.
items.default_editorial: Winner of five awards in Venice including the Special Jury Prize, this ambitious domestic epic underlines the importance of food in cross-cultural encounters. Aided by Abdellatif Kechiche’s signature naturalistic dialogue, The Secret of the Grain is a multi-layered portrait of an immigrant family.

items.title: The Straight Story
items.short_synopsis: In his 70s, retired farmer Alvin Straight discovers his brother, Lyle, is critically ill. Stuck without a car or license in Iowa, he decides on a unique odyssey—traveling to Wisconsin on his old lawnmower. His journey is both picturesque and deeply spiritual.
items.default_editorial: Alvin Straight’s true journey through the American midwest on a lawnmower to see his brother was revisited by David Lynch in this compassionate, spiritual road movie, simple yet epic in its honesty and grace. An ode to family and country folk, carried by Richard Farnsworth’s sublime performance.

items.title: The Taste of Others
items.short_synopsis: Castella, a business executive with little interest in culture, falls in love one evening with “Bérénice”—a play he reluctantly attends—and with its leading actress, Clara. Determined to win her over, he awkwardly attempts to enter the artistic and intellectual circle that surrounds her.
items.default_editorial: Acting alongside Jean-Pierre Bacri, who also cowrote the script, Agnès Jaoui skilfully dissects dissatisfaction with French provincial life in her charming and erudite directorial debut. Like hamsters bouncing on a wheel, lovelorn souls chase after the mirage of contentment to tragicomic ends.

items.title: Tie Me Up! Tie Me Down!
items.short_synopsis: Fresh out of a mental institution, Ricky seeks love with the love of his life, B-movie actress Marina. Facing her amnesia, Ricky takes extreme measures—tying her up to rekindle their past. With a captive audience, Ricky is sure it’s only a matter of time before his beloved returns his affections.
items.default_editorial: Hot off the major success of Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown, Almodóvar soon switched gears, taking his twist-filled melodramatic style into more dangerous territory for what is arguably the darkest romcom ever made. Not for another two decades would he get this kinky again. Viva Pedro!

items.title: 5x2
items.short_synopsis: Gilles and Marion, a young French couple, separate. Told in reverse, the story traces five key moments of their relationship: their divorce, a strained dinner with friends, the birth of their child, their wedding, and their first meeting.
items.default_editorial: By distilling the essential fragments of a relationship and putting them side by side, François Ozon delivers a chronicle presenting the destructive and cruel effects that time can have on our most noble feelings. A heartfelt observation of a couple’s odyssey, simultaneously unique and universal.

items.title: A Bigger Splash
items.short_synopsis: A high-profile couple—famous rock star Marianne Lane and filmmaker Paul—are holidaying on the picturesque secluded Italian island of Pantelleria. But their tranquil retreat is interrupted by the arrival of an old friend and charismatic music producer, Harry, and his daughter, Penelope.
items.default_editorial: A reworking of Jacques Deray’s La Piscine, this sun-scorched, suspenseful thriller from Luca Guadagnino (Queer) assembles a star-studded central quartet—Tilda Swinton, Dakota Johnson, Matthias Schoenaerts, and Ralph Fiennes—and lets sparks fly. An alluring, luscious adult drama.

items.title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night
items.original_title: A Girl Walks Home Alone at Night
items.short_synopsis: In the shadows of Bad City–a lawless hellhole, inhabited by underworld figures, drug users, and pimps–a lonesome vampire wanders around. Dressed in a hijab and a striped t-shirt, she follows local villagers. One night she meets Arash, an Iranian James Dean lookalike. There is an instant attraction.
items.default_editorial: Let the intriguing title lure you into the mysterious world of this modern, feminist take on the vampire film. Set in Iran and shot in crisp black-and-white, this invigorating debut is a reappropriation of a genre usually known for undermining women as the ultimate victims. No more, time’s up!

items.title: A Woman Is a Woman
items.short_synopsis: Exotic dancer Angela attempts to have a child with her unwilling lover Emile. But Alfred, Emile’s best friend who is in love with Angela, is happy to be a father. Angela loves Emile and refuses Alfred’s advances, but leads Emile to believe that she is infatuated with his friend.
items.default_editorial: Godard’s radical “neorealist musical” is one of the most iconic films of the French New Wave. Re-inventing Hollywood’s aging genre, it is full of fourth-wall-breaking playfulness, Eastmancolor Parisian streets, Legrand’s lush score, and the sparkling presence of Belmondo, Brialy, and Anna Karina.

items.title: All We Imagine as Light
items.short_synopsis: In Mumbai, Nurse Prabha’s routine is troubled when she receives an unexpected gift from her estranged husband. Her younger roommate, Anu, tries in vain to find a spot in the city to be intimate with her boyfriend. A trip to a beach town allows them to find a space for their desires to manifest.
items.default_editorial: Bathed in luminous shades of blue, Payal Kapadia’s Cannes prizewinner conjures an oasis of warmth amid the hustle and bustle of Mumbai. Making space for tenderness in an unforgiving society, this soulful portrait of female friendship and resilience swells with the sensuous poetry of everyday life.

items.title: Another Round
items.short_synopsis: Four friends, all high school teachers at various stages of middle age, are stuck in a rut. Unable to share their passions either at school or at home, they embark on an audacious experiment: to see if a constant level of alcohol in their blood will help them find greater freedom and happiness.
items.default_editorial: We’re raising a glass to Mads Mikkelsen, an electric presence in this booze-sodden, Oscar®-winning ode to male friendship from Danish provocateur Thomas Vinterberg. A philosophical hymn to the joys—and regrets—of middle-age misbehaviour, Another Round is an existential comedy of bad manners. Skål!

items.title: Apocalypse Now
items.short_synopsis: Vietnam, 1970. Captain Willard takes a journey upriver to assassinate Colonel Kurtz, a once-promising officer who has gone completely mad. In the company of a Navy patrol boat filled with street-smart kids, an Air Cavalry officer, and a freelance photographer, Willard ventures into enemy territory.
items.default_editorial: “My film is not about Vietnam. It is Vietnam,” said Francis Ford Coppola of his visionary, Palme d’Or-winning adaptation of Heart of Darkness. With a mythic, truly unforgettable appearance by Marlon Brando, Apocalypse Now traces a visceral descent into madness to comment on the folly of war.

items.title: Bicycle Thieves
items.short_synopsis: Unemployed Antonio is elated when he finally finds work hanging posters around war-torn Rome. However on his first day, his bicycle—essential to his work—gets stolen. His job is doomed unless he can find the thief. With the help of his son, Antonio combs the city, becoming desperate for justice.
items.default_editorial: One of the most legendary films of all time, Vittorio De Sica’s Oscar®-winning classic not only defines the Italian neorealist movement but also transcends time and space. Powered by the boundlessness of paternal love, Bicycle Thieves sees the sublime amid the mundanity of ordinary everyday life.

items.title: Black Bear
items.short_synopsis: At a remote lake house, filmmaker Allison arrives as a house guest to a troubled couple, who have eschewed their life in the city. Battling writer’s block, Allison sparks a calculated game of desire and jealousy in pursuit of a new work that blurs the boundaries of autobiography and invention.
items.default_editorial: Reaching new heights of structural ingenuity, this mind-boggling meta-comedy is an explosive affair. In one of her best performances, Aubrey Plaza is spellbinding alongside Christopher Abbott in a dark reflection on indie filmmaking, toxic relationships and power dynamics: so tense but so thrilling.

items.title: Black Robe
items.short_synopsis: In 1634 Quebec, a Jesuit priest and his young companion journey through the wilderness with Algonquin guides to reach a remote mission. But as they attempt the arduous 1,500 mile trek upriver, the testing elements and the ever-present shadow of death are never far behind.
items.default_editorial: Long before Martin Scorsese made Silence, Bruce Beresford delivered one of his finest films: a harrowing, Conradian renunciation of the Christian missionary project. Exquisitely photographed on location in French Canada, Black Robe journeys into the heart of darkness for the ultimate test of faith.

items.title: Breaker Morant
items.short_synopsis: At the turn of the twentieth century, three Australian officers are court-martialed for alleged war crimes. With no time to prepare, an Australian major, appointed as defense attorney, must prove that they were just following orders and are being turned into political pawns.
items.default_editorial: One of the most acclaimed Australian films—including an Oscar® nod for its script—Bruce Beresford’s Breaker Morant remains a gripping anti-war classic, a subtle retooling of Paths of Glory shot through with political passion, outstanding performances, and golden hour photography.

items.title: Celia
items.short_synopsis: An imaginative and somewhat disturbed young girl fantasizes about evil creatures and other oddities to mask her insecurities while growing up in rural Australia.
items.default_editorial: Taking deadly aim at sentimental depictions of childhood, this distinctive debut from underrated Australian auteur Ann Turner explores the shadowy corners of a child’s world. Linking 1950s anticommunism and a plague of rabbits, Celia finds youthful rebellion in dark fantasy and eerie ritual.

items.title: Contempt
items.short_synopsis: Paul Javal is hired to write a script for a new film version of Homer’s ’The Odyssey’. But the screenwriter soon finds himself torn between the demands of a proud European director, a crude and arrogant American producer, and Camille, his disillusioned wife.
items.default_editorial: An iconic, pop-colored exposé of the film industry as only Godard can do. 1960s stars Michel Piccoli and Brigitte Bardot fight and make love during a Fritz Lang (playing himself!) production of the Odyssey at Italy’s famed Cinecittà studios, scored to the most beautiful film music of all time.

items.title: Damage
items.short_synopsis: Stephen Fleming, a conservative MP, is married to Ingrid, with whom he has two children: Martyn, a brilliant political reporter, and Sally, a bright, curious teenager. However, his political career crumbles when he becomes obsessed with his son’s lover, Anna, with whom he begins a passionate affair.
items.default_editorial: Airs and graces are a thin veil over sexual deviance in this erotic drama, as young Juliette Binoche and a wolfish Jeremy Irons set the screen on fire. One of the final films from the great Louis Malle, this delectable tale of forbidden desire cuts to the incestuous heart of Britain’s upper classes.

items.title: Dementia 13
items.short_synopsis: After John Haloran dies, his wife Louise realizes she won’t inherit anything once Lady Haloran passes. To secure her share, she fakes a letter from John, claiming he’s away on business, and travels to the family estate in Ireland. Her plan to ingratiate herself into the family quick unravels.
items.default_editorial: Produced under the tutelage of Roger Corman, this eerie 1963 B-movie is the schlocky debut of none other than Francis Ford Coppola! A low-budget Gothic horror about family and entrapment, which wears the influence of Bava and Hitchcock, Dementia 13 shows what would become his trademark obsessions.

items.title: Don's Party
items.short_synopsis: When you mix a left-wing teacher, a loud-mouthed sex maniac, a mild-mannered accountant, a failed philosopher, a promiscuous nineteen year old nymphette, a frustrated wife, a drunken pornographer, a sexy temperamental artist, and an arrogant dentist with a lot of booze, anything can happen!
items.default_editorial: Tempers flare and friskiness teems amid the cocktail sausages and tinnies in this razor-toothed comedy of manners.
