Set on the eve of the 1969 election, Don’s Party sets up a shooting range of satirical targets, exuberantly skewering champagne socialism, the male libido, and the Australian dream.

items.title: Driving Miss Daisy
items.short_synopsis: Elderly Jewish widow Daisy is determined to maintain her independence. But when she crashes her car, her son arranges for her to have a chauffeur, an African-American man named Hoke. Daisy and Hoke’s relationship gets off to a rocky start, but they gradually form a close friendship over the years.
items.default_editorial: Based on the Pulitzer prize-winning play, this tale of a hard-won friendship between an elderly Jewish woman and her African-American driver was lauded for addressing racism, injustice and prejudice while conveying a message of tolerance. The film nabbed 4 Oscars, including Best Picture!

items.title: Escape from New York
items.short_synopsis: In the not-so-distant future of 1997, crime levels have exploded and Manhattan has been transformed into an anarchic maximum-security prison. When an Air Force One is hijacked and the president is stranded on the island, only special-forces soldier turned mercenary Snake Plissken can save him.
items.default_editorial: John Carpenter’s cult classic epic plunges his muse Kurt Russell into an expressionist New York seemingly stuck in eternal night. The iconic presences of Lee Van Cleef and Ernest Borgnine, combined with peerless widescreen camerawork, shape this into a neo-western with an anti-authoritarian edge.

items.title: Flow
items.short_synopsis: Cat is a solitary animal, but as his home is devastated by a great flood, he finds refuge on a boat populated by various species, and will have to team up with them despite their differences.
items.default_editorial: Following an intrepid cat on a heart-stopping journey through an animated world of wonder and peril, Gints Zilbalodis’s Oscar®-winner is a moving ode to friendship. With delightfully expressive animal characters, stunning visuals, and immersive sound design, Flow captures nature in all its majesty.

items.title: Hearts of Darkness: A Filmmaker's Apocalypse
items.original_title: Hearts of Darkness: A Filmmaker's Apocalypse
items.short_synopsis: This film documents the sensational events that unfolded during the making of Francis Ford Coppola’s Apocalypse Now. Featuring Eleanor Coppola’s footage of the Philippines production, the film details the director’s self-financed, chaotic creation, teetering on the brink of complete collapse.
items.default_editorial: Count it alongside Burden of Dreams as one of the best documentaries about a disastrous production! This riveting window into the chaos behind Coppola’s war epic—coupled with footage shot by his wife, Eleanor—proves that a “making-of” story can be every bit as extraordinary as the film itself.

items.title: Hereditary
items.short_synopsis: When Ellen, the matriarch of the Graham family, passes away, her daughter’s family begins to unravel cryptic and increasingly terrifying secrets about their ancestry. The more they discover, the more they find themselves trying to outrun the sinister fate they seem to have inherited.
items.default_editorial: A leading contender for the scariest film of the century so far, Hereditary made a global splash following its Sundance debut. First features rarely come as precociously assured, and while shock tactics abound, they’re wholly in service of a troubling study in grief and unreconciled family trauma.

items.title: I Am Love
items.short_synopsis: Among the upper classes in turn-of-the-millennium Milan, ailing patriarch Edoardo Sr passes the family business over to his son Tancredi and grandson Edoardo Jr. Tensions soon begin to show beneath the family’s controlled veneer as Tancredi’s wife, Russian-born Emma, succumbs to an illicit affair.
items.default_editorial: Dazzling the senses, I Am Love revives the lavish, elegant, emotionally expressive style of classic ’50s melodramas and proves their timeless vitality. It also confirms Tilda Swinton—who learned both Italian and Russian for the role(!)—as one of the best, most unpredictable actors.

items.title: Lebanon
items.short_synopsis: June 6, 1982. Israeli armed forces enter Lebanon in the First Lebanon War. How is the event seen by four Israeli recruits reduced to the extremely limited perspective of a tank’s peephole? The 20-year-olds are dispatched to search a hostile town—a simple mission that turns into a nightmare.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Golden Lion and described as “Das Boot in a tank,” this gripping, claustrophobic, ingenious war film sprung from the writer/director’s own experiences in the Lebanon War. Few films put the audience so squarely, so viscerally, so unforgettably in the center of the action.

items.title: Like Father, Like Son
items.short_synopsis: One day, Ryota and his wife get an unexpected phone call from the hospital. Keita, the six-year-old boy they have raised, is not their son. The news is hard to take for stern businessman Ryota. He meets his actual child, Ryusei, who has been brought up in a poorer, but more loving environment.
items.default_editorial: Inspired by real-life instances in the late 1960s of Japanese babies being switched at birth, this heartrending meditation on parenthood took the Jury Prize at Cannes. One of Hirokazu Koreeda’s most personal films, Like Father, Like Son is a sublime study in redemption and familial responsibility.

items.title: Love Rites
items.short_synopsis: Vain clothing buyer Hugo meets beautiful Myriam on the subway and pursues her, discovering to his delight that she’s a sex worker. The crafty Myriam, of course, has more in mind for their encounter than smug Hugo bargained for.
items.default_editorial: Walerian Borowczyk’s final film is relatively more sexually restrained than the dizzyingly pink heights of his late 60s and 70s cinema. Had he mellowed with age? Nonetheless, Boro’s adaptation of André Pieyre de Mandiargues’s novel still plunges into contemporary sexual mores with gleeful abandon.

items.title: Nowhere
items.short_synopsis: Follows a day in the lives of a group of Los Angeles high school students and the strange lives they lead.
items.default_editorial: A time capsule of underground mayhem in ‘90s Los Angeles, Nowhere has irreverent, iconoclastic fun with the world of messed-up teenagedom. Space lizards wield guns, Elvis gets kinky, and gangsters wear glitter in a riot of end-of-days delirium, drenched in Gregg Araki’s signature fashion and flair.

items.title: Our Little Sister
items.short_synopsis: Three sisters live together in Kamakura. When their father—absent for 15 years—dies, they travel to the countryside for his funeral and meet their teenage half-sister. Bonding quickly with the orphaned Suzu, they invite her to live with them and a new life of joyful discovery begins for them.
items.default_editorial: From the prolific writer-director of the Palme d’Or-winning Shoplifters comes this tender family drama in the vein of Yasujirō Ozu or Mikio Naruse. Hirokazu Koreeda wisely assembles a series of vignettes of everyday moments to explore sisterly relationships and the deep bonds between families.

items.title: Please, Please Me
items.short_synopsis: Ariane is convinced that her husband Jean-Jacques is interested in another woman. To save her marriage, she asks him to have an affair with this woman, believing this is the best way to get rid of Jean-Jacques’s fantasies.
items.default_editorial: Emmanuel Mouret writes, directs, and stars in this hilarious and impish romantic comedy. Please, Please Me moves effortlessly from one madcap scene to the next, lying somewhere on the scale between the physical comedy of Jacques Tati & Buster Keaton and the witty banter of Éric Rohmer.

items.title: Prince of Darkness
items.short_synopsis: In the basement of an abandoned church lies a bottle of green liquid being investigated by local physics students. But as the night draws in, the students soon realise that the relic holds a dark force beyond their control that could well be the essence of pure evil: the remains of Satan himself.
items.default_editorial: Iconic horror director John Carpenter’s Prince of Darkness is partly terrifying and partly goofy: a wondrously low-budget ‘80s affair. Physics, theology, and the devil’s green slime go in the stew for this second part of the filmmaker’s “Apocalypse” trilogy. Oh, and there’s an Alice Cooper cameo.

items.title: Puberty Blues
items.short_synopsis: In 1970s Sydney, two teenage girls who have desperately trying to break into the “in” crowd who dominate the Greenhill beach. Once they are accepted into the group, they realise that the group’s laid-back, ultra-cool facade is just that: a glossy cover-up.
items.default_editorial: Director Bruce Beresford gives the California teen movie a singularly Australian spin with this spirited coming-of-age time capsule. Casting a warm, nonjudgmental eye on its hormonally propelled protagonists, Puberty Blues plots a decidedly feminist path through the crushes and hang-ups of youth.

items.title: Shoplifters
items.short_synopsis: On the margins of Tokyo, a family is united by fierce loyalty and a penchant for petty theft. One day the father and son meet an abandoned little girl, and, despite their poverty, the family takes her in. But an incident will expose their secrets that upend their tenuous, below-the-radar existence.
items.default_editorial: Japanese maestro Hirokazu Koreeda took the Palme d’Or at Cannes for this heart-wrenching drama about a family living on the margins of society. Told with peerless humanity and compassion, Koreeda’s intimate and engrossing masterwork is a quietly devastating indictment of Japan’s class divide.

items.title: Summer of 85
items.short_synopsis: After capsizing his friend’s boat in a storm, teenager Alexis is rescued by the charismatic David, then seduced by his irresistible charm. A tumultuous love affair occurs between the two, but how long will this dreamy relationship last? Will the dream last for more than one summer, the summer of 85?
items.default_editorial: A ravishing 1980s time capsule, François Ozon’s queer romance whisks us off to the French coast where the sun shines bright and earworms from The Cure and Bananarama are on at full blast. Like the changing ocean tides, the wistful fleetingness of youth only intensifies the passions of first love.

items.title: Swimming Pool
items.short_synopsis: A British author suffering from a writing block seeks inspiration and solitude at her publisher’s house in the South of France. When his daughter unexpectedly appears, her reckless, erotic lifestyle disrupts the author’s quietude. Their tumultuous interactions set off a series of disturbing events.
items.default_editorial: A repressed novelist gets more than she bargained for on a writer’s retreat to the French countryside in this sizzling erotic thriller by François Ozon. Starring Charlotte Rampling and Ludivine Sagnier as the adversarial femme fatale, Swimming Pool is a Hitchcockian mystery with a twist to die for.

items.title: The Doom Generation
items.short_synopsis: Amy Blue (Rose McGowan) is wallowing in a boring relationship with her high school sweetheart Jordan White (James Duval) when white-hot drifter Xavier Red (Johnathon Schaech) literally lands on their car and climbs aboard.
items.default_editorial: Soundtracked to shoegaze, industrial music, and noise rock, this Gregg Araki’s cult classic gives an edgy makeover to the ultraviolent road movies of the ’90s, looking like the weird younger sibling of True Romance and Natural Born Killers. America has rarely looked so twisted—or so damn cool.

items.title: The Fog
items.short_synopsis: As a small California town nears its centenary, eerie events unfold: objects animate, Rev. Malone uncovers a town secret, announcer Stevie sees a mystic fire, and Elizabeth finds a mutilated fisherman. A luminous fog envelops the town, bringing death in its wake.
items.default_editorial: After the unexpected success of Halloween, cult auteur John Carpenter kicked off the ‘80s with The Fog. This spooky-silly California ghost tale is transformed by Carpenter’s anamorphic widescreen images into something densely ethereal and rich in macabre atmosphere.

items.title: The Getting of Wisdom
items.short_synopsis: At a strict Melbourne finishing school in the late Victorian era, country girl Laura Tweedle Rambotham struggles against rigid expectations. Imaginative and defiant, she navigates friendship, rivalry, and heartbreak while refusing to conform to the model of a proper young lady.
items.default_editorial: A passion project for Bruce Beresford, this spirited boarding-school drama shares some DNA with the seminal Picnic at Hanging Rock. With a wilful lead performance from Susannah Fowle as the young ward receiving her sentimental education, The Getting of Wisdom is a New Wave coming-of-age classic.

items.title: The Graduate
items.short_synopsis: Recent college graduate Ben Braddock returns to his parents’ California home and stumbles through a haze of indecision as he navigates life in the real world. He starts an unexpected sexual relationship with the much older wife of his father’s business partner, only to fall for her daughter as well.
items.default_editorial: A true classic that still feels as fresh as ever, Mike Nichols’s prototypical coming-of-age drama pinpoints the desires and angst of a new generation about to enter adulthood. Dustin Hoffman and Anne Bancroft bring it to life, merging with their indelible characters to create new cinematic icons.

items.title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
items.original_title: The Killing of a Sacred Deer
items.short_synopsis: Steven, an eminent cardiothoracic surgeon, presides over a spotless household with his ophthalmologist wife, Anna, and two exemplary children. Their lives take a dark turn when Martin—a fatherless teen Steven has quietly taken under his wing—starts insinuating himself into the family’s life.
items.default_editorial: It was only a matter of time before Yorgos Lanthimos tipped the caustic ironies of Dogtooth into full-blown horror. Starring Colin Farrell and Nicole Kidman, The Killing of a Sacred Deer transposes the myth of Iphigenia from ancient Greece to modern America for a devilishly deadpan tale of revenge.

items.title: The Love Witch
items.short_synopsis: Elaine, a beautiful young witch, is determined to find a man to love her. In her gothic Victorian apartment she makes spells and potions, and then picks up men and seduces them. However, her spells work too well, leaving her with a string of hapless victims.
items.default_editorial: At once a vibrant pastiche of 1960s horror and a contemporary corrective to the era’s—and the genre’s—sexual politics, The Love Witch is, at heart, a warm look at loneliness and love. Written, directed, and scored by Anna Biller, this vivid ode to cult Technicolor treasures is simply magical.

items.title: The Lovers on the Bridge
items.short_synopsis: On an under-construction Pont Neuf, Paris’s oldest bridge, a hard-drinking street performer and a post-relationship young painter with failing eyesight live as vagrants. As her vision deteriorates, she becomes increasingly dependent on him, and they manage to fall in love amid their daily strife.
items.default_editorial: It doesn’t get better than this! Léos Carax, France’s arthouse enfant terrible, courted controversy and budget overruns for this delirious, tragic romance of the down-and-out starring a glorious Juliette Binoche. Panned at the time, it’s emerged as one of the last great movies of the 20th century.

items.title: The Outsiders
items.short_synopsis: A teen gang, the Greasers, are perpetually at odds with the Socials, a rival group. When Greasers Ponyboy and Johnny get into a brawl that ends in the death of a Social member, the boys are forced to go into hiding. Soon Ponyboy and Johnny must contend with the consequences of their violent lives.
items.default_editorial: Based on S.E. Hinton’s iconic novel, Francis Ford Coppola’s humorous and often tender adaptation is a material detour for one of Hollywood’s masters. Fueled by an all-star cast—including Tom Cruise, Patrick Swayze, and Matt Dillon—The Outsiders is an underappreciated tale of juvenile delinquency.

items.title: The Secret in Their Eyes
items.short_synopsis: Hoping to put to rest years of unease concerning a past case, retired criminal investigator Benjamín begins writing a novel based on the unsolved mystery of a newlywed’s rape and murder. With the help of a former colleague, judge Irene, he attempts to make sense of the past.
items.default_editorial: At once a love story, a revenge epic, and a mystery of political intrigue, this excellent thriller from Argentina won 2009’s Best Foreign Film Academy Award® (in a crowded year!) and has become one of Latin American cinema’s most popular exports.

items.title: The Taste of Things
items.short_synopsis: Esteemed cook Eugenie and gourmet Dodin have worked together for 20 years. As their bond deepens into romance, they create dishes that impress even the world’s top chefs. Faced with Eugenie’s reluctance to commit, Dodin decides to cook for her, hoping to win her heart.
items.default_editorial: Starring Juliette Binoche and Benoît Magimel as 1880s gourmands, this sensuous film is aromatic with romance and bathed in buttery luminosity. Adding the delights of cooking to the pleasures of cinema in a delectable mélange, Trần Anh Hùng won Best Director at Cannes for this belle époque treat.

items.title: They Live
items.short_synopsis: Nada, a streetwise drifter, makes a shocking discovery when he finds a pair of special sunglasses that make him see the world for what it really is: aliens disguised as humans are indoctrinating the public with subliminal messages. With the truth now visible, Nada decides to expose the conspiracy.
items.default_editorial: Plunge into the nightmarish vision of the codes, signs and demons of capitalism with John Carpenter’s iconic, visionary dystopia They Live. A message of warning against Reagan politics and overpowering media lies at the core of this Los Angeles thriller—one that feels particularly timely today.

items.title: Thunder Road
items.short_synopsis: After he delivers a disastrous eulogy at his mother’s funeral, grieving police officer Jim Arnaud is ordered by his captain to take compassionate leave. Jim vows to use this time to become a better father to his daughter, Crystal, but soon discovers his ex, Rosalind, wants full custody of her.
items.default_editorial: Director Jim Cummings turns the figure of the virile cop upside down to present his evocative debut film: an indie portrait of masculinity in crisis through the prism of grief and parenthood. At once touching and unpredictable, Thunder Road is a welcome oddity that does not shy away from sentiment.

items.title: Under the Silver Lake
items.short_synopsis: One night, aimless slacker Sam finds a mysterious woman swimming in his apartment’s pool. But when she disappeared without a trace in the morning, Sam embarks on a quest across L.A. to find her, and along the way, uncovers a bizarre conspiracy in the Hollywood Hills.
items.default_editorial: From the dazzling imagination that brought you It Follows comes a feverish neo-noir starring Andrew Garfield! An epic, code-cracking, acid-spiked amateur sleuth story that tips its hat to Hitchcock, Lynch, Carpenter, and everything in between, while using the city of Los Angeles as its playground.

items.title: Youth
items.short_synopsis: Septuagenarian friends film director Mick and retired composer Fred are holidaying at a luxury resort in the Alps. While Mick scrambles to finish the script for what might be his last important film, Fred has no intention of working again. But a request from a well-known figure makes him reconsider.
items.default_editorial: After his arthouse success The Great Beauty, Italian director Paolo Sorrentino assembled a stellar cast to explore aging and the tyranny of beauty. Michael Caine, Harvey Keitel, Rachel Weisz, and Paul Dano star in this aesthetically impeccable, languid chamber-spa drama. With a Jane Fonda cameo!

items.title: A E I O U: A Quick Alphabet of Love
items.original_title: A E I O U - Das schnelle Alphabet der Liebe
items.short_synopsis: Anna, an out-of-work actress in Berlin, is mugged by a young man. But later that day, she meets him again… as his speech teacher. Their lessons grow into an unlikely friendship, then a pact. Cheered on by each other’s affection, without a penny to their name, they leave town and head for the sea.
items.default_editorial: The clear diction of its heroine, her neat-as-a-pin apartment, and the pure even tones of the soundtrack counterpoise this film’s asymmetrical May–September liaison. Mismatched but star-aligned, these lovers skip along a Côte d’Azur esplanade as plosives should trip off the tongue.

items.title: A Most Violent Year
items.short_synopsis: New York, 1981. As the city experiences a spike in criminal activity, Abel Morales—a respectable heating business owner—becomes the target of thieves. Abel takes matters into his own hands to track down those responsible. In doing so, he attracts the attention of the assistant district attorney.
items.default_editorial: The spirit of American crime cinema of old is revived in this sleek thriller from J.C. Chandor (Triple Frontier). A Most Violent Year teams the powerhouse duo of Oscar Isaac and Jessica Chastain in a remarkable portrait of a marriage dueling with capitalism amidst the decay of 1980s New York City.

items.title: Accattone
items.short_synopsis: On the mean streets of Rome, a pimp leads a hand-to-mouth existence on the very margins of society—soliciting women, scrounging around, and exploiting others. When his prize sex worker Maddalena is arrested and jailed, Accattone’s fortunes dwindle, and he is forced to confront his existence.
items.default_editorial: The holy and the damned. The Renaissance reborn to pimps, poets, and hustlers. A work of first starts and last stands, Pasolini’s vivid debut is often cited as the last of the Italian neorealist films. Shining a light on the lives of the urban poor, Accattone unearths the sacred in the profane.

items.title: Afternoon Delight
items.short_synopsis: A woman takes her husband to a strip club to spice up their marriage. After she gets a private dance from a sexy blond dancer, she invites the girl to work for her as a live-in nanny.
items.default_editorial: The set-up for Jill Soloway’s debut feature might suggest an outrageous sex comedy, but the writer-director quickly unveils a more serious-minded agenda. With a welcome lead role for the brilliant Kathryn Hahn, Afternoon Delight asks rattling questions of womanhood, marriage, and sexual stagnation.

items.title: Ain't Nothin' Without You
items.short_synopsis: Falling in love after a meet-cute on Hamburg’s frozen-over Alster Lake, Martha—a filmmaker with guilt over her privilege—and stalled architecture student Alfred begin a lively back-and-forth on every topic du jour. Meanwhile, Martha cohabits with her nanny’s family to feel a sense of social reality.
items.default_editorial: Shaking up the romance of a snowy cityscape, this comedy briskly hurtles from cozy meet-cute and artistic soul-searching to class anxiety and bureaucratic mess. Starring in her wryly self-reflective debut feature, Pia Frankenberg bottles life’s commotion into scenes of irresistible effervescence.

items.title: All About My Mother
items.short_synopsis: Following the tragic death of her teenage son, Manuela travels from Madrid to Barcelona in an attempt to contact the long-estranged father the boy never knew. She reunites with an old friend, an outspoken transgender sex worker, and befriends a troubled actress and a pregnant, HIV-positive nun.
items.default_editorial: One of Almodóvar’s most acclaimed and beloved films, All About My Mother won the Best Director award in Cannes and an Oscar®! An immaculate maximalist melodrama full of intense emotion, this love letter to actresses is brought to life by a fierce cast of Almodóvar regulars, including Penélope Cruz.

items.title: An Autumn Tale
items.short_synopsis: Magali is a widowed wine grower whose best friend, Isabelle, is concerned that she is lonely now that her daughter has grown up. Isabelle secretly decides that she must find her a new husband, and puts an advert in a lonely hearts column. When she looks for a suitable candidate, she finds Gerald.
items.default_editorial: Rohmer’s last comedy of manners in his “Tales of Four Seasons” cycle was a big commercial success and won the Best Screenplay award in Venice. In the bucolic vineyards of Southern France, the search for love of Magali, played by Marie Rivière, gives way to a multitude of romantic entanglements.

items.title: Assault on Precinct 13
items.short_synopsis: An LA gang’s revenge-fuelled killing spree leads them to a half-abandoned police station in the throes of closing down. Under siege with power and phone lines cut, a lone cop and his skeleton staff recruit a condemned killer from the cells in a desperate battle to survive the night.
items.default_editorial: A cult classic from one-man band John Carpenter (who wrote, directed, scored and edited the film) this is the quintessential B-movie that became a director’s big breakthrough. So successful, Assault on Precinct 13 enabled Carpenter to subsequently reinvent the slasher with his horror hit Halloween.

items.title: Babylon
items.short_synopsis: Blue, a young Black dancehall DJ living in 1980s South London, hopes to win a local Sound System competition. But as he pursues his musical ambitions, Blue fiercely battles against the racism and xenophobia of employers, neighbors, police, and the National Front.
items.default_editorial: When Babylon premiered in Cannes 40 years ago, its subversive spirit was met with bewilderment—hinting at why this British cult classic remains tragically underseen. Branded “a time capsule of late 70s Brixton,” we wish its raw depiction of racial tension wasn’t as fiercely relevant as it is today.

items.title: Bad Education
items.short_synopsis: Two boys, Ignacio and Enrique, know love, fear, and abuse in a Catholic boarding school in the 1960s. Father Manolo, the headmaster, is witness to and part of these discoveries. The three meet again many years later, and their past actions and new lives intertwine in creative and destructive ways.
items.default_editorial: Based on his Catholic schoolboy memories, Almodóvar’s magnificent hybrid of film noir and melodrama, starring Gael García Bernal, is a ravishing tour de force. Within three distinct timelines, fact, fiction, gender identity, and the boundless qualities of cinema are interwoven to dazzling effect.

items.title: Bed and Board
items.short_synopsis: Antoine has married his sweetheart Christine, and the couple has set up a cozy life—Christine sells flowers and teaches violin while Antoine works on his long-overdue novel. As Christine becomes pregnant with their first child, Antoine finds himself enraptured by a young Japanese woman.
items.default_editorial: After Stolen Kisses, Antoine Doinel is once again up to all sorts of tricks and domestic misconduct. Revealing François Truffaut’s interest in depicting the hazards of marital life with zany humour yet honest realism, Jean-Pierre Léaud and Claude Jade are irresistible as an erratic couple.

items.title: BMX Bandits
items.short_synopsis: Three big-haired, BMX-riding teens from Sydney—Judy, P.J., and Goose—stumble upon a stash stolen police walkie-talkies and plan to sell them for new bikes. But when the radios turn out to belong to bank robbers, a high-stakes chase erupts after Judy is kidnapped.
items.default_editorial: An explosion of bright polyester, zany synth music, and childish hijinks, Brian Trenchard-Smith’s sunny teen movie is powered by a sweet spirit of gleeful innocence. Only a young Nicole Kidman steals the spotlight from charmingly retro BMX stunts, performed against gorgeous Australian vistas.

items.title: Burning Beds
items.short_synopsis: During Hamburg’s housing shortage, German car mechanic Gina must share an apartment with Harry, a newly single drummer and pyromaniac from London. She plans to get rid of him immediately, but Harry, well-experienced in marital conflicts, proves to be an equal match to relationship-terrorist Gina.
items.default_editorial: What begins as a relationship of convenience bursts into surprising flames in this screwball comedy. Throwing pointed darts in with cupid’s arrows, filmmaker Pia Frankenberg and punk musician Ian Dury play mischievously with odd-couple dynamics, fuelling their sparring characters with a blazing wit.

items.title: Cat People
items.short_synopsis: Irena, a mysterious Serbian-born fashion artist, falls in love with and marries Oliver. But Irena believes that, because of an ancient curse, any physical intimacy with the man she loves will turn her into a feline predator. Oliver thinks that is absurd—but truth is sometimes stranger than fantasy…
items.default_editorial: Fusing psychoanalysis with mythology, Jacques Tourneur’s supernatural tale casts an enduring spell; it was even remade by Paul Schrader in the 1980s! As taboo desires escape the cage of dreams and spring onto the streets of New York, Cat People evokes the feral spectacle of the monstrous feminine.

items.title: Coming Out
items.short_synopsis: Philipp and Tanja, teachers at the same school, begin dating. Tanja falls for Philipp, but Philipp soon uncovers the truth about his sexuality and starts seeing a younger man. Caught between two relationships, Philipp must embark on a journey of self-discovery amid emotional and societal pressures.
items.default_editorial: A raw, tender tale of desire and transformation with a stirring performance by Matthias Freihof, Coming Out is a landmark film about homosexuality. Shot in East Germany, this queer classic premiered in Berlin on the night the Wall fell and now doubles as an invaluable document of a bygone world.

items.title: Dark Blue Girl
items.short_synopsis: When divorced couple Jimmy and Hannah finally find a buyer for their decrepit holiday home on a Greek volcanic island, they return with their young daughter Luca to the place where they separated two years ago. As old tensions resurface, Luca cleverly navigates and disrupts their fragile balance.
items.default_editorial: Before Sound of Falling, Mascha Schilinski made a bracing debut that travels to Greece for a story of mythical resonance. With performances that stun like the sapphire blues of the Aegean Sea, this family drama is electrified by the thunderous spite of a daughter vying for paternal attention.

items.title: Dead Girls Dancing
items.short_synopsis: On a road trip across Italy, recent high school graduates Ira, Malin and Ka pick up the intriguing backpacker Zoe. As the four girls stumble across an abandoned village, they start to experiment with the limits of their newly found freedom, away from the expectations of their parents and teachers.
items.default_editorial: Hazy with an atmosphere of delicate mystery, this impressive debut dives into a summer that is both the prologue to adulthood and its exhilarating deferral. Unfurling with fluid cinematography that hints at a subtle undertow of darkness, this coming-of-age film is authentic and achingly bittersweet.

items.title: Dealer
items.short_synopsis: Can is a small-time dealer for drug boss Hakan in Kreuzberg, Berlin’s tough Turkish neighborhood. Fed up with his life, Can sees a bright new beginning for himself and his family when Hakan offers him a bar to run. But Can has little control over the pressures that gradually build up around him.
items.default_editorial: While other European crime films of the 1990s such as La Haine and Pusher depict illegality in the Scorsese style, in the second film of his airy and bright “Berlin Trilogy”, Thomas Arslan resists making the day-to-day existence of a low-level drug dealer any greater or grittier than it already is.

items.title: Dream Scenario
items.short_synopsis: An ordinary professor’s life changes when millions of strangers begin seeing him in their dreams. Overnight, he becomes an unlikely celebrity, but public fascination soon turns to hostility, forcing him to navigate unexpected fame, shifting perceptions, and the collapse of his normal world.
items.default_editorial: Earning a Golden Globe nomination for his chameleonic turn, Nicolas Cage stars as the man of everyone’s dreams in Kristoffer Borgli’s fantastically surreal satire. Adding viral fame to the messy whirlpool of a midlife crisis, this modern-day cautionary tale abandons all logic with devilish glee.

items.title: Fitzcarraldo
items.short_synopsis: Brian Sweeney Fitzgerald is an opera-loving fortune hunter who dreams of bringing opera to a remote trading post in the Peruvian jungle. With the help of Madam Molly, his crew, and an indigenous tribe, he ventures into the wilderness to access the riches of unexploited rubber territory.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Best Director award at the 1982 Cannes Film Festival, this is one of cinema’s most insane undertakings—the crew literally had to drag a steamboat up a mountain. Werner Herzog’s crowning masterwork is a sweeping ode to mankind’s quest to leave a footprint on an infinite world.

items.title: France
items.short_synopsis: France is a star journalist running between a television set, a distant war and her busy family life. But everything is turned upside down after she injures a delivery man in a car accident. As France attempts to slow down and retreat into an anonymous life, her fame continues to pursue her.
items.default_editorial: Heralded by both John Waters and the Cahiers du cinéma clan, this withering comedy from French provocateur Bruno Dumont is a pugnacious state-of-the-nation satire. Led by a cyclonic Léa Seydoux, France mounts a hilarious assault on the rampancy of media culture and its insatiable consumers.

items.title: Hao Are You
items.short_synopsis: The American War in Vietnam scattered them across three continents. Nearly 50 years after their escape, contact between the seven family members has all but broken down. Director Dieu Hao Do travels to Vietnam, Hong Kong, California, and Germany to reconnect with his estranged clan.
items.default_editorial: Powered by a determination to investigate and heal old family rifts, Dieu Hao Do takes a strikingly personal look at the intimate devastation caused by war. A vividly honest effort to reckon with one’s heritage, Hao Are You won a First Steps award, recognizing the documentarian as a talent to watch.

items.title: Head-On
items.short_synopsis: Desperate to escape her suffocatingly traditional family, young Sibel convinces disillusioned alcoholic Cahit to marry her. After their wedding, the two lost souls live together as flatmates but gradually fall in love with one another. However, problems arise quickly.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Golden Bear, top prize of the Berlin Film Festival, acclaimed director Fatih Akin’s Head-On is a raw, emotional love story.  Both epic and intimate, and as direct and forceful as its title, it captures irony and complexity in the way only the best humanist drama can.

items.title: I Walked with a Zombie
items.short_synopsis: A Canadian nurse, Betsy, arrives on a Caribbean island to tend to an invalid woman who appears to suffer from an unexplained paralysis. The horrific truth soon emerges, however—amid the haunting rhythms of the voodoo drums.
items.default_editorial: An early example of the zombie film, Jacques Tourneur’s unsung masterpiece marries the gothic dread of Charlotte Brontë’s classic Jane Eyre with Haitian traditions and folklore. Haunting the recurring images of confinement and chains are no simple ghosts, but the phantoms of slavery and racism.

items.title: I'm Still Here
items.short_synopsis: Brazil, 1971. As the country falls under the tightening grip of a military dictatorship, Eunice Paiva, a mother of five, is forced to rebuild her life after her husband is abducted by the regime. As time passes without answers, she raises her children amid fear and uncertainty.
items.default_editorial: The first Brazilian film to win an Oscar®, Walter Salles’s masterful biographical drama sheds crucial light on one of the most harrowing periods in the country’s history. In a towering performance that speaks truth to power, Fernanda Torres channels the pain and the resilience of a generation.

items.title: Igor Levit: No Fear
items.short_synopsis: At 34, Igor Levit is a leading force in classical music—a bold, restless artist always seeking new challenges. With over 100 global concerts planned, the COVID-19 pandemic brings his journey to a sudden halt and pushes him to rethink and redefine his artistic path.
items.default_editorial: Facing each performance as a challenge to live fearlessly, Igor Levit puts his principles into practice as this riveting documentary portrait finds him at a critical turning point in his career. Bearing his soul to the camera, the passionate artist imbues the film with a contagious, fiery energy.

items.title: In My Room
items.short_synopsis: Lost in life and beset by a recent passing, Armin has nowhere to go and just as much to show for himself. Fate intervenes when Armin awakes one morning and discovers that seemingly all of humanity has disappeared, leaving him to his limited devices and opening the door for self-discovery.
items.default_editorial: Recalibrating the end of the world as an apocalypse of identity, In My Room is a profound spin on “Robinson Crusoe” from Berlin School director Ulrich Köhler. With welcome appearances from both Pet Shops Boys and Clint Eastwood, this wry gem is an ingenious portrait of a bourgeois life in ruins.

items.title: In the Shadows
items.short_synopsis: Trojan is a professional criminal who specializes in armed robbery. Released from prison, he picks up from where he left off—but now he has to begin again almost from scratch. Meanwhile, numerous obstacles get in the way of Trojan’s pressing need for independence.
items.default_editorial: Together with Angela Schanelec and Christian Petzold, Thomas Arslan (Gold) is an active member of the Berlin School. His first genre film, In the Shadows, is a taut and twist-filled, Berlin-set crime thriller with echoes of Melville, centered on an ex-con whose past catches up with him.

items.title: Jeanne Dielman, 23, Quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles
items.original_title: Jeanne Dielman, 23, Quai du Commerce, 1080 Bruxelles
items.short_synopsis: Jeanne Dielman is a middle-aged widow whose daily routine of chores includes making the beds, cooking dinner for her teenage son, and some occasional sex work. The rhythm and the rites of her every day are unchangeable. But when something changes, her routine slowly begins to unravel.
items.default_editorial: Swatting Hitchcock’s Vertigo off its perch as the greatest film of all time in Sight and Sound magazine’s 2022 decennial poll, Chantal Akerman’s masterpiece is a radical work of commanding power. In a steady accumulation of domestic scenes, Jeanne Dielman revolutionises the language of cinema.

items.title: Kids
items.short_synopsis: The lives of street-tough Manhattan teens unfold over a frenetic twenty-four hours. Skateboarders Telly and Casper spend their time hanging out, shoplifting, using drugs, and seducing girls. Meanwhile, Jennie follows the pair across New York, desperate to confront them with a terrible truth.
items.default_editorial: A defining film of 90s American independent cinema, Kids is full of eye-opening, unsentimental insights into the lives of New York teenagers. The first film credit for screenwriter Harmony Korine (just 19 years old), and much of its ensemble cast, including Chloë Sevigny and Rosario Dawson.

items.title: Kuhle Wampe or Who Owns the World?
items.original_title: Kuhle Wampe oder Wem gehört die Welt?
items.short_synopsis: At the height of the Great Depression, Anni’s brother commits suicide. Anni and her parents are evicted from their Berlin home and sent to Kuhle Wampe, a lakeside camp home to increasing numbers of unemployed. Eventually, Anni moves back to Berlin and gets involved in the workers’ youth movement.
items.default_editorial: Written by Bertolt Brecht, this social realist classic was banned by the Nazi party within weeks of its release. Influenced by Eisenstein’s montage theory, Kuhle Wampe is a formally adventurous and fervently leftist critique of capitalism that includes a scene directed by the playwright himself!

items.title: La Pointe Courte
items.short_synopsis: A penetrating study of a marriage on the rocks, set against the backdrop of a small Mediterranean fishing village. Both a stylized depiction of the complicated relationship between a married couple and a documentary-like look at the daily struggles of the inhabitants of Sète in the South of France.
items.default_editorial: Made independently with no backing and no budget, Agnes Varda was just 26 when she wrote and directed this stark, precocious relationship drama, approaching various themes she would later develop further in Le bonheur. An inspiring first impression from a now-legendary filmmaker.

items.title: Law of Desire
items.short_synopsis: Pablo loves Juan but Juan is lukewarm about the relationship. Antonio becomes obsessed with Pablo after one evening intended to be a mere one-night stand. Paralleling this dangerous love triangle is the story of Pablo’s sister Tina, a transgender woman about whom Pablo is writing a play.
items.default_editorial: One of Almodóvar’s personal favourites, this early great shares a kinship with his 2019 film Pain & Glory, not only in Antonio Banderas’ unforgettable turn but also its explorations of lust and fiction. A baroque melodrama celebrating new family models, Law of Desire feels more pertinent than ever.

items.title: Lights from Afar
items.short_synopsis: After reunification, a young photographer from East Berlin enjoys his new-found freedom. But soon he feels constrained by the new order in which financial success is the only measure of success. Paralyzed as an artist, he watches as his hometown transforms into an international metropolis.
items.default_editorial: Adopting the photographic and doubtful gaze of one ex-East Berliner, Helga Reidemeister zeroes in on the realities of 1990s Berlin. Digging into questions of migration, labor, and community that popular media glossed over, the granular detail of this intimate documentary glints in a new restoration.

items.title: Love Meetings
items.short_synopsis: Pier Paolo Pasolini travels throughout Italy, from the factories to the beaches, and interviews passersby about their attitudes toward sex. He questions them, mic in hand, on a wide range of topics: the importance of sex in everyday life, prostitution, homosexuality, and the legalization of divorce.
items.default_editorial: One of very few documentaries Pasolini ever made, this little-seen gem explores his country’s complex attitudes to sex and love. The Italian radical-atheist auteur covers themes like marriage, homosexuality, and prostitution with subversive curiosity and a typically sparkling sense of humor.

items.title: Love on the Run
items.short_synopsis: Antoine Doinel, now in his thirties, is amicably divorcing his wife, Christine, while enjoying success as a novelist and still clinging to his romantic fantasies. After falling for a record store clerk, the indecisive Antoine impulsively takes off with an old flame and confronts his chaotic past.
items.default_editorial: A character created by French auteur François Truffaut, Antoine Doinel is here portrayed as the ultimate intellectual womanizer. Running to the four corners of Paris to escape from (or fall into) his many lovers’ arms, this is Jean-Pierre Léaud at his best, starring alongside Marie-France Pisier.

items.title: Love Songs
items.short_synopsis: Julie lives with her boyfriend Ismaël, and rather than worry about the time he spends with his colleague Alice, Julie invites Alice to join them. The delicate balance of their idyllic world is threatened when tragedy strikes, challenging them to keep love alive through loss and mourning.
items.default_editorial: In spite of emotive bursts into song, this throwback to the 1960s musical is a personal, deeply felt film for its director. An intriguing, bold work at the same time self-conscious and sincere—with an ensemble cast that includes Honoré’s regular collaborators Louis Garrel and Chiara Mastroianni.

items.title: Madonnas
items.short_synopsis: After being neglected as a child, Rita gives birth to six children of her own and challenges her mother to act as a parent to her grandchildren. Rita is sent to prison, and upon her release, she takes back her kids. With the aid of Marc—a US soldier—she develops something of a normal family life.
items.default_editorial: As daughter or mother, friend or sister, Sandra Hüller’s character is on the run from convention in Maria Speth’s second feature. Sharing its itinerant spirit with Agnès Varda’s Vagabond, but colored in shades of Berlin School minimalism, Madonnas disavows feminine ideals with stark realism.

items.title: Material
items.short_synopsis: Unpublished footage from filmmaker Thomas Heise’s career chronicles his home country from 1980s GDR to Germany in 2008. Heise’s outtakes capture many moments, including the 1989 mass demonstrations outside Alexanderplatz, scenes inside Brandenburg prison, and a far-left attack at a film screening.
items.default_editorial: A celebrated chronicler of societal change in Germany, documentary filmmaker Thomas Heise performed a stunning act of cinematic archeology with this colossal, decades-spanning work. Assembled from previously unused footage, Material is a radical vision of a resurrected, profoundly fractured history.

items.title: Millennium Mambo
items.original_title: 千禧曼波  | Qian xi man po
items.short_synopsis: In the future of 2011, Vicky recalls her romances that unfolded a decade ago among the techno-scored neon nightlife of Taipei. Back in 2001, Vicky is a free spirit and party girl working as a hostess at a bar who begins to drift away from her DJ boyfriend towards a suave, sensitive gangster.
items.default_editorial: Sensuous pleasures are cut with the modern malaise of Taiwanese youth in this hypnotic film from Hou Hsiao-hsien. Immersed in love, hedonism, and the fluorescent blur of the new millennium, mesmerizing images distill the screen presence of nascent star, Shu Qi, into visions of cinematic ecstasy.

items.title: Mulholland Drive
items.short_synopsis: Blonde Betty Elms has only just arrived in Hollywood to become a movie star when she meets an enigmatic brunette with amnesia. Meanwhile, as the two set off to solve the second woman’s identity, filmmaker Adam Kesher runs into ominous trouble while casting his latest project.
items.default_editorial: Initially conceived as a TV pilot, only to be transformed into a feature film, Mulholland Drive is an uncorked lightning-in-a-bottle of Hollywood fantasies, baroque emotions, and noir dreamscapes. David Lynch’s surreal puzzle box unfolds a bewitching story of love and revenge in the City of Angels.

items.title: Murder on the Orient Express
items.short_synopsis: After wrapping a case, detective Hercule Poirot anticipates a tranquil journey on the Orient Express. However, a murder of an unpopular billionaire occurs on board, making everyone a suspect. Poirot utilizes an avalanche to his advantage and uncovers revenge motives among passengers.
items.default_editorial: All aboard, as the great Sidney Lumet re-routes briefly into the murder mystery genre. This sumptuous adaptation of Agatha Christie’s detective novel stars Albert Finney as the indomitable Hercule Poirot, and an ensemble cast to die for—Lauren Bacall, Sean Connery, Anthony Perkins & Ingrid Bergman!

items.title: Muriel's Wedding
items.short_synopsis: Muriel finds her life dull and spends her days alone in her room listening to ABBA music and dreaming of her wedding day. Slight problem, Muriel has never had a date. After stealing some money, she decides to go on a tropical vacation and befriends the wacky Rhonda who turns her world upside down.
items.default_editorial: An international phenomenon on its release in 1994, this BAFTA-nominated romcom made a star of its leading lady, Toni Collette. Witheringly funny but with a toughness emblematic of its unflappable heroine, Muriel’s Wedding suggests all you need is some grit and an ABBA mixtape to follow your dreams.

items.title: Naked Lunch
items.short_synopsis: Bill Lee is a part-time exterminator and full-time drug addict, who uses insecticides to get high, plunging into a nightmarish interzone of sinister cabals and giant talking bugs. Believing himself to be a government agent, he flees to a secret organization after accidentally killing his wife.
items.default_editorial: It’s hard to know where William S. Burroughs ends and David Cronenberg begins in this symbiotic adaptation of the former’s modernist masterwork. Spiralling into a world of Mugwumps and talking typewriters, Naked Lunch extends a hallucinatory invitation to the quicksands of the creative subconscious.

items.title: Never Sleep Again
items.short_synopsis: After attending a wedding on a steamboat traveling down the river Spree, three friends from Hamburg become stranded in a newly reunified Berlin. They begin a restless odyssey through the wastelands of a metropolis wavering between an unpredictable future and a lingering past.
items.default_editorial: Whether passing monuments to endings or ceremonies to new beginnings, Pia Frankenberg’s charming characters move with lightness and freedom. Breezily apace with a Berlin newly unburdened of the Wall, the director’s third feature has a liberated stance on narrative, capturing a capital in flux.

items.title: No Other Land
items.short_synopsis: Palestinian activist Basel Adra documents the destruction of his community in Masafer Yatta under Israeli occupation. He forms an unlikely alliance with Israeli journalist Yuval. For years, they fight against mass expulsion—forging a complex bond haunted by the extreme inequality between them.
items.default_editorial: Using the testimony of cameras, young Palestinians and Israelis document settler violence in the West Bank in this rousing, Oscar®-winning film. Few grounds for collaboration are as volatile—yet solidarity establishes itself against all odds, creating an essential work of contemporary cinema.

items.title: Oedipus Rex
items.short_synopsis: Amid the awe-inspiring landscapes of the Moroccan desert, the myth of Oedipus plays out, where the fated boy’s willful blindness to his nature unleashes a cataclysmic reckoning. Meanwhile, a prologue and epilogue set in twentieth-century Italy bring the legend of Oedipus into the modern day.
items.default_editorial: Following The Gospel According to Matthew, Pier Paolo Pasolini turned to another classical text for this deeply personal take on Sophocles’ immortal tragedy. Hopping from Morocco to Bologna for his first film shot in color, Pasolini fashions a hugely ambitious, three-part epic of modern mythmaking.

items.title: On Football
items.short_synopsis: Sergio and his father haven’t seen each other for over 20 years. On the eve of the 2014 World Cup Sergio returns to his hometown, São Paulo. As days go by, their relationship starts to wander into unknown territory and their pact to watch the entire tournament together turns into a dangerous ritual.
items.default_editorial: Elegantly straddling documentary and fiction, Sergio Oksman takes a frank and intimate look at football and father-son relationships, reminding us that sport is always more than just a game. This delicate miniature quickly becomes a profound rumination on life, death, and everything in between.

items.title: One Second
items.short_synopsis: During the Chinese Cultural Revolution, a convict escapes to seek out a film reel which contains footage of his estranged daughter. In a nearby village, he meets a homeless girl who is also searching for the film reel by any means. Soon, this reel becomes the root of their unexpected friendship.
items.default_editorial: An act of communal restoration lies at the heart of this tragicomic epic from Zhang Yimou, a film which shares a spiritual kinship with the nostalgic classic Cinema Paradiso. A visually ravishing tale of triumph over adversity, One Second is a bittersweet ode to the magic of the silver screen.

items.title: Only Lovers Left Alive
items.short_synopsis: Centuries-old lovers Adam and Eve are vampires. He’s playing rock in Detroit while she’s hanging out in Tangiers. They struggle with depression and an ever-changing world and watch time go by, each finding stability in the other. However, the appearance of her brazen younger sister brings trouble.
items.default_editorial: Jim Jarmusch makes his own distinctive spin on the vampire film with this stylish, atmospheric two-hander set in present-day Detroit and Tangier. Tom Hiddleston and Tilda Swinton embody the laconic bohemianism of vampires in love in this wicked-cool reflection on immortality and gentrification.

items.title: Only the River Flows
items.short_synopsis: Dedicated police detective Ma Zhe is tasked with solving a series of brutal murders in a rural Chinese town. As pressure mounts from his superiors, a hasty arrest is made, but while his colleagues celebrate, several clues push Ma Zhe deeper into a desperate investigation of his own.
items.default_editorial: Continuing the recent trend of moody neo-noirs from mainland China, this tenebrous psychological thriller from director Wei Shujun follows a small-town detective into the mouth of madness. Stunningly shot on Super 16, Only the River Flows is a pungently atmospheric serial-killer procedural.

items.title: Our Ark
items.short_synopsis: Humans are backing up the planet, creating 3D models of animals, rainforests, cities, and people—archiving as if ecological collapse could be staved off through a digital Noah’s Ark of beasts and objects. The artists explore our efforts to create a virtual replica of the real world.
items.default_editorial: A creative contemplation of the implications of ubiquitous digitalization, this spectacular short suggests what a 21st-century Noah’s Ark might look like. An astonishing utopian vision that invites questions about the notion of the simulacra and the digital archiving of our planet.

items.title: Our Hospitality
items.short_synopsis: After twenty years away Willie McKay returns to his Appalachian homestead to take possession of his family home. On the trip, he falls for a young woman. The only problem is her family has vowed to kill every member of his family due to an ongoing feud that led to him being sent away as a baby.
items.default_editorial: In Buster Keaton’s dashing period romance, swelling courtship tumbles into precipice-hanging acrobatics, including a literally death-defying sequence which saw the comic nearly drown on camera. Colliding luscious design with antic spectacle, Our Hospitality is Keaton at his most gorgeously bravura.

items.title: Out of Season
items.short_synopsis: Mathieu lives in Paris, Alice in a small seaside resort in Western France. He is a famous actor, about to turn 50. She is a piano teacher in her 40s. They were in love fifteen years ago, then separated. When Mathieu goes try to overcome his melancholia in a thermal spa, he stumbles upon Alice.
items.default_editorial: Guillaume Canet and Alba Rohrwacher make a dream duo in this poignant romance from French filmmaker Stéphane Brizé. Bringing warmth to cool, minimalist architecture and the wintertime seascape of Brittany, the two leads beam with easy comedy and chemistry in an elegantly wistful love story.

items.title: Pain and Glory
items.short_synopsis: Salvador Mallo, a film director in his physical decline, reencounters or remembers his past: his childhood in a village, the first desire, his first adult love in 80s Madrid, the pain of that breakup. In recovering his past, Salvador finds the urgent need to recount it, and also finds his salvation.
items.default_editorial: The Spanish master of transgression returns with a sublime semi-autobiographical film, suffused with his signature vivid colours and eye for melodrama, yet full of melancholic introspection. Banderas is mesmerising as an ageing filmmaker haunted by his own ghosts—and took home Best Actor in Cannes!

items.title: Palo Alto
items.short_synopsis: In the affluent Californian city of Palo Alto, three stories of teenage lust, boredom, and self-destruction intersect. April is torn between a flirtation with her coach and a crush on sweet stoner Teddy. Emily offers sexual favors to any boy—and Fred’s behavior may or may not be sociopathic.
items.default_editorial: You’re certainly familiar with Francis and Sofia Coppola, but there’s already a third generation bursting onto the scene. In her directorial debut, Gia—granddaughter of “the Godfather”—assuredly adapts James Franco’s short stories to deliver an exquisite, darkly moving portrait of high-school life.

items.title: Parallel Mothers
items.short_synopsis: Janis and Ana meet in a hospital before giving birth. Both are single and became pregnant by accident. Janis, middle-aged, doesn’t regret it. Adolescent Ana is scared. A close link between the two blossoms, which develops into a complex relationship that will change their lives in a decisive way.
items.default_editorial: Penélope Cruz gives what might just be her greatest performance in this seventh collaboration with Pedro Almodóvar. Marrying exquisite melodrama to a searing interrogation of Spain’s historic trauma, Parallel Mothers is a vivid tale of female companionship that stands among the maestro’s finest.

items.title: Past Lives
items.short_synopsis: Nora and Hae Sung are classmates at a school in Seoul. But their friendship ends when Nora’s family moves to Canada. Twelve years later, Nora notices that Hae Sung’s been searching for her on social media. They reconnect, but another dozen years pass before they meet during his visit to New York.
items.default_editorial: Awash with wistful reveries about the “what ifs” and “maybes” of life, Celine Song’s exquisite debut stars the luminous Greta Lee (Russian Doll) in a breakout lead role. As fate brings two childhood sweethearts back together, Past Lives basks in the pleasure of yearning for what could have been.

items.title: People on Sunday
items.short_synopsis: Five young Berliners—including a taxi driver, a wine dealer, and a model—enjoy a typical Sunday outing to the countryside. Flirtations, rivalries, and other dynamics within the group begin to surface. But as the day ends, the prospect of returning to the weekday routine looms over the city-dwellers.
items.default_editorial: Shot over several Sundays in the summer of ’29, this hybrid experiment combines documentary and fictional techniques to explore the wonders of Weimar-era leisure-time. A stellar collaboration from directors on the cusp of breaking into Hollywood (Robert Siodmak, Edgar G. Ulmer & Billy Wilder!).

items.title: Pépé le Moko
items.short_synopsis: Pépé le Moko, one of France’s most wanted criminals, hides out in the Casbah section of Algiers. He knows the police will be waiting for him if he tries to leave the city. When Pépé meets Gaby, a Parisian girl, he is compelled to risk his life and leave its confines once and for all.
items.default_editorial: Featuring one of Jean Gabin’s most outstanding performances, Pépé Le Moko’s depiction of the underworld through sublime, stylish cinematography has established it as a landmark of French Poetic Realism. The maze of streets of Algiers’ Casbah provides a pulsating backdrop to this resounding classic.

items.title: Persepolis
items.short_synopsis: In 1970s Iran, Marjane, an 8-year-old girl, dreams of saving the world. Cherished by her beloved family, she watches the events that led to the downfall of the Shah’s brutal regime through her young eyes. Now a punk-loving teenager, Marjane witness her country transform into an oppressive society.
items.default_editorial: This acclaimed coming-of-age feature chronicles a young girl during the 1979 Iranian Revolution. Co-directed and adapted by Marjane Satrapi from her graphic autobiography into beautiful black-and-white animation, the film is voiced by mother-daughter duo Chiara Mastroianni and Catherine Deneuve!

items.title: Repo! The Genetic Opera
items.short_synopsis: In the near future, as humankind is suffering a worldwide epidemic of organ failures, a multinational biotech corporation launches a finance program for organ transplants. But those who miss their monthly payments are pursued by Repo Men, who retrieve the company’s property swiftly and painfully.
items.default_editorial: Marrying the gore of the Saw franchise with the campiness of The Rocky Horror Picture Show, Darren Lynn Bousman’s gothic rock opera is a full-throated celebration of kitsch. Lampooning corporate greed through daring tunes and outrageous costumes, this flamboyant cult classic makes dystopia fun.

items.title: Ryuichi Sakamoto | Opus
items.short_synopsis: In late 2022, as his health declined, Ryuichi Sakamoto gathered his strength for one final performance. Alone with his piano and filmed by his son, Neo Sora, he plays 20 pieces spanning his career—from his Yellow Magic Orchestra days to his Bertolucci film scores to his final album, 12.
items.default_editorial: Shot by Ryuichi Sakamoto’s son, this recording of the composer’s final concert captures all the care and attention that he poured into his work. Achieving a harmonious balance between sound and silence, his music finds a spellbinding echo in the delicate black and white of the film’s cinematography.

items.title: Schlingensief: A Voice That Shook the Silence
items.short_synopsis: Christoph Schlingensief’s Heimat films, performance art, installations, and provocative television, operatic, and artistic productions shaped Germany’s cultural and political discourse for two decades. Unpublished and newly digitized footage captures the vast spectrum of Schlingensief’s impact.
items.default_editorial: Bettina Böhler—editor extraordinaire for filmmakers including Christian Petzold—takes the director’s chair for this documentary about an essential figure of German experimental cinema. Years of archival material constellate to create a picture not only of Schlingensief, but also of history itself.

items.title: September Says
items.short_synopsis: Sisters September and July share an intense bond, speaking in a secret language and keeping the outside world at a distance. After September is suspended from school, their mother brings them to a remote house on the Irish coast—where July begins to resist her sister’s increasingly sadistic control.
items.default_editorial: Power dynamics seesaw and daring playground games become deadly serious in Ariane Labed’s startlingly unique first feature as director. Offering up a dark, distinctive vision of adolescence and girlhood, this unpredictable film sees the strangeness of the sibling bond for its wild, feral intensity.

items.title: Shame
items.short_synopsis: New Yorker Brandon lives in a high-rise apartment and has a well-paying job. He is also a sex addict who hides his shame behind this facade of respectability. The unexpected arrival of his wayward sister threatens to unravel everything.
items.default_editorial: Michael Fassbender took the Best Actor prize in Venice for his emotionally wounding portrayal of a sex addict in Steve McQueen’s shattering examination of self-loathing and urban isolation. With acute formal deliberation, Shame anatomises follies of the flesh as a means to interrogate the soul.

items.title: Shoah: Part One
items.short_synopsis: Through interviews with survivors, witnesses, and former perpetrators, memories of the Holocaust unfold across the landscapes where it occurred. Over images of the Polish fields and forests that once were Treblinka, Chelmno, and Auschwitz, voices recount stories of deportation and survival.
items.default_editorial: Claude Lanzmann establishes the powerfully uncomplicated method of his immense cinematic monument to the victims of the Holocaust in Shoah: Part One. Intercutting eyewitness testimony with present-day footage of concentration camps, the director makes history shatteringly urgent.

items.title: Shoah: Part Two
items.short_synopsis: Through interviews with survivors, witnesses, and former perpetrators, memories of the Holocaust unfold across the landscapes where it occurred. Over images of the Polish fields and forests that once were Treblinka, Chelmno, and Auschwitz, voices recount stories of deportation and survival.
items.default_editorial: Examining the most violent period of the Nazi genocide, the second half of Lanzmann’s unsparing and unshakeably moral work is a singular document of one of history’s darkest moments. Culminating with the story of the Warsaw Ghetto rebellion, Shoah’s final note is one of resolute human dignity.

items.title: Shut Up and Play the Piano
items.original_title: Shut Up and Play the Piano
items.short_synopsis: The son of Hungarian Jews who fled to Canada during the war, Grammy-winning musician Chilly Gonzales inspired and collaborated with the likes of Daft Punk and Drake. Converging between rap, electro and chamber music, the eccentric entertainer invited himself into the ivory tower of classical music.
items.default_editorial: Proving as outrageous and entertaining as its subject, Philipp Jedicke’s documentary follows the unpredictable career of one Chilly Gonzales—prankster, pianist, self-proclaimed genius—and features interviews with Gonzales’s friends and collaborators, including Jarvis Cocker, Feist, and Peaches!

items.title: Sisters
items.short_synopsis: Journalist Grace witnesses a murder in the neighboring apartment of two twin sisters. However, when the police find no evidence of the crime, Grace takes things into her own hands. With the help of a private detective, she soon discovers more about the sisters’ relationship than she bargained for.
items.default_editorial: Billed at its time as “the most frightening film since Psycho,” this ‘70s homage to all things Hitchcock by his biggest fan Brian De Palma, overflows with slasher artifice, split screen bravura and glorious plot twists. Bernard Herrmann’s score is chilling, and the descent into madness irresistible.

items.title: Sonne
items.short_synopsis: Three teenage girls in Vienna film themselves twerking in hijab to a pop song. When the video goes viral, Yesmin, the only Kurdish person among the friends, distances herself from her culture. Meanwhile, Nati and Bella meet two young Kurdish patriots, and the situation threatens to escalate.
items.default_editorial: Electrified by adolescent ambivalence, irreverence, and daring, Kurdwin Ayub’s dynamic film thrusts the politics of the veil boldly into the spotlight. Streaking modern girlhood with instant fame’s glitter and rebellion’s risks, Sonne frees discourse around cultural appropriation to new, nervy ends.

items.title: Spencer
items.short_synopsis: The marriage of Princess Diana and Prince Charles has long since grown cold. Though rumours of affairs and a divorce abound, peace is restored for the Christmas at the Queen’s Sandringham Estate. As always, there’s eating and drinking, shooting and hunting. But this year, things will be different.
items.default_editorial: A haunted house movie told with spiralling subjectivity, Pablo Larraín’s ravishing Diana fable has more in common with The Shining than it does with The Crown. Led by a magnificent Kristen Stewart, and with an evocative score from Jonny Greenwood, Spencer matches formal maximalism with high camp.

items.title: Stars
items.short_synopsis: Bulgaria, 1943. Wehrmacht sergeant Walter oversees Bulgarian workers in a small-town repair shop while nearby Greek Jews await deportation to Auschwitz. Through the camp’s barbed wire, he meets Ruth, a young Jewish woman, and their conversations awaken unexpected feelings and fragile hopes.
items.default_editorial: Awarded the Special Jury Prize at Cannes, this wartime drama by East German director Konrad Wolf opposes Nazi barbarism with tender humanity. Constellating a fulgurant spectrum of cinematic techniques to telegraph the dreams and fears of the Jewish people, Stars is a triumph of art in dark times.

items.title: Stolen Kisses
items.short_synopsis: Dishonorably discharged from the army, 20-year-old Antoine Doinel finds it hard adapting to civilian life in Paris. While resuming his on-again, off-again relationship with Christine, he takes on a series of jobs, including a failed stint as a hotel clerk and a turn working as a private detective.
items.default_editorial: In Stolen Kisses, Jean-Pierre Léaud has now become Antoine Doinel as an adult (barely), and is running the streets of Paris as a detective. This mischievous and whimsical adventure shows François Truffaut at his most exquisite, playing with the detective thriller genre while running after romance.

items.title: Sukiyaki Western Django
items.short_synopsis: Ever since the Genpei War a few centuries before, two opposing clans have been fighting over a hidden treasure. When a stranger comes to town, he says he’ll join whichever clan offers him more money. However, the stranger has a hidden agenda: he is there to seek revenge on behalf of a sex worker.
items.default_editorial: Cult director Takashi Miike has directed nearly 100 movies in the last 25 years and isn’t slowing down. Brace yourself for this one: a stylized, irresistibly hip mashup of spaghetti westerns and samurai epics, bound for midnight movie glory. As a bonus, keep your eye out for Quentin Tarantino!

items.title: System Crasher
items.short_synopsis: Wherever 9-year-old Benni ends up, she is expelled. She has become what child protection services call a “system crasher.” But she is not looking to change her ways, and has one goal: go back home to her mother. When anger management trainer Micha is hired to help, suddenly there is hope.
items.default_editorial: Few films provoke a gripping feeling deep in one’s guts… System Crasher is such a film, a visceral look at childhood—with a spectacular, rage-fuelled performance by Helena Zengel—jumping between feral violence and heart-rending empathy as we witness the limitations of love, and protection systems.

items.title: Talk to Her
items.short_synopsis: Benigno is infatuated with Alicia, a dancer he watches from the anonymity of his apartment. After an accident, she is brought to the hospital where Benigno happens to be her caregiver. When wounded bullfighter Lydia is brought into the same ward, her companion, Marco, bonds with Benigno.
items.default_editorial: Winner of a Best Original Screenplay Oscar®, Talk To Her boasts a sublimely improbable premise making for a perfect distillation of modern melodrama. This darkly exquisite version of Sleeping Beauty, where wounds and desire become indiscernible, is a transcendent celebration of male vulnerability.

items.title: Tampopo
items.short_synopsis: A determined widow running a small ramen shop in Tokyo seeks to transform it into the best in the city. With help from two truck drivers and a group of eccentric allies, she experiments, learns, and refines her craft, turning a simple bowl of noodles into a celebration of dedication and community.
items.default_editorial: Meaty action, silky sex, deliciously tangled plot strands, and a garnish of postmodern playfulness are the flavorful ingredients in Juzo Itami’s delightful “ramen Western.” Colorful, inventive, and unfailingly good-natured, Tampopo fills the belly with laughter and nourishes the soul. Itadakimasu!

items.title: The Apple
items.short_synopsis: In Tehran, 12-year-old twin sisters have lived as prisoners in their house since they were born, imprisoned by their father and blind mother. The father argues: “My daughters are like flowers. They may wither with the sun.” But a social worker tries to persuade him that the girls need their freedom.
items.default_editorial: At just seventeen, Samira Makhmalbaf realized her first feature and traveled with it to Cannes. A tale of twins cut off from society, the film nevertheless beams with the proud regard of an older sister, when the girls finally take their small, miraculous steps toward the world in all its wonder.

items.title: The Ardor
items.short_synopsis: Mysterious and mystical Kai emerges from the Argentinean rainforest to rescue Vania, who has been kidnapped by mercenaries. Together, Kai and Vania face off against the men who have ruthlessly murdered Vania’s father, a poor farmer, and taken over his land.
items.default_editorial: A reimagined western with an eco-conscious twist, Pablo Fendrik’s action-packed drama brings Sergio Leone-style thrills to the lush jungle of Misiones in Argentina. With the dashing Gael García Bernal as its mysterious hero, this dazzling film sizzles with old-school romance and daredevil adventure!

items.title: The Believer
items.short_synopsis: A young Jewish man develops a fiercely anti-Semitic philosophy. Based on the factual story of a K.K.K. member in the 1960s who was revealed to be Jewish by a New York Times reporter.
items.default_editorial: Ryan Gosling gives an incendiary breakthrough performance as the highly articulate Jewish neo-Nazi Danny Balint. Based on a complex true story, Henry Bean’s ferocious, extremely controversial drama won the Grand Jury Prize at Sundance, and stars Theresa Russell, Billy Zane, and Summer Phoenix.

items.title: The Conversation
items.short_synopsis: Surveillance expert Harry Caul is hired to tail a young couple. Tracking the pair through San Francisco’s Union Square, the man manages to record a cryptic conversation between them. Tormented by memories of a previous case that ended badly, Caul sets out to determine if the couple are in danger.
items.default_editorial: This Oscar®-nominated classic directed by Francis Ford Coppola and starring Gene Hackman is an enthralling character study inspired by Antonioni’s Blow-Up. Embodying the Cold War era of paranoia with formal and political rigor, The Conversation deservingly won the Palme d’Or in 1974.

items.title: The End
items.short_synopsis: Twenty-five years after the Earth’s environmental collapse, Mother, Father and Son cling to a sense of normalcy while confined to a palatial bunker. But when a Girl turns up at their doorstep, with her own past and perspective, the family’s blind optimism begins to unravel.
items.default_editorial: The golden age of Hollywood musicals is given a postapocalyptic twist in this dazzling epic from Oscar®-nominated filmmaker Joshua Oppenheimer. With Tilda Swinton and George MacKay leading a stellar ensemble cast, The End journeys to the end of the world to explore the limits of our shared humanity.

items.title: The Forest for the Trees
items.short_synopsis: Melanie leaves home to start her teaching career, armed with alternative methods and bright-eyed optimism. But after her first day of classes, during which she gives an ambitious speech, Melanie finds rejection from her colleagues, torture from her students, and loneliness in her personal life.
items.default_editorial: Long before she scored an Oscar® nomination for Toni Erdmann, Maren Ade made her feature debut with this razor-sharp portrait of an idealistic teacher’s emotional unravelling. Ruthlessly unsentimental, The Forest for the Trees is an empathetic anatomisation of loneliness and social awkwardness.

items.title: The Gleaners and I: Two Years Later
items.original_title: Les glaneurs et la glaneuse... deux ans après
items.short_synopsis: Agnes Varda returns to the people she met in her 2000 documentary on gleaning and meets some new people who were inspired by her first film.
items.default_editorial: In this sequel to one of her most acclaimed films, Agnès Varda returns to her previous subjects, and the many meanings of “gleaning,” with deeper insight and plenty of surprises along the way—including participants’ differing feelings about her filmmaking approach. We just can’t get enough!

items.title: The Great Beauty
items.short_synopsis: Jep Gambardella, a 65-year-old journalist, lives among Rome’s decadent high society in a swirl of rooftop parties and late-night soirees. But when he learns of the death of his friend’s wife, a woman he once loved, his life is thrown into perspective and he begins to see the world through new eyes.
items.default_editorial: An ornate and eye-popping extravaganza, Paolo Sorrentino’s dazzling, suitably self-conscious spectacle conceals a despairing satire, a nauseous indictment of the glamorous facade and moral bankruptcy of Italy’s recent Berlusconi era. Winner of the Academy Award® for Best Foreign Language film.

items.title: The Hawks and the Sparrows
items.short_synopsis: An old man and his son are walking along the road when they suddenly meet a speaking crow, which represents Marxist beliefs. They are soon moved back 750 years in time, changed into monks and sent by St. Francis to convert the hawks and the sparrows to Christianity.
items.default_editorial: Pasolini, who considered this the favorite of his films, takes aim at all of his usual targets: the Catholic Church, intellectuals, the bourgeoisie. Brought to life by Totò—a comic genius under-appreciated outside of Italy—who, playing himself, encounters a talking crow with Marxist leanings.

items.title: The Human Beast
items.short_synopsis: It is the start of the summer holidays for Quinquin, and it is also the start of a local killing spree after a woman is chopped up and fed to a cow found dead in an old bunker.
items.default_editorial: Presented in its original serialized form, this epitome of the arthouse TV series (is there such a thing?) is a first-class surreal whodunit which has already earned its place next to Twin Peaks. Who would have thought Bruno Dumont could make us laugh out loud? Enjoy: this is just the beginning.

series.title: Li'l Quinquin

content_rating.label: mature
content_rating.description: Contains material and themes suitable only for mature audiences.

series.short_synopsis: After a corpse is discovered inside a cow, a wild police investigation unfolds in a bizarre French village that has fallen prey to evil. Meanwhile, a band of young, mischievous scoundrels watches from the sides.
series.short_synopsis_html: After a corpse is discovered inside a cow, a wild police investigation unfolds in a bizarre French village that has fallen prey to evil. Meanwhile, a band of young, mischievous scoundrels watches from the sides.

seasons.title: Season 1
seasons.default_editorial: In the world of Li’l Quinquin, stuffed cow is not a cordon bleu dish, but the bull’s-eye of a characterfully odd whodunit. Embracing all-out absurdity, French director Bruno Dumont sets the offbeat tempo for an ensemble cast, leading them—like a prankish bandmaster—into riotously weird scenarios.
seasons.default_editorial_html: In the world of Li’l Quinquin, stuffed cow is not a cordon bleu dish, but the bull’s-eye of a characterfully odd whodunit. Embracing all-out absurdity, French director Bruno Dumont sets the offbeat tempo for an ensemble cast, leading them—like a prankish bandmaster—into riotously weird scenarios.

items.title: The Last Bet
