items.short_synopsis: Elderly couple Ernst and Leni have a tradition: they bet on who will die first, with the last piece of chocolate as the prize. Each hopes to go before the other—but for very different reasons.
items.default_editorial: Companionship may be cozy, while a sense of imminent mortality may be gloomy, but Austrian director Meike Wüstenberg has fun with life’s endings in The Last Bet. Indulging in irreverent, wicked humor, this toothsome short intensifies cocoa-flavored indulgence with a dark game of tempting fate.

items.title: The Legend of Paul and Paula
items.original_title: Die Legende von Paul und Paula
items.short_synopsis: Paul and Paula have had bad experiences with love: Paul is financially well off but has lost all affection for his wife, and Paula leads a troublesome life raising two children on her own. They meet and discover a strong passion for each other.
items.default_editorial: A box-office sensation, this tragicomedy was made during a brief period of relaxed censorship in East Germany. Full of yearning for personal freedom and punctuated by scenes of old buildings blowing up, The Legend of Paul and Paula struck a cord with the public and became a perennial cult favorite.

items.title: The Ordinaries
items.short_synopsis: In a world split into main characters, supporting roles, and outtakes, Paula must prove she has what it takes to be in the spotlight. But when she uncovers secrets about her heroic father’s death, Paula’s investigations lead her to the fringe society of outtakes—who challenge everything she knows.
items.default_editorial: Bringing to mind the metafictions of Charlie Kaufman, high concepts and absurd curveballs abound in Sophie Linnenbaum’s cerebral, comic debut. Set in a dystopia where the whole world is cinema and not everyone can be a star of the screen, The Ordinaries asks who among us gets to be special—and why?

items.title: The Silence
items.short_synopsis: Khorshid, a young blind boy from Tajikistan, earns rent money for his family by tuning rare instruments but becomes enraptured by the sonorous music he hears on his way to work each day.
items.default_editorial: Sightless, a curious child with an elevated sense of hearing and touch delights in the pleasures that he encounters by ear and by hand in the markets and workshops of Tajikistan. Mohsen Makhmalbaf’s capacious camera shares in these plentiful gifts, basking in their boundless color and music.

items.title: The Sparrow in the Chimney
items.short_synopsis: Karen lives with her husband Markus and their children in her idyllic childhood home. Karen’s sister Jule and her family are visiting for Markus’ birthday. The two women could not be more different. Soon, grim reminders of their deceased mother incite Jule to rebel against her domineering sister.
items.default_editorial: Chimney? Sparrow? That’s just the start of all the untameable commotion in this fuming domestic drama. Throwing a headless chicken, flaming feuds, and a scalding Maren Eggert into a combustible menagerie, the Zürchers unsettle a meticulous setup with viciousness and ominous spots of blood.

items.title: The State and Me
items.original_title: L'état et moi – Der Staat und ich
items.short_synopsis: Judge Josephine Praetorius-Camusot falters in her legal routines when, during celebrations of Franco-German relations, an exhibit awakens from a 150-year slumber: composer Hans List from the Paris Commune—who looks just like her! Chased by authorities, List hides in a rehearsal at the opera.
items.default_editorial: An inventive “what if” experiment, this comedy lampoons the hypocrisies of the German legal system with thrilling wit and a light touch. As the romcom meets the courtroom procedural and the period drama, past and present playfully collide in Sophie Rois’s ingenious dual performance.

items.title: The Strange Little Cat
items.short_synopsis: Siblings Karin and Simon are visiting their parents’ flat in Berlin. That evening, other relatives will join them for dinner. Hectic preparations take place, the washing machine is repaired, people sit together at the kitchen table, carry out an experiment with orange peel, talk about lungs…
items.default_editorial: Never mind the curious marmalade cat who ambles in and out of frame: the people here are just as peculiar. Choreographing all the hustle and bustle of a household into an intricate symphony of family life, Ramon Zürcher earned glowing comparisons to Jacques Tati for this impressive first feature.

items.title: The Substance
items.short_synopsis:
Have you ever dreamt of a better version of yourself?
You. Only better in every way.
You should try this new product, The Substance. 
IT CHANGED MY LIFE.
items.default_editorial: With sharp wit and cathartic intensity, Coralie Fargeat turns toxic beauty culture inside out in her Oscar®-winning latest feature. Powered by a career-best performance from Demi Moore, The Substance fearlessly bulldozes its way into the midnight-movie pantheon and the feminist canon.

items.title: The Swimmers
items.short_synopsis: A series of vignettes using archival footage set around swimming pools unpicks the pool’s role in contemporary life from class issues to work, leisure, sex, and tragedy.
items.default_editorial: Folding memoir, etymological study, and archival excavation into an opalescent short, Charlie López lends an inquiring eye to the myriad functions of the swimming pool. Inspired by Ed Ruscha’s iconic photography, The Swimmers siphons aquatic reveries from the collective cultural consciousness.

items.title: The Tin Drum
items.short_synopsis: Oskar is an unusual boy. Refusing to leave the womb until promised a tin drum by his mother, he vows on his third birthday to never grow up. Miraculously, he gets his wish. As the Nazis rise to power, Oskar wills himself to remain a child, screaming in protest at the chaos surrounding him.
items.default_editorial: Famously sharing the Palme d’Or with Apocalypse Now, Schlöndorff’s scandalous adaptation of Günter Grass’ novel wound up as one of the highest-grossing German films of the decade. A new generation acutely examines the one that came before it: just like a child, now grown up, looks at their parents.

items.title: The Witch
items.short_synopsis: New England in the 1630s: William and Katherine lead a devout Christian life with five children, homesteading on the edge of an impassable wilderness. When their newborn son vanishes and crops fail, the family turns on one another.
items.default_editorial: Transfiguring the tired field of 2000s shock-horror with olde, auratic terror, Robert Eggers’s debut feature garnered critical acclaim for taking the genre seriously. Impressing with stunning performances of haunting puritanical fervor, The Witch wrests exquisitely creepy imagery from barest woods.

items.title: Typhoon Club
items.short_synopsis: As evening falls on a provincial town just outside Tokyo, a typhoon looms over a secondary school and traps a group of students inside. Stranded in their schoolhouse, the group undergoes an awakening as they dispel all insecurities, fear, and desire under the swell of the tempest.
items.default_editorial: Junior high schoolers cut loose while waiting out a storm in Shinji Sōmai’s cult film, dancing in the driving rain and venting their teenage angst. This immersively elemental film suspends its classmates in limbo, between waking dreams of freedom and the agonising postponement of futures unknown.

items.title: What Did You Dream Last Night, Parajanov?
items.original_title: Was hast du gestern geträumt, Parajanov?
items.short_synopsis: After moving away from his family in Isfahan, Iran, to study film in Germany, Faraz Fesharaki documented his digital exchanges with them over ten years. From his mother’s experience in prison to a father insisting on hearing his son’s dream from last night, the webcam witnesses everything.
items.default_editorial: News from home might touch on global politics or point to the gathering of persimmons—Faraz Fesharaki has enough bandwidth for both. Woven together from a decade of video calls, complete with soft pixellation and haphazard lagging, his directorial debut glows with modern forms of tenderness.

items.title: While We're Young
items.short_synopsis: Josh and Cornelia are a happily married, middle-aged NYC couple. When Josh, a filmmaker, attempts to overcome an artistic blockage through a new friendship with a hipster couple, he and Cornelia find themselves neglecting their friends in favor of spending time with the uninhibited Brooklynite pair.
items.default_editorial: Noah Baumbach revisits the middle-age experience: this time with a couple (Stiller, Watts) whose relationship needs to rekindle its sense of youth (enter: Driver, Seyfried)—or so they think. A reckoning with adulthood, commitment, and genuine artistry that is at once hilarious and tender.

items.title: Women on the Verge of a Nervous Breakdown
items.original_title: Mujeres al borde de un ataque de nervios
items.short_synopsis: Dumped by her lover Iván, soap actress Pepa needs to track him down to deliver an important message. But her life is soon invaded by a series of distractions: Pepa’s friend Candela might have got involved in a terrorist plot, while Iván’s son, who is flat-hunting, ends up visiting Pepa’s apartment.
items.default_editorial: And we reach peak Almodóvar! Alive with a wild pace and an irresistible rhythm, this witty classic redefined screwball comedy for a new era of arthouse pleasure. The insanity of love and sex had never been so fun nor colourful—and as for Pedro, he was forever thrust into the international spotlight.

items.title: Wrong
items.short_synopsis: Dolph Springer awakens one morning to find he has lost the sole love of his life—his dog, Paul. Desperate to reunite with his best friend and to set things right, Dolph embarks on a journey which spirals into the realm of the absurd.
items.default_editorial: French director Quentin Dupieux (Rubber) may have his brain in backwards—how else to explain such bracing, fresh absurdism? Wrong, which premiered at Sundance in 2012 and split critics down the middle, is a bonkers dark comedy of the American west with strains of Kafka and Buñuel.

items.title: Wrong Cops
items.short_synopsis: A group of bad cops look to dispose of a body that one of them accidentally shot.
items.default_editorial: Quentin Dupieux is perhaps better known as the infamous French DJ, Mr. Oizo, but he also directs magnificent absurdist films like this one. Guided by a audacious cast ranging from Marilyn Manson to Eric Wareheim, Wrong Cops is a comedy of meaninglessness about crime and our contemporary reality.

items.title: I vitelloni
items.short_synopsis: Five men, the not-so-young sons of middle-class parents, linger in a postadolescent limbo, dreaming of adventure and escape from their small coastal town. Perpetually unemployed, they waste their lives away by spending their families’ money on drink, women, and nights at the pool hall.
items.default_editorial: Vital viewing for Scorsese fans, given its profound influence on Mean Streets, I vitelloni was Fellini’s first great film—some might even say his greatest. Restless in the tender languor of summer’s end, five vain, immature youths dream of escape in this coming-of-age classic from a cinematic titan.

items.title: 3 Faces
items.short_synopsis: Filmmaker Jafar Panahi and actor Behnaz Jafari travel to a tiny village after receiving a plea for help from a girl whose family has forbidden her from studying acting. Amusing encounters abound, but they soon discover that the local hospitality is rivaled by the desire to protect old traditions.
items.default_editorial: After the success of Taxi Tehran, Jafar Panahi embarks on an ingenious, meta road movie across Iran’s landscapes, swerving between fiction and documentary. A poetic and political meditation on truth, this subtle homage to the late master Abbas Kiarostami won Best Screenplay in Cannes.

items.title: A Hero
items.short_synopsis: Rahim is in prison because of a debt he was unable to repay. During a two-day leave, he tries to convince his creditor to withdraw his complaint against the payment of part of the sum. But things don’t go as planned.
items.default_editorial: Few filmmakers can sculpt a moral drama with such unerring precision as Asghar Farhadi (A Separation). Winner of the Grand Prix at Cannes, A Hero finds the Iranian maestro at his nail-biting best, stacking cultural codes of honor and obligation into a house of cards for a masterclass in suspense.

items.title: A Serious Man
items.short_synopsis: The story of an ordinary man’s search for clarity when his life begins to come apart at the seams. Struggling for equilibrium, he seeks advice from three different rabbis. Can anyone help him cope with his afflictions and become a righteous person, a mensch, a serious man?
items.default_editorial: One of the Coens’ finest dark comedies, this is a thrillingly unpredictable parable of the chaos and cruelty that rears its head in everyday existence. Featuring some of the brothers’ funniest characters, this eccentric vision of Jewish-American life in 1960s suburbia is profound in its mysteries.

items.title: A Touch of Sin
items.short_synopsis: Four people in different provinces are driven to violent ends: An angry miner is enraged by corruption in his village. A migrant discovers the possibilities of owning a firearm. A receptionist is pushed beyond her limits by an abusive client. A young factory worker goes from one job to the next.
items.default_editorial: Famed for his elegant portraits of modern China, Jia Zhangke made a sudden switch, combining arthouse neorealism and kung-fu vengeance into an angry political firebomb. This highly controversial look at unchecked power—which the Chinese government tried to suppress—won Best Screenplay at Cannes.

items.title: A White, White Day
items.short_synopsis: In a remote Icelandic town, an off-duty police chief begins to suspect a local man of having had an affair with his late wife, who died in a tragic accident two years earlier. Gradually his obsession for finding out the truth takes over his life and begins to endanger himself and his loved ones.
items.default_editorial: Hlynur Pálmason’s (Winter Brothers) engrossing second feature marked the arrival of a major new voice in international cinema. Upending revenge-thriller genre tropes, the film is a simmering, profound story of grief—aided by a quietly heartbreaking performance from Ingvar Eggert Sigurðsson.

items.title: After Yang
items.short_synopsis: When his young daughter’s beloved companion—an android—malfunctions, a father searches for a way to repair him. In the process, he discovers the life that has been passing in front of him, reconnecting with his wife and daughter across a distance he didn’t know was there.
items.default_editorial: In this wistful, intelligent drama, an invigorating dance scene is the surprising catalyst for a family crisis. Ruminating on both cross-cultural adoption experiences and the ethereal power of loved ones’ mementos, Kogonada’s film is a testament to sci-fi’s capacity for tender human insight.

items.title: Aguirre, the Wrath of God
items.short_synopsis: The legend of El Dorado, a land rich in gold, tempts Gonzalo Pizarro to lead an expedition beyond the Andes in 1560. Forced to halt, two men are sent downriver with a patrol. When their rafts are damaged, one decides to return to the camp, while Aguirre leads a mutiny and takes charge of the patrol.
items.default_editorial: A trip into the heart of darkness, Herzog’s mix of historical storytelling and documentary styling delivers an immediacy rarely found in period tales. Anchoring the brutal, bleakly farcical dissection of colonial arrogance and cruelty is Klaus Kinski’s hypnotizing madman with delusions of grandeur.

items.title: All the Beauty and the Bloodshed
items.original_title: All the Beauty and the Bloodshed
items.short_synopsis: Nan Goldin, celebrated photographer and opioid crisis activist, reflects on her life through slideshows, interviews, and archival footage. From her formative years in New York’s art scene to her present-day campaign against the Sackler family, she traces her evolution as both artist and advocate.
items.default_editorial: Ablaze with determination and verve, Laura Poitras’s collaboration with artist and activist Nan Goldin was the second documentary ever to win the Golden Lion at Venice. Tracing a lifetime of raw survival and passionate protest, it is an ardent ballad to our autonomy from Goliath-like power.

items.title: American Animals
items.short_synopsis: Kentucky, 2004. Spencer and Warren dream of remarkable lives beyond their middle-class suburban existence. In college, Spencer discovers his school’s priceless rare book collection and recruits Warren to help steal it—launching one of the most audacious art heists in recent history.
items.default_editorial: Director Bart Layton has always been fascinated by the ways documentary can intersect with storytelling, and this sophomore feature blends nonfiction with dramatic reconstructions to riveting ends. Starring the brilliant Barry Keoghan, American Animals is a thrilling tale of rich kids gone wild.

items.title: And Then We Danced
items.short_synopsis: Merab, a devoted dancer, has been training for years with his partner Mary for a spot in the National Georgian Ensemble. The arrival of another male dancer, Irakli, sparks both an intense rivalry and romantic desire that may cause Merab to risk his future in dance as well as his relationships.
items.default_editorial: Before traveling to Istanbul for Crossing, Levan Akin turned to Georgia for a different story of longing. With its impressionistic depiction of desire and stirring dance sequences, this silky, intimate film frees the local conservative folk-dance scene up to queer pleasures and daring allusions.

items.title: Apples
items.short_synopsis: As an unpredictable, sweeping pandemic causes people to develop sudden amnesia, a man finds himself enrolled in a recovery program designed to help him build a new life. His treatment: performing daily tasks prescribed by his doctors on cassette tape, and capturing each task with a Polaroid camera.
items.default_editorial: An amnesia pandemic is the backdrop for this subtly poignant and elegantly composed tragicomedy. The deadpan debut of former Yorgos Lanthimos collaborator Christos Nikou, Apples is an allegorical meditation on memory, identity and technology that heralds a profound new voice in the Greek Weird Wave.

items.title: Atlantics
items.short_synopsis: Along the Atlantic coast, Ada is in love with Souleiman. But she has been promised to another man. One night, Souleiman and his co-workers leave the country by sea, in hope of a better future. Several days later, a fire ruins Ada’s wedding and a mysterious fever starts to spread.
items.default_editorial: The French-Senegalese actor and filmmaker Mati Diop became the first Black female director to premiere in the Cannes competition with this shimmering feature debut. Winning the Grand Jury Prize, Atlantics is at once a stunningly immersive spectral love story and a piercing work of spiritual realism.

items.title: Babyteeth
items.short_synopsis: When seriously ill teenager Milla falls madly in love with small-time drug dealer Moses, it’s her traditional parents’ worst nightmare. But Milla’s first brush with love brings her a new lust for life, and she begins to show everyone in her orbit how to live like you have nothing to lose.
items.default_editorial: First love is already messy—and in Shannon Murphy’s sensational feature debut, it crashes into other angst-inducing obstacles too. Featuring some of Australia’s finest working actors, this electric drama resists easy mawkishness, and finds unique ways to salvage poignant beauty from pain.

items.title: Bacurau
items.short_synopsis: Bacurau, a settlement in rural Brazil, is shaken by its matriarch’s death. But something strange is happening, the water supply has been cut off, and the village has disappeared from satellite maps completely. Under threat from an unknown enemy, Bacurau braces itself for a brutal fight for survival.
items.default_editorial: From Kleber Mendonça Filho (Aquarius) and Juliano Dornelles comes a daring, intoxicating blend of neo-Western, siege thriller and political allegory—powerfully resonating with today’s Brazil, where the film was a box-office hit! A winner of the Cannes Jury Prize, starring Udo Kier and Sônia Braga.

items.title: Being 17
items.short_synopsis: Damien and Thomas are French teenagers from very different upbringings who go to the same school but can’t stand each other. When circumstances bring Damien’s mother Marianne to invite Thomas to live with them, the young men have to work through their emerging attraction and complicated desires.
items.default_editorial: Some two decades after Wild Reeds, André Téchiné revisits the subject of queer adolescent desire with this intimate, hyper-naturalistic drama. Co-written by Céline Sciamma, and set against the breathtaking backdrop of the French Pyrénées, Being 17 is a poignantly sensitive coming-of-age epic.

items.title: Belgica
items.short_synopsis: The story of two brothers who, even though they have absolutely nothing in common, open a bar together that quickly becomes a regular hangout for nighthawks. Despite this success, the two brothers must soon face up to the difficulties inherent in running a family business.
items.default_editorial: Felix van Groeningen won a Directing Prize at Sundance for his intoxicating dive into the nightlife of a bar, and the rise and fall of the two brothers that run it. Set to a Soulwax soundtrack, this electrifying yet sobering look at the rock’n’roll life shows the wild partying, and what comes after.

items.title: Blind
items.short_synopsis: After losing her sight as an adult, Ingrid begins a slow retreat from the world. Encapsulated in the safety of her home, a place where she can feel in control, alone with her husband and her thoughts. She builds fictions around the memory of the things she could once see, but these soon take over.
items.default_editorial: The fascinating sightless heroine of Norwegian screenwriter Eskil Vogt’s feature debut is a simmering figure that embodies both imagination and sorrow. A sensitive, intriguing leap to the director’s chair by the screenwriter of Oslo, August 31st and Louder than Bombs.

items.title: Blue Is the Warmest Color
items.short_synopsis: Teenager Adèle’s life is turned upside down the night she meets Emma, a young woman with blue hair, who will allow her to discover desire, to assert herself as a woman and as an adult. In front of others, Adèle grows, seeks herself, loses herself, finds herself…
items.default_editorial: In one of the most extraordinary film performances in modern cinema, Adèle Exarchopoulos soars as a young woman exploring her sexuality in this masterful coming-of-age chronicle. Winner of the 2013 Palme d’Or for Kechiche and, in a Cannes Film Festival first, Exarchopoulos and co-star Léa Seydoux.

items.title: Brownian Movement
items.short_synopsis: Charlotte and Max live in Brussels with their son. The couple hits a crisis when Max discovers that Charlotte has been having short but intense affairs with her patients. Charlotte goes into therapy and has to give up her job as a doctor, and the pair try to start their lives over together.
items.default_editorial: As a woman with desire to spare and opaque motivations, Sandra Hüller is the stunning center of this erotically charged, quietly daring drama. In a tripartite structure of surgical precision, Nanouk Leopold’s rigorous and provocative fourth feature lays the fact of female sexuality brazenly bare.

items.title: Cairo Conspiracy
items.short_synopsis: Adam, the son of a fisherman, is given the chance to study at a prestigious university in Cairo. Shortly after his arrival, the institution’s Grand Imam suddenly dies, rendering him a pawn in the power struggle between Egypt’s religious and political elite.
items.default_editorial: Sweden’s entry for Best International Feature at the Oscars® in 2022, this tense thriller from Tarik Saleh took the Best Screenplay award at Cannes. An inspired spin on the classic murder mystery, Cairo Conspiracy is a thrilling tale of intrigue and corruption set among Egypt’s political elite.

items.title: Dark Inclusion
items.short_synopsis: Petty Paris-based thief Pier Ulmann comes from a family of powerful diamond dealers based in Anvers. After his estranged father’s death, he vows vengeance against his relatives who had abandoned him, returning to the business with an elaborate robbery in mind.
items.default_editorial: Puncturing its drum-tight tension with impromptu fits of violence, this directorial debut from Anatomy of a Fall co-writer Arthur Harari is an ice-cool revenge thriller. Through minatory tracking shots and startling twists, Dark Inclusion dredges the moral morass synonymous with a life of crime.

items.title: Early Spring
items.short_synopsis: In postwar suburban Tokyo, Shoji, a restless office worker, begins an affair with his colleague Chiyo, straining his marriage to Masako. As workplace gossip spreads and tensions grow at home, Shoji struggles with the consequences of his choices.
items.default_editorial: With the postwar workforce forgoing home for office, lustful glances are risked on the morning commute in this moving film. Chronicling a generation in search of distraction, Yasujirô Ozu contours the ennui of the young and restless, as they grasp at the ineluctable desires that shape a life.

items.title: Eros
items.short_synopsis: Three tales of love and sex take place around the world. In Hong Kong, a sex worker and tailor start an impossible game of seduction. In Tuscany, a man on vacation with his wife falls in love with an unknown woman. While in LA, an advertiser tells a psychologist about a woman he dreamt about.
items.default_editorial: Bringing together renowned cinema masters Wong Kar Wai, Steven Soderbergh, and Michelangelo Antonioni, this star-studded, sexually charged anthology traverses the mysterious realm of the senses. From carnal delights to the pleasurable pain of yearning, Eros boldly delivers all the flavors of love.

items.title: Everybody Loves Jeanne
items.short_synopsis: Everybody has always loved Jeanne. These days, she hates herself. Up to her ears in debt, she has to go to Lisbon and sell her mother’s apartment, who passed away one year ago. At the airport, she runs into Jean, a whimsical and somewhat intrusive former high school classmate.
items.default_editorial: Drawing the romcom in vibrant new colors, Céline Devaux switches well-worn battles of the sexes for an animated tussle between rival world views. As a relatable cynic and an eccentric optimist, Blanche Gardin and Laurent Lafitte fizz with perfect chemistry in this Cannes-selected, delightful debut.

items.title: Far from Heaven
items.short_synopsis: In 1950s Connecticut, Cathy and Frank Whitetaker, the very picture of a suburban family, face a marital crisis and mounting racial tensions in the outside world. Cathy is faced with choices that spur gossip within the community and change several lives forever.
items.default_editorial: Channeling the Technicolor melancholy of Douglas Sirk’s melodramas, Todd Haynes’s lush period piece is driven by a yearning for love in an era stifled by prejudice. Ravishing as the picture-perfect 1950s housewife, Julianne Moore masterfully unmasks the cracks beneath the gloss of domestic bliss.

items.title: Flavor of Green Tea Over Rice
items.original_title: お茶漬けの味 | Ochazuke no aji
items.short_synopsis: In postwar Tokyo, secrets and deceptions strain the already fragile relationship of a childless, middle-aged couple as Taeko’s city-bred sophistication clashes with her husband Mokichi’s small-town simplicity. Meanwhile, the arrival of Taeko’s modern, headstrong niece shakes up their household.
items.default_editorial: Modernity and small-town tradition collide in this poignant domestic drama from Yasujirô Ozu. Shot on the streets of postwar Tokyo, and released a year before the career-defining Tokyo Story, The Flavor of Green Tea Over Rice is an exquisitely modulated tale of a marriage coming apart at the seams.

items.title: Hatching
items.short_synopsis: 12-year-old gymnast Tinja is desperate to please her demanding mother. Her mother runs a popular blog where she obsessively shows the world how perfect her family is. When Tinja discovers a strange egg, she takes it home to keep it warm. But when the egg hatches, a shocking discovery follows.
items.default_editorial: A time of both emotional and physical metamorphoses, the thorny passage of early adolescence takes on an avian dimension in Hanna Bergholm’s unnerving debut. A modern-day fairy tale mixed with body horror gore, Hatching charges at the tyranny of parental expectations with sharp claws.

items.title: Hell or High Water
items.short_synopsis: When brothers Tanner and Toby become in danger of losing their ranch, they embark on a series of well-planned robberies on small local banks. Because the amounts are always small, the brothers stay out of harm’s way—until almost-retired Texas ranger Marcus gets involved in the case.
items.default_editorial: Before Yellowstone established Taylor Sheridan as TV’s leading genre revisionist, his screenplay for this propulsive thriller outfitted the heist movie in neo-western garb. Nick Cave and Warren Ellis lay down the score, while Jeff Bridges delivers a performance that ranks among his late-career best.

items.title: Jiro Dreams of Sushi
items.short_synopsis: Jiro Ono, a chef in his eighties, owns the only sushi restaurant to hold three Michelin stars. Located in a Tokyo metro station, it only has seating for 10 guests who have to reserve a month in advance to enjoy the delicacies prepared before their eyes by the esteemed sushi master.
items.default_editorial: It’s rare to describe a film as “mouth-watering,” but this one definitely fits the bill! A crowd-pleasing documentary hit with a surprising depth of soulfulness, it explores food-as-art with a perfectionist at the core. Jiro was later expanded by the filmmaker into the series Chef’s Table.

items.title: Lean on Pete
items.short_synopsis: Charley Thompson, a teenager living with his single father, gets a summer job working for horse trainer Del Montgomery. Bonding with an aging racehorse, Charley is horrified to learn he is bound for slaughter, and so he steals the horse, and the duo embark on an odyssey.
items.default_editorial: A sublime literary adaptation from British filmmaker Andrew Haigh (45 Years), this intimate drama aches with a deep yearning to belong, hindered by precarious living conditions. Shot in an ever-changing Portland, intense connections and shattering losses are articulated with an unfussy simplicity.

items.title: Leila's Brothers
items.short_synopsis: At 40 years old, Leila has spent her whole life taking care of her parents and her four brothers. The family argues constantly and is crushed by debts, in a country caught in the grip of international economic sanctions. As her brothers are trying to make ends meet, Leila formulates a plan.
items.default_editorial: Pulsating with political fervor reflecting the tensions of modern-day Iran, this epic family saga from Saeed Roustayi (Just 6.5) fiercely depicts the deep corruption of a society through the lens of a woman. A mesmerizing work comparable in scope to Visconti’s masterpiece Rocco and His Brothers.

items.title: Little Girl
items.short_synopsis: 7-year-old Sasha has always known that she is a girl. Sasha’s family has recently accepted her gender identity, embracing their daughter for who she truly is while working to confront outdated norms and find affirmation in a small community of rural France.
items.default_editorial: Shot in a vérité style, this groundbreaking portrait of a young trans girl traces a family’s struggle for acceptance in the face of bigotry and bureaucracy. Sébastien Lifshitz’s frank yet nuanced study of gender dysphoria winds up as a blistering state-of-the-nation diagnostic on identity.

items.title: Lou Reed's Berlin
items.short_synopsis: A searing song cycle about two lovers going to pieces in the shadow of the Berlin Wall, Lou Reed’s Berlin was greeted by a chorus of rebuke upon its release in 1973. In, 2006, Reed played the album live for the first time, taking a five-night stand at St. Ann’s Warehouse in Brooklyn, New York.
items.default_editorial: Lou Reed refused to perform his misanthropic masterwork for 33 years. Berlin, a cinematic album of doomed love, had been a critical failure, and was simply too painful to bear. Julian Schnabel captures its triumphant return to the stage in this prismatic concert film of pure rock ‘n’ roll swagger.

items.title: Louder Than Bombs
items.short_synopsis: The fractious family of a father and his two sons confront their different feelings and memories of their deceased wife and mother, a famed war photographer. Three years after her unexpected death, when an unsettling secret resurfaces, the three men are forced to look at each other in a new light.
items.default_editorial: In his English-language debut, Norwegian director Joachim Trier (The Worst Person in the World) meticulously pieces together this fragmented family drama. An ambitiously elliptical tragedy of memory and grief, the film stars Gabriel Byrne, Jesse Eisenberg, and none other than Isabelle Huppert.

items.title: Lucky
items.short_synopsis: Having out-lived and out-smoked all of his contemporaries, the cantankerous, fiercely independent and self-reliant 90-year-old atheist Lucky finds himself at the precipice of life, thrust into a journey of self-exploration, leading towards that which is so often unattainable: enlightenment.
items.default_editorial: Reflecting on ageing while celebrating life through carefree humor, Lucky sees the late Harry Dean Stanton in his first leading role since Wenders’ Paris, Texas. A moving love letter to one of America’s great character actors, starring his friend (and longtime collaborator!) David Lynch.

items.title: Maggie's Plan
items.short_synopsis: Maggie is a thirty-something New Yorker who, without success in finding love, decides now is the time to have a child on her own. But when she meets John, a married novelist, Maggie falls in love. Maggie kickstarts a new plan that catapults her into a nervy love triangle with John and his wife…
items.default_editorial: Intellectual and romantic conundrums wittily collide in Rebecca Miller’s pitch-perfect New York comedy, a remarkable gem from Greta Gerwig’s acting career. Delicately structured around a revolving door of relationships, Maggie’s Plan smartly reimagines contemporary motherhood and the modern family.

items.title: Margin Call
items.short_synopsis: Ahead of the 2008 financial crisis, investment firm analyst Peter Sullivan uncovers sensitive information that could plunge the entire business into peril. Over the next 24 hours, Sullivan realizes that the decisions he makes will affect not only his colleagues but the lives of everyday Americans.
items.default_editorial: Director J.C. Chandor made his feature debut with this sizzling inside take on the subprime mortgage crisis. With a starry ensemble cast that includes Paul Bettany, Demi Moore, and—on glorious, leonine form—Jeremy Irons, Margin Call is a Mametian procedural that trades in ruthless moral detachment.

items.title: Midsommar
items.short_synopsis: Dani and Christian are a young couple on the rocks. But after tragedy keeps them together, Dani invites herself to join Christian and his friends’ trip to a rural Swedish midsummer festival. What begins as an idyllic retreat quickly devolves into an increasingly violent and bizarre competition.
items.default_editorial: Florence Pugh was propelled to stardom thanks to her unforgettable role in Midsommar, which sees her deal with devastating grief, a murderous Swedish cult, and a terrible boyfriend. Shockingly bright and subtly disturbing, Ari Aster’s horror is an exquisitely crafted nightmare in broad daylight.

items.title: More Than Ever
items.short_synopsis: Hélène and Mathieu have been together for many years and live a happy and hectic life in Bordeaux. When Hélène becomes seriously ill, she is faced with an existential decision and decides to travel alone to Norway to seek peace—an act that will test the strength of their love.
items.default_editorial: Desire to live free, whatever the sacrifice, lies at the heart of Vicky Krieps’s star persona. In a performance that is as bracing as glacial water on tender skin, she channels that longing feeling into Emily Atef’s crystalline story of acute illness, lost intimacies, and the kindness of strangers.

items.title: Much Loved
items.short_synopsis: In present-day Marrakech, Noha, Randa, Soukaina, and Hlima make a living through sex work. Living together, the friends navigate wild parties, corrupt police, and exploitative pimps—overcoming the violence of a society that takes advantage of them while at the same time condemning them.
items.default_editorial: This unvarnished portrait of a group of sex workers takes a frank look at the relationship between sex, money, power, and freedom. Vibrant performances capture the turbulent maelstrom of emotions that comes with a demanding life, but also the resilience of clear-eyed women who have no use for pity.

items.title: Mud
items.short_synopsis: Ellis and his friend Neckbone are two boys who meet a fugitive hiding on an island in the Mississippi. Skeptical but intrigued by his fantastic scenarios, Ellis and Neckbone agree to help him.
items.default_editorial: Continuing the prescient vision of white-American masculinity of Take Shelter, director Jeff Nichols teamed with an expert cast (McConaughey! Witherspoon!) for this fable of youth and romance in the heartland. With shades of crime films of old, Mud is familiar yet entirely renewed and sincere.

items.title: New Order
items.short_synopsis: In contemporary Mexico City, a lavish high society wedding is interrupted by violent rioters who take the house by siege. It soon becomes apparent that this seemingly random attack is part of a violent, nationwide uprising, as one political system collapses and a more harrowing replacement arises.
items.default_editorial: Mexican cinema’s foremost provocateur Michel Franco detonates a bomb of dystopian chaos and outrage with this Venice Silver Lion-winning thriller. An electrifying tempest of working-class revolution with a sting in its tail, New Order is a nerve-jangling political allegory of apocalyptic potency.

items.title: Onoda: 10,000 Nights in the Jungle
items.short_synopsis: Japan, 1944. Hiroo Onoda is sent to a small island in the Philippines where the Americans are about to land. His role will be to wage a guerilla war until the return of the Japanese troops. The Empire will surrender soon after, but for Onoda and his men, the war will go on for 10,000 more days.
items.default_editorial: Patriotism curdles into dangerous delusion in Arthur Harari’s immersive portrait of a tragic real-life figure. Saturated cinematography lends a surreal, artificial look to this absurd tale, while bringing out its beauty: isolated by paranoia, soldiers find comfort in their loyalty to one another.

items.title: Pity
items.short_synopsis: Initially stricken when his wife passes into a coma, a soft-spined lawyer begins to draw a sense of satisfaction from all the compassion, kindness, and attention of his peers. He soon becomes addicted to their pity, so much so that he now feels unhappy when happy—and happy only when unhappy.
items.default_editorial: With its fixed-position camerawork, peculiar line delivery, and lashings of gallows humor, Babis Makridis’s sophomore feature is unmistakably the progeny of the Greek Weird Wave. Co-written by Efthymis Filippou (Dogtooth), Pity is a compelling dark comedy played with a perversely straight face.

items.title: Pride
items.short_synopsis: Margaret Thatcher is in power and the National Union of Mineworkers is on strike. At the Gay Pride March in London, a group of gay and lesbian activists decides to raise money to support the families of the miners. But there’s a problem—the Union seems embarrassed to receive their support.
items.default_editorial: The unlikely alliance of a young LGBTQ+ community and small-town miners results in this witty and light-hearted political comedy. Based on a true Thatcher-era story, British director Matthew Warchus’s optimistic film conveys the high-spirited feeling of being united in a common cause.

items.title: Rabbit Hole
items.short_synopsis: In the suburbs of America, Becca and Howie Corbett, once a picture-perfect couple, struggle to return to their everyday existence several months after the loss of their child. Embarking on separate journeys, Becca and Howie make increasingly unexpected choices that threaten to pull them apart.
items.default_editorial: Rocketing to cult movie stardom by turning his musical Hedwig and the Angry Inch into a film, John Cameron Mitchell serves as the directing hand behind this unpredictable exploration of grief starring Nicole Kidman. An evocative, quietly unraveling domestic drama that will catch you by surprise.

items.title: Rafiki
items.short_synopsis: In Nairobi, Kenya, Kena and Ziki long for a life beyond their circumstances. Despite the political rivalry between their families, the two girls support each other in pursuing their dreams within a conservative society. But Kena and Ziki face a difficult choice when love blossoms between them.
items.default_editorial: Despite being banned in its country of origin, Rafiki dazzled audiences in Cannes and became the first Kenyan film to premiere at the festival. Vibrant and sizzling with the excitement of first love, this lesbian teen romance takes a stand against homophobic laws while remaining utterly joyful.

items.title: Rams
items.short_synopsis: Brothers Gummi and Kiddi are sheep farmers living on neighbouring farms in Iceland. They haven’t spoken to each other for 40 years. Following an outbreak of a potentially lethal disease for sheep, the government insist they have to be slaughtered. The brothers must reunite to save their way of life.
items.default_editorial: This winner of the Un Certain Regard competition in Cannes is a perfect example of Nordic deadpan, highlighted by the stark and vast landscapes of rural Iceland. A tale of brotherly rivalry that combines dry humor, intense emotions and crescendo intrigue, supported by two remarkable performances.

items.title: Richard III
items.short_synopsis: In 1930s England, a brutal civil war erupts with the Houses of Lancaster and York battling for control of the throne. Amid the turmoil, the despotic Richard, Duke of Gloucester, plots his own route to power, deviously scheming a murderous agenda to ascend as dictator monarch.
items.default_editorial: Ian McKellen brings his landmark theatrical performance to the screen for a triumphant take on Shakespeare’s antiheroic tragedy. Costarring Kristin Scott Thomas and Robert Downey Jr., this dynamic adaptation streamlines the text for a propulsive charge through the grubby antechambers of sovereignty.

items.title: Saint Laurent
items.short_synopsis: Over a decade, spanning 1967 to 1976, the legendary French fashion designer Yves Saint Laurent enters an era of freedom. In a dark, hedonistic, and wildly creative time, the couturier moves through a string of ateliers and nightclubs whose centers of gravity all seem to realign around him.
items.default_editorial: Daring director Bertrand Bonello fashioned this stylish biopic of French designer YSL through episodic, period-detail perfection. Flaunting a starry cast with the late Gaspard Ulliel at its helm, Saint Laurent is an intoxicating ride through the performative artifice of fashion.

items.title: Steamboat Bill, Jr.
items.short_synopsis: While Steamboat Bill Sr. is a hard-working steamboat captain, his son is the opposite: educated, accident-prone, and simple-minded. However, Steamboat Bill Jr. might be able to assist his father in overcoming a rival local business – and win the affections of the rival’s daughter while he’s at it.
items.default_editorial: Buster at his peak! One of the most beloved, iconic comedies in a career full of them, Steamboat Bill Jr. was Buster Keaton’s last independent production before joining MGM, and contains some of the slapstick master’s most elaborate set-pieces. Silent comedy neophytes, step right up!

items.title: Still the Water
items.short_synopsis: In the aftermath of a typhoon on the Japanese island of Amami Ōshima, teenager Kaito discovers a tattooed body washed ashore. Meanwhile, his girlfriend Kyoto must deal with the approaching death of her mother, an island shaman. Together, the pair struggle to find their place in the world.
items.default_editorial: Retracing her ancestry back to Japan’s southern island of Amami Ōshima, Naomi Kawase touchingly set this meditation of youth in her family’s originating community. Calling it her own masterpiece, Kawase envelops one in a rare distillation of nature and existence painted upon a canvas of pure calm.

items.title: Suspiria
items.short_synopsis: A darkness swirls at the center of a world-renowned dance company, one that will engulf the artistic director, an ambitious young dancer, and a grieving psychotherapist. Some will succumb to the nightmare. Others will finally wake up.
items.default_editorial: Luca Guadagnino’s (Call Me By Your Name) electrifying horror film stars Tilda Swinton and Dakota Johnson in a new take on the 1977 original cult classic, with a mesmeric score by Radiohead’s Thom Yorke! Prepare for your skin to crawl with gory, erotic and hallucinatory splendour.

items.title: Sweet Bean
items.short_synopsis: Grumpy Sentaro runs a small bakery that serves dorayaki, pastries filled with sweet red bean paste (“an”). When an old lady, Tokue, offers to help in the kitchen, he reluctantly accepts. She will soon prove to have magic in her hands. Thanks to her secret recipe, the little business flourishes.
items.default_editorial: From director Naomi Kawase comes this small but heartfelt feel-good movie, an affecting tale of friendship that asks us to remember the simple pleasures in life. Gentle and absorbing throughout, the film features a beautifully controlled performance by the late Japanese actor Kirin Kiki.

items.title: Synecdoche, New York
items.short_synopsis: Life is looking bleak for theater director Caden Cotard—his wife has left him and a strange disease is taking over his body. But after winning a MacArthur Genius Grant, Caden relocates to a giant warehouse and buries himself in a theatrical epic about his own life, set in a life-size replica of NYC.
items.default_editorial: Charlie Kaufman, the writing hand behind some of Spike Jonze’s most praised brain-teasers—Being John Malkovich, Adaptation—made his directing debut with this dreamlike, profound portrait of a creative mind in artistic crisis. Featuring a towering performance from the late Philip Seymour Hoffman!

items.title: The Assistant
items.short_synopsis: Jane, a college graduate and aspiring film producer, has landed her dream job as an assistant to an entertainment mogul. As she follows her daily routine, she grows aware of the abuse that colors every aspect of her workday, an accumulation of degradations against which she decides to take a stand.
items.default_editorial: Based on interviews with many female assistants, Kitty Green’s slow-burn #MeToo thriller depicts a pervasive office culture fuelled with fear and abuse. A film from the post-Weinstein era, the visceral discomfort captured by Julia Garner’s staggering performance stays with you long after viewing.

items.title: The Big Sick
items.short_synopsis: Pakistan-born comedian Kumail Nanjiani and grad student Emily Gardner fall in love but struggle as their cultures clash. When Emily contracts a mysterious illness, Kumail finds himself forced to face her feisty parents, his family’s expectations, and his true feelings.
items.default_editorial: Starring funnyman Kumail Nanjiani, who co-wrote the semi-autobiographical script with Emily V. Gordon, this loveable hit revitalizes the romantic comedy genre. Besides hilarious faux pas, the endearing awkwardness of multicultural courtship also brings out unexpected moments of warmth and sincerity.

items.title: The Broken Circle Breakdown
items.short_synopsis: Elise and Didier fall in love at first sight. They bond over their shared enthusiasm for American music and culture, and dive headfirst into a sweeping romance that plays out on and off stage—but when an unexpected tragedy hits their new family, everything they know and love is tested.
items.default_editorial: Felix Van Groeningen’s devastating portrait of a family coming together and falling apart tugs at the heartstrings like a passionate love song. Punctuated by entrancing musical performances, this raw romantic drama jumps between past and present with all the force of longing and regret.

items.title: The Chaser
items.short_synopsis: Joong-ho is a dirty detective turned pimp in financial trouble as several of his girls have recently disappeared without clearing their debts. While trying to track them down, he finds a clue that the vanished girls were all called up by a same client whom one of his girls is meeting with right now.
items.default_editorial: A streak of dark humor runs through this noirish serial killer mystery, which marked an auspicious debut for South Korean director Na Hong-jin. Gut-wrenching violence meets ludicrously intense foot chases in an absurd but stylish world of corrupt cops and bizarre coincidences.

items.title: The End of the Tour
items.short_synopsis: In 1996, Rolling Stone reporter David Lipsky begins a five-day interview with acclaimed novelist David Foster Wallace following the publication of his groundbreaking epic, Infinite Jest. As the days progress, a tenuous yet intense relationship develops between the journalist and his subject.
items.default_editorial: A compassionate biography that swerves convention, The End of the Tour is anchored by two ambitious lead performances and a sharp, observational screenplay. James Ponsoldt fashions a literary road movie that finds humor and a pensive melancholy in the intangibility of fame and the creative process.

items.title: The Enigma of Kaspar Hauser
items.original_title: Kaspar Hauser - Jeder für sich und Gott gegen alle
items.short_synopsis: Kaspar Hauser lives locked in a cellar, where he cannot see or speak to anyone. One day, a mysterious man pulls him out, teaches him to walk and talk, and then leaves him in the middle of a town square with a letter in his hand addressed to the authorities. Kaspar’s journey begins…
items.default_editorial: Werner Herzog won the Grand Prix at Cannes for this comic, wondrous adventure from lifelong isolation out into the world, starring Berlin street musician Bruno S. in the lead role. In German, the title is Every Man for Himself and God Against All—it doesn’t get much more Herzogian than this!

items.title: The General
items.short_synopsis: After being rejected by the Confederate military, not realizing it was due to his crucial civilian role, an engineer must single-handedly recapture his beloved locomotive after it is seized by Union spies and return it through enemy lines.
items.default_editorial: Regularly hailed as one of the greatest comedies ever committed to celluloid, Buster Keaton’s slapstick jewel uses a real-life incident from the American Civil War as the backdrop for bold and ingenious physical comedy. With a wildly climactic chase scene that earned its place in cinema history.

items.title: The Grandmaster
items.original_title: Yut doi jung si | 一代宗师
items.short_synopsis: In 1930s China, Ip Man is celebrated as the grandmaster of Wing Chun. During a competition, he wins the affection of Gong Er, a master of the northern Chinese martial arts tradition. But the occupation by Japanese troops separates the two, and they will only meet again after the war ends.
items.default_editorial: A martial-arts historical drama that balances an intimate, perceptive romantic drama with complexly choreographed high-wire action sequences, this is Wong Kar Wai working on a much larger and livelier scale, making a film as philosophical and poetic as it is unforgivingly kick-ass.

items.title: The Innocent
items.short_synopsis: Abel, a museum educator and widower, is at his wits’ end when his mother Sylvie rushes into a marriage with Michel, a convict she met while teaching drama at the local prison. Abel disapproves, and he decides to stalk his new stepfather, bringing along his best friend Clémence for the ride.
items.default_editorial: Louis Garrel returns to the director’s chair, spinning the heist movie, family farce, and romantic comedy into a gamboling confection. With riotous support from an exuberant Noémie Merlant, this lively caper film brings warmth and humor to its high-spirited examination of the things we do for love.

items.title: The Lodge
items.short_synopsis: A soon-to-be-stepmom snowed in with her fiance’s two children at a remote holiday village. Just as relations finally begin to thaw between the trio, strange and frightening events threaten to summon psychological demons from the woman’s strict religious childhood.
items.default_editorial: For their English language debut, the directing team behind Austrian cult horror Goodnight Mommy takes to a snowbound cabin for a nightmare of a family getaway. Led by an unforgettable Riley Keough, this twisted tale of secrets and lies trembles under the terrifying grip of religious paranoia.

items.title: The Misfortunates
items.short_synopsis: 13-year-old Gunther lives with his father and uncles at his grandmother’s house. Growing up, he faces alcoholism, womanizing and shameless slacking. Everything suggests that Gunther is bound to suffer the same fate. Does he still have the opportunity to escape the misfortune of his family?
items.default_editorial: This adaptation of a bestselling Belgian semi-autobiographical novel depicts a peculiar childhood, fueled by alcohol, rejection, and love. Both disturbing and highly entertaining, this bittersweet coming-of-age drama emphasizes the humor rather than the grit and finds tenderness amid the chaos.

items.title: The Most Dangerous Game
items.short_synopsis: When legendary hunter Bob Rainsford is shipwrecked on the perilous reefs of a mysterious island, he finds himself the guest of the reclusive Count Zaroff. Very gracious at first, Zaroff eventually forces Rainsford and two other survivors to participate in a sadistic game of cat and mouse…
items.default_editorial: Before hitting it big (really big) with King Kong, Ernest Schoedsack and Merian Cooper teamed up for this cult classic, which, in the tradition of Hollywood’s best pre-Code horror movies, is eerie fun and deeply, wonderfully strange.  Co-starring the original scream queen Fay Wray!

items.title: The Old Man and the Gun
items.original_title: The Old Man and the Gun
items.short_synopsis: At 70, Forrest Tucker executes an audacious escape from San Quentin prison and embarks on an unprecedented string of heists.  Wrapped up in the pursuit are detective John Hunt, who becomes captivated by Forrest’s commitment to his craft, and Jewel, who loves him despite his chosen profession.
items.default_editorial: A tribute to Robert Redford’s timeless and easygoing charm, David Lowery’s delightfully romantic crime-comedy is a sweet and soothing gem. Mischievously reveling in a well-earned nostalgia for a type of cinema and star all too rare today, The Old Man and the Gun will steal your heart away.

items.title: The Sisters Brothers
items.short_synopsis: Oregon, 1851. At the height of the Gold Rush, infamous gunslingers Charlie and Eli Sisters find themselves doing the bidding of their villainous boss. Hired to chase down an elusive prospector holding a pivotal secret, the assassins embark on a challenging quest.
items.default_editorial: Who would have thought that French filmmaker Jacques Audiard (A Prophet, Rust and Bone) would direct a Western with Joaquin Phoenix & John C. Reilly as quarreling brothers? A surprising and highly rewarding adventure, The Sisters Brothers is a fun and touching reimagining of a hypermasculine genre.

items.title: The Ugly Stepsister
items.short_synopsis: Seemingly plain but ambitious Elvira is pushed by her mother to win over a vain prince and save their family. But when her stunning stepsister Agnes becomes a rival, Elvira is driven to extremes. As the royal ball nears, she must face the harsh truths of the world she longs to belong to.
items.default_editorial: Festering with maggots and tapeworms, this majestically gruesome feature debut from Norwegian writer-director Emilie Blichfeldt guts facile fantasies of inner beauty. Adapting the timeless tale, this body-horror spin on Cinderella writhes with the darkness of the Grimm Brothers’ original vision.

items.title: The White Ribbon
items.original_title: Das weiße Band - Eine deutsche Kindergeschichte
items.short_synopsis: In a rural German village in 1913, brutal authority is enforced by the baron and the pastor. Malevolent occurrences involving the upper class gradually take on the character of a punishment ritual. A school teacher investigates and slowly discovers the incredible truth.
items.default_editorial: Tracing the genesis of a fascist ideology as it develops and swiftly proliferates in a small community, Michael Haneke’s riveting Palme d’Or winner is a prescient, perhaps timeless parable. A compelling drama, conveyed in stark black-and-white cinematography, co-written with Jean-Claude Carrière.

items.title: The Young Karl Marx
items.short_synopsis: Paris in 1844: Karl Marx lives in exile with his wife Jenny. When he is introduced to Friedrich Engels, he has nothing but contempt for the son of a factory owner. But the dandy Engels proves to be the last piece of the puzzle that Marx needs to create a new political movement.
items.default_editorial: Co-written with the legendary Pascal Bonitzer, Raoul Peck’s engaging period piece chronicles the starting point of a friendship that changed the course of history. A light-hearted biopic celebrating the vibrant intellectual milieu of the early-19th-century and the legacy of Marx and Engels.

items.title: Thelma
items.short_synopsis: A young, religious student, moves to Oslo to attend university. As she tries to deny her feelings for a female friend, she suffers from a number of powerful seizures, and it’s not long before she begins to realise that her condition is caused by a mystery supernatural ability.
items.default_editorial: With an electrifying romance at its heart, Thelma plunges deep into its titular character’s soul to unleash long suppressed demons. Exquisitely blending the supernatural with the psychological, Trier has concocted a slow-burning Scandi update of De Palma’s Carrie likely to take your breath away.

items.title: Three Days of the Condor
items.short_synopsis: When bookish CIA analyst Joe Turner finds his coworkers murdered, he’s lured into a deadly trap and forced to go on the run. Taking stranger Kathy Hale hostage, he eventually gains her trust and together they work to uncover a conspiracy and find out who he can truly trust.
items.default_editorial: This superlative conspiracy thriller from the genre’s golden age follows the fallout from Robert Redford’s bad day at the office. Autumnally frosted and engulfed in a fog of post-Watergate malaise, Three Days of the Condor is a neurotically propulsive study in sex, death, and Deep State paranoia.

items.title: Tokyo Story
items.short_synopsis: An aging couple, Tomi and Sukichi, journey to visit their two adult children in Tokyo. The reception is disappointing: too busy to entertain them, their children send them off to a health spa. After Tomi falls ill, they return home, while the children, grief-stricken, hasten to be with her.
items.default_editorial: A masterpiece in radical subtlety, Yasujiro Ozu’s Tokyo Story is less concerned with plot than it is feeling. Crafted in his compassionate, contemplative style, this sensitive, quiet miracle of a film patiently reveals universal truths: about families, and moreover, the cycles and rhythms of time.

items.title: Tokyo Twilight
items.short_synopsis: In 1950s Tokyo, college student Akiko unexpectedly becomes pregnant, while her older sister Takako, recently separated, returns to their family home. As they uncover the existence of their long-lost mother, Akiko struggles to accept the painful truth of being abandoned as a child.
items.default_editorial: Four years after his “Noriko” trilogy, Yasujirô Ozu reunites its iconic actors Setsuko Hara and Chishû Ryû in his final black-and-white film. But this one belongs to Ineko Amira, who embodies the unshakable anguish of inherited shame with exquisite torment, turning to dens of mahjong, sake, and sin.

items.title: Under the Tree
items.short_synopsis: Agnes throws Atli out and does not want him to see their daughter Ása anymore. He moves in with his parents, who are involved in a bitter dispute over their tree that casts a shadow on the neighbours’ deck. As Atli fights for the right to see his daughter, the clash with the neighbours intensifies.
items.default_editorial: This deadpan comedy-noir about neighbourhood warfare quickly spirals into much darker territory. Under the Tree captures the simmering tensions and uneasy resentments bubbling up in Reykjavik’s suburbia with bone-dry humour and an eye for the offbeat, the macabre, and the absurd.

items.title: Vox Lux
items.short_synopsis: In 1999, teenage Celeste survives a violent high-school shooting. After singing at a memorial service, she transforms into a famous pop star with the help of her songwriter sister and talent manager. By 2017, adult Celeste is mounting a comeback after a scandalous incident that derailed her career.
items.default_editorial: Dive into the definitive portrait of stardom in our Age of Terror, where the glitter of pop drowns in a surge of fame and violence. A soul-stirring satire, featuring a bewildering Natalie Portman as the XXI century celebrity, Jude Law, Sia’s songs, Scott Walker’s score & Willem Dafoe’s narration!

items.title: Wind River
items.short_synopsis: When wildlife officer Cory Lambert discovers the body of a young woman on Wyoming’s Wind River Native American reservation, FBI agent Jane Banner investigates. Banner hires Lambert as her tracker, and the two must brave the isolated winter terrain and local criminal underworld to crack the case.
items.default_editorial: Following acclaimed screenplays for Sicario and the Oscar®-nominated Hell or High Water, Taylor Sheridan made his directorial debut with this dolorous murder mystery. Starring Elizabeth Olsen and Jeremy Renner, Wind River coats the old-school crime thriller with a brumal neo-western sheen.

items.title: Woman at War
items.short_synopsis: Fifty-year-old Halla seemingly leads a quiet existence. However, she is actually a radical eco-activist who has declared a one-woman-war on the local aluminium industry. In the midst of her environmental crusade, Halla receives the surprising news that her application to adopt a child was approved.
items.default_editorial: Magical realism meets dark humor in this fable-like eco-thriller that has been garnering acclaim since its Cannes debut. Director Benedikt Erlingsson and actress Halldóra Geirharðsdóttir have created a heroine both of the moment and for the ages: wise, defiantly empowered and profoundly humane.

items.title: You Only Live Once
items.short_synopsis: Joan, the secretary to the public defender in a large city, is in love with a career criminal named Eddie. She believes that he is a basically good person who just had some tough breaks. After she uses her influence to get him released early, they get married and he attempts to go straight.
items.default_editorial: Austrian-born auteur Fritz Lang’s second Hollywood film is a thrilling, pioneering melodrama with Sylvia Sidney & Henry Fonda. With its great influence on cinematic versions of Bonnie and Clyde, Lang’s taut, romantic masterpiece stands as yet another testament to the great films he made in America.

items.title: You Were Never Really Here
items.short_synopsis: The tormented veteran Joe tracks down missing girls for a living. However, when he sets out to rescue the kidnapped daughter of a US Senator from a sex trafficking ring, things go horribly wrong. As he finds himself weathering a storm of corruption and vengeance, nightmares start to overtake him.
items.default_editorial: After a six year absence, Lynne Ramsay returned with this stripped-to-the-bone adaptation of Jonathan Ames’ muscular novella. Featuring a powerhouse lead performance from Joaquin Phoenix, and a mesmerising Jonny Greenwood score, this enigmatic thriller is a triumph of form and psychological texture.

items.title: You're Sleeping, Nicole
items.short_synopsis: Making the most of the family home while her parents are away, Nicole, 22 years old, is enjoying a peaceful summer with her best friend Véronique. When Nicole’s older brother shows up with his band to record an album, the girls’ friendship is put to the test.
items.default_editorial: Stumbling towards self-discovery, a young woman drifts between prickly friendships and romantic possibilities in Stéphane Lafleur’s luminous, slyly comic drama. As attuned to millennial ennui as Frances Ha, this Quebecois gem basks in the dreamy lethargy of summer, and the pleasure of wasting time.

items.title: About Dry Grasses
items.short_synopsis: Disenchanted art teacher Samet longs to escape his quiet Anatolian village, wrestling with unfulfilled ambitions and accusations of misconduct at school. A budding friendship with Nuray, a charismatic fellow teacher, offers solace, but jealousy arises when her affection shifts to another colleague.
items.default_editorial: Merve Dizdar won the Best Actress award in Cannes for her shattering performance in this generously portioned drama from Turkish maestro Nuri Bilge Ceylan. Nimbly mapping the erotic and spiritual tensions of small-town life, About Dry Grasses is a novelistic wonder of Chekhovian scope and intimacy.

items.title: Caught by the Tides
items.original_title: Feng liu yi dai | 风流一代
items.short_synopsis: In 2001, Qiaoqiao makes a small living as a singer and nightclub dancer in Datong, an industrial city in China. When her lover Bin leaves Datong without a word in search of a better life, Qiaoqiao begins a decades-long search that spans the whole nation along its profound social transformations.
items.default_editorial: Time, memory, and decades of accelerating modernity fold in on themselves in this dazzling coup de cinéma from director Jia Zhangke. Comprised of footage shot over twenty years—with star Zhao Tao, as ever, front and center—Caught By the Tides glides through the slipstream of China’s 21st century.

items.title: No Bears
items.short_synopsis: Jafar Panahi plays a fictionalized version of himself, who has relocated to a rural border town in Iran to remotely direct a new film in nearby Turkey. While there, he finds himself thrust in the middle of a local scandal, confronting the opposing pulls of tradition and progress.
items.default_editorial: Clandestinely shot in an open defiance of censorship, Jafar Pahani’s crowning masterpiece probes the power–and the limitations–of cinema in a culture ruled by fear. Railing against the forbidding rigidity of physical as well as ideological borders, No Bears is a miraculous work of political dissent.

items.title: The Monk and the Gun
items.short_synopsis: The Kingdom of Bhutan is to become a democracy and holds a mock election as a training exercise. In the town of Ura, an old lama orders a monk to get a gun to face the imminent change in the kingdom. Meanwhile, an American collector is in search of a valuable gun that falls in the lama’s hands.
items.default_editorial: Following his Oscar®-nominated debut Lunana: A Yak in the Classroom, Pawo Choyning Dorji returns to rural Bhutan for his sophomore feature, an intricate mosaic of wittily converging stories. At once a political satire and a picturesque fable, this is an offbeat look at a nascent nation in flux.

items.title: The Zone of Interest
items.short_synopsis: The commandant of Auschwitz, Rudolf Höss, and his wife, Hedwig, strive to build a perfect life for their family in a house and garden next to the camp. When a promotion threatens to undo everything the family has built, Hedwig refuses to leave their dream home.
items.default_editorial: Awarded with the Oscar® for Best International Feature Film, this chilling masterwork marks Jonathan Glazer’s return to the big screen after a ten-year absence. Starring Sandra Hüller, and with a haunting score by Mica Levi, The Zone of Interest is a profound interrogation of mankind’s darkest hour.

items.title: Lek and the Dogs
items.short_synopsis: In his adaptation of Hattie Naylor’s play Ivan and the Dogs, experimental filmmaker Andrew Kötting travels to the Chilean desert to recreate the life of the young boy who left his Moscow apartment to live with a pack of wild dogs. A crossover between narrative film and contemporary art piece.
items.default_editorial: Another marvellous oddity from British avant-garde extraordinaire Andrew Kötting, Lek and the Dogs is an experiential meditation on trauma and society’s shortcomings through the multi-layered tale of a man choosing dogs over humans. Is this an antidote or a companion piece to Isle of Dogs?

items.title: Mary is Happy, Mary is Happy
items.original_title: Mary is Happy, Mary is Happy
items.short_synopsis: A cheerful title for a playful, jittery film. The story that emerges is that of Mary, who is grappling with the the vicissitudes of life in her senior year of secondary school. Confused, but incredibly witty, fun and very freely acted. A Twitter comedy.
items.default_editorial: The first film adaptation of a Twitter stream! A delirious coming-of-age tale that makes 410 consecutive real tweets from an anonymous teen its narrative device. Fragmented and unpredictable as teenagehood itself, ferociously contemporary, and very moving. Wes Anderson & Michel Gondry would love it.

items.title: On Body and Soul
items.short_synopsis: Two introverted people, both workers at an abattoir, find out by chance that they share the same dream every night. At first, they are puzzled and incredulous, but as they begin to accept this strange coincidence, they try to recreate in broad daylight what happens in their shared subconscious.
items.default_editorial: After an 18-year hiatus, Ildikó Enyedi returned to directing with this serene, astute dissection of loneliness, taking home the top prize at Berlinale and an Oscar® nomination for best foreign language film. An unexpected love story suffused with surreal beauty and an undercurrent of black humour.

items.title: Ruined Heart: Another Lovestory Between a Criminal & a Whore
items.original_title: Pusong Wazak: Isa Na Namang Kwento Ng Pag-ibig Sa Pagitan Ng Puta At Kriminal
items.short_synopsis: Boy meets girl. But no, it’s not about that or the giddiness of a new romance. It’s about untimely death (no one’s sure of anything these days), true love, soul mates. It’s about the gun and the rose. Genre bending. Heart breaking. An avalanche of colors. Deadpan romance. Lips syncing, singing.
items.default_editorial: Directed by Khavn, one of our favorite Filipino New Wave filmmakers, and shot by the great Christopher Doyle, Ruined Heart is a sincere mosaic of what feels like every emotion the filmmaker has encountered. A film of boundless energy and explosive color that you won’t be forgetting anytime soon!

items.title: Slack Bay
items.short_synopsis: Northern France, 1910. The bourgeois Van Peteghem family return to their towering mansion above ‘Slack Bay’ every summer. An unlikely romance blossoms between the mischievous Bille Van Peteghem and local mussel-gatherer, ‘Ma Loute’. Meanwhile, a series of mysterious disappearances are taking place.
items.default_editorial: No one’s enjoying Dumont’s foray into comedy more than us. The former king of New French Extremity has proven to take slapstick like a duck to water with this darkly twisted, hysterically funny whodunnit meets class satire. Plus—to close our devoted tribute—Binoche like you’ve never seen her before.

items.title: The Other Lamb
items.short_synopsis: Deep in the woods, an all-female cult called the Flock is presided over by a single man, Shepherd. Selah, a devoted young believer on the brink of maturity, finds her faith tested as dark visions begin to reveal the fates awaiting the women as they age.
items.default_editorial: In her English language debut, award-winning Polish director Małgorzata Szumowska impeccably crafts a folk horror coming-of-age set in a religious cult. Raffey Cassidy’s haunting performance anchors this allegorical fable of fading faith and toxic masculinity with echoes of The Witch and Midsommar.

items.title: The Romantic Barber
items.short_synopsis: It is the story of a neighborhood barber who begins to rebuild his emotional life from the death of his mother. His life revolves around his house and the hairdresser until one day, by chance, he’ll get to travel to Rio de Janeiro.
items.default_editorial: What happens when the unexciting routine of small-town life gets interrupted by an unexpected family visit? The third feature by Mexican writer-director Iván Ávila Dueñas – who also edited the film – is a strangely compelling, poignant cross-over between character study and road movie.

items.title: A Proletarian Winter's Tale
items.short_synopsis: Three Georgians have to clean a castle where an arms manufacturer’s art collection is on exhibit. They aren’t welcome at the opening party and are banished to the attic, but downstairs the splendid buffet attracts them. Why not just ignore the unfair prohibition and cross the line of class society?
items.default_editorial: Julian Radlmaier’s playful short film takes aim at class relations in uncanny scenarios involving black holes, revolution, séances, and high-society parties. Informed by a whimsical fairy-tale sensibility, A Proletarian Winter’s Tale confirms Radlmaier’s status as a distinctive new cinematic voice.

items.title: A Strange Path
items.short_synopsis: A young filmmaker returning to his hometown is caught off guard by the rapid onset of a pandemic and must find his father, whom he hasn’t spoken to in over ten years. After their first meeting, strange things begin to happen.
items.default_editorial: A prizewinner at the Tribeca Film Festival, Guto Parente’s stunning piece of pandemic cinema fuses the autobiographical with the experimental. Awash with surreal, hallucinatory images, this soul-bearing exploration of generational difference unleashes the dormant specters of unhealed traumas.

items.title: Basic Sanitation, The Movie
items.short_synopsis: A small community of descendants of Italian immigrants in the interior of the state of Rio Grande do Sul resorts to making a video to try to solve the problems of basic sanitation that plague their village.
items.default_editorial: Caught in the maze of Brazilian bureaucracy, a ragtag group of ordinary townsfolk discover an extraordinary loophole in Jorge Furtado’s charming hit comedy. Starring a hilarious Fernanda Torres as the naive yet obstinate leader, this is a loveable ode to the scrappy magic of guerilla filmmaking.

items.title: Brainstorm
items.short_synopsis: Like every teenager, Neto enjoys small acts of rebellion. But he is misunderstood by his strict parents. Fearing they are losing control, they commit Neto to a psychiatric hospital, where he experiences an inhuman reality and undergoes emotions and horrors that he never imagined could exist.
items.default_editorial: Shot on handheld cameras and pulsing with life, Laís Bodanzky’s unflinching debut feature is a vital cri de coeur against heavy-handed parenting and intergenerational mistrust. Rodrigo Santoro’s all-or-nothing performance captures the exhilaration of youth and the will to survive.

items.title: Bye Bye Brazil
items.short_synopsis: A motley crew of traveling performers on the Caravana Rolidei rolls into various towns across Brazil’s northwestern Amazonian landscape, entertaining locals who still have no access to television. Accordionist Ciço and his wife Dasdô join the lively caravan, leading to a string of adventures.
items.default_editorial: As colorful as the patterns on the caravan, Carlos Diegues’ rollicking road movie follows a ragtag troupe of musicians, magicians and rumba queens across a country on the cusp of change. This Cinema Novo classic is an ardent love letter to the sights and sounds of Brazil—with music by Chico Buarque!

items.title: Chamada a Cobrar
items.short_synopsis: Clarinha is a wealthy lady who enjoys a comfortable life in the city of São Paulo. The peace and tranquility of this upper-middle-class woman ends when she answers a phone call from an alleged kidnapper who has kidnapped her daughter.
items.default_editorial: Anna Muylaert continues her perceptive study of society and motherhood in this pulse-quickening film. Hauling her well-heeled protagonist out of humdrum existence and into a thriller with a brazen con artist, the Brazilian filmmaker sets in motion a mordant tale of extortion and sudden volatility.

items.title: Conversation Piece
items.original_title: Gruppo di famiglia in un interno
items.short_synopsis: A retired professor lives alone in luxurious Rome apartment, withdrawn from the world and accompanied only by his art.  His seemingly peaceful existence is shattered when he’s convinced to rent out space to a group of young lodgers.
items.default_editorial: Approaching 70, the great Luchino Visconti reunited with Burt Lancaster, the star of his Palme d’Or winner The Leopard, to offer this wry and exquisite chamber piece. One of cinema’s irreplaceable masters contemplates a new world in this modestly scaled yet conceptually rich drama.

items.title: Doce Amianto
items.short_synopsis: Inhabited by her delusions and unbridled hope, Amianto lives isolated in her own fantasy world, where her ingenuity and melancholy coexist hand in hand. After feeling abandoned by her love, The Boy, Amianto finds shelter in the presence of her dead friend, Blanche.
items.default_editorial: Rendered through baroque lighting and playfully garish digital effects, the aesthetics of queer melancholy get a colorful makeover in Guto Parente’s brazenly passionate film. Embracing the melodrama and the irony of love with open arms, Doce Amianto is an irresistible ode to the hopelessly romantic.

items.title: Drained
items.short_synopsis: A pawn shop proprietor buys used goods from desperate locals—as much to play perverse power games as for his own livelihood. However, when the perfect rump and a backed-up toilet enter his life, he loses all control.
items.default_editorial: Lending his irresistible charm to a darkly comic personification of narcissism, Selton Mello delivers a masterfully complex performance in Heitor Dhalia’s acidic portrait of male ego. In a materialistic world where everything, including lust, is quantified and monetized, even morality has a price.

items.title: El mar la mar
