items.short_synopsis: Representing the sensory experience of landscape, fauna and climate, this anthropological essay about border crossings explores the harrowing journeys of undocumented migrants crossing the inhospitable and arid Sonoran Desert—a strategic point of passage located between Mexico and the USA.
items.default_editorial: Combining chilling audio interviews and 16mm images of the Sonoran Desert, this engrossing documentary offers a damning portrait of the U.S. and Mexico border crisis. From directors Joshua Bonnetta and J.P. Sniadecki, El mar la mar_ is an immersive portrait of the conditions endured by migrants.

items.title: Four Days in September
items.short_synopsis: Fernando and César join rebel group MR8 in order to fight Brazilian dictatorial regime during the late 1960s. When César is captured during a bank holdup, Fernando decides to kidnap the American ambassador in Brazil and ask for the release of fifteen political prisoners.
items.default_editorial: This Oscar®-nominated and gripping political thriller stars the great Alan Arkin, and is lauded as one of Bruno Barreto’s best films. Based on a true story, it looks at activism and political action under military rule, daring to ask the controversial question of whether the end justifies the means.

items.title: General Della Rovere
items.short_synopsis: In wartime Italy, Emanuele Bardone cons his fellow Italians by promising to help find their missing loved ones in exchange for money. But when the Nazis force him to impersonate a dead general in prison to extract information from fellow inmates, Bardone finds himself wrestling with his conscience.
items.default_editorial: For his postmortem of Italian attitudes under Nazi occupation, Roberto Rossellini cast fellow neorealist auteur Vittorio De Sica in a staggering lead performance. A Golden Lion winner at Venice, this searing masterwork examines the thin lines between cowardice and heroism, fiction and documentary.

items.title: Instinct
items.short_synopsis: Psychologist Nicoline starts work at a secure men’s rehab facility and meets Idris, a charming, manipulative sex offender nearing probation. While others trust him, Nicoline remains skeptical. As her intrigue escalates to infatuation, Nicoline recognizes in Idris something unsettled in herself.
items.default_editorial: Before the steamy Babygirl, Halina Reijn delves into another taboo liaison with her combustible directorial debut, a provocative reconfiguration of the erotic thriller. Circling a cat-and-mouse game of attraction tinged with violence, Instinct plumbs the uncomfortable depths of self-destruction.

items.title: L'âge d'or
items.short_synopsis: A surrealist tale of a man and a woman who are passionately in love with one another, but their attempts to consummate their love are thwarted by their families, the Church, and the bourgeois society.
items.default_editorial: Scorpions, lust, etiquette, war—his final collaboration with Dalí finds Luis Buñuel at a peak, offering up a provocative, darkly funny, and cheerfully blasphemous look at a “civilized” society about to tear itself apart.  An essential classic of cinema, beckoning new viewers to take the plunge.

items.title: La Haine
items.short_synopsis: A regular housing estate with no specific problems wakes up one morning in a state of siege after learning that a 16-year-old resident, Abdel, is between life and death after being injured by a police inspector. Three of his friends wander around the city, waiting for news about his well-being.
items.default_editorial: Mathieu Kassovitz was just 27 when he rose to prominence for directing this provocative urban odyssey. Casting a searing look at police brutality and marginal lives on the brutal outskirts of Paris, La haine marked a prescient, full-throttle entry in the now ubiquitous banlieue film.

items.title: Long Distance Relationship
items.short_synopsis: A man has an obsessive fantasy of having sex with extraterrestrial beings. His quest leads him to Brazil, where he enters into an alien phone sex program to edge him closer to his out-of-this-world desires.
items.default_editorial: Melding conspiracy thriller, hand-drawn animation, and erotic confession, this short is a sticky concoction. Laying bare the bizarre nature of lust, Carolina Markowicz’s atmospheric film peers at a fixation that lies on the troubling edge between hard science and boundless imagination.

items.title: Love in the City
items.short_synopsis: Six separate episodes exploring themes of love, sex and romance in the Italian capital. A provincial dance hall. An investigative reporter posing as a husband-to-be. A young unwed mother. Girl-watching techniques of Italian men. A glimpse into prostitution.
items.default_editorial: Michelangelo Antonioni joined forces with six directors—including Fellini—for this amorous anthology film. Made while neorealism was on the wane, but before his ascension to cinema’s Valhalla with his modernist masterpieces, Love in the City is a fascinating testament to a master’s evolving style.

items.title: Love Me Forever or Never
items.original_title: Eu Sei Que Vou Te Amar
items.short_synopsis: Young and recently separated couple meet in a modern house and start discussing their past relationship.
items.default_editorial: For her starring role in Arnaldo Jabor’s volatile drama, Fernanda Torres made history as the first Brazilian to win the Best Actress prize at Cannes. Circling a combative pair of former lovers, this tale of obsession bristles with an erotic charge, a flurry of torrid caresses, and heated quarrels.

items.title: My Own Private Hell
items.short_synopsis: Deusimar’s bar is very special. The kind of place where the bartender wears a pink rabbit suit and the vocalist doesn’t quite make the notes. Gay, straight, dragqueen or Disney fan: here people can live out their dreams to the full, surrounded by flashing Christmas lights and pink glitter trimmings.
items.default_editorial: Pedro Diogenes and Guto Parente’s glamorous yet low-budget wonder brings to life the lurid world of dive-bars and down-and-outs who dream of better things. Yuri Yamamoto shines as the Campari-swigging tranvestite owner of the Inferninho in this empathetic queer ode to community and camaraderie.

items.title: Nosso Diário
items.short_synopsis: The film presents behind-the-scenes footage of the film adaptation of Lavoura Arcaica (2001), which includes the creative process of the director and actors. Raquel Couto was Carvalho’s assistant director in the production.
items.default_editorial: Bolstered by an insider’s perspective, Raquel Couto’s idiosyncratic making-of documentary dives into the rigorous rehearsals and casting process behind an evergreen classic of Brazilian cinema. Instead of an observational approach, unusual visual effects render onset footage beguilingly enigmatic.

items.title: Postponed
items.short_synopsis: After three people die, their first step in the afterlife is to meet with a death consultant. During this session, the consultant allows each of them to ask one question about anything they desire.
items.default_editorial: Hubris is on trial in Carolina Markowicz’s gripping and mischievous short, featuring tales of greed, impatience, and credulity. Brought together by a playful, high-concept scenario, these pitiful stories form a poignant and darkly comic exploration of primal fears and existential questions.

items.title: Quando o Tempo Cair
items.short_synopsis: An elderly man lives in a cramped apartment with his unemployed son and a young grandson too young to grasp their struggles. Hoping to ease the family’s burdens, he sets out to find work—but soon discovers a world that has left him behind.
items.default_editorial: Selton Mello drew praise for his turn in the Oscar®-winning I’m Still Here (2024), but he is also a fine director, impressing with this laudably poised debut short shot on 16mm. Subverting actor Jorge Loredo’s fame as a zany Casanova on Brazilian TV, this impactful drama shatters the heart.

items.title: Que Teus Olhos Sejam Atendidos
items.short_synopsis: Documentary on the research for the production of the film Lavoura Arcaica (2001), based on the novel of the same name by Raduan Nassar. Two filmmakers take a trip with an uncertain destination through the mountains of Lebanon, Syria and southern Spain.
items.default_editorial: Taking us to the beautiful landscapes that inspired one of his most renowned films, Luiz Fernando Carvalho’s documentary stuns with its visual immediacy, achieved with the use of a digital camera. In this singular travelog, the research process is not a solitary pursuit, but an act of communion.

items.title: Robot Dreams
items.short_synopsis: Dog lives in Manhattan and he’s tired of being alone. One day he decides to build himself a robot, a companion. Their friendship blossoms, and they become inseparable. One summer night, Dog, with great sadness, is forced to abandon Robot at the beach. Will they ever meet again?
items.default_editorial: A colourful, hand-drawn vision of 1980s New York, Pablo Berger’s Oscar®-nominated film swaps dialogue for comical sight gags and delightfully surreal reveries. Imbued with both the charms and the loneliness of big city life, this bittersweet tale of friendship lost and found is a salve for the soul.

items.title: Skinamarink
items.short_synopsis: One night in 1995, 4-year-old Kevin and 6-year-old Kaylee awoke to find their father missing… and the doors and windows of their home gradually disappearing as well. As the hours drag on and the unnerving phenomena pile up, are they truly living a nightmare-and will they ever awaken from it?
items.default_editorial: A word-of-mouth phenomenon, Kyle Edward Ball’s surreal film of nightmare logic is a testament to the experimental possibilities of microbudget horror. Exploiting technological limitations in its unnerving, liminal framing of space, this haunted-house tale taps wickedly into primal fears of the dark.

items.title: Tatuapé Mahal Tower
items.short_synopsis: Javier Juarez Garcia, an Argentinian scale model figure, decides to live in São Paulo to seize the city’s real estate boom. But after a tragedy, he  changes his life and work in architectural models around the world. But he’ll never forget his real goal: come back and take revenge.
items.default_editorial: A playful allegory for the discontentment of life under capitalism, Carolina Markowicz’s colorful short soon flees the confines of metaphor for zanier horizons. As a self-aware figurine narrates its own pursuit of love and happiness, the eye-popping animation explores radical transformations.

items.title: The Hidden Tiger
items.short_synopsis: Juninho, Menor, Neguinho, Adilson and Eldo are young dwellers of Nacional’s neighborhood, Contagem’s suburbs. Divided between work and fun, crime and hope, each one of them will have to find ways to overcome the obstacles and tame the tiger they bring inside their veins.
items.default_editorial: Affonso Uchôa’s (Araby) debut film is a calling card for one of cinema’s finest talents, capturing the hardships of life with a gentle gaze. Casting non-actors from his Brazilian hometown, Uchôa’s strong, social-realist narrative finds beauty in the everyday while remaining politically fierce.

items.title: The Kiss
items.short_synopsis: Upon witnessing a hit-and-run, Arandir, a newlywed banker, tries to help the victim. However, the dying man only has time to make one final request: a kiss. Arandir complies, but his act is seen by his father-in-law, Aprígio, and captured in a photo by Amado Ribeiro, a sensationalist crime reporter.
items.default_editorial: Adapted from an incendiary play by revolutionary writer Nelson Rodrigues, Bruno Barreto’s stunning drama witnesses the breakdown of a family following a shocking tragedy. A scathing indictment of the insatiable tabloid press, The Kiss lays bare the damning cost of kindness in an oppressive society.

items.title: The Man of the Year
items.short_synopsis: In the outskirts of Brazil, shy Máiquel loses a bet and dyes his hair blond—sparking a strange transformation. When he kills a local thug in self-defense, the community hails him as a hero, and Máiquel is pulled into a dangerous new life as an unwilling vigilante.
items.default_editorial: Turning to a life of crime is morbidly tempting in this stylish and eerie vision of turn-of-the-millennium Brazil. As Murilo Benício’s cynical young man sees his dull existence turn into an orgy of drugs, sex, and violence, concepts of identity and free will are provocatively thrown into question.

items.title: The Orphan
items.short_synopsis: Jonathas is a young boy living in a children’s home, waiting to be adopted. He is taken in for a trial period by a married couple, but he is soon ‘returned’ to the home because of his effeminate mannerisms. Jonathas must now come to terms with a new reality.
items.default_editorial: Beautifully capturing the fluidity of identity in dreamy, languid cinematography, this queer short film explores the underside of adoption in subtly devastating terms. A ravishing tale of a young person’s quest for approval and belonging, The Orphan won the Queer Palm award at Cannes Film Festival.

items.title: The Vanquished
items.short_synopsis: A trilogy of stories of well-off youths murderers. A group of high school students kill one of their colleagues for his money, a university student’s involved in smuggling cigarettes and a lazy poet finds the body of a woman on the downs and tries to sell his story to the press.
items.default_editorial: No one does murder like Antonioni! Challenging the accepted rules of film storytelling, this early triumph by cinema’s poet of modern angst foreshadows Blow-Up and is an excellent discovery in its own right. You can feel a rumble—the cinematic revolution of the 1960s was waiting to begin!

items.title: Treason
items.short_synopsis: Three stories of infidelity unfold: a man falls for a married woman, a young girl draws the gaze of her sister’s fiancé, and a husband takes his unfaithful wife hostage after discovering her affair with his best friend.
items.default_editorial: Nelson Rodrigues’s passionate short stories come to vivid life in this torrid adaptation, starring Fernanda Torres alongside her mother, the legendary Fernanda Montenegro. Conjuring a Rio de Janeiro awash with betrayal and illlicit romance, Treason exposes the fragility of traditional relationships.

items.title: Twins
items.short_synopsis: In the 1980s, in Rio de Janeiro, identical twins Iara and Marilena deceive men by pretending to be each other. One day, Marilena meets Osmar, the owner of a school, with whom she falls in love. Iara tries to seduce her sister’s boyfriend starting a rivalry between them.
items.default_editorial: Under the direction of her life and creative partner Andrucha Waddington, Fernanda Torres enthrals in the dual role of mischievous twins, whose childlike games of deception turn macabre. As disorienting as a corridor of mirrors, this warped tale of sisterhood trembles to the seismic force of desire.

items.title: What Now? Remind Me
items.short_synopsis: Joaquim Pinto, who has been living with HIV for more than two decades, looks back at his life in cinema, at his friendships and loves, at the mysteries of art and nature—all of that while undergoing an experimental drug treatment.
items.default_editorial: A longtime luminary working on Portugal’s best films, Joaquim Pinto won the Locarno Jury Prize by stepping in front of and behind the camera for this tender diary film. Living with pain, joy, love, memories: these are but some of the rich textures of this personal, intimately sprawling work.

items.title: Age of Uprising: The Legend of Michael Kohlhaas
items.short_synopsis: In the 16th century in the Cévennes, a horse dealer leads a happy family life. When a lord treats him unjustly, he raises an army and puts the country to fire and sword in order to have his rights restored.
items.default_editorial: As gritty and austere as it is beautiful and explosive, Age of Uprising tells a sweeping story of personal justice coinciding with the decline of feudalism. Mads Mikkelsen’s brooding intensity matches the vengeful determination of the protagonist, resulting in a fiercely compelling performance.

items.title: Django
items.short_synopsis: The lone stranger roams the West, dragging a coffin filled with chaos towards a destiny ruled by vengeance. Sergio Corbucci packs his landmark classic with indelible images, unforgettable performances, and some of the most shocking brutality of any Spaghetti Western ever made.
items.default_editorial: We love Quentin Tarantino’s spaghetti western pastiches as much as the next fan, but there’s no substitute for the real deal. Sergio Corbucci’s Django is so iconic it spawned a slew of false sequels—its dusty, dubbed, and blood covered ingenuity and Franco Nero’s gravitas makes this a classic.

items.title: Gun Woman
items.short_synopsis: After the brutal rape and death of his wife at the hands of Hamazaki’s son, crippled Japanese doctor Mastermind plans an act of revenge. Buying a Japanese meth head young woman, Mastermind rehabilitates her and trains her up to be a highly skilled killer to assassinate Hamazaki’s son.
items.default_editorial: Known for her work in Noboru Iguchi’s horror-comedies, cult favourite Asami Sugiura kicks ass as the titular Gun Woman in the latest of Kurando Mitsutake’s gloriously gory genre films. An extravagant, outrageous punch to the face—an incredible revenge thriller that proves nothing but a blast.

items.title: Lore
items.short_synopsis: After being abandoned by their Nazi parents at the end of World War II, five German siblings embark on a harrowing journey across their war-torn country. Led by the eldest, 14 year-old Lore, the children are forced to confront their parents’ actions and the reality of a new world.
items.default_editorial: This ambitious sophomore feature from Cate Shortland arrived some 8 years after her sensuous debut, Somersault. With an enigmatic score from Max Richter and a powerhouse lead in newcomer Saskia Rosendahl, Lore sees an impressionistic study in collective guilt emerge from the dissolving fog of war.

items.title: Rubber
items.short_synopsis: Robert, an inanimate tire that has been abandoned in the desert, suddenly and inexplicably comes to life. As Robert roams the bleak landscape, he discovers that he possesses terrifying telepathic powers that give him the ability to destroy anything he wishes without having to move.
items.default_editorial: French director Quentin Dupieux (also the musician Mr. Oizo, under which name he composed the film’s soundtrack!) is known for his very own wacky, absurdist style. Set in the barren landscapes surrounding L.A., this irrational parody of a killer-on-the-loose story follows a most unusual subject.

items.title: The Conformist
items.short_synopsis: Set in 1930s Italy, Marcello has spent his life accommodating others, in search for a sense of belonging. When he is drawn into the fascist party, he agrees to assassinate a political refugee who turns out to be his former college professor.
items.default_editorial: Rightly hailed as one of the greatest films ever made, Bertolucci’s masterpiece is both a taut political thriller and a highly sensual and surreal journey through Europe’s troubled past. A huge influence on Coppola, Scorsese and Spielberg, rarely has the psychopathy of violence looked so damn good.

items.title: The Rules of the Game
items.short_synopsis: At the onset of World War II, a weekend at a Marquis’ country château lays bare some ugly truths about a group of haut bourgeois acquaintances. The Rules of the Game is a scathing critique of corrupt French society, cloaked in a comedy of manners.
items.default_editorial: A hugely influential social satire that flits swiftly and effortlessly between comedy and drama, Jean Renoir’s canonical classic strings together expertly crafted and supremely entertaining set pieces, skewering high-society at the eve of the second World War. No less than a masterpiece.

items.title: Touchy Feely
items.short_synopsis: Abby is a massage therapist and a free spirit, while her brother Paul thrives on routine and convention, running a dental practice and enlisting the assistance of his daughter, Jenny. Suddenly, transformation touches everyone, as Abby develops an uncontrollable aversion to bodily contact.
items.default_editorial: What happens when a massage therapist turns out to have a phobia of touching other people’s skin? Playing on our lurking anxieties about human contact, this quirky drama stars alt-indie superstars Elliot Page and Rosemarie DeWitt, and was made by the late, great American independent, Lynn Shelton.

items.title: Alphaville
items.original_title: Alphaville, une étrange aventure de Lemmy Caution
items.short_synopsis: Lemmy Caution is on a mission to eliminate Professor Von Braun, the creator of a malevolent computer that rules a city. Befriended by the scientist’s daughter Natasha, Lemmy must unravel the mysteries of the strictly logical Alpha 60 and teach Natasha the meaning of the word “love.”
items.default_editorial: Leave it to Godard to re-invent sci-fi moviemaking with a New Wave budget, stealing images of modern Paris to throw us into a pop dystopian future. An ingenious mix of futurism, detective noir, and romance, with, of course, Anna Karina along with the indomitable Eddie Constantine as “Lemmy Caution”.

items.title: Archangel
items.short_synopsis: In 1919, one-legged Canadian soldier Lt. John Boles arrives in the northern Russian town of Archangel where Bolsheviks, White Russians and German Huns converge during World War I. When Boles encounters a local woman Veronkha, he faints and becomes convinced that she is his dead wife Iris.
items.default_editorial: Archangel is one of the earliest films from the wizard of Winnipeg, the one and only Guy Maddin. A trip to the Josef von Sternberg era of the early 1930s, where the birth of sound and memories of the First World War yielded singular results—and inspired Maddin’s bewitching alternate history.

items.title: Benediction
items.short_synopsis: Poet Siegfried Sassoon survived the horrors of fighting in the First World War and was decorated for his bravery, but became a vocal critic of the government’s continuation of the war when he returned from service.
items.default_editorial: From wartime resistance to champagne-addled dalliances with thespians and aristocrats, this soul-bearing biopic opens up the intimate life of Siegfried Sassoon. Writing the poet a silver tongue of devastating erudition, Terence Davies lays the emotional battles of this famous English pacifist bare.

items.title: Breathless
items.short_synopsis: Gangster Soon-Hong’s life is a cycle of violence and self-loathing. When he meets schoolgirl Han Yeon-Heui, he not only meets his match, but his possible salvation. Is his lifestyle one he can transcend?
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Tiger Award at the Rotterdam Film Festival, Breathless is the emotionally blistering debut feature of Korean auteur Yang Ik-joon. Featuring a masterful performance by the director himself, the film offers a personal and astute analysis of violence that cuts to the core.

items.title: Calm at Sea
items.short_synopsis: October 1941. Eighteen months into France’s occupation by German troops, young Communist members of the Resistance shoot dead an officer of the German Army. In retaliation, Hitler demands the deaths of 150 Frenchmen, as ‘retribution’.
items.default_editorial: We travel to occupied France of the Second World War with New German Cinema maverick and Palme d’Or-winning director Volker Schlöndorff. No stranger to the urgency of historical drama, Schlöndorff sheds light on a wrenching wartime tragedy infamous in France but relatively unknown here—until now.

items.title: Christmas Eve in Miller’s Point
items.short_synopsis: Four generations of the Balsano family gather for what may be the last Christmas in their family home. As they lose themselves in rowdy celebration, cousins Emily and Michelle sneak away to a winter wonderland, where suburban teenagers find their rebellious paradise.
items.default_editorial: Destined to become a perennial favourite in the yuletide canon, this nostalgic bauble from director Tyler Taormina sparkles with festive magic. A multigenerational portrait of a sprawling Italian-American family, Christmas Eve in Miller’s Point is an effervescent celebration of suburban life.

items.title: Demons
items.short_synopsis: Two girls are given free tickets to a special screening in an isolated movie theater. The film, a violent horror movie, exerts a malevolent influence over the theatre audience, who are transformed into a horde of crazed demons.
items.default_editorial: From Italian master of the macabre Lamberto Bava (son of the great Mario Bava), and co-written and produced by Dario Argento, this film in true 1980s horror fashion turns on pop culture (here, the movies) attacking the audience. Soundtrack by Claudio Simonetti.

items.title: Détective
items.short_synopsis: In a Paris hotel, a hotel detective—fired after a murder took place there—continues to investigate the death, helped by his inspector nephew and girlfriend. Meanwhile, boxing trainer Jim Fox Warner is praying that his boy will win so he can pay back the Mafia.
items.default_editorial: A film from Godard’s 1980s period of reinvention, Détective has images as beautiful as paintings and cleverly fragments shards of movie conventions to forge new critiques. Promising his producers a genre film, they instead got a caustically funny remix of all possible hotel movie mysteries.

items.title: Earth Light
items.short_synopsis: Twenty-year-old Pierre, whose mother died in Tunisia when he was only 5 years old, lives in Paris with his father, a piano teacher. Realising that his life is dull, he leaves the capital in search of his maternal roots, following the trail of the woman who has been missing from most of his life.
items.default_editorial: An achingly romantic vision of wanderlust and unsettled ennui, Earth Light is the most optimistic of Guy Gilles’s features. Like his earlier films, it’s a rhythmic, fragmented study in memory, and how the pleasures of the present moment can stave off the emotional dead-ends of a regretful past.

items.title: Emmanuelle
items.short_synopsis: In a plane taking her to join her diplomat husband, Emmanuelle allows two strangers to use her body. In Bangkok, Bee introduces her to the pleasures of sadism, then Mario initiates her into sexual refinements which make her an expert in the arts of love.
items.default_editorial: A tremendous hit that propelled Sylvia Kristel to international stardom, Emmanuelle made extramarital affairs an instant cause célèbre, and soft-core romps fashionable. Heightened by the beauty of Bangkok and an array of chic outfits, the thrills of this erotic classic are more than just carnal.

items.title: First Name: Carmen
items.short_synopsis: Carmen X, the female member of a terrorist gang, asks her uncle Jean if she can borrow his beachside house to make a film with some friends. In reality, her clan is planning on robbing a bank. During the burglary, Carmen falls in love with a security guard and will attempt to escape with him…
items.default_editorial: Godard stars as an eccentric filmmaker in this fragmentary love poem from his 1980s period. Loosely based on Bizet’s opera, First Name: Carmen reinvents cinema into elliptical broken rhythms and passages of poetry to renew one of the oldest of tales: that of two lovers on the run.

items.title: First Reformed
items.short_synopsis: Ernst Toller, a troubled priest of a small church in upstate New York, begins to spiral out of control after a soul-shaking encounter with Mary and her unstable environmental activist husband. Consumed by thoughts that the world is in danger, Toller embarks on a perilous self-assigned undertaking.
items.default_editorial: That Paul Schrader is a disciple of Bresson and Dreyer is nowhere more evident than in this towering modern classic: a film about America, its histories of violence, and its hopes for redemption. As the spartan protagonist striving for salvation, Ethan Hawke is nothing short of transcendent.

items.title: Funny Pages
items.short_synopsis: Aspiring cartoonist Robert believes to be an artist is to suffer. So, he rejects his suburban life and drops out of school to work at a comic store and a public defender’s office. There he meets and becomes besotted by former low-level comic artist Wallace, leading him down a path of misadventures.
items.default_editorial: A wannabe cartoonist chooses chaos over comfort in this deliciously dark debut feature from writer-director Owen Kline. Produced by the Safdie brothers, and with a grungy aesthetic indebted to the comic-book creations of Robert Crumb, Funny Pages is a brutally funny tale of coming-of-age turmoil.

items.title: Heartbeat Detector
items.short_synopsis: A psychologist, played by Mathieu Amalric, discovers troubling links between Nazism and modern-day big business.
items.default_editorial: A dense, intellectually ambitious drama that only the French could produce! An unbeatable cast (Mathieu Amalric, Michael Lonsdale, Edith Scob, Lou Castel) come together under the cloud of conspiracy to connect contemporary European corporate excess to the legacy of World War II.

items.title: I, Of Whom I Know Nothing
items.original_title: Yo, de quien no sé nada
items.short_synopsis: Filmed during the Autumn and Winter of 2012/2013 at John Calder’s – Samuel Beckett’s London publisher, collaborator and close friend – home in Montreuil. It witnesses his very particular domestic life, as well as his journey to London to visit for the last time legendary actress, Billie Whitelaw.
items.default_editorial: Visiting two legends of the literary avant-garde, the publisher John Calder and actor (and Beckett interpreter) Billie Whitelaw, this documentary portrait casts no judgments and withholds great revelations. Instead, just like a work of Beckett’s, we are left to make sense of what’s left behind.

items.title: In the Court of the Crimson King: King Crimson at 50
items.original_title: In the Court of the Crimson King: King Crimson at 50
items.short_synopsis: One of rock’s most enigmatic bands, King Crimson’s final lineup tours the globe during the group’s 50th anniversary. Through intimate access and candid interviews—past and present—reveal the tensions, dedication, and artistry that have defined the band’s half-century legacy.
items.default_editorial: A Pompeii amphitheater and the rat-a-tat-tat of disciplined practice are background and soundtrack to this good-humored look at serious musicianship. Famously uncompromising, bandleader Fripp takes more than a passing interest in the filmmaking process, and—for one (long) moment—movingly lets go.

items.title: Irreversible
items.short_synopsis: A woman’s lover and her ex-boyfriend take justice into their own hands after she becomes the victim of a rapist. Because some acts can’t be undone. Because man is an animal. Because the desire for vengeance is a natural impulse. Because most crimes remain unpunished.
items.default_editorial: Starring Vincent Cassel and Monica Bellucci, Gaspar Noé’s infamous backtracking revenge thriller is a groundbreaking, frightening provocation that caused much controversy at its premiere in Cannes. A viciously dark story audaciously told, Irreversible is not for the faint of heart!

items.title: Jobriath A.D.
items.short_synopsis: Called “The American Bowie,” “The True Fairy of Rock & Roll” and “Hype of the Year,” Jobriath’s reign as the first openly gay rock star was brief and over by 1975. Now, 35 years later, Jobriath A.D. spotlights his life, music, groundbreaking influence.
items.default_editorial: Documenting the life of an infamous glam rocker, director Kieran Turner examines the megalomaniacal ad campaign used to turn a flamboyant personality into a self-appointed icon. Interrogating the star’s extravagant nonconformity, Jobriath A.D. is a sharp portrait of the hustle for 15 minutes of fame

items.title: Lady Macbeth
items.short_synopsis: England, 1865. Katherine is stifled by her loveless marriage to a man twice her age, and his unforgiving family. When she embarks on a passionate affair with a young worker on her husband’s estate, a force is unleashed inside her so powerful that she will stop at nothing to get what she wants.
items.default_editorial: Florence Pugh broke into the mainstream at age 21 with her revelatory and transfixing performance in William Oldroyd’s Lady Macbeth. Period piece meets thriller in this adaptation of Nikolai Leskov’s 1865 novella, resulting in an uncompromising and subversive story of female revenge.

items.title: Little Big Soldier
items.short_synopsis: In the aftermath of a great battle between rival kingdoms, only two men remain standing: a peasant soldier and a warrior prince, who has been wounded fighting for his country. Tempted by the chance to collect a large reward, the soldier overpowers the prince and sets off to collect his bounty.
items.default_editorial: Part Bruce Lee, part Charlie Chaplin, Jackie Chan has been delighting us for years. But if you only know his Hollywood work, you’re missing out—he’s kept plenty busy at home. This twist on the action epic is a joy, laced with slapstick combat and capped with surprisingly tragic heft.

items.title: Love
items.short_synopsis: Murphy listens to his voicemail: Electra’s mother wants to know whether he has heard from her daughter, now missing for a long time. Murphy finds himself alone in his apartment, reminiscing about the greatest love affair of his life—a burning passion full of promises, games, excesses, and mistakes.
items.default_editorial: We can always rely on enfant terrible Gaspar Noé to raise eyebrows. More than a decade after Irreversible, Noé shocks once more with Love, a fittingly tongue-in-cheek title for this erotic ménage-a-trois drama. Its infamous unsimulated sex scenes with young and unknown actors were shot in 3D!

items.title: Love at Sea
items.short_synopsis: A young Parisian woman falls in love with a sailor she meets on holiday. Whilst the summer brings them together, the autumn pulls them apart. They continue to write to each other but live separate lives, he in Brest with his friends, her in Paris waiting to see him again.
items.default_editorial: Buried treasure from the margins of the nouvelle vague, this poetic enigma sensitively captures young love through changing tides. Shot over three years in nostalgic color and shimmering black and white, Love at Sea is an elliptical marvel, and the first masterwork from French auteur Guy Gilles.

items.title: Maria
items.short_synopsis: After years in the public eye, legendary opera singer Maria Callas withdraws to her Paris apartment, grappling with memories from a tumultuous life.
items.default_editorial: Following his kaleidoscopic portraits of Jackie Kennedy and Princess Diana, Pablo Larraín turns to Maria Callas with this stately biopic of the cultural icon. Portraying the epochal diva in her psychologically brittle final days, Angelina Jolie gives a performance of resounding elemental intensity.

items.title: Oasis: Supersonic
items.short_synopsis: The story of the 1990s rock phenomenon, Oasis, is traced from their explosive rise from working-class Manchester to global superstardom. Told in the band’s own words, archival live footage blends with behind-the-scenes glimpses of fame, chaos, and brotherly strife.
items.default_editorial: This polychromatic documentary pulses with “mad for it” energy, interweaving era-defining highs with backstage horseplay. Cockeyed amateur camerawork and a fond and sweary voiceover capture the craic of happier years, before the band collapsed under its own gravity in a champagne supernova.

items.title: Oh, Woe Is Me
items.short_synopsis: At a Swiss lakeside resort, a book publisher investigates a mysterious tale: the story of a god-like being entering the body of a man, Simon, to experience physical love with his wife, Rachel. Did this happen? Or is Rachel just covering up her infidelity to her husband?
items.default_editorial: Here’s another post-New Wave favorite, and one of Godard’s most philosophically inspired works. Marking his only collaboration with Gérard Depardieu, Oh, Woe Is Me fractures Greek myth and the detective tale to question love and spirit in a fallen world. Legends clash and a strange new film is born.

items.title: Queens of the Qing Dynasty
items.short_synopsis: Star, a suicidal teen now too old for foster care, develops a candid rapport with An, a student from Shanghai assigned to watch over her in the hospital. A nightly exchange of secrets, text messages and possessions quickly expands the boundaries of their relationship, altering their inner chemistry.
items.default_editorial: Countering the iciness of the Canadian healthcare system with love, Ashley McKenzie’s offbeat tale of friendship embraces the turmoil—and the beauty—of neurodiversity and gender nonconformity. Along with the magnetic performers, the ethereal score crafts a potent alchemy of emotions and sensations.

items.title: Relic
items.short_synopsis: When Edna, the elderly and widowed matriarch of the family, goes missing, her daughter Kay and granddaughter Sam travel to their remote family home to find her. Soon after her return, they start to discover a sinister presence haunting the house and taking control of Edna.
items.default_editorial: Spun from the silver cobwebs of a forgotten life, this striking debut by Australian-American filmmaker Natalie Erika James weaves together dust, dread, and tender feeling. At the nervous heart of three generations of women, Emily Mortimer tussles with the horrors of time’s tenacious pull.

items.title: Sasquatch Sunset
items.short_synopsis: In the misty forests of North America, a family of Sasquatches—possibly the last of their enigmatic kind— embark on an absurdist, epic, hilarious, and ultimately poignant journey over the course of one year.
items.default_editorial: The elusive Bigfoot gets its moment in the sun in this one-of-a-kind marvel from writer-director duo the Zellner brothers. An unrecognisable Riley Keough and Jesse Eisenberg star in a primatic character study that dances between scatological absurdism and existential elegy with poignant ingenuity.

items.title: Showing Up
items.short_synopsis: In Portland, sculptor Lizzy prepares for an upcoming exhibition while navigating daily frustrations—from her artist-landlord’s distractions to family pressures and a wounded pigeon. As the show approaches, tensions quietly mount in her carefully balanced life.
items.default_editorial: Sculpting from a creative life and its stubborn interruptions, Kelly Reichardt’s critically adored film models the fine art of understatement. Allowing Michelle Williams the rare pleasure of a performance that grumbles in an introverted minor key, Showing Up deals in small yet profound epiphanies.

items.title: Tales from the Gimli Hospital
items.short_synopsis: Late 19th century. A smallpox epidemic ravages Gimli, a small Icelandic-Canadian fishing village on the shores of Lake Winnipeg. In a hospital room, two patients, Einar and Gunnar, become friends at first—but bitter jealousy emerges once they reveal their darkest secrets to one another.
items.default_editorial: Shot on 16mm, this impulsive experiment from Canadian auteur Guy Maddin (My Winnipeg) is a true cult hit from the 1980s—one that echoes David Lynch’s Eraserhead in both form and scope. There has rarely been a movie as unbound by rules yet richly, rewardingly textured as this slow-burning gem.

items.title: The King
items.short_synopsis: Filmmaker Eugene Jarecki takes Elvis Presley’s 1963 Rolls-Royce on a musical road trip from Memphis to New York, Las Vegas, and beyond. Forty years after the King’s death, voices from all walks of life—including Alec Baldwin, Chuck D, Ethan Hawke, and Mike Myers—reflect on his rise and fall.
items.default_editorial: An unchained melody of archive footage, interviews, and rock ‘n’ roll, this searching documentary finds American history echoing through the music of Elvis Presley. Eugene Jarecki’s thought-provoking film holds up the icon as a mirror on the nation—one that may also show its fraught future.

items.title: The Neon Demon
items.short_synopsis: 16-year-old aspiring model Jesse moves to Los Angeles to pursue her dreams and quickly finds herself working with some of the city’s top designers and photographers. But her innocence and youth make her a target of her fellow models, who are willing to go to any lengths to possess Jesse’s X factor.
items.default_editorial: Following two films with Ryan Gosling, Nicolas Winding Refn enlists Elle Fanning for the dazzling, hypnotic Neon Demon—an entrancing and especially stylized indictment of the ugliest grotesqueries of the modelling industry. A visually stunning, self-conscious satire of the horrors of vapidity.

items.title: The Souvenir: Part II
items.short_synopsis: In the aftermath of her relationship with a manipulative older man, film student Julie begins to untangle her fraught love for him in making her graduation film, sorting fact from his elaborately constructed fiction, while also pushing against the constraints of the London independent film scene.
items.default_editorial: For the magnificent conclusion to her autobiographical epic, Joanna Hogg constructs an intricate emotional labyrinth through the formative years of an artist in search of her voice. Starring Honor Swinton Byrne, this dazzlingly reflexive masterwork draws memoir and fantasy into iridescent reverie.

items.title: The Starling Girl
items.short_synopsis: Seventeen-year-old Jem Starling struggles with her place within her Christian fundamentalist community. But everything changes when her magnetic youth pastor Owen returns to their church.
items.default_editorial: A teenager in an isolated religious community is drawn into a dangerous relationship with her charismatic youth pastor in this simmering coming-of-age drama. With a tremendous lead performance from Eliza Scanlen, The Starling Girl examines the bristling tensions between devotion and desire.

items.title: Two Horses of Genghis Khan
items.original_title: Das Lied von den zwei Pferden
items.short_synopsis: An old, broken morin khurr (horse head fiddle) compels renowned Mongolian singer Urna Chahar Tugchi to take a road journey to Ulan Bator and the steppes of Mongolia.
items.default_editorial: Gracefully fusing documentary with fiction filmmaking, The Two Horses of Genghis Khan tracks a vocalist named Urna and her cathartic reconnection with the wealth of beauty contained in her homeland of Mongolia’s culture, society, and landscape in the shadow of the cultural revolution. Essential.

items.title: Wall Engravings
items.short_synopsis: Jeanne and the sensitive Jean have one last rendezvous at the café where they always meet. A few weeks later, Jean’s body is found in the suburbs of Lyon. Unaware of his death, Jeanne confides in her friend Pierre and his father to begin an investigation into the young man’s disappearance.
items.default_editorial: A piercing portrait of doomed romance that trembles with intensity of feeling, Wall Engravings dances between the sensuality of the moment and the haunted halls of memory. A tale of passion and its melancholy ruins, every one of its 68 minutes feels fit to burst with Guy Gilles’ emotional abundance.

items.title: Wildcat
items.short_synopsis: In 1950, twenty-four-year-old writer Flannery O’Connor, recently diagnosed with lupus, visits her mother in Georgia. Desperate to make her mark as a great writer, her crisis pitches her imagination into a feverish exploration of belief—and she dives deeper into her craft.
items.default_editorial: Ethan Hawke’s searching biopic plunges inside the mind of Flannery O’Connor, a writer who let in both the darkness and the light. Her stories got close to the bone of a changing America, and are brought to vivid life here by the director’s daughter, Maya Hawke, and a star-studded supporting cast.

items.title: bluish
items.short_synopsis: Errol and Sasha, two somewhat disoriented characters in their twenties, are each aimlessly drifting through a city’s gloomy winter days. While casting a soft gaze on fragments of their everyday lives, people, stories, places, and realities start to overlap and intertwine.
items.default_editorial: Smudging introversion with a subtle touch, Milena Czernovsky and Lilith Kraxner’s double character study is also an experiment in color. Evoking mood through shades of blue—pensive periwinkle, hesitant cerulean, boldest sapphire—bluish distills the blurred feeling of hovering between phases of life.

items.title: Cairo Time
items.short_synopsis: Juliette is a Canadian magazine editor who arrives in Cairo for a vacation with her husband, a UN official working in Gaza. Delayed, her husband asks his friend, a handsome Egyptian named Tareq, to watch over her. Juliette finds herself falling in love not only with the city but with Tareq.
items.default_editorial: Featuring a transformative performance from the enchanting Patricia Clarkson, Ruba Nadda’s romantic drama is a transnational affair that unravels with endearing charm and stirring wistfulness. The splendor of Egypt is in full bloom, alternating between urban restlessness and poignant tranquility.

items.title: Cell 211
items.short_synopsis: Knocked out during his first day on the job, prison guard Juan awakens to find that his co-workers have abandoned him amid an inmate uprising. Juan must pose as a prisoner in a desperate attempt to survive the ordeal and is soon taken under the wing of Malamadre, the riot’s leader.
items.default_editorial: A prison in the grip of a vicious, blood-spattered riot is the arena for Daniel Monzón’s propulsive storytelling and kinetic approach to craft. Always on the move and seemingly edited with a garrotte wire—don’t be fooled by the quiet, measured opening, there’s no stopping Cell 211 once it kicks off.

items.title: It's a Free World...
items.short_synopsis: Angie, a recently fired job recruiter, decides to launch her own employment agency out of her apartment, catering to local migrants desperate for work. But as she ventures into a world of cheap labor and exploitation, Angie must make some troubling compromises to keep her business alive.
items.default_editorial: From the filmmaking team behind Palme d’Or winners I, Daniel Blake and The Wind that Shakes the Barley, this similarly socially-conscious drama from Ken Loach & Paul Laverty has—in the years since its release—lost little of its relevance. A nuanced take on complex issues of immigration and labor.

items.title: Nothing Personal
items.short_synopsis: Anne leaves her previous life in Holland behind to lead a solitary, wandering existence in Ireland. During her travels, she discovers a house where hermit Martin lives. They close a deal: food in exchange of work. On one condition: no personal contact, no questions. Who will break the deal first?
items.default_editorial: After receiving extensive praise in festivals and winning the Best First Film and Best Actress prizes at Locarno, this film unjustly fell off the radar. Subtly portrayed, repressed emotions become majestic in this heart-wrenching tale set within the wild, ragged landscapes (and faces) of Ireland.

items.title: Quiet Chaos
items.short_synopsis: Aging entertainment industry exec Pietro returns from a beach trip to find his wife dead. Distraught, Pietro renews his dedication to raising his 10-year-old daughter, Claudia. But trouble ensues when he begins neglecting his job, electing to sit on a park bench outside Claudia’s school instead.
items.default_editorial: Starring the wonderful Nanni Moretti in the lead role, Quiet Chaos’ eccentric storyline is the perfect means to explore a panoply of characters, proving that it is our most bizarre thoughts and behaviors that makes us all the more human. This award-winning film is an enchanting and touching delight.

items.title: Shortbus
items.short_synopsis: Sex counselor Sofia has never once had an orgasm. But everything changes when Jamie and James, a gay couple she treats, introduce her to New York’s polysexual sex party scene. As dominatrix Severin helps Sofia to reach climax, Jamie and James’ sex life complicates with the arrival of a third lover.
items.default_editorial: An audacious follow-up to Hedwig and the Angry Inch, John Cameron Mitchell’s Shortbus is both an erotic drama and a sex-comedy, a sprawling ensemble film that approaches the spectrum of sexuality from diverse points of view. Includes bonus shoutout to Nagisa Oshima’s In the Realm of the Senses!

items.title: The Barbarian Invasions
items.short_synopsis: Rémy, a Montreal college professor who is divorced and in his early fifties, learns that he is dying of liver cancer. During his final days, he is reunited with old friends, former lovers, his ex-wife, and his son, as they reflect on their exploits and political ideals.
items.default_editorial: The first Canadian film to win an Academy Award® for Best Foreign Language film, this Québécois hit is both beautifully observant and politically attuned, skillfully balancing comedy and drama. Marie-Josée Croze won the Best Actress prize at Cannes for her intense, tenacious performance.

items.title: The Class
items.short_synopsis: François and his fellow teachers prepare for a new year at a high school in a tough neighborhood of Paris. Neither stuffy nor severe, François’ frankness often takes the students by surprise. But his classroom ethics are put to the test when his students begin to challenge his methods.
items.default_editorial: The surprise winner of the Palme d’Or at Cannes, this riveting schoolroom drama is based on the book by educator-turned-writer François Bégaudeau, who also stars. A revealing and engrossing exposé of the triumphs and challenges of teacher-student relationships in a disadvantaged Parisian school.

items.title: The Wind that Shakes the Barley
items.original_title: The Wind that Shakes the Barley
items.short_synopsis: Ireland, 1920: people unite to form volunteer guerrilla armies to face the ruthless “Black and Tan” squads that are being shipped from Britain to block Ireland’s bid for independence. Damien abandons his burgeoning career as a doctor and joins his brother, Teddy, in a violent fight for freedom.
items.default_editorial: Social realism luminary Ken Loach won his first Palme d’Or for this uncompromising chronicle of the Irish War of Independence and ensuing Civil War starring Cillian Murphy. A rightfully angry film that explores—in stark and shocking detail—Britain’s amnesic relationship to its violent colonial past.

items.title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints
items.original_title: A Guide to Recognizing Your Saints
items.short_synopsis: Set in 1980s Astoria, Queens, Dito, called home after 15 years because his father is ill, encounters old friends—the ones he lost, the ones he left behind the ones he can’t help but remember.
items.default_editorial: A bloody and gripping coming-of-age drama about breaking out and finding your own way in life. With lively performances from Robert Downey Jr. & Channing Tatum, A Guide… presents a strong directorial debut from Dito Montiel, who also wrote the autobiographical book the film is based on.

items.title: Alexander
items.short_synopsis: The King of Macedonia leads his legions against the giant Persian Empire. After defeating the Persians, he leads his army across the then known world, venturing farther than any westerner had ever gone, all the way to India.
items.default_editorial: Oliver Stone’s Alexander, born from the director’s lifelong admiration for the Macedonian king, is a meticulous chronicle of the achievements of Alexander the Great. The huge scale of the battle scenes and the baroqueness of the production design match the richness of the historical material.

items.title: An American Crime
items.short_synopsis: The true story of suburban housewife Gertrude Baniszewski, who kept a teenage girl locked in the basement of her Indiana home during the 1960s.
items.default_editorial: Elliot Page gives a nerve-shredding performance in this provocative true-crime tale first released on Mother’s Day. It was a wilfully subversive bit of counter-programming on the part of its producers, given An American Crime features the most monstrous maternal figure since Mommie Dearest.

items.title: Applause
items.short_synopsis: Paprika Steen delivers a tour-de-force performance in this devastating drama about an alcoholic actress trying to put her life back together.
items.default_editorial: A devastating portrayal of life after rehab, Applause is deeply indebted to, and inflected with, the raw majesty of Gena Rowlands in Cassavettes’ Opening Night. Danish director Martin Pieter Zandvliet’s blistering feature debut is a vehicle for its gutsy star, Paprika Steen. Gena would be proud.

items.title: Autumn Ball
items.short_synopsis: Six lost souls live in a repulsive housing development from the Soviet era. This indifferent world is steadily advancing towards winter, demonstrating the possibility for laughter even where hope has long since become a sparse commodity.
items.default_editorial: Estonian director Veiko Õunpuu’s spicy debut, which premiered at Venice, was adapted from a novel by Mati Unt. Replete with cinematic references and the twisted touch of Bergman, the film approaches human relationships with a dark and deliciously cynical sense of humor. Keep an eye out for Õunpuu.

items.title: Beast
items.short_synopsis: Bruno loves his wife Maxine, but his love and body are slowly undergoing a transformation. Something is beginning to stir inside him and there is nothing he can do to stop it. Because when you first delve into the dark side of love to find power, aggression and hatred, there is no turning back.
items.default_editorial: Christoffer Boe’s Beast resembles monster movies of old, but in actuality it’s a portrait of love and infidelity in bourgeois society of modern Denmark. With striking digital photography and a host of highly accomplished performances, Beast will not leave you once you’ve witnessed it.

items.title: Capitalism: A Love Story
items.short_synopsis: An examination of the social costs of corporations pursuing profits at the expense of the public good, Michael Moore’s Capitalism: A Love Story comes home to the issue he’s been examining throughout his career: the disastrous impact of corporate dominance on the everyday lives of Americans.
items.default_editorial: Profiteering from juvenile incarceration or the death of an employee? Nothing is off-limits for the corporate vultures targeted in this sweeping polemic from Michael Moore. Premiering shortly after the 2008 crisis, Capitalism charts the ruthless pursuit of short-term profit with accessible zeal.

items.title: Confidence
items.short_synopsis: Jake Vig is a consummate grifter about to pull his biggest con yet, one set to avenge his friend’s murder. But his last scam backfired, leaving him indebted to a mob boss and his enforcer.
items.default_editorial: The joys of any great scam flick lie in the mechanics of the con. Build a house-of-cards ready to tumble, throw in some red herrings and set up the twist. Confidence has all this in spades, and serious star wattage to boot—not least an infectiously fun Dustin Hoffman as the ADHD-afflicted kingpin.

items.title: Diary of the Dead
items.short_synopsis: Jason and a small crew of film students are making a low-budget horror film. At first the fear is acted, but it is soon clear that the dead are really coming to life. While the government is incompetent in combating the crisis, and communications with the world are cut off, Jason keeps on filming.
items.default_editorial: 39 years after Night of the Living Dead, George A. Romero returned to his independent roots for this fifth entry in his cycle of zombie films. Prescient in its vision of a media landscape dominated by user-generated materials, Diary of the Dead is a hugely undervalued vivisection of the online age.

items.title: Inshallah a Boy
items.short_synopsis: Jordan, nowadays. After the death of her husband, Nawal, 30s, has to fight for what she thinks is her inheritance for her only daughter in a region where having a son is a game changer.
items.default_editorial: The first Jordanian film to play at Cannes, Amjad Al Rasheed’s passionate feature debut tackles the country’s legal and social hurdles surrounding single motherhood. Full of vulnerability and strength, Mouna Hawa’s breakout performance powerfully articulates the unstoppable force of maternal love.

items.title: Rabiye Kurnaz vs. George W. Bush
items.original_title: Rabiye Kurnaz gegen George W. Bush
items.short_synopsis: The battle for the release of her son Murat from Guantanamo catapults Turkish housewife Rabiye Kurnaz from her house in Bremen straight into world politics and all the way to the Supreme Court in Washington. The temperamental mother and a human rights lawyer fight side-by-side to get Murat out.
items.default_editorial: Based on Rabiye Kurnaz’s real-life story, Andreas Dresen’s Berlinale-winning political satire introduces German-Turkish comedienne Meltem Kaptan as an international star. With its tension and gallows humor, this post-9/11 narrative turns a controversial incident into a rich character comedy.

items.title: The Aviator
items.short_synopsis: A biopic depicting the early years of legendary director and aviator Howard Hughes’ career, from the late 1920’s to the mid 1940’s.
items.default_editorial: Scorsese’s fascination with obsessive personalities and old Hollywood find their match in his sprawling biopic of famed flyboy, millionaire, movie producer and recluse Howard Hughes. It snagged five Oscars, including for its retro Technicolor camerawork and Cate Blanchett as Katharine Hepburn.

items.title: The Hurt Locker
items.short_synopsis: When a new sergeant, James, takes over a highly trained bomb disposal team amidst the Iraq War, he surprises his two subordinates, Sanborn and Eldridge, by recklessly plunging them into a deadly game of urban combat. As the men struggle to control their new leader, the city explodes into chaos.
items.default_editorial: Kathryn Bigelow became the first woman to win the Oscar® for Best Director with this heart-pounding action-thriller. Turbo-charging its white-knuckle set pieces with a procedural attention to detail, The Hurt Locker examines the psychological toll of everyday heroics with electrifying urgency.

items.title: The Machinist
items.short_synopsis: Trevor suffers from insomnia so severe that it affects his weight and his mental health. When Trevor unintentionally causes a horrible on-the-job accident, he begins to become even more troubled. Trevor descends further into paranoia, blaming his problems on an enigmatic figure named Ivan.
items.default_editorial: Christian Bale made headlines with his jaw-dropping transformation for this film, shedding over 60 pounds to play an insomniac losing his grip on reality. But don’t let that overshadow the film itself: an acclaimed and nightmarish psychological thriller, reminiscent of Lynch, Fincher, and Aronofsky.

items.title: The Temptation of St. Tony
items.short_synopsis: A mid-level manager who develops an aversion to being “good”  finds himself confronting the mysteries of middle-age and morality as he loses grasp of what was once his quiet life.
items.default_editorial: Although steeped in references to Dante, Buñuel, and Chekhov, Estonian director Veiko Õunpuu’s surrealistic parable of capitalism and social alienation still keeps things darkly funny. Riotously creative, this monochrome marvel tonally recalls the films of Roy Andersson and Aki Kaurismäki.

items.title: Tuya's Marriage
items.short_synopsis: In Inner Mongolia, Tuya takes care of her two children and her paralysed husband, collects the water, and minds the flock of sheep that is their livelihood. The unending toil begins to show on their health however, and Tuya faces the question of how to continue to provide for the family’s existence.
items.default_editorial: Following the epic odyssey of a proud, tenacious woman, Chinese director Wang Quan’an strikingly portrays the barren landscapes, colorful costumes, and nomadic lifestyle of the shepherds of inner Mongolia. This breathtaking ode to a disappearing culture won the prestigious Golden Bear at Berlin.

items.title: Bicycling with Molière
items.short_synopsis: A warm and winning chamber piece about two actors taking on The Misanthrope and trying not to strangle one another in the process.
items.default_editorial: Philippe Le Guay’s homage to Molière’s comedy of manners finds a droll pair of rival actors in Lambert Wilson and Fabrice Luchini, two veterans of French cinema. A rustic island becomes the perfect setting for contemplations on acting and love, to be pondered—and debated—over scenic bike rides.

items.title: Breathing
items.short_synopsis: Roman is serving time in a juvenile detention center.  After half of his term, Roman is released on probation and, after many failed attempts, he finds a job at the morgue in Vienna. One day, Roman is faced with a dead woman who bears his family name, and he begins to wonder about his past.
items.default_editorial: Austrian cinema has given birth to some of the most accomplished dramas of existential self-discovery in recent years. Shortly after Revanche, there was Breathing: a sympathetic and deeply felt portrait of a juvenile relocating his place in an imperfect society. A thoughtful, compelling movie.

items.title: Der Firmling
items.short_synopsis: Confirmand and godfather, ie. Father and son go to a fancy restaurant after celebrating the confirmation and drinking all day. They want to order Emmentaler cheese, but can only find Affentaler (wine) in bottles on the menu. How did the Affentaler, which they think is cheese, get into the bottle?
items.default_editorial: Legendary German comedian Karl Valentin directed this classic short about a father celebrating his son’s confirmation with a bottle of liquor. Valentin stars opposite frequent partner Liesl Karlstadt, combining their talents to form an eternally hilarious and over-the-top comedy.

items.title: Favoriten
items.short_synopsis: Over three years in Vienna’s largest primary school in the district of Favoriten, a class of 25 children moves from second to fourth grade. Their experiences reveal the daily lives of migrant students, the dedication of their teacher, and the challenges they face amid scarce resources.
items.default_editorial: A classroom of children take lessons in decency, democracy, and better futures in this compassionate documentary from Ruth Beckermann. Offsetting the underfunded public sphere with one educator’s hopeful dedication to Vienna’s next generation, Favoriten is often lovely, yet no less political for it.

items.title: Finsterworld
items.short_synopsis: There is no country in Europe that is so difficult to reduce to digestible clichés as contemporary Germany: Finsterworld, a mosaic of bizarre stories and humorous dialogues is like a distorting mirror with fairy-tale sarcasm and pessimism alongside surprises and hope.
items.default_editorial: Weaving a tapestry of interconnecting tales, this fiction debut from documentarian Frauke Finsterwalder is an ambitious reckoning with notions of German identity. With an all-star cast that includes Sandra Hüller and Shia LaBeouf, Finsterworld is an Altmanesque interrogation of the national psyche.

items.title: For Sama
items.short_synopsis: Presented as a love letter to her daughter, this is the story of Waad al-Kateab’s life during five years of the uprising in Aleppo, Syria. With a camera in her hand, she captures when she falls in love, gets married, and gives birth to Sama—all while cataclysmic conflict rises around her.
items.default_editorial: Romance, motherhood, and impossible choices are universal themes, but they are rarely explored in the first person, and amidst one of the most destructive conflicts of our time: the Syrian war and the siege of Aleppo. For Sama is a devastatingly intimate documentary, bursting with courage and love.

items.title: Gloria
items.short_synopsis: Gloria is a 58 year old divorcée. Her children have all left home but she has no desire to spend her days and nights alone. Determined to defy old age and loneliness, she rushes headlong into a whirl of singles’ parties on the hunt for instant gratification…
items.default_editorial: Sebastián Lelio’s breakout success is a spinning, invigorating and heart-warming film which told the world that middle-aged women could be the most complex and touching characters in cinema. Let yourself be seduced by the enchanting Paulina García, and her fierce performance as Gloria.

items.title: I Am Not Your Negro
items.short_synopsis: In 1979, the writer and civil rights activist James Baldwin embarked on a project to tell the story of America through the lives of three of his murdered friends: Medgar Evers, Malcolm X and Martin Luther King, Jr. He died before it could be completed and Raoul Peck imagines the book he never wrote.
items.default_editorial: An incisive dive into the mind of James Baldwin, who speaks of the disturbing history of American race relations. Raoul Peck’s award-winning film blends archive footage, interviews and excerpts from Baldwin’s unfinished novel—read by Samuel L. Jackson—for a portrait that sadly still resonates today.

items.title: Little Fugitive
items.short_synopsis: When the seven-year-old Joey is cruelly tricked into believing he killed his older brother, he flees to New York’s nether wonderland: Coney Island. Upon and beneath the crowded boardwalk, Joey experiences a day and night filled with adventures and mysteries.
items.default_editorial: If you think America’s indie film scene began with John Cassavetes’ Shadows, think again. Five years earlier, this microbudgeted marvel took to the streets of NYC to forge a vivid time capsule out of enterprise and courage. A work of thrilling immediacy, it’s one of the great films about childhood.

items.title: Love, Deutschmarks and Death
items.short_synopsis: The German Federal Republic’s 1961 recruitment agreement with Turkey not only brought workers, but also their music. The stories of the band Derdiyoklar, Radio Yılmaz, protest rocker Cem Karaca’s German exile, and many more are testament to the unique liveliness of Turkish music in Germany.
items.default_editorial: A captivating fusion of infectious music, humor, and cultural insight, this resplendent look at the roots of Turkish-German music delves deeply into notions of identity, protest, and solidarity. Turn up the volume for a heart-palpitating cocktail of psychedelic riffs and rebellious beats.

items.title: Nostalghia
items.short_synopsis: The Russian poet Andrei Gorchakov travels through Italy accompanied by his guide and translator as he researches the life of an 18th Century Russian composer, Pavel Sosnovsky. There he meets Erland Josephson, a local pariah who declares that the world is coming to an end.
items.default_editorial: With only seven feature films, Andrei Tarkovsky created a world: of prophecy, madness, grace, and spiritual transcendence. Made in exile from the USSR, Nostalghia is a uniquely personal masterwork that stands with his best. Winner of Best Director at Cannes, an honor he shared with Robert Bresson!

items.title: Orchesterprobe
items.short_synopsis: In this early comedy short film from Germany, one of the musicians in a large group of instrumentalists extremely annoys the conductor during orchestral practice…
items.default_editorial: Revel in twenty minutes of non-stop slapstick and over-the-top physical humor as an orchestra rehearses for a performance in this playful, short gem from the Czech film director and actor Karel Lamač. If pure, unadulterated silliness is what you’re after, we’ve just the thing!

items.title: Scorched Earth
items.short_synopsis: Twelve years after career criminal Trojan fled Berlin, his search for jobs leads him back to the city, where his traditional methods are increasingly out-of-step in the capital’s tech-centric underworld. He eventually lands an old-school job to steal a painting—but the job soon goes off the rails.
items.default_editorial: Thomas Arslan’s acclaimed In the Shadows adapted the heist flick to late-capitalist Berlin, and this follow-up watches the sun set on old forms of felony. Beneath slick, petroleum-black surfaces of crime, art thieves fight against diminishing returns of modern labor in this smoldering, clever film.

items.title: Sunny
items.short_synopsis: 19-year-old Hajo wrestles with caring for his 6-month-old son and finding both work and his role of being a father. Hajo has a plan, but it will put his infant son in danger.
items.default_editorial: This Dardennes-like short was director Barbara Ott’s graduation project, and went on to win the German Short Film Award among its slew of film festival prizes. Following a young man struggling with the demands of adulthood and fatherhood, Sunny marries neorealist drama to nerve-jangling suspense.

items.title: The Baron of the Locks
items.short_synopsis: The lucky Baron wins a boat in a card game and takes off with his former lover to find new adventures. Adverse circumstances land them in a small town, where the Baron’s seafaring companion leaves for more attractive scenery offered by a wealthy local man.
items.default_editorial: An ever-charming Jean Gabin leads the charge in this stylishly lean romantic drama, based on a story by Maigret author Georges Simenon. Against the backdrop of winemaking in Champagne and gambling dens in Monte Carlo, watch as sparks fly and debts are settled.

items.title: The Big Night
items.short_synopsis: The story of two very different half brothers, played by Benoît Poelvoorde and Albert Dupontel. The first is an old punk, who roams around with his dog and his belongings, while the second is the good boy full of future business plans, who goes wrong following his dismissal and divorce…
items.default_editorial: Benoît Délepine and Gustave Kervern have established themselves as the directors of idiosyncratic and satirical comedies, advocating that a non-profit life on the margins might generate a growth in well-being. This anarchic view of life brings two siblings together in this touchingly punk story.

items.title: The Faithful Hussar
items.short_synopsis: The worst thing that can happen to a Rhinelander is a carnival ban. When his stern wife once again points her moral finger, her husband imagines a cunning plan which makes it possible for him and his friends to plunge into this “immoral swamp”.
items.default_editorial: A staggeringly prolific actor, Rudolf Schündler may be best known for his performances in Suspiria, The Exorcist, and The Testament of Dr. Mabuse, but he also directed more than a dozen features. Named after the popular German folk song, this carnivalesque comedy of manners is one of his very best.

items.title: The Girl and the Spider
items.short_synopsis: Lisa is moving out of her flatshare with Mara and Markus, and her move now means the end of an era. As boxes are shifted, walls painted and cupboards built, abysses begin to open up. While Lisa is looking forward to the change, for Mara it triggers a rollercoaster of emotions.
items.default_editorial: Playing host to a duel between its characters’ inner lives and shared experiences, this confined confection is a film of simple pleasures and delectably profound mysteries. The sophomore feature from Ramon and Silvan Zürcher, The Girl and the Spider confirms the Swiss siblings as major talents.

items.title: The Waldheim Waltz
items.short_synopsis: Vienna, 1986. Filmmaker Ruth Beckermann joined activists in the streets to stop Kurt Waldheim from being elected Austrian President. More than 30 years later, using her recordings and a wealth of archival material, Beckermann analyzes the Waldheim Affair and Austria’s struggle with its Nazi past.
items.default_editorial: Delaminating the respectable image of Kurt Waldheim, this perspicacious documentary zeroes in on the systematic evasion of a dark history. Exploring right-wing populism and bringing the Austrian diplomat’s misinformation to surface, Ruth Beckermann’s portrait is one of far-reaching relevance.

items.title: Visit to the Theatre
items.short_synopsis: Someone gave Karl Valentin und Liesl Karlstadt tickets to see Goethe’s „Faust" which is playing at the theater. Both of them go through lots of trouble getting themselves ready for the occasion. However, many things go wrong and time is running short.
items.default_editorial: German cult comedian Karl Valentin and his congenial partner Liesl Karlstadt star in this hilarious short from director Joe Stöckel. Playing a married couple preparing for a visit to the theatre, the two actors turn their charming chemistry into timeless and comically absurd chaos.

items.title: 24 Hour Party People
items.short_synopsis: A vibrant portrait of the Manchester music scene during the mid-to-late 1970s, through the eyes of TV presenter Tony Wilson, founder of Factory Records, as he introduces the world to such notable musical acts as Joy Division, New Order, and The Happy Mondays.
items.default_editorial: With an inspired performance by Steve Coogan, this wacky drama about the Manchester music scene travels in time to portray a way of relating to music that’s now partly extinct. Smartly blending archival footage with fictional characters, 24 Hour Party People dances to the beat of its own drum.

items.title: 8½
items.short_synopsis: Struggling to find inspiration for his next project, acclaimed director Guido Anselmi wrestles with his dreams, memories and desires in his search for creativity. Blending visions with reality, his artistic crisis leads him down many a strange and twisted paths, as his life unravels around him.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Academy Award® for Best Foreign Language Film, there is strange undeniable magic to Federico Fellini’s semi-autobiographical, self-referential film about film. It is an iconic, modernist work of absolute genius that manically flits between the fantastic and the realistic.

items.title: A Real Young Girl
items.short_synopsis: Alice, a sulky teenage girl, reluctantly returns to her parents’ house for yet another boring summer vacation. Preyed by sexual desire and caged fantasies, she fantasizes about Jim, her father’s young employee, and tries to seduce him by all means.
items.default_editorial: Deemed obscene for its fearless depiction of teenage sexuality, A Real Young Girl did not receive a proper release until 2001. A landmark film debut from rebel Catherine Breillat that, in hindsight, first introduces the controversial themes the filmmaker has subsequently dedicated her career to.

items.title: A Secret
items.short_synopsis: In 1953, a French boy finds out from a neighbour that his family is Jewish. An exploration of a dark family secret and the story of a passion, told through the interior journey of François, a solitary child who invents a brother and imagines his parents’ past.
items.default_editorial: A late offering from the French director Claude Miller (who was Truffaut’s protégé!), A Secret is a fractured yet beautifully crafted, time-hopping melodrama about one family’s painful history. It was impressively nominated for 11 Cesars, including Best Picture, Screenplay, Director, and Actress!

items.title: A Zed and Two Noughts
items.short_synopsis: A car collides with a swan outside a zoo. Two women passengers die but the driver Alba survives with a leg amputation. Obsessed with the accident, the zoologist husbands of the dead women—twins Oliver and Oswald—become fascinated by the processes of decay and embark on a strange affair with Alba.
items.default_editorial: As perversely, teasingly comic as it is shocking, A Zed and Two Noughts is full of surprises. At once a self-reflexive intellectual puzzle and a wickedly dark comedy, the film marked the beginning of Peter Greenaway’s two-decade collaboration with Last Year at Marienbad cinematographer Sacha Vierny.

items.title: Ali: Fear Eats the Soul
items.short_synopsis: Emmi is lonely in her old age. Her husband died years ago, and her grown children offer little companionship. One night she goes to a bar and strikes up a friendship with middle-aged mechanic Ali. They soon fall in love, and their families and neighbors are outraged by their spontaneous marriage.
items.default_editorial: The pinnacle of Fassbinder’s infatuation with the Technicolor melodramas of Douglas Sirk, this homage to All That Heaven Allows is a revisionist masterwork. Imbued with unexpected tenderness, its portrait of an odd-couple romance scrutinizes racial and class struggle in a fierce cry for humanity.

items.title: Beach Rats
items.short_synopsis: On the outskirts of Brooklyn, Frankie, an aimless teenager, suffocates under the oppressive glare cast by his family and a toxic group of friends. Struggling with his own identity, Frankie begins to scour hookup sites for older men while entering into a relationship with a young woman.
items.default_editorial: Prior to making waves with Never Rarely Sometimes Always, Eliza Hittman directed this sensual and assured coming-of-age story. Winner of the Directing Award at Sundance, Beach Rats stars Harris Dickinson (Babygirl) as a Brooklyn teenager imbued with vulnerability and quiet yearning.

items.title: Beasts of the Southern Wild
items.short_synopsis: Six-year-old Hushpuppy lives with her father, Wink, in “the Bathtub,” a South Louisiana community at the edge of the world. When Wink falls mysteriously ill, nature seems to fall ill with him. Rising waters threaten to engulf their small world, sending Hushpuppy in search of her long-lost mother.
items.default_editorial: Perhaps one of the most baroque expressions of magical realism in recent years, Beasts of the Southern Wild took 2012 by storm with its fantastical vision of southern Louisiana. With a boundless imagination and a rare sense of adventure, this film is brimming with great tenderness and warmth.

items.title: Beau travail
items.short_synopsis: In the Gulf of Djibouti, a platoon of the French Foreign Legion repairs the roads and trains for war under the strict discipline of Sergeant Galoup. For him, this male community represents his life and home. But the order will gradually break with the arrival of the recruit Sentain.
items.default_editorial: Set amid the French Foreign Legion in the sun-parched desert landscapes of Djibouti, Claire Denis’s masterpiece is a hypnotic exploration of obsessive male desire, masculine codes, and the dark legacy of colonialism. Bonus: Denis Lavant’s magnetic disco moves in a dance scene for the ages.

items.title: Brother
items.short_synopsis: Abandoned by the brotherhood of his yakuza clan, tough guy Yamamoto is forced to leave Tokyo. He goes to Los Angeles in search of Ken, his younger half-brother. Alone and with a new identity, Yamamoto finds himself frustrated by foreign surroundings, especially since he doesn’t speak the language.
items.default_editorial: What happens when a Japanese yakuza ends up in L.A.? For that matter, what happens when Japanese phenomenon Takeshi Kitano (Zatôichi, Battle Royale) writes, directs and stars in an American gangster film?
