The results are classic Kitano: startling violence, deadpan humor, and unexpected emotion.

items.title: Chameleon Street
items.short_synopsis: William Douglas Street Jr., a Black Michigan man tired of his dead-end job, decides to scam his way up the socioeconomic ladder. He reinvents himself again and again, expertly impersonating a magazine reporter, an Ivy League student, a lawyer, and a surgeon—while staying one step ahead of the law.
items.default_editorial: Wily creativity sparks across this newly restored masterwork of Black American cinema, which won the Grand Jury Prize at Sundance in 1990. Written and directed with ferocious wit and quicksilver style by its star, Wendell B. Harris Jr., this true-to-life tale of brazen hustle is a whirlwind of fun.

items.title: City of God
items.short_synopsis: In the poverty-stricken favelas of Rio de Janeiro in the 1970s, two young men choose different paths. Rocket is a budding photographer who documents the increasing drug-related violence of his neighborhood, while Li’l Zé is an ambitious drug dealer diving into a dangerous life of crime.
items.default_editorial: An essential arthouse staple of the naughts, Fernando Meirelles and Kátia Lund’s epic of favela life crackles with passion, violence, color, and visual wizardry. Brazil’s submission to the Oscars® uses primarily nonprofessional actors, who light up scenes of relentless violence and restless flight.

items.title: Cosmopolis
items.short_synopsis: Unfolding over a single cataclysmic day, a 28-year-old billionaire asset manager rides his tricked-out limo to get a haircut. Over the course of his journey, intimate encounters, grid-locked traffic and the death of a rap star contribute to his reality melting away.
items.default_editorial: In this insidiously corrosive adaptation of Don DeLillo’s dystopian satire, Cronenberg offers a sharp critique of rogue capitalism. Starring an icy Robert Pattinson as a conspicuously rich trader unfazed by the apocalyptic chaos outside his limo, Cosmopolis ignited the actor’s arthouse career.

items.title: Da Vinci
items.short_synopsis: In an operating theatre in a hospital robotic surgery department, a journey through the human body is undertaken by a specialized robot named Da Vinci. The surgeon conducts the entire operation remotely, controlling the robot’s intricate movements with a joystick.
items.default_editorial: Cast in various shades of calming blues, Yuri Ancarani’s experimental short observes a spellbinding dance between man and machine. Masterfully operated by skilled surgeons, a robotic device probes strange contours deep within the human body, in a beautiful choreography of technology and imagination.

items.title: Fear and Desire
items.short_synopsis: A ficticious war in an unidentified country provides the setting for this drama. Four soldiers survive the crash-landing of their plane to find themselves in a forest six miles behind enemy lines.
items.default_editorial: Famously, Stanley Kubrick spent decades suppressing this, his first feature. We think he was too hard on himself: Fear and Desire is a rough B-movie spiked with inspired ideas and imagery, and its long sought-after availability allows us to trace the origins of the master.

items.title: Frank
items.short_synopsis: Jon, an eager yet untalented musician, joins the avant-garde pop band The Soronprfbs in an attempt to extricate himself from his small-town life and everyday routine. The frontman is the eccentric and emotionally unstable Frank, who hides under an enormous papier-mâché head that he never takes off.
items.default_editorial: A year before his heartbreaking, award-winning Room, Irish director Lenny Abrahamson made Frank—a comedy loosely based on the life and persona of cult musician Chris Sievey. With a beautifully tuned, subtle performance from Michael Fassbender, this is a funny, poignant ode to artistic creation.

items.title: Funeral Parade of Roses
items.original_title: 薔薇の葬列 | Bara no sôretsu
items.short_synopsis: In 1960s Tokyo, Gonda owns a bar in which the gay, cross-dresser, and trans scenes meet. Gonda is in a relationship with the madam of the bar, Leda. As the younger Eddie starts a passionate affair with Gonda, she ignites the jealousy of Leda, unaware of another kind of history between them.
items.default_editorial: Spiked with hallucinatory visuals and verité documentary techniques, this is a bold, surrealist, and truly transgressive first feature from iconoclastic Japanese director Toshio Matsumoto. This underground docudrama offers us a rare and revelatory immersion into Japan’s 1960s queer and drag culture.

items.title: High Life
items.short_synopsis: Monte and his baby daughter are the last survivors of a damned and dangerous mission to deep space. The crew—death-row inmates led by a doctor with sinister motives—has vanished. As the mystery of what happened onboard the ship is unraveled, father and daughter must rely on each other to survive.
items.default_editorial: Master Claire Denis sending Robert Pattinson and La Binoche to space? More than a film, High Life is a dream impossible to look away from. Soaking up the physicality of bodies and the darkness of the human soul, this wild ride into the unknown is a bizarre, stunning, ominously sexy cosmic vision.

items.title: Honeyland
items.short_synopsis: Hatidze lives with her ailing mother in the mountains of Macedonia, making a living cultivating honey using ancient beekeeping traditions. When an unruly family moves in next door, what at first seems like a balm for her solitude becomes a source of tension as they, too, want to practice beekeeping.
items.default_editorial: The first documentary to be nominated for Best International Feature and Best Documentary at the Oscars, Honeyland is an indelible fable. Starting as an astonishing portrait of a disappearing way of life, the film pivots into a cautionary tale on the effects of capitalistic greed on natural life.

items.title: Hot Summer Nights
items.short_synopsis: American flags wave as fireworks light the sky, it’s 1991 in Cape Cod, Massachusetts, and summer is in full swing. A lonely teenage boy is taken under the wing of the town rebel, falls in love with the prettiest girl in town, and gets entangled in a drug ring.
items.default_editorial: Before the whirlwind success of Call Me by Your Name, Timothée Chalamet had another unforgettable summer of love in Elijah Bynum’s first feature, also starring It Follows alum Maika Monroe. Lifted by nostalgic earworms, this propulsive coming-of-age thriller revels in the reckless abandon of youth.

items.title: Il capo
items.short_synopsis: In the quarries of Carrara, Italy, men and machines dig Monte Bettogli for marble. Managing, coordinating, and guiding quarrymen and their heavy-duty machines is the chief—“Il Capo”—who uses a language consisting solely of gestures and signs to coordinate this dangerous, noisy operation.
items.default_editorial: With the grace of an orchestra conductor, a seasoned quarryman commands a fleet of mining excavators in this hypnotic short. Harmonizing the sinuous lines of the male form with the rugged alps of Carrara, Yuri Ancarani and Pietro Savorelli carve a sensuous visual poem from strenuous hard work.

items.title: Il divo
items.short_synopsis: In Rome, at dawn, when everyone is asleep, one man is awake. That man is Giulio Andreotti. Calm, ambiguous, inscrutable, Andreotti is synonymous with power in Italy for over four decades. Without arrogance or humility, he advances towards his 7th mandate as Prime Minister, unscathed from everything.
items.default_editorial: Well before The Great Beauty launched him to new levels of arthouse superstardom, Paolo Sorrentino scooped the Jury Prize at Cannes with this wild true story of political corruption in Italy, starring Beauty star Toni Servillo. Part biopic, part thriller, and glossed to a gorgeous, decadent sheen!

items.title: Little Men
items.short_synopsis: 13-year-old Jake befriends Tony, raised by his mother Leonor. When feud ignites between the parents—Brian and Kathy and Leonor—the boys remain silent against their parents in protest.
items.default_editorial: Inspired by Ozu’s childhood films, Ira Sachs’s coming-of-age drama is both microcosmically intimate and vast in its thematic concerns. Anchored by a remarkable pair of performances from its young leads, Little Men essays the tension between youthful aspiration and the jaded imperatives of adulthood.

items.title: Love & Friendship
items.short_synopsis: Young widow Susan Vernon visits her in-laws’ estate while waiting for social chatter about her personal indiscretions to pass. While there, she decides to secure a husband for herself and her reluctant daughter. Enlisting the help of an old friend, she attracts the attention of many interesting men.
items.default_editorial: American sophisticate Whit Stillman followed his comeback Damsels in Distress with a film at once unexpected and oh-so-fitting. With his delicious adaptation of Jane Austen, he proves as adroit at chronicling the wry social scheming of the Regency as he did young Manhattanites and disco revelers.

items.title: Magdalena Viraga
items.short_synopsis: In east Los Angeles, Ida is a sex worker who is accused of killing a client. She is dragged into a prison overseen by nuns and shadows of the crucifix. However, the other prison is her inner life. She battles at the walls which surround her—both material and psychic.
items.default_editorial: An atmospheric fever dream unfurling over motel rooms and prison cells, Nina Menkes’s groundbreaking first feature traces the cyclical nature of exploitation. Simmering with rage, Tinka Menkes’s potent evocation of a fractured female psyche unveils the emotional ravage of transactional encounters.

items.title: Manifesto
items.short_synopsis: Cate Blanchett portrays 13 distinct characters, including a homeless man, an anchorwoman, a factory worker and a corporate CEO. All of them in vignettes that incorporate timeless manifestos of the nineteenth and twentieth century, ranging from Communism to Dogme 95 and Pop Art.
items.default_editorial: Tár star Cate Blanchett portrays 13 characters—including an anchorwoman, factory worker and corporate CEO—in Julian Rosefeldt’s innovative experimental piece. Inspired by Dadaism and Situationism, this tribute to artistic and political manifestos owes much to Blanchett’s tour-de-force performance.

items.title: Marina Abramović: The Artist is Present
items.original_title: Marina Abramović: The Artist is Present
items.short_synopsis: Seductive, fearless, and outrageous, Marina Abramovic has been redefining what art is for nearly forty years. Using her body as a vehicle, pushing herself beyond her physical and mental limits––and at times risking her life in the process––she creates performances that challenge, shock, and move us.
items.default_editorial: Taking us through New York City’s Museum of Modern Art and behind the scenes of Marina Abramovic’s 736-hour performance piece, this insightful documentary profile is a great glimpse at the artist’s steadfast commitment to her work. Featuring some familiar faces—from James Franco to Josephine Decker!

items.title: Merry Christmas, Mr. Lawrence
items.short_synopsis: During WWII, British soldier Jack Celliers is captured by Japanese forces and held in a camp run by Capt. Yonoi and Sgt. Hara. Yonoi develops an obsession with Celliers who is defiant in the face of their old ideas. Meanwhile, a translator tries to find common ground between their opposing beliefs.
items.default_editorial: Nagisa Oshima’s ravishing war film is fueled by charged, unforgettable performances from no less than David Bowie, Takeshi Kitano and Ryuichi Sakamoto (who also composed the film’s haunting synth score). A poignant and seasonal culture-clash drama shot through with queer desire and redemption.

items.title: Metropolitan
items.short_synopsis: Home on winter break during the debutante season, middle-class Princeton student Tom falls in with a group of Upper East Side friends from the urban haute bourgeoisie. As naïf Tom is accepted into the group, he becomes smitten with Audrey while struggling with his feelings for his ex Serena.
items.default_editorial: Whit Stillman burst onto the American cinema scene with this ferociously funny look at the “urban haute bourgeoisie” in New York. With a distinct comic voice and authentic observations of human behavior, Stillman established himself as one of the most promising breakthrough directors of the 90s.

items.title: Mommy
items.short_synopsis: A feisty widowed single mom finds herself burdened with the full-time custody of her unpredictable 15-year-old ADHD son. As they struggle to make ends meet, Kyla, the peculiar new neighbor across the street, offers her help. Together, they find a new sense of balance, and hope is regained.
items.default_editorial: Québécois enfant terrible Xavier Dolan won his first prize at Cannes for Mommy, a triangular family drama full of flair, with the director’s signature mid-00s soundtrack and one risky formal device—the film’s much-discussed 1:1 square aspect ratio—that in fact pays off big time.

items.title: Naked
items.short_synopsis: Johnny is a charming and eloquent, but relentlessly vicious, drifter. Rejecting anyone who might care for him, the volcanic Johnny hurls himself around London on a nocturnal odyssey, colliding with a succession of other desperate and dispossessed people and scorching everyone in his path.
items.default_editorial: With a manic and dark sense of humor, an unforgettable David Thewlis drifts through the cold streets of London on a probing, desperate and furious existential odyssey. One of the greatest works from British filmmaker Mike Leigh, Naked deservedly won the Best Actor and Best Director awards at Cannes.

items.title: No
items.short_synopsis: In 1988, international pressure comes to bear on Chilean dictator Pinochet forcing him to call a referendum. The country will vote either yes or no on extending his rule for another eight years. Leaders of the “no” movement recruit Saavedra—a young advertising executive—to spearhead their campaign.
items.default_editorial: With his first collaboration with Gael García Bernal, Pablo Larraín scored a true art-house hit. Shot on vintage video cameras, the film boasts a rare authenticity and its aesthetic of immediacy is nothing short of genius. No closes Larraín’s accidental Pinochet trilogy with wit, humour and hope.

items.title: Nosferatu the Vampyre
items.short_synopsis: Sent to Transylvania to negotiate for a house purchased by the monstrous Count Dracula, Jonathan Harker leaves his idyllic town, turning a deaf ear to his wife Lucy’s ill omens. Soon, Jonathan finds himself trapped, and Dracula descends from the mountains towards Lucy, with death and plague in tow.
items.default_editorial: Revisiting F.W. Murnau’s classic, Werner Herzog made a unique and elemental take on the Dracula story. This haunting vision of life, death, and superstition is aglow with deep color, and finds pity for Kinski’s deathless wraith. With the brilliant Isabelle Adjani: the carnal queen of Euro-horror.

items.title: Perfect Blue
items.short_synopsis: Pop singer Mima Kirigow looks forward to a bright new career when she quits her chart-topping trio to become an actress.  When she lands a role in a sexually charged murder mystery, Mima’s life begins to fall apart.
items.default_editorial: Ranked among the most influential anime of all time, Satoshi Kon’s haunting masterpiece erects a psychological house of mirrors filled with eerie hallucinations and murderous doppelgangers. A prescient parable on the price of celebrity and the commodification of the female body in the digital age.

items.title: Piattaforma Luna
items.short_synopsis: A group of six scuba divers specializing in deep underwater operations live for three weeks at the bottom of the ocean. Staying alternately in the recompression chamber on board the platform Luna or conducting work on the bottom of the sea, the divers meticulously adhere to strict protocols.
items.default_editorial: Unlike his dialogue-free documentaries, Yuri Ancarani’s Piattaforma Luna is peppered with spoken directions and reports, words of labor that disrupt undersea silence. Anchored by the disciplined routines of veteran divers, this tableau of life inside a submarine is at once scientific and artful.

items.title: Prince Avalanche
items.short_synopsis: Alvin and Lance spend the summer of 1988 in a deserted, fire-damaged forest, with the monotonous task of repainting the markings on a country road. The isolated landscape becomes a place of misadventure as the men find themselves at odds with each other and the women they left behind.
items.default_editorial: Before his blockbuster Halloween reboot, David Gordon Green revitalized another beloved genre with an atypical buddy movie. Showcasing his skill with broad comedy, this warm film fuses that wit with the intimacy of the director’s earlier, sensitive character studies like George Washington.

items.title: Queen of Diamonds
items.short_synopsis: Firdaus is a Blackjack dealer in a Las Vegas landscape juxtaposed between glittering casino lights and the deteriorating desert oasis. Negotiating a missing husband and neighboring domestic violence, Firdaus’ world unfolds as a fragmented interplay between repetition and repressed anger.
items.default_editorial: Awash with striking imagery, Nina Menkes’s indelible portrait of alienated womanhood counters the glitz of nocturnal Las Vegas with its daytime loneliness. Sullenly glamorous, the blood-red claws sported by Tinka Menkes’s croupier evokes a gesture of resistance against the drudgery of casino life.

items.title: Romance X
items.short_synopsis: After three months as a couple together, Paul no longer feels any physical desire for Marie, yet claims he loves her. But for Marie, sex is essential to her expression of love. She decides to look elsewhere for physical affection, and embarks on a series of increasingly extreme sexual encounters.
items.default_editorial: Catherine Breillat’s cinema has the vocation to embrace female sexuality and break the taboos that continue to stifle our puritan eyes. Provocatively titled, Romance X subverts the ideas of love and sex—and everything in between!—with abrasive explicitness and vivid echoes of Belle de jour.

items.title: San Siro
items.short_synopsis: The stadium takes center stage as countless people work its infrastructure and the crowd rises into its columns—all in anticipation of our modern gladiators.
items.default_editorial: Shot at the San Siro arena, Milan’s mecca to football, Yuri Ancarani’s sensorial short redirects our gaze towards workers whose efforts often go unnoticed. Building to a crescendo that matches the religious fervor of sports fans, a symphony swells from seemingly mundane rituals of preparation.

items.title: Sleeping Beauty
items.short_synopsis: Death-haunted, quietly reckless, Lucy is a university student who takes a job as a Sleeping Beauty. In the Sleeping Beauty Chamber old men seek an erotic experience that requires Lucy’s absolute submission. But soon she develops an increasing need to know what happens to her when she is asleep.
items.default_editorial: Tipping its hat to Buñuel’s Belle de Jour, this bitingly satirical take on the eponymous romantic fable is an audacious one-off from novelist-turned-filmmaker Julia Leigh. A languid interrogation of voyeurism, sublimation, and commodification, Sleeping Beauty is a pointedly feminist erotic odyssey.

items.title: Stalker
items.short_synopsis: A hired guide leads his two clients—a writer looking for inspiration and a professor seeking scientific discovery—through a hazardous wasteland and into the heart of the Zone, the restricted site of a long-ago disaster. Within the Zone is the Room: a place rumored to fulfil one’s deepest desires.
items.default_editorial: Hailed as one of the greatest films of all time, Andrei Tarkovsky’s mesmerizing opus is striking in its sepia palette, and staggering in its thematic and metaphysical weight. A profound post-apocalyptic grail story whose vision of ecological degradation and moral decay remains startlingly prescient.

items.title: Suspiria
items.short_synopsis: American ballet dancer Suzy Bannion arrives in Freiberg, Germany, to attend the prestigious Tanz Academy. From the moment she arrives, she senses that something evil lurks within the walls of the age-old institution. As she probes the depths of the dance school, terrible accidents start to happen…
items.default_editorial: Argento’s psychedelic giallo is a dark Gothic horror story told in exceptionally vivid colors. Its jagged visuals, moody Goblin score, disturbing screenplay (which Argento co-wrote with Daria Nicolodi), and meticulously designed, pulpy production make for that most chilling of viewing experiences.

items.title: Swiss Army Man
items.short_synopsis: Hank is stranded on a deserted island, having given up all hope of ever making it home again.  But one day everything changes when a corpse named Manny washes up on shore; the two become fast friends, and ultimately go on an epic adventure that will bring Hank back to the woman of his dreams.
items.default_editorial: Before they hoovered up seven Oscars® with Everything Everywhere All at Once, Daniel Scheinert and Daniel Kwan made their collective debut with this singularly bizarre and brazen buddy comedy. Starring Daniel Radcliffe and Paul Dano, Swiss Army Man finds profound emotion in an over-the-top premise.

items.title: Teorema
items.short_synopsis: A handsome and enigmatic stranger arrives at an upstanding wealthy household in Milan and successively seduces the son, the mother, the daughter, the father, and the maid. Each individual experiences some sort of revelation or epiphany. Then, as abruptly and mysteriously as he arrived, he departs.
items.default_editorial: One of the most brilliant, radical thinkers—and, of course, filmmakers—of the 20th century, Pier Paolo Pasolini outdid himself with this enigmatic allegory. A meditation on Italy’s transformation from spirituality to consumerism, Theorem remains one of the most relevant critiques of modern life.

items.title: The Bitter Tears of Petra von Kant
items.original_title: Die bitteren Tränen der Petra von Kant
items.short_synopsis: Petra von Kant is a successful fashion designer—arrogant, caustic, and self-satisfied. She’s in a fairly satisfactory S&M relationship with her assistant, Marlene. But when she develops an obsession with fashion model Karin, things become far more complicated, and love intermingles with hate.
items.default_editorial: Recently adapted by François Ozon in a gender-flipped take, Fassbinder’s all-female melodrama is a fiery and fervent love-and-hate story for the ages. A sly game of power that breathes excess as much as it displays masterful control, you best brace yourselves for a cinema of unparalleled intensity.

items.title: The Bloody Child
items.short_synopsis: A young US Marine, recently back from serving in the Gulf War, is found digging a hole in the middle of the Mojave Desert while his car, with his wife’s bloody and lifeless body inside, is found nearby. A female officer begins probing the inexplicable death.
items.default_editorial: Casting her spellbinding sister as an officer investigating a murder, Nina Menkes journeys into a sandstorm of military and sexual violence. Refusing resolution, this fascinating film excavates an atmosphere of haunting that is aswirl with dreamlike imagery and mesmeric incantation.

items.title: The Handmaiden
items.short_synopsis: In 1930s Korea, a new girl is hired as a handmaiden to a Japanese heiress who lives a secluded life on a large countryside estate. But the maid has a secret: She is a pickpocket recruited by a swindler, who is posing as a Japanese Count, to help him seduce the Lady and steal her fortune.
items.default_editorial: Park Chan-wook’s distinctive flair for stylish visuals and jaw-dropping plot twists shines through in this deliciously subversive erotic thriller, set during the Japanese occupation of Korea. As seductive as it is bone-chilling, The Handmaiden is a many-splendored gem full of cinematic pleasures.

items.title: The Host
items.short_synopsis: When a young girl is snatched away from her father by an unidentified giant creature that emerges from the Han River to wreak havoc on Seoul, her entire family sets out to locate the horrifying monster and bring their little girl back home to safety.
items.default_editorial: Having turned the police procedural on its head with the magnificent Memories of Murder, director Bong Joon Ho looked to the kaiju movie for his next genre recalibration. A supremely entertaining monster mash, The Host marries political satire to family drama in an action extravaganza for the ages.

items.title: The Juniper Tree
items.short_synopsis: Set in medieval Iceland, Margit and her older sister Katla flee for safety after their mother is burned to death for witchcraft. Finding shelter  with Johan and his resentful young son, Jonas, the sisters help form an impromptu family unit that’s soon strained by Katla’s burgeoning sorcery.
items.default_editorial: Björk made her dazzling film debut in this monochromatic medieval fantasy, in which she channels a witchy, supernatural energy. A feminist retelling of the Brothers Grimm fairy tale, director Nietzchka Keene shoots the otherworldliness of Iceland on 35mm: enjoy it in this stunning restoration.

items.title: The Last Movie
items.short_synopsis: Production wraps on a Hollywood western in a Peruvian village but stuntman Kansas remains, attempting to find redemption in isolation and the arms of a former sex worker. Meanwhile, local Native Americans have taken over the abandoned set and are staging a ritualistic re-enactment of the film.
items.default_editorial: Dennis Hopper’s misunderstood countercultural masterpiece almost ruined his career: and that’s not the half of it! A drug-fueled production, stellar cast (Peter Fonda! Sam Fuller! Kris Kristofferson!) and stunning Peruvian setting turn this wild artistic feat into unforgettable cinema.

items.title: The Marriage of Maria Braun
items.short_synopsis: The Marriage of Maria Braun  is the “German Hollywood film” Fassbinder had long dreamed of making. A heartbreaking study of a woman picking herself up from the ruins of her own life, as well as a pointed metaphorical attack on a society determined to forget its past.
items.default_editorial: Starring Hanna Schygulla in an award-winning performance, this scandalous melodrama is a flagrant vision of what women do on the spoiled peripheries of war. Wrecking sentimental ideas of devotion, Rainer Werner Fassbinder scored his biggest box-office success with this indecently magnificent film.

items.title: The Milk of Sorrow
items.short_synopsis: Fausta, we are told, suffers from ‘the milk of sorrow’, a melancholy transmitted through her mother’s breast milk. For Fausta’s mother, like many in her village, was raped during the years of Peru’s bloody civil conflict in the 1980s, and Fausta still lives with the consequences of the violence.
items.default_editorial: Intimate, political, and quietly sublime, The Milk of Sorrow is a beautifully shot story about female identity in war-torn Peru. Emotionally affective all along, the film earned young director Claudia Llosa the first nomination to the Academy Awards® for a Peruvian film. Plus a Golden Bear!

items.title: The Mother and the Whore
items.short_synopsis: Jean Eustache’s marathon drama focuses on three twenty-something Parisians in a bizarre love triangle: Alexandre is a seemingly unemployed narcissist involved with both a live-in girlfriend and a Polish nurse whom he picked up at a café, and with whom he begins a desultory affair.
items.default_editorial: In 1973, Jean Eustache sounded the death knell for the revolutionary sixties and trashed the anarchic jubilance of the French New Wave in one long and sordid swoop. Still revered by cinema’s enfants terribles, this punk paragon of disillusionment is indispensable filmmaking: a defiant must-watch.

items.title: The Rider
items.short_synopsis: After a traumatic brain injury, rising young rodeo star Brady is forced to give up his passion and career, causing financial strain for his family. As he struggles to find a new purpose in life, he must redefine what it means to be a man in the heartland of America.
items.default_editorial: In a masterful blend of documentary and fiction, The Rider’s characters play themselves in an intimate retelling of their own lives. Mental health and the pressures of masculinity are gracefully explored in Chloe Zhao’s contemporary take on the western genre, set in the patriarchal world of rodeo.

items.title: The Scary of Sixty-First
items.short_synopsis: Two roommates discover and relive the murky secrets of their new Upper East Side apartment which used to belong to paedophile billionaire Jeffrey Epstein.
items.default_editorial: Best known as one of the “bohemian layabouts” behind the Red Scare podcast, Dasha Nekrasova makes her directorial debut with this spunky horror-comedy. With Jeffrey Epstein the subject of its conspiratorial satire, The Scary of Sixty-First throws a middle finger up at the proprieties of good taste.

items.title: The Trip
items.short_synopsis: When Steve Coogan is asked by The Observer to tour the country’s finest restaurants, he envisions it as the perfect getaway with his beautiful girlfriend. But, when she backs out on him, he has no one to accompany him but his best friend and source of eternal aggravation, Rob Brydon.
items.default_editorial: Let’s hit the road for a totally absurd road-trip comedy featuring the dynamic duo of Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon. Michael Winterbottom takes us on an off-kilter journey featuring some very British gags, hilarious character-based improvisation, and plenty of food porn along the way.

items.title: Thirst
items.short_synopsis: A Catholic priest becomes involved in a medical experiment during which he is infected with a deadly virus. A strange transfusion cures him, but the blood, of unknown origin, turns him into a vampire. Attempting to remain chaste and faithful, he fights the carnal desires that begin to take over.
items.default_editorial: In his cult hit Thirst, South Korean auteur Park Chan-wook takes a stab at the canonical French novel Thérèse Raquin—with vampires! Graphic yet still gorgeous, the film shifts seamlessly between erotic drama, horror, and even comedy. Winner of the Jury Prize at the Cannes Film Festival.

items.title: Three Monkeys
items.short_synopsis: After a hit and run accident, Eyüp takes the blame for his politician boss Servet, and accepts a pay-off from him, believing it will make life better for his wife Hacer and his son. But whilst Eyüp is in prison, his son falls into bad company. Hacer approaches Servet for help, but gets manipulated.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Best Director prize at Cannes, Three Monkeys is another moving, visually unforgettable triumph from the Turkish master Nuri Bilge Ceylan (Winter Sleep). A mesmerizing 21st century noir, which shows Ceylan as the inheritor of Michelangelo Antonioni’s spaces filled with mystery.

items.title: Vivre sa vie
items.original_title: Vivre sa vie: Film en douze tableaux
items.short_synopsis: Nana, a restless young Parisian, descends into prostitution when her aspirations to become an actress falter. Recently separated from her husband, Nana is completely alone except for her heartless pimp and the women she knows from hooking in the banlieue.
items.default_editorial: Perhaps one of Jean-Luc Godard and Anna Karina’s most beautiful and loving collaborations, this jewel of the French New Wave contains some of the movement’s most iconic scenes. While it whizzes through Paris, Godard’s fourth film remains a socially conscious and profoundly cinematic artwork.

items.title: Wanda
items.short_synopsis: In grim, rust-belt Pennsylvania, Wanda is down and out. She works sporadically, has abandoned her husband and children, sleeps on her sister’s couch, drinks and smokes too much, and goes home with men just to have a roof over her head.
items.default_editorial: Formerly an actor in Elia Kazan’s company, Barbara Loden directed a single feature film before her death at just 48 years old. Starring Loden herself, Wanda is a heart-wrenching, vérité portrait of a marginalised drifter, and remains one of the most influential works of American independent cinema.

items.title: Wiener-Dog
items.short_synopsis: Over her short lifetime, a single dachshund touches the lives of several oddballs. First, she teaches a young boy some twisted life lessons, before being taken in by compassionate vet tech, Dawn Wiener. She also encounters a floundering film professor, as well as an embittered elderly woman.
items.default_editorial: With a top-tier ensemble cast that includes Greta Gerwig as a grown-up Dawn Wiener—the awkward protagonist of Todd Solondz’s Welcome to the Dollhouse_—_Wiener-Dog sees a daschund pup traverse four short tales. A disturbingly funny look at the nature of (un-)happiness from the king of modern malaise.

items.title: A Single Man
items.short_synopsis: Mourning the loss of his partner Jim, George Falconer, an English professor working in Los Angeles, is finding life increasingly difficult to face. The series of events and encounters occurring over a single day will ultimately lead him to decide if there is a future for him in this world.
items.default_editorial: The first film from famed designer Tom Ford, A Single Man is a highly stylized tale of love and loss in the tradition of Wong Kar Wai’s sumptuous melodramas. With deeply felt performances from Colin Firth and Julianne Moore, and direction to match, the film established Ford as a talent to watch.

items.title: Adaptation.
items.short_synopsis: Charlie Kaufman is a confused L.A. screenwriter overwhelmed by feelings of inadequacy, sexual frustration, self-loathing, and the screenwriting ambitions of his freeloading twin brother Donald. While struggling to adapt the latest book by Susan Orlean, Kaufman’s life spins from pathetic to bizarre.
items.default_editorial: As a screenwriter, Charlie Kaufman’s style of reality-bending comedy made him a superstar. With Adaptation, he turned a case of writer’s block into a brilliantly weird and weirdly touching comic tribute to living life as a movie—and earned an Oscar® nod for both himself and his imaginary twin!

items.title: Affliction
items.short_synopsis: In a small New Hampshire town, washed-up cop Wade Whitehouse has a troubled past and an unimpressive streak as a lawman. When hunting guide Jack Hewitt reports a businessman’s accidental death during a hunting trip, Wade has a chance to turn around his life, if he can prove it was murder.
items.default_editorial: Screen legend James Coburn may have been the one to win an Oscar® for his role in this shattering drama from director Paul Schrader—but as the washed-up sheriff caught in the suffocating grip of small-town acrimony and generational trauma, it’s Nick Nolte who gives the performance of his career.

items.title: An Evening with Beverly Luff Linn
items.original_title: An Evening with Beverly Luff Linn
items.short_synopsis: The film follows a woman whose unsatisfying marriage takes a fortunate turn for the worse when a mysterious man from her past comes to town to perform a mysterious event called “An Evening With Beverly Luff Linn; For One Magical Night Only.”
items.default_editorial: Set in a kitsch world of ill-fitting polyester jumpers and bizarre hairstyles, Jim Hosking’s ludicrously cringe comedy stars Aubrey Plaza, Jemaine Clement, and Craig Robinson at their deadpan best. The yearning of 1980s love songs booms through this surreal tale of awkward flirting and petty crime.

items.title: Animals
items.short_synopsis: Would-be writer Laura and her free-spirited bestie Tyler share a messy Dublin apartment and a hearty appetite for booze. Yet when Laura decides to focus on her novel and falls for Jim, a charming but straitlaced pianist, their friendship is strained and Tyler worries that the party may soon be over.
items.default_editorial: The spirit of Fleabag pervades this booze-fueled comedy about the transition of a friendship from youth to adulthood. Led by wonderfully complementary performances by Alia Shawkat and Holliday Grainger, Animals offers a portrait of millennial womanhood that is equally melancholy and funny.

items.title: Babette's Feast
items.short_synopsis: Denmark, 1871. Having fled France, cook Babette Hersant arrives in West Jutland and soon becomes a housekeeper for two unmarried sisters. But when Babette wins the lottery, she decides to spend the money on a sumptuous meal for these melancholic and frugal people.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Oscar® for Best Foreign Film, Babette’s Feast is a mouthwatering marriage between gastronomy and cinema. Stéphane Audran, in a subtle and stunning performance, plays Babette, who through an act of culinary generosity, invites us to observe the cultural event that is the dinner table.

items.title: Bright Young Things
items.short_synopsis: In 1930s England, a group of reckless socialites dominate national gossip. Among them, aspiring novelist Adam is trying to raise enough money to marry Nina. While his attempts are constantly thwarted, his friends are slowly on the road to destruction in their search for newer and faster sensations.
items.default_editorial: As exciting as a flutter on the races or bidding for a darling hand in marriage, Stephen Fry’s directorial debut is a dapper look at the swish society circles of prewar London. Fizzing with wit and insight, this frolicking adaptation of Evelyn Waugh’s Vile Bodies brims with well-polished pleasures.

items.title: Butterfly Vision
items.short_synopsis: After spending months as a prisoner in Donbas, Ukrainian aerial reconnaissance expert Lilia returns home, but the trauma of captivity continues to torment her and surface in dreamlike ways. Something growing within Lilia will not allow her to forget, yet she refuses to identify as a victim.
items.default_editorial: The scars of war are laid bare in this piercing drama from writer-director Maksym Nakonechnyi. Stylistically inventive and featuring a compelling lead performance from newcomer Rita Burkovska, Butterfly Vision is a timely testament to the trauma and resilience of women on the Ukrainian frontlines.

items.title: Drive
items.short_synopsis: A quiet stuntman works in Hollywood by day and as a driver for the mob by night. He becomes the target for some of L.A.‘s most dangerous men after agreeing to help his neighbor Irene’s husband. When the job goes awry, the only way he can keep Irene and her son safe is to do what he does best: drive.
items.default_editorial: The Taxi Driver of the new millennium? Drive has rewritten coolness in cinema. An instant cult classic that adds a twist to the bad-guy-but-good figure, establishing Gosling as a new kind of antihero (and a real human being!). Welcome to a world of intoxicating beauty and sadness. Enjoy the ride.

items.title: First Love
items.short_synopsis: One night in Tokyo, Leo, a young boxer, meets his first love, Monica, an imprisoned sex worker. Caught up in a drug-smuggling scheme, they find themselves pursued by a corrupt cop, a yakuza, his nemesis, and a female assassin.
items.default_editorial: Tearing through Tokyo at breakneck pace, this riotous lovers-on-the-lam confection from Takashi Miike finds the Japanese maestro at his most hopelessly romantic. Which in Miike-speak means: katana-wielding yakuza, spectral visions, and a vicious, unkillable femme fatale—all the wholesome good stuff!

items.title: Frances Ha
items.short_synopsis: A New York woman (who doesn’t really have an apartment) apprentices for a dance company (though she’s not really a dancer) and throws herself headlong into her dreams, even as the possibility of realizing them dwindles.
items.default_editorial: Noah Baumbach immortalizes the big spirit and small life of a lovably goofy and idealistic young woman, adrift and alone in N.Y. Shot with past-tense tenderness in evocative monochrome, a millennial spirit ignites this new classic, which was both led and cowritten by a luminous Greta Gerwig.

items.title: Frankie
items.short_synopsis: Unfolding over the course of a summer day in the resort town of Sintra, Portugal, this film follows three generations who have gathered for a vacation organized by the family matriarch. Stirred by their romantic impulses, they discover the cracks between them, as well as unexpected depth of feeling.
items.default_editorial: Like Passages, this luminous drama from Ira Sachs dives into a web of interlocking relationships unsettled by the sudden tides of life. Led by the queen of angst Isabelle Huppert, Frankie muses on love and art, the small comforts that bring a levity to the weight of mortality.

items.title: Good One
items.short_synopsis: 17-year-old Sam embarks on a backpacking trip in the Catskills with her dad and his oldest friend. As the two men quickly settle into a quarrelsome dynamic, airing long-held grievances, Sam attempts to mediate. But when lines are crossed and her trust is betrayed, tensions reach a fever pitch.
items.default_editorial: Tree trunks deliver privacy, and brooks fill water bottles: The mountains provide in India Donaldson’s keenly observed debut. Lily Collias gives a poignant performance as a graciously overburdened daughter, balking at the tribalism and dated gender dynamics that rear their ugly heads in the woods.

items.title: Half Nelson
items.short_synopsis: Dan, a dynamic and inspirational history teacher in a Brooklyn high school, leads a secret life of addiction. Juggling his hangovers and homework, Dan keeps his lives separate—until troubled student Drey catches him getting high after school. Soon the two lost souls strike up an unlikely friendship.
items.default_editorial: One of the finest actors of his generation and the face that launched a thousand memes, Ryan Gosling earned an Oscar® nod for his morally ambiguous turn as a burned-out teacher with a dark secret. This gripping drama about an unlikely friendship takes a devastating look at modern alienation.

items.title: House by the River
items.short_synopsis: While his wife is away, Stephen Byrne—a wealthy, deranged, and failed writer—accidentally murders his maid after she resists his advances. He ropes his brother John into helping him hide the body and then does his best to pin the blame for the murder on his sibling.
items.default_editorial: By 1949, Fritz Lang had been exiled to “poverty row”. Though stuck with a small budget and no stars, the noir master used the creative freedom to make one of the eeriest, most downright Lynchian thrillers of his storied career. Long buried, it’s been revived with a shot at getting its due.

items.title: Leonor Will Never Die
items.short_synopsis: Leonor Reyes, a former pioneer of Filipino action cinema, now struggles with ageing, debt, and her son’s death. After being struck by a falling TV, she’s knocked into a coma. In the hospital, fantasy and reality blur as she awakens inside her own story.
items.default_editorial: Celebrating the unsung female voices of a male-dominated genre, this Sundance award-winner is a marvel of stylistic pastiche. Throwing melodrama, fisticuffs, and even a musical number into its meta melting pot, Leonor Will Never Die pays heartfelt tribute to the Philippines’ action-movie heyday.

items.title: Limbo
items.short_synopsis: An offbeat observation of the refugee experience. On a fictional remote Scottish island, a group of new arrivals await the results of their asylum claims. Among them is Omar, a young Syrian musician burdened by the weight of his grandfather’s oud, which he has carried all the way from his homeland.
items.default_editorial: Announcing the arrival of a major homegrown talent in filmmaker Ben Sharrock, Limbo is a deadpan delight bursting with humanity. Illuminating the hopes and hardships of the refugee experience, this wry, poignant, and bracingly funny ode to the kindness of strangers is the British film of the year.

items.title: One Fine Morning
items.short_synopsis: In Paris, a young, widowed mother juggles her job as a translator with caring both for her young daughter and her elderly father, who suffers from a degenerative illness. Her life is further complicated when she embarks on a passionate affair with an old friend in an unhappy marriage.
items.default_editorial: As sensual as the first rays of summer, Mia Hansen-Løve’s latest triumph journeys through the threshold of love and loss with exquisite tenderness. Delivering a career-best performance that aches with vulnerability and strength, Léa Seydoux stuns in this profound portrayal of contemporary womanhood.

items.title: Only God Forgives
items.short_synopsis: Julian, a drug-smuggler thriving in Bangkok’s criminal underworld, sees his life get even more complicated when his mother arrives from the US. Thirsty for vengeance, she compels him to find and kill whoever is responsible for his brother’s recent death, who was killed after murdering a young woman.
items.default_editorial: Continuing his sublimely minimalist collaboration with Ryan Gosling after the sharkskin-sleek Drive, Nicolas Winding Refn returned with his most controversial feature to date. A dangerous, exoticized mash-up of spirituality, Shakespeare, and hyper-violence, Only God Forgives is a blast of pure pulp.

items.title: Orlando, My Political Biography
items.short_synopsis: In 1928, Virginia Woolf wrote Orlando, in which her protagonist changes sex in the middle of the story. A century later, writer and activist Paul B. Preciado sends a filmed letter to Virginia Woolf: Orlando has stepped out of fiction and is living a life she would never have imagined.
items.default_editorial: Forgoing the path of faithful adaptation, Paul B. Preciado stitches new presents and futures into a classic of feminist literature in this glittering celebration of gender abolition. Casting binaries aside to dance to the call of the collective, this plural Orlando advocates for freedom with flair.

items.title: Paris Memories
items.short_synopsis: Three months after a terrorist attack in a Paris bistro, Mia struggles to process her trauma and recall the events of that night. Returning to the city, she retraces her steps and connects with fellow survivors, hoping to find the stranger who comforted her.
items.default_editorial: Tracing the broken contours of traumatic memories, Alice Winocour’s moving film speaks to post-Bataclan Paris as a place of collective grief and resilience. Virginie Efira emanates compassion as a woman assembling puzzle-piece fragments and forming new, intimate bonds in the aftermath of disaster.

items.title: Parthenope
items.short_synopsis: Born in the Bay of Naples in 1950, Parthenope searches for happiness over the long summers of her youth, falling in love with her home city and its many memorable characters. But when tragedy strikes, and carefree romances lose their thrill, she decides to seek a deeper sense of purpose.
items.default_editorial: Returning to the iridescent coastline of Naples, Paolo Sorrentino delivers a sumptuous disquisition on his career-defining preoccupations: youth and beauty. Starring Gary Oldman and—in a star-making turn—Celeste Dalla Porta, Parthenope is a ravishing epic that unfurls with melodious, sirenic allure.

items.title: Paterson
items.short_synopsis: Paterson is a bus driver in the city of Paterson, New Jersey. Every day, Paterson adheres to a simple routine: he drives his bus, observing the city and overhearing fragments of conversation; he writes poetry; he walks his dog; he goes to the same bar to drink a beer; he goes home to his wife Laura.
items.default_editorial: Following an everyman observer as he transfigures his low-key daily routine into verse, Jarmusch’s film depicts moments of epiphany and inspiration, finding the rhymes and rhythms of everyday life. A disarming, imperfectly symmetrical relationship drama, starring Adam Driver and Golshifteh Farahani.

items.title: Pirates
items.short_synopsis: At the dawn of the new millennium, three lifelong friends and pirate radio DJs—Cappo, Kidda and Two Tonne—are looking to bring on the year 2000 in style. A lack of money, tickets, and room in Cappo’s minuscule Peugeot won’t deter them from their desired destination: a raging party in South London.
items.default_editorial: Actor, DJ, and first-time director Reggie Yates throws it back to the Moschino-wearing, two-stepping garage raves of the late ’90s in this after-hours comedy of errors. Capering through London on the eve of Y2K, Pirates spills over with the cheeky, shambolic energy of a night out with best mates.

items.title: Reprise
items.short_synopsis: Erik and Philip have been best friends since childhood and both want to become writers. While Erik’s manuscript is refused by the publishers as lacking in talent, Philip is eagerly welcomed and overnight becomes a young star in Norway’s literary scene. Soon, their young dreams clash with reality.
items.default_editorial: The first in Joachim Trier’s masterful “Oslo Trilogy” is an electric and affecting dual portrait of two writer friends whose ambitions are challenged by the trials of life. Saturated with punk playfulness, Reprise explores the tantalizing promise—and peril—of fulfilling your creative aspirations.

items.title: Results
items.short_synopsis: Danny is newly divorced, wealthy, and totally aimless. To add structure to his life, he joins a gym where he meets the self-styled owner Trevor. But he quickly falls for his audacious new trainer, Kat, who is Trevor’s ex-flame. Soon, their lives become entangled, both professionally and personally.
items.default_editorial: With more famous actors and a less lo-fi look than his earlier films (Funny Ha Ha), Results is still unmistakably Andrew Bujalski. As it wavers between the peppy credulity of a self-starter and the wry cynicism of a divorcé, this warm rom-com echoes the highs and lows of independent filmmaking.

items.title: She Dies Tomorrow
items.short_synopsis: After waking up convinced that she is going to die tomorrow, Amy’s carefully mended life begins to unravel. As her delusions of certain death become contagious to those around her, Amy and her friends’ lives spiral out of control in a tantalizing descent into madness.
items.default_editorial: Epiphanies of impending demise are infectious in Amy Seimetz’s ominous and operatic sophomore feature, which stars two of our favorite indie actors, Kate Lyn Sheil and Jane Adams. With flickering imagery and an absurd sense of humor, She Dies Tomorrow is a haunting, hypnotic pleasure.

items.title: Smoking Causes Coughing
items.short_synopsis: After a devastating battle against a diabolical giant turtle, five superheroes known as the Tobacco Force are sent on a mandatory week-long retreat to strengthen their decaying group cohesion. Their sojourn goes wonderfully well until Lézardin, Emperor of Evil, decides to annihilate planet Earth.
items.default_editorial: An absurdist comedy from the director of Deerskin and Rubber, Smoking Causes Coughing combines superhero pastiche with horror anthology, as macabre tales interrupt a tense vacation for the Power Rangers-like Tobacco Force. You will believe a woman can fall in love with a talking rat!

items.title: Sorry, Baby
items.short_synopsis: Something bad happened to Agnes, but life goes on for everyone else. When a beloved friend on the brink of a major milestone visits, Agnes starts to realize just how stuck she’s been, and begins to work through how to move forward.
items.default_editorial: Salting psychological trauma with sly humour and a mackerel kitten, this bracing debut from comedian Eva Victor puts roses in the cheeks. Recalling Kenneth Lonergan’s dramas with piercing honesty and confident tread, this tale of self-compassion and companionship is an adagio in New England snow.

items.title: Sword of Trust
items.short_synopsis: A grumpy pawnshop owner and his man-child employee join forces with a quirky couple to sell a Civil War-era sword, which comes with a convoluted report that claims the South won the war. This draws the attention of conspiracy theorists who are desperate to get their hands on the legendary sword.
items.default_editorial: Lynn Shelton twists her mumblecore ties to authenticity in this outlandish comedy, in which an array of dubious conspiracies are unleashed. As characters countering those theories with wild, harebrained schemes of their own, the ensemble cast makes a gonzo commitment to absurdity and surprise.

items.title: Tangerine
items.short_synopsis: On Christmas Eve, transgender sex worker Sin-Dee Rella meets her friend and fellow transgender sex worker Alexandra at Donut Time. Once informed that her boyfriend and pimp, Chester, has been cheating on her with a white cisgender woman, Sin-Dee storms out to search the neighborhood.
items.default_editorial: How can a movie shot on a mobile phone look as gorgeous as this intrepid portrait of female friendship? Filmmaking tricks aside, Sean Baker’s fifth feature gives voice to one of L.A.’s least explored subcultures while emerging as a tactful working-girl revenge hit. A major hit at Sundance!

items.title: The Eight Mountains
items.short_synopsis: In a secluded village in the Italian Alps, an unlikely brotherhood forms between two boys, Pietro and Bruno. Over the years Bruno remains faithful to his home while Pietro aspires to greater heights, but as decades pass and lives unfold, their paths ultimately lead them back to where they first met.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Cannes Jury Prize in 2022, The Eight Mountains is a tenderly told story of boyhood and friendship that unfolds unhurriedly against the astonishing landscapes of Northern Italy. Luca Marinelli (Martin Eden) is magnificent once again in this gentle yet grandiose film.

items.title: The Falling
items.short_synopsis: In an English girls’ school in 1969, sixteen-year-old Abbie and Lydia are best friends. A tragedy at the school triggers a mysterious epidemic among the pupils. The authorities claim there is nothing wrong, but Lydia refuses to accept this. In seeking the truth, she discovers a long-buried secret.
items.default_editorial: Carol Morley became one of Britain’s most celebrated directors with this mysterious tour de force starring Maisie Williams, Maxine Peake, and Florence Pugh in her acting debut! A case of mass hysteria in a 60s girls’ school acts as a chilling, mesmerising and allegorical dive into the female psyche.

items.title: The House by the Cemetery
items.short_synopsis: The Boyles buy a house in rural New England. Little do they know, the previous owner was the deranged Dr. Freudstein, whose experiments left behind a legacy of bloody mayhem. Now the devilish doctor sets his sights on the young family, and home sweet home is about to become a horrific hell on earth.
items.default_editorial: Generously sprinkled with his signature sadistic kills, Lucio Fulci’s gory take on the haunted-house film also invokes a rich atmosphere of wintry melancholy and paranormal unease. From creaky doors to rumbling cellars, the mysterious soundscape churns out fresh horrors, beckoning our deepest fears.

items.title: The Image Book
items.short_synopsis: Godard’s film essay delves into cinema’s history and modern world. He manipulates film fragments, reflecting on dissonance. His voice guides through metaphysical musings, anchored by an obsession with images, offering a poignant ontological exploration.
items.default_editorial: Presenting the final masterwork by Jean-Luc Godard, the French New Wave titan whose inventive brilliance will be impossible to replace. Winner of the first-ever Special Palme d’Or at Cannes, The Image Book is a riotous whirlwind of images and sounds from the father of modern cinema. Forever JLG.

items.title: The Last Showgirl
items.short_synopsis: When the glittering Las Vegas revue she has headlined for decades announces it will soon close, showgirl Shelly sets out to plan her next act. Reconciling the decisions she’s made and the life she’s built, Shelly decides to repair her complicated relationship with her daughter.
items.default_editorial: Pamela Anderson gives a revelatory performance in this poignant drama from director Gia Coppola. With zesty support from Jamie Lee Curtis and original songs by Miley Cyrus, The Last Showgirl burnishes the tarnished rhinestones of downtown Las Vegas for a reflective study in artistic resilience.

items.title: The Loveless
items.short_synopsis: 1959. A motorcycle gang led by Vance is en route to the races at Daytona. They make a pit stop in a small rural Georgia town for repairs. Soon, the town’s tight-knit locals begin to grow uneasy with the unruly outsiders, who appear to encourage rebellion in anyone they encounter.
items.default_editorial: Kathryn Bigelow made her debut with this atmospheric dive into the rebellious, leather-clad world of motorcycle gangs and the open road. Initially a thesis film, The Loveless evolved into something far greater, launching both Willem Dafoe and Bigelow’s invaluable contributions to American cinema.

items.title: Time of the Wolf
items.short_synopsis: The time preceding the apocalypse is known in Germanic mythology as the time of the wolves. Fleeing a disaster, a middle-class family travel to their countryside holiday home, believing themselves to be escaping the consequences of the general state of chaos, but they find it occupied by strangers.
items.default_editorial: The most divisive film from one of the most divisive filmmakers, Time of the Wolf expands Michael Haneke’s reach into post-apocalyptic territory for a sci-fi-tinged drama as tense and provocative as anything he’s done. Starring the Austrian auteur’s frequent collaborator Isabelle Huppert.

items.title: 25 Ways to Quit Smoking
items.short_synopsis: Noted animator Bill Plympton helps you kick the habit by illustrating 25 ways to curb your nicotine cravings that are effective, simple, and often far more hazardous to your health than a 5-pack-a-day habit. Beware the sumo treatment!
items.default_editorial: If you’ve ever struggled to quit smoking: you’ll know just how frustrating it can be to kick that habit. Here’s a solution! Why not watch this short “how-to” from the American “King of Indie Animation,” Bill Plympton? This quirky compendium of novel, animated vignettes might be just the ticket.

items.title: A Room in Town
items.short_synopsis: In this musical melodrama set against the backdrop of a workers’ strike in Nantes, a young woman wishes to leave her brutish husband for an earthy steelworker, though he is involved with another. Unbeknownst to the girl, the object of her affection boards with her no-nonsense baroness mother.
items.default_editorial: With The Umbrellas of Cherbourg, A Room in Town is Jacques Demy’s other “sung” film, in which he depicts a political, local crisis alongside a personal one, in which pressure and desperation lead to fatal acts. A twirling and dark drama starring Dominique Sanda, Michel Piccoli and Danielle Darrieux.

items.title: A Slightly Pregnant Man
items.original_title: L'événement le plus important depuis que l'homme a marché sur la lune
items.short_synopsis: Marco, an Italian driving instructor living in Paris, pays a visit to the doctor, who promptly diagnoses him as four months pregnant. The medical miracle is heard round the world, as Marco becomes fodder for the press, a curiosity to the scientific world, and a cash cow for a maternity-wear company.
items.default_editorial: This exuberant comedy by Jacques Demy stars Marcello Mastroianni as… a pregnant man! Joyful, colorful and with a score by Michel Legrand, this is pure Demy at his most farcical, but also at his most metaphorical, emphasizing a need for change of attitudes towards gender roles and families.

items.title: Adieu Philippine
items.short_synopsis: France, 1960. In two months, young technician Michel will leave for Algeria to fulfill his military duties. Until then, he spends his time dating best friends Liliane and Juliette. When he goes on holiday to Corsica, the girls join him, and a game of seduction and rivalry evolves between them.
items.default_editorial: A high-spirited gallivant, Jacques Rozier’s feature debut has to be among the most genuinely spontaneous and formally radical of the early French New Wave films. This once-overlooked masterwork sets out on a youthful excursion through Corsica that fizzes with political urgency and sensory vividness.

items.title: Brand Upon the Brain!
items.short_synopsis: Guy and his sister grow up on an island. His domineering mother keeps watch over everything from the lighthouse, while his eccentric father experiments in the basement laboratory. Another pair of siblings, the Lightball Kids, are two detectives sent to the island to bring light into the darkness.
items.default_editorial: Visionary director Guy Maddin creates a delirious ode to gothic silent cinema and the land of his childhood in Brand Upon the Brain. A cinematic whirlwind of bizarre apparitions, combining personal memoir and science-fiction into a baroque extravaganza. A wild ride through an eccentric imagination.

items.title: Careful
items.short_synopsis: Guy Maddin’s early masterpiece takes place in a 19th-century Alpine village where the wary residents must speak softly and tread lightly lest they cause an avalanche. But sexual frenzies teem in this world of repression, setting off incestuous love triangles and quadrangles with deadly consequences.
items.default_editorial: Canadian madman Guy Maddin conjures an alternate film history, one where we never left that unreal time in the late 20s when silent film was at its creative peak but sound was knocking at the door. Here’s his brilliant, dreamy transport to a reimagined lost world!

items.title: Dracula: Pages from a Virgin's Diary
items.original_title: Dracula: Pages from a Virgin's Diary
items.short_synopsis: A ballet rendition of Bram Stoker’s gothic novel, presented in a style reminiscent of the silent expressionistic cinema of the early 20th Century.
items.default_editorial: A both more and less conventional vampire film. Yes, it tells the familiar Dracula story—but filtered brilliantly first through a ballet version of Bram Stoker (!) and secondly thru director Guy Maddin’s exuberantly inventive homage to silent and early sound cinema. A sensual delight!

items.title: Faded Roads
items.short_synopsis: A country song about life on the highway, searching for lost love. This short is a wonderful blend of Bill’s classical surreal animated style and a more spare rotoscoped look.
items.default_editorial: Portland, Oregon’s renowned “King of Indie Animation” takes on a lost love and the thrill of the open road in this joyful short ditty. An animated country music video of sorts that moves restlessly through the different life stages, multiplying eyeballs and heads with feverish delight.

items.title: Hair High
items.short_synopsis: A gothic ’50s high-school comedy about a love-triangle that goes terribly bad, as two young, murdered teens returning to their prom to get revenge.
items.default_editorial: Bill Plympton takes a distorted swipe at high-school prom movies with this Gothic-grotesque animated comedy about a love-triangle gone horribly wrong. In his characteristically whimsical manner, Plympton manages to make the body a site of bizarre mishaps—teen love has rarely looked so strange!

items.title: How to Kiss
items.short_synopsis: As a brave couple demonstrates, the narrator uses quotes, examples and advice to help us all reach the highest heights in the art of kissing.
items.default_editorial: The legendary American animator explores the many variations of kisses, including the classic French kiss. A palpable dissonance emerges between Bill Plympton’s trippy, elastic and disconcertingly physical animations of people kissing and the cheery voice-over. A playful ode to smooching.

items.title: How to Make Love to a Woman
items.original_title: How to Make Love to a Woman
items.short_synopsis: An animated look at the 11 essential steps to make the pilgrim’s progess from finding a woman to making love to her.
items.default_editorial: In five minutes, the mischievous indie animation filmmaker Bill Plympton shares with us some advice through this how-to guide about… sex! Through voice-over instructions and Plympton’s offbeat, ingenious drawings, he ironically mocks the silly sanctity surrounding intercourse and a women’s body.

items.title: I Married a Strange Person!
items.short_synopsis: A newlywed develops a strange lump on his neck that gives him the ability to transform people or objects at will. His wife is very upset. Meanwhile, the CEO of Smilecorp learns of this man and his ability and sees a way to achieve world domination if only the man can be taken alive.
items.default_editorial: In a world of nagging corporate bosses–oh, and also shape-shifting humans–Bill Plympton’s newlyweds must juggle their insatiable sex drive and save the world from evil conglomerates. Wildly inventive and delightfully inappropriate, this animated farce of modern romance has a surprisingly big heart!

items.title: Idiots and Angels
items.short_synopsis: Angel, a selfish and morally bankrupt man, wakes up one morning with wings on his back, in this dark comedy about a person’s battle for their soul.
items.default_editorial: The bonkers opus from American indie animator Bill Plympton provides an in-depth reflection on good and evil. With a style of humor reminiscent of another great American enfant terrible, R. Crumb, Plympton imbues his work with a strange brew that only he knows the recipe for.

items.title: In Absentia
items.short_synopsis: A woman alone in a room repeatedly writes a letter with tiny broken off pieces of pencil lead. Outside her window, vistas of ever-changing light register her every emotion.
items.default_editorial: One of the Quay Brothers’ most abstract films, In Absentia combines live-action and animation with the sinister music of Stockhausen to generate a doom-metal landscape of the mind. Fraught, haunting, yet eerily beautiful, the images move and flicker in a shifting dance of light and shadow.

items.title: In the Family
items.short_synopsis: Chip Hines, a precocious six year old, has only known life with his two dads, Cody and Joey. When Cody dies suddenly in a car accident, Joey and Chip struggle to find their footing again. Just as they begin to, Cody’s will reveals that he named his sister as Chip’s guardian.
items.default_editorial: Patrick Wang makes his mark on the landscape of independent American cinema with this impressive self-distributed debut, in which the writer-director also stars. A humane, deeply felt family drama of growth and survival, the film embraces grief and loss as the source of extraordinary strength.

items.title: Keyhole
items.short_synopsis: A surreal indoor odyssey of one man, Ulysses Pick (Jason Patric) struggling to reach his wife (Isabella Rosellini) in her bedroom upstairs, this hypnotic dreamlike journey bewilders and captivates.
items.default_editorial: Watching a Guy Maddin picture is like rummaging through a celluloid flea market of the found and forgotten. Keyhole is a spectral summoning of the ‘30s gangster movie, boiled in a cauldron of expressionist horror for a brew that at once shouldn’t exist, yet seemingly, in Maddin’s hands, always has.

items.title: Les vacances c'est la liberté
items.short_synopsis: A group of four young workers, caught up by a need for change, decide to head for the sea after a day of work. Elsewhere, farther away, a young woman, victim to solitude, wanders in the streets of Paris.
items.default_editorial: This short film by Yuna Alonzo explores the sense of freedom that only a sea escapade can bring, and the loneliness of the city over the summer season. A whimsical breath of fresh air and revitalizing tonic for its characters and viewers alike: just like a good summer getaway!

items.title: Lola
items.short_synopsis: Roland, a bored young man, meets Lola, a woman he was in love with during his teens. Now a cabaret dancer and a devoted single mother, Lola hopes the father of her child, who deserted during her pregnancy, will return. Roland finds himself falling back in love with her.
items.default_editorial: Sparkling with the spirit of the early years of the French New Wave, Jacques Demy’s first feature dances to the iconic music of Michel Legrand and is framed with beautiful melancholy by Raoul Coutard. As Lola, the eponymous object of our affections, Anouk Aimée is wistful but spellbinding.

items.title: Mutant Aliens
items.short_synopsis: Cult icon Bill Plympton dishes out his fourth foray into feature-length animation with this outrageous send-up of outer space adventures.
items.default_editorial: We love the wild visions of excess of legendary animator Bill Plympton. With Mutant Aliens, his fourth foray into feature-length animation, Plympton goes gross-out, with a science-fiction fantasia laced with high camp and disturbed erotica. You’ve been warned!

items.title: My Winnipeg
items.short_synopsis: The geographical dead center of North America and the beloved birthplace of Guy Maddin, Winnipeg, is the frosty and mysterious star of Maddin’s film. Fact, fantasy and memory are woven seamlessly together in this work, conjuring a city as delightful as it is fearsome.
items.default_editorial: A cinematic “city symphony” of sorts, this is a mind-bending trip to Winnipeg guided by iconoclastic and ingenious Canadian auteur Guy Maddin. Half demiurge, half mad scientist, Maddin has taken cinema to the next level, and even created his own genre: the docu-fantasia.

items.title: Nose Hair
items.short_synopsis: A man plucks a hair from his nostril. The hair wants back in.
items.default_editorial: Another of Bill Plympton’s joyously physical animated shorts, Nose Hair burrows into the deepest recesses of our nostrils to pull out the joyful elasticity of unwanted facial hair. The irreverent American animator’s loose and fluid line veers off in new directions and the results are delightful!

items.title: Nude Caboose
items.short_synopsis: A jovial shirtless man attempts to rouse a contingent of lethargic dancers to life in Nude Caboose. His highjinks really get the deadbeats bustin’ out until something unusual catches his eye. Dance floor seduction distilled into a fateful moment.
items.default_editorial: Another wonderful oddity from Guy Maddin, Nude Caboose quizzically chases its own tail, like an ouroboros. A semi-nude conga line is led by one particularly gregarious man—a peculiar scene rendered in a VHS/CRT aesthetic—and nicely paired with gloriously funky music. Watch it and you’ll understand.

items.title: Out
items.short_synopsis: A man suffers from a disturbed perception and is affected by hallucinatory images. Is it all reality or is he just dreaming? Ten seconds of life can flow like honey.
items.default_editorial: Experimenting with flashbacks to hypnotic results, Vincent Hazard’s Out guides us through the disorienting, often blurry past of a mysterious lead character. Split frames, kaleidoscopic lighting and non-diegetic sounds are just some of the key ingredients for this offbeat, atmospheric short.

items.title: Push Comes to Shove
items.short_synopsis: An animated short in which two volunteers demonstrate the proper way to vent the aggressive feelings that one has for one’s fellow man from time to time. Calmly, quietly, and with as many power tools as possible.
items.default_editorial: This anarchically surreal study in violence from animation maestro Bill Plympton sees a pair of besuited, Gilbert & George-looking gents inflict increasing damage on each other’s person. A beautifully hand-drawn comic miniature, Push Comes to Shove gives new meaning to the word “punchline.”

items.title: Rehearsals for Extinct Anatomies
items.short_synopsis: Oscillating hands each hold a pen; a man made of wire has a malevolent look and an roving eye as he pokes at a bump on his forehead. Op-art stripes are in the fabric. Lines become jumbles that become balls that oscillate, bounce, or stay suspended in air.
items.default_editorial: The Quay Brothers’ visionary, avant-garde stop-motion has dazzled audiences for decades. In this, the first of their films shot in B&W, a Fragonard painting inspires a quivering visual study of graphic lines and anatomical specimens that brings to life the strange inner life of objects.

items.title: Sex and Violence
items.short_synopsis: In eight minutes, animator Bill Plympton gives us 24 vignettes: seven are clearly about sex, 10 about violence, and seven others deal with human frailties, particularly the body as it ages.
items.default_editorial: Somehow, in only eight minutes, American animator Bill Plympton cycles through studies of sex, violence, God, time, and human frailty in 24 dizzyingly animated vignettes. Sex and Violence highlights the animal nature of human beings and their bestial sexual desires with cool, nihilistic abandon.

items.title: Singapore Sling
items.original_title: Singapore Sling: Ο Άνθρωπος που Αγάπησε ένα Πτώμα
items.short_synopsis: One night Singapore Sling finds himself in a mysterious villa, watching two women bury a body. He falls into their trap and, in an atmosphere of isolation and decadence, the trio act out insane pleasure games and a ritual of blood and murder.
items.default_editorial: Impossible to be contained by a single genre, Singapore Sling challenges, teases and shocks the viewer with a plot that features various kinds of perversion and depravity. This legendary cult film subverts moral expectations and cinematic conventions to create something unique and deeply weird.

items.title: Sissy Boy Slap Party
items.short_synopsis: This film plays like a goofy homage to Kenneth Anger’s Fireworks and Jean Genet as well as some po-faced example of ethnographic documentary.
items.default_editorial: No one could ever complain that Guy Maddin’s riotous six minute short doesn’t deliver on the promise of its title. An astonishing feat of editing, Sissy Boy Slap Party fuses Three Stooges silliness with the fever-dream milieu of Kenneth Anger—it’s not hard to see why John Waters is a superfan.

items.title: Sorrowful Shadow
items.short_synopsis: Widow Paramo has lost her husband to the plague. Their daughter Dolores is considering suicide, with El Muerto—the eater of souls— preparing himself to welcome her into the darkness. Paramo must triumph over Death in the boxing ring if she wishes to save both her husband and daughter.
items.default_editorial: Though he has risen to prominence for acclaimed feature-length films such as Dracula and My Winnipeg, Canada’s Guy Maddin remains a highly prolific, inventive virtuouso of a short film form. Here is one of our favorites: an outrageously deranged comic reimagining of Mexican melodrama.

items.title: Stille Nacht I: Dramolet
items.short_synopsis: The Quays’ familiar puppet animation is here enhanced by the use of animated iron filings, which suggest the rapid formation of frost over every surface, the swaying of the individual particles suggesting a hefty buffeting by a keen, piercing wind.
items.default_editorial: We invite you to peer through the peephole into the Gothic and disjointed universe of the Quay Brothers’s own strange imaginings. In this dark, two-minute micro-short, the vivid textures of metal filings, animated by the force of a magnet, fuel a strange doll’s breakfast. Heady and evocative.

items.title: Stille Nacht II: Are We Still Married?
items.short_synopsis: The Quays’ familiar puppet animation is here enhanced by the use of animated iron filings, which suggest the rapid formation of frost over every surface, the swaying of the individual particles suggesting a hefty buffeting by a keen, piercing wind.
items.default_editorial: Part of the Quay Brothers’ Stille Nacht series, this hypnotic 3-minute animated short assembles a curious cast of assorted odds and ends—a ping pong ball, a white rabbit, a rag doll—to perform a magical, menacing dance. As ever with the Quays, here lies the stuff of dreams: or is that nightmares?

items.title: Stille Nacht III: Tales from the Vienna Woods
items.short_synopsis: The Quays’ familiar puppet animation is here enhanced by the use of animated iron filings, which suggest the rapid formation of frost over every surface, the swaying of the individual particles suggesting a hefty buffeting by a keen, piercing wind.
items.default_editorial: Prefiguring some of the arboreal imagery that they would later use in their classic feature Institute Benjamenta, the Quay Brothers’s third entry in the Stille Nacht series delves into the darkest corners of the forest for its dream-like and psychotronic imagery.

items.title: Stille Nacht IV: Can’t Go Wrong Without You
items.short_synopsis: The Quays’ familiar puppet animation is here enhanced by the use of animated iron filings, which suggest the rapid formation of frost over every surface, the swaying of the individual particles suggesting a hefty buffeting by a keen, piercing wind.
items.default_editorial: In this, the fourth and final in the Quay Brothers’s Stille Nacht series, we return to the creepy imagery of rabbits and dolls that bolstered the second entry, alongside the music of His Name Is Alive. Expressionistic disorientation and jagged edges abound in this Lewis Carroll-esque animated short.

items.title: Street of Crocodiles
items.short_synopsis: A museum keeper spits into the eyepiece of an ancient peep-show and sets the musty machine going. Inside, the puppets partake of a series of bizarre rituals amongst the dirt and the grime.
items.default_editorial: The Quay Brothers’ legendary stop-motion short was chosen by Terry Gilliam as one of the best animated films ever and its not hard to see why. Based on a short story by Bruno Schulz, Street of Crocodiles is cloaked in shadows and stalked by mystery: as the dormant creakily comes back to life.

items.title: Surprise Cinema
items.short_synopsis: A mischievious man plays an assortment of extreme practical jokes on unsuspecting victims – like replacing one man’s razor with a chainsaw.
items.default_editorial: A late-’90s animated short from American indie animator Bill Plympton, Surprise Cinema introduces a series of impossible situations and lets us watch them play out. Always irreverent, playful, witty, and off-the-cuff, this is exactly the kind of skilled silliness we expect from Plympton.

items.title: The Beaches of Agnès
items.short_synopsis: Returning to the beaches that have been part of her life, Agnès Varda invents a kind of self-portrait-documentary. Agnès stages herself among excerpts of her films, images and reportages; weaving public and private struggles, loves and friendships, films and people, and the history of French cinema.
items.default_editorial: Agnès Varda, the beloved “godmother” of the French New Wave, proved that ageing is something to celebrate in this marvelous, bittersweet self-portrait of a life well-lived. Made up of film excerpts and dramatic restagings, it manages to be tenderly reflective and funny, yet always full of wisdom.

items.title: The Comb
items.short_synopsis: The film opens in the shadowy bedroom of a sleeping beauty and seems to enter her mind and burrow into her dreams.
