Based on the text by the Austrian writer Robert Walser, The Comb is an exploration of the subconscious visualized as a labyrinthine playhouse haunted by a doll-like explorer.
items.default_editorial: Go forth on a most hypnotic odyssey with the Brothers Quay. A labyrinthine dreamscape bursting with detail and wonder, The Comb is a work of meticulously handcrafted cinema that both borrows from our world and seems projected directly from another dimension. The Brothers never fail to inspire us!

items.title: The Grief of Others
items.short_synopsis: The Ryries have suffered a loss: The death of a baby just after birth. Without words to express their grief, the parents try to return to their previous lives. The kids respond to the tensions around them in idiosyncratic ways. But as the family scatters into grief, an unexpected visitor arrives.
items.default_editorial: Adapted from Leah Hager Cohen’s eponymous novel, Patrick Wang’s staggering family drama unfurls the tortuous cycles and domino effects of grief with immense empathy and acuity. A uniquely renewing emotional experience where artmaking emerges as the cathartic conduit for exorcizing personal demons.

items.title: The Heart of the World
items.short_synopsis: It is both a spoof and a loving recreation of Soviet silent film. It is also an inventive movie in its own right. It is so full of images, one rapidly following the other in montage style, that it feels like it has the imagery and storytelling of a much longer movie.
items.default_editorial: Commissioned by the Toronto Film Festival, Guy Maddin created this hypnotic, six-minute gem that was inspired by Russian Constructivism. A glittering parody of Soviet propaganda films, told through delirious Eisensteinian montage, the film is a cinephile’s mission statement for the future of cinema.

items.title: The Mountain of Terror
items.short_synopsis: Part of Antoine Barraud’s triptych devoted to three Japanese directors.
items.default_editorial: Having already crafted experimental portraits of Kenneth Anger and Kōji Wakamatsu, French filmmaker Antoine Barraud turned to Shūji Terayama for his next tribute. An avant-garde rumination on the Japanese iconoclast, Mountain of Terror is a richly textured odyssey that traces the soul of the poet.

items.title: The Northerners
items.short_synopsis: During the summer of 1960, the unique residents of a one-street Dutch suburb collide in intertwining tales of desire and frustration. Among them is a 12-year-old boy obsessed with events on the broadcast news, a butcher who has sex problems, and a postman who opens all the mail.
items.default_editorial: Stylishly captured in clean lines and primary colors, modern life is nonetheless far from perfect in Alex van Warmerdam’s acclaimed cult film. Nestled into mid-century houses next to humdrum marital discord, saintly delusion and the end of empire rattle throughout this surreal, explosive satire.

items.title: The Piano Tuner of Earthquakes
items.short_synopsis: The Quay Brothers return for their first film in a decade with this live-action story of an 19th-century opera singer who is murdered on-stage shortly before her upcoming wedding.
items.default_editorial: The Quays’ second feature-length work is a demonically dark and eerily beautiful live-action fairy-tale set in the gothic Carpathian Mountains. Guy Maddin describes it as “the most strangely and subtly variegated march-past of Love’s delirious mechanisms ever committed to film.”

items.title: The Saddest Music in the World
items.original_title: The Saddest Music in the World
items.short_synopsis: A sort-of musical set in Winnipeg during the Great Depression, where a beer baroness organizes a contest to find the saddest music in the world. Musicians from around the world descend on the city to try and win first place – a $25,000 prize.
items.default_editorial: Winnipeg’s iconoclastic weirdo conjured his most spectacular film to date with this wild melodrama composed of beer, music, and glass legs. The Saddest Music in the World does the near impossible and entirely lives up to its perfect title by way of a welcome cocktail of the surreal and the sincere.

items.title: The Tune
items.short_synopsis: Del is a song writer for the obnoxious Mr. Mega, and in love with Didi, Mega’s secretary. His quest to write a hit tune brings him to the wacky world of Flooby Nooby, where he just might learn to write songs from the heart.
items.default_editorial: Just how Bill Plympton managed to draw every image in this brilliantly wacky feature-length animation, we’ll never know. A marvelous musical frolic from the cult hero of independent animation, The Tune is guaranteed to cheer you up, and plant a couple of ear worms in the process!

items.title: The World of Jacques Demy
items.short_synopsis: In tribute to her late husband Jacques Demy, filmmaker Agnès Varda honors his life and artistic legacy by weaving together film clips, archival footage, and interviews with collaborators such as Michel Legrand, Catherine Deneuve, Jeanne Moreau, and Harrison Ford.
items.default_editorial: After her more intimate, formally-unconventional Jacquot de Nantes, Agnès Varda films a third portrait of her late partner Jacques Demy in this touching tribute to Demy’s resplendent filmmaking career. Featuring Lola’s Anouk Aimée and The Umbrellas of Cherbourg’s Catherine Deneuve.

items.title: Toto Who Lived Twice
items.short_synopsis: This black-and-white film kicked off a censorship debate in Italy after state censors refused to classify it, stalling release. The anthology format links three episodes: an idiot has no funds to hire the village whore, so he steals from the local Mafia don’s holy shrine.
items.default_editorial: A film of miracles, crucifixion and resurrection, this subversive allegory of the life of Christ found an enemy in the state censor. A ripe parody of religion and masculinity, rich in local Sicilian color, Toto Who Lived Twice is a gleefully grotesque take on The Gospel According to Matthew.

items.title: Trinkets and Dark Thoughts
items.short_synopsis: On a Sunday morning, a group of young revelers enter a large, vacated apartment. Tired drag queens mix with debauched grannies, drunken vagrants and shy virgins over the course of the morning.
items.default_editorial: Detailing a raucous afterparty in a tiny French apartment, this kaleidoscopic short from Alexis Langlois positively sparkles with electric aesthetic energy. With great tunes—and a cartoon cat!—Langlois mounts a vivid communal spectacle that celebrates sexual identity in all in its forms.

items.title: Your Face
items.short_synopsis: One of the most profitable short films ever made, this set the style and started the career of Bill Plympton. As a second-rate crooner sings about the beauties of his lover’s face, his own face metamorphosizes into the most surreal shapes and contortions possible.
items.default_editorial: In his 1987 Academy Award®-nominated short, the “King of Indie Animation” Bill Plympton makes a charmingly playful and wonderfully effortless study of facial distortions. Your Face traces a tenor’s many facial distortions as he sings a ballad to his lover—the simplest ideas are often the best.

items.title: Road North
items.short_synopsis: Timo is an esteemed concert pianist whose personal life is on the rocks. One day Timo finds an older, shabby-looking man at his door. The man, Leo, turns out to be his father who left the country when Timo was three — and hasn’t been in touch in 35 years.
items.default_editorial: You may know the lovely cinema of garage-rock auteur Aki Kaurismäki, but his brother Mika is in fact just as prodigious a filmmaker who dexterously and with pleasure jumps from genre to genre. Here’s his Finnish take on the buddy comedy road movie, proving Americans hardly have a claim on the idea!

items.short_synopsis: 36 is the number of shots on an analogue roll of film. It’s also the number of shots in this film. Yet it’s not a strict film, but the playful quest of a young photographer for the photos that disappeared on her computer: a whole year’s worth, including one of a challenging encounter.
items.default_editorial: An exquisite work of Thai art cinema, Nawapol Thamrongrattanarit’s award-winning debut feature is a languorous, intelligent, and deeply inquisitive look at photography. An experiment in formalism that also explores how images document memories and the textures of human relationships.

items.title: A Dog Called Money
items.short_synopsis: Award-winning war photographer and filmmaker Seamus Murphy explores the creative inspiration behind PJ Harvey’s album The Hope Six Demolition Project, filming her in a London recording studio and charting their travels together in Afghanistan, Kosovo and the U.S.
items.default_editorial: PJ Harvey fans and film lovers alike will be captivated by this thought-provoking documentary—both an intimate journey into the creative process, and a kaleidoscopic travelogue in zones of war and social unrest. Dreamlike and elliptical, this is a stunning portrait of an enigmatic musical icon.

items.title: Ali & Ava
items.short_synopsis: A shared love of music ignites sparks between Ali and Ava. Ali finds comfort in Ava’s warmth and kindness while Ava finds Ali’s complexity and humour irresistible. They have to find a way to keep their newfound passion being overshadowed by the stresses of their separate histories.
items.default_editorial: Claire Rushbrook and Adeel Akhtar give magnificent performances at the center of this cross-cultural romance from British filmmaker Clio Barnard. A charismatic, Bradford-set drama energised by a rousingly eclectic soundtrack, Ali & Ava intimately unfurls the knotted entanglements of life and love.

items.title: Belle de jour
items.short_synopsis: Frigid, beautiful young housewife Séverine cannot reconcile her kinky, sadomasochistic imagination with her everyday life alongside dutiful husband Pierre. She starts an afternoon job in a local, high-class brothel under the name Belle de Jour while her husband is away at work.
items.default_editorial: Luis Buñuel’s magnificently kinky dark comedy about secret desire was his biggest popular success, and continues to shock, provoke, and delight audiences to this day. Catherine Deneuve is the film’s guiding light. Sly, opaque, gorgeous, and dressed top-to-toe in YSL, she is nothing short of iconic.

items.title: Bushman
items.short_synopsis: A young Nigerian living in San Francisco in the 1960s, lovestruck and culturally stranded, faces the harsh realities of life. Interwoven through his adventures in America are glances of his origins, and the dualities of the political and racial mood of the US alongside the Civil War in Nigeria.
items.default_editorial: Worldly, witty, and often sexy, Bushman exquisitely realizes the textures of  the immigrant experience—and had critics buzzing with excitement after its recent restoration. Taking a mighty wrecking ball to filmic conventions and social stereotypes, this is independent cinema at its most revelatory.

items.title: Caligula: The Ultimate Cut
items.short_synopsis: The extensive reconstruction of the notorious 1980 spectacle. Shadowed by the murder of his family, Caligula eliminates his devious adoptive grandfather and seizes control of the Roman Empire alongside his wife Caesonia before descending into a spiral of depravity, destruction, and madness.
items.default_editorial: First released in 1979 to instant infamy, the star-studded Caligula is now presented in a glorious new cut, painstakingly reconstructed from never-before-seen footage. Fashioning an artful interpretation of a debauched Rome, this refreshed vision of a cult classic continues to seduce and astound.

items.title: Calm With Horses
items.short_synopsis: When a former boxer is offered a gig as an enforcer with the local drug mafia, life seems on the uptick—but the demands weigh heavily as he makes inroads with his young son.
items.default_editorial: Cosmo Jarvis is magnetic as a man of tender feelings but brutal deeds in Nick Rowland’s muscular debut feature. With thumping music, striking neons, and a restless turn from Barry Keoghan, Calm With Horses paints a tragicomic portrait of bruised masculinity in a criminal world verging on the absurd.

items.title: Carnal Knowledge
items.short_synopsis: Jonathan and Sandy share an endless fascination with women. As time passes, their relentless pursuits become more competitive and damaging. Their lives become a vicious circle of girls, booze, and unfulfillment—realizing too late that in the war of the sexes, they are their own worst enemy.
items.default_editorial: One of the great New Hollywood films, Carnal Knowledge is an oft-overlooked gem in the careers of Jack Nicholson and Mike Nichols. A scathing, decades-spanning portrait of misogyny, male ego, and the women left in its wake, this acidic study in arms-length intimacy is an anti-romcom for the ages.

items.title: Chicken
items.short_synopsis: Richard longs to put down roots but his restless and destructive brother, Polly needs to keep moving. When the land they live on is bought by a new landowner, and the electricity supply to their caravan is cut, their already precarious living conditions get even worse.
items.default_editorial: Here’s to indie British cinema! With echoes of Ken Loach’s indelible Kes, Joe Stephenson’s compassionate debut finds the perfect (and rare!) balance between rawness and tenderness. A talent to watch, already working on his second feature, starring no less than Ian McKellen & Vanessa Redgrave.

items.title: Days of the Bagnold Summer
items.short_synopsis: A teenager spends his summer listening to heavy metal music and trying to get along with his librarian mom.
items.default_editorial: In his heartfelt feature debut as director, Simon Bird crafts acerbic comedy from the tedium of a gray British summer, pitting teenage angst against the gentle irritation of motherly concern. As a bittersweet Belle and Sebastian score swaddles heartache, loneliness is drawn in soothing pastel tones.

items.title: Dreams
items.short_synopsis: The disparate lives of shell-shocked soldier Ali, medical student Mehdi and bride Ahlaam — whose fiancé was kidnapped by Saddam Hussein’s forces on their wedding day — converge in a psychiatric hospital.
items.default_editorial: Shot a mere year after the fall of Saddam Hussein—during a turbulent 55-day shoot in Baghdad—Dreams is a stark and compelling look at life in post-Hussein Iraq. Filmed in a documentary style, director Mohammed al-Daradji’s film unforgettably captures those last moments of a bloody regime.

items.title: Edith Walks
items.short_synopsis: A 60 minute 66 second feature film inspired by a walk from Waltham Abbey in Essex via Battle Abbey to St Leonards-on-Sea in East Sussex. The film documents a pilgrimage in memory of Edith Swan Neck.
items.default_editorial: Shot prior to The Whalebone Box with Super 8 iPhone apps, this psychogeographical journey from British artist Andrew Kötting is a rich, provocative and brilliantly singular rumination on history, happenstance and Englishness. Featuring writer Iain Sinclair and comic book legend Alan Moore!

items.title: Fish Tank
items.short_synopsis: Fifteen-year-old Mia is in a constant state of war with her family and the world around her. When she meets her party-girl mother’s charming new boyfriend Connor, she is amazed to find he returns her attention, and believes he might help her start to make sense of her life.
items.default_editorial: Fish Tank kickstarted Michael Fassbender’s acting career, but it was newcomer Katie Jarvis who stole the show with her raw and volatile portrayal of a teenager’s search for transcendence amid poverty. This beautiful, explosive portrait of innocence lost won Andrea Arnold the Cannes Jury Prize.

items.title: Have a Nice Day
items.short_synopsis: A hard rain is about to fall on a small town in Southern China. In a desperate attempt to find money to save his fiancée’s failed plastic surgery, Xiao Zhang, a mere driver, steals a bag containing 1 million from his boss. News of the robbery spreads fast, and everyone starts looking for Xiao Zhang.
items.default_editorial: Earning immediate comparisons to Tarantino, Liu Jian’s low-key, sly animated neo-noir is full of biting critique––anti-Trump and Brexit references!––and its subversive depiction of moral decay in today’s China did not amuse the censors. Bonus: an infectious score by The Shanghai Restoration Project.

items.title: Hoard
items.short_synopsis: Maria’s childhood in South London with her mother Cynthia, an obsessive hoarder, feels magical until tragedy separates them. Years later, Maria seeks to reconnect with her mother in the only way she knows how—by rummaging through bins for discarded treasures and collecting bags full of garbage.
items.default_editorial: Disgust and desire are two sides of the same coin for the unruly misfits in Luna Carmoon’s visceral debut feature. Playing diamonds in the rough, Saura Lightfoot Leon and Joseph Quinn go on a tender, yet unusual quest for happiness, looking for a place in the world and pearls in the dirt.

items.title: In Camera
items.short_synopsis: Aden dreams of becoming a successful actor, but the grind of the auditions, with its rejections and microaggressions, is starting to take its toll. But when self-assured fashion and lifestyle guru Conrad moves in, his confidence inspires Aden to take it upon himself to find a new part to play.
items.default_editorial: With striking imagery and a star-making turn from Nabhaan Rizwan, Naqqash Khalid’s audacious feature debut captures the uncanniness of life under late capitalism with staggering accuracy. Formally and structurally bold, In Camera fiercely satirises the hall of mirrors that is consumer society.

items.title: Inland Empire
items.short_synopsis: Actress Nicki Grace has landed a hot new role, but when she falls for her co-star, she realizes that her life is beginning to mimic the film she’s shooting. Adding to her confusion, she discovers the film is a remake of an unfinished Polish production—never finished due to an unspeakable tragedy.
items.default_editorial: With a fearless Laura Dern by his side, David Lynch delivers his least linearly plotted (!) and most experimental (!!) feature film in this long-awaited, fragmented follow-up to Mulholland Drive. A Hollywood nightmare in mini DV, Inland Empire is undiluted, unfiltered, weapon-grade surrealism.

items.title: It Follows
items.short_synopsis: After Jay sleeps with her new boyfriend, she discovers she’s the latest recipient of a fatal curse. Death will creep towards her, taking the form of anyone it chooses. As her friends begin to see the phantom assassins, they band together to help Jay escape or confront the terrifying presence.
items.default_editorial: Ten years before Longlegs, Maika Monroe starred in one of the most frightening films of the 2010s: an excavation of trauma as experienced by America’s suburban youth. With his acute portrayal of teen terror, David Robert Mitchell brings a singularly modern touch to the high-school movie canon.

items.title: Jour de fête
items.short_synopsis: In a French town, postman François spends his working hours casually delivering the mail. When a carnival arrives in town, he watches a film depicting the efficiency of the U.S. Postal Service. Inspired by the footage, François sets out to become just like the mail carriers in the United States.
items.default_editorial: The iconic French maestro of slapstick Jacques Tati has enchanted generation after generation of children and cinephiles alike. His first feature is both a hilarious comedy and an incisive observation on post-war French society, seen through the eyes of the most charming, and clumsy, of postmen.

items.title: Kids Return
items.short_synopsis: Masaru and Shinji, two teenage friends, spend most of their school days harassing classmates and playing pranks. Dropping out, they take different paths: one becomes a small-time boxer, the other one a low level gangster. Yet, their life decisions still find a way of catching up with each other.
items.default_editorial: A coming-of-age gem, Takeshi Kitano’s spirited look at teenage delinquency delicately tempers its violent provocations with tender moments of male camaraderie and affection. Featuring gorgeous music by Joe Hisaishi and an unforgettable color palette, Kids Return is a richly emotional paean to youth.

items.title: Let the Corpses Tan
items.short_synopsis: During a Mediterranean summer, Rhino and his gang steal a cache of gold and hide in an abandoned hamlet occupied by a woman seeking inspiration. However, surprise guests and two cops disrupt their plan, turning the once-heavenly retreat of wild happenings into a gruesome battlefield.
items.default_editorial: Hélène Cattet and Bruno Forzani turn their genre-scrambling attention to European crime films of the 1970s with this kinetic brain-melter. Fixing Sergio Leone in its stylistic crosshairs, Let the Corpses Tan reduces plot to essentials, all the better to let rip with a psychedelic formal assault.

items.title: Lucky Grandma
items.short_synopsis: In New York’s Chinatown, 80-year-old Grandma, a feisty and independent widow, visits a casino after a fortune teller predicts good luck. But when her gamble backfires, she attracts gangsters’ attention. To protect herself, she hires a bodyguard from a rival gang, sparking a Chinatown gang war.
items.default_editorial: Fortune favours the bold in this raucous caper comedy from director Sasie Sealy. Starring two-time Bond girl Tsai Chin (You Only Live Twice; Casino Royale) as a spectacularly ornery octogenarian, Lucky Grandma goes to show that action heroes sometimes come in the unlikeliest pint-sized packages.

items.title: M. Hulot's Holiday
items.short_synopsis: Monsieur Hulot goes on a holiday to a seaside resort, but accidents and misunderstandings follow him wherever he goes. The peace and quiet of the hotel guests don’t last very long with Hulot around, because although his actions are in good faith, they always turn out catastrophically for everybody.
items.default_editorial: A cyclonic force of chaos, Jacques Tati’s beloved Monsieur Hulot wreaks delightful havoc on a sleepy French seaside town in his first cinematic outing. Favoring mayhem over bourgeois comfort, this riotous, meticulously choreographed comedy gently pokes fun at the travel habits of the leisure class.

items.title: Mean Streets
items.short_synopsis: Charlie is in a dilemma: he aspires to be a big shot in New York’s Little Italy mafia, but he also wants to be purged of his sins. He seeks penance in the attempted salvation of his friend, the troublemaker Johnny Boy. But this risks complicating his relationship with his mafioso uncle Giovanni.
items.default_editorial: While neither Scorsese nor De Niro’s debut, few films have launched young talent with such rousing confidence as this first collaboration. More intimate than their future crime epics, Keitel’s attempts at penance also keep the film of a piece with Scorsese’s later explorations of crises of faith.

items.title: Minari
items.short_synopsis: A Korean American family starts a new life on an Arkansas farm, chasing their version of the American dream. As they navigate the hardships of the Ozarks, they come to understand the strength of family and the true meaning of home.
items.default_editorial: Tracing the contours of national belonging, Lee Isaac Chung’s film was nominated for six Oscars®—and actor Youn Yuh-jung won a golden statue on the night. As a grandmother whose traditions clash with Mountain-Dew-devoted America, she casts light on generational difference with humor and warmth.

items.title: Mon oncle
items.short_synopsis: Gérard Arpel lives with his parents in a hilariously ultramodern house, but prefers the company of his uncle Hulot, who takes him on trips to the old city. Meanwhile, Gérard’s parents attempt to adjust Mr Hulot to modern life—so they find him a job in Mr Arpel’s antiseptic plastic hose factory.
items.default_editorial: Winner of an Oscar®, Jacques Tati’s first film in color pits his famous Monsieur Hulot against the tyranny of the mid-century modern home. In turning stylish but impractical gadgets into visual gags, Mon oncle hilariously skewers the consumerist culture that followed France’s postwar economic boom.

items.title: Monica
items.short_synopsis: A transgender woman, Monica, reluctantly returns to her estranged Midwestern hometown as her mother, Eugenia, battles dementia. Having left years ago, Monica feels like a stranger in her family, but now she must confront unresolved tensions and embark on a path of healing and acceptance.
items.default_editorial: Led by trans actress Trace Lysette in a tour-de-force performance, Andrea Pallaoro’s quiet marvel keenly conveys the unspoken heartache of familial estrangement. Opting for a narrower aspect ratio, in which every frame gains a portrait-like feel, Monica is a film of delicate gestures and emotions.

items.title: Monsters
items.short_synopsis: After a NASA space probe crashes, an alien infestation quarantines an area between Mexico and the US. As the military battles to contain the creatures, a photojournalist must escort his boss’s daughter through the danger zone to the US border, forcing them to confront the terrifying reality.
items.default_editorial: Crafting a sci-fi epic with less than a million dollars, Gareth Edwards turned heads with his heartfelt twist on a genre too often dominated by spectacle. An emotionally intelligent creature feature with breathtaking homemade FX, Monsters readily transcends its genesis as a Hollywood calling card.

items.title: Nosebleed
items.short_synopsis: Following a pivotal week for long-time best friends Lilah and Coby (whose friendship is morphing into something far more venomous and toxic), a flower that once delicately bloomed proves to just as easily draw blood with its thorns…
items.default_editorial: Female friendship is a temperamental, prickly thing in this lively and provocative short. With thrilling invention and force, Luna Carmoon captures the intense, often contradictory emotions and unpredictable behaviors of girlhood. Love and hate intertwine, but in the end, only one wins out.

items.title: Pan's Labyrinth
items.short_synopsis: Spain, 1944. Ofelia, a 10-year-old obsessed with fairy tales, moves with her pregnant mother to join her stepfather, a Fascist officer stationed in the mountains. Soon Ofelia discovers an overgrown labyrinth in the forest. There she meets Pan, an ancient satyr who claims to know her secret destiny.
items.default_editorial: Guillermo del Toro reconfigures all manner of literary and cinematic fables—from Alice in Wonderland to The Spirit of the Beehive—for this exemplary gothic fantasy. An uncanny, oneiric vision of adolescence, Pan’s Labyrinth reaffirms the Grimm brothers’ notion that fairy tales aren’t just for kids.

items.title: Peeping Tom
items.short_synopsis: Mark is a shy cameraman, but by night, he is a sadistic killer, stalking his victims with his camera to capture genuine, unadulterated fear. Mark becomes enamoured with Helen, who lives below him with her blind mother. But how long before he turns the deadly gaze of his camera towards her?
items.default_editorial: The film that almost ended Michael Powell’s career, this controversial classic was described by Martin Scorsese as “one of the great films about cinema.” A seedy tale of voyeurism and trauma that trades in the audience’s complicity with the killer, Peeping Tom has lost none of its chilling power.

items.title: Playtime
items.short_synopsis: When he has to contact an American official in the French capital, Monsieur Hulot finds himself perplexed by the complexity of a gadget-filled Paris. He gets lost in the city’s maze of modern architecture, and roams around with some American tourists, ending up causing a lot of chaos.
items.default_editorial: In this daring masterpiece, Jacques Tati expands his critique of societal conformity to a majestic scale. Built over three years, his colossal set—known as Tativille—presents a glass-and-concrete vision of Paris, in which ennui and chaos wondrously melt into an idiosyncratic symphony of modern life.

items.title: Rey
items.short_synopsis: In the nineteenth century, a French adventurer sets off to establish a kingdom in the inhospitable South of Chile, uniting the feared Mapuche under him. The response of the Chilean army is devastating. At least, that’s one version of this true story.
items.default_editorial: An unconventional and kaleidoscopic biopic that plays with history, myth, and memory, Niles Atallah’s Rey attests to the endless possibilities of cinema. Strikingly beautiful, gloriously decadent, and delectably avant-garde, this is a phantasmagorical gem of a film.

items.title: Second Coming
items.short_synopsis: Jackie discovers she’s pregnant and knows it is not her husband’s child. Jackie and Mark haven’t been intimate in some time, but Jackie claims she hasn’t been with anyone else either. The unnerving side effects of her pregnancy begin to affect her mental state, creating turmoil within the family.
items.default_editorial: Hallucinatory visions, supernatural omens, and a mysterious pregnancy encroach eerily on a seemingly ordinary family in Debbie Tucker Green’s immaculate debut. Starring Idris Elba alongside powerhouse actress Nadine Marshall, Second Coming brings a touch of the divine to the classic domestic drama.

items.title: Shagbands
items.short_synopsis: In the summer heatwave of 200,. a gang of teenage girls in South London face strange sexual awakenings driven by gossip and the mysterious ritual of shagbands—small plastic bracelets representing the wearer’s sexual history.
items.default_editorial: A vivid snapshot of adolescence and the peculiar mood of clammy summer holidays, Shagbands offers a frank look at the sweetnesses and dangers of coming of age. Between bouts of teen ennui and casual flirtation with boys, the supportive girls in this tempestuous short put the world to rights.

items.title: Son of Saul
items.short_synopsis: October 1944, Auschwitz. Saul is a Jewish prisoner working as a Sonderkommando. When he discovers the body of a boy he takes for his son, Saul decides to carry out an impossible task: save the child’s body, find a rabbi to recite the mourner’s Kaddish, and offer the boy a proper burial.
items.default_editorial: One of the most acclaimed debuts in recent memory, this is visceral, immediate cinema. Told in disorienting over-the-shoulder cinematography, Son of Saul captures the chaos and atrocity of the Holocaust like you’ve never seen before. Prizewinner at the Cannes Film Festival and the Academy Awards®.

items.title: Stories We Tell
items.short_synopsis: What is real? What is true? What do we remember? Using home movies, photographs, and interviews, Sarah Polley delves into the life of her mother, a creative yet secretive woman. But while she is talking to her relatives, her interest lies in the bigger picture of what families hold onto as truth.
items.default_editorial: This astounding documentary digs into a family history to portray the director’s mother through a patchwork of stories and materials. By disclosing her filmmaking process, Sarah Polley audaciously shows that the past we construct can be warped through the lens of both our memories and cinema.

items.title: The Bling Ring
items.short_synopsis: In the fame-obsessed world of Los Angeles, a group of teenagers use the internet to track their favorite celebrities’ whereabouts in order to rob their homes. Based on true events, the group stole more than $3 million in luxury goods from the homes of stars like Paris Hilton and Orlando Bloom.
items.default_editorial: Featuring some of the finest curation of needle drops in modern cinema, the ever divisive Sofia Coppola provides the best pop filmmaking has to offer with this probing yet sensitive (and appropriately hilarious!) look at celebrity, youth, and capitalism gone awry in the Hollywood hills. Glorious.

items.title: The Deep Blue Sea
items.short_synopsis: Hester Collyer is the wife of an upper-class judge and a free spirit trapped in a passionless marriage. Her encounter with Freddie Page, a young, troubled former royal Air Force pilot, throws her life in turmoil, as their erotic relationship leaves her emotionally stranded and physically isolated.
items.default_editorial: Echoing Brief Encounter, Terence Davies’s gorgeous postwar romance puts British values of propriety on the line. Forget any effort to sift love from infatuation, the heights of tragedy from swooning, sordid melodrama—in Rachel Weisz’s achingly beautiful performance, they’re inextricably entwined.

items.title: The Elephant Man
items.short_synopsis: In Victorian London, Dr. Treves discovers Joseph Merrick in a circus side show. Born with a congenital disorder, Merrick uses his disfigurement to earn a living as the “Elephant Man.” Treves takes an interest in Merrick’s welfare, discovering that his rough exterior hides a refined soul.
items.default_editorial: From iconic director David Lynch comes this moving and macabre, Oscar®-nominated historical drama, starring a truly unforgettable John Hurt. Examining disfigurement and prejudice, Lynch’s first Hollywood feature will surprise you with its humane and tender melancholy—and scare you with its darkness.

items.title: The Florida Project
items.short_synopsis: Set in the shadow of the most magical place on Earth, 6-year-old Moonee and her two best friends forge their own adventures. Meanwhile Moonee’s struggling mom and a kindhearted motel manager protect the kids from the harsh reality that surrounds them.
items.default_editorial: A kaleidoscopic portrait of life on the margins, this neorealist gem from Palme d’Or winner Sean Baker adopts a child’s perspective to ask what makes a good childhood, and what precludes it. This compassionate film is propelled to exuberant heights by Brooklynn Prince’s effervescent performance.

items.title: The Producers
items.short_synopsis: Max Bialystock is a washed up Broadway producer forced to romance old ladies to finance his plays. When timid accountant Leo Bloom is brought in to do his books, he inadvertently reveals to Bialystock that a producer can earn more money with a flop than a hit…
items.default_editorial: First inspiring a Broadway musical, then later a film remake of said musical, The Producers is a true phenomenon: it lives up to and even exceeds the hype. A perfect turn from Gene Wilder, among countless other virtues, certifies this cult classic as one of the funniest films of all time.

items.title: The Road
items.short_synopsis: In a post-apocalyptic world, a father must protect his son from a group of cannibals who menace the streets. They embark on a journey on foot, traversing the charred remains of North America as they make their way to the warmer southern regions, unsure of what—if anything—awaits them there.
items.default_editorial: An electrifying adaptation of Cormac McCarthy’s Pulitzer Prize-winning novel, The Road is both a brutal examination of mortality and a study of father-son relationships. With raw performances from Viggo Mortensen and Charlize Theron, it perfectly captures the dark mood of a post-apocalyptic world.

items.title: The Souvenir
items.short_synopsis: Julie is a young film student struggling to find a firm direction in life when she meets Anthony. An intense romance blossoms between them, but as the relationship develops it becomes clear that Anthony is not being completely honest, and that this could have devastating consequences for them both.
items.default_editorial: British master Joanna Hogg delves into her own memories for this staggering work of heartbreaking intimacy. At once an alluring and shattering study in privilege, artistic creation, and first love, The Souvenir features revelatory performances by Honor Swinton Byrne, Tilda Swinton, and Tom Burke.

items.title: The Wrestler
items.short_synopsis: Randy is a lonely professional wrestler pushing 50, who can now only look back on a once glorious career. These days, regional exhibition matches have replaced screaming headlines in sports magazines, and when he starts to have health problems, The Ram knows he’s at one of life’s major crossroads.
items.default_editorial: A Golden Lion winner at Venice, Darren Aronofsky directed Mickey Rourke in this stirring Oscar-nominated comeback performance. Framing the gritty, physical world of professional wrestling with meticulous hand-held tracking shots, the film digs into the emotional core of a man at the end of his rope.

items.title: Touch Me Not
items.short_synopsis: On the fluid border between reality and fiction, a filmmaker and her characters venture into a personal research project about intimacy. Craving for intimacy yet also deeply afraid of it, they work to overcome old patterns, defence mechanisms and taboos, to cut the cord and finally be free.
items.default_editorial: Billed as the most controversial Berlinale Golden Bear in history, Adina Pintilie’s fearless investigation of intimacy and sexuality persuasively invites the spectator to participate in its exploratory narrative. A treatise on bodies and our perception of the Other that won’t leave you indifferent.

items.title: Trafic
items.short_synopsis: The bumbling Monsieur Hulot takes to Paris’s highways and byways. He is hired as the design director of an auto company and accompanies his new product—a camping car outfitted with absurd gadgetry—to an auto show in Amsterdam. But for M. Hulot, the journey to the show will be a bumpy ride.
items.default_editorial: Jacques Tati’s final outing as M. Hulot, Trafic continues where Playtime left off. This time using a seemingly never-ending voyage from A to B as his playground, Trafic is a similarly sharp, ambitious parody of the chaos of modern life, highly stylized and tempered by Tati’s masterful hand.

items.title: Whitney
items.short_synopsis: With over 200 million album sales and seven consecutive US No.1 hits, Whitney Houston was the voice of a generation. Yet, her success is footnoted by a story of addiction. With exclusive access to her family and collaborators, this documentary features unseen footage from her career.
items.default_editorial: The icon of a generation, Whitney Houston remains one of the past century’s greatest pop divas. Equally celebrating her extraordinary life and coming to terms with its tragic end, Whitney creates a complex tableau showing both the joy and darkness of a woman whose soulful vibrato touched the world.

items.title: Young Adam
items.short_synopsis: Joe, a rootless young drifter, finds work on a barge travelling between Glasgow and Edinburgh, owned by Les and his wife Ella. One afternoon they discover the corpse of a young woman floating in the water. As the police investigate, Joe’s past connection to the victim is slowly revealed.
items.default_editorial: Ewan McGregor and Tilda Swinton star in David Mackenzie’s second feature, an emotionally volatile study in guilt and sexual tension. Adapted from the cult novel by Scottish beat author Alexander Trocchi, and with a score by David Byrne, Young Adam is a moody, booze-sodden tale of unchecked desire.

items.title: Zombi Child
items.short_synopsis: Haiti, 1962. A man is brought back from the dead only to be sent to the living hell of the sugarcane fields. In Paris, 55 years later, at the prestigious Légion d’honneur boarding school, a Haitian girl confesses an old family secret to a group of new friends—with unthinkable consequences.
items.default_editorial: From French king of cool Bertrand Bonello, this endlessly mysterious chiller subverts horror tropes in unexpected ways, fearlessly unleashing suppressed demons. Boasting a sharp political edge, lavish visuals, and an ace synth score by Bonello himself, Zombi Child is a sublime slice of sinuous pulp.

items.title: A Short Film About Killing
items.short_synopsis: Jacek, an angry drifter, murders a taxi driver brutally and without motive. His case is assigned to Piotr, an idealistic young lawyer who is morally opposed to the death penalty, and their interactions take on an emotional honesty that throws into stark relief, for Piotr, the injustice of killing.
items.default_editorial: Krzysztof Kieślowski’s extended take on the fifth episode of his TV series Dekalog was a stunning success at the 1988 Cannes Film Festival. A staggering and existential portrayal of both victim and perpetrator that sets out to explore the origins and manifestations of evil in late-Communist Poland.

items.title: A Short Film About Love
items.short_synopsis: 19-year-old postal worker Tomek routinely spies on his older neighbor Magda, a sexually liberated artist who lives in the apartment across the courtyard from his. As their private worlds merge, fascination turns to obsession, and the line between love and curiosity becomes blurred.
items.default_editorial: Developed from an episode of Krzysztof Kieślowski’s epic, ten-part television series, Dekalog, this acclaimed romantic comedy-drama tells a darkly twisted and ironic tale of voyeurism and fantasy. Kieślowski brings his typically compelling and cerebral style to explore the feeling—or idea—of love.

items.title: And Life Goes On...
items.short_synopsis: A filmmaker drives with his son through the nightmarish chaos caused by the 1990 Iranian earthquake catastrophe. They are searching for two young actors from a movie the director made a few years ago. While on their journey, they discover a resilient community pressing on in the face of tragedy.
items.default_editorial: Beaming at the sanguine perspective of people cast into rubble and ruin, Abbas Kiarostami’s second journey to the village of Koker crystallizes some of his favored methods and motifs: a story spun delicately out of reality, a car, and also (of course!) a boy who hates homework but loves football.

items.title: Ash Is Purest White
items.original_title: Jiang hu er nü | 江湖儿女
items.short_synopsis: Bin is a gangster whose leadership ends when a rival gang comes after his territory. To save him from being beaten to death, Bin’s girlfriend Qiao fires a gun and gets five years in prison for her act of loyalty. When she is released, she hopes to pick up where they left off, but times have changed.
items.default_editorial: As if any further proof were needed, Ash is Purest White confirms Zhao Tao as one of world cinema’s most exciting actors. She’s a force of nature as the wronged moll in Jia Zhangke’s exhilarating gangster epic; a sprawling, chromatically-charged thriller set at the dawn of China’s capitalist rush.

items.title: Blind Chance
items.short_synopsis: Facing an unclear future, Witek, a young Polish medical student, puts his education on hold. He hurries to catch the last train to Warsaw. But as Witek races down the platform, three successive scenarios spawn, each determined by whether Witek catches or misses his train.
items.default_editorial: Fascinated by the idea of how many different paths a life can possibly take—and later influencing such films as Mr. Nobody, Sliding Doors, Run, Lola, Run— Blind Chance is one of Kieślowski’s most political films. Censored in Poland for many years, this is a work of sublime poetry.

items.title: Camera Buff
items.short_synopsis: Factory worker Filip buys an 8mm movie camera on the occasion of his child’s birth. As it’s the first camera in his town, Filip is named the official photographer by the local Communist Party boss. Soon, amateur film becomes an obsession of his, transforming his modest and formerly contented life.
items.default_editorial: Beware the dangers of cinephilia! Krzysztof Kieślowski’s sophomore feature is a riveting study of filmmaking as a tool for telling other people’s stories. Exploring the reality of censorship in Communist Poland, it asks us to reflect on the artist’s social responsibility in trying political times.

items.title: First Graders
items.short_synopsis: A concealed camera follows a group of first graders during their day at school. While some pupils chant in the playground, others are summoned to the superintendent’s office—where the supervisor deals with latecomers and troublemakers by interviewing the innocent boys and offering wise advice.
items.default_editorial: Kiarostami’s tender observational documentary takes the inner lives of children seriously, while also showing the patience of educators in instilling values needed for the next generation to prosper. Some lessons must be taught the hard way, but there’s considerable heart and empathy on display.

items.title: Homework
items.short_synopsis: In this documentary, Iranian schoolboys complain about the amount of homework they have to do.
items.default_editorial: Returning to the classroom after First Graders, Abbas Kiarostami interviews schoolboys, and just wait until you hear what tumbles from their mouths. Underneath a simple—and simply devastating—premise, Kiarostami unearths a maelstrom of suffering, indicating something rotten in the state of Iran.

items.title: Like Someone in Love
items.original_title: ライク・サムワン・イン・ラブ
items.short_synopsis: In Tokyo, sociology student Akiko works nights as a high-class sex worker. Instead of studying for her exams, she reluctantly goes to her new client, retired sociology professor Takashi. However, when Takashi drives Akiko to her university the next day, they strike up an odd role-playing routine.
items.default_editorial: Iranian master Abbas Kiarostami took to the neon-glazed cityscapes of Tokyo for this enigmatic, expressionist masterpiece. Shimmering digital reflections trace an ongoing fascination with the tensions between appearance and reality, as the piercing humanity invokes the ghosts of Ozu and Mizoguchi.

items.title: Mountains May Depart
items.original_title: 山河故人 | Shan he gu ren
items.short_synopsis: Fenyang, 1999: Tao has two suitors, Zhang and his best friend Liangzi. Tao decides, with a note of regret, to marry Zhang, an aspiring entrepreneur. Flash-forward 15 years, the couple’s son Dollar is paying a visit to his now-estranged mother and everyone has grown more distant in time and space.
items.default_editorial: The films of Sixth Generation auteur Jia Zhangke are history-spanning, masterful delights. Mountains May Depart is set in the past, present, and future—each innovatively shown in a different aspect ratio. This makes for a rivetingly modern Chinese melodrama guided by the star presence of Zhao Tao.

items.title: Pickpocket
items.short_synopsis: 1997, Fengyang. Xiao Wu is a pickpocket. Having never managed to get away from the streets like his friends, he finds himself alone with his troubles. A cop is out to get him and his love affair with local karaoke hostess Mei Mei is going nowhere. He realises it’s time to think about his future.
items.default_editorial: Exploring the pervasive, entrenched connection between crime and capitalism throughout society, Pickpocket hails from A Touch of Sin and Ash is Purest White director Jia Zhangke, who has gone on to become one of the greatest chroniclers of his country. An auspicious debut from a modern master.

items.title: The Bread and Alley
items.short_synopsis: Shot in black and white, the film tells the story of a little boy walking home with a loaf of bread who is confronted by a hungry dog, placing his safety at risk.
items.default_editorial: Considered by Abbas Kiarostami to be “the mother of all my films,” his wondrous first short relishes in the poetry of everyday life, a driving force in his later masterworks. Seen through a child’s eyes, a simple errand takes on the thrill of a great adventure, packed with tension and playfulness.

items.title: The Traveler
items.short_synopsis: A grade-school-age boy, neglected by his parents, lies, cheats, and steals to accumulate enough money to afford a bus ride to a large city and a ticket to see his favorite soccer team play.
items.default_editorial: For Abbas Kiarostami, the misbehavior of schoolboys is often a mark of ambition, and some lessons are better learned outside of the classroom. Featuring a juvenile protagonist on a spirited, soccer-oriented quest, this is one of the auteur’s finest films about taking a journey toward a dream.

items.title: Through the Olive Trees
items.short_synopsis: Trouble arises on the set of Abbas Kiarostami’s And Life Goes On when the romantic misfortune of one of the actors—a young man who pines for the woman cast as his wife, even though, in real life, she will have nothing to do with him—leaves the director caught in the middle.
items.default_editorial: In this metafictional masterpiece, Kiarostami contemplates cinema and its romantic fallacies. Grounded in Northern Iran’s folk traditions and with a soft focus on its shaken yet convalescent landscape, this warmhearted tale explores what happens when an unrequited love on a film set causes a stir.

items.title: 9x10 novanta
items.short_synopsis: Young Italian filmmakers create nine ten-minute shorts using unseen footage from the Istituto Luce’s archives. Each short reflects on Italy’s recent history—from wartime to peace, from ruins to reconstruction, and from Fascism’s lost promised futures to the present day.
items.default_editorial: In this captivating work of historical excavation, a stunning rainbow of forgotten stories surfaces from black-and-white archival footage. Counting Alice Rohrwacher and Pietro Marcello among its cohort of then-emerging filmmakers, 9×10 novanta looks to the past to nurture the future of cinema.

items.title: A Man Called Ove
items.short_synopsis: Ove is your typical angry old man next door. Enter a lively young family who accidentally flattens Ove’s mailbox while moving in. Yet from this inauspicious beginning an unlikely friendship forms, exemplifying a tale of unreliable first impressions and the reminder that life is sweeter when shared.
items.default_editorial: Nominated for two Oscars® (and a box-office hit in its home country!), this lovingly-crafted Swedish tragicomedy offers a refreshing take on cross-generational friendship. Poignantly capturing the sense of nostalgia that comes with old age, A Man Called Ove is a powerful ode to the act of sharing.

items.title: A Tale of Love and Desire
items.original_title: Une histoire d'amour et de désir
items.short_synopsis: When starting university, Ahmed meets Farah, a Tunisian girl who has just arrived in Paris. While discovering a corpus of sensual and erotic Arabic literature he never imagined existed, Ahmed falls deeply in love with Farah, and although literally overwhelmed with desire, he will try to resist it.
items.default_editorial: From Leyla Bouzid comes this sensual coming-of-age drama, the Tunisian writer-director’s assured sophomore feature. As a sizzling romance emerges between two students, the film casts a riveting look at identity, hypocrisy, and sexual mores, while exploring the language and literature of love.

items.title: A Theory I Dreamt Up in London
items.original_title: Una Teoria che Ho Sognato a Londra
items.short_synopsis: A man dreams. Awake, he wanders the streets of London as memories of his dream resurface forming a bizarre theory. Reality is not quite the same now.
items.default_editorial: Emerging from the ruminative realm of deep sleep, this six-minute film beholds the modern metropolis with philosophical eyes. Through grainy distortion and associative montage, director Fulvio Risuleo visualizes slumber’s psychic residue: the restless excitement of nebulous, fuzzy thoughts.

items.title: Amélie
items.short_synopsis: Bursting with imagination and having seen her fair share of tragedy and fantasy, Amélie is not like any other girl. As she grows up, she becomes a waitress in a Montmartre bar. One day, she discovers that her goal in life is to fix up other people’s troubles by influencing their destinies.
items.default_editorial: Jean-Pierre Jeunet’s vibrant smash comedy is the ultimate rush of giddy energy. A fantasy version of Paris life infused with an intoxicating romantic spirit, Amelie was one of the big arthouse hits of the 00s, and no wonder—its charms were impossible to resist.

items.title: Anatomy of a Fall
items.short_synopsis: When her husband Samuel is mysteriously found dead in the snow below their secluded chalet, Sandra becomes the main suspect when the police begin to question whether he fell or was pushed. The trial soon becomes a psychological journey into the depths of Sandra and Samuel’s complicated marriage.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Palme d’Or and an Oscar® for Best Original Screenplay, Justine Triet’s twisty Hitchcockian puzzle stars the formidable Sandra Hüller as a woman under suspicion. Suspenseful, self-reflexive, and darkly funny, this compelling battle of minds will keep you guessing until the very end.

items.title: Armando e la politica
items.short_synopsis: For years Armando embodied the supreme fidelity to the values of social democracy. His life was travels in Eastern Europe, election campaigns, the battles for workers’ rights. All this until he decided to vote for Berlusconi. Chiara, his daughter, tries to reconstruct this choice.
items.default_editorial: Puzzled by her father’s change of political alliance, Chiara Malta set her gaze on the shifting ideologies of Italy in her mercurial debut. Blending animation, interviews, and home videos, this inventive documentary renders the generational divide of the Berlusconi years with both humor and insight.

items.title: Audition
items.short_synopsis: Widower Shigeharu seeks advice on how to find a new wife from a colleague. Taking advantage of their position as a film company, they stage an audition. Interviewing a series of women, Shigeharu is enchanted by the quiet Asami. But soon things take a twisted turn as Asami isn’t what she seems to be.
items.default_editorial: The notorious (and insanely prolific) Takashi Miike shot to fame with this cult horror classic, which starts out as deceptively light before diving gleefully off the deep end. To see Audition is to see a director at the peak of his powers breaking all the rules—but it’s not for the faint of heart.

items.title: Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call New Orleans
items.original_title: The Bad Lieutenant: Port of Call - New Orleans
items.short_synopsis: After Hurricane Katrina, police sergeant Terence McDonagh rescues a prisoner, hurting his back in the process. He earns a promotion to lieutenant but develops an addiction to cocaine and painkillers. Six months later, Terence is assigned a case investigating the drug-related killing of a family.
items.default_editorial: Eyebrows were raised when Werner Herzog announced he was reimagining Abel Ferrara’s Bad Lieutenant. How do you top that perverse classic? Leaving the original far behind, Herzog ecstatically mounts a frenzied operatic fantasia, with a lead—in Nicolas Cage—on thunderous, unforgettable form.

items.title: Basic Instinct
items.short_synopsis: In San Francisco, an unstable police detective is working on a string of homicides involving an ice pick. As the investigation unravels, he ends up falling for the main suspect, a seductive novelist whose recent book also features a killer who uses an ice pick to murder their victims.
items.default_editorial: After his provocative explorations of America’s cultural attitudes to violence with Robocop and Total Recall, arch-satirist Paul Verhoeven turned to the question of sex with this dazzling psychosexual noir. Featuring Sharon Stone in a star-making turn, Basic Instinct is the ultimate erotic thriller.

items.title: Border
items.short_synopsis: Tina is a customs agent with a nose for trouble. She can literally smell human emotions, which is a handy talent for sniffing out suspicious border crossers. But when a mysterious male traveller’s odour confounds her, she’s faced with hugely disturbing insights about who she is and what she wants.
items.default_editorial: Before competing for the Palme d’Or with his Donald Trump biopic The Apprentice, director Ali Abbasi made a splash on the Croisette with the genre-defying fairytale Border. Set in modern-day Sweden, this eerie and thought-provoking allegory is also a tender, moving love story unlike any other.

items.title: Bread and Roses
items.short_synopsis: In Los Angeles, undocumented Mexican immigrant Maya finds work through her sister, Rosa. After putting up with abuse from her bosses and grim work conditions, Maya is open to the pro-union rhetoric offered by organiser Sam Shapiro, but Rosa is less interested in clashing with management.
items.default_editorial: Leaving Britain behind for his first—and only—American film, Ken Loach turns a Justice for Janitors campaign into a heartfelt site of struggle. Co-starring Adrien Brody, it’s Pilar Padilla who steals the show in this spirited drama, which reveals the true plight of immigrants in the city of angels.

items.title: Cesária Évora
items.short_synopsis: Legendary singer Cesária Évora—the Barefoot Diva—was a woman born in colonial Cape Verde whose voice took her from poverty to stardom. Never-before-seen archival footage, including personal home videos,  recordings, and unique testimonies, traces the political and social contexts of Évora’s life.
items.default_editorial: As soulful as the voice of the Cape Verdean icon herself, Ana Sofia Fonseca’s intimate documentary observes the great Cesária Évora both on and off the stage. Placing her public success and private struggles side by side, the film probes the nuances of fame in a discriminatory, unforgiving industry.

items.title: Daughter of Mine
items.short_synopsis: In Sardinia, shy ten-year-old Vittoria is close to her mother Tina. But the young girl soon discovers that local party girl Angelica is her birth mother. When Angelica must move away, she asks to become acquainted with Vittoria before she leaves. Against Tina’s wishes, the two become deeply bonded.
items.default_editorial: Laura Bispuri’s second work with Alba Rohrwacher sets the actor’s luminous talents loose on the rural landscape of sunsoaked Sardinia. Ambivalent toward maternal instinct and duty, Daughter of Mine delicately traces the swaying of girlhood, unfurling from humble twig to tenacious force of nature.

items.title: Dearest Relatives, Poisonous Relations
items.short_synopsis: An elderly couple gathers their four adult children and grandchildren for Christmas at their home in Sulmona. When they announce some shocking news, the festive evening erupts into chaos—exposing buried resentments and threatening to tear the family apart.
items.default_editorial: Twinkling with jewel-toned tinsel, a provincial Italian apartment comes alive with the arrival of family in Mario Monicelli’s cult-classic black comedy. The serenity of snowfall and churchgoing is no match for the unholy noise of squabbling in this film that captures the risible chaos of Christmas.

items.title: Diciannove
items.short_synopsis: Palermo native Leonardo arrives in London to attend business school. As the novelty of his new surroundings wears off, he moves on to Siena to study his true passion: literature. Though enamoured with the city, Leonardo clashes with his teachers and retreats into his own world.
items.default_editorial: Produced by Luca Guadagnino, Giovanni Tortorici’s debut feature quivers with the inchoate longings and bitter frustrations of its titular awkward age. Between bouts of rebellion and pangs of ennui, Manfredi Marini’s candid turn brims with the nervous hopefulness of young adulthood, so easily dashed.

items.title: Dillinger Is Dead
items.short_synopsis: During one seemingly routine night, Glauco, an industrial designer, returns home to find his wife in bed with a serious headache. Glauco prepares himself a meal, and while looking for some kitchenware, he discovers a revolver wrapped in a newspaper from 1934 announcing the death of John Dillinger.
items.default_editorial: Michel Piccoli’s aimless bourgeois is a bewitching mystery in Marco Ferreri’s incisive portrait of modern alienation. Rich in detail, Dillinger Is Dead cloaks its critique in the material comforts of domesticity—all the better to take down a society emptied of meaning, ruled by consumerism.

items.title: Double Lover
items.short_synopsis: After starting therapy, Chloé falls in love with her psychoanalyst Paul. When they move in together, everything seems perfect until some discoveries lead her to suspect that he may be living a double life. As she begins investigating, she dives into a dark world of smoke, mirrors, and doppelgangers.
items.default_editorial: The stylish and immaculately crafted Double Lover attests to François Ozon’s reputation as a master of the erotic thriller. With daring performances from Marine Vacth and Jérémie Renier, this hallucinatory treat plays its psychosexual games of cat-and-mouse in the spirit of Hitchcock and De Palma.

items.title: Dreams
items.short_synopsis: A fifteen-year-old girl experiences a sexual awakening when she falls head over heels in love with her female teacher. She writes this down in her diary, and writes so well, vividly and recognizably that both mother and grandmother think the book should be published.
items.default_editorial: One in a trio of cinematic love letters to Oslo, Dag Johan Haugerud’s dreamy wonder made history as the first Norwegian film to win the Golden Bear at Berlinale. Fired by the intensity of first crushes, writing becomes a sensual act in this ravishing tale of teenage infatuation and creative ecstasy.

items.title: Dwelling in the Fuchun Mountains
items.original_title: 春江水暖 | Chun Jiang Shui Nuan
items.short_synopsis: At her 70th birthday celebration, the aged mother of the Gu family suffers from a stroke, which precipitates her decline into dementia. Who will take care of her? The four brothers face crucial changes in their relationships to one another, as they deal with their own family problems.
items.default_editorial: Named after a scroll painting, Gu Xiaogang’s moving study of a family in Zhejiang Province entrances with slow-tumbling long takes and realist detail like fine linework. Debts and duties bear down on siblings with the weight of mountains, but the river—inky blue or palest mauve—soothes and sustains.

items.title: Early Summer
items.short_synopsis: Noriko lives contentedly in an extended family household that includes her parents and her brother’s family. When an uncle’s visit prompts the family to find her a husband, Noriko, surprisingly, has her own plans.
items.default_editorial: A slice of buttercream cake, a stroll on the riverbank: Summery pleasures abound in Yasujirô Ozu’s delectable classic. Echoing a Tokyo in the midst of postwar recovery, Setsuko Hara’s luminous heroine hides a quiet rebellion behind her gentle smile, taking matrimonial matters into her own hands.

items.title: Euphoria
items.short_synopsis: Matteo is a young successful entrepreneur who is open-minded and charming. His brother Ettore still lives in the provincial town where they grew up, teaching at the local school. A difficult situation results in the two distant brothers being given the opportunity to get to know each other.
items.default_editorial: Set among Rome’s cobbled streets, this engaging drama sees Riccardo Scamarcio’s hedonist play god with his own kith and kin. A sleek second feature from director Valeria Golino, Euphoria’s brothers grapple with the rot in their relationship, only for their acrimony to melt into a loving embrace.

items.title: Francofonia: Le Louvre Under German Occupation
items.short_synopsis: Jacques Jaujard and Count Franziskus Wolff-Metternich shared a compulsory collaboration at the Louvre Museum under the Nazi Occupation. First enemies, then collaborators, these two would become the driving force behind the preservation of museum treasures.
items.default_editorial: Following the success of one-shot wonder Russian Ark, and his Golden Lion-winning Faust, Aleksandr Sokurov conducts something of a seance, exploring the Louvre during WWII. An historiographic film that chases concepts, not logic, ruminating on the weight of history and construction of culture.

items.title: Gimme Danger
items.short_synopsis: Emerging from Michigan amidst a countercultural revolution, The Stooges’ powerful and aggressive style of rock ‘n’ roll blew a crater in the musical landscape of the late 1960s. Through a blend of rock, blues, R&B, and free jazz, the band planted the seeds for what would be soon called punk rock.
items.default_editorial: Was it inevitable that Jim Jarmusch would make a documentary about The Stooges? After all, its strutting frontman, Iggy Pop, recurs in his films, from Coffee and Cigarettes and Dead Man to The Dead Don’t Die. As a die-hard fanboy, Jarmusch paints a loving portrait of his favorite rock ‘n’ roll band.

items.title: Good Time
items.short_synopsis: After a bank robbery lands his younger brother Nick in prison, Connie embarks on a twisted odyssey through the city’s underworld as he attempts to rescue him. Over the course of one night, Connie races against the clock to save his brother and himself, knowing their lives hang in the balance.
items.default_editorial: With this hypnotic and gripping descent into the rotten core of the Big Apple, the Safdies proved their knack for against-the-clock crime dramas. Featuring Robert Pattinson at the top of his game and end credits song by Iggy Pop, Good Time delivers a thrilling dose of classic New York sleaze.

items.title: Goodbye to Language
items.short_synopsis: A married woman and a single man meet. They love, they argue, fists fly. At the same time, a dog strays between town and country elsewhere. As the seasons pass, the man and woman meet again, and the dog finds itself between them. Then, a second film begins: it looks like the first, and yet is not.
items.default_editorial: One of the greatest cinematic thinkers of our age, Jean-Luc Godard created an enigmatic visual essay starring his own dog. Winner of the Jury Prize in Cannes, Goodbye to Language is ahead of its time, prophetic and evocative. A delightful riddle about nature and metaphors in the digital age.

items.title: Harmonica
items.short_synopsis: In the sun-soaked south of Iran, a young boy receives a gleaming Japanese harmonica from abroad. Enchanted by the object, his friends become increasingly fixated, sparking rivalries and quiet power struggles as they vie for the fleeting chance to hold it—or play a single note.
items.default_editorial: A poetic evocation of the impulsivity and enthusiasm of childhood, Amir Naderi’s neorealist tale of wide-eyed innocence is also a trenchant social allegory. Through the unflinching gaze and sobering experience of a guileless child, good business seems little more than a control tactic.

items.title: Heart of a Dog
items.short_synopsis: In 2011, artist Laurie Anderson’s beloved rat terrier Lolabelle died. By weaving together her thoughts on Tibetan Buddhism, reincarnation, the modern surveillance state, and the artistic lives of dogs, Anderson reflects on the deaths of her husband Lou Reed, her mother, and her cherished dog.
items.default_editorial: Ruminations on memory, mortality, and vision intertwine in Heart of a Dog, as Laurie Anderson turns her hand to the essay film. Venturing to a space between life and death to commune with lost ones, the singular, shape-shifting artist dedicates this wonderful work to her husband, the late Lou Reed.

items.title: Her
items.short_synopsis: A heartbroken writer falls in love with an operating system that evolves into a unique entity during their union. Things become complicated as Theodore’s complex emotions are exacerbated by ’Samantha’s’ inability to provide physical comfort.
items.default_editorial: Working from an Academy Award®-winning original screenplay (his first!), Spike Jonze’s subtle, perceptive drama impressively imagines a Los Angeles of the near-future—featuring an affectingly wistful score from Arcade Fire, and a heartbreaking performance from the superlative Joaquin Phoenix.

items.title: Honey
items.short_synopsis: Irene lives alone on the coastline outside Rome. To her father and her married lover, she is a student. In reality, she helps terminally ill patients to ease their suffering. One day, she meets a man who will put to the test Irene’s convictions.
items.default_editorial: This feature directorial debut from actor Valeria Golino confidently and consistently deflects expectation. A brittle character study seasoned with choice music cuts, Honey tackles the question of assisted-dying in philosophical rather than moral terms, and with an impressive lack of sentimentality.

items.title: Hugo
items.short_synopsis: A young orphan living in the hidden corners of a Paris train station in the 1920s, discovers a mystery left behind by his late father—a broken automaton, a heart-shaped key, and a secret tied to a toy shop owner. With the help of his friend Isabelle, he uncovers a lost chapter of early cinema.
items.default_editorial: Lamplit and whistling with steam, 1930s Paris comes alive in Martin Scorsese’s enchanting family adventure. A mystery to be solved, the mechanics of toy-making, and the mesmerizing trick films of silent-era director Georges Méliès click into place in this wondrous vision of early cinema magic.

items.title: I Knew Her Well
items.short_synopsis: Adriana, a naive Italian country girl, moves to Rome to become a movie star and experiences the dark side of the business.
items.default_editorial: Typifying the funny-sad alchemy of 1960s Italian comedies, this haunting and electric showbiz send-up balances flights of comic fancy against the gravity of social critique. Stefania Sandrelli’s quicksilver turn as a wannabe starlet paints an indelible portrait of alienated modern womanhood.

items.title: Identification of a Woman
items.short_synopsis: After his wife leaves him, a film director starts a passionate affair with a young aristocratic woman. Soon a stranger threatens him to stop seeing her and, after a lover’s row, she vanishes. Whilst searching for her, he meets a young actress, whose curiosity is piqued to find the missing woman.
items.default_editorial: After 1975’s international production with Jack Nicholson, The Passenger, and his experiment in video, The Mystery of Oberwald, Michelangelo Antonioni returns to the kind of film that made him famous, like L’avventura and L’eclisse: the chic dissection of troubled romance in modern Italy.

items.title: Il solengo
items.short_synopsis: A group of elders gathers in a hunting lodge and recalls the life of Mario “de’ Marcella”, a man who lived in a cave over 60 years of his life. Why he chose to live a solitary existence is unknown. Perhaps it had something to do with a mysterious and tragic event of his childhood.
items.default_editorial: This unique documentary, shot in the mountains outside Rome, explores the true legend of a local hermit. A probing look at loneliness and eccentricity that is at once beautiful, curious, and revealing. In Il solengo, an unusual subject is portrayed through an inspired form.

items.title: Jacquot de Nantes
items.short_synopsis: Once upon a time, a boy was raised in a garage where everyone enjoyed singing. He is fascinated by every kind of show, and soon buys a camera. Meanwhile, footage of the aging director Jacques Demy unveils intimate reflections on his life’s journey and his love for cinema and musicals.
items.default_editorial: Agnès Varda’s fascinating, formally bold portrait-tribute to her partner of 32 years, Jacques Demy, recounts his influences and inspirations, his beginnings as an artist, and constructs its own (extra-marital) intertextual relationship between Varda and Demy’s two singular styles of filmmaking.

items.title: La Confessione
items.short_synopsis: As the world nears its end, two young lovers, lost in a suspended past, begin to question their feelings. Consumed by the collapse of their love, they fail to see the catastrophe unfolding around them.
items.default_editorial: Circling around two lovers unsettled by an impending cosmic disaster, Nicola Sorcinelli’s passionate short ruffles the conventions of the period film with a dose of science fiction. As volatile emotions spill onto the sweeping landscape, La confessione lends a majestic grandeur to private doubts.

items.title: Last Summer
items.short_synopsis: Anne, a brilliant lawyer, lives in perfect harmony with her husband Pierre and their daughters in a house on the heights of Paris. One day, Theo, Pierre’s seventeen-year-old son from a previous marriage, moves in with them. Anne and Theo quickly form an unexpected connection.
items.default_editorial: Adding an incestuous tryst to her infamous repertoire, Catherine Breillat’s first film in a decade doesn’t disappoint. Adulterating images that are lustrous with desire, abuse of power darkens the sun-kissed idyll of this erotic drama—but its gaze never moralizes, laying attraction exquisitely bare.

items.title: Late Autumn
items.short_synopsis: Three ageing businessmen gather in a ceremony to commemorate their friend Miwa, who died a few years ago. When college nostalgia inspires them to match-make for their friend’s widow and her daughter, they have no idea of the strife their careless interference will cause.
items.default_editorial: In one of his final films, Yasujiro Ozu inverts another of his signature family dramas, the 1949 classic Late Spring. Starring an older Setsuko Hara, Late Autumn once more captures a parting parent and child’s mutual letting-go with all of Ozu’s usual sustained, sensitive attention to character.

items.title: Late Spring
items.short_synopsis: Noriko is a young, single, professional woman who lives with her father. She is encouraged by him and her friends to marry but has yet—or is unwilling—to find someone suitable. So, to prompt her to take her suitors seriously, her father pretends he is considering a new marriage.
items.default_editorial: Profoundly moving, this gorgeous and unparalleled classic from Yasujirō Ozu transcends its father-daughter drama to find a universal, and always inevitable tension between tradition and modernity. An absolute and indubitable masterpiece—as well as Ozu’s first film (of six!) with star Setsuko Hara.

items.title: Laurence Anyways
items.short_synopsis: In the ’90s, Laurence tells Fred that she identifies as a woman. Over ten years, in spite of the odds, in spite of each other, the couple confront the prejudices of their friends, ignore the council of their families, and brave the bigotry of the society they offend.
items.default_editorial: Circling gender and romance, Xavier Dolan’s prodigious third film views the complex journey of transition through the vibrant and baroque lens of melodrama. Jumping freely between different timelines, Laurence Anyways beautifully articulates the kaleidoscopic and nonlinear nature of self-discovery.

items.title: Long Day's Journey Into Night
items.original_title: 地球最后的夜晚 | Di qiu zui hou de ye wan
items.short_synopsis: Luo Hongwu returns to Kaili, the hometown from which he fled many years before, to find himself musing on the past and trying to retrieve its traces. Back for his father’s funeral, Luo recalls the death of an old friend, Wildcat, and searches for lost love Wan Qiwen, who continues to haunt him.
items.default_editorial: A dazzling, dizzying visual feast, Bi Gan’s opulent neo-noir rides a time-twisting slipstream of memory, dream and reality through the urban wastelands of Guizhou. The central set-piece invites special mention: a staggeringly audacious coup de cinéma in the form of an unbroken 59-minute shot.

items.title: Love
items.short_synopsis: Marianne, a doctor, and Tor, a nurse, avoid relationships. After meeting on a ferry where Tor seeks casual encounters, Marianne explores the possibility of spontaneous intimacy, questioning societal norms.
items.default_editorial: Oslo summer nights are for drifting, talking, and loving. One part of Dag Johan Haugerud’s trilogy on modern relationships, this luminous entry samples all the flavors of sex and romance, from online hookups to offline infatuation. Flushed with the glow of late August, Love tugs at the heartstrings.

items.title: Love and Anger
items.short_synopsis: New Testament parables and gospels are retold in contemporary settings. In New York, people ignore others needing help. In Rome, a cheerful, innocent young man walking a city street during a time of war pays a price for this innocence. Elsewhere, striking students take over a university classroom.
items.default_editorial: Cinematic luminaries—Pasolini, Godard, Bellocchio, and more—join forces in this impassioned anthology, a vital time capsule of 1960s discontent. As hushed indifference gives way to a feverish cacophony of dissent, Love and Anger powerfully voices the political angst of a restless generation.

items.title: Man With a Movie Camera
items.short_synopsis: 24 hours in the life of the inhabitants of a large city. From dawn to dusk, his device perched on his tripod, the man with a movie camera records and captures the hustle and bustle of an ordinary day.
items.default_editorial: Dziga Vertov’s masterpiece remains a visually thrilling chronicle of modern life, and an ode to the power of film. A lucid mixture of documentary and avant-garde techniques, it’s a radical redefinition of cinema’s boundaries—essential viewing that is just as groundbreaking many years later.

items.title: Mario's War
items.short_synopsis: The juvenile court assigns nine-year-old Mario to the care of Giulia and Sandro, a childless couple in their forties. Used to a life of abuse, little Mario is now spoiled and pampered by his new parents. Meanwhile, Giulia finds joy as a mother, but Mario has trouble fitting into this new reality.
items.default_editorial: Questions around care and class are faced with frank open-mindedness in Antonio Capuano’s moving story of an unconventional family. Attentive to the complex social realities of modern-day Naples, Mario’s War makes space for the moments of fantasy and imagination that form a childhood.

items.title: Misericordia
items.short_synopsis: Out-of-work Jérémie drifts back to his hometown after the death of his beloved former boss, a bakery owner. Staying long after the funeral, the seemingly benign Jérémie casually insinuates himself into his mentor’s family, including his kind-hearted widow and venomously angry son.
items.default_editorial: Secrets rustle among the brownish mulch of woodland leaves in Alain Guiraudie’s twisting tale of transgression and desire. Foraging for intrigue in insomniac nights, mushroom clusters, and chit-chat loosened with carafes of pastis, Misericordia salts suspense with comic outbursts and eccentricities.

items.title: Modern Times
items.short_synopsis: Subjected to the infernal production rate of the factory, the Little Tramp suddenly has a nervous breakdown. From hospital, to prison, to unemployment, he gets caught up in the sprockets and cogs of modern industrialization. That is, until he comes across a kind orphaned girl.
items.default_editorial: Possibly Chaplin’s greatest masterpiece—though with so many, who’s to say?—Modern Times contains some of the comic’s most brilliantly iconic and politically savvy routines. A biting satire of modern industrialized society, Chaplin staved off the 20th-century (and sound cinema) with wit and elegance.

items.title: My Golden Days
