items.short_synopsis: As he prepares to leave Tajikistan, anthropologist Paul Dédalus reflects on three moments from his youth. First, his childhood in Roubaix, then a school trip to the USSR. Finally, he recalls university life in Paris and partying in his hometown. Most of all he remembers Esther, the love of his life.
items.default_editorial: Arnaud Desplechin directs Mathieu Amalric in this whirlwind melodrama, a sequel of sorts to the director’s epic My Sex Life…or How I Got Into an Argument. Subtly evoking the free-wheeling nature of youth, My Golden Days  is a personal, emotionally resonant portrait of adolescence.

items.title: Nico, 1988
items.short_synopsis: Approaching 50, singer-songwriter Nico leads a solitary existence, far from her glam days as a Warhol superstar and vocalist for cult band The Velvet Underground. A new manager convinces Nico to hit the road again. Meanwhile, she struggles with her demons and the consequences of a muddled life.
items.default_editorial: Worlds away from the white heat of the swinging ‘60s, this unexpected biopic of German singer Nico homes in on her enigmatic final chapter. Creatively interspersed with archival footage, Susanna Nicchiarelli’s loose and open-ended take on the icon’s last days and legacy doesn’t demand clear answers.

items.title: Other Cannibals
items.short_synopsis: Fausto, a bored middle-aged factory worker, connects with philosophy student Ivan online. They both share an extreme thought—that is dark and beyond human standards. In a remote valley eaten away by industrial towns, they meet and plan an escape from their everyday existence.
items.default_editorial: Toying with knives and dropping acid—Francesco Sossai’s hypnotizing debut film is a regular buddy movie, but for the taboo-dark scheme that brings its lonely characters together. Silvery monochrome photography lends a keen edge to a genuinely sweet connection between outsiders, one short, one tall.

items.title: P. P. Rider
items.original_title: ションベン・ライダー | SHONBEN RAIDA- | Shonben Rider
items.short_synopsis: Three teens embark on a wild road odyssey to rescue their kidnapped class bully from a gang of yakuza. En route, they run afoul of some cops, befriend a motley former gangster, and experience the first seismic shocks of growing up.
items.default_editorial: Party balloons, toy windmills, and glistering fireworks flash playground color along the coast southwest of Tokyo in this coming-of-age picaresque from Shinji Sōmai. Long takes and aerial shots track the acrobatic antics of three wilful adolescents, clinging—with all their might—to childhood things.

items.title: Persona
items.short_synopsis: After Elisabet, a famed actress, lapses into silence from what appears to be a breakdown, she goes to a beach house with only Alma, a nurse, as company. Over the next weeks, as Alma struggles to reach her mute patient, they both find themselves experiencing a strange emotional convergence.
items.default_editorial: An endlessly fascinating labyrinth of desires, repressions, and compulsions: Bergman’s modernist masterpiece is truly indispensable to understanding contemporary cinema. The visionary Swedish director experiments with the subconscious to reach sublime and transcendent levels of narrative freedom.

items.title: Pickpocket
items.short_synopsis: Michel takes up pickpocketing as a hobby but is arrested almost immediately, giving him the chance to reflect on the morality of his crimes. However, after his release, his mother dies. He rejects the support of friends and returns to pickpocketing, knowing it’s the only way he can express himself.
items.default_editorial: In one of his greatest films, Robert Bresson crafts an enigmatic and suspenseful character study: a story of redemption and a profound retelling of Dostoevsky’s Crime and Punishment. Through philosophical and extraordinarily choreographed acts of theft, Pickpocket proves to be transcendental.

items.title: Polytechnique
items.short_synopsis: Valérie and Jean-François study at a school in Montreal. One day, a brutal event causes irreversible changes in their lives. A 25-year-old man enters the school with a rifle in his hand and his goal is to murder every woman in the building.
items.default_editorial: Before Denis Villeneuve had made his unexpected rise as a director of cerebral blockbusters with the likes of Arrival, he confronted the subject of the 1989 Polytechnique massacre in Montreal to pay tribute to the victims with this powerful film on the futility of violence. Difficult, yet essential.

items.title: Prague's Girl
items.short_synopsis: Through old photos, Francesco and Eloisa reconstruct the love story of their grandparents. In 1968 Prague, Maša, an exile, and Gianlorenzo, an Italian diplomat, fall in love just before the Russian occupation. They flee to Rome—but Maša is driven by an uncontrollable desire for freedom…
items.default_editorial: In Andree Lucini’s documentary, what begins as a gentle portrait of an ordinary Czech grandmother gradually reveals harsh truths about generational trauma. Through familial anecdotes and faded photographs, this engrossing short traces the jagged contours of an immigrant’s life in postwar Italy.

items.title: Preparations to Be Together for an Unknown Period of Time
items.short_synopsis: At a conference, 40-year-old neurosurgeon Márta falls in love with fellow surgeon János. She decides to leave her successful career in the US behind to return to Budapest to start a new life with him. However, when she arrives, János claims they have never met before, let alone fallen in love.
items.default_editorial: With film noir tension and dreamlike enchantment, Lili Horvát sweeps us off our feet with a love story pulsating with refined mystery. Carried by a magnetic performance from Natasa Stork—in her first leading film role!—this mesmerizing, elegant enigma is reminiscent of both Kieślowski and Hitchcock.

items.title: Pulse
items.short_synopsis: A group of young people in Tokyo experience strange phenomena involving missing friends and technological breakdown. After the unexpected suicides of several friends, three strangers set out to explore a decaying city, and to solve the mystery of a forbidden room in an abandoned construction site.
items.default_editorial: Long before winning the Silver Lion for Wife of a Spy, master genre stylist Kiyoshi Kurosawa took Cannes by surprise with this reflection on loneliness and technology. Utterly terrifying, Pulse is a prophetic, intensely eerie cult classic that is still superior to its many imitators.

items.title: Respiro
items.short_synopsis: A close-knit fishing community in South-West Sicily has remained unchanged for centuries. However, Grazia, the wife of one of the fishermen, has an unconventional attitude to life. The community decides that Grazia needs medical attention and attempts to have her treated in the city.
items.default_editorial: With an elegant economy of style and striking imagery, Emanuele Crialese captures the beauty and cruelty of a culture with contradictory ideas around untamed power. Wreaking havoc on her small town, Valeria Golino’s firebrand of a housewife exposes the absurdity of antiquated traditions.

items.title: Scenes from a Marriage (Theatrical Version)
items.short_synopsis: Doctor Johan and attorney Marianne are a successful professional couple who juggle their careers with marriage and children. Over many years of love and turmoil, their relationship progresses through multiple stages: matrimony, infidelity, divorce, and subsequent partnerships.
items.default_editorial: Attesting to the life-changing force of great cinema, this devastating classic from Ingmar Bergman sent separation rates in Sweden soaring. Reckoning with the effect of modern gender relations on domestic bliss, terrific performances from Liv Ullmann and Erland Josephson wound with enduring insight.

items.title: Sex
items.short_synopsis: Two married, heterosexual chimney sweeps face experiences that unsettle their views on sexuality and identity. One has a same-sex encounter without considering it either as an expression of homosexuality or infidelity. The other finds himself in dreams where he is seen as a woman.
items.default_editorial: Opening up a social world of sex to the soothing erotics of conversation, Dag Johan Haugerud’s drama airs taboos in the crisp Norwegian sunlight. One in a tessellating trilogy, this sensitive film is lifted by empathetic performances that work to find the hard and the soft in modern masculinity.

items.title: Silence
items.short_synopsis: Two Christian missionaries travel to Japan in search of their missing mentor at a time when Christianity is outlawed. When they are captured and imprisoned, both men are plunged into an odyssey that will test their faith, challenge their sanity and, perhaps, risk their very lives.
items.default_editorial: Martin Scorsese’s adaptation of Shūsaku Endō’s eponymous novel is a harrowing epic of devotion and doubt. With a stellar cast featuring Adam Driver, Andrew Garfield, and Liam Neeson, this powerful period piece questions the lines between faith, ideology and colonialism in 16th-century Japan.

items.title: Snowden
items.short_synopsis: Disillusioned with the intelligence community, Edward Snowden leaves his job at the NSA. He knows that a virtual mountain of data is being assembled to track all forms of digital communication. When Snowden decides to leak this classified information, he becomes a traitor to some, a hero to others.
items.default_editorial: With a transformative central performance by Joseph Gordon-Levitt and Oliver Stone in the director’s chair, this rousing biopic turns real-life events into a gripping thriller. Exposing grievous modern misuses of information, Snowden tackles issues of patriotism and privacy with searing urgency.

items.title: Spring Breakers
items.short_synopsis: Four childhood friends land in jail after robbing a restaurant to fund their spring break vacation. They are bailed out by a rapper who promises to provide all the thrill and excitement they could hope for. But how far are they willing to go to experience a spring break they will never forget?
items.default_editorial: Another raucous, rowdy work from Harmony Korine, this entrancingly voyeuristic look at girls gone wild is as overwhelming as it is overstimulating. In your face, ingeniously iconoclastic, and shocking from start to finish, Spring Breakers stars an unrecognizable and excellent James Franco.

items.title: Story of a Love Affair
items.short_synopsis: A wealthy industrialist becomes curious about his trophy wife Paola’s past and hires a private investigator. The detective discovers that she had fallen desperately in love with the handsome Guido as a young girl, and may have participated in a crime to win his hand…
items.default_editorial: Michelangelo Antonioni was one of the great innovators of narrative film, and here’s where he begins.  With a basis in film noir and neo-realism, he was already moving beyond both, towards the existential cinema that he would perfect with L’avventura, La notte, and L’eclisse. A master’s debut!

items.title: Summer of Giacomo
items.short_synopsis: Nineteen-year-old Giacomo, newly regaining his hearing, heads to the river with his sixteen-year-old friend Stefania. As they wander the sunlit woods of northeastern Italy, they lose their way and drift into an afternoon that stretches like the whole summer.
items.default_editorial: Two idling teens lead a biddable camera off the beaten track in this sun-dimpled docufiction, which winds back the clock to a simpler time. Ushering in a new naturalism, director Alessandro Comodin undresses cinema to its bare essence, reveling in its raw materials: movement, play, presence, light.

items.title: Sunday Night
items.short_synopsis: Alex, an ultras, returns home empty-headed after his team’s loss. Living with his grandmother, he sells Rivotril to make ends meet. He meets Nemy at a rap battle. They cross the night in a stolen car—their bodies brush against each other in what seems to be the beginning of a love story.
items.default_editorial: A Venice Critics’ Week selection in 2024, Matteo Tortone’s audacious short brings subtle traits of toxic masculinity to the surface. Articulating the unspoken dynamics of various social spaces, this combustible character study maps out the hidden twists and turns of a troubled mind.

items.title: Suzhou River
items.short_synopsis: After getting out of prison, small-time crook Mardar stumbles upon a woman who looks exactly like his long-lost lover.
items.default_editorial: Now dazzlingly restored, Lou Ye’s seductive neo-noir casts a mysterious spell over Shanghai, where industrialization and myths dreamily collide. Echoes of Vertigo ricochet through this love story, an urban fairytale haunted by wandering city slickers, beautiful lookalikes, and shimmering mermaids.

items.title: Sworn Virgin
items.short_synopsis: In remote Albania, Hana escapes from her destiny of being a wife by invoking a traditional law: taking an oath of eternal virginity to live free as a man. To locals, Hana becomes Mark. Years later, something restless stirs under these men’s clothes. Mark embarks on a transformative voyage to Italy.
items.default_editorial: Layering vulnerability and stoicism, Alba Rohrwacher is magnetic in Laura Bispuri’s formidable debut. Shedding light on an obscure Albanian ritual where young women surrender their femininity, this decades-spanning family saga muses on gender fluidity and the possibility of personal liberation.

items.title: Taxi Monamour
items.short_synopsis: In Rome, two young women face complicated moments in their lives. Anna is in conflict with herself and her family, while Cristi is fleeing from Ukraine, forced away by a war that keeps her far from home. Their brief encounter will become an unpredictable and intense dive into freedom.
items.default_editorial: Sensitive to the emotional inner lives of women, Ciro De Caro’s ingeniously structured drama channels the multicultural spirit of Italy, as two unmoored souls discover solace and understanding against all odds. Transcending language and social barriers, the power of true friendship knows no borders.

items.title: The Adventures of Gigi the Law
items.short_synopsis: Police officer Gigi routinely patrols a small rural community in Italy where nothing much ever happens. But now there’s a macabre case to solve, as for the second time in a short period, a local has jumped in front of a train. Gigi—the filmmaker’s uncle—starts investigating.
items.default_editorial: A sleepy town is a breeding ground for dark secrets and make-believe in this lovingly observed docufiction. Set in a part of Italy made familiar by filmmaker Pier Paolo Pasolini, Alessandro Comodin’s film makes Fruili strange again, a place where plant life partners death in a dreamlike pas de deux.

items.title: The Battle of Algiers
items.short_synopsis: 1950s Algeria: Ali La Pointe is recruited to join the National Liberation Front, becoming involved in its armed insurgency against the French colonial powers. French paratrooper Colonel Mathieu is entrusted with squelching the uprisings. As violence escalates on each side, no act is too unthinkable.
items.default_editorial: One of the most significant political films ever made, Gilles Pontecorvo’s Battle of Algiers is pure revolutionary cinema. Shot on location in newsreel-style B&W, it uses mostly non-professional actors whose lived experience of the battle inform the drama—to a spectacular Ennio Morricone score.

items.title: The Challenge
items.short_synopsis: A falconer enters an important tournament in Qatar, competing with wealthy Qatari sheikhs with a passion for amateur falconry. With their opulence on full display, the men fly their prized birds on private jets, race SUVs through the dunes, and take their pet cheetahs for rides in their Ferraris.
items.default_editorial: A rare glimpse at a secret world of surreal opulence, Yuri Ancarani’s feature debut is a sight to behold. Falcons, sheikhs, Ferraris, and cheetahs line up in this arresting parade of haunting imagery, as the pursuit of leisure takes on an uncanny dimension, revealing the empty spectacle of wealth.

items.title: The Deer Hunter
items.short_synopsis: In 1968, three lifelong friends from a working-class Pennsylvania steel town prepare to ship out to Vietnam to fight in the war after one last hunting trip. There, their dreams of military honor are quickly shattered by the inhumanities of war—and those who survive are haunted by their memories.
items.default_editorial: A classic of New Hollywood cinema, Michael Cimino’s powerful anti-war epic summons a trio of intense, terrific performances from its stars Robert De Niro, Christopher Walken, and Meryl Streep. Cimino’s breakthrough, and winner of five Academy Awards® including Best Picture.

items.title: The Desert of the Tartars
items.short_synopsis: Drogo, a young lieutenant, is assigned to the defense of an isolated fortress in a mountainous desert region. The garrison’s mission is to fight off any attacks by the Tartars. In reality though, the real enemy is time, sapping their lives and vitality as they wait for an enemy that never shows up.
items.default_editorial: The last film by underrated Italian master Valerio Zurlini (Violent Summer) is an ambitiously orchestrated adaptation of Dino Buzzati’s novel. Starring Jacques Perrin alongside a cast of A-list actors, and scored by Ennio Morricone, this is an epic, staggering take on the psychology of war.

items.title: The Eggregores' Theory
items.short_synopsis: He cannot remember much from that time. Things have faded, like the colors of a painting exposed to too much light. The only thing bothering him is the music. It keeps popping up in his mind. He thinks he’s forgotten what it meant. He cannot get it out of his head.
items.default_editorial: Using new technologies for creative expression and social commentary, Andrea Gatopoulos’s haunting short conjures a dystopian future where art and language are outlawed. At once painterly and discomfiting, a flood of surreal black-and-white images sounds alarm bells about the loss of individuality.

items.title: The Gospel According to St. Matthew
items.short_synopsis: Starting from his Immaculate Conception, the life of Jesus is retraced according to the Gospel of St. Matthew. When Jesus begins to travel through Palestine with his disciples to spread the word of God, the Romans conspire to have him silenced, leading to his arrest, crucifixion, and resurrection.
items.default_editorial: A gorgeously textured and soulful take of the life of Christ from Italy’s greatest poet-filmmaker. Given Pasolini’s reputation as an atheist-Marxist-homosexual, the film’s radically realist—dare we say reverential—treatment of religious belief was startling, even winning acclaim by the Vatican!

items.title: The Invitation
items.short_synopsis: Will and Eden were once a loving couple, then they separated after a tragedy took their son. Two years later, Eden returns with a new husband and invites Will to a dinner party, which quickly becomes an unsettling affair that reopens old wounds and creates new tensions.
items.default_editorial: The cleanly chic interiors of a Hollywood home give little away in Karyn Kusama’s murkily mysterious thriller. Goose-pimply with paranoia, The Invitation leans in close to glean cultish intent from a host’s overattentiveness, and catch whispers of suspicion in coincidence.

items.title: The Kingdom of Naples
items.short_synopsis: In a troubled neighborhood in post-war Naples, a decade-spanning chronicle of a local family unfolds. Following the premature death of his wife, a man struggles to raise his two children. Later, his son rises through the ranks of the burgeoning Communist Party while his daughter enters the church.
items.default_editorial: Famous for his stylized and experimental provocations, German auteur Werner Schroeter took a surprising turn toward realism for this volatile epic, a searing chronicle of Italy’s political upheavals. Adrift on the cruel tides of history, a broken family and their plight mirror a nation in crisis.

items.title: The Man Who Sold His Skin
items.original_title: L'homme qui a vendu sa peau
items.short_synopsis: To travel to Europe and live with the love of his life, Sam Ali, a Syrian refugee, has his back tattooed by one of the world’s leading contemporary artists. However, by turning his own body into a prestigious piece of art, Sam will realize that his decision might actually mean anything but freedom.
items.default_editorial: What price dignity? So asks this sinuous drama from Kaouther Ben Hania, as a refugee trades the proverbial pound of flesh for safe passage. Crafted as elaborately as its hero’s skin is inked, this Oscar®-nominated film scratches its satirical criticisms into the varnish of the extractive art world.

items.title: The Metamorphosis of Birds
items.short_synopsis: Filmmaker Catarina Vasconcelos sifts through the memories of her ancestors. Her naval officer grandfather, Henrique, who married her grandmother, Beatriz, on her 21st birthday, spent extended periods at sea, leaving her with six children. This is the beginning of a generational saga.
items.default_editorial: Picking up a slew of awards from the likes of Berlin, San Sebastián, and IndieLisboa, this intoxicating Portuguese debut by Catarina Vasconcelos is an artisanal hybrid documentary. A poetic ode to family and loss, ravishingly captured on 16mm, its lyrical vignettes carry a profound cumulative power.

items.title: The Milky Way
items.short_synopsis: Two men—part beggar, part pilgrim—are journeying to Santiago de Compostela in Spain. On their religious odyssey, they meet a whole assortment of people—some cruel, some violent, and some bizarre—and they experience many adventures—some mysterious, some erotic, some even supernatural.
items.default_editorial: A gem in Luis Buñuel’s treasure chest, The Milky Way is a masterpiece in subversive surrealism from his late career. Assembling a stellar ensemble cast—including Delphine Seyrig and Michel Piccoli—it takes aim at the legacy of organized religion through an array of memorably comic scenarios.

items.title: The Peacock's Paradise
items.short_synopsis: On a cold winter day, Nena’s family reunites in their house in front of the sea to celebrate her birthday. Everybody in the family is there—including Paco, Alma’s peacock, who falls in love with a little painted dove. This impossible love will force the whole family to reckon with their feelings.
items.default_editorial: With a rare recent turn from French New Wave actor Dominique Sanda, Laura Bispuri’s film feels around for the knots and splinters in a family tree with warmth and intuition. Embellishing a familiar scenario, the titular bird feathers fractious scenes with iridescent colors and mysterious symbolism.

items.title: The Runner
items.short_synopsis: A young orphan navigates life on the streets of a southern Iranian port city. Determined to rise above his circumstances, he takes on odd jobs, spends time with friends, learns to read—and runs, always running, toward a future of his own making.
items.default_editorial: This meditative character study captures the first inklings of a child’s curiosity about the world and all it might have to offer. Stunning sunsets and open horizons evoke the promise of expansive days to come in Amir Naderi’s moving ode to the salutary power of knowledge and art.

items.title: The Sweet East
items.short_synopsis: Lillian, a high school senior from South Carolina, gets her first glimpse of the wider world on a class trip to Washington, D.C. Separated from her schoolmates, she embarks on a fractured road trip—a picaresque journey through the cities and woods of the Eastern coast of the United States.
items.default_editorial: Pizzagate! Skinheads! Independent filmmakers! Take a wild ride into the subcultural underground with the feature debut from celebrated cinematographer Sean Price Williams. Riotously funny and ticklishly subversive, The Sweet East is a picaresque adventure along a nation’s disaffected fringes.

items.title: The Tale of King Crab
items.short_synopsis: Today, some still call him a saint, an outcast or a murderer: Luciano, fueled by his love for the fiery Emma, stood for his freedom till committing the unforgivable. Exiled to the distant and hostile Tierra del Fuego, there he might find his way towards salvation in a quest for a legendary treasure.
items.default_editorial: Drawing its idiosyncratic power from the wellsprings of legend, this ecstatic folktale travels from 19th-century Italy to Argentina’s Tierra del Fuego. A primal meditation on the potency of storytelling, The Tale of King Crab is a redemptive fable charged with mythic grandeur and elemental beauty.

items.title: To the Wonder
items.short_synopsis: After a whirlwind romance in France, Neil and Marina, a single mother, move to Oklahoma. But as Marina struggles to adjust to American life and their relationship fractures, Neil reconnects with a former flame from his past. Meanwhile, Marina befriends a priest grappling with doubts about his faith.
items.default_editorial: To the Wonder is Malick’s sensual evocation of a couple coming undone. The American impressionist boldly sets this adulterous drama in the present day, rooting his characters’ quest for harmony in our world’s precarious beauty. Starring Ben Affleck, Olga Kurylenko, Rachel McAdams & Javier Bardem.

items.title: Tout va bien
items.short_synopsis: A couple in crisis—an American journalist and her former French New Wave filmmaker husband—visit an industrial sausage factory to interview its director. However, they are unaware that the factory is occupied by striking workers. Soon they are locked up with the chief in his office.
items.default_editorial: Directed by filmmaking duo Jean-Luc Godard and Jean-Pierre Gorin (under the name Dziga Vertov Group), Tout va bien offers a biting critique of capitalist culture in post modern France. Starring Jane Fonda and Yves Montand, this is a playful, rule-breaking look at the leftist struggles of the time.

items.title: Toxic Love
items.short_synopsis: A group of heroin users hanging out at Ostia beach in Rome spends their time squabbling among themselves as they relentlessly pursue their next score, fuelled by petty theft and armed robbery. This routine is only momentarily punctuated with the faint hope of getting clean.
items.default_editorial: An unflinching portrayal of heroin use on the streets of Rome, Claudio Caligari’s bracing masterwork captures the mundanity and desperation of life between fixes. With its nonprofessional cast of real-life addicts, Toxic Love tempers its graphic verisimilitude with profound empathy and compassion.

items.title: Waiting
items.short_synopsis: In southern Iran, a fourteen-year-old boy is sent each day to fetch ice from a neighbor’s house, where a girl hands it to him through a doorway—only her hennaed hand ever visible. Soon, he becomes quietly consumed with the desire to glimpse her face.
items.default_editorial: Longing builds quietly through this hypnotic short, which charts the routine of a young boy bewitched by beauty. In Amir Naderi’s assured hands, light, color, and texture take on majestic significance, forming an exquisite cinematic language that spells out the swooning agony of yearning.

items.title: Wild Strawberries
items.short_synopsis: In the company of his daughter-in-law, Professor Isak Borg journeys by car to collect an honorary degree from his former university. The trip kickstarts a series of reminiscences and reveries as the aging Borg revisits the scenes of his youth and reflects on an unhappy marriage.
items.default_editorial: The universe of dreams is often portrayed in films, but nightmares have rarely looked so distinctively unsettling. The opening of Wild Strawberries sets the rules of this game: what ensues is a haunting depiction of a man’s battle against the ghosts of time. A psychological road movie, à la Bergman!

items.title: Yesterday, Today and Tomorrow
items.short_synopsis: In Naples, Adelina sells cigarettes on the black market whilst avoiding prison thanks to a long string of pregnancies. Meanwhile, the wealthy Anna in Milan escapes boredom through escapades with a struggling journalist. Elsewhere, in Rome, sex worker Mara tackles a young priest’s infatuation.
items.default_editorial: Vittorio De Sica is most famous for his neo-realist dramas, but he was just as skilled at comedy, and his collaborations with the great Sophia Loren and Marcello Mastroianni were a match made in heaven. Winner of the Best Foreign Film Oscar®, this three-pronged serio-comic burlesque is a delight.

items.title: The Fox Exploits the Tiger's Might
items.original_title: The Fox Exploits the Tiger's Might
items.short_synopsis: A story about two teenagers who are having a struggle in their sexual awakening and the relations between power and sex, set in a military base ghost town.
items.default_editorial: The first Indonesian film to play Critics Week in Cannes since 1989, The Fox Exploits the Tiger’s Might signaled a renaissance in the nation’s cinema. An erotically-charged tale of sexual awakening set on a disused military base, Lucky Kuswandi’s provocative short is a political cri de coeur.

items.title: Mold
items.short_synopsis: Basri, walks every day for miles along the tracks working as a railroad watchman. His only thought is finding his missing son. 18 years ago, while the boy was at the university in Istanbul, the police took him into custody for anti-government activities. Then, he mysteriously disappeared.
items.default_editorial: Starring Ercan Kesal (Once Upon a Time in Anatolia), Mold is a noir-like journey into social oppressions experienced in modern Turkey. With the requisite oppressive atmosphere to match, Ali Aydın’s debut film moves with dour yet beguiling rhythms towards a nuanced critique of a troubled society.

items.title: 'Til Madness Do Us Part
items.short_synopsis: Within an isolated mental institution in China’s Yunnan province, patients are confined to one single floor of a building. Once locked in, with little contact from the outside world, anything goes. The inmates have been committed for different reasons, but all share the same cramped living quarters.
items.default_editorial: Wang Bing places his camera in spaces and predicaments other filmmakers would be afraid to. Here he gains access to an asylum whose use and practices beg questions that extend beyond mental health and probe the very nature of freedom. This is immersive, often haunting, contemplative cinema.

items.title: All the Wrong Reasons
items.short_synopsis: Making one of his final screen performances, the late Cory Monteith leads a superb Canadian ensemble in this sharply nuanced comic drama from debut Canadian director Gia Milani.
items.default_editorial: Beloved Glee star Cory Monteith makes one of his last screen performances in this delightfully unexpected ensemble comic drama about a group of “normal” people, which marks Canadian director Gia Milani’s debut. Expect the unexpected.

items.title: Apart
items.short_synopsis: Linked by a rare psychological disorder, Noah Greene and Emily Gates must uncover the mystery of a tragic past in order to find hope for the future.
items.default_editorial: Inspired by real-life case studies of rare psychiatric disorders, Aaron Rottinghaus’s romantic thriller grapples with the crippling shockwaves of delusion and past trauma. Straddling hallucinations and reality, this visually striking debut believes in the resilience of love at the darkest of times.

items.title: Arirang
items.short_synopsis: A personal film for Kim Ki-duk in which he addresses his “disappearance” for three years and a look back in his career.
items.default_editorial: A deeply-personal, intimate and unconventional documentary film from Kim Ki-duk (3-Iron), Ariang is both a bracing exercise in catharsis and an uncompromising self-portrait, laying bare the director’s own struggles and self-destruction. Winner of the Cannes Film Festival’s Un Certain Regard prize.

items.title: Awakening Dust
items.short_synopsis: This is the story of a man who has suffered the transgressed living a life of crime and corruption. The hood is the stage where he roams the streets invisible, ignored, lonely, lost in misery. An unfortunate event will move Chano´s protective instinct and will make him go back to the crime world.
items.default_editorial: A visceral yet empathetic look at the origins of violence, Awakening Dust surveys the desperation that seeps into the souls of those who live on the margins. Hari Sama worked with people from the real-life community of “Campamento 2 de Octubre,” giving a raw authenticity to fictional events.

items.title: Borgman
items.short_synopsis: An enigmatic vagrant named Camiel Borgman enters the lives of a middle-class family and quickly unravels their carefully curated lifestyle. It isn’t long before the charming and mysterious figure has the wife, children, and nanny under his spell in a calculated bid to take over their lives.
items.default_editorial: The archetypal story of an outsider upending the values of a middle-class family is revised anew in this uncanny thriller by Alex van Warmerdam. A modernist fable on the subject of evil and domesticity (with welcome shades of dark humor!), Borgman is an experience you’re unlikely to ever shake.

items.title: Breath
items.short_synopsis: Yeon, a passionate and lonely artist, is intrigued to learn that Jiang Jin is awaiting execution on death row for the murder of his wife and children. She decides to visit him in prison, and their relationship evolves into a dreamy yet violent passion.
items.default_editorial: Nominated for the Palme d’Or in 2007, Breath is a daring, surrealist mix of sex, death, and an impossible love rendered with poetic melancholy. Kim Ki-duk’s typically meditative style subtly brings out the inner lives of his characters, who are searching for happiness in the simplest of pleasures.

items.title: Clash
items.short_synopsis: Already Vietnam’s highest grossing film this year, Clash is a twisted martial arts of love, deception, and betrayal set against the backdrop of modern Saigon.
items.default_editorial: We love a good con movie. There’s something about watching pros fool someone…and then usually fool the audience because there’s always a twist. From the director of Glenngarry Glen Ross comes this smart con whose great cast has Edward Burns, Rachel Weisz, Paul Giamatti and Dustin Hoffman.

items.title: Father
items.short_synopsis: Guilia’s father was a great composer. After his death, he now communicates with his daughter through his music. An old family friend initiates Guilia in the mysteries of communicating with the bereaved and leads her to an initiation into this invisible world.
items.default_editorial: Inspired by the works of Italian songwriter Franco Battiato, Giada Colagrande’s eerie film deals with a young woman’s grief following the death of her father, and her journey into a supernatural world where the dead reside. A spiritual reflection on loss starring Willem Dafoe and Marina Abramović.

items.title: Four Dragons
items.short_synopsis: When 19th-century Chinese immigrants find themselves fighting against a powerful lord and a vengeful gang with secretive aims, they summon the ancient power of Wushu to wage an epic battle of good vs. evil.
items.default_editorial: The first homegrown martial arts film to come out of Malaysia, this period kung fu adventure pits a quartet of blood brothers against a ruthless mine owner in 19th-century Perak. With Hong Kong veteran Chin Kar-lok on fight choreography duties, Four Dragons delivers the high-kicking action goods.

items.title: Freedom's Fury
items.short_synopsis: Documentary about the Melbourne, Australia 1956 Summer Olympics semifinal water polo match between Hungary and the Russia, and the events that led up to the violent battle, the match that what would later be known as the “Blood in the Water match.”
items.default_editorial: Known as the “blood in the water match,” the water polo event of 1956 was immortalized as one of the bloodiest in Olympic history. Narrated by the record-breaking athlete Mark Spitz, Freedom’s Fury is a nail-biting account of a moment when sport and revolution intersected unforgettably.

items.title: Gigantic
items.short_synopsis: Mattress salesman Brian Weathersby (Dano) finds his plan to adopt a Chinese baby augmented by the arrival of a young woman, Happy (Deschanel), who comes into his workplaces, falls asleep on one of the beds, and starts to affect his life upon waking up.
items.default_editorial: Matt Aselton’s feature debut counts on three ingredients which we love in our films: Paul Dano, Zooey Deschanel & John Goodman. Combine with some existential crisis and a Chinese baby to complete this quirky, goofy tale of love, family, and the challenges in getting what you want.

items.title: Griff the Invisible
items.short_synopsis: Griff, office worker by day, superhero by night, has his world turned upside down when he meets Melody, a beautiful young scientist who shares his passion for the impossible.
items.default_editorial: Have you ever felt invisible? Ryan Kwanten, who you might know from the television series True Blood, is the protagonist of this Australian film about the superhero that lies within us all, but which only one person can see. The world may make us feel invisible, but love can make us invincible.

items.title: Hoax_canular
items.short_synopsis: How do you survive the end of the world? The young people in this exceptional found-footage film discuss their plans and expectations in a series of online videos. Some of them think they can survive, others embrace the end. Sometimes parody, sometimes scarily real.
items.default_editorial: Accumulating a series of YouTube videos into a hypnotic found-footage collage, artist Dominic Gagnon assembles a bracing document of teen paranoia. Intimately entering the private worlds of young adults obsessed with the apocalypse, Hoax_canular is a sociological plunge into internet-age nihilism.

items.title: Home
items.short_synopsis: The story of Kevin, who has just been released from a remand home. Going back to live with his parents is no longer an option, so he is going to move in with his aunt’s family. Will his new home be able to save him from juvenile delinquency? Or will he miss this opportunity?
items.default_editorial: Winning a Best Director award in Venice, Home explores the fraught relationship between parents and teenagers, in which brewing miscommunication results in poisonous actions. Shot in a raw, realist style, this insight into youngsters’ lives and confusion is an unsparing yet rewarding experience.

items.title: If I Didn't Care
items.short_synopsis: Hitchcockian film noir/thriller set in the exclusive resort community of The Hamptons. Trophy husband Davis Meyers meets local investigator Linus. Davis Meyers’ ill-fated attempt to produce an heir leads to infidelity, murder and tragic consequences.
items.default_editorial: Notable for Roy Scheider’s penultimate performance as a droll, Columbo-esque raincoat detective, this effortlessly stylish noir sniffs out the delicious secrets that lurk behind the gilded gates of the Hamptons. From illicit affairs to murders, the super elite sure know how to spend their idle time!

items.title: Inescapable
items.short_synopsis: One afternoon, on a typical day at work, Adib is confronted with devastating news: His eldest daughter, Muna, has gone missing in Damascus. Now Adib, who has not been back in over 30 years, must return to Syria and deal with his secret past in order to find her.
items.default_editorial: A nail-biting thriller embedded around an unfurling mystery, Inescapable takes a heartbreakingly relevant geopolitical situation to examine the challenges of escaping our past. Working with Dawson’s Creek star Joshua Jackson, director Ruba Nadda revs up the political intrigue via tense performances.

items.title: Lands Close to Paterson
items.short_synopsis: In New York to present her film Siberia, Joana Preiss documents the city through its pace and meetings. We are wrapped in a mysterious journey through her imagination, which is both breathtaking and hypnotic.
items.default_editorial: A beguiling cacophony of sirens, strange beeps, and even the sound of subway trains grinding on their rail tracks, Joana Preiss’ metropolitan snapshot hypnotically accentuates the rough edges of New York. The shaky, swoony camera movement seizes the delirious mania of the city that never sleeps.

items.title: Lola Pater
items.short_synopsis: After his mother’s death, 27-year-old Zino decides to go looking for his father, Farid, who disappeared 25 years earlier. He learns that Farid is living in the south of France and that his parents never got divorced. But when he arrives there, instead of Farid he finds Lola, a belly dancing teacher.
items.default_editorial: A path to discovery becomes a tale of acceptance and parental love in Lola Pater, in which the dazzling Fanny Ardant plays a transgender woman who reconnects with the son she never knew. Balancing melodrama and light humor to delightful effect, this film reminds us all to embrace our identity.

items.title: Manakamana
items.short_synopsis: High above the jungle in Nepal, pilgrims go on an ancient journey, travelling by cable car to reach the Manakamana temple. Qualified as a remarkable formal experiment, it is also a flat out marvellous and wildly funny kind of a ride.
items.default_editorial: This risk-taking, radically immersive documentary from Harvard’s Sensory Ethnography Lab strips cinema to its essentials, locking down the camera and letting us observe all kinds of people as they travel to a sacred temple. A serene project that experiments with form while staying powerfully humane.

items.title: Manta Ray
items.short_synopsis: Near a coastal village of Thailand, a local fisherman rescues a stranger, who does not speak a word, offers him his friendship and names him Thongchai. When the fisherman suddenly disappears at sea, Thongchai slowly begins to take over his friend’s life—his house, his job and his marriage.
items.default_editorial: The gorgeous images and gentle storytelling of Thai director Phuttiphong Aroonpheng’s entrancing debut subtly build a compassionate evocation of the Rohingya refugee crisis in Thailand. A tale of empathy, culpability, recuperation, and blurred identities, it marks the voice of a bold new talent.

items.title: Mary, Mary, Bloody Mary
items.short_synopsis: A beautifull artist moonlights as a vampire while in Mexico, killing lovers of both sex. It seems that the only person who has any chance of stopping her reign of terror is her father.
items.default_editorial: Looking for a taste of Italian giallo, transported to the U.S., and made by a Mexican purveyor of art-horror exploitation? We’ve got you covered with this low-budget dose of ‘70s sleaze—a blood-soaked vampire thriller with queer sensibilities, that happens to be one of Tarantino’s favorite films.

items.title: Nepal Forever
items.short_synopsis: A documentary comedy. This film features two Russian communist politicians. Their horizons are broad, but what concerns them the most is the future of global communism. At one point, by decree of fate, their booming activities begin to expand far beyond the boundaries of the Russian Federation.
items.default_editorial: It’s hard to disagree with Russian filmmaker Aliona Polunina’s description of her award-winning feature as a “documentary-comedy.” Following a pair of politicians as they negotiate peace between two Communist splinter groups, Nepal Forever is one for fans of The Thick of It and In the Loop.

items.title: Nice Guy Johnny
items.short_synopsis: A master of the modern relationship dramedy, Edward Burns crafts a summery gem centered on baby-faced 24-year-old Johnny Rizzo, who’s about to trade his dream job in talk radio for some snoozeville gig that’ll pay enough to please his fiancée.
items.default_editorial: Edward Burns has made a name for himself on the independent scene with his self-proclaimed “tiny little stories about people I know.” The actor-director is on scene-stealing form in Nice Guy Johnny, a winning romcom infused with local flavor and boasting a palpable chemistry between its two leads.

items.title: Not All Is Vigil
items.short_synopsis: Antonio and Felisa have been together their whole and now that their health is more fragile their are afraid of not being able to take care of each other. The prospect of having to go into a retirement home appears on the horizon as a threat.
items.default_editorial: Starring the director’s own grandparents, Hermes Paralluelo’s poignant docufiction feature cuts unnervingly close to home. A heartfelt tribute to the staggering resilience of autumnal love, this beautifully realized film foregrounds the unspoken loneliness of old age and the fear of losing control.

items.title: Not Junk Yet: The Art of Lary 7
items.original_title: Not Junk Yet: The Art of Lary 7
items.short_synopsis: A film about New York musician, multi-instrumentalist, producer, sound artist, filmmaker and photographer Lary 7.
items.default_editorial: Though not exactly a household name, the iconic N.Y.C. sound artist Lary 7 worked with many of the greats of the Downtown scene, like Lydia Lunch, Tony Conrad, Matthew Barney, & JG Thirwell. A paen to creativity, Not Junk Yet features sound design by  Einstürzende Neubauten member, Alexander Hacke!

items.title: Ocean Blues
items.short_synopsis: Isabel is an Actress. Xavier wants to be a Director. Isabel is looking for Love. Xavier is looking for the Love of his Life. Isabel is stuck on a bad relationship. Xavier is looking for one. Isabel sings while Xavier watches. Will love rule the Ocean? Or will the waves strike hard on both of them?
items.default_editorial: In Salomón Askenazi’s emotionally-charged debut, pools of blues and reds threaten to spill out of every frame, mirroring the torrid intensity between the film’s tormented lovers. Just like the mercurial ocean, the waves of passion can either reveal new destinations or leave you gasping for air.

items.title: Penelope
items.short_synopsis: A mother of an autistic little girl, director Claire Doyon decides to try and find a way to make her child feel better by undertaking a long journey. Together they travel to the deepest corners of Mongolian Siberia, searching for a shaman with healing powers.
items.default_editorial: Diaristic and contemplative, Claire Doyon’s chronicle of a family odyssey to the Mongolian highlands honors the beauty as well as the conflicts of the landscape. Transformative in its quiet simplicity, this luminous portrait of motherly love and resilience unfolds like a poem for her young daughter.

items.title: Pieta
items.short_synopsis: A man works as a loan shark who threatens those who can’t make their payments. One day a woman appears on his doorstep claiming to be the mother who abandoned him as a baby. At first he rejects her, but then gradually accepts her into his life. When she is kidnapped, he must track down the culprit.
items.default_editorial: Basing his film on the artistic representation of Mary’s devotion to her son Jesus, the ever-controversial Kim Ki-duk won the 2012 Golden Lion (beating The Master) for this intense, provocative psychodrama. Definitely not for the faint of heart, it sent the fest spinning.

items.title: Ploy
items.short_synopsis: Ploy is a highly detailed, erotic psychological drama in which three strangers are locked inside one hotel room. It starts with subtle suspicions and builds up to jealousy, as the appearance of a young woman triggers devastating consequences for a married couple.
items.default_editorial: Pen-Ek Ratanaruang’s psychological thriller premiered during the Directors’ Fortnight at the 2007 Cannes Film Festival. Ploy’ is a thriller unlike any others and you will have to watch it to feel it.

items.title: Portrait of the Artist
items.short_synopsis: A famous filmmaker works on his next film, which will focus on monstrosity. He is obsessed by the idea of finding a painting that will be central to the film and will crystallize all the power and beauty of monsters.
items.default_editorial: A treat for lovers of Parisian art museums, Antoine Barraud’s self-reflexive excursion into the innate monstrosity of artmaking boasts a grand cast. Besides cameos from Barbet Schroeder and Charlotte Rampling, in a rare acting credit, Bertrand Bonello plays a director who is at odds with himself.

items.title: Puncture
items.short_synopsis: The tattooed and drug-addicted townie has more than his share of personal demons, but can he straighten up long enough to lead a renegade safety-needle inventor to victory against a monopolizing medical supply corporation?
items.default_editorial: Based on a true story, Puncture has the visual panache of a 1970s conspiracy thriller. Boasting an electrifying performance from Chris Evans, whom Roger Ebert compares to a young Al Pacino, the film earnestly beckons us to condemn the heartless greediness of American medical supply corporations.

items.title: Ravens
items.short_synopsis: A hard-working farmer, desperate due to the harsh reality of his daily struggle, is determined to have his son take over the farm and continue his legacy. The mother tries her best to keep the family together, but with increasing horror the son witnesses his father’s psychotic behavior escalate.
items.default_editorial: A sensory depiction of rural life in 1970s Sweden, Jens Assur’s meticulous character study lays bare the generational differences that parallel the rise in new farming technologies. Unlike the birds that soar above the seemingly boundless horizon, a family finds itself in a cycle of stagnancy.

items.title: Santo vs. The Evil Brain
items.short_synopsis: A secret police agent is turned into a zombified slave by a mad scientist using a mind-control machine. To stop him, Lt. Zambrano creates a masked vigilante, Incógnito, who must restore Santo’s true self and foil the evil plans of the criminal mastermind, the Evil Brain.
items.default_editorial: Dressed in his signature silver mask, skintight pants, and metallic boots, the legendary Santo first appeared in this action-packed adventure, shot on location in Cuba before the revolution. As seductive cabarets give way to shadowy villain lairs, the film blends noir suspense and sci-fi with flair.

items.title: Santo vs. the Infernal Men
items.short_synopsis: Agent Joaquín recalls his latest mission while lying wounded in an ambulance: Joaquín has infiltrated a band of smugglers. When the villains learn the truth about him, they kidnap Joaquín’s fiancée. Santo comes to her rescue and fights the band.
items.default_editorial: In his second cinematic excursion, shot and released at the same time as Santo vs. The Evil Brain, our masked hero flexes not only his muscles but also his ingenious wits. As Santo deciphers coded messages and intercepts secret rendezvous, an intriguing atmosphere of espionage lingers in the air.

items.title: Santo vs. the Riders of Terror
items.original_title: Santo contra los jinetes del terror
items.short_synopsis: A bunch of angry lepers escape an institution, turn into outlaws, raid a town, and attract the attention of some local badmen who want to team up with them to wreak havoc. Enter a good hombre with a silver mask: El Santo, who shall restore peace.
items.default_editorial: Cowboys, step aside. Santo has come to the rescue in the Wild West! In this surprisingly straight-laced outing for the masked hero, director René Cardona brilliantly subverts Hollywood stereotypes of Mexican characters, lending a local flavor to the well-worn tropes of classic frontier tales.

items.title: Savage
items.short_synopsis: An exploration of masculinity and violence. A story of obsession and revenge, as a man tries to come to terms with a brutal, random attack and it’s consequences.
items.default_editorial: In this taut, high-wire revenge thriller, a disaffected press photographer struggles to reckon with the psychological wounds of a violent attack. Director Brendan Muldowney’s Dublin is a city of immense foreboding, ripe with the threat of inexplicable violence.

items.title: She Was Dania
items.short_synopsis: A teenage mother faces the challenge of raising a child alone while trying to reinvent herself in an unforgiving social environment.
items.default_editorial: Told through an intriguing central concept, Mexican director Dariela Ludlow presents a dynamic portrait of a young and hardworking single mother. Playing with the borders between fiction and documentary, as between life and cinema, She Was Dania presents a daring experiment in reinvention.

items.title: Surire
items.short_synopsis: Cinematic observational film about an environmentally protected salt flat exploited as a mine while the last native inhabitants watch from their run-down towns how the wealth is extracted from their ancestral lands.
items.default_editorial: In Iván Osnovikoff and Bettina Perut’s hypnotic documentary, the old and the new, the micro and the macro intertwine. After centuries of living in harmony, desert animals and the last descendants of Aymara culture find their bond threatened by the environmental exploitation of the Surire salt flat.

items.title: Tamara and the Ladybug
items.short_synopsis: Doña Meche, an old lonely lady, and Tamara, a mentally challenged woman in her forties, whose life was thrown into disarray after her brother left her alone, meet in their solitude in an endeavor to return a baby that Tamara found on a newspaper stand.
items.default_editorial: A promising new directorial voice from Latin America, Lucía Carreras devotes her third venture behind the camera to exploring femininity in this cross-generational drama. Set amid the buzzing streets of Mexico City, Tamara and the Ladybug is a resonant, sensitively-told tale of human bonding.

items.title: Tanner Hall
items.short_synopsis: A vivid peek into the private world of an all-girls boarding school. In a cozy, but run down New England town, the knot of adolescent complexity is unraveled through the coming of age stories of four teen-age girls.
items.default_editorial: Before Girl with a Dragon Tattoo, Rooney Mara starred in Tanner Hall, a beautifully shot tale of adolescence in an all-girls boarding school. The debut feature from co-director Tatiana von Furstenberg (daughter of the famous designer") and Francesca Gregorini also stars Brie Larson.

items.title: The Batwoman
items.short_synopsis: A wacky scientist is kidnapping wrestlers and extracting their spinal fluid to create a race of Gill Men. So, two cops call in Batwoman to investigate. But when her mission leaves the scientist horrifically scarred, he seeks revenge. His plan? To capture Batwoman and turn her into Gill Woman!
items.default_editorial: Riding the wave of the 1960s Batman craze, René Cardona’s seaside adventure introduces the thrill of Mexico’s lucha libre wrestling to the superhero canon. With outrageous outfits that rival the grooviness of Adam West’s cape crusader, fighting crime is no gloomy business, but pure sun-drenched fun!

items.title: The Gold Bug
items.short_synopsis: Feminism, Victoria Benedictsson, Leandro N. Alem, the Radical Party in Argentina, suicide, stunts, Edgar Allan Poe, the complicated relationship between low-budget films with a political aim and the film industry.
items.default_editorial: Moguillansky—co-editing with Mariano Llinás, co-directing with Fia-Stina Sandlund, and writing with both!—leaps from The Parrot’s take on documentary-making into an even more undefinable mixture of genres, connecting moviemaking to treasure hunting, national history and politics.

items.title: The Mansion of Madness
items.short_synopsis: The inmates of an insane asylum take over the institution, imprison the doctors and staff, and then put into play their own ideas of how the place should be run.
items.default_editorial: This hidden gem from Juan López Moctezuma, an overlooked director who also co-produced El Topo, is one of the weirder Edgar Allan Poe adaptations. The unsettling mood slowly grows into what can only be described as sumptuous carnage, as the film finds a strange beauty in its characters’ madness.

items.title: The Panther Women
items.short_synopsis: The Panther Women are a witch cult who resurrect their leader by sacrificing the descendants of the family which murdered him. As the cult seeks to kill the youngest descendent, they are taken on by fearless luchadoras Loreta Venus and the Golden Rubí.
items.default_editorial: More than an arena for male fighters, lucha libre films also welcome the _luchadoras _ into their cinematic ring. Conjuring a satanic cult of feline witches who wrestle their prey to death, René Cardona’s brew of occult magic, gory horror, and sultry eroticism is at once titillating and empowering.

items.title: The Student
items.short_synopsis: Teenager Veniamin studies the Bible obsessively and comes to believe that the world is nearing its end. His studies lead him on a path to religious fanaticism, drawing him into conflict with his mother, his classmates and his biology teacher Elena, who will alone challenge him on his own ground.
items.default_editorial: For his eighth feature, Russian filmmaker Kirill Serebrennikov (Leto) incisively targets fanaticism for a gripping satire of religious oppression. Featuring a tremendous lead performance from Pyotr Skvortsov, The Student mounts a barbed attack on the Orthodox church’s iron grip on everyday life.

items.title: The Third Wife
items.short_synopsis: In 19th-century rural Vietnam, 14-years-old May is to be the third wife of a wealthy landowner. Her new home seems idyllic, her husband favours her, and she quickly becomes pregnant. But trouble is quietly brewing: she witnesses a forbidden tryst that sparkles a chain reaction of misfortunes.
items.default_editorial: In this sensual debut from Ash Mayfair, the pastoral sumptuousness of rural life in feudal Vietnam belies the systematic cruelty of patriarchal traditions and values. Brimming with forbidden yearning, the film’s portrayal of women’s subjugation remains startlingly relevant in our contemporary times.

items.title: The Untamed
items.short_synopsis: A meteorite crashes on an isolated part of a mountain. Meanwhile, at a nearby town in the Mexican lowlands, a young couple in crisis struggles to find themselves but cannot avoid destroying each other in the process. Something out of this world will come to alter their lives.
items.default_editorial: Amat Escalante followed the critically acclaimed Heli and Los Bastardos with this sci-fi exploration of sex, violence, and gender roles. Winner of the Silver Lion in Venice and inspired by Andrzej Żuławski’s Possession, The Untamed marries acute social commentary to tentacular, Lovecraftian horror.

items.title: Unit 7
items.short_synopsis: Unit 7 is a semi-official police detail with a seemingly impossible mission: kick Seville’s most vicious drug trafficking ring out of town ahead of a major international expo. As they slip outside the bounds of the law in the name of duty, two officers end up on opposing paths.
items.default_editorial: Unit 7 proves that even sunny Seville can pull off the shadowiest of neo-noirs. Dialed up to 100, this corrupt-cop thriller gleefully bounces from crime scenes and new-found celebrity to the rotten-core corruption of a criminal underclass, all unfolding in the shadow of Spain’s war on drugs.

items.title: X500
items.short_synopsis: Three young migrants from the American continent are confronted with the death of someone close. These traumatic events lead them to travel and physically change so as to survive while starting the long process of grieving.
items.default_editorial: Cutting between three settings—Mexico, Colombia, Canada—Juan Andrés Arango’s sprawling sophomore feature presents multiple stories of migration, each ambitiously interwoven and ambiguously connected. Confidently crafted, X500 proves a thriller reminiscent of the work of Alejandro González Iñárritu.

items.title: Cloud Atlas
items.short_synopsis: Across five centuries, intertwined lives reveal how souls are shaped and how actions echo through time. A fleeing slave helps an attorney in 1849; a composer in pre-WWII Britain struggles to finish his magnum opus; a genetically engineered worker in 2144 feels the stirring of consciousness.
items.default_editorial: Lana & Lilly Wachowski team up with Tom Tywker (Run Lola Run) for this fascinating big-budget adaptation of David Mitchell’s bestselling novel, situating its large ensemble cast—including Tom Hanks!—across many plots, genres, settings, and time periods. A divisive, yet undoubtedly ambitious epic.

items.title: Moonrise Kingdom
items.short_synopsis: In the summer of 1965, two 12-year-olds fall in love, make a secret pact, and run away together into the wilderness. As various authorities and a troop of Boy Scouts try to hunt them down, a violent storm brews off-shore, and the peaceful New England island community is turned upside down.
items.default_editorial: The wacky and hyper-stylized world of Wes Anderson has never been so rich and charming than in Moonrise Kingdom, in which his usual ensemble cast (Bill Murray, Tilda Swinton, Edward Norton, and the list goes on!) is reunited to track down two young lovers on the lam. With a soundtrack to die for!

items.title: The Room Next Door
items.short_synopsis: It has been years since long-time friends Ingrid, a best-selling novelist, and Martha, a war journalist, have seen each other. Upon learning of Martha’s cancer diagnosis, Ingrid rushes to her side and they rekindle their bond. With each shared memory, their connection grows.
items.default_editorial: Winner of a Golden Lion at Venice, the first English-language feature from Spanish master Pedro Almodóvar swells with luxurious colours and a spectral score. Channelling the ebb and flow of memory and grief with exquisite precision, Tilda Swinton and Julianne Moore make for a sublime duo on screen.

items.title: 13 Assassins
items.original_title: 十三人の刺客 | Jûsan-nin no shikaku
items.short_synopsis: Shimada leads a team of assassins in 19th-century Japan to kill the ruthless Lord Matsudaira, who is wreaking havoc against his own people. Hired secretly by a government official hoping to end this reign of terror, Shimada recruits the best samurai to set a trap for the lord’s faithful bodyguards.
items.default_editorial: Think the age of the samurai film ended years ago? Think again! Kurosawa may no longer be with us, but the insanely prolific Takashi Miike (Audition) delivers an old-fashioned samurai epic for an extreme 21st century, slashing its way across the widescreen frame with panache.

items.title: Man on Wire
items.short_synopsis: This Oscar-winning documentary depicts the “artistic crime of the century” in which French tightrope walker Philippe Petit performed a brave, illegal high-wire walk between the World Trade Center’s twin towers in New York City in 1974.
items.default_editorial: Recently adapted into a Hollywood movie starring Joseph Gordon-Levitt, this thorough documentary portrait of Philippe Petit and his collaborators remains as the definitive take on one of the greatest stunts ever pulled. A unique post 9/11 cinematic object and Marsh’s gift to the city of New York.

items.title: Neds
items.short_synopsis: Set in 1970s Glasgow, this film tells the story of a shy and intelligent young boy who, through a series of circumstances, turns into a NED—a non-educated delinquent. Attending a new school, he becomes increasingly violent and aggressive, all the while searching for a way out.
items.default_editorial: Scottish actor-turned-director Peter Mullan (My Name Is Joe) takes a raw and sensitive look at teen delinquency in 70s Glasgow in his award-winning third feature. Neds won two Scottish BAFTAs for Best Direction and Screenplay, and features bold, brilliant performances headed by Conor McCarron.

items.title: Rome, Open City
items.short_synopsis: In WWII-era Rome, underground resistance leader Manfredi attempts to evade the Gestapo by enlisting the help of Pina, the fiancée of a fellow member of the resistance, and Don Pietro, the priest due to oversee her marriage. But it’s not long before the Nazis and the local police find him.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Cannes Grand Prize and an Oscar® nominee, Roberto Rossellini’s neorealist classic is one of the defining works of Italian cinema. A tale of resistance and liberation that fastened its newsreel style to the traditions of melodrama, Rome, Open City’s influence would prove revolutionary.

items.title: The Garden of the Finzi-Continis
items.short_synopsis: The Finzi-Continis are among the most cultivated and old-established families in Ferrara, firmly rooted in tradition and part of the city’s Jewish intelligentsia. But, in the years leading up to World War II, the family is caught up in the politics of racial discrimination…
items.default_editorial: Italian master Vittorio de Sica helped usher in Italy’s famed Neo-Realist period of films with such classics as Shoeshine, Bicycle Thieves, and Umberto D.. But his career extended far beyond this style, and this majestic tale of an old, rich family in tumultuous times is one of his very best.

items.title: The Innkeepers
items.short_synopsis: During the final days at the Yankee Pedlar Inn, two employees determined to reveal the hotel’s haunted past begin to experience disturbing events as old guests check in for a stay.
items.default_editorial: Indie director Ti West followed the success of The House of the Devil with another visit to the American horror cinema of the 1980s. A crafty and fun haunted hotel film film shot for under a million, The Innkeepers is a ghost story that builds slowly, smartly, making much from its limited resources.

items.title: Séraphine
items.short_synopsis: Primitivist painter and outsider Séraphine toils as a maidservant in 1914 in Senlis, France. She harbors a secret passion for painting in the evenings, one that is discovered by German art collector Wilhelm Uhde. Taken by her enormous talent, Uhde becomes determined to bring her art to the world.
items.default_editorial: In a time when artist biopics have become homogenized, Séraphine is a heart-warming portrait of an artist and her unlikely scale to fame. Showing rather than telling, this venturous drama stands as a sincere ode to the fragile, yet transformative power of self-expression.

items.title: A Personal Journey with Martin Scorsese Through American Movies
items.original_title: A Personal Journey with Martin Scorsese Through American Movies
items.short_synopsis: Martin Scorsese explores the history of American cinema by focusing on the work of a number of highly influential filmmakers. In addition to examining pioneering productions by D.W. Griffith and F.W. Murnau, he looks at a variety of key directors, while featuring interviews with cinema luminaries.
items.default_editorial: Like having an intimate conversation with your favorite director about the movies, this acclaimed documentary offers a whirlwind tour through American film history. With his hallmark rapid-fire chat, Scorsese’s cinematic love letter is an inspiration (and a guiding light) for cinephiles everywhere.

items.title: A Summer's Tale
items.short_synopsis: Graduate Gaspard goes on holiday to the seaside. He’s hoping his sort-of girlfriend Léna will join him there, but as time passes, he welcomes the interest of Margot. When Margot encourages him to date her friend Solène, he complies. But when Léna turns up, Gaspard will have to choose.
items.default_editorial: Another gorgeously sun-drenched drama from New Wave director Éric Rohmer, this tender, often playful coming-of-age story captures the curiously mercurial nature of first love. One of his “Tales of the Four Seasons,” it stars Amanda Langlet, who played the titular character in Pauline at the Beach.

items.title: A Winter's Tale
items.short_synopsis: One summer, the young Felicie and Charles fall deeply, passionately in love. Five years later, after accidentally giving him a false address, she is raising his child and drifting back and forth between two infatuated men with whom she’s unwilling, or unable, to settle down.
items.default_editorial: The second entry in Rohmer’s “Tales of the Four Seasons” is a graceful exploration of love and faith, a romantic comedy with engrossing characters that will stay with you long after the end credits.  Life’s choices proliferate—and Felicie’s quest for the right direction is completely entrancing.

items.title: Afterschool
items.short_synopsis: Robert is a student at an elite East Coast school who accidentally captures on camera the tragic death of two classmates. Their lives become memorialized as part of an audio-visual assignment designed to speed up the campus-wide healing process. But the video results in an atmosphere of paranoia.
items.default_editorial: The ruthlessly assured debut from Antonio Campos, Afterschool is a narcotized study of detachment in the YouTube era. With echoes of Michael Haneke and Gus Van Sant, Campos forges a style marked by its disquieting distance, capturing the deadening moral and emotional effects of a life lived online.

items.title: Around a Small Mountain
items.short_synopsis: French maestro Jacques Rivette directs Jane Birkin in this comedy-drama about a woman who returns to a small provincial circus.
items.default_editorial: The very last film by Jacques Rivette, the most consistently underrated of the French New Wave critics-turned-filmmakers (a group which includes François Truffaut and Jean-Luc Godard), Around a Small Mountain is a wry, gentle gem starring 60s icon Jane Birkin.

items.title: Daddy Longlegs
items.short_synopsis: A swan song to excuses and responsibilities, to fatherhood and self-created experiences, and to what it’s like to be truly torn between being a child and being an adult.
items.default_editorial: Long before their outstanding excursion into genre filmmaking with 2017’s Good Time, the Safdie brothers crafted this dramatic powder keg regarding a troubled father. Daddy Longlegs moves with a rare energy, perceptivity, and warmth in its complex examination of (and even tribute to) fatherhood.

items.title: Drowning by Numbers
items.short_synopsis: A curious tale of three women of the same name, whose solidarity for one another brings about three copy-cat drownings. Their husbands are the victims and the motive is dissatisfaction. The women are confident that their crimes will not be punished because they have in tow a coroner who loves them.
items.default_editorial: In another collaboration between cinematographer Sacha Vierny, composer Michael Nyman and the painstakingly attentive and avant-garde Peter Greenaway, this wryly comic, exceedingly clever mystery film forms the perfect puzzle. Intricate and elusive, a dark drama that’s still hugely playful.

items.title: Henry Fool
items.short_synopsis: Simon is a garbage man living a miserable life until he meets Henry Fool, a mysterious writer working on a major piece of literature. Henry convinces Simon to write in a journal and learns that he is a poetic prodigy. When Simon becomes a controversial sensation, Henry turns to Simon for help.
items.default_editorial: American independent filmmaker Hal Hartley culminated his bravura run of ’90s greats with this droll, bawdy epic which took the Best Screenplay award at Cannes. Starring the wondrous Parker Posey, Henry Fool is a singularly stylised fable that existentially ponders the value of an artistic life.

items.title: Howl
items.short_synopsis: San Francisco, mid ’50s. Poet Allen Ginsberg lives with fellow writers Jack Kerouac and Neal Cassady. He is about to publish Howl, an electrifying poem which will make him a cultural icon and define the soon-to-be Beat Generation. But soon after its release, Ginsberg is put on trial for obscenity.
items.default_editorial: Poetic revolutions and societal transgressions course throughout this hybrid biopic of the iconic Allen Ginsberg. Mixing courtroom drama, found footage, and swirling animation, LGBTQ+ duo Rob Epstein and Jeffrey Friedman channel a jazzy, Beatnik energy into an exhilarating homage to the epic Howl.

items.title: Joy Division
items.short_synopsis: An account of the musical journey and ongoing legacy of Joy Division, the influential Manchester post-punk rock band of the late 1970s, featuring interviews with the surviving band members (now known as New Order), never-before-seen live performance footage, and newly discovered audio tapes.
items.default_editorial: Documentarian Grant Gee reveals the mystical power of Joy Division in this extensive documentary on the rock band who played not for fame but from necessity. A brilliant insight into the youth punk culture of Britain, it is an essential watch for anyone curious about this musical phenomenon.

items.title: Our Life
items.short_synopsis: Claudio is a young construction worker who lives happily with his pregnant wife Elena. One day at the construction site, he discovers the corpse of an illegal Romanian worker, but decides not to report the discovery for fear he’ll be out of a job. Claudio’s life suddenly takes an unexpected turn.
items.default_editorial: A former assistant director to Italian auteur Nanni Moretti, Daniele Luchetti followed up his moving My Brother Is an Only Child with this turbulent portrait of Roman suburban life. Featuring a ravishing performance from actor Elio Germano, Our Life is an inspired piece of social realist cinema.

items.title: Patti Smith: Dream of Life
items.short_synopsis: Capturing both Patti Smith’s charged live performances and her informal interactions with friends and collaborators including Philip Glass, this documentary is also a touching tale of survival, detailing as it does the artist’s recovery from the unexpected deaths of her husband and her brother.
items.default_editorial: This all-encompassing, award-winning documentary gives us a chance to discover the music icon Patti Smith behind closed doors. A very special portrait of a very special artist, this appropriately unconventional film was shot over 11 years and offers a vivid, often off-the-cuff insight into a legend.

items.title: Perceval
items.short_synopsis: Filled with wonder at the sight of shining armor of a group of knights he has mistaken for angels, naive Perceval immediately solves the mystery of his destiny: he will become one of King Arthur’s knights. Valiant astride his horse, he rides from one ordeal to another, obsessed with a dream.
items.default_editorial: In many ways a departure for Rohmer, Perceval is a colorful, period-drama retelling of Chrétien de Troyes’s 12th-century Arthurian romance. The stylized splendor of the sets; strange, mythic cadences of speech; and flourishes of dry, Rohmerian humor vividly transpose the Medieval to the present day.

items.title: Potiche
items.short_synopsis: Suzanne is the elegant housewife of the industrialist and iron fist Pujol. When his workers go on strike, she steps in to manage the factory and proves to be competent. However, her new role throws her back in touch with union leader Babin, a romantic fling from the past that still has sparks.
items.default_editorial: François Ozon dives into delightful satire with this pastiche of 70s bourgeois chauvinism which evolves into a burlesque comedy of female empowerment! With Catherine Deneuve and Gérard Depardieu playing attracted opposites, Potiche indulges in a hilarious camp portrait of class conflict mayhem.

items.title: Prospero's Books
items.short_synopsis: Prospero is a magician who gets to keep only a small fragment of his enormous library when he is exiled with his daughter to an enchanted island. As Prospero describes the books he loves, visions begin to unfold. However, problems arise when Prospero’s daughter falls in love with the wrong man.
items.default_editorial: Spurred on by star John Gielgud and brought to life by Peter Greenaway, this is Shakespeare’s The Tempest interpreted as pure avant-garde cinema: an intense, opulent mash-up of different art forms and formal techniques shot through with baroque textures and vibrant colors. Greenaway, take a bow.

items.title: Shirin
items.short_synopsis: A film adaptation of “Khosrow and Shirin”, a 12th-century Persian tale, is shown to an audience of more than 110 celebrated actresses, all Iranian except for one from France. Though the film is invisible, the faces of the women watching the show tell the story as they gaze upon the heroine.
items.default_editorial: The final film in Kiarostami’s experimental video phase, Shirin is the story of Iran’s social oppression of women told purely through powerful reaction shots of famous actors as they watch an unseen performance. Includes Juliette Binoche, who would later star in Kiarostami’s Certified Copy.

items.title: Tamara Drewe
items.short_synopsis: When Tamara Drewe returns to the village of her youth, life for the locals is thrown upside down. Tamara – once an ugly duckling – has been transformed and is now a minor celebrity, beginning a comedy of manners with the townsfolk.
items.default_editorial: From versatile director Stephen Frears comes this British countryside comedy: a modern retelling of Thomas Hardy’s  Far from the Madding Crowd whose source material is a graphic novel! Transposing the romantic foibles of Victorian England to the modern day, Tamara Drewe is pure escapist fun.

items.title: The Pillow Book
items.short_synopsis: As a child in Kyoto in the 1970s, Nagiko’s calligrapher father used her body to write a birthday message in paint. Now grown up and living in Hong Kong, she seeks a lover who will use her body as a blank canvas. English translator Jerome reverses roles and becomes the subject of her penmanship.
items.default_editorial: Adorning the screen with words as well as images, Peter Greenaway expands our conception of narrative cinema in this mysterious tale—one of his most sensual films. Gossamer textures evocative of paper and skin layer across this sexy study of artistic expression, starring a young Ewan McGregor!

items.title: Trust
items.short_synopsis: Kicked out of home, rebellious teenager Maria meets Matthew, an unstable genius in electronics. But their life as an “ordinary normal couple” is less and less easy. Hal Hartley’s follow-up to The Unbelievable Truth.
items.default_editorial: Is any American independent filmmaker more criminally underrated than Hal Hartley? Part of the same wave as Richard Linklater and Todd Haynes (who debuted at Sundance the year Trust won the screenwriting prize), Hartley’s tales of American eccentrics are essential—and this dark rom-com is a peak.

items.title: Wittgenstein
items.short_synopsis: The life story of Ludwig Wittgenstein, one of the greatest philosophers of his time, is revealed in a series of sketches. A child prodigy who became a professor at Cambridge, Wittgenstein spent his life distancing himself from his privileged upbringing while coming to terms with his homosexuality.
items.default_editorial: When Derek Jarman was dared to film a script about a queer philosopher without showing a single buttock, he refrained from ogling sumptuous bottoms but maintained a mischievous outlook.
