After Wittgenstein’s own aphorisms, cleverness frolics with silliness in this delightfully offbeat biopic.

items.title: A Happy Event
items.short_synopsis: Celebrated French director Rémi Bezançon’s incisive, yet tender and humorous, third feature follows a young couple whose carefree lifestyle is interrupted by the birth of their first child, a happy event that also turns their world completely upside-down.
items.default_editorial: Based on Éliette Abécassis’s bestselling novel, Remi Bezancon’s endearing portrayal of modern parenthood approaches the challenges faced by young couples with a hefty dose of wit. When date nights are replaced by morning sickness and daily diapers, baby blues can be the ultimate poison for romance.

items.title: Broken Land
items.short_synopsis: In a desert landscape, a small community of Americans lives in the shade of the wall erected to protect them from illegal immigrants.
items.default_editorial: This piercing documentary from Luc Peter & Stephanie Barbey follows the inhabitants of a small town in the shade of the wall that runs along the U.S.-Mexican border. A film about migration in which the migrants themselves are a structural absence, Broken Land is a poignant study in fear and empathy.

items.title: Hannah Arendt
items.short_synopsis: Hannah Arendt is a portrait of the genius that shook the world with her discovery of “the banality of evil.” After she attends the Nazi Adolf Eichmann’s trial in Jerusalem, Arendt dares to write about the Holocaust in terms no one has ever heard before…
items.default_editorial: German luminary Margarethe von Trotta depicts one of the 20th century’s most important philosophers in this gripping biopic. The film focuses on Hannah Arendt’s cover of the Eichmann trial and the controversy surrounding her theory on the banality of evil, while using real footage from the hearing.

items.title: Majority
items.short_synopsis: Mertkan drifts through an aimless life in Istanbul, working at his father’s construction firm, loitering in malls with friends, and cruising the city in a 4×4. Wrapped in comfort and routine, he feels no urgency to confront the emptiness beneath it all.
items.default_editorial: Winner of three Golden Orange awards, this debut from director Seren Yüce is a powerful critique of Turkish patriarchal society. Majority treats its moral tale subtly, building emotional resonance through an outstanding and penetrating performance from Bartu Küçükçağlayan.

items.title: Me and You
items.short_synopsis: Lorenzo, 14, is a quirky loner. He plans to fulfill his teenage dream of happiness by hiding out in his apartment building’s cellar. To escape his parents, Lorenzo will tell them that he is going away to ski camp. But an unexpected visit from his worldly, older half-sister Olivia changes everything.
items.default_editorial: The final film from Italian arthouse maestro Bernardo Bertolucci (The Conformist, Last Tango in Paris) is an affecting adaptation of Niccolò Ammaniti’s coming-of-age novel. Gently tuned to an Italian cover of Bowie’s Space Oddity, Me and You poignantly explores the awkward fragility of youth.

items.title: Metrobranding: A Love Story Between Men and Objects
items.original_title: Metrobranding - O poveste de dragoste între oameni şi obiecte
items.short_synopsis: While people in Western Europe were used to choose between hundreds of brands, the communist Romania used to have a different experience: one brand for each basic product. Imagine the importance these “monobrands” acquired in the lives of those who made them and who used them.
items.default_editorial: Directors Ana Vlad and Adrian Voicu examine the secret lives of objects in this fascinating glimpse at the consumer industry behind the Iron Curtain. Iconic brands of communist Romania—the Relaxa mattress, Dragasani sneakers, the Pegas bicycle—are more than just objects to the people that made them.

items.title: Morgen
items.short_synopsis: Nelu, a man in his forties, works as a security guard at the local supermarket in Salonta, a small town on the Romanian-Hungarian border. Every day is the same for him, until the day he “fishes” something different from the river: a Turkish man trying to cross the border. Nelu agrees to help him.
items.default_editorial: The feature debut from Romanian auteur Marian Crișan is a gently observed satire on present-day prejudice, which examines how friendship can help bridge our cultural differences. At once a dashing buddy drama and a fish-out-of-water tale, Morgen won four awards at Locarno in 2010.

items.title: Silent Souls
items.short_synopsis: When Miron’s wife Tanya passes away, he asks his friend Aist to help him say goodbye according to the rituals of the Merya culture—an ancient tribe from West-Central Russia. As the two men set out on a long journey with her body, Miron relates details of his marriage, with unintended consequences.
items.default_editorial: Winner of the Critics Prize at Venice and highly acclaimed on its US release, Silent Souls is both a haunted love story and an existential road trip. Filling a compact 75 minute runtime with emotional richness and gorgeous photography, rarely does melancholy feel so beautiful or flow so easily.

items.title: Starbuck
items.short_synopsis: David Wozniak has reached his 40s without a single adult responsibility. Just when he decides to take control of his life, news arrives that after a series of sperm donations he made 20 years earlier, he’s fathered 533 children, of which 142 are determined to discover his identity.
items.default_editorial: With a high-concept pitch as his springboard—an enthusiastic sperm donor discovers he’s fathered 533 kids—Québécois writer-director Ken Scott dives into a winning series of set-pieces and sight gags. Deftly attuned to the nuances of genre, Starbuck brings new meaning to the term “coming-of-age.”

items.title: Stopped on Track
items.short_synopsis:
After he finds out his days are numbered, a man leaves wife and children behind, parents, friends, neighbours and yesterday’s lover, the people in his life.
Day by day a little farewell.
items.default_editorial: Made without a script, and with a supporting cast made up of real doctors and health professionals, this piercing feature from German filmmaker Andreas Dresen offers a rigorously unsentimental account of a brain cancer diagnosis. It’s a tough subject, but one handled with boundless compassion.

items.title: The Light Thief
items.short_synopsis: The main hero of the film is an electrician with a far greater effect on the people around him than his job defines. He is the last link in a huge energetic system and he becomes the binding bridge between the geopolitical problems of post-soviet space and the common people.
items.default_editorial: Reflecting on both change and corruption in Kyrgyz society, this acclaimed allegorical tragicomedy stars writer-director Aktan Abdykalykov as Svet-Ake, a small-town hero striving to improve the lives of his neighbors. Subtle and sensitive, The Light Thief is a gem of socially-conscious cinema.

items.title: Waste Land
items.short_synopsis: Vik Muniz travels from Brooklyn to his native Brazil and the world’s largest garbage dump, Jardim Gramacho. There he photographs the “catadores”—self-designated pickers of recyclable materials. The collaboration reveals both the dignity and despair of the catadores as they re-imagine their lives.
items.default_editorial: The story not of the world’s largest landfill—though Rio’s Jardim Gramacho is the setting—but rather that of those who make a living from picking its garbage. Through the work of artist Vik Muniz we find a vital portrait of the people on the margins whose lives are made from what we leave behind.

items.title: When We Leave
items.short_synopsis: When young Turkish-German woman Umay can no longer stand her husband’s ill-treatment, she flees from Istanbul with her five-year-old son into the arms of her family in Berlin.
items.default_editorial: Based on the real-life story of an honor killing that took place in Berlin in 2005, When We Leave marks the debut of actor-turned-director Feo Aladag. With subtlety and great sensitivity, Aladag mounts a potent study in cultural assimilation, mapping the various dead-end roads of forced conformity.

items.title: A Scene at the Sea
items.short_synopsis: Shigeru, a young deaf garbage collector, finds a broken surfboard in a trash can. Soon, he becomes obsessed with surfing. Despite multiple setbacks, Shigeru may finally have a chance to become one with the sea and the surfing community with the support of his longtime girlfriend, Takako.
items.default_editorial: An icon of Japanese pop culture, Takeshi Kitano is a multimedia artist who both writes poetry and paints when he is not making films or playing in them (Hana-bi, Zatoichi). A Scene at the Sea is one of his most beautiful works: a subtle romantic drama in the spirit of master Yasujiro Ozu.

items.title: Kikujiro
items.short_synopsis: It’s the summer holidays, and Masao is bored: all his friends have left Tokyo, and he spends his time alone while his grandmother works. One day, he meets Kikujiro, a loudmouthed old yakuza, and the unlikely duo embark on a road trip to find Masao’s long lost mother, whom he has never met before.
items.default_editorial: Japanese auteur Takeshi Kitano pays homage to both The Wizard of Oz and Chaplin’s The Kid in this hypnotic, heart-warming drama. Kitano clashes the tough guy yakuza image of his titular character with the bittersweet, yearning naiveté of childhood. Joe Hisaishi’s score is, as ever, extraordinary!

items.title: Mad Detective
items.short_synopsis: The film centers on Bun (Lau Ching-Wan), a schizophrenic, former police inspector who comes out of retirement to help a rookie detective (Andy On) solve a complex murder case, involving a missing colleague and a suspected policeman (Lam Ka-Tung) suffering from a multiple personality disorder.
items.default_editorial: Ask a hardcore action fan, and Hong Kong’s Johnnie To is one of the most talented filmmakers working today.  His latest, Blind Detective, was a favorite at Cannes, where it had a midnight screening.  Check out its “mad” predecessor—a perfect introduction to To’s widescreen brilliance!

items.title: Nobody Knows
items.original_title: 誰も知らない | Dare mo shiranai
items.short_synopsis: A twelve-year-old boy must care for his three younger siblings when their irresponsible mother leaves them with very little money in their Tokyo apartment When the money runs out, the children are forced to do whatever it takes to ensure they have food and hide the secret of their abandonment.
items.default_editorial: At just 14 years old, Yūya Yagira became the youngest person to win Best Actor in Cannes for this heartbreaking masterpiece from Hirokazu Koreeda. Unsentimental, but told with boundless empathy and compassion, Nobody Knows lowers its gaze for an unflinching, child’s-eye view of neglect and survival.

items.title: The Beat That My Heart Skipped
items.original_title: De battre mon coeur s'est arrêté
items.short_synopsis: Tom is 25 and seems to be following in the tracks of his father, a corrupted real estate agent. But an unexpected encounter brings him to think he could be the talented solo pianist he always wanted to be, as his mother was. He keeps working in real estate but starts preparing for an audition.
items.default_editorial: The dextrous Jacques Audiard (A Prophet) grabs the American crime film by the collar and gives it a very French twist in this dazzling remake of James Toback’s Fingers. The result is an irresistible cocktail of loose rhythms and tightly wound men, conjuring Paris’s fatalistic crime underworld.

items.title: The Death of Mr. Lăzărescu
items.short_synopsis: After suffering terrible headaches and stomach cramps, Mr. Lăzărescu, a lonely 63 year-old man, calls for an ambulance, beginning one man’s hellish journey through Bucharest hospitals in search of proper medical care. As the night unfolds, his health starts to deteriorate fast.
items.default_editorial: Two years before his compatriot Cristian Mungiu won the Palme d’Or, Cristi Puiu won a prize at Cannes for this ingenious 21st-century classic, a key film from the Romanian New Wave. A pitch-black and Kafkaesque contemporary comedy, it reveals the myriad nuances involved in the quest for human care.

items.title: Tony Takitani
items.short_synopsis: Tony Takitani seems to find emotions illogical and immature. When he falls for Eiko, his life changes. But Eiko has an all-consuming obsession: designer clothes.  Based on a short story by Haruki Murakami. Music by Ryuichi Sakamoto.
items.default_editorial: Based on the work of acclaimed Japanese author Haruki Murakami, this exquisitely lyrical, deceptively simple, and frequently funny film won big at Locarno in 2005, got picked up by Sundance, and landed in theaters to critical acclaim.  It remains a triumph of the loveliest, tenderest melancholy.

items.title: Triad Election
items.original_title: 黑社會: 以和爲貴 | Hak se wui: Yi wo wai kwai
items.short_synopsis: As election time nears, current Triad chairman Lok faces competition from his godsons. At the same time, Jimmy looks to increase his business relations with mainland China.
items.default_editorial: One of Hong Kong director Johnnie To’s masterpieces: a gangster film, as well as a sequel that boldly stands on its own. Following the nail-biting electoral process within a triad gang, Election 2 is a deceptive yet welcome reminder that all gangster films are political.

items.title: A Cup of Turkish Coffee
items.short_synopsis: An old woman and her granddaughter sit around a table and go through old family photographs. The old woman tries to resist looking at these pictures, yet she cannot resist what the past evokes.
items.default_editorial: Memory steeps like coffee in this animated reverie, where personal and national histories blur. A lyrical act of remembrance, the politically charged A Cup of Turkish Coffee draws power from what’s unsaid, illustrating generational traumas with quiet, pointed grace.

items.title: A Family Film
items.short_synopsis: Set in 1970s Istanbul, A Family Film captures the everyday life of a family through Super 8mm home movies, with the mother’s narration guiding viewers through their shared memories and moments.
items.default_editorial: A sun-dappled reverie on fleeting summers spent with family, Uğur Bayazıt’s found footage film captures the warmth and fragility of memory. Guided by a mother’s voice and echoes of the 1970s, this tender short bittersweetly evokes a place and a moment through the aching shimmer of old film stock.

items.title: A Funny Man
items.short_synopsis: Comedian Dirch Passer has found himself in perennial loneliness after a fast-tracked rise to fame. He struggles between his own desire to gain critical respect and servicing the audience’s needs. His talent is both a blessing and a curse…
items.default_editorial: If you don’t know who Dirch Passer is, now is the perfect time to find out! Martin Zandvliet’s entertaining and insightful portrait of the beloved Danish performer injects the typical biopic with some much needed flare. Beautifully shot and acted, A Funny Man is a colourful look into showbiz.

items.title: A Hero of Our Time
items.short_synopsis: Mert, an immature man in his thirties, lives in Istanbul but must travel to a small northeastern town for his father’s funeral. Over three days, as he avoids problems and confronts tragicomic events, he’s forced to face the growing cracks in his life and undergo a sudden, intense transformation.
items.default_editorial: A wry, deadpan critique of modern malaise, A Hero of Our Time examines a self-absorbed antihero adrift in a Black Sea village. With quiet humor and piercing insight, newcomer director Miraç Atabey captures the struggles of a generation and the absurdity of its inertia.

items.title: A Long Journey Into the Truth of Cinema: Necip Sarıcı
items.original_title: Si̇nema Haki̇kati̇ni̇n İçi̇nde Uzun Bi̇r Yolculuk: Neci̇p Sarıcı
items.short_synopsis: Necip Sarıcı began his cinema journey at a young age as a projectionist and worked as a sound engineer on hundreds of films at Lale Film Studio throughout his career. He also produced many films, including The Well (1968) and Oh Beautiful Istanbul (1982).
items.default_editorial: A master of sound and a living archive, Necip Sarıcı’s legacy is inseparable from the pulse of Yeşilçam. For over 70 years, his work has woven the auditory fabric of Turkish cinema, blending technical brilliance with an unparalleled historical awareness, preserving both the art and its memory.

items.title: A Magnificent Haunting
items.short_synopsis: Pietro is a young, gay pastry chef. He decides to leave Sicily and move to Rome in order to pursue his dream of becoming an actor. In Rome, he has to built his own support system in order to cope with setbacks and success.
items.default_editorial: Elio Germano charms as the hapless aspiring actor at the center of this unusual ghost story, an oddball reckoning with the past. With comic irreverence and a healthy dose of supernatural phenomena, petty grievances and painful questions of betrayal are tackled daringly, all at once.

items.title: A Perfect Day
items.short_synopsis: A jealous and violent bodyguard can’t accept his ex-wife’s abandonment.
items.default_editorial: Breaking from the romantic dramas and comedies that largely define his career, this hard-hitting film from Ferzan Özpetek maintains his usual focus on a cross section of contemporary Italian society in all its complexity. In a maelstrom of intersecting subjectivities, tensions flare up and explode.

items.title: A Run for Money
items.short_synopsis: Selim is a shop owner in Istanbul. Selim is an affectionate family man who has devoted his life to his home and his work, and is known for his honesty and integrity. One day, Selim finds a bag full of dollar bills in a taxi. This brings a small crime and a big tragedy to him and his family.
items.default_editorial: Reha Erdem’s festival darling has quite the electric premise, finely capturing a family man overwhelmed by this new circumstance he finds himself in—a sudden windfall of money that leads only to ethical quandary, a crisis of conscience, and mounting paranoia.

items.title: A Season in Hakkari
items.short_synopsis: An urban Turkish teacher is transferred for political reasons to a remote village in the mountains near the Iranian border of Eastern Anatolia. He is welcomed with distrust, but during that harsh year the mutual cultural misunderstandings fade away.
items.default_editorial: Erden Kıral’s snowbound classic A Season in Hakkari, a poignant narrative of exile and resilience, resurfaces in a stunning restoration. Adapted from Ferit Edgü’s poetic novella, this 1983 Berlinale triumph, once suppressed in its homeland, captures the scorching ethnic tensions of eastern Turkey.

items.title: A Special Day
items.short_synopsis: On a special day in 1938, all of Rome is attending a parade celebrating Hitler’s meeting with Mussolini. A working-class housewife, left alone to tend to household duties, meets the only person not attending the parade, a liberal radio broadcaster, and the two forge an unexpectedly close friendship.
items.default_editorial: Set over the course of a single hot day in Rome, this Golden Globe winner is Ettore Scola’s romantic epic, shot in splendid muted colors. A passion struck between ideological and sexual opposites poignantly reveals the brainwashing propaganda of fascist Italy and an ultimately universal humanity.

items.title: A Strange Sight To Behold: The Van Lake Monster
items.original_title: Seyirlik Bir Gariplik: Van Gölü Canavarı
items.short_synopsis: Gaining mainstream attention in the 1990s, the Lake Van Monster became a lasting symbol of the city. This short documentary examines the phenomenon with a critical eye.
items.default_editorial: Through the shifting reflections of Anatolia’s Lake Van, debutant director Behçet Güleryüz meditates on folklore and the human need to impose meaning on the unknown. Excavating the cultural and historical currents behind belief, the film questions how legends take root and why they endure.

items.title: Aaahh Belinda
items.short_synopsis: Serap, a young actress with a strong, lively personality and a special dislike for middle-class family life, takes part in a TV-commercial for a recently marketed shampoo, “Belinda”. She plays the role of a typical housewife called Naciye.
items.default_editorial: What if you wake up one day only to find out that you have become everything you ideologically despise? Atıf Yılmaz’s bittersweet masterpiece, which combines social commentary with surrealist comedy, both subverts the values of consumer society and the social roles attributed to women.

items.title: Absent
items.short_synopsis: Mert, a 30-year-old male, is employed at an abandoned-looking amusement park. He is grappling with an internal duality, while sensing a lurking identity bent on undermining him.
items.default_editorial: Hair-raising fairground rides and signs that light up the night sky take on an ominous aura in this moody short. As an aimless young man investigates his own ineffable fear, the film teeters on the edge of paranoia, with uncanny images threatening to appear with each atmospheric frame.

items.title: Any Time in October
items.short_synopsis: A quiet companion to Reha Erdem’s 2006 film Times and Winds, this work continues his quest to translate the cyclical rhythm of the world into pure cinematic time.
items.default_editorial: A slow-burning reverie shaped by the tempo of wind, light, and silence. Continuing the sensorial lineage of Times and Winds, this short distills cinematic time into a tactile experience of the seasonal sublime.

items.title: Arizona Dream
items.short_synopsis: Axel gets caught up into the family car business when his cousin Paul coaxes him to come to Arizona to attend their Uncle Leo’s wedding. As Axel makes the decision to try selling Cadillacs, he meets an eccentric woman and her equally quirky stepdaughter. Their lives become inextricably intertwined.
items.default_editorial: Serbian auteur Emir Kusturica’s only American film is a surreal, unhinged deconstruction of the American dream. A ’90s postmodern classic steeped in cinematic references (starring Faye Dunaway, Jerry Lewis, Johnny Depp & Vincent Gallo), it delights in the absurdity of grand, unfulfilled ambitions.

items.title: As If It Could
items.short_synopsis: After realising her plant isn’t growing as it should, Olive leaves her home and goes on a quest to find new grounds to let her plant re-root.
items.default_editorial: Thick, simple lines; uniform blocks of color. At first, this film appears unassuming. Using the shapeshifting power of animation, artist Ada Güvenir soon changes that—split screens, elevators, revolving doors, and comic-strip panels multiplying and morphing where one rectangular window was before.

items.title: At Last
items.short_synopsis: On a seemingly ordinary night in Istanbul, a young couple are on the way to a friend’s farewell party. They soon begin to face the strenuous challenges of navigating their city, causing them to grow increasingly tired and agitated, questioning their own lives as the night progresses.
items.default_editorial: What begins in stillness soon ruptures in Resmiye Emir’s tightly wound short, as a relationship buckles under the weight of grievances and a city’s unrelenting pace. In the shadows of a place that demands much and offers little, love and resentment bleed together in glances and haunting silences.

items.title: Athlete
items.short_synopsis: Hatice, a young and ambitious weightlifter living with her unemployed mother, aims to win the lifetime allowance provided to athletes who win medals in international competitions. In her pursuit of success, she decides to use an unconventional doping technique at the world championships.
items.default_editorial: A probing study of how women athletes navigate power, precarity, and the politics of the body, Semih Gülen and Mustafa Emin Büyükcoşkun’s clear-eyed debut Athlete frames strength as both burden and battleground, offering an unflinching look at what ambition asks of flesh.

items.title: Avarya
items.short_synopsis: Embarked on a spaceship in the hope of finding a new habitable planet, the human is trapped in his own ship after the robot overseer finds every single candidate planet unsuitable. Eventually, the human finds a way out, but that will only reveal a dark secret.
items.default_editorial: A man in search of a new home becomes a prisoner of logic in Gökalp Gönen’s stark sci-fi parable. Rendered in shadowy, metallic tones, Avarya explores the illusion of progress and the horror of a system that protects by preventing freedom, raising unsettling questions about the cost of survival.

items.title: Ayka
items.short_synopsis: Ayka is a young Kyrgyz girl that lives and works illegally in Moscow. After giving birth to her son she leaves him in hospital as she cannot afford to raise a child. Some time later, however, her motherly yearning leads her to desperate attempts of finding the abandoned child.
items.default_editorial: Following his feature debut Tulpan, Kazakhstani director Sergey Dvortsevoy’s tense and thrilling drama traces the fate of a runaway mother through a wintry Moscow. Understated yet extraordinary, Samal Yeslyamova’s lead performance won her the award for Best Actress at Cannes.

items.title: Behind Open Doors
items.short_synopsis: A computer engineer, Gökçe, relocates from Turkey to Berlin only to realize her expectations of support from friends are misguided. After a long day, her perspective on her future in Berlin dramatically changes.
items.default_editorial: Set amid the bustle of Berlin, this indie gem casts light on the solitude of expats via a woman’s quest for home. Subtly capturing the emotional intricacies of millennial migration, Alpgiray Uğurlu’s debut feature reflects on the fragility of solidarity and notions of belonging in a foreign land.

items.title: Bergman: A Year in a Life
items.short_synopsis: Journeying through 1957—the year Bergman released The Seventh Seal and Wild Strawberries, made a TV film and directed four plays for theatre—a wealth of archive and contemporary interviews reveals previously untold stories and insight into Bergman’s life and character.
items.default_editorial: Focusing on a year in the life of the great Swedish auteur, director Jane Magnusson makes the case for 1957 as being Bergman’s extraordinarily creative year—he made The Seventh Seal, Wild Strawberries and was just getting started! A stimulating portrait of a complex and multi-faceted artist.

items.title: Between Delicate and Violent
items.short_synopsis: Can we see the violence of the painter’s hands in the brushstrokes of his paintings? Could cross-stitch be an alphabet of some sort?
items.default_editorial: Hands are instruments of creation and archives of trauma in Şirin Bahar Demirel’s tactile exploration of unspoken legacy, memory, and resistance. Connecting personal stories to collective human experience, the short’s poignant fragments use evocative gestures to trace enduring wounds.

items.title: Between Two Dawns
items.short_synopsis: After a worker is severely injured in their family business, Kadir is forced into making a moral decision, which will have an impact on his dreams, his family and the life of the injured worker’s wife.
items.default_editorial: Heralding an exciting new voice in world cinema, Selman Nacar’s assured debut is an intense slice-of-life about the power dynamics woven through a family-owned factory. Shot in the realist vein of Asghar Farhadi, Nacar brings to life the moral dilemmas of his characters with subtlety and verve.

items.title: Bicycle
items.short_synopsis: Firat and his father collect garbage to survive. One day, the young boy discovers a partly intact bicycle in the trash and begins dreaming of a life of play.
items.default_editorial: Applying a simple yet powerful style to weave an emotional story of a father and his son, Serhat Karaaslan’s no-budget film is an homage to Vittorio De Sica’s classic Bicycle Thieves. Without a single line of dialogue, the minimalist Bicycle manifests a compassionate way of looking at destitution.

items.title: Big Big World
items.short_synopsis: Ali and Zuhal take their first step into this big world committing a crime and it becomes impossible for them to live among people. A boy and a girl that were thrown out of the civilized world would live the entire human story from scratch.
items.default_editorial: In Big Big World, two runaways seek refuge on the fringes of society, where innocence collides with violence and fantasy. Reha Erdem crafts a raw, hallucinatory fable, part coming-of-age, part primal scream, set against a nature that offers no easy salvation.

items.title: Billy Elliot
items.short_synopsis: When 11-year-old Billy discovers a ballet class sharing the hall with his boxing club, he’s captivated by dance. Encouraged by his teacher, he pursues his newfound passion in secret, defying his working-class family’s expectations amid the miners’ strike in Northern England.
items.default_editorial: Pirouetting his way to a historic BAFTA win, a young Jamie Bell inspired a new generation of male dancers with his breakout role in Stephen Daldry’s full-hearted classic. Proving that art is for everyone, Billy Elliot leaps above rigid gender expectations and class stereotypes, one twirl at a time.

items.title: Birds of Passage
items.short_synopsis: In the Guajira desert in the 1970s, a Wayuu family takes a leading role in the burgeoning Colombian drug trade. Headed by feared matriarch Úrsula, the family discovers the perks of wealth and power. When Rapayet falls in love with Úrsula’s daughter, he must carve a role in the family business.
items.default_editorial: Doubling down on the national mythmaking of his mesmerizing previous film Embrace of the Serpent, Ciro Guerra expands the parameters of genre filmmaking with this chimerical follow-up. A poetic examination of Colombia’s narcotics trade, Birds of Passage is an oneiric, unclassifiable triumph.

items.title: Boiling Point
items.short_synopsis: On the busiest night at a top London restaurant, head chef Andy Jones faces mounting personal and professional crises. A surprise health inspector visit, high guest demands, and staff tensions push him to his limits as he fights to keep everything from unraveling.
items.default_editorial: Echoing the rambunctious, nonstop thrills and spills of a service industry shift, this nail-biting restaurant drama unfolds in a single, unbroken take. With a livewire lead performance from Stephen Graham, Boiling Point sets myriad plates spinning before crashing every one of them to the ground.

items.title: Bye Bye Turtle
items.short_synopsis: Five-year-old Inci wanders alone through the vast hilly landscape by the Black Sea. Her mother has just died. When she meets the adult Zeynep, she decides to follow her.
items.default_editorial: Wreathed in fog and steeped in stillness, Selin Öksüzoğlu’s debut unfolds in a landscape where time feels suspended. In this quietly poetic and subtly playful short, unspoken kinships take shape as memory lingers like mist, grief moves in silence, and each step forward carries the weight of return.

items.title: C'mon C'mon
items.short_synopsis: Radio journalist Johnny is interviewing children across the U.S. about their thoughts on the future. When tragedy strikes, Johnny must look after his precocious nine-year-old nephew, Jesse. Voyaging from Los Angeles to New York, the two forge a tenuous yet transformational relationship.
items.default_editorial: Joaquin Phoenix may be the top draw in Mike Mills’ heart-tugging melodrama, but he more than meets his match in his preternaturally gifted, nine-year-old co-star. Shot by Robbie Ryan in swoonworthy black and white, C’mon C’mon embraces vulnerability for an exquisite meditation on the ties that bind.

items.title: Cahide's Open Marriage
items.short_synopsis: Cahide and her husband Cahit Devekuşu visit İstanbul for the funeral of Mrs. Cahide’s hairdresser. Sick and tired of her husband’s lack of attention towards her, Mrs. Cahide decides to tell Mr. Cahit that she wants an open marriage after a young man shows interest in her.
items.default_editorial: With its vibrant blend of camp and burlesque, Cahide’s Open Marriage gleefully dismantles societal norms as it follows a woman in bold pursuit of desire. Director Ali Kemal Güven crafts a delightfully absurdist spectacle where life and death intermingle with flamboyant dark humor.

items.title: Children of the White Mountain
items.short_synopsis: We are at a village school in Anatolia during a cold and snowy winter. The village school located in the cemetery contains many mysteries.
items.default_editorial: A warm, humane portrait of a snowbound village school, photographer Yalçın Çiftçi’s debut documentary finds beauty in hardship and grace in routine. Blending documentary insight with lyrical composition, Children of the White Mountain captures the quiet resilience of forgotten places.

items.title: Collage
items.short_synopsis: As a girl grows up, her world starts to become more complicated. She notices lines appearing on people’s faces that she hadn’t noticed before. While trying to see the hidden lives in between her neighbors’ facial features, her own face struggles to ignore an unwanted line from her childhood.
items.default_editorial: Faces become emotional landscapes in this tender reflection on childhood and perception. As lines deepen—on others and on the protagonist—this evocative short animation uncovers how we carry hidden stories in plain sight, and how the etchings of memory quietly shape the way we see.

items.title: Confrontation
items.short_synopsis: Hızır loses his wife, Halime, who had been in intensive care for a long time. Their daughter, Hatice, learns from the nurse, Evren, that there is an unsettling truth behind her mother’s death. Hatice is hesitant to reveal this secret to her sisters.
items.default_editorial: Buried truths come to surface in Filiz Kuka’s gripping debut, an intricate portrayal of sibling bonds. Mapping the unspoken tensions that affect a family in the wake of loss, this emotionally charged film is marked with silences, each harboring the weight of a confession waiting to emerge.

items.title: Cosmos
items.short_synopsis: Kosmos is a thief and a miracle-worker. He appears one morning in a tiny, snowbound border village where he is welcomed with open arms – on account of arriving just in time to resuscitate a small boy who would otherwise have drowned.
items.default_editorial: A haunting, enigmatic drama tinged with fantasy, _Kosmos_is perhaps Reha Erdem’s most accomplished work. Infused with what the great Turkish director calls his utopian vision of a human being, this is a profoundly sensual and philosophical piece of art.

items.title: Critical Zone
items.short_synopsis: Amir leads a lonely life. With his dog for sole company, he drives through the underworld of Tehran, dealing drugs of all kinds and healing troubled souls. He navigates the city streets aimlessly, following the directions of his GPS while getting high to escape a town with no future.
items.default_editorial: Shot in secret, this rebellious film is an intense hypnogenic trip punctuated by moments of drug-induced reverie. Fiercely conveyed through off-kilter camera placements and immersive sound design, the alienation felt in an oppressive society is pierced through with bright flashes of solidarity.

items.title: Crying Is Allowed Laughing Is Not!
items.short_synopsis: Due to the sudden death of his grandfather, Nejat (8) arrives at a funeral home for the first time in his life. As soon as they arrive, he is left all alone by his devastated mourning parents. Nejat finds himself in a great struggle of ‘not to get sad.’
items.default_editorial: A sharp, mocking gaze turns a house into a theater of absurdity in this short, where the architects of adulthood face their own unwitting comedy. Young filmmaker Oğuzhan Akalın teases out humor, unraveling the rigidity of identity with a playful smirk and a knowing wink.

items.title: Custody
items.short_synopsis: The Besson couple divorce. To protect her son from a father she accuses of violence, Miriam asks for exclusive custody, but the father says his son has been turned against him. The judge, unsure, grants a shared custody. Julien, a hostage between his parents, will do everything to prevent the worst.
items.default_editorial: The experience of divorce and its many ripple effects of dissolution are rarely seen from a child’s point-of-view in cinema. Xavier Legrand’s award-winning debut film does exactly that with this stirring tale of a family shattering amidst a domineering patriarch. A heartrending study of control.

items.title: Demolition
items.short_synopsis: Investment banker Davis Mitchell returns to work after losing his beloved wife in a tragic car accident. One day he comes across Karen, a customer service rep from the company. As his new friendship with the woman and her son grows, Mitchell finds the strength he needs to rebuild his life.
items.default_editorial: Two years before his critically acclaimed Big Little Lies, Montreal filmmaker Jean-Marc Vallée teamed up with Jake Gyllenhaal to tackle this engrossing tale of self-discovery. A true roller coaster from start to end, Demolition twists and turns while exploring the darkest corners of human grief.

items.title: Dinner in America
items.short_synopsis: Two misfits—an on-the-lam punk rocker and a young woman obsessed with his band—unexpectedly fall in love and go on an epic journey together through America’s decaying Midwestern suburbs.
items.default_editorial: Taking the pulse of contemporary America, Adam Rehmeier finds suburban residents flatlining in limbo or in the grips of a sustained panic attack. Coming from either side of that spectrum, Emily Skeggs and Kyle Gallner’s lovable rebels turn this raucous satire into a disarmingly sweet love story.

items.title: Do You Think God Loves Immigrant Kids, Mom?
items.original_title: Tanrı Göçmen Çocukları Sever mi Anne?
items.short_synopsis: Armenian families who migrated to Istanbul in 2003 struggle to provide education for their children at a school in a church basement, run by volunteer educators. This documentary delves into their daily lives, hardships, and longings in a foreign land.
items.default_editorial: Immersed in the struggles of Armenian immigrants, this touching documentary vividly captures the stark contrast between belonging and alienation. Through the eyes of children in pursuit of an education, director Rena Lusin Bitmez reveals the intimate realities of displacement and resilience.

items.title: Dolma
items.short_synopsis: Young Bora, who dreams of becoming a renowned actor, visits his parents at his childhood home, hoping for a peaceful dinner, only to find himself entangled in unexpected opinions and situations.
items.default_editorial: A nuanced reflection on the quiet tensions that affect familial bonds, this intimate short delves into how family expectations twist the search for self-fulfilment. Capturing the emotional complexities of unspoken divides, Dolma grapples with the strain of an uncertain future with sensitive insight.

items.title: Dormitory
items.short_synopsis: Forced to leave the comfort of his middle-class lifestyle at his father’s behest, fourteen-year-old Ahmet is sent to an all-boys religious dormitory where he must navigate familial expectations, his religious obligations, and the childhood to which he so desperately clings.
items.default_editorial: A poignant coming-of-age debut from Nehir Tuna, Dormitory transforms the political tensions of 1990s Turkey into an intimate study of faith, conformity, and the quiet rebellion of youth. A strikingly mature first feature from a distinctive new voice in Turkish cinema.

items.title: Dreams, Hopes and Rotating Dolphins
items.short_synopsis: A new technology pops up, now everyone can see who they were reincarnated from. Erdi tries to find out who he was in his past life while going through an existential crisis.
items.default_editorial: This entertainingly thoughtful short skewers our obsession with past lives and billionaire fantasies with deadpan wit. Turning existential dread into a sly joke, Adil Burak Aydın exposes the absurd lengths we go to to measure our worth, and the strange comforts we seek along the way.

items.title: Everyday It Gets a Little Easier
items.short_synopsis: 17-year-old Cemre has trained for years for the provincial swimming competition, but balancing exams, her boyfriend, and family disrupts her coach’s advice to rest. A sleepless night and a traumatic incident make her late, yet her surprising reaction to it reveals unexpected resilience.
items.default_editorial: A glimpse into quiet defiance, this understated film captures a young woman’s journey in overcoming everyday obstacles with grace and resolve. Each moment reveals her vulnerability as well as her unyielding spirit, and showcases strength flourishing against a world that often demands surrender.

items.title: Facing Windows
items.short_synopsis: Giovanna has been married to her devoted husband for nine years. She carries the responsibility for the whole family. The strain of this begins to show when her overly considerate husband adds another burden by bringing home an elderly amnesiac, a man with a painful past…
items.default_editorial: Fantasy and memory intertwine in this emotional drama that engages both the heart and the mind. With graceful command over a surprising story, Ferzan Özpetek follows a woman finding her way through a labyrinth of intense desire, profound love, and the responsibilities we all have to care for others.

items.title: Fail Better
items.short_synopsis: An ambitious director strives to make a film under Turkey’s challenging conditions. After its completion, the film faces censorship, suppression, and banning. What purpose does such prohibition serve? For what reasons, by whom, and why can a film be silenced?
items.default_editorial: A bold meditation on artistic struggle and the cost of defiant creativity, Aydın Orak’s self-reflexive story confronts the forces that stifle expression. With unflinching honesty, it reveals the unyielding pursuit of truth, and becomes a testament to resilience in the face of relentless opposition.

items.title: Faruk
items.short_synopsis: Faruk, in his nineties, becomes the protagonist in his daughter’s film about the impending demolition of his Istanbul home. Attending management meetings to delay it, the lines between reality and fiction blur.
items.default_editorial: Aslı Özge crafts a playfully tender ode to her aging father and the ever-changing scenery of Istanbul. This heartfelt exploration of mortality, gentrification, and familial bonds brims with wit and warmth, revealing the quiet vitality in life’s final chapters and our enduring connections to home.

items.title: Fasten Your Seatbelts
items.short_synopsis: Elena balances the demands and rewards of intimacy over thirteen years of passion, friendship, and heartache with the two great loves of her life.
items.default_editorial: This sensitive drama swaps romantic clichés for a raw portrayal of love as an ever-changing connection. Taking us inside a tumultuous relationship, Fasten Your Seatbelts alternates between a long view on its characters’ lives and a keen attention to the details that ultimately matter the most.

items.title: Faust
items.short_synopsis: Faust, a learned and prayerful alchemist who is struggling with his faith amidst a devastating plague, is offered the power to cure and the gift of youth…in exchange for his soul. An adaptation of Goethe’s iconic eponymous novel.
items.default_editorial: Among the crowning achievements of German silent cinema, F.W. Murnau’s baroque fantasy epic is a canny marriage of cinematic modernism and ancient awe. Framed in dualistic chiaroscuro and brimming with boundary-pushing effects,  Faust is a magical work of sublime, cosmological grandeur.

items.title: Ferret
items.short_synopsis: A solitary human figure embarks on a symbolic odyssey of self-discovery and transformation. Naked and vulnerable, he emerges from the barren quarry, a place of raw, primal energy, and begins his silent pilgrimage toward the infinite horizon of the sea.
items.default_editorial: A meditation on identity and our connection to other beings, this experimental short delves into the tension between self-perception and transformation. Through enigmatic storytelling, Ferret immerses itself in the body’s complex relation to the earth, and culminates in a radical metamorphosis.

items.title: Fire at Sea
items.short_synopsis: Samuele, a 12-year old boy, lives in Lampedusa, a remote Mediterranean island that has become a major entry point for refugees into Europe. He lives simply, climbing rocks by the shore and playing with his slingshot, while nearby thousands of men, women, and children risk their lives for a new life.
items.default_editorial: A profoundly haunting film, this Oscar® nominee moves beyond headline caricature to paint a remarkable portrait of life on a Mediterranean island and the efforts of the migrants that hope to reach it. Another ground-breaking work from Rosi as the first documentary to win the Golden Bear at Berlin!

items.title: For the Blinds
items.short_synopsis: In a world of parallel realities, individuals live briefly as a single character, with memories erased and rewritten to maintain the illusion of permanence. As identities shift and cities mutate, people unknowingly drift through ever-changing streets, clinging to lives that were never truly theirs.
items.default_editorial: Conjuring visions of erased pasts and fabricated selves, Ozan Adam’s otherworldly film sees time, voice, and image slip out of sync. A cinematic palimpsest of invention, it pulses with the strangeness and unease of a dream that, on waking, becomes difficult to place.

items.title: Fractal: Money Man
items.short_synopsis: Caner’s life changes when he suggests an unethical idea during a business meeting, manipulated by aggressive businessmen. As he begins to profit, he rejects losing his humanity, facing backlash from others who have already succumbed in this bleak world.
items.default_editorial: A hallucinatory take on corporate dystopia, this surreal short laces psychedelic animation with biting irony. Transforming the workplace into a nightmare arena where humans are reduced to profit-generating objects, director Zahid Çetinkaya confronts the absurdities of late capitalism.

items.title: Gabbeh
items.short_synopsis: A gabbeh—an intricately-designed folkloric carpet picturing a man and a woman riding away on horseback—is the prized possession of a nomadic elderly couple. When they sit to wash it on the bank of a creek, it begins recounting the story of the courtship of a young woman by a stranger from the clan.
items.default_editorial: Circling around a marriage plot in which a father fabricates obstacles to defer his daughter’s desires, Mohsen Makhmalbaf’s acclaimed film aches with feminine longing. Woven into vibrant rugs and sung across fields of wildflowers, said desire transforms into a majestic celebration of color.

items.title: Game
items.short_synopsis: A story about the games played around the world, leaving the future of humanity in the dark.
items.default_editorial: Drawing a causal line from miniature tanks in a child’s room to the military machinery of war, Turkish animator-filmmaker Önder Menken implies that toys which seem benign can corrupt the imagination. As the playful sound of scribbles turns thunderous, sketchpad drawings are shaded with violence.

items.title: Golden Shot
items.short_synopsis: Rusty machines living in their small houses imagine that the sun will come and take them to the sky someday. A small light keeps them alive and dreaming. But one of the machines wants to see the sun itself and he has a plan for that.
items.default_editorial: One machine dares to break from collective reverie in this short about a place governed by fragile rituals and fading dreams. Gökalp Gönen’s imaginative animation is an immersive meditation on longing, disillusionment, and the perilous pursuit of light in a dimming world.

items.title: Good Morning Mom
items.short_synopsis: At a very huge farm in the middle of nowhere, two sisters engage in a secret struggle with each other in order to win their mother’s love. The family is irreparably shaken on the day the sister gets stuck in the swamp due to an unfortunate accident.
items.default_editorial: A study in restraint and the quiet rituals of cohabitation, this visually rich minimalist drama channels the structure of classical tragedy. Focusing on two sisters caught in a subtle power play, it reveals how tension can thrive in stillness and how conflict need not raise its voice.

items.title: Hakkı
items.short_synopsis: Middle-aged HAKKI lives in a historical Aegean village with his family. He provides for them by selling statuettes in front of the nearby ancient city as well as guiding local tours. The region harbors business opportunities as touristic interest booms; however, HAKKI fails to catch the trend.
items.default_editorial: A tender, tragicomic tale of greed and ruin, Hikmet Kerem Özcan’s debut feature unearths the cost of ambition. In this cautionary tale written into sunbaked soil, what begins in quiet, simplicity, and warmth spirals into cold loneliness, as one fortune-seeker digs a hole too deep to escape.

items.title: Hâl
items.short_synopsis: A performer moves through a shifting space, searching for a pure state of presence. Their body struggles, adapts, and responds to its surroundings, caught between stillness and motion.
items.default_editorial: Movement becomes memory and lingers like a haunting echo in Hâl, which channels the intimate dialogue between body and space into a visceral experience. A meditation on impermanence, Gözde Karaoğlan’s film captures the traces that performance leaves behind—art’s last breath before vanishing.

items.title: Harem Suare
items.short_synopsis: As the Ottoman Empire comes to an end, an old servant spins a tale to keep the women in the Sultan’s harem distracted. The story is about Safiye, who first becomes the Sultan’s favorite concubine, and later the official wife.
items.default_editorial: Building on a symbiotic connection between reality and folklore, this lavishly designed drama pays tribute to the power of storytelling as a way to make sense of our destiny. Behind a seductive facade of luxury, Marie Gillain and Alex Descas’s unlikely allies must coldly scheme for love and freedom.

items.title: Harmonium
items.short_synopsis: Toshio’s ordinary life takes an ominous turn when Yasaka, an old acquaintance, is released from prison and in need of help. Toshio gives him a job and takes him in to live with his family. He soon regrets this decision, as Yasaka gradually disrupts the family before causing irreparable damage.
items.default_editorial: The great Tadanobu Asano (Ichi the Killer) stars as the insidious house guest in this deeply stirring, hypnotic thriller which slowly and assuredly unfurls the many questions of what composes and inspires evil. Winner of Un Certain Regard’s Jury Prize, Harmonium casts a rare spell upon its viewer.

items.title: Hello My Dear
items.short_synopsis: The documentary is named after Arkadas Z. Özger’s poem which had caused much controversy in that period. In this episodic poem considered to be in defiance of heteronormativity; there are references to his personality, his family, his relationship with society and his “unexpected” death.
items.default_editorial: Poet, revolutionary, queer icon. The poetry of Arkadaş Z. Özger was subverting heteronormativity among leftist circles of Turkey in the 1960s and ‘70s. Ulaş Tosun’s documentary follows the verses of this extraordinary figure to paint a complex picture of an era, as well as 25 years of his life.

items.title: Her First
items.short_synopsis: Two aspiring filmmakers embark on a two-year journey across Turkey, traveling 5000 kilometers to interview established women directors. Along the way, they capture their process of discovery and self-discovery, realizing the real journey has only just begun.
items.default_editorial: Her First pulls back the curtain on the Turkish film industry, exposing the labyrinth of challenges faced by women directors. Chronicling the journey of two emerging filmmakers, this layered documentary also reflects on a broader struggle against patriarchal norms.

items.title: Her Name Is Vasfiye
items.short_synopsis: Vasfiye, a provincial woman whose life shifts between men in Aegean towns, is portrayed through different narrators. With each perspective, her story changes, leaving the truth uncertain.
items.default_editorial: Who is Vasfiye? A woman, a fantasy, or a reflection of the men who claim to know her? Atıf Yılmaz’s hypnotic meditation on identity, memory, and power reveals a life through fragmented male narratives, disclosing more about those who define her than about the enigmatic protagonist herself.

items.title: Hesitation Wound
items.short_synopsis: Criminal lawyer Canan divides her time between mornings in court and evenings at her mother’s hospital bed. On the day of the sentencing hearing of a murder suspect whom Canan is defending, she must make a moral choice that will affect the lives of her mother, the judge, and the defendant.
items.default_editorial: Following a striking debut in Between Two Dawns, Selman Nacar’s award-winning, gripping study of a lawyer delves into themes of justice and ambition. Unraveling the tension of a life balanced on the edge of ethical and personal turmoil, the film masterfully examines the weight of our choices.

items.title: Hey There!
items.short_synopsis: While Istanbul is under lockdown, Felek and Kerim have their scheme set up: they plan to infiltrate the computers of people at home, pretend they’re the government, scare them with their “crimes,” and rip them off. But this is Istanbul, and people come in all types.
items.default_editorial: Turkish auteur Reha Erdem turns the limitations of lockdown into an exuberant musical comedy with humanistic overtones. Ingeniously intersecting the lives of nine people from different backgrounds,  Hey There! is a stunning meditation on feelings of guilt and the unbearable lightness of confessing.

items.title: How Did the Pandas Become Extinct?
items.short_synopsis: As dominant religions take hold, a once-vibrant Shamanist community quietly slips into decline.
items.default_editorial: With a light touch and a sly tonal shift, this allegorical fable captures the fading of spiritual traditions in mainstream belief systems. What begins as whimsy slips into elegy, as animator Halim Yentür traces cultural loss with disarming contradiction and quiet sorrow.

items.title: How to Blow Up a Pipeline
items.original_title: How to Blow Up a Pipeline
items.short_synopsis: Xochitl’s frustration with the climate crisis leads her to engage in symbolic acts of sabotage and property destruction. With radical determination, she assembles a crew of friends and strangers, each with their own struggles, to undertake a daring mission to destroy a pipeline in West Texas.
items.default_editorial: Applying the high-tension tropes of the heist film to a hyper-contemporary tale of eco-terrorism, this second feature from director Daniel Goldhaber is a taut, urgent thriller. With its ace ensemble of stars-in-the-making, How to Blow Up a Pipeline maps the now-or-never stakes of the climate crisis.

items.title: How to Disappear
items.short_synopsis: While Ekin (27) and Murat (28) return from a wedding at night, Ekin fails to see a bump in the road and his carelessness results in two flat tires. When they arrive at the repair shop with the help of a tow truck, Ekin and Murat see that the mechanics have set up a table with drinks and music.
items.default_editorial: A delicately contemplative short film that traces a woman’s quiet disappearance in a world that leaves little room for her. Director Tilbe Cana İnan’s enigmatic vision drifts through a male-dominated night, where silence is self-preservation and vanishing becomes the only form of resistance.

items.title: How to Save Asiye
items.short_synopsis: After receiving a letter from a woman named Asiye asking for help to save her, the President of the Associations Against Prostitution visits the brothel to save Asiye. However, she finds herself in a strange musical show.
items.default_editorial: Atıf Yılmaz turns the cabaret stage into a battleground where class, gender, and resistance collide in this radical reinvention of the musical. As the film dismantles the illusion of agency in a system where survival is mistaken for liberation, Müjde Ar delivers a fearless performance.

items.title: Huda's Salon
items.short_synopsis: A woman whose visit to a hair salon turns into a nightmare when she is blackmailed by its owner.
items.default_editorial: Based on real-life stories of blackmail and coercion, Hany Abu-Assad’s taut thriller taps into the fervor of paranoia that grips the West Bank. Charged by the entwined terrors of political persecution and misogyny, Huda’s Salon grapples with the plight of Palestinian women living under occupation.

items.title: Hysteria
items.short_synopsis: A film shoot takes a dark turn when the burning of a Quran throws the crew into turmoil. Caught in the crossfire of accusations, intern Elif is drawn into a dangerous game of secrets and lies and finds herself at the heart of an all-absorbing conspiracy.
items.default_editorial: The making of a film about racism becomes a mirror of its subject in _Hysteria_. Crafting a timely psychological thriller with sharp political undertones, Mehmet Akif Büyükatalay probes the uneasy ethics of art and the fragility of sincerity in a culture haunted by unacknowledged prejudices.

items.title: I Had a Dream You Won’t Understand Even If I Tell
items.original_title: Bir Rüya Gördüm, Anlatsam da Anlamazsınız
items.short_synopsis: In 1992, Tevfik Esenç, the last person speaking the Ubykh language, died as the Ubykh language disappeared from the world. Directed by Burcu Esenç and Cantekin Cantez, this documentary tells the story of the people of Ubykh and the disappearance of a language from the world.
items.default_editorial: This intriguing first-person documentary tells the story of a lost language while commenting on notions of identity, exile, and assimilation. Centered around the last person speaking Ubykh, this poetic and personal journey takes the viewer from Turkey to Paris, Oslo, and the Caucasus region.

items.title: Ice Cream
items.short_synopsis: Rojhat (11) has been living with his mother in a small village of Van. One day, an Ice-cream seller comes to village with his motorcycle. All children of village surround the ice cream seller. They all buy ice cream in exchange for eggs, copper wires, old objects they have brought from their houses.
items.default_editorial: Shot in the dusty town of Van in Turkey, Serhat Karaaslan’s enchanting short is a moveable feast, as the dynamic handheld camera chases after a group of boys running wild and playing football. The simple pleasures of childhood–like the taste of ice cream on a hot summer day–come movingly alive.

items.title: In the Fade
items.short_synopsis: When her husband and young son are suddenly killed in a bomb attack, Katja’s life is torn apart. A police investigation points to a pair of young neo-Nazis as the key suspects, but when a lack of evidence fails to fully incriminate them, Katja is forced to take matters into her own hands.
items.default_editorial: Diane Kruger (Inglourious Basterds) won the Best Actress award at Cannes for her powerhouse performance in this Golden Globe-winning thriller. Director Fatih Akın based In the Fade on a true story, crafting an engrossing and existential look at the survivors of terrorism.

items.title: International Departures
items.short_synopsis: Deniz has won the Greencard and is preparing to start this journey along with the sad, pessimistic, indifferent, angry, hopeful, and worried reactions of all.
items.default_editorial: Structured in fragments, this haunting short film turns the act of leaving into a quiet rebellion. In the spaces between presence and absence, detachment and intimacy, Erinç Durlanık gracefully captures a generation’s muted grief, hope, and estrangement.

items.title: It's Burning
items.short_synopsis: In Germany, an Arab family named Amal, Omar, and their son Ahmad encounter a man named Franz in a playground. Unfortunately, things escalate when he attacks Amal due to her headscarf. This leads to a court case, where everything changes.
items.default_editorial: A searing debut on racism’s corrosive effects, Erol Afşin’s It’s Burning confronts the violence embedded in systems and gestures alike. What begins as a single insult spirals into tragedy, laying bare the fractures of today’s Western world and the cycles of harm they perpetuate.

items.title: Jin
items.short_synopsis: A guerrilla lives in a cave and decides to escape from the organization. She finds some civilian clothes and goes down from the mountain to the city. However, the city is no safer than the mountain.
items.default_editorial: With a rifle on her back and nature as her only refuge, Jîn follows a young guerrilla fighter in flight from both war and patriarchy. Reha Erdem’s luminous, near-wordless tale unfolds like a fable: poetic, brutal, and achingly attuned to the wild.

items.title: Lâl
items.short_synopsis: Born from a word out of nothing, the creature must eat one of its own to survive. This word which the creature has managed to pronounce brings him friends, enemies, and new prey, although it’s difficult to maintain the balance.
items.default_editorial: A spark of language ignites both connection and destruction in this brutal fable of survival. Crafting a haunting allegory in which a creature’s first word unleashes a spiral of violence, kinship, and rebirth, Gökalp Gönen charts a cycle that is as primal, mythic, and unsettling as creation itself.

items.title: Last Nomads in Anatolia: Sarikecilis
items.short_synopsis: Sarikecilis are the last representatives in Anatolia of the centuries-old tradition of nomadism. Making their way to sea level in winter, and to the highlands in summer, they spend seven months of the year in transit, living off of the goats they keep.
items.default_editorial: In Last Nomads in Anatolia, Yüksel Aksu handles the delicate tapestry of nomadic tradition with an anthropologist’s curiosity. Charting the seasonal migrations of Sarıkeçililer, this poignant documentary creates a rich tableau of Anatolian culture caught in the inexorable march of time.

items.title: Les Misérables
items.short_synopsis: Stéphane has recently joined the Anti-Crime Squad in Montfermeil, in the suburbs of Paris. Alongside his new colleagues, he quickly discovers tensions running high between local gangs. When they find themselves overrun during the course of an arrest, a drone captures the encounter.
items.default_editorial: An electrifying portrait of a multi-ethnic society dealing with racism and poverty, Les Miserables makes a passionate case against police oppression. Catch this moving and invigorating Academy Award® nominee that also deservedly bagged the Jury Prize at Cannes Film Festival 2019.

items.title: Let the Sunshine In
items.short_synopsis: Isabelle is a successful painter living in Paris, whose apparent independence belies what she desires most: real romantic fulfillment. Isabelle reveals deep wells of yearning, vulnerability, and resilience as she tumbles into relationships with all the wrong men.
items.default_editorial: A Claire Denis romcom? We’re sold! Subverting fairytale tropes with fine irony, this wonderfully unpredictable take on middle-age female desire and the volatility of emotions stars an exquisitely mercurial Juliette Binoche—searching for love, encountering mostly disappointment. Oh, and that ending!

items.title: Leto
items.short_synopsis: Leningrad, one summer in the 80s. Smuggling LPs by Lou Reed and T-Rex, the underground rock scene is thriving ahead of Perestroika. Musician Mike and his wife Natasha meet Viktor Tsoi, and a love triangle soon emerges. Together they will change the destiny of rock’n’roll in the Soviet Union.
items.default_editorial: From Russian enfant terrible Kirill Serebrennikov comes this freewheeling snapshot of youthful rebellion in the underground scene of 1980s Leningrad. Set to a soundtrack of classics from David Bowie to The Sex Pistols, and filmed in stunning B&W, Leto is a rock ‘n’ roll musical like no other.

items.title: Loose Cannons
items.short_synopsis: Tommaso is the youngest son and soon-to-be partner of an Italian pasta tycoon. On a trip home from Rome, where he studies literature and lives with his boyfriend, Tommaso decides to tell his parents the truth about both his sexuality and his life plans. But his older brother Antonio ruins his plans.
items.default_editorial: Transplanted from native Turkey to Italy, director Ferzan Ozpetek (Facing Windows) flourished there and Loose Cannons is a prime example of his talents: an appreciative understanding of cultural and family dynamics, and attractive storytelling that moves naturally from comedy to drama.

items.title: Lost in the Post
items.short_synopsis: An experiment in the possibilities and impossibilities of communication, refuge, and love in the era of digital connection.
items.default_editorial: A fragmentary ode to longing in the digital age, featuring Elit İşcan. Erdem captures the static between screens and souls, where desire flickers, glitches, and floats untethered across invisible networks.

items.title: Lost in Transition
items.short_synopsis: The life of a family takes an unexpected turn when they recieve an official notice about a highway that will be passing through their son’s bedroom. And so begins the fantastic transformation of their house and life.
items.default_editorial: A haunting reflection of shifting identities, the quiet disappearance of an ordinary family into a changing city unsettles in this sardonic short. With storytelling craft and journalistic precision, director Pınar Öğünç questions what we sacrifice when we accept and normalize a new world order.

items.title: Manchester by the Sea
items.short_synopsis: After the death of his older brother, Joe, Lee Chandler is shocked that Joe has made him sole guardian of his teenage nephew. Lee reluctantly returns to Manchester-by-the-Sea. There, he is forced to deal with a past that separated him from his wife, and the community where he was born and raised.
items.default_editorial: One of the finest American dramas of recent years, this harrowing ensemble piece from Kenneth Lonergan is a visceral examination of grief. Michelle Williams is on career-best form, but it’s Casey Affleck’s shattering, Oscar®-winning turn as a father broken by guilt that proves impossible to shake.

items.title: Manhunter
items.short_synopsis: FBI criminal profiler Will Graham is called out of early retirement to assist on a deadly case involving a murderer known as the “Tooth Fairy”. After enlisting the help of imprisoned serial killer Dr. Hannibal Lecktor, Graham and the FBI are soon entangled in a menacing cat-and-mouse game…
items.default_editorial: From the master American filmmaker Michael Mann, Manhunter is a truly experiential foray into two opposing minds. Belying its 80s neon hues and (welcome!) pop music cues, the film grows into a complexly woven inquiry into the origins of serial murder and its amorphous relation with domesticity.

items.title: Me and the Other
items.short_synopsis: The game organized by a lonely, unsuccessful, and hopeless 35-year-old guy to talk to the woman about his problems will result in him facing his own disappointments and fears.
items.default_editorial: Buse Halaçoğlu’s atmospheric short examines the fragile, tense balance between self-destruction and renewal. Through a cyclical confrontation with inner fears and unfulfilled dreams, the film captures the struggle to transform pain into strength and to rediscover the courage to move forward.

items.title: Meeting Jim
items.short_synopsis: A journey back to the lifetime of Jim Haynes, “the godfather of social networking”, an extraordinary man, a self-proclaimed world citizen who grabbed with heart & soul the spirit of the 60s and continued to carry it throughout his life, making a strong contribution to the artistic scene of his time.
items.default_editorial: Jim Haynes is a counterculture figure of the ‘60s, a superhero whose special power was to get people together and establish real connections between them. Ece Ger’s charming portrait fits the man’s spirit perfectly: vivid, life-affirming, and affectionate. You should definitely meet Jim!

items.title: Memento
items.short_synopsis: Leonard Shelby suffers from acute short-term memory loss. He cannot to remember anything for more than a few minutes at a time. This makes things difficult when his one mission in life is to track down his wife’s killers. Aided by notes and tattoos, Shelby embarks on a journey down memory lane.
items.default_editorial: A murder mystery told through non-linear timelines, Christopher Nolan’s breakthrough film is now a fascinating example of a director discovering and refining career-long obsessions and techniques. But most importantly, Memento is endlessly inventive, perfectly calibrated, and emotionally rich.

items.title: Memory
items.short_synopsis: Social worker Sylvia leads a simple, structured life revolving around her daughter, her job, and her AA meetings. Her daily routine takes an unexpected turn when Saul, a figure from her past, follows her home. This surprise encounter will profoundly impact them as they open the door to the past.
items.default_editorial: Jessica Chastain and Peter Sarsgaard give heartrending performances in this intelligent drama of enduring traumas, clouded judgment, and best intentions. Directed with stark profundity by Michel Franco, the award-winning actors lift Memory from darkness to a place of rare warmth and understanding.

items.title: Mimaroğlu Remix Project
items.short_synopsis: A collection of 8mm film reels from İlhan Mimaroğlu’s archive—once tucked away in whisky boxes—has found new life through art. Over 30 artists transformed the footage into fifteen distinct audiovisual pieces, blending experimental soundscapes with contemporary video art.
items.default_editorial: Reverberating with the restless spirit of İlhan Mimaroğlu and channeling it into new forms, Mimaroğlu Remix Project is a collective homage to a pioneer of electronic music. Echoing defiance and boldness, these experimental works turn archival noise into a flickering politics of sound and image.

items.title: Mimaroğlu: The Robinson of Manhattan Island
items.original_title: Mimaroğlu: The Robinson of Manhattan Island
items.short_synopsis: Legendary electronic music composer İlhan Mimaroğlu and his vibrant wife Güngör migrated to the USA from Turkey in early 1960s. Using the couple’s personal archives, the documentary captures the career of İlhan as an edgy artist, and the power of their life-long companionship.
items.default_editorial: An extraordinary audiovisual experience that portrays a pioneer in the field of electronic music using analog tapes and old recordings. This subversive documentary about music, love, and immigration captures the authentic life of an expat couple living in New York in a politically charged era.

items.title: MimiRap
items.short_synopsis: Inspired by Reha Erdem’s film Big Big World, this collaborative work with his longtime cinematographer Florent Herry presents a looped video installation featuring Ecem Uzun performing a rap song written by Erdem.
items.default_editorial: Ecem Uzun’s hypnotic performance anchors this charged loop of rhythm and image, where cinema meets spoken word. A compact burst of defiance and lyricism, it finds music in repetition and protest in performance.

items.title: Mondays in the Sun
items.short_synopsis: In a Spanish port city, a group of former shipyard workers grapple with unemployment and fading dreams. As they spend their days sharing stories, searching for work, and clinging to dignity, their bond offers warmth amid economic hardship and social disillusionment.
items.default_editorial: Javier Bardem is a charismatic man thwarted by the blunt forces of capitalism in Fernando León de Aranoa’s award-winning drama. A compassionate portrait of jobless people struggling to find their place, this bittersweet film quietly celebrates the camaraderie that helps them survive.

items.title: Morî
items.short_synopsis: The only memory left to Mori from his father is the audio recording of the story he told him. Mori listens to this tale from time to time. One day, a new teacher comes to school. When Mori sees the teacher, he thinks he is his father.
items.default_editorial: In this meditative, delicate short, the quiet force of longing shapes the way that a young girl builds an inner world. A fragile echo of love resonates in the muted drift of winter, as the hope she carries within her becomes both her refuge and her calling.

items.title: Moses Without Rod
items.short_synopsis: The life of the writer, intellectual, spokesman of democracy, and activist Musa Anter is now a movie rich in metaphors and images.
items.default_editorial: Aydın Orak’s eulogy to a Kurdish man of letters who was assassinated in 1992 is aptly essayistic and poetic, evoking a state of being and thinking as much as a person. As crystalline images repeat and return across the film’s fragments, Moses Without Rod grows ever more mesmeric and spectral.

items.title: Mrs. Salkım’s Diamonds
items.short_synopsis: Durmuş and his wife Nimet immigrate from an Anatolian town, Niğde to Istanbul to have a better life and they start to live with Bekir. Bekir is an old friend of Durmuş from motherland and works as an attendant in a hostelry which belongs to Mr. Halit…
items.default_editorial: A landmark in Turkish political cinema, this piercing portrait of ambition, dispossession, and silent complicity confronts a buried national trauma. With rare courage, director Tomris Giritlioğlu illuminates the human cost of a dark chapter in history—one shaped by power, prejudice, and erasure.

items.title: Musa
items.short_synopsis: Director Zeki Demirkubuz runs into Musa, who sells bootleg DVD’s for living, and sees that his films are also on sale. Zeki Demirkubuz makes an offer to Musa.
items.default_editorial: In Serhat Karaaslan’s tender love letter to cinema, an imaginary confrontation between Turkish auteur Zeki Demirkubuz and a street vendor turns into a reflection on filmmaking and the city. A minimalistic short film with a keen eye for the details of precarious lives on the outskirts of Istanbul.

items.title: My Child
items.short_synopsis: What happens when your child comes out to you? In this feature documentary, parents of lesbian, gay, bisexual and trans-gender individuals in Turkey intimately share their experiences with the viewer, as they redefine what it means to be parents in this conservative society.
items.default_editorial: Directly facing the camera, Turkish parents of LGBTQ+ individuals are not only pouring their hearts out to viewers but also addressing those still harboring prejudiced views. Beautifully lifted by unconditional familial love, this powerful call for acceptance underlines the cruciality of community.

items.title: My Only Sunshine
items.short_synopsis: 14-year-old Hayat, no longer a child but not yet a woman, lives with her father and grandfather by the shores of the Bosphorus in Istanbul. Her father works as a fisherman but makes most of his money through shady dealings. Even more corrosive than the family’s poverty is their neglect toward Hayat.
items.default_editorial: One of Turkey’s top filmmakers, Reha Erdem, directs this transformative gem about the strength and perseverance of a strong, young heroine. It is a tale of universal contrasts—big city, pastoral riverside—and familial challenges told in equal parts lyrical poetry and harsh reality.

items.title: My Uncle
items.short_synopsis: The story of a man who realizes his passion for flying one day and descends into the desert 42 years later, as told through the words of his nephew.
items.default_editorial: A brilliant piece of personal filmmaking, Tayfun Pirselimoğlu’s melancholic yet ingeniously vibrant ode to his free-spirited uncle is a love letter to cinema and aviation. The narrative inventiveness of this romantic short film is fresh and galvanizing for every new generation of cinephiles.

items.title: Neredesin
items.short_synopsis: A farewell portrait built around the late artist Tardu Kuman’s sculptures and the voices that seem to emanate from them. An elegy rendered through sound and form.
items.default_editorial: In this sculptural elegy, memory takes form in stone and voice. A meditation on presence and absence, Reha Erdem weaves a tender farewell that blurs the line between stillness and spirit.

items.title: Neukölln Spiderman
items.short_synopsis: Facing the risk of deportation from Germany, Altay learns that he must present a valid reason to the immigration office in order to stay. On his way home, he encounters a man wearing a Spider-Man mask and, curious about his own valid reason, conducts a brief interview.
items.default_editorial: A young Turkish immigrant in Berlin, a masked drifter, and the fragile ties that connect them. In this playfully punk documentary, Altay Erlik turns a fleeting encounter into a vibrant reflection on urban life, class, displacement, belonging, and the fictions that keep us afloat.

items.title: Omar
items.short_synopsis: A Palestinian baker regularly risks crossing the West Bank wall to see his beloved Nadia. Alongside his childhood friends Tarek and Amjad, he trains for armed resistance against Israeli soldiers. During one of these crossings, he is captured and subjected to violence and humiliation.
items.default_editorial: Hany Abu-Assad’s various films have all handled the many complexities of the Israeli-Palestine conflict with great precision and sensitivity. Despite moving with the caustic speed of a thriller, Omar is no exception with its intimate sense of life under occupation and political struggle.

items.title: On the Shore
items.short_synopsis: After their father’s death, four sisters reunite at the family inn they inherited. Yasemin, Nilüfer, Defne, and Deniz, each with their own paths in life, come together on the same shore after years apart and swim in the sea together.
items.default_editorial: Old wounds resurface with the tide in Büşra Bilginer’s assured debut, which traces the ebb and flow of sisterhood with grace. Letting saltwater and time do the work of reconciliation, On the Shore frames the rhythmic returns of grief and memory with the serene beauty of the Turkish Riviera.

items.title: Once Upon a Time in the Future: 2121
items.short_synopsis: In the future, the earth becomes uninhabitable due to climate crisis and famine. The few survivors from colonies and start to live in underground blocks.
