According to The Scarcity Laws of the Young Administration which controls system, old generations must be destroyed in exchange for new lives.
items.default_editorial: Serpil Altın’s debut imagines a future where survival demands sacrifice, and motherhood becomes a dilemma shaped by law rather than love. Set in subterranean confines, this quiet dystopia questions whether inherited systems can still hold meaning when the future itself is in doubt.

items.title: Once Upon a Time Yeşilçam - Abdurrahman Keskiner
items.short_synopsis: This is a documentary from Mehmet Güreli about the famous producer Abdurrahman Keskiner, who took great strides in promoting our country’s cinema to the world and who is one of the shining lights of our cinema.
items.default_editorial: Multidisciplinary artist Mehmet Güreli crafts a vivid portrait of Abdurrahman Keskiner, a visionary producer whose unwavering belief in bold, ambitious cinema shaped Turkey’s film legacy. This documentary honors the courage and artistry that pushed Turkish cinema onto the world stage.

items.title: One of Those Days When Hemme Dies
items.short_synopsis: Eyüp works relentlessly under the blazing sun during a tomato harvest in southeastern Turkey, driven by the urgent need to settle an impending debt. After a clash with his supervisor, he roams the city in search of a radical solution.
items.default_editorial: A simmering tale of thwarted rage and everyday absurdity, One of Those Days When Hemme Dies reveals the tragicomic rhythms of a sun-scorched day. With quiet rebellion and poetic detours, visionary newcomer Murat Fıratoğlu delivers a striking debut attuned to the inner life of a worker on the brink.

items.title: Oray
items.short_synopsis: Oray, a young Muslim, pronounces the Islamic term for separation, ‘talaq’, during an argument with his wife. The imam informs him of the consequences: Oray must now part from Burcu for three months.
items.default_editorial: A quietly shattering debut, Oray chronicles a young man’s struggle to reconcile faith, love, and identity after a religious utterance irrevocably alters his life. With understated intensity, director Mehmet Akif Büyükatalay captures the emotional weight of belief and belonging in diaspora.

items.title: Passed by Censor
items.short_synopsis: As a prison letter examiner, Zakir’s job is to black out objectionable content from the inmates’ incoming and outgoing mail. In his free time, Zakir attends a writing course: his secret passion, and a means to socialise outside of work.
items.default_editorial: A gripping meditation on surveillance, Serhat Karaaslan’s debut feature deftly critiques authoritarian control through the eyes of a censor torn between duty and curiosity. As that fixation grows, boundaries blur, reflecting a society where personal lives are neither private nor safe from scrutiny.

items.title: Plastic Dream
items.short_synopsis: Belma’s self-confidence gets damaged when the doctor she went to for her skin rash problem tells her that she should get Botox. She becomes a woman who is uncomfortable with her skin and gets Botox but things do not go as she expected.
items.default_editorial: What defines our identity? Can it be easily replaced? In this tense tale of society’s obsession with youth, the cruelty of the plastic surgery industry reflects the traumatic wounds caused by distorted beauty standards. Nihal Yalçın gives a performance masterclass, even under the influence of Botox!

items.title: Ran
items.short_synopsis: After years of ruthless slaughter, warlord Hidetora Ichimonji divides his medieval kingdom among his three sons, seeking a peaceful retirement. However, his life descends into chaos as he is unable to escape the greed and corruption within his own family and the torment within his soul.
items.default_editorial: Is Kurosawa the greatest director ever? We’d be hard-pressed to argue. Some may prefer his earlier classics like Rashômon and Seven Samurai, but we adore this majestic epic, which re-purposes Shakespeare into an awesome feudal saga of tremendous spectacle, unforgettable in sight and sound.

items.title: Recce
items.short_synopsis: When a renowned film director clashes with the young son of a house she’s using as a filming location, a power struggle ensues, forcing the director to confront her own arrogance.
items.default_editorial: Set behind the scenes of a film shoot, Recce observes worlds brushing up against each other with quiet precision. Through subtle gestures and silences, it reveals an unspoken class divide between those making the film and those whose lives they seek to frame.

items.title: Rush
items.short_synopsis: A biography of Formula 1 champion driver Niki Lauda and the 1976 crash that almost claimed his life. Mere weeks after the accident, he got behind the wheel to challenge his rival, James Hunt.
items.default_editorial: Set to Hans Zimmer’s propulsive rock score, Ron Howard’s high-octane look at racing history eschews nostalgia for a frank, roaring portrait of two mavericks. Chris Hemsworth and Daniel Brühl command the screen as rivals who have opposite ideas of success, yet are united in death-defying grit.

items.title: Sacred Heart
items.short_synopsis: Irene, an unscrupulous business woman, is forced to re-evaluate her priorities after the suicide of her two best friends.
items.default_editorial: Through a serendipitous series of coincidences, this moving and unpredictable film charts a woman’s reawakening to everyday magic. With understated style, Ferzan Özpetek traces the limits of caring in an absorbing, audacious reflection on altruism and its thorny opposite in selfishness.

items.title: Saturn in Opposition
items.short_synopsis: This film focuses on contemporary 30- and 40-somethings trying to make sense of their lives in an age in which the old certainties have disappeared.
items.default_editorial: Elegant direction and refined performances mark this refreshing portrait of modern Italian society breaking away from rigid sexual mores and gender roles. A heartfelt ensemble drama, Saturn in Opposition explores the nuances of love and friendship with compassionate curiosity.

items.title: Sidewalk Sisters
items.short_synopsis: A story about Elif, who, at the age of 16, is forced to confront the harshest and most painful aspects of life. It follows her struggle to remain a good person despite facing tragic events that are too overwhelming for someone so young.
items.default_editorial: Fractured lives intersect against a background of unspoken histories in Yasemin Alkaya’s unflinching film. Capturing a resilience that endures despite societal neglect and generational trauma, Sidewalk Sisters shows how memory and reality can collide, exposing wounds only solidarity can heal.

items.title: Singing Women
items.short_synopsis: An island off the coast of Turkey is about to be evacuated due to a possible earthquake — but its inhabitants have been stricken with a mysterious illness, consigning them to an uncertain fate.
items.default_editorial: On an island haunted by silence, grief, and myth, Singing Women unfolds as a bewitchingly mournful chorus of strong female voices, reclaiming space for themselves. Auteur Reha Erdem blurs the line between the real and the ritual, crafting a hypnotic tale of rupture, resilience, and rebirth.

items.title: Sleep of the Crow
items.short_synopsis: Nasip, a sleepwalker haunted by the fear of harming his son İsmail, locks them in separate rooms every night. Tormented by guilt and contemplating suicide, he becomes determined to find a trustworthy family to care for his son.
items.default_editorial: A haunting exploration of alienation and inner turmoil, this award-winning psychological thriller plunges deep into the fractured psyche of its protagonist. Through shadowy, foreboding spaces and an immersive atmosphere, it crafts an unsettling portrait of a mind consumed by its own darkness.

items.title: Snow
items.short_synopsis: Müzeyyen is twenty and still in high school. Her mid-term report shows no sign of improvement. She has a group of friends—Bekir, Ebru, Hazerhan, Ferdane and Kadir—who mean everything to her. One day Ali, a half-brother she has known about but never met, arrives.
items.default_editorial: Emre Erdoğdu’s tumultuous debut Snow captures the fragility of lives suspended between rebellion and resignation. Every fleeting bond carries the weight of a generation’s quiet disillusionment, bruised dreams, and unspoken hopes in this raw, restless portrait of youth on the edge.

items.title: Soil
items.short_synopsis: This short film narrates the journey of a young man carrying a handful of soil into the grave of a deceased soldier who happens to be burying his own dead body.
items.default_editorial: Nine split screens, one haunting vision. In Alican Durbaş’s nocturnal parable, the weight of soil refuses to disperse, an elemental burden carried across screens, where each act of burial deepens into a meditation on mortality and the Sisyphean efforts we tirelessly endure.

items.title: Song of Sea
items.short_synopsis: Part of the ‘10 Poets 10 Directors’ project, Song of the Sea transforms a poem into moving image, offering a meditation on rhythm, language, and the invisible pulse connecting words and water.
items.default_editorial: With painterly restraint and poetic cadence, Erdem drifts between stanzas and tides, offering a study in elemental rhythm—where each frame breathes with the quiet force of verse made flesh.

items.title: Spotless
items.short_synopsis: In an Istanbul apartment, a man hides his job loss while his partner, once blocked, channels his silent turmoil into her writing. As he grows obsessed with a small blemish in their home, she engages with those outside their bubble.
items.default_editorial: Set within the quiet confines of a high-rise, Spotless sees a single stain threaten to consume an entire world. Dissecting class, gender, and identity with unnerving precision, Ali Ercivan’s debut short is a taut, psychological chamber piece where silence speaks louder than words.

items.title: Stiletto: A Pink Family Tragedy
items.short_synopsis: Hasan is a night-shift taxi driver in Istanbul. He sees a woman in stilettos passing by while he is on his way back home in the morning. In a world where the boundaries of being a man are already set, he does something that is to become a disaster even greater than global warming.
items.default_editorial: Overflowing with queer effervescence, Can Merdan Doğan’s boisterous short marshals a light-hearted, subversive take on traditional gender roles and the institution of marriage. A wild ride of comedy, music, and melodrama manifesting unconventional ways of keeping a family together.

items.title: Story of a Job Interview
items.short_synopsis: Erdem is a 35-year-old journalist. He has been unemployed for the last fifteen months and he’s about to become a father. He desperately needs a job. Being rejected once again in a job interview, he takes the news editor as a hostage.
items.default_editorial: A darkly comic descent into professional desperation, Story of a Job Interview lays bare the quiet violence of economic precarity. With razor-sharp precision, Alkım Özmen crafts a biting portrait of a man pushed to the edge, exposing the unseen toll of unemployment.

items.title: Suicide Room
items.short_synopsis: Dominik, a student at an elite private school, withdrawals from his classmates’ torments and humiliations drifts into an online chat world, where he meets a young girl in a “suicide room” who lures Dominik into a dangerous game.
items.default_editorial: In this his first film, talented Polish director Jan Komasa looks at how virtual reality allows a young teenager to flee the real world by immersing himself in an internet subculture. A bold, experimental debut that explores the problems of youth and our urgent need for escape.

items.title: Suna
items.short_synopsis: Suna, a woman in her fifties with no income, marries an elderly man for shelter. Although she cares for him, she is repulsed by their physical relationship. Overwhelmed by her situation, Suna falls into depression and begins secretly drinking to escape her despair.
items.default_editorial: Capturing the tension between longing for liberation and feeling the weight of life’s obligations, Suna is a haunting reflection on freedom and confinement. In a muted yet poignant narrative, Çiğdem Sezgin crafts a world where nonconformity feels both vital and perilous.

items.title: Tchaikovsky's Wife
items.short_synopsis: In 1872, Antonina, a devoted admirer of composer Tchaikovsky, pursues him obsessively and proposes marriage. Though he is largely absent, he remains a haunting presence in her life, fueling a one-sided love that spirals into isolation and emotional torment.
items.default_editorial: Chronicling the wretched union between a composer and his oblivious spouse, this captivating biographical drama couples devotion with feverish delusion. Infecting the pallor of his period piece with vulgar red and festering green, Kirill Serebrennikov makes emotional and societal ugliness visceral.

items.title: Tenement
items.short_synopsis: The Janitor, Serkan, who created the opportunity to experience different lives by sneaking into residents’ houses, finds diapositive photographs and audio recordings in the Yücel’s house, an old and lonely man.
items.default_editorial: Flung from prosaic routine and placid solitude by chance, the curious character in this short encounters other ways of living. Filming an apartment building with an affection for detail and design—from house plants to terrazzo tiles—director Can Baran basks in architectural and domestic delights.

items.title: The Adventures of Sukran the Lame
items.short_synopsis: A portrait of Şükran, whose life changed forever after a childhood accident at the age of ten. Longing for connection, she drifts through life, her every attempt to reach others met with quiet failure.
items.default_editorial: A darkly comic fable without a single line of dialogue, The Adventures of Şükran the Lame distills Onur Ünlü’s singular vision into a world ruled by paradox. Divine logic clashes with human folly, revealing a strange tenderness at the heart of our most unreasonable desires.

items.title: The Age of Shadows
items.short_synopsis: Set in the late 1920s, this film follows the cat-and-mouse game that unfolds between a group of resistance fighters led by Gong’s character, trying to bring in explosives from Shanghai to destroy key Japanese facilities in Seoul, and Japanese agents trying to stop them.
items.default_editorial: With South Korean cinema recently in the spotlight, we look back at this spy drama from director Kim Jee-woon (A Bittersweet Life). Inspired by real events, The Age of Shadows offers an unpredictable, thrilling cat-and-mouse game. Prepare yourself for a rather breathtaking train ride sequence!

items.title: The Antenna
items.short_synopsis: The inhabitants of an apartment building are caught in a living nightmare when a radical, new communications technology goes horribly awry.
items.default_editorial: A creeping sense of dread pulses through The Antenna, as director Orçun Behram channels dystopian horror into a potent allegory of state control. Blending political unease into body horror, this slow-burning nightmare roots itself in mood and metaphor with eerie precision.

items.title: The Awareness of Dreaming
items.short_synopsis: Veysel has never slept in his life. He sees this ability as a deficiency. Therefore, he hides this situation from everyone. He works at a luxury hotel to spend his free time at night. One night, one of the customers notices Veysel’s situation and a conversation begins between them.
items.default_editorial: Immersed in the hush of night, The Awareness of Dreaming drifts through the intimate spaces shared between strangers. In gently meandering dialogue and soft silences, it traces the threshold between wakefulness and dreaming, where fear, desire, and memory blur into something quietly transformative.

items.title: The Bear
items.short_synopsis: A bear cub is left alone, unable to feed or defend itself, when its mother is killed in a rockslide. Eventually, the cub attempts to bond with a male grizzly, which initially ignores it. When the grizzly is pursued by hunters, the cub comes to its aid and wins the grizzly’s affection.
items.default_editorial: Jean-Jacques Annaud brings to life the fate of the grizzly bear in this moving adaptation of James Oliver Curwood’s The Grizzly King. With almost no dialogue and an exquisitely minimal score, The Bear is an ursine classic that reveals the fragile bonds that exist between humans and animals.

items.title: The Cabinet of Dr. Caligari
items.short_synopsis: At a carnival, Francis and his friend Alan encounter the eccentric Dr. Caligari. He presents them the hypnotized Cesare, who can allegedly predict the future. Shockingly, he predicts Alan’s death, and by morning his prophecy has come true. Thus, Cesare and Dr. Caligari become the prime suspects.
items.default_editorial: Still strikingly modern after all these years, this early horror masterpiece may be the perfect gateway to silent film: a tight and sinister murder mystery, an eerie world of shadows gone mad, and all of it unforgettably capped with one of cinema’s first twist endings.

items.title: The Criminals
items.short_synopsis: In a small town in Anatolia, in the middle of the night, a young couple, Emre and Nazlı, are looking for a room to make love. They are rejected from the hotels because they do not have a marriage certificate. While they think they have found a trick, the situation quickly gets out of hand.
items.default_editorial: A Jury Prize-winner at Sundance, Serhat Karaaslan’s nocturnal tale of two young lovers shows that intimacy is not a private matter in a sex-obsessed society. In this engrossing short, Karaaslan’s signature tone is both sardonic and sincere, resulting in an acute portrait of conservative hypocrisy.

items.title: The Crowd
items.short_synopsis: Inspired by İlhan Mimaroğlu and Freddie Hubbard’s experimental track, The Crowd is a surreal animated game of associations, blending anti-war poetry, jazz, and musique concrète into a visual fantasia.
items.default_editorial: Having created illustrations for Lewis Carroll books, artist Pelin Kırca brings a spirit of surrealism and play to this animated short, which grooves to the rhythm of avant-garde jazz. From chirpy harlequins to giant eyeballs and regal ostriches, this fun house of fantastic creatures mesmerizes.

items.title: The Diary of an Exile
items.short_synopsis: The film unfolds around the memories and daily life of revolutionary musician Fuat Saka, who had to leave Türkiye just before the military coup d’etat in 1980 because of his political views and a fascist attack against him on the eve of 1979.
items.default_editorial: A quietly resonant study of a life shaped by rupture, this contemplative documentary drifts through memory and music to follow the stubborn pulse of a man unwilling to abandon his artistic compass. As Turkey’s political undercurrents surface, exile becomes the terrain where sound gathers resolve.

items.title: The Doll
items.short_synopsis: When Fatma Teyze moves into the rundown mansion after her house is demolished due to urban renewal, she meets Dunya, an Afghan refugee who has just given birth. The two realize that there are beings other than themselves in the house.
items.default_editorial: A spectral meditation on displacement and belonging, The Doll conjures a ghostly portrait of İzmir, a port city marked by exile and migration. In its crumbling walls, past and present cohabit uneasily as the living seek shelter and the dead return in search of what was lost.

items.title: The Funeral
items.short_synopsis: Cemal drives a hearse for a living. He’s entrusted with secretly carrying the body of a young girl at the request of her family. One night, he hears strange groans from the back of the truck, even though she the girl hasn’t got a pulse.
items.default_editorial: Delivering an atmospheric twist on the zombie film, director Orçun Behram uses and breaks its conventions for a stark exploration of systematic decay and silent submission. Anchored by Ahmet Rıfat Şungar’s gripping performance, it’s a haunting parable of the living and the dead.

items.title: The Golden Glove
items.short_synopsis: Notorious German serial killer Fritz Honka haunted Hamburg’s red light district in the 1970s, frequenting his favorite bar, the “Golden Glove,” where drinking is a reflex against pain and longing. There, Honka, a pitiful loser chasing after lonely women, keeps more than just secrets in the attic.
items.default_editorial: Drawn from the real-life story of a serial killer who terrorised Hamburg’s red-light district, this pungent character study from Fatih Akin is not for the faint of heart. With a vividly inhabited performance from Jonas Dassler, The Golden Glove is unflinching in its fetid portrayal of national rot.

items.title: The Grand Siege
items.short_synopsis: Berna Tuna, a renowned academic has just died. Her husband Macit will take this opportunity to face past wrongdoings and reconnect with his long-neglected daughter İpek.
items.default_editorial: A darkly humorous elegy for a fading republic, Sinan Kesova’s striking feature debut undermines illusions of legacy, progress, and paternal authority. With biting precision and tragic irony, The Grand Siege excavates the ruins of a nation and observes a man clinging to a past that no longer holds.

items.title: The Holdovers
items.short_synopsis: A grumpy prep school instructor must stay on campus over Christmas break to supervise a few stranded students. Over time, he bonds with a rebellious, intelligent teen and the school’s grieving head cook, who recently lost her son in Vietnam.
items.default_editorial: With Oscar®-winning support from Da’Vine Joy Randolph, an ornery Paul Giamatti leads a stellar ensemble cast through Alexander Payne’s riotous tale of found family. Sweetening the melancholy of its wintry New England setting with warmth and friendship, The Holdovers is an instant holiday classic.

items.title: The Idol
items.short_synopsis: A film about the popular Palestinian singer Mohammad Assaf, from childhood to adulthood, and his life in Gaza until he won the Arab idol.
items.default_editorial: Award-winning director Hany Abu-Assad’s leap to Hollywood with The Mountain Between Us was forecast by the enormous success of The Idol, a charming and thoroughly engrossing biopic of the Palestinian singer who won “Arab Idol.” We hope more diverse voices can be given new opportunities.

items.title: The Ignorant Fairies
items.short_synopsis: AIDS doctor Antonia’s husband is killed by a car. She gets depressed until she learns he had been cheating on her with a man.
items.default_editorial: One of few Italian films of the time to depict gay characters, The Ignorant Fairies sees a heteronormative world collide with a queer underground to surprising effect. Warm and inquisitive, this mature film about grief, secrets, and lies bravely undermines expectations around love and family.

items.title: The Last Laugh
items.short_synopsis: An elderly but proud doorman of a posh Berlin hotel, long considered expendable, is reassigned to polishing tiles and tending to guests in the men’s lavatory. As he navigates his new duties, a sudden event upends his routine and the position he has held for decades.
items.default_editorial: A dazzling and groundbreaking drama of modern city life from the German master of silent cinema, F.W. Murnau (Faust). Emil Jannings delivers one of Weimar German cinema’s most indelible (and melancholic!) performances in a story that spans the full range of epic tragedy and breathtaking beauty.

items.title: The Legend Of Yasar Kemal
items.short_synopsis: The life of legendary writer Yaşar Kemal is depicted through his words and those of close friends. Using unpublished footage, audio, and documents, the film portrays his epic journey, literature, and worldview.
items.default_editorial: A defiant portrait of artistic courage and political conviction, Aydın Orak’s intimate documentary captures the indomitable spirit of a literary icon. Resonating with countless histories of oppression, this thoughtful film becomes a testament to the enduring power of words to challenge and inspire.

items.title: The List of Those Who Love Me
items.short_synopsis: Yılmaz is a dealer and close friends with famous filmmakers and actors. With drug operations on the rise in Istanbul, Yılmaz is getting paranoid about not being loved by them anymore. This paranoia makes him take bigger risks day by day and he will be destroyed by the desire for being loved.
items.default_editorial: In a world where connection is a currency, Emre Erdoğdu’s quietly melancholic portrait of Istanbul’s creative class traces the erosion of self amid false intimacies and blurred loyalties. In glittering, but brittle surfaces of belonging, lonely fractures and hidden yearnings emerge.

items.title: The Longest Night
items.short_synopsis: Hüseyin, a family man, is forced to share a bed with his brother-in-law Firat, who happens to be staying overnight in their apartment. The weather is unbearably hot and Hüseyin’s “longest night” begins.
items.default_editorial: In his latest work, Can Merdan Doğan confronts the suffocating boundaries of masculinity, unraveling layers of repressed desire that can simmer beneath the surface in macho environments. His delicate exploration of unspoken tension reveals the fragile, human impulses that resist cultural conformity.

items.title: The Maze
items.short_synopsis: While searching for an exit in the corridors of the labyrinth, a middle-aged man faces his past and through the cracks on the wall confronts his hidden conscience.
items.default_editorial: A wordless protagonist and surreal visuals create an absorbing atmosphere of disquiet in this metaphorical short, which finds an imaginative and visceral way into a sensitive topic. Smooth 3D animation clashes with brutal truths, as abstract fears are revealed to conceal an all-too-real trauma.

items.title: The Tamed
items.short_synopsis: Firaz, a young girl seeking a way out from her village, is waiting for a relative at her father’s funeral ceremony. While taking care of her grandfather becomes a burden, the funeral meal ordered the night before is missing a couple of plates.
items.default_editorial: Deniz Uymaz weaves a deeply personal memory into a poignant reflection on grief, resilience, and longing in this touching short. Through a documentary-style lens, the newcomer director captures the quiet defiance of a young girl, and the intricate family ties that endure amid the rituals of loss.

items.title: The Teacup
items.short_synopsis: A man is afraid to go outside. When he was a child his beloved grandmother had told him “Go outside and burst into flames you shall!” A grown man now, he is content and happy living in his little house. One day there is a knock on his door and everything changes…
items.default_editorial: Small bursts of color in a world of gray are enticing temptations for the isolated protagonist of this animated fable. Endearing hand-drawn designs evoke the comfort of the familiar, but also the thrill of the unknown, while soothing voiceover narration gently guides us to an unexpected conclusion.

items.title: The Truth
items.short_synopsis: Cinema legend Fabienne is about to publish her memoirs. The version of her life in the book, however, is critiqued by her daughter Lumir, who visits Fabienne with her American husband and their daughter. Resentments eventually explode as Fabienne and Lumir confront the reality of their dynamic.
items.default_editorial: Japanese master Hirokazu Koreeda’s venture into the land of the French is a pitch-perfect, humorous delicacy with Catherine Deneuve, Juliette Binoche & Ethan Hawke! This irresistible take on the diva actress—pointing at Deneuve’s legendary status—reveals the tender yet maddening nature of family.

items.title: The Whale
items.short_synopsis: Charlie is an English teacher living with severe obesity. As he feels his time is running out, he makes a last bold attempt to reconcile with his broken family. Soon, Charlie must confront, with his full heart and fierce wit, long-buried traumas and unspoken love that have haunted him for decades.
items.default_editorial: A resurgent Brendan Fraser gives an astonishing, Oscar®-winning performance in this heart-wrenching tale of grace and redemption from director Darren Aronofsky. With remarkable support from Hong Chau (also Oscar®-nominated), The Whale is a profoundly empathetic parable of regret and empowerment.

items.title: There Is Nothing Called Home
items.short_synopsis: The story of a person who is stuck with the concept of home and attaches a lot of meaning to small things, choosing herself as a weapon at a Russian roulette table and the battle of her inner roulette.
items.default_editorial: A hypnotic descent into the fractured rhythms of thought, this experimental short animation unravels the illusion of safety we attach to belonging. Here, home is not a refuge, but a loaded metaphor for self-confrontation, which unfolds in an unsettling impression of looping psychological space.

items.title: Thou Gild'st the Even
items.short_synopsis: In a small Anatolian town with two suns and three moons, ordinary people bear extraordinary powers: Cemal sees through walls, Yasemin moves objects, and Defne freezes time. Around them unfold the quiet sorrows and uncanny rhythms of everyday life.
items.default_editorial: A playful fusion of Shakepearean verse and superhero lore, Onur Ünlü’s beautifully shot black-and-white fable transforms small-town melancholy into absurd, surreal poetry. The divine and the banal intertwine in a luminous meditation on solitude, ennui, and love.

items.title: Three Kilometres to the End of the World
items.original_title: Trei kilometri până la capătul lumii
items.short_synopsis: Adi is spending the summer in his home village in the Danube Delta. One night he is brutally attacked on the street, the next day his world is turned upside-down. His parents no longer look at him as they did, and the seeming tranquility of the village starts to crack.
items.default_editorial: Investigating the bruising aftermath of a homophobic hate crime, Emanuel Parvu’s arresting drama magnifies the conflicting agendas of church, police, and state. Shot in widescreen, this unfaltering film never loses sight of its rural setting, where old orthodoxies stagnate among the river reeds.

items.title: Time of Impatience
items.short_synopsis: Unruly brothers from a poor neighbourhood will do anything to plunge into a swimming pool on a luxury property.
items.default_editorial: An exploration of youthful longing and systemic inequality, Aydın Orak’s searing social-realist vision captures the quiet resilience of those on the margins. Echoing larger struggles, small acts of defiance are magnified by an intimate lens, which balances hope and despair with poignant clarity.

items.title: Times and Winds
items.short_synopsis: The pain of growing up, as seen by three Turkish youths: Ömer, the son of the local imam, who wishes the death of his father; his best friend, Yakup, who’s enamored with the village schoolteacher; and Yildiz, who is forced to balance her studies with the needs of her demanding mother.
items.default_editorial: Winner of Best Picture and the Critics Prize at the Istanbul Film Festival, Reha Erdem’s intimate, poetic drama both explores the issue of its homeland and transcends national barriers, earning the film comparisons to the work of Satyajit Ray and Abbas Kiarostami. A vision of sheer beauty.

items.title: To a Land Unknown
items.short_synopsis: After fleeing a camp in Lebanon, two Palestinian cousins are stranded in Athens, living in an underground limbo. Desperately seeking a way to reach Germany, they find themselves caught in an uncontrollable spiral.
items.default_editorial: Where broadcasters scaremonger about refugees, Palestinian-Danish filmmaker Mahdi Fleifel finds the humanity behind reactionary headlines. Empathetic but not sentimental, thrilling but never unnecessarily gritty or tawdry, this spin on the difficult dream of migration is gripping and real.

items.title: Together, Alone
items.short_synopsis: In their late twenties, Sevgi and Doğan survive by stealing old cars in the outskirts of Istanbul. During their routine of theft, their latest attempt leads to an unexpected situation that brings underlying tensions in their relationship to the surface.
items.default_editorial: In the dim glow of Istanbul’s outskirts, two lives intertwine in a fragile dance of trust and despair. The characters’ journey, raw and jagged, reflects the brutal poetry of survival—where love splinters, truth cuts deep, and redemption flickers in the shadows of shattered steel and broken hearts.

items.title: Tomato, Pepper, Depression
items.short_synopsis: Tomatoes, peppers and all other plants in Adana’s Çetirevli village survive with pesticides. Just like diagnosed depression patients who make up half of the village.
items.default_editorial: A wry portrait of seasonal rhythms, resilience, and routine, Aybüke Avcı’s playfully observant debut documentary squeezes laughter from lethargy. From the grinding of peppers to the grinding of days, Tomato, Pepper, Depression turns family fatigue into a quietly absurd hymn to endurance.

items.title: Transylvania
items.short_synopsis: Zingarina arrives in Transylvania, in the heart of Romania, searching for the man she loves. Accompanied by her friend Marie, who watches over her jealously, Zingarina throws herself headlong into her quest for love and lets herself be carried away by this country that fascinates her so.
items.default_editorial: Tony Gatlif has become renowned for bringing gypsy culture to cinema, and delivers with Transylvania another drama filled with joyful scenes of Romany celebrations, as well as moments of heartfelt drama. A dizzying road movie, it stars Asia Argento and Amira Casar as travelling buddies.

items.title: Tulliana
items.short_synopsis: Two zoologists are on a journey in Anatolia, researching the extinct Anatolian panther. Their quest for the panther make them question themselves and what they know. They will find much more than the panther they were seeking.
items.default_editorial: Orçun Köksal’s Tulliana drifts through forests and ruins, tracing the vanishing outlines of a land and a leopard that may never return. Between myth and memory, it emerges as both an elegy for Anatolia’s lost identity and a road film of restless pursuit, where two men forge a fragile bond.

items.title: Universal Language
items.short_synopsis: In Winnipeg, Nazgol and Negin try to help a classmate recover an Iranian banknote. At the same time, a character named Matthew Rankin quits his job in Montreal to be closer to his family in Winnipeg, where he meets Massoud, a tour guide who also takes care of Rankin’s mother.
items.default_editorial: The feathery melodies of the santoor and a snow shoveler’s cries fill the chill air in this sportively cinephilic film that winks at the cinema of Abbas Kiarostami. In a portmanteau Manitoba, tea served the Persian way and a florist’s trough of crocuses warm a brutalist Winnipeg ramparted with snow.

items.title: Varda by Agnès
items.short_synopsis: After over half a century of making films, Agnès Varda offers a personal insight into her oeuvre and experiences as a director. As she travels from Paris to Los Angeles and Beijing, Varda explains her “cine-writing” practice, using excerpts from her work to illustrate her unique approach to cinema.
items.default_editorial: The ever-inspiring Agnès Varda left with this final act of generosity. Her luminous last film offers a playful personal tour through her prolific career and the beautiful memories of a life lived fully: juxtaposing conversations with collaborators alongside dramatic, beach-set tableaux. Merci Agnès.

items.title: Vision
items.short_synopsis: Eyes are magical spheres that make up dreams and retain memories. In our eyes, the visions of the within and of the beyond overlap. New worlds come to be when our gazes meet.
items.default_editorial: Black lines against a white background are all this dazzling short needs to explore the miracle of sight. In one pleasingly smooth movement, drawings of eyes and flora explode into ever-shifting shapes, bringing to revelatory light the close relation between perception and existence itself.

items.title: Wajib
items.short_synopsis: Abu Shadi is a divorced father and teacher in Nazareth. Shadi, his son, arrives from Rome after years abroad to help his father with his sister’s wedding, hand delivering the invitations to each guest per local custom. As the pair spend the day together, the tense relationship comes to a head.
items.default_editorial: Palestinian filmmaker Annemarie Jacir directs this lively, deceptively low-key road movie, which drives up alongside its conflicted leads, deftly performed by a real-life father and son. Exploring the clash between tradition and modernity, Wajib shows how humor can be a powerful tool of resistance.

items.title: We Hit the Road
items.short_synopsis: Laborers of the film industry decide to march against the new censorship act in 1977, interrupting 60 years of silence in cinema for good. From actors and actresses to set workers, 400 women and men start a five-day-long walk to Ankara.
items.default_editorial: A landmark work of cinematic remembrance, Deniz Yeşil’s trenchant political documentary rekindles the spirit of collective resistance from a march against censorship. Testifying vividly to solidarity and the radical power of film, We Hit the Road pulses with the urgency of unfinished struggle.

items.title: We Need to Talk About Dilan
items.short_synopsis: Dilan works in her uncle’s real estate office and lives with her mother. She will turn thirty soon, and feels she is not living up to her potential. A documentary crew follows her while they try to figure out the problem.
items.default_editorial: A tenderly comic inquiry into creative paralysis, generational pressure, and the performance of selfhood, staged with sharp self-awareness and the quiet absurdity of the everyday. Social media personality Sude Belkıs brings disarming authenticity to this portrait of thirtysomething angst.

items.title: Wedding Dance
items.short_synopsis: Taxi driver Ahmet, who is about to get engaged to the young girl his mother pushes for, starts a passionate affair with the tailor Leyla, who is his elder. Semih’s return will be a great danger to Ahmet and Leyla’s relationship. From now on, nothing will remain the same.
items.default_editorial: Exploring the emotional turbulence of a woman resisting societal rules, Çiğdem Sezgin’s gripping film reveals the raw, unsettling moments that come from defiance. A collision between passion and tradition, Wedding Dance sees love, guilt, and duty spiral into a perfect storm of conflicting desire.

items.title: What's a Human Anyway
items.short_synopsis: After being knocked unconscious in an accident and losing his memory, Ali is like a newborn baby, exploring his new world and putting the pieces of his identity back together. Focusing on a group of families and close friends, the story is set in a nostalgic version of the “Istanbul neighborhood”.
items.default_editorial: Reha Erdem’s Mommy, I’m Scared is a dark comedy unafraid to challenge social constructs, particularly patriarchal ones. Erdem ties together the threads of interconnected and intertwining narratives between friends, family members and neighbors in Istanbul to reflect on the nature of being human.

items.title: Wherever the Path Takes Us
items.short_synopsis: Havva moves to Madrid with her boyfriend but soon feels adrift, challenged by language barriers and a growing sense of isolation. She searches for connection, finding brief solace in moments shaped by shared emotion.
items.default_editorial: In her debut short, Elif Büşra Keleş captures the subtle pressures of displacement through a confined 4:3 frame, following an actor negotiating shifting fears. In its final widening moment, the film finds fragile hope, as music and love give shape to a new place of belonging.

items.title: Wine Dark Sea
items.short_synopsis: This documentary explores a region Homer famously called the “Wine Dark Sea”, where temperatures are rising 20% faster than the global average. As daily life, the environment, and the economy face mounting challenges, initiatives in renewable energy and adaptation are reshaping the area.
items.default_editorial: A requiem for a sea in flux, Wine Dark Sea gazes into the vanishing horizon of the Mediterranean, where climate change threatens a way of life. Nefin Dinç crafts an urgent reflection on the weight of collective action, asking not what has been lost, but whether a new future can still be written.

items.title: Ziazan
items.short_synopsis: Four-year-old Armenian girl Ziazan one day decides to go on an adventure. She will sneak in from Armenia to Turkey inside her uncle’s luggage. Will she be able to go over the closed borders between two countries and realize her adventure?
items.default_editorial: A border-crossing fable told through the wide eyes of a child, Ziazan disarms with its innocence while quietly indicting the bureaucratic absurdities that divide lives. Best known as an actor, Derya Durmaz here steps behind the camera to craft a bittersweet miniature of quiet defiance and longing.

items.title: Zugzwang
items.short_synopsis: Selim and Muazzez are a happily married couple. One fateful day, Muazzez makes a blunder that hurts Selim, leading to an abrupt breakup. During their months-long period of ambiguous separation, Selim discovers his kidneys have failed.
items.default_editorial: Love is a chess match in Muhammed Günaydın’s searing short, a game where pride and vulnerability collide. Through its devastating meditation on interdependence, Zugzwang reveals the fragile balance between ego and devotion with razor-sharp focus, in a breathtaking tale of marital resilience.

items.title: Beautiful Darling: The Life and Times of Candy Darling
items.original_title: Beautiful Darling: The Life and Times of Candy Darling
items.short_synopsis: Recapturing the excitement of a long lost New York City, Beautiful Darling tells the story of transgender pioneer Candy Darling, a star in the constellation that was Andy Warhol’s Factory.
items.default_editorial: In this comprehensive film honoring actor and luminary trans icon Candy Darling, director James Rasin gives precedence to compelling interviews with an expansive number of Darling’s contemporaries and greatest admirers. To top it off, the film is lovingly narrated by Chloë Sevigny and Patton Oswalt.

items.title: Betty Blue
items.short_synopsis: When the easygoing novelist Zorg meets the tempestuous and impulsive Betty in a sunbaked French beach town, it’s the beginning of a whirlwind passionate love affair. But as the increasingly erratic Betty’s grip on reality begins to falter, Zorg finds himself willing to do things he never expected.
items.default_editorial: Jean-Jacques Beineix’s Oscar®-nominated, erotic masterpiece erupted on the scene with such a slick new style that a whole movement was named around it (alongside the work of Luc Besson and Leos Carax): Cinéma du look. Featuring a scintillating and unforgettably fierce debut by Béatrice Dalle.

items.title: Charlie's Country
items.short_synopsis: Charlie lives in a remote Aboriginal community in northern Australia, where government intervention has left many of the residents feeling powerless. When his gun and hand-crafted spear are confiscated, leaving him nothing to hunt with, Charlie heads into the bush to live the old way.
items.default_editorial: Rolf de Heer has had an eclectic, unsung career as a director of sharp thrillers and small character pieces alike. A terrific example of the latter is this portrait of an Australian Aboriginal—played by the great David Gulpilil—and his resistance to the unjust laws beset upon him and his community.

items.title: Coldwater
items.short_synopsis: A teenage boy is sent to a juvenile reform facility in the wilderness. As we learn about the tragic events that sent him there, his struggle becomes one for survival with the inmates, the counselors, and with the retired war colonel in charge.
items.default_editorial: Shattering all expectations of the American indie coming-of-age genre, Coldwater tackles the challenging subjects of toxic masculinity and adolescence, whilst doubling as a thriller to offer a complex and incisive critique of the juvenile detention (and by extension, the prison and military) system.

items.title: Downriver
items.short_synopsis: James has served time for drowning a little boy when he was a child, although the body was never found. A visit from his victim’s mother upon parole sends him on a quest to find the truth. With little time and danger at every turn, James risks his freedom and his life to uncover a trail of sins.
items.default_editorial: In this dark thriller, an unsolved murder haunts a community and exiles the young suspect from his adulthood. The search for the truth behind traumatic events guide the film’s carefully plotted mystery, which moves in hypnotic rhythms with a rich cast of characters and an enveloping sense of place.

items.title: London River
items.short_synopsis: After travelling to London to check on their missing children in the wake of the 2005 terror attack on the city, two strangers come to discover their respective children had been living together at the time of the attacks.
items.default_editorial: Between the hit wartime epics Days of Glory (about North Africans fighting for France during WW2) and Outside the Law (Algerians fighting for independence), Rachid Bouchareb made this intimate drama about the 2005 London terror attacks, which won the Silver Bear in competition at the Berlinale.

items.title: Out in the Dark
items.short_synopsis: Two young men—a Palestinian grad student and an Israeli lawyer—meet and fall in love amidst personal and political intrigue in this striking debut feature.
items.default_editorial: This feature debut vividly uses the anxiety, precariousness and paranoia of Israeli-Palestinian relations to infuse the clandestine atmosphere of a love story where cross-cultural, cross-political conflict is only part of its couple’s troubles. A director to watch!

items.title: She's Lost Control
items.short_synopsis: Fiercely independent, Ronah works as a sexual surrogate in New York City, teaching her clients the very thing they fear most—to be intimate. Her life unravels when she starts working with a volatile new client, blurring the thin line between professional and personal intimacy in the modern world.
items.default_editorial: A terse drama which defiantly rejects the modern conventions besetting American indie films, Anja Marquardt’s debut is a movie of great psychological complexity. A rare look into the world of sexual surrogacy, guided by enveloping cinematography carefully attuned to its characters’ many gestures.

items.title: Sweaty Betty
items.short_synopsis: In a row house near Washington D.C., two stories of big dreams take place. Floyd and his family have raised a 1000 lbs. pig, determined to turn her into the Redskins’ mascot. A few blocks away, Rico and Scooby, two teenage single fathers and best friends, are scheming up a way to sell their new dog.
items.default_editorial: Quietly praised in its all-too-brief festival run, this exceptional documentary moves with the loose feel of a home movie, yet proves to be rigorously composed in its careful articulation of community and friendship. Like the best of recent independent cinema, it’s raw, alive and completely sincere.

items.title: The Little Deputy
items.short_synopsis: Trevor tries to have his photo taken with his father.
items.default_editorial: From faux-archival VHS home videos to reenactments of the Wild West, Trevor Anderson’s droll short reimagines a seminal childhood trip to the mall as a time-jumping portal through different decades. The idiosyncratic visual collage playfully mirrors the jubilant multitudes of gender expression.

items.title: The Most Important Thing in Life Is Not Being Dead
items.original_title: Lo más importante de la vida es no haber muerto
items.short_synopsis: An esteemed piano tuner and repairer, Jacobo leads an apparently happy life with his wife, Helena. His serene existence is thrown into a state of confusion when insomnia creeps in, and pianos that previously repaired miraculously overnight remain unfixed.
items.default_editorial: Paranoia and comedy can be so deliciously close together. Just witness this festival treat from Spain—the promising debut of a fresh filmmaking collective—which turns an insomniac’s hallucinations into a game that ties reality into a knot and stretches the cord tight. Visually rich magic realism.

items.title: Weirdos
items.short_synopsis: Nova Scotia. 1976. The weekend of the American Bicentennial. 15-year-old Kit is running away from home, hitchhiking with his girlfriend Alice to move in with his estranged mother (Molly Parker) and, hopefully, to find himself.
items.default_editorial: Bruce McDonald’s tender and bittersweet teen drama is the perfect summer film: A road trip of self-discovery that travels across a beautiful Nova Scotia, all set to fabulous 70s tunes. A gentle gem featuring a star-making performance by Julia Sarah Stone.

items.title: Xingu
items.short_synopsis: Xingu is about the real-life Villas-Boas brothers who worked for over 25 years to create a homeland for the indigenous peoples of the Amazon.
items.default_editorial: In this portrait of a near 30-year expedition to establish a reservation for the Amazon’s Kaiabi Indians, Brazilian director Cao Hamburger works in broad strokes on a vast canvas to craft a film of epic scope, potent simplicity, and of great historical and political relevance. An underrated gem.
